title: Plastics Industry Is Said to Welcome Decontrol of Prices
description: Major chemical companies and an industry association representing plastics manufacturers welcomed yesterday the action by the Cost of Living Council to decontrol most prices of raw materials used heavily by the plastics, rubber and fiber industries.

title: G.E. Plans Silicon Turbine Blade
description: The General Electric Company announced yesterday that it had made a breakthrough in the use of ceramics in turbine blades.

title: Philadelphia: What Being Brotherly Means
description: PHILADELPHIA  When President Martin Meyerson asked me last spring to serve a twoyear term as the University of Pennsylvania's ombudsman, I quickly accepted. The opportunity was an unusual one for a professor of administrative law.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (Reuters)Factory orders The United States fell $2.78billion, or 3.5 per cent, in December largely due to a sharp decline in orders for automobiles, the Commerce Department reported today. New orders in December totaled a seasonally adjusted $76.66billion, compared with a downward revised $79.44billion November.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
WESTERN ELECTRIC SEEKS CABLE ORDERS
description: For the first time, the Western Electric Company is seeking longterm contracts for furnishing some of its need for exchange cable. The giant supply arm of the Bell System said yesterday it would be able to avoid building a plant of, its own If enough interest was shown by outside cable makers.

title: MARKET IS MIXED IN SLOW TRADING
description: Investors showed little enthusiasm yesterday for President Nixon's televised State of the Union address on Wednesday evening, and the market ended mixed in slow trading.

title: Stage: Laing's Knots
description: There is something the matter with me because do not feel there is something the matter with me! That is perhaps the key to a brief but fascinating entertainment being presented in repertory by the Actors Company from Britain at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. It is called Knots, lasts about an hour and has been devised by the company and staged by one of the actors, Edward Petherbridge.

title: Guerrillas in Ulster Kill 2 and Wound 2 In Sectarian Attack
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 31 (UPI)  Two masked men held up a group of construction workers playing cards in a shack during their lunch, hour today, told Protestants to kneel and then opened fire with a machine gun on the men still standing, killing two and wounding at least three others, police officials said.

title: Truckers' Protest Cuts Flow of Food and Steel
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 31Prote.sting truck drivers began today to reduce the flow of raw materials and foodstuffs in many parts, of the country, prompting scattered closings of plants and warnings of shortages of fuel and food.

title: The State of the Union
description: President Nixon's State of the Union Address was unique combination of legislative review and personal comeback appeal, The two sections of the speech were interdependent. The President's survey of his past and present legislative recommendations was intended convey the image of an active, busy, working Chief Executive and thereby lay the basis for Mr. Nixon's emotional concluding appeal for an end to public preoccupation with the Watergate scandals.

title: London: The Dark, From the Top of the Stairs
description: LONDONI think I had my first glimpse of how life and hard times in London must seem to outsiders when I got a letter from the States just before Christmas. It began delicately, I hate to think of you suffering, and went on, Is there anything, but anything, that I can send you?

title: Two World Marks Set In Games
description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Friday, Feb. 1Australia's Steve Holland set a world swimming record of 8 minutes 15.88 seconds for the 800 meters early today on his way to winning the gold medal in the 1,500meter freestyle in the Commonwealth Games.

title: Nastase Wins in Richmond
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 31 (AP)  Ilie Nastase of Rumania and Tom Gorman of Seattle advanced to the quarterfinals of a $50,000 World Championship Tennis tournament today.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Jan. 31Rutgers has six consecutive basketball victories and Tom Young, the coach, has the answer to the success that reads 12 triumphs in 16 games.

title: Cause of Death Disputed at L.I. Trial
description: MINEOLA, LI., Jan. 31A noted pathologist who said he had performed more than 30,000 autopsies in 47 years as a physician, testified today that the death of Eugene Bauer was due to cancer and a pulmonary embolism, and was not caused by an injection of potassium chloride, as charged by the state.

title: Oil Shale Corp. Reports On Recoverable Holdings
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31 (AP)  The Oil Shale Corporation said today that at least 1.6 bilIlion barrels of oil were recoverable through existing technology from its oil shale holdings in the United States.

title: Beame Offers 1.7Billion Capital Budget
description: Mayor Beame, a onetime accountant whose governmental career has concentrated on finance, proposed his first municipal budget yesterday, deliberately using it to point up his new image at City Hall.

title: LONDON METAL MARKET
description: (in pounds starling per metric ton)

title: Dauplaise Zeroes In on Twin Goals
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 31 Back in competition after a fiveday suspension, Norman Dauplaise has been demonstrating that his absence has not caused him to lose hissharpness. Commenting on his career, at Roosevelt Raceway today, Dauplaise said he was confident he would have a good year and was hopeful of attaining two ambitions as harness racing driver.

title: Greek Junta Dismisses Foremost Archeologist
description: ATHENS, Jan. 31Prof. Spyridon Marinatos, the leading Greek archeologist, was dismissed today from the post of Inspector General or Ancient and Historical Monuments, a job he had held since the 1967 military coup.

title: Saigon Troops Reported on the Spratly Islands
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Feb. 1Military sources said yesterday that about 120 South Vietnamese soldiers had landed on a barren, uninhabited island group in the South China Sea, apparently in an effort to head off its occupation by Chinese forces.

title: Carol Dribinsky Wed to Surgeon
description: Miss Carol Dribinsky, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Dribinsky of the Bronx, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Steven Steiner, son of Mr. and Mrs.

title: European Industry Is Calling in Efficiency Experts To Help Curtail the Spiraling Costs of Production
description: PARIS, Jan. 31European industry, facing its leanest period since World War II, is taking a hard look at costs as it adjusts to a slowdown in consumer demand, ever higher rates of inflation, the quadrupling of energy prices in the last three months and a stiffening of union demands. It is calling in efficiency experts.

title: RABBI JACOB LEIBOWITZ
description: Rabbi Jacob Leibowitz, who had been associated with the East Flatbush Jewish Community Center for 38 years, died at his home yesterday. His age was 73, and he lived at 386 East 46th Street in Brooklyn.

title: Miners in Britain Voting; Strike Approval Expected
description: LONDON, Jan. 31  Britain's 260,000 miners began voting today on a strike that could bring industry to a halt and lead to unemployment for millions.

title: ALGERIA ASKING U.N. TO MEET ON ENERGY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 31Algeria called today for General Assembly meeting to discuss raw materials and economic development, a session that would open the way for a fullscale debate on the energy crisis by th e135 United Nations members.

title: Red Smith
description: At this moment on farms and in renal houses, cities and suburbs, baseball players are trying to decide whether to sign the contract that has been lying in a dresser drawer for six weeks, or make one more appeal to the boss by mail or telephone, or take the case to impartial arbitration. This is the first time in all history that the third course has been open, and the time of decision is now. The period for submitting a salary dispute to arbitration starts today and ends a week from next Monday. Starting that day, Feb. 11, arguments will be heard through Feb. 22. Nobody knows how much time an individual hearing will consume, because none has ever been held, but the people involved are guessing that half a day should suffice. Fourteen arbitrators are standing by, each prepared to serve for three days. That means 42 mandays are available, theoretically enough time to handle 84 cases.

description: It is not easy for enthusiasts to adopt the complex form of the Precision System used by some of the Italian stars in winning the last two world team titles. title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
INDEXES OF AMEX AND COUNTER DIP
description: The market indexes used by the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market fell yesterday but advances outnumbered declines on both markets.

title: Screen: Monroe Myths
description: How long can you dwell with selfparody? That special gift swims close to humiliation, and it's now more conspicuous than ever in the work of Marilyn Monroe. The hyperhappy smiles, the arched eyebrows, the body that she seemed unable to control, the playschool voice all seemed to radiate increasing mockery as the years went by. Yet she didn't appear to be making fun of the audience, or of any target outside herself. Of course various directors channeled her tendency to caricature herself. But it's nowhere more apparent than when she sang Happy Birthday to John F. Kennedy in Madison Square Garden, where she spoofed her own style to a degree that was almost grotesque. There's also a bleak historical moment when Peter Lawfordgagging it up about her tardiness  introduces her as the late Marilyn Monroe. This footage is part of Homage to Marilyn Monroe, which is appearing at the Film Forum, 256 West 88th Street, through Sunday and from Feb. 7 through Feb.10.

title: Opera: I Vespri Siciliani at the Met
Airline's Net Soars
description: UAL, Inc., which owns United Air Lines, the world's largest air carrier, as well as Western International Hotels, yesterday restored its stock to a dividendpaying basis, after reporting that 1973 profits were the best in three years.

title: Courageous Courreges: He Refuses to Flee to the 30's
description: PARIS, Jan. 31We're up to the nineteensixties, you'll he happy to know. It's the work of Andr. Courrges, and who could be more entitled?

title: CandidFilm Viewof Yugoslavia
description: "Man Is Not a Bird," Dusan Makavejev's first film, was shown at the First Avenue Screening Room Sunday and will be repeated there tomorrow and Sunday with showings at noon and midnight. It was made in 1966, and it is by far the most original, intelligent, witty and important film I've seen so far this year, which is meant as high praise even admitting that January's movies hit something of a new low.Mr. Makavejev is the brilliant, idiosyncratic Yugoslav filmmaker who was most recently represented here in 1971 by his anti-Stalinist "WRMysteries of the Organism," a collage of political and sexual satire, fantasy, porno film, musings on the life and teachings of Wilhelm Reich, interviews with Candy Darling (and others). It was a movie that I could either take or leave. The freedom of its form seemed dictated less by the artist's wide-roving imagination than by the footage he had on hand to edit into some kind of feature film.Mr. Makavejev is a bristly sort of director. "Mysteries of the Organism" was never given full release in Yugoslavia, and a year ago he was drummed out of the Yugoslav Communist party, not because of the film but because of some remarks he made to a German newspaper allegedly insulting Yugoslav war veterans.I mention all this to establish Mr. Makavejev's independence of spirit, which, in Man Is Not a Bird," manages to be both profound and rollicking. The narrative seems to be about a moody, middle-aged, introspective factory engineer (Janez Urhovec) and the brief, unsatisfactory affair he has with a pretty, much younger woman, a barber (Milena Dravic) who seduces him out of boredom. The setting is a bleak Yugoslav industrial town that, though beautifully and realistically photographed, seems as mad and fantastical as something in a dream.Mr. Makavejev is not particularly interested in photographing the real world, but in reproducing the feelings inspired by being in it, and since his is a socialized country, one can never escape an awareness of political systems and pressures. "Man Is Not a Bird" is less about the engineer and the bird-brained barber than it is a conception of life in Tito's eccentrically Communist state.It's a world where the citizen-comrade dreams of the good life around the corner but makes do with considerably less, which, according to Mr. Makavejev, results in certainwellemotional strains. At least half the people in the film seem teetering on the edge of hysteria or lunacy. A jolly scene is a workmen's nightclub, where an overfed stripper is performing mightily, erupts into a riot that leaves the stripper dead, off-screen. A jealous wife has a knockdown, drag-out fight in the market place with her husband's mistress. The sadness is that the husband is a crazy old drunkard and both woman long past any primes.While the engineer is inspecting the room he is to rent the soundtrack is full of unexplained screams from the street outside. Bits of a love scene between the engineer and the barber are cross-cut with scenes of a fight in a police station. At one point the camera pans up the nude body of the pretty barber, lying on her stomach on a bed, and lands in a close-up of her large, vacant eye.Some of the film's ironies are heavy, but mostly they work. A worker at a smelting plant skylarks on top of a crane to amuse his buddies. "Man is not a bird," someone, yells. That is, man cannot fly, but Mr. Makavejev is saying throughout the film that man can, at least, try.Next to "Memories of Underdevelopment," "Man Is Not a Bird" is the most sophisticated and complex film from a Communist country that I've ever seen.The freedom of style that was chaotic in "Mysteries of the Organism" is perfectly disciplined in this first film. It is so poetic and true and multi-leveled that it reminds me of the best prose. Not because it is literary but because it simply could not exist in any other form. It also makes me want to see two later Makavejev films that were released here earlier. "An Affair of the Heart," which is also known as "Switchboard Operator" (1967), and "Innocence Unprotected" (1971).

title: F.B.I.'s Open Policy on Press Called Only Partly Successful
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 Traditionally, except when Gmen were shooting down notorious bank bandits in the 1930's and wanted to build an image, the Federal Bureau of Invstigation has viewed the press with the same friendliness it reserved for domestic Communists and the less exotic felons.

title: CITY WON'T DELAY CONVENTION HALL
description: Officials of the city's proposed $200million convention center said yesterday that they would proceed with construction, despite the failure of a Congressional committee to reccommend a declaration that would have waived the Federal Government's jurisdiction over the site.

title: U.S. Offers an Action Plan For Coming Energy Talks
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 31  The United States has proposed that the major oilconsuming nations that are to meet in Washing. ton Feb. 11 agree at the conference to work toward a farreaching cooperative action program that would include the sharing of energy resources in an emergency.

title: G.M. Quarterly Net Off
description: Profits of the General Motors Corporation for the fourth quarter of 1973 fell 22 per cent to $517million, although for the full year earnings were a record $2.4billion. Details on Page 35.

title: The U.S. Note on Energy Conference
description: Following is the text of a United States note on the Washington energy conference that has been made available to The New York Times. It was delivered to the participating governments and officials Wednesday.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: 7 Births Every Minute: Bangladesh's Biggest LongRange Problem
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Jan. 29 Seven babies are born each minute in Bangladesh, 10,000 each day. The population of 75 million is expected to double in two decades.

title: Warriors Triumph On Barry's Basket
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 31 (AP)Rick Barry hit a 28foot jump shot at the buzzer tonight give the Golden State Warriors a 109108 National Basketball Association victory over the Houton Rockets.

title: FARM PRICES SOAR BY 9% IN MONTH; MEAT LEADS WAY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Prices received by farmers ros?? sharply again from midDecember to midJanuary, reaching a point exactly twice the average for 1967 and signaling further increases at retail counters in the weeks ahead.

title: Samuel Goldwyn Dies at 91
description: Samuel Goldwyn, one of the last of the pioneer Hollywood producers, died early yesterday at his Los Angeles home at the age of 91. He had been in frail health since 1968 and two weeks ago had been released from a hospital after several weeks of treatment for an undisclosed illness.

title: N.L. Owners Accept Sale Of Padres
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Jan. 31 (AP)National League club owners approved unanimously today the sale of the San Diego Padres to Ray A. Kroc, chairman of the board of McDonald's Restaurants.

title: Heart Fund Month Starts
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) Vice President Ford had his blood pressure taken today as the official start of Heart Fund Month, February. Margene Wilson, a registered nurse, took the Vice President's reading in the National Press Club ballroom and said afterward it was well within normal limits.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
Housing Chief Reappointed; 2 Chosen for City Bodies
description: Joseph J. Christian was reappointed as chairman of the City Housing Authority by Mayor Beanie yesterday. The Mayor also appointed Harris J. Klein to the Human Rights Commission and Rabbi Samuel Fogelman to the Youth Board.

title: WARNING SYSTEM DUE ON APLANTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) The Government disclosed plans today to create a special warning system designed to minimize radiation casualties in the highly unlikely event of a major accident in a nuclear power plant anywhere in the country.

title: KISSINGER EXPECTS SOME ARABS TO ASK OIL EMBARGO'S END
description: WASHINGTON Jan. 31Secretary of State Kissinger said today that several Arab leaders would recommend the lifting of the oil embargo when the Arab oilproducing nations met in Tripoli, Libya, on Feb. 14or on an earlier date. One of the leaders was understood to be King Faisal of Saudi Arabia.

title: Study Finds 35 Gave 1.4Million To '72 Candidates for Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31Thirtyfive wealthy contributors gave $1.4million on Congressional candidates in 1972, according to a study released today by Common Cause.

title: Department Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $747million, up 11 per cent from the yearearlier $671million. Total retail store sales were about $8.657billion, up 7 per cent from last year's $8.107billion.

title: WILLIS BOYER, 58, STEEL CHIEF, DIES
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 31  Willis B. Boyer, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Republic Steel Corporation, died today in Lakeside Hospital, after an illness of six week. He was 58 years old.

title: Gloom Over Transit
description: The ritual every two years of trying to keep the city's transit fare from going up has taken on a gloomy new aspect.

title: U.S. BIDS TO FREEZE SOME VESCO ASSETS
description: An attempt by the Federal Government to freeze about $40million in assets in England of a concern owned by Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, has been authorized by a Federal judge in New York, Reuters reported.

title: To L.I.R.R. Faithful, 2Hour Ride From Speonk Is a Way of Life
description: SPEONK, L.I., Jan. 31 Slightly more than two hours  if the train is on time. That's how long it takes the Long Island Rail Road to reach Penn Station from this little village midway through Suffolk County. Yet there are hardy souls who do it every day.

title: Black Jack Is 27
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) Two hundred guests, a new halter and cake and apples marked the 27th birthday party yesterday of Black Jack, one of the best known horses in the country. Black Jack, known for his role in Presidential funerals, was given the party by Mrs. Michael V. Schado the wife of a retired Army officer.

title: Notes on People
description: Today is the 27th birthday of Capt. Donald Dawson of the Air Force, who was charged with disobeying an order to fly a bombing mission over Cambodia, and he certainly has something to celebrate. Yesterday he learned that the Pentagon had granted him conscientiousobjector status and that he would be discharged from the Air Force under honorable conditions. Captain Dawson, now stationed in. the Philippines, said last June that he was opposed to bombing Cambodia after the Vietnamese peace agreement had been signed. He subsequently refused an order to fly a bombing mission. Previously, he had flown 90 missions over North Vietnam. Had he been courtmartialed for disobeying orders he would have faced a maximum penalty of five years imprisonment, forfeiture of pay and dishonorable discharge.

title: Market Place: In 2 Months: Wall St. Shifts
description: Exactly two months from today  on April 1  investors will get a peek at the brokerage world of the future in terms of an experimental array of services and charges.

title: Dean's Credibility Backed By Watergate Prosecution
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The staff of the special Watergate prosecutor said today in Federal Court that it had no reason to believe that John W. Dean 3d had lied in the Watergate case.

title: Forgetting Watergate
description: The critical question is whether Mr. Nixon succeeded in persuading Congress and the nation that Watergate should be laid to rest in order for all of us to join together in devoting our full energies to these great issues that I have discussed tonight.

title: J. Russell Forgan Dead at 73; Banker Was Official of O.S.S.
description: J. Russell Forgan, an Investment banker and the retired board chairman of du Pont Glore Forgan, Inc., died yesterday of cancer at St. Luke's Hospital. Mr. Forgan was 73 years old and lived at 640 Park Avenue.

title: About New York
description: Outside 152 West 49th Street, the Royal Apartments, the blond prostitute in the high red boots was smiling. See her? the cop in the car said, the biggest ripoff in town. His partners barely nodded. She's out on $7,500 bail, one said. That building, the other one said, you know how many times we've had to go in there?

title: Nest Egg Lottery Set
description: ALBANY, Jan. 31 (UPI)The State Lottery Division is starting a new $2 lottery special next week. The nest egg special will provide prizes of $200 a week for life, along with 19,999 cash prizes ranging from $5,500 to $10 for each million worth of tickets sold. Tickets will go on sale beginning Feb. 6.

title: RODINO UNIT ASKS A HOUSE MANDATE FOR NIXON INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 31The House Judiciary Committee unanimously adopted a resolution today asking that full constitutional authority for the impeachment inquiry on President Nixon, including subpoena power, be given the committee by the House of Representatives.

title: Contract Awards
description: Textron, Inc.'s, Bell Helicopter division received a $59.2million Army contract for modifying AH1G gunship helicopters.

title: Dean's Credibility Backed By Watergate Prosecution
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The staff of the special Watergate prosecutor said today in Federal Court that it had no reason to believe that John W. Dean 3d had lied in the, Watergate case.

title: Jersey Orders Lobbyists to Reveal Funds
description: TRENTON, Jan. 31The New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission today ruled that all funds spent in trying to influence legislation here must be disclosed publicly.

title: Mobil Raises Gas Price; Allocation Here Tightens
description: A nationwide 3centagallon increase in the price of gasoline to retailers was announced yesterday by the Mobil Oil Corporation amid indications that gasoline supplies generally would be shorter this month than they were in January. The increase is effective today.

title: U.S. AID WON'T SAVE FARE, BERME SAYS
description: New York City's share of proposed Federal operating subsidies for transit will not be nearly enough to save the 35cent fare, Mayor Beame and top transit leaders declared yesterday.

title: Gloom Over Transit
description: The ritual every two years of trying to keep the city's transit fare from going up has taken on a gloomy new aspect.

title: Prices of Silver Futures Climb In Unusually Heavy Trading
description: The price of silver for future, delivery resumed its advance toward record levels yesterday in unusually heavy trading. The nearest, delivery, March, rose the daily permissible limit of 10 cents an ounce, with the more distant months closing a bit lower.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.5 billion tonmiles, 3.1 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings during the same period totaled 520,297 cars, 0.7 per cent above last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 4.5 per cent above last year.

title: Belgian Bank Raises Rate
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 31 (UPI)The Belgian National Bank announced today, it would increase is discount rate one percentage point to 8.75 per cent as of Feb. 1. A bank spokesman said the increase is a technical one to adapt the rate to the general money market rates, which increased considerably in the past few weeks. The rate, the bank's basic interest rate, had been set at 7.75 per cent last Nov. 29.

title: Blue Jeans For Bob Dylan
description: Bob Dylan closed his Madison Square Garden concert the other night with Blowin in the Wind (how many times must the cannon balls fly/before they're forever banned), which may well be the nearest thing to a hymn the peace movement had. Before that, alone on the stage with harmonica and guitar, Dylan sang The Times They Are AChangin, with that peculiarly poignant twang only he can give to those quintessential lines of the sixties (There's a battle/ outside and it's ragin'/ It'll soon shake your windows/ and rattle your walls).

title: Ski Resorts' Inducement: Free Night
description: To try to cope with the indecision among enthusiasts about whether to head north because of President Nixon's Never on Sunday gasoline sales request, some ski operators have started an Always on Mondays benefit. The upstate Lake Placid  Wilmington community is involved in a cooperative movement in this direction. More than 40 inns, motels and lodges are offering free Sunday nightMonday morning housing to guests spending weekends at their respective establishments.

title: List of Those Believed Killed in Pagopago Air Crash
description: Following, as made public by Pan American World Airways in New York, is a list of 92 passengers and crew members who reportedly died in a plane crash at Pagopago. Three others who died later were not identified.

title: Miss Woods's Lawyer Denies She Intentionally Erased Tape
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31An attorney for Rose Mary Woods, President Nixon's personal secretary, expressed certainty today that his client had not intentionally erased part of a crucial White House tape recording but held open the possibility that someone else might have done so.

title: Tokyo Reporter Who Obtained Secret Cables Wins Acquittal
description: TOKYO, Jan. 31A Japanese court today acquitted a news reporter accused of illegally obtainilg copies of three secret diplomatic cables.

title: 100 Mental Halfway Houses Proposed
description: Setting up 100 fully staffed and wellsupervised halfway houses for discharged mental patients in the state this year, half of them in New York City, is proposed as part of a plan to end the situation that has forced thousands of these patients to live under inhuman conditions:

title: Damaged Norwegian Ship Ransacked at New Orlear
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 31 (UP Officers quarters on the ba?? ly damaged Norwegian freigh?? er Baune have been ransack?? and a number of valuable pe?? sonal belongings stolen, t?? ship's chief officer report?? yesterday.

title: Mildren and Fairbanks Join Forces as Patriots
description: Jack Mildren and Chuck Fairbanks have joined forces again and the reunion could make a dent in pro football. During the National Football League's draft last Wednesday Mildren was traded by the Baltimore Colts to the New England Patriots for a sixthround draft choice, which isn't much.

title: Nixon May Meet Press
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI)., President Nixon will probably hold a news conference, within two weeks, the White House press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, said today. The conference would be the first time Mr. Nixon has answered questions from Me White House; press corps since Oct. 26 and the first time he has submitted) to public questioning since an hourlong session with newspaper managing editors at a convention in Florida on Nov. 17.

title: UNITED AIRCRAFT SETS ESSEX DEAL
description: Shareholders of the United Aircraft Corporation and Essex International, Inc., at separate meetings yesterday approved the $400million merger of the two concerns, effective Feb. 5, when Essex becomes a wholly owned subsidiary of United. Harry J. Gray, chairman and president of United, also disclosed to stockholders the corporation's results for last year.

title: Terrorists in Singapore Menace Refinery, Then Take 5 Hostages
description: SINGAPORE, Jan. 31 (AP)Four men tried to blow up a Shell refinery here today, then seized five hostages aboard ferryboat and threatened to kill themselves and the hostages unless they were given safe conduct to an Arab country, Singapore officials said.

title: Nets, Still Minus Paultz, Await Spurs
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Jan. 31 Although Julius Erving and Larry Kenon are back from the American Basketball Association's AllStar game in Norfolk, Va., where both were outstanding performers for the victorious East squad, the New York Nets will still have two of their stars missing when they resume the regular season tomorrow night.

title: Bruins Win As Esposito Scores Pair
description: BOSTON, Jan. 31 (AP) Phil Esposito, the National Hockey League scoring leader, tallied two goals tonight that helped carry the Boston Bruins to a 42 victory over the Atlanta Flames.

title: Quarter of 17State Rail Lines Are Said to Be Found Excess
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI) The Department of Transportation has concluded that onefourth of the railroad lines in 17 Northeastern and Midwestern states are potentially excess and should be considered for abandonment or consolidation with other lines, it was learned today.

title: RULES UNIT VOTES COUNCIL CHANGES
description: The City Council Committee on Rules approved 15 changes in the Council's procedures yesterday, eliminating some practices that have long offended good government groups. Other proposals for more radical reform were voted down.

title: Stage: New Rosencrantz
description: Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead is very much alive off Off Broadway in the CSC Repertory Company's latest production of Tom Stoppard's dazzling brainwasher.

title: Chicago to Restore Former Gold Coast
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 31Many years ago, in far more halcyon days, it was called the sunny street that held the sifted few.

title: 81 on Cruise Ship From Poland Defect At Western Ports
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Jan. 31 (AP)Eightyone passengers defected from a Polish cruise liner earlier this week during stopovers in Denmark, Norway and West Germany, authorities said today. It was believed to be the largest mass defection that Communist Poland has had.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Catfish Farmers Prosper
description: Those who have dined on pompano or poached trout or broiler Atlantic salmon might view the common channel catfish with disdain, but many find its flesh delectable.

title: KISSINGER EXPECTS SOME ARABS TO ASK OIL EMBARGO'S END

One of the leaders was understood to be King Faisal of Saudi Arabia.

title: Witness Testifies He Saw 3 Girls Hit by Ellmers Car
description: MORRISTOWN, Jan. 31  A Wayne resident testified here today that he had seen John Ellmers's car swerve off Route 24 in Madison and hit and kill two young girls and injure a third last June 14.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS Jan. 31, 1974
description: New York300332

title: WESTINGHOUSE SUES G.E. IN PATENTS CASE
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation filed suit yesterday against the General Electric Company in the United States Court for the Northern District of Illinois in Chicago charging infringement on two patents.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Nicklaus, Nevil Tie With 65's
description: HONOLULU, Jan. 31 (AP) Jack Nicklaus returned to the pro golf tour today with a sparkling sevenunderpar 65 and a share of the firstround lead in the $220,000 Hawaiian open.

title: Books of The Times
description: FAT EMILY. By Susan Ries Lukas. 203 pages. Stein & Day. $6.95.

title: Quake Felt in California
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Jan. 31 (UPI)A mild earthquake rumbled through the Riverside and Perris areas late last night and touched off a flurry of phone calls from homeowners.

title: People in Sports: Austin Peay's Message to L.I. U.Fly Is Back
description: The Fly is back in action. That will be good news to his Brooklyn neighbors and his Austin Peay State basketball teammates but bad news to Long Island University, which meets Austin Peay in Madison Square Garden tomorrow afternoon.

title: '73 Results Set Highs
Nixon Reported to Spurn Pleas To Break Ties With ExAides
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The White House chief of staff, Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., and Secretary of State Kissinger have sought unsuccessfully for six months to persuade President Nixon to break his ties with three former assistants involved in the Watergate investigation, the Washington Post reported in its Friday editions.

title: Schlesinger Testifies Fuel Allocations To Military Must Be Raised This Spring
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger said today that fuel allocations to the military would have to be increased his spring to maintain the combat readiness of the armed forces.

title: New Perspective on American Folk Art
description: The exhibition called The Flowering of American Folk Art 17761876, which opens today at the Whitney Museum of American Art, is so completely delightful that it seems almost unnecessary to point out that it is also an event of considerable arthistorical importance. As a visual spectacle, this survey of some 300 worksnot only paintings and sculpture but also furniture, quilts, shop signs, toys, rugs, embroidery and other items of household and commercial usewill beguile the eye and enrich the imagination of just about anyone with an appetite for artistic excellence. For others, who take a more professional interest in such matters, it will also mark a turning point in the place traditionally assigned to folk art in the hierarchy of esthetic experience.

title: CAMBODIAN SENATOR INJURED IN SHELLING
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 31 (UPI)Rebel rocket teams fired three Sovietbuilt 122mm. rockets into the western section of Phnom Penh and an airport complex today, wounding a Cambodian senator and 10 other persons.

title: SPATE COMPLETES PLAN ON ABORTION
description: TRENTON, Jan. 31The State Department of Health anpounced today it had completed its proposals for licensing abortion facilities for pregnancies in their first three months.

title: RODINO UNIT ASKS A HOUSE MANDATE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The House Judiciary Committee unanimously adopted a resolution today asking that full constitutional authority for the impeachment inquiry on President Nixon, including subpoena power, be given the committee by the House of Representatives.

title: News Summary and Index FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 1, 1974
description: International

title: MARKET WARNED BY ITS EXECUTIVE
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 31  The 13member Executive Commission of the European Common Market warned today that the ninenation Community was in a deep crisis, and it called on the members to say whether they wanted to act individually or together to meet the problems facing them.

title: Women With Talent and Tuition MoneyJust What Colleges Need
description: It's a good thing that so many mothers went back to school. Otherwise, all students might still have to swim so many lengths of the college pool to get their diplomas.

title: Insurance Companies Find More Jobs for Blacks, but...
description: HARTFORD  The Urban League here has decided that for a year, at least, it will not distribute Its customary annual awards for accomplishment in providing equal opportunities to minorities.

title: Tyler Sets Canadian Deal
description: The Tyler Corporation announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement with PanCanadian Petroleum, Ltd., to build a $45million ammonia complex in southern Alberta, Canada. The joint complex is expected to produce more than 400,000 tons of anhydrous ammonia annually. Tyler holds a 40 per cent interest in the venture.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: (Millions of dollars)

title: Otis Acquires Electrobus
description: The Otis Elevator Company has acquired Electrobus, a division of the Tork Link Corporation of California. Electrobus makes batterypowered buses capable of 35mileanhour speeds that can transport up to 40 passengers. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Verdi's Heart Wasn't in It
description: As commonly titled, it is I Vespri Siciliani by Giuseppe Verdi. In English it is The Sicilian Vespers. In French, the language in which it was originally, sung, it Les Vepres Siciliennes. On the title page of the first Italian edition it is Giovanna di Guzman. In Italy before the independence of 1861 it might have turned up as Giovanna di Braganza or Betilde di Turenna.

title: Cause of Death Disputed at L.I. Tria
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 31 A noted pathologist who said he had performed more than 30,000 autopsies in 47 years as a physician, testified today that the death of Eugene Bauer was due to cancer and a pulmonary embolism, and was not caused by an injection of potassium chloride, as charged by the state.

title: EDUCATION
description: 1st Summer Session Begins Monday, June 3 For Information, Write or Phone Pace University, Pace Plaza, N.Y C. 2853000

title: Revised '72 Figure in Rate of Growth Shows 8.7% Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The Federal Reserve Board published today statistical revisions showing that the nation's money supply grew at a postwar record rate in 1972 and first half of 1973.

title: Transit ShortChanged
description: President Nixon's proposal for a sixyear urban transportation program that will provide increasing Federal assistance for mass transit gives encouraging support to the nation's neglected public transportation systems. But funding provisions in the President's plan apparently will fall far short of the expectations and needs of such hardpressed cities as New York. They will also fall short of the commitment to mass transportation that environmental and energy considerations demand.

title: Wang Chiahsiang Dead at 68; ExChinese Envoy to Moscow
description: TOKYO, Jan. 31 (AP)Wang Chiahsiang, the first postrevolutionary Chinese Ambassador to Moscow and an early party leader, died Jan. 25, the official press agency Hsinhua said today. He was 68 years old.

title: Blacks in Newark Putting More Stress on City Council Races and Less on Mayoralty
description: NEWARK, Jan. 31  As campaigns open for next May's municipal elections, much political interest is focusing on the race for the Newark Municipal Council, and less on the mayoral contest, which drew most attention four years ago when this predominantly black city elected its first black Mayor.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Woman Is Slain, Another Hurt on Queens Streets
description: Two women walking to their home in Sunnyside, Queens, in in late evening hours on Wednesday were attacked one fatallyin separate incidents, the police reported yesterday.

title: 645 MEASLES CASES REPORTED BY STATE
description: TRENTON, Jan. 31 (UPI) A State Health Department official said today that 645 cases of measles had been reported and called the current epidemic a tragic occurrence because it is an entirely preventative one.

title: ILLINOIS PAYOFFS CHARGED TO 3 MEN
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 31A millionaire contractor, a prominen Chicago lawyer and an Arkansas businessman have been named in a 21count Federal indictment here alleging $80,000 in kickbacks to the late Paul Powell who was Illinois Secretary of State.

title: New York: The Househusband's Son Replies
description: My father, Robert Claiborne, wrote an article that appeared on the OpEd Page Jan. 21 and in which he calculated that during the seven weeks of his wife's disability from surgery all housekeeping chores consumed only 27 hours a week.

title: Brezhnev Promises to Help Cubans Search for Oil
description: MIAMI, Jan. 31 (UPI)Leonid I. Brezhnev has promised Cuba technical aid so that she can search for new petroleum resources, according to Havana broadcasts monitored here today.

title: KISSINGER CALLED ON ALLEGED SPYING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The Senate Armed Services Committee announced today that it had summoned Secretary of State Kissinger and Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to testify about the alleged military spying operations inside the White House in 1971.

title: Study Finds 35 Gave 1.4Million To '72 Candidates for Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31Thirtyfive wealthy contributors gave $1.4million on Congressional candidates in 1972, according to a study released today by Common Cause.

title: System Injected a Large Volume of Reserves
description: The Federal Reserve System, in a significant step toward easier credit conditions, definitely made money easier to borrow during the week ended Wednesday, banking statistics released yesterday showed.

title: T.W.A. and Boeing Plan To Modify Aircraft Deal
description: Trans World Airlines announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle with the Boeing Company to modify the 1974 and 1975 delivery schedules of B727.231 aircraft on firm order.

title: SENATE APPROVES LEGAL AID AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 31The Senate approved tonight creation of a new public agency to provide the legal services for the poor that were formerly part of the poverty program. The vote, 69 to 17, came after critics had spent more than nine hours attacking the program.

title: ARABS CALL SYRIA KEY TO OIL POLIC
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 31Arab, leaders say that any lifting of the embargo on oil shipments to the United States will be linked closely to progress in achieving an Israeli pullback from the Golan Heights front in Syria.

title: G.M. Profit Fell 22% in Fourth Quarter
description: The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday that profit for the fourth quarter of 1973 fell 22 per cent to $517million, equal to $1.80 a common share, from $667million, or $2.32 a share, the year before.

title: Oil Payments Are Raised
description: Texaco, Inc., and the Standard Oil Company of California said yesterday that they were raising payments to Pertamina, the Indonesian state oil enterprise. Agreements have been reached, it was said, with Indonesian authorities in Jakarta for additional payments to Pertamina by Caltex Pacific, owned 50 per cent by Texaco and 50 per cent by Socal. Discussions on payments were initiated by Indonesia.

title: G.M. Quarterly Net Off
description: Profits of the General Motors Corporation for the fourth quarter of 1973 fell 22 per cent to $517million, although for the full year earnings were a record $2.4billion. Details on Page 35.

title: FRANCE IS GOING ABROAD FOR LOANS
description: PARIS, Jan. 31France is turning to international lenders in London and New Yorkand indirectly the Middle East to help pay for the higher cost of oil this year, high officials reported today.

title: The Rheingold River Flows Gently to a City Sewer
description: On the third floor of the cool, pristine storage rooms of the Rheingold brewery in Brooklyn yesterday, there was a sweet smell tinged with tartness and a sound strangely reminiscent of the gushing of a small brook.

title: 2 of 3 Defendants in LSD Case Found Guilty by Jury on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31  A threemonth long trial in United States District Court here ended last night when a jury found two of three defendants guilty of manufacturing LSD and conspiracy to evade Federal income taxes. The third defendant was acquitted.

title: SoHo Restaurant Caters to Artists Who've Made It Uptown
description: John Ballato's 12table restaurant on East Houston Street barely qualifiesgeographicallyfor SoHo classification, since number 55 gives onto the south sidewalk of that dividing thoroughfare. Ballato's sounds more decisively SoHo as the place where all the artists eat, which has become its epithet. But don't expect to find there a picturesque slice of La Vie de Bohme.

title: U.S. ALTERS SYSTEM ON WELFARE CHECKS
description: The Social Security Administration yesterday discontinued a temporary system of providing emergency replacement checks overnight to aged, blind or disabled people here who fail to receive their checks under th enew Supplemental Security Income Program.

title: Reserve Report
description: In Billions

title: A Tempest in a Furnace: Steel Patent Is the Issue
description: The steel industry in the United States suffered a major setback in the United States District Court in Pittsburgh on Tuesday. Judge Louis Rosenberg decided there that the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation had infringed on a patent held by an Austrian company on the basic oxygen furnace (BOF).

title: H.I.P. Pact With City Calls for Ombudsman
description: The Health Insurance Plan, which provides prepaid medical services to more than 760,000 people In the New York metropolitan area, will be the first medical insurance program In the country to have an ombudsman and the first in the state to have outside physicians check its own, under a new contract worked out with the city.

title: Dargay Pace Ski Jumpers
description: COPPER PEAK, Mich., Jan. 31 (UPI)  Tom Dargay of Minneapolis soared 443 feet today to lead 40 rivals from seven nations during qualifications for the fifth annual Ironwood skijumping meet.

title: Accountant Accused of Attempt To Influence Gambler's Case
description: A Brooklyn accountant and a man described by the police as a major bookmaker have been indicted by a Manhattan grand jury on charges of attempting to influence State Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts on the behalf of the bookmaker, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: James T. Kirk Is Dead at 78; ExMayor of Elizabeth, N.J.
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 31James T. Kirk, who was mayor of Elizabeth from 1939 to 1952, died today at the age of 78.

title: Jaworski Asks Delay in Ervin Report
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The special Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, requested today that the Senate Watergate = committee delay filing final reports on its work to avoid prejudicing future criminal trials.

title: Senator Faults Companies And U.S. Over Oil Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The oil companies' failure to stand together and bungling by the State Department were major factors in the sharp rise in world petroleum prices, Senator Frank Church declared at Senate hearing today.

title: PRESIDENT URGES COUNTRY TO PRAY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 President Nixon, looking vigorous and refreshed after his State of the Union address last night, urged Americans today to join in silent prayer to determine God's will for the country.

title: COMPENSATION SET ON KUWAIT OIL DEAL
description: KUWAIT, Jan. 31 (Reuters)Kuwait is to pay $112million compensation for a 60 per cent takeover of the Kuwait Oil Company, (K.O.C.) owned by the British Petroleum Company, Ltd., and the Gulf Oil Corporation.

title: Wietecha, Enis Signed By Giants
description: Bill Arnsparger moved closer to completing his New York Giants coaching staff yesterday with the selection of Ray Wietecha and Hunter Enis as offensive assistants.

title: Dylan Ends Stand Here With See Ya Next Year
description: The two concerts yesterday by Bob Dylan and the Band at Madison Square Garden served to reinforce the triumph of their first concert on Wednesday. This was great rock n roll music, and if their voices sounded a bit more tired than they had on Wednesday, they never gave oin to tiredness: the excitement of the occasion was more than enough to sweep fatigue aside. This superbly produced, superbly engineered tour isn't over yet, but one can't help thinking that the New York concerts will be looked back upon as its climax.

title: 500 THIRDARMY MEN WELCOMED IN CAIRO
description: CAIRO, Jan. 31 (Reuters) The first group of soldiers from Egypt's Third Army in Sinai arrived here today by train from Suez amid frenzied scenes of welcome at Cairo's main railroad station.

title: A New Issue Raised on Nixon Taxe: Depreciation on His Office Furniture
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31Congressional investigators and the Internal Revenue Service have raised a new issue concerning the propriety of President Nixon's tax returns, in addition to the two he has acknowledged publicly.

title: SWISS BAN ON SALES TO FOREIGNERS ENDS
description: GENEVA, Jan. 31Switzerland followed today the lead given by the United States and West Germany on the dismantling of barriers to the international flow of funds by scrapping her ban on the sale of Swiss securities to foreigners.

title: FARM PRICES SOAR BY 9% IN MONTH; MEAT LEADS WAY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31Prices received by farmers rose sharply again from midDecember to midJanuary, reaching point exactly twice the average for 1967 and signaling further increases at retail counters in the weeks ahead.

title: Advertising: Reverse Evolution
description: A pinch in advertising budgets this year could well hasten the reverse evolution of the American advertising agency.

title: Retailers Close Year With Sales Gains
description: The nation's largest retail chains closed out their fiscal years last month on a strong note with substantial sales gains in January over the same 1973 month.

title: Mobil Raises Gas Price; Allocation Here Tightens
description: A nationwide 3centagallon increase in the price of gasoline to retailers was announced yesterday by the Mobil Oil Corporation amid indications that gasoline supplies generally would be shorter this month than they were in January. The increase is effective today.

title: CurtissWright Board Votes 10Cent Dividend
description: Directors of the CurtissWright Corporation declared yesterday a 10cent dividend on the company's common stock, payable April 24 to stockholders of record Feb. 19.

title: People and Business
description: Lawrence S. Phillips, president of the PhillipsVan Heusen Corporation, a large apparel manufacturer and retailer, wrote a letter this week to his company's top officials asking them to respond in any way we can to the immorality of France.

title: Samuels Resigns As OTB President
description: Howard Samuels resigned yesterday as president of the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation, clearing the way for his entry into a different kind of horse race as a political candidate.

title: Andretti Out of Hospital
description: ONTARIO, Calif., Jan. 31 (AP)Mario Andretti was released from a hospital today two days after suffering a mild concussion during a crash at Ontario Motor Speedway.

title: HARRY T. BYRNE
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Jan. 31 Harry T. Byrne, a retired stockbroker and tax consultant, died today in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 17 Dante Street.

title: DeBusschere 22: Basketball Hero Of Two Cities
description: The back of his basketball uniform read DeBusschere 22, and the front, New York, but honors for the Knick forward tonight will come from old friends and the opposition the Detroit Pistons. It's rare for sports teams to give recognition to opposing players, but in Detroit Dave DeBusschere is something special.

title: Black Officer Named Head of City's Uniformed Units
description: Thomas P. Mitchelson, a 49yearold former Marine Corps sergeant, was promoted yesterday to chief of field services for the Police Department, the highest rank ever reached by a black officer.

title: SKYLAB 3 CLEARED ON LAST WEEK ALOFT
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 31 (UPI)The Skylab 3 astronauts said today that they were in better physical shape than when they were launched 77 days ago and had proved that man could set up housekeeping in space and adjust to weightlessness.

title: Israel Indicates Pullback Offer to Syria
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 31Israel's top leaders have indicated a willingness to withdraw from the Syrian territory captured in October as part of a troopseparation agreement to be negotiated with Syria similar to that being carried out with Egypt.

title: White House Plans 5Year Funding for Public TV
description: The White House is preparing a fiveyear funding bill for public broadcasting asking for graduated annual appropriations to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting that would reach $100million at the end of the fifth year, a source close to the Administration disclosed yesterday.

title: TV: Migrants, a Drama That Portrays Poverty
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System continues its expedition into quality drama this Sunday evening with a production entitled Tennessee Williams The Migrants. Following The Autobiography of Miss Jane Pittman only a few days, this Playhouse 90 presentation makes the C.B.S. track record look remarkably impressive.

title: New Try on Welfare
description: By all odds the most imaginative social initiative the Nixon Administration was the President's 1969 proposal to put a floor under family income as a means moving away from the colossal failure of the public welfare system.

title: 2D WITNESS LINKS NELL TO PLAN
description: A prosecution witness in the trial of former Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell testified yesterday that he hadreceived assurances from a former Queens County detective that Mackell is in this.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 31

title: Business Records
description: Petition Filed By; WINFIELD W. COLEMAN, sales clerk, 256 E. 10th St., N.Y. Liabilities, $17,830; assets, 55,275.

title: DELMONT PFEFFER, FINANCE AUTHORITY
description: SOUTHBURY, Conn., Jan. 31 Delmont K. Pfeffer, a retired executive of the First National City Bank of New York and an authority on public finance, died in Heritage Village here on Sunday. He was 71 years old.

title: Tramunti Nod Said to Sanction Drug Buy
description: A key witness testified yesterday that Carmine Tramunti, a reputed Mafia boss, nodded his head in reply when an alleged heroin distributor requested money to pay for a narcotics shipment.

title: The Rheingold River Flows Gently to a City Sewer
description: On the third floor of the cool, pristine storage rooms of the Rheingold brewery in Brooklyn yesterday, there was a sweet smell tinged with tartness and a sound strangely reminiscent of the gushing of a small brook.

title: MONTECARLO
KISSINGER TO FLY TO PANAMA FEB. 7
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31Secretary of State Kissinger will fly to Panama City next Thursday to sign a declaration of principles that will serve as a guideline for a new treaty regulating the Panama Canal, the State Department announced today.

title: U.S. AID WON'T SAVE FARE, BEAME SAYS
description: New York City's share of proposed Federal operating subsidies for transit will not be nearly enough to save the 35cent fare, Mayor Beame and top transit leaders declared yesterday.

title: BEAME PROPOSES HIS FIRST BUDGET
Bolivian Farm Workers Threaten Renewed Resistance
description: COCHABAMBA, Bolivia, Jan. 31 (Reuters)  Bolivian farm workers threatened new defiance today to the Government of President Hugo Banzer Suarez after troops swept aside their barricades yesterday, leaving nine people dead and at least 30 wounded, according to reports.

title: Senator Faults Companies And U.S. Over Oil Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The oil companies' failure to stand together and bungling by the State Department were major factors in the sharp rise in world petroleum prices, Senator Frank Church declared at a Senate hearing today.

title: Off Off Broadway
description: It is advisable to telephone theaters for schedules and prices before going to the show. Most, if not all, theaters accept Theater Development Fund vouchers.

title: JOB RIGHT SUIT LOST BY GEORGIA UTILITY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)  The Justice Department won a final court order today requiring the Georgia Power Company to pay more than $2million to black victims of job discrimination.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Negotiators for the union representing 2,800 faculty members at eight state colleges and for the State Department of Higher Education met until 1 A.M. yesterday in an effort to reach agreement on a contract before Monday's strike deadline.

title: Samuel Goldwyn Dies at 91
description: Samuel Goldwyn, one of the last of the pioneer Hollywood producers, died early yesterday at his Los Angeles home at the age of 91. He had been in frail health since 1968 and two weeks ago had been released from a hospital after several weeks of treatment for an undisclosed illness.

title: Prices of Silver Futures Climb In Unusually Heavy Trading
description: The price of silver for future delivery resumed its advance toward record levels yesterday in unusually heavy trading. The nearest delivery, March, rose the daily permissible limit of 10 cents an ounce, with the more distant months closing bit lower.

title: Brazil Devalues Cruzeiro
description: BRASILIA, Jan. 31 (UPI)Brazil's currency, the cruzeiro, was devalued today, the central bank reported. The new parity, 6.30 cruzeiros per dollar for buying and 6.34 cruzeiros for selling is a devaluation of 1.95 per cent from rates established 48 days ago.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Mrs. Constance Rogers of Forest Hills, Queens, indicted in connection with racefixing charges against New York harness drivers, was convicted yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court on three counts of giving false identification the Internal Revenue Service. A jury of eight women and four men found Mrs. Rogers guilty of using false identity in cashing $57,347 worth of superfecta tickets last year shops of the Offtrack Betting Corporation. The violations took place on March 21 in Rego Park, Queens, and April 2 and April 4 in Manhattan.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: With the Presidency in the Balance

title: Snead, at 67, Leads Senior Golf by Shot
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Jan. 31 (AP)Sam Snead moved into a onestroke lead today in his hid for a third straight Professional Golfers' Association Seniors title. He carded a fiveunderpar 67.

title: Ships Passing In the Night
description: In his State of the Union speech, President Nixon told the American people that things are going fairly wellno war, no military draft, more jobs and more real spendable income than ever before. He added that while we still have some problems with inflation, prices and energy, he has policies to deal with all this and there will be no recession in the United States of America.

title: Carpi Planning Book on Criminal Justice
description: PRINCETON, Jan. 31  Relaxed in sweater and tennis shoes, Colin C. Carpi plunged into the task today of rebuilding and expanding the investment analysis business he conducts from the sunny living room of his big home in an exclusive section of this university town.

title: Mrs. Florence Brooks, Head Of 3 Papers in Connecticut
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 31  Mrs. Florence Goodwin Brooks, board chairman of The Westport News, a semiweekly newspaper, and a director of The Brooks Community Newspaper, which also publishes The Darien News and The Fairfield Citizen, died Wednesday at her home, 17 Harding Lane. Her age was 69.

title: ASSEMBLY VOTES TO OPEN MEETINGS
description: TRENTON, Jan. 31The State Assembly voted 73.0 today for changes in rules and procedures to open up the government with reforms of committee and legislative proceedings.

title: FRANKLIN NATIONAL NOTES FRANC ERROR
description: The Franklin National Bank acknowledged yesterday a bookkeeping error in its foreignexchange trading operations related to the bank's balances in French francs.

title: 95 Are Reported Killed in Crash Of a U.S. Jetliner at Pagopago
description: A Pan American World Airways 707 jetliner crashed and burned yesterday while attempting to land in bad weather at Pagopago, American Samoa, and a Samoan government spokesman said that 95 of the 101 persons aboard were killed.

title: Nest Egg Lottery Set
description: ALBANY, Jan. 31 (UPI)The State Lottery Division is starting a new $2 lottery special next week. The nest egg special will provide prizes of $200 a week for life, along with 19,999 cash prizes ranging from $5,500 to $10 for each million worth of tickets sold. Tickets will go on sale beginning Feb. 6.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WHAT'S THE STORY? If you're a student, the place for you from 7:30 to 11:30 tonight is the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street (9566100).

title: A Moderate Among Militants Joseph Gormley
description: LONDON, Jan. 31Joseph Gormley started in the Lanshire coal pits at 14 and spent nearly 30 years underground. Now he is president of Britain's mine workers national figure with a house in a plesant river suburb, a hefty expense account for whose enthusiasuse he is sometimes criticized and a significant voice in national affairs.

title: St. John's Turns Back Rhode Island by 7759
description: KINGSTON, R. I., Jan. 31 St. John's started slowly but scored a 7759 victory over Rhode Island University before 4,000 basketball fans tonight.

title: CONTINENTAL OIL RAISES PROFIT 91%
description: The Continental Oil Company, the nation's eighth largest oil company, recorded a 91.6 per cent increase in profits for the fourth quarter of 1973, while income for the year rose 42.6 per cent over the 1972 level.

title: Briefs on Energy
description: ROME, Jan. 31  Court sources said today that three magistrates and more than 40 policemen were trying to determine whether oil companies bribed Government officials with a reported $25million slush fund, in a conspiracy to raise prices. The inquiry started in Rome and Genoa last December when service stations complained that their gasoline supplies were being stopped, and a black market in fuel oil for industrial purposes and for heating developed. Investigators searched the offices of various oil companies and reportedly seized records showing that tankers at sea had received instructions from Italy to change course and deliver their crude oil elsewhere. This was taken as evidence that the oil storage facilities in Italy were full at the time of the presumed shortages. Meanwhile, the price for a gallon of premium grade gasoline, now $1.24, is expected to go up to at least $1.54.

title: Defense of Privacy
description: Ironic as it may seem for the creator of the White House plumbers to lead a crusade in defense of individual privacy, the President's strong plea for controls on electronic surveillance and other invasions of privacy deserves a constructive response from both his own executive branch and Congress.

title: POPE WILL EXPAND MARRIAGE RULES
description: ROME, Jan. 31  Pope Paul VI announced today that the Roman Catholic Church's rules on marriage would soon be formulated in a more complete and modern way.

title: CREDIT MARKETS SHOW FIRM TONE
description: Profit taking by professional traders trimmed prices of recently issued corporate bonds yesterday but elsewhere in the credit markets this week's firm tone persisted.

title: Cramped Quarters
description: The two best basketball teams in Manhattan played one of the most critical games of the season in an elementary school gymnasium last Tuesday. Hughes, the leader the Public Schools Athletic League Manhattan Division, defeated Haaren, the home team, 7974.

title: A. & P. Earnings Projection For Fiscal Year Challenged
description: Michael McIntosh, who filed a lawsuit in January to gain access to the books of the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, yesterday questioned the motivation of the company's projection of earnings Tuesday.

title: F.B.I.'s Open Policy on Press Called Only Partly Successful
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Traditionally, except when Gmen were shooting in notorious bank bandits in the 1930's and wanted to build an image, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has viewed the press with the same friendliness it reserved for domestic Communists and the less exotic felons.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Dempsey Wins by T.K.O.

title: Borg, Moore in Final
description: OSLO, Norway, Feb. 1 (AP)Bjorn Borg and Ray Moore moved into the men's final of the Scandinavian tournament today after Leslie Charles of Britain won the women's final with a 64, 6.4 triumph over Ellen Grindvoid of Norway.

title: Man's Denial Reported
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 1 (Reuters)  The man arrested here as one of the 1963 gang of train robbers has denied that he is Ronald A. Biggs, diplomatic sources said tonight.

title: Gottfried Moves On
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 1 (AP) Brian Gottfried of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Raul Ramirez of Mexico advanced to the semifinals of the Day ton pro tournament today by defeating Australians.

title: SWINDLE INVESTOR TELLS OP PROFITS
description: An investor in a pyramid investment scheme testified yesterday that a Queens detective  himself an investor in the scheme  interviewed him about the swindle but never asked him to sign a complaint.

title: Saigon and Vietcong to Resume Prisoner Exchange Next Week, Ending Impasse
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 1Breaking a sixmonth deadlock, the Saigon Government and the Vietcong set a date today for the resumption of their exchange of prisoners.

title: Income Distribution Found Little Changed Since War
RHODES WORRIED BY G.O.P. EXODUS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 1Representative John J. Rhodes, the House minority leader, said today that he was very concerned over the unusually large number of Republicans who do not plan to seek reelection this year.

title: FURTHER EASING By RESERVE SEEN
description: The Federal Reserve operated actively in the money markets yesterday, pumping additional reserves into the banking system and driving shortterm interest rates downward.

title: MARGARET MARSHALL
description: UPLAND, Calif., Feb. 1 Margaret Marshall, a book and magazine editor, died today at the age of 74.

title: A Private Funeral Service For Goldwyn Held on Coast
description: HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 1 (UPI) Samuel Goldwyn was buried today in a private service with only members of his family as mourners.

title: Cougars Rally to Win
description: MEMPHIS, Feb. 1 (AP)Ted McClain hit a 15foot jump shot with four seconds left to give Carolina a 104102 victory over the Memphis Tams tonight.

title: Exxon Official Links Oil Crisis to Errors by U.S. and Producers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1A key executive of the world's largest oil company conceded under questioning by Senators today that mistakes by petroleum producers and the Government had contributed to the world energy crisis.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Announcements of deaths, may ?? telephoned to Oxford 53311 ?? 11 P.M. In Regional ?? 9:00 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Monday through Friday New Jersey (201) Market ?? Westchester Co. and Northorn New York State Counties (914) White Plains 95300; Nassau. Co. (516) 7470500; Suffolk Co. (516) 6691800; Connectticut (203) 3487767.

title: ASTRONAUTS FINISH LAST PHOTO SWEEP
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 1 (UPI)  With a final 8,500milelong photographic sweep of earth, the Skylab 3 astronauts brought to a close today one of man's most productive efforts to understand his planet.

title: Theory on Accountability Discussed by Richardson
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 1 (UPI) Former Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson said yesterday that President Nixon could be held accountable for the Watergate breakin and coverup even if he was not aware of them.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: Bangkok  Don Pisarnchai, Thailand, 115 pounds knocked out Ramon Ignacio, 116, Philippines, 3 rounds.

title: Insuring Health
description: President Nixon's proposal for a comprehensive health insurance program is the most concrete item in a 1974 agenda that abounds in vague pledges. In essence, the plan would require employers to pay 75 per cent of health insurance premium costs, with the employe adding the remaining 25 per cent. The Federal Government would pay the premiums of lowincome families. Although the level of benefits would be Governmentdirected, the protection would be left entirely in the hands of private insurance companies or health maintenance organizations.

title: Verdi's Heart Wasn't in It
description: As commonly titled, it is I Vespri Siciliani by Giuseppe Verdi. In English it is The Sicilian Vespers. In French, the language in which it was originally sung, it Vepres Siciliennes. On the title page of the first Italian edition it is Giovanna di Guzman. In Italy before the independence of 1861 it might have turned up as Giovanna di Braganza or Betilde di Turenna.

title: Trucker Protest Slowing Gasoline Deliveries Here
description: Thousands of motorists in the metropolitan area, their fuelgauge needles quivering dangerously close to E, were denied their first tankful of February's gasoline allotments yesterday by picketing independent truck drivers who were protesting the fuel squeeze on their industry.

title: Dow Stock Index Off 11.61; No Exchange Strike Seen
description: Gloomy economic and energy developments sent the stock market sharply lower yesterday in continued quiet trading.

title: 400 Picket to Protest a Possible Federal Rollback in Pay Raise for Policemen in Nassau
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 1 About 400 offduty policemen from the metropolitan area picketed in front of Village Hall here today to protest a possible rollback in the recent contract settlement between Nassau County and the 5,600member Nassau Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

title: Nation's Car Output In January Off 31% From Last Year
description: DETROIT, Feb. 1 (UPI)United States automakers, reacting to sharply dropping big car sales, reported today that auto production in January was 31 per cent below a year ago and the worst yearly start since 1970.

title: For Burma a Face Lift, For Rangoon a Concrete Bird
description: RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 22 For 12 years this country has been politically inert under a military regime that called itself revolutionary and socialist. Now, in, what for Burma amounts to a paroxysm of activity, the regime is giving itself a face of lift.

title: CONSUMERS POWER IN DOW SALES PACTS
description: The Consumers Power Company and the Dow Chemical Company reported yesterday agreements under which the chemical company will purchase process steam from the utility's Midland nuclear power plant and electric energy from its electric power network. The agreement calls for Dow to purchase process steam from the plant for 20 years after it starts operations. Separate contracts for the sale of electricity to Dow and supplies of water to Consumer Power were also executed.

title: Kissinger Expected to Talk to Gromyko on Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1Secretary of State Kissinger plans to assess Soviet reaction to the EgyptianIsraeli agreement on troop separation and to discuss the next phase in Middle East peace negotiations when he meets soon with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union, Administration officials said today.

title: South Korea Jails 2 for 15 Years For Criticizing the Constitution
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 1 A special emergency courtmartial at the South Korean Defense Ministry today sentenced two adversaries of the Government to 15 years in prison for criticizing the nation's Constitution in violation of presidential decree.

title: Wildcat Tin Strike Adds to Bolivia's Political Woes
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 1A new confrontation developed today in Bolivia's twoweekold political crisis when 4,800 tin miners announced a 48hour wildcat strike to protest food shortages and the economic policies of President Hugo Banzer Surez's Government.

title: South Africa Curbs Union Organizers
description: CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 1The South African Government today restricted for five years the freedom and rights of three white trade union officials involved in organizing black trade unions.

title: Bays of Tanzania sets World 1,500Meters Record
description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Saturday, Feb. 1 (UPI)Filbert Bays of Tanzania shattered the world record for 1,500 meters with a time of a 3 minutes 32.2 seconds today to win his country's first gold medal on the final day of the Commonwealth Games.

title: DR. LOUIS L. DIENES, BACTERIOLOGIST, 88
description: BOSTON, Feb. 1 (AP)Dr. Louis L. Dienes, who discovered in man the diseaseproducing Mycoplasma organism, died yesterday of complications from a heart attack and a stroke. His age was 88.

title: Man, 26, Accused of Rape And Ax Murder of Girl, 15
description: The police arrested a 26yearold man yesterday and charged him with the rape and ax murder of a 15yearold girl and the wounding of her 16yearold boy friend. The police said the youth remained in a serious condition from the ax wounds he received.

title: Memorial Services
description: WEINBERGRobert C. On Jan. 25, 1474. Memorial service will be Mid on Thursday, Feb. 14, at 4 P.M., at the Loeb Student Center, New York University, 566 LaGuardia Place (Washington So. South), Fifth Floor. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Memorial SloanKettering Hospital.

title: DHJ Industries Sets Swift Textiles Deal To Enter Denim Field
description: DHJ Industries, Inc., the nation's largest producer of interlining and interfacings for the apparel industry, is expanding into the indigo dyed denim field through the acquisition of Swift Textiles, Inc., for more than $10million cash. The announcement yesterday following approval by the boards of both companies.

title: Scott Won't Yield an Inch On Charge of Lie by Dean
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 1Senator Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania said today that he was not backtracking one single inch on his charge that John W. Dean 3d had lied about President Nixon's role in the Watergate coverup.

title: Yale Triumphs
description: HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 1 (AP)Tim Kearns scored 26 points and Jim Cartwell got 21 rebounds as Yale beat Dartmouth, 7363, tonight in college basketball.

title: Judge Asks Prosecution for Specifics in Trot Case
description: A Federal magistrate said yesterday he was amazed that 13 harness drivers accused Dec. 20 of fixing superfecta races still didn't know the specifics of the Government's charges.

title: Radio
description: 69 A.M., WQXR. Symphony No. 8, Beethoven; Cello Concerto in B flat, Boccherini; Hebrides Overture. Mendelssohn; Adagio for Clarinet and Strings, Wagner; Symphony No. 3 in E, Alfven; Overture to Cleopatra, Mancinelli; Symphonic Nocturne, Bristow; Piano Concerto No. 2 in A, Liszt.

title: Gasoline Prices Raised
description: Four more oil companies announced gasoline price increases today but a fifth said it was holding the price of gasoline and increasing the cost of diesel fuel and home heating oil only.

title: Bulls Hang On
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP) Jerry Sloan, hitting from long range, stemmed a final Kansas CityOmaha rally with four baskets in the final minute's tonight to send the Chicago Bulls to a 9988 triumph over the Kings.

title: SALES TOP EARNINGS FOR ONE TO HEAD PARTY PLAN ORGANIZATION MANHATTAN AREA
description: Major party plan jewelry company operating in 41 states now ready to establish here. Interviewing experienced party plan people for one to be selected to head Manhattan area. Act II officials include top direct selling management Ken Bird, Gary McDonald, Nat Tanenbaum, Charles McBurney, and Pat Russell Butterfield.

title: Schoolboy Killed in Dark
description: ATLANTA, Feb., 1 (UPI)An Eightyearold boy, Charles Gantt, was struck by a pickup truck and killed today while waiting for a school bus in predawn darkness. At almost the same time, Gov. Jimmy Carter sent a message to the Georgia General Assembly asking it to adopt a resolution calling on Congress to repeal winter daylight saving time.

title: Chesirnard Pregnancy Leads to Mistrial
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J. Feb. 11 A mistrial was declared today in the murder trial of Mrs. Joanne D. Chesimard because of the problems of her pregnancy and the possibility that she might suffer a miscarriage.

title: 5 in 1 Getting It All Together
description: Tony Rosenthal's sculpture Five in One, whose parts have been lying all over Police. Plaza since last September, is finally going up.

title: MENTAL HOSPITALS PACE SNIDER STUDY
description: ALBANY, Feb. 1The state's Department of Mental Hygiene, which has been looking into crime incidents at Creedmoor State Hospital in Queens, has extended the investigation to all 22 downstate facilities maintained by the department.

title: 170 Dead in Brazilian Office Fire
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Feb. 1Fire burned through the upper floors of a modern 25story bank building today and officials said that at least 170 people had died, many of them jumping out of windows in futile effort to escape the flames.

title: Printing Is Big in Israel
description: JERUSALEM (AP)  Israel's printing industry ranks third after Sweden and the Netherlands in the number of new books and editions republished, with 76 per 100,000 population yearly.

title: Aiding Trade
description: President Nixon has lost no time in letting Congress know that his Administration plans no retreat in its stand for reducing international trade barriers, and especially for opening American markets to imports from developing countries. He coupled this notice with a renewed call, to provide a fair American share of economic assistance for the world's needy, particularly under International Development Association programs.

title: Dance
