description: American Ballet Theater came up with a powerhouse of a new cast in Antony Tudor's Jardin aux Lilas on Thursday night at the City Center, when Cynthia Gregory, Martine van Hamel and Michael Denard joined Gayle Young for the first time in the leading roles.

title: Briefs on Energy
description: NEWARK, Feb. 1 (AP)William E. Ozzard, head of the State Public Utility Commission, has accused major oil companies of hitting New Jersey with a petroleum bomb to force state officials to approve offshore drilling or a deepwater oilport. In a letter to the Federal Energy Administrator, William E. Simon, Mr. Ozzard said the gasoline shortage in New Jersey appeared to be a deliberate attempt to bludgeon state officials. In an interview, Mr. Ozzard said he favored the oilport and offshore drilling, but only with state controls. In his letter, Mr. Ozzard complained about a lack of information available from oil companies. Information is given grudgingly, is somewhat inaccurate and often unobtainable, he said.

title: Pistons Beat Knicks, 9691, Despite DeBusschere Night
description: DETROIT, Feb. 1The Detroit Pistons gave Dave DeBusschere a night and DeBusschere, always a perfect gentleman, gave it back to them.

title: New Mexico Loses
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 1 (AP)New Mexico, ranked 17th nationally, continued its skid tonight as Larry Warren and Greg Grady, sophomores, and three freshmen led Florida State to a 9071 victory.

title: Squires Win, 111110
description: HAMPTON, Va., Feb. 1 (AP) George Gervin's field goal with four seconds remaining gave the Virginia Squires a 111110 victory over the Kentucky Colonels tonight.

title: Man's Mysterious Precursors
description: Discoveries in East Africa, gaining momentum for 15 years, are producing fragmentary scientific snapshots of precursors of man who very gradually improved their skills, between 3 million and one million years ago, at such manlike skills as hunting, toolmaking and foodsharing.

title: Miss Lende Wins Roch Cup Skiing
description: ASPEN, Colo., Feb. 1(UPI) Leithe Lende, the leader on the CanAm women's circui?? finished fifth in the downhill competition today and skid off with the women's title i the 28th annual Roch up competitionthe sixth on the 15stop circuit.

title: Noncombat Troops Denied Parachutists' Hazard Pay
description: WASHINGTON Feb 1 (UPI) The Army ended today a longstanding practice of giving hazardousduty pay to noncombat troops who made parachute jumps.

title: Percentage Gains
description: Stocks with the largest percentage gains on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: Northmen Pick Cahill
description: TORONTO, Feb. 1 (UPI)Leo Cahill, the former coach of the Toronto Argonauts of the Canadian Football League, was named general manager today of the Toronto entry in the new World Football League. John F. Bassett Jr., head of a group of Toronto businessmen behind the W.F.L. franchise here, said the team would be known as the Toronto Northmen. The Canadian grizzly will be its emblem.

title: Graebner in Semifinals
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 1 (AP)Jurgen Fassbender of West Germany and Clark Graebner of New York. reached the semifinals in the $20,000 Baltimore tournament today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 1 (UPI)  The Houston Rockets the National Basketball Association traded Jack Marin and Matt Guokas today for a 7foot rookie center, Kevin Kunnert, and a 62 thirdyear guard, Dave Wohl, of the Buffalo Braves, Marin, 29 years old, a 66 forward, came to the Rockets from Baltimore in 1972 in exchange for Elvin Hayes. Guokas, 29, was acquired by the Rockets from Kansas CityOmaha earlier this season.

title: Costa Ricans to Vote for President Tomorrow
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb, 1  Almost selfconsciously, slightly embarrassed by their status as one of Latin America's few remaining genuine democracies, 700,000 Costa Rican voters are preparing to pick the man who will govern them for the next four years.

title: In a Fuel Shortage, Things Stop Working  And So Do People
description: Paul Howard, neatly dressed in a plaid wool suit, was sitting in Area C of the huge office at 90th Street and Broadway, waiting for his name to be called.

title: Singapore Hits Snags in Deal With Guerrillas on Ferryboat
description: SINGAPORE, Feb. 1 (AP)Four seasick Japanese and Arab guerrillas began their second night aboard a hijacked ferryboat with three hostages today after the Singapore Government reported difficulties in arranging their transport out of the country.

title: A.M.C. TO INCREASE COMPACT OUTPUT
description: DETROIT, Feb. 1 (AP)The American Motors Corporation, announced today plans to add a second shift at its Lakefront plant in Kenosha, Wis., effective March 4.

title: New Protest Staged In Grenada Despite Drive on Subversion
description: ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada, Feb. 1 (Reuters) Antigovernment marchers staged a new demonstration through the streets of Grenada's capital today.

title: ATLANTIC STORE BID APPROVED BY F.T.C.
description: The Federal Trade Commission has approved an applicatin by the Arlen Realty and Development Corporation to reacquire control of Atlantic Department Stores, Inc. Arlen owns the E. J. Korvette Department store chain.

title: ComputerMemory Aid Devised
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Bell Telephone Laboratories received a patent this week for what it regards as a major advance in computer memoriesa device that efficiently and economically generates magnetic bubbles. Invisible except under a microscope, the bubbles act like bar magnets, and carry bits of information in manmade brains. Patent 3,789,375 was granted to Yussu S. Chen, Joseph E. Geusic, Terpnce J. Nelson and Herbert M. Shapiro of the plant at Murray Hill, N. J., for what is called a single wall domain nucleator.

title: ECONOMIC CLOUDS LIFTING IN EUROPE
description: PARIS, Feb. 1Europe's economic prospects look brighter than they did a few months ago because oil is now flowing more plentifully.

title: Nilsson and Vickers Cheered at Met
description: From an antilitter standpoint, It was deplorable. When Birgit Nilsson and Jon Vickers stepped out on the Metropolitan Opera stage for their solo bows after Wednesday night's performance of Tristan and Isolde, snowstorms of confetti greeted each in turn. But even the sternest ecologist in the audience might have agreed that there is a time for everything and that this was a time for confetti.

title: Tarnished Gym Revives Golden Dreams
description: The Solar Sporting Club occupies the fifthfloor loft of an old, gray building on Manhattan's West Side, and is serviced by a tired, rather decrepit elevator. When the lift does get a call for the Solar, it bumps to a halt before swinging its doors open to a large, plain training room.

title: The Other News
description: International

title: Potentially Excess Mileage On Railroads in State Is Cited
description: Onethird of the railway network in New York State is considered potentially excess mileage in the massive report on rail reorganization issued by the Department of Transportation in Washington yesterday.

title: JOSEPH M. SOVIERO, STATE JUSTICE, DIES
description: Justice Joseph M. Soviero of the State Supreme Court, Second Judicial District, covering Kings and Richmond Counties, died Thursday night of a heart ailment at his home, 76 Warwick Street, Brooklyn. His age was 66.

title: Bridge: Authorities Offer Remedies For a Standard 4321 Count
SUFFOLK COUNTY BUYS COLLEGE SITE
description: BRENTWOOD, L.I., Feb. 1Suffolk County today purchased 206 acres from the state to build a community college campus closer to the bulk of the population.

title: Art: American SelfPortraits
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1No exhibition devoted to 300 years of American art is likely to be selected on a strictly esthetic basis. Other interestsespecially documentary interestsinevitably play a role. Art and history are joined to illuminate the larger vicissitudes of American culture.

title: LATE JERSEY EDITION
description: General news, P. 33; sports, P. 21. ?? Cloudy and cold with rain likely today, tonight. Temp. range 2538. South: Cloudy and cold, rain likely today, tonight. Temp. range 2840. Additional details on Page 58.

title: MANSFIELD BARS WATERGATE'S END IN REPLY TO NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield, declared tonight that Congress and the courts must pursue their Watergate investigations in order to cleanse the political processes of the nation.

title: SILVER FUTURES RISE DAILY LIMIT
Wishful Economics
description: Like King Canute up to his ankles in the rising tide, President Nixon has proclaimed, There will be no recession in the United States of America. This is a nonsensical reassurance at a time when the economy already appears to have entered a recession. Unemployment, rising for three months, has just surged to 5.2 per cent.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a review yesterday in The New York Times of The Flowering of American Folk Art 17761876 at the Whitney Museum, the name of Alice Winchester was dropped. Miss Winchester was guest curator of the exhibition and coauthor of the catalogue.

title: Blind Patients See Dots of Light in Electrode Test
description: A team of researchers at the University of Utah and the University of Western Ontario have reported the successful stimulation of artificial sight in two blind patients, one of whom has seen nothing for 28 years.

title: RHEINGOLD PLANT GETS A REPRIEVE
description: A Federal judge last night temporarily extended the life of the famous Rheingold brewery in Brooklyn, where workers were sitting in to protest the planned permanent closing of the plant.

title: HalfHearted Reform
description: The leadership of New York's City Council fumbled an opportunity to make the Council a more respected and effective instrument of municipal government the other day when it rammed through a compliant Rules Committee a watereddown reform package that leaves glaring legislative deficiencies virtually untouched.

title: 43 Seized in and Near Vassar In Predawn Narcotics Raids
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Feb. 1About 150 policemen from four agencies staged predawn raids on homes and Vassar College dormitories today, and arrested 43 persons on narcotics charges, including one female and eight male students of the college.

title: MAN HELD IN DEATH UNDER AN IND TRAIN
description: A 50yearold man was killed last night when he was allegedly knocked in front of a subway train by another man who was later captured after chase by witnesses along the platform at 50th Street and the Avenue of the Americas.

title: '71 U.S. Subpoena Sought Phone Data On 2 Newspapers
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 1 (AP)Telephone records of the Washington bureaus of The St. Louis PostDispatch and the Knight Newspapers were secretly subpoended in 1971 by the Justice Department, The PostDispatch said today. The paper said that records for a home telephone for its chief correspondent had aslo been subpoenaed.

title: Rise of 100,000 Housing Units Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1The Nixon Administration plans to increase the number of subsidized housing units by 100,000 and to provide 52.8billion in the budget for the fiscal year 1975 to finance current community development projects while a new housing program is formulated and a community development bill clears Congress.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: Gas Lag Called Gateway Boon
description: The fuel shortage, which has dimmed the outlook for a lot of other enterprises, is brightening the future of the Gateway National Recreation Area.

title: Spurs Beaten By Nets
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 1 Although it wasn't one of his most scintillating performances from the floor, Julius Erving scored a gamehigh 29 points tonight to lead the New York Nets to a 95.91 victory over a tenacious San Antonio team at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Maura Hurley Is Bride in Virginia
description: FALLS CHURCH, Va., Feb. 1  Miss Maura Hurley and James Brackett, who are with the State Department's Agency for International Development, were married here this evening. The bride is chief of the Latin America Bureau's health, nutrition and population coordination division. The bridegroom is chief of the demographic and economic analysis division in the Bureau of Population and Humanitarian Affairs.

title: STOCKOPTION DEALS LINKED TO OUTLOOK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) Members of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today preliminary information suggested that buyers of stock options increased their activity as the chances of making a profit diminished.

title: Canadiens Lose, 53, To Flames
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 1 (AP)Bob Leiter scored two goals, one in the first and another in the third period, and the. Atlanta Flames defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 53, tonight in a National Hockey League game.

title: STOCKS ARE DOWN ON AMEX AND OTC
Text of the President's Annual Report to Congress on the State of the Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1Following is the text of President Nixon's Economic Report to Congress:

title: ARABS QUALIFYING SUPPORT OF SADAT
description: CAIRO, Feb. 1 President Anwar elSadat won support for his disengagement agreement with Israel from most of the other Arab leaders during his recent tour of their capitals, according to informed sources here, but there is a time limit on their commitment.

title: Lamar Barnes, Specialist In Corporate Law, 46, Dies
description: C. Lamar Barnes, a partner in the New York law firm of Wickes, Riddell, Bloomer, Jacobi & McGuire, died at Roosevelt Hospital on Wednesday after a brief illness. He was 46 years old and lived in this city.

title: MOTOR CARRIERS GET A 4% RISE IN RATES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP)  The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today numerous Eastern and middle Western iron and steel motor carriers to increase their rates by 4 per cent tomorrow in order to offset rising fuel costs.

title: BILL ON CHILD ABUSE IS SIGNED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) President Nixon signed today a $60million, threeyear measure establishing a national center to deal with child abuse and neglect.

title: NIXON PREDICTS SHARP INFLATION WITH LITTLE GROWTH IN ECONOMY; SEES BETTER TIMES LATER IN YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1President Nixon and his Council of Economic Advisers predicted today severe inflation in the months immediately ahead, with little or no economic growth, but foresaw better. times in the second half of the year.

title: AutoExhaust Tests Begin; Rejection Rate Up to 25%
description: LITTLE FERRY, Feb. 1The failure rate ranged from about 4 per cent to a high of 25 per cent today as the state's vehicle inspection stations became the first in the nation to begin a formal testing program for automobile air pollution flaws.

title: In Wales, Coal Dust Influences Union Vote
description: TONYREFAIL, Wales, Feb, 1Blackfaced and filthy with coal dust, nightshift workers climbed out of a rusty elevator atop the 840foot vertical shaft at the Coedely colliery here this morning and trudged through the rain to a drab meeting hall.

title: Two Pairs Of Athletes Lead Golf
description: LAS CROABAS, P. R., Feb. 1Merlin Olsen of the Los Angeles Rams and Jim Wynn of the Los Angeles Dodgers shared the first round lead in the $30,000 American Airlines golf classic with Jeff Burroughs of the Texas Rangers and Bob Anderson of the Denver Broncos today at E1 Conquistador Club. Each duo carded a net 57.

title: G.O.P. House Chief Backs Full Inquiry on Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1  An eventual vote on the impeachment of President Nixon was virtually assured today when the ranking Republican in the House of Representatives predicted strong minority support for a move to give the House Judiciary Committee full constitutional authority to pursue its inquiry.

title: Mosbacher Is Retained
description: ALBANY, Feb. 1 (UPI)Governor Wilson today reappointed Emil Mosbacher Jr. as chairman of the State Racing and Wagering Board for a term ending Feb. 1, 1980. Mosbacher's salary is $75,000 a year. The board was set up to supervise horse racing and other gambling activities throughout the state. Mosbacher's appointment requires Senate confirmation.

title: Pension Plan Improved
description: The United Steelworkers of America and the three major aluminum companies reached agreements yesterday that reduce the normal retirement age from 65 to 62 and provide costofliving supplements for workers who retire. Page 34.

title: Borg, Moore in Final
description: OSLO, Norway, Feb. 1 (AP)Bjorn Borg and Ray Moore moved into the men's final of the Scandinavian tournament today after Leslie Charles of Britain won the women's final with a 64, 64 triumph over Ellen Grindvoid of Norway.

title: COMPANY PROFITS SNOW A 25% RISE
description: United States corporations increased their aftertax profits in the fourth quarter of 1973 by an average of 25 per cent over the same period a year earlier, the First National City Bank reported yesterday. The increase was achieved, the bank noted, despite the energy crisis and signs of a possible recession.

title: 8 Witnesses Are Called By Montemarano Defense
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 1The murder trial of Dr. Vincent A. Montemarano started to wind down today when the defense began calling character witnesses.

title: ExNixon Aide: On Joining the Rebellion
description: BETHESDA, Md.Regrettably, after giving voice several years ago to America's silent majority on the issue of the Vietnam war, the Nixon White House has now undertaken to cow that majority back into silence by making them doubt their own decent instincts on an even more basic issue executive responsibility and the rule of law in our democracy.

title: 500 Germans, Own Colleges Full, Will Study in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 About 500 German students, perhaps the first of thousands, will enroll next year in American colleges, where there is ample room, to relieve overcrowding in German universities.

title: Dow Stock Index Off 11.61; No Exchange Strike Seen
description: A threatened strike by clerical employes and floor personnel at the New York Stock Exchange appears to have been averted.

title: Lawyers for Tramunti Impeach The Government's Key Witness
description: Defense lawyers attacked the credibility of a key witness yesterday at the narcotics trial of Carmine Tramunti, a reputed Mafia chief accused of financing a major heroin organization.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Bridge Across the Delaware Opens A highway cantilever bridge nearly four miles long and 43 stories high was opened yesterday across the Delaware River between Bridgeport, N. J., and Chester, Pa., ending 200 years of ferry service on the river. The five lane toll bridge is part of U.S. 322 between Harrisburg, Pa., and Atlantic City.

title: Pam Higgins Cards a 68 And Leads by 2 Shots
description: MIAMI, Feb. 1 (UPI)Pam Higgins shot a fiveunderpar 68 today and took a twoshot, firstround lead in the $35,000 Burdines tournament, the first event on the 1974 Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.

title: Syrians Report Ambush Foiled, 10 Israelis Slain
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 1 (UPI)A Syrian communiqu said that at least 10 Israelis were killed early today when they tried to ambush a Syrian force on the Golan Heights.

title: Scott, Howe Gain Court Tennis Final
description: Two amateur teams, Gene Scott and Ralph Howe of New York, and Jerry Bijur and E. Newbold Black 4th of Philadelphia, reached the final of the United States open court tennis doubles championship yesterday at the New. York Racquet and Tennis Club.

title: LEONARD LEVINSON, RADIO WRITER, DIES
description: Leonard L. Levinson, radio writer and author, died Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 69 years old and Jived in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: BEAMS ASSAILED ON HIRING WOMEN
description: The Beame administration was taken to task yesterday for not appointing more women to top city positions by a coalition of 15 women led by Representative Bella S. Abzug.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: Page

title: Federal Raises Deemed Not a Violation of Controls
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) The director of the Civil Service Commission says proposed pay rise for top Federal officials does not violate Federal wage controls.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
Phnom Penh and Its Airport Hit By 100Round Artillery Attack
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Saturday, Feb. 2 (UPI)Insurgent forces bombarded Phnom Penh and its suburbs with more than 100 rounds of artillery before dawn today in one of the heaviest attacks of the almost fouryearold Cambodian war.

title: Opera: Vespri Siciliani
Arbitration Ordered in Postal Workers Dispute
description: NEWARK, Feb. 1A Federal Judge ordered the Metro Area. Postal Union today to take its objections on a management plan to alter workshift starting times at the giant New York Bulk and Foreign Mail facility in Jersey City to formal arbitration.

title: BRINEGAR BACKS NEW RAIL PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Facing an almost certain barrage of regional resistance, the Department of Transportation insisted today that its plan to abandon 25 per cent of railroad trackage in the Northeast and Midwest would not impair passenger service.

title: Helen Gourlay Proves a Point
description: Continued From Page 19 me a long time to adjust to playing outside one week and inside the next. (The first women's tourney, was indoors, last week's was outdoors.)

title: Nastue Wins a Quickie
description: Topseeded Ilia Nastase of Rumania and secondranked Tom Gorman of Seattle led an advance tonight by three of the four favorites into the semifinals of the World Championship Tennis event here.

title: Man Held in Brazil In 1963 Robbery On a British Train
description: LONDON, Feb. 1  Scotland Yard announced tonight that Ronald A. Biggs, the last of the Great Train Robbery gang still free, was arrested today in a hotel in Rio de Janeiro.

title: CHARLES M. STONE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Charles M. Stone, coordinator of station services for the National Association of Broadcasters, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 59 years old.

title: ARABS QUALIFYING SUPPORT OF SADAT
description: CAIRO, Feb. 1 President Anwar elSadat won support for his disengagement agree rent with Israel from most of the other Arab leaders during his recent tour of their capitals, according to informed sources here, but there is a time limit on their commitment.

title: JAMES THOMPSON
description: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Feb. 1James MacNaughton Thompson, who retired as a vice president of personnel for the First National City Bank in New York in 1965, died today at Webber Hospital in Biddeford after a short illness. His age was 66 and he lived here.

title: KARPOV IS NEARING CHESS SEMIFINALS
description: Anatoly Karpov, the 22yearold Soviet grandmaster who the Russians expect to be the next world champion, came close yesterday to moving into, the semifinals of the world chess tournament to pick a challenger to the world champion, Bobby Fischer, of the United States.

title: On Fuel Shortages and Damages to Regions
description: PHILADELPHIAWhether the energy crisis proves a real threat or simply an exaggerated alarm sounded by the oil interests, it will nevertheless have pointed up a basic need for strong national policy to regulate and allocate energy production. And for any policy to be effective, it must take account of regional variations both in energy requirements and supply capabilities.

title: 500 Germans, Own Colleges Full, Will Study in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1About 500 German students, perhaps the first of thousands, will enroll next year in American colleges, where there is ample room, to relieve overcrowding in German universities.

title: Spurs Sue Squires; Claim Sale of Gervin
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 1 (AP)The San Antonio Spurs of the American Basketball Association filed suit today in Federal court against the Virginia Squires, charging breach of contract and seeking surrender of Virginia's al star forward, George Gervin.

title: Judge Rules Husband Can't Block Abortion
description: DECATUR, Ill., Feb. (UPI) In a precedentsetting ruling, Circuit Court Judge Joseph Munch ruled yesterday that a husband had no legal right to prevent his wife from having an abortion.

title: GLENN MORRIS, 62, TRACK STAR, DEAD
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Feb. 1 (AP)Glenn Morris, 1936 Olympic decathlon champion and a former movie Tarzan, died yesterday after a long illness. His age was 62.

title: Appeals in Hackensack
description: TRENTON, Feb. 1  State Supreme Court Chief Justive Richard J. Hughes announced today that oral arguments of appeals before the Appellate Division of Superior Court will also be heard now in Hackensack as well as Newark and Trenton. Mr. Hughes made the announcement with Milton B. Conford, presiding judge of the Appellate Division, the second highest state court.

title: Oslo Convicts 5 for Involvement In Killing Tied to Mideast Spies
description: OSLO, Norway, Feb. 1 (AP) Three persons were found guilty today of having helped murder a Moroccan in the international war between Arab and Israeli agents.

title: I Utility Denied Increases
description: ALBANY, Feb. 1 The State Public Service Commission denied today a request by New York State Electric and Gas Corporation for interim electric rate increases totaling $13.2million and gas rate increases of $1.8million. The utility is seeking permanent annual increases of 14.56 per cent in electric rates totaling $26million and 7.7 per cent in gas rates, totalling $4.2million. The utility serves 573,000 electric and 124,000 gas customers in upstate New York.

title: U. S. POLICY SHIFT ON TRADE MAPPED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1The United States declared today its intention of seeking new international rules on access to supplies, to go with the more traditional rules on access to markets, in the forthcoming international trade negotiations.

title: Youth Survives Span Leap
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. (UPI)John W. Adams, 21 years old, walked around only dazed today after jumping from the Golden Gate Bridge and landing on an embankment 190 feet below. The Stanford University student was hospitalized after the incident last night but did not suffer serious injury. The Highway Patrol said Mr. Adams was believed to have hit an embankment near a bridge tower and slid down to the rocks below.

title: California Official Rules Nixons Nonresidents for Tax Purposes
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 1 President and Mrs. Nixon are lot California residents for state income tax purposes, Martin Huff, executive officer of the Franchise Tax Board, ruled today.

title: Alberta OilGas Revenue Up
description: EDMONTON, Alberto, Feb. (Canadian Press)The Alberta Government's revenue from its oil and natural gas rights totaled $123.9million in the fourth quarter of 1973 compared with $78.3million in the same period of 1972, it was announced today.

title: Gas Lag Seen as Boon to Gateway
description: The fuel shortage, which has dimmed the outlook for a lot of other enterprises, is brightening the future of the Gateway National Recreation Area.

title: SHOP TALK
description: For a working girl or student with a practically nonexistent clothes allowance, the solution has long been to save nickels and dimes to buy a quality pair of shoes or a wellmade pair of pants that will last long enough to offset the cost.

title: Robert Weinberg Service
description: A memorial service for Robert C. Weinberg, architect, regional planner and consultant, will be held at the Loeb Student Center of New York University, 566 LaGuardia Place (Washington Square South), Thursday, Feb. 14, at 4 P.M. Mr. Weinberg died Jan. 25 at the age of 72.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 2.4 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 217.5 from 215.1 last week.

title: Dance: Ballet Theater
description: It is a continual problem to maintain ballets in repertory with the style, and sometimes even the content, they originally possessed. Style, ambiance and those special grace notes of atmosphere, these can prove evanescent. I was thinking of this problem last night at the City Center, 55th Street Theater, where the American Ballet Theater is approaching the finale of their current New York season, which ends tomorrow night.

title: Economic Analysis Group Wants Plan Used Abroad
description: The National Bureau of Economic Research, the developer and champion of hundreds of domestic economic indicators, is attempting to spread its method of forecasting and analysis around the globe. By this summer, the bureau hopes to develop a set of 26 comparable economic indicators in eight major industrialized countries.

title: Brazil as a Coffee Importer?
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The news came as a national shock. Brazil, the world's foremost coffee producer, announced she would be importing coffee in substantial quantities in 1974.

title: DR. JOHN L. SENGSTACK
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., Feb. 1 Dr. John Louis Sengstack, chief of staff of the Huntington Hospital from 1955 to 1970, died Tuesday at his home on Greenlawn Road. He was 79 years old.

title: RHEINGOLD PLANT GETS A REPRIEVE
description: A Federal judge last night temporarily extended the life of the famous Rheingold brewery in Brooklyn, where workers were sitting in to protest the planned permanent closing of the plant.

title: Include GoldwynIn
description: In a long lifetime in Hollywood, Samuel Goldwyn produced films that met his own standard of what motion picture theater should be: A place where everybody can go and not blush over what they see on the screen. But this onetime glovemaker from Poland was more than a popular moviemaker. He was an independent long before the breakup of major studios and their chains. He was among the first advocates of the primacy of writers, of putting classics on film, of transferring Broadway hits to Hollywood cameras.

title: BRANCH DISPOSAL SET BY DUPONT WALSTON
description: DuPont Walston, Inc., which decided Jan. 21 to get out of the brokerage business as its losses continued to mount, said here yesterday that to date it had oral agreements with 22 brokerage firms to take over 114 of its 138 domestic branches.

title: Dublin's Leaders Fly Secretly To Ulster to Discuss New Links
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 1 Liam Cosgrave, Prime Minister of the Irish Republic, flew here secretly today by helicopter with seven of his Cabinet ministers for talks on establishing formal links, between Northern Ireland and the Republic.

title: Circumnavigation
description: The sorriest way to shore up decentralized government is to make endruns to Albany or Washington to reverse decisions made by New York City's elected officials on purely municipal matters. That discredited device has now been used by Representative Bella Abzug of Manhattan's West Side to show that her heart is with neighborhood groups opposed to construction of a $200million convention center on Hudson River piers off West 48th Street.

title: Socrates, Jesus and Nixon: Readers' Views
description: In an article on the OpEd Page on Jan. 16, Evan G. Koons, principal of Exeter Junior High School in Reading, Pa., likened Richard M. Nixon's situation to the fates of Jesus and Socrates. His views drew a number of litters, some of which are excerpted here.

title: Trucker Protest Slowing Gasoline Deliveries Here
description: DETROIT, Feb. 1The spreading fuel protest by independent truckers was seriously disrupting the shipment of fruit, produce, meat and steel today, forcing some distributors and plants to close and threatening others with shutdowns next week.

title: Mrs. Chesimard Wins Mistrial; Pregnancy Complications Cited
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J. Feb. 1 A mistrial was declared today in the murder trial of Mrs. Joanne D. Chesimard because of the problems of her pregnancy and the possibility that she might suffer a miscarriage.

title: Hanoi Unable to Cut Road
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb, 1 (AP)  Military sources reported today that North Vietnamese troops had tried unsuccessfully to cut the only supply road to 5,000 Government soldiers in the Gia NghiaDak Song region in the lower Central Highlands. It was the first serious fighting in that area since December.

title: Oil Price Rollback Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP)The head of The Union Oil Company, the country's 12th largest oil concern, urged Congress today to order a rollback in the price of oil.

title: Court Attendant, 54, Is Slain in Her Home
description: WATERFORD TOWNSHIP, Feb. 1A 54yearold woman was shot and killed in her rural farmhouse here last night. She was gunned down by shotgun blast that ripped through a living room window just after she had been called to the telephone by her 8yearold son.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Senate

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MOORE THE MERRIER Grace Moore, the singer who started a generation of operatic talent beating a path to the movies, is the current star at Theater 80 Saint Marks, at 80 St. Marks Place (24474001), the house that specializes in old musicals. Miss Moore is appearing, tomorrow through Tuesday, in two moving pictures not seen around very much lately.

title: People and Business Security Analysts Give Award
description: Edward R. Holt, a veteran security analyst and former partner of Newburger, Loeb & Co., was presented yesterday with the first Ralph A. Rotnem Award for his contributions to security analysis.

title: Britain Cuts Lending Rate
description: LONDON, Feb. 1 (Reuters)The Bank of England today lowered its minimum lending rate to 12 per cent from 12 per cent.

title: BRONX LANDLORDS END LABOR PACTS
description: Landlords of an estimated 750,000 Bronx residents have voted to cancel their contracts with superintendents and other apartmenthouse workers, it was announced yesterday, and the result could be a strike by the employes as early as Feb. 12.

title: Two Escape Plane Crash
description: GEORGE AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Feb. 1 (UPI)An F4E Phantom jet piloted by a German Air Force student crashed while on a training flight today but the two men aboard the craft parachuted to safety.

title: The State of the Real Union
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1State of the Union speech composed while waiting in a gasoline line:

title: 170 Dead in Brazilian Office Fire
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Feb. 1Fire burned through the upper floors of a modern 25story bank building today and officials said that at least 170 people had died, many of them jumping out of windows in futile effort to escape the flames.

title: Europe's 9 Looking Hard at Their Crisis
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 1A, habit has developed here at the headquarters of the European Economic Community of shouting crisis! as often as the shepherd cried wolf! But suddenly, the international staff of Eurocrats has come to remember that the wolf in the fable did appear and gobble the flock when no one bothered to listen any more.

title: TV Review
description: An excellent, provocative onehour television documentary titled Gold on Blue pays tribute to the New York City Police Department and courage in line of duty. Scheduled for airing tomorrow at 9 P.M. over WNEW/Channel 5, this is the station's third such program, pegged to the annual Medal of Honor award ceremonies and recreating cases of heroism in candid interviews of policemen and their families.

title: Sawhill Doubtful on Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) Deputy energy director John C. Sawhill said today that the nation cannot break the back of the energy crisis this year a hope voiced by President Nixonand urged consumers not to buy gasoline until their tanks were half empty.

title: HUNTLIDDY TAPING OF NIXON IS HINTED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1, (ReutersThe Columbia Broadcasting System said tonight that investigations were under way to confirm that tape recordings had been made of conversations between the Watergate burglars and high White House officials, including President Nixon.

title: SOVIET AIDE WARNS TROOPS ON LAXNESS
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 1The chief political commissar of the Soviet armed forces has told Soviet troops in East Germany that accommodation with the West must not give birth to elements of pacifism, compla cency and class vegetarianism within Soviet military ranks.

title: Wilson Finds Encouragement In Nixon's MassTransit Plan
description: Governor Wilson said yesterday that despite pessimism by others, he was optimistic about President Nixon's discussion of mass transportation in his recent State of the Union message.

title: Gottfried Moves On
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 1 (AP) Brian Gottfried of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Raul Ramirez of Mexico advanced to the semifinals of the Dayton pro tournament today by defeating Australians.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Budget Hearings to Be Held At Sites in All Five Boroughs
description: The city decided yesterday to shift hearings on the Mayor's proposed capital budget from City Hall to sites throughout the five boroughs.

title: MASS MURDER TRIAL IN TEXAS IS SHIFTED
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 1 (UPI)A state Judge today ordered the mass murder trial of Elmer Wayne Henley moved to San Antonio because of pretrial publicity in the Houston area.

title: Israel, Used to Surviving Brief Crises, Must Now Face LongTerm Challenges
description: TEL AVIVQuietly, but with great intensity, Israeli Govern. ment and military officials, leaders of the economy and university scholars are debating an issue raised by the October war: How can Israel mobilize for longlasting crises without crippling the life of the country?

title: Business Briefs
description: Construction Gains Offset by Inflation

title: People in Sports: Bids to Coach In W.F.L. Weighed by Morrall
description: Earl Morrall, who has spent 18 seasons in half a dozen National Football League uniforms, may turn to coaching in the new World Football League next season.

title: Nicklaus Paces Hawaiian Golf by 4 Strokes on 132
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 1 (AP) Jack Nicklaus, dead  serious amidst this city's holiday atmosphere, carded a fiveunderpar 67 today on top of his opening 65 and pulled away to a fourstroke lead in the $220,000 Hawaiian open golf tournament. His total was 132 for 36 holes.

title: MORRIS KANTOR, ARTIST, 77, DEAD
description: Morris Kantor, an artist and leading teacher of painting in New York, died Thursday night In Nyack Hospital following a long illness. Mr. Kantor, who lived at 45 South Mountain Road in New City, was 77 years,old.

title: CITY IS SWITCHING ITS GAS SUPPLIER
description: Under a new Federal energy regulation, the city was forced yesterday to switch gasoline suppliers. But the official responsible for acquiring the 25 million gallons, used by municipal agencies annually said he had no idea, Why the switch was being Made nor what the new supplier's price would be.

title: Scott Won't Yield an Inch On Charge of Lie by Dean
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1Senator Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania said today that he was not backtracking one single inch on his charge that John W..Dean 3d had lied about President Nixon's role in the Watergate coverup.

title: Graebner in Semifinals
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 1 (AP) Jurgen Fassbender of West Germany and Clark Graebner of New York reached the semifinals in the $20,000 Baltimore tournament today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 1 (UPI)  The Houston Rockets the National Basketball Association traded Jack Marin and Matt Guokas today for a 7foot rookie center, Kevin Kunnert, and a 62 thirdyear guard, Dave Wohl, of the Buffalo Braves. Marin, 29 years old, a 66 forward, came the Rockets from Baltimore in 1972 in exchange for Elvin Hayes. Guokas, 29, was acquired by the Rockets from Kansas CityOmaha earlier this season.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Shortly before James (Fly) Williams was to leave his dormitory room at Austin Peay University for last Monday Might's game with Western Kentucky, his phone rang. When he answered, he recognized the voice of Brenda Walker, his girl friend in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn where he grew up.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 2, 1974

title: Silvercup Sues to Bar Rumors by Competitors
description: Silvercup Bakers, Inc., accused yesterday the Continental Baking Company and the American Bakeries Company, two of its competitors, of spreading false rumors that it was in financial distress and going out of business.

title: More Retailers Exempted From PriceWage Curbs
description: The Cost of Living Council yesterday exempted from price and wage curbs all retailers that were still under controls except those that sell food, motor vehicles and parts and petroleum products.

title: Court Bars Tax Deduction For Child in Private School
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1 (AP)A California law allowing persons to deduct $125 from state income tax returns for each child attending private schools was declared unconstitutional today by a Federal court.

title: A.B.C. News CloseUp to Take A Look at TV Next September
description: Television, and all that it is criticized forsex, violence, hucksterism, the values it promotes and its treatment of children, for examplewill be the subject of a forthcoming A.B.C. News CloseUp documentary, in what appears to be a good mood of selfexamination at the networks.

title: Ski Flying Event Paced by Martin
description: IRONWOOD, Mich., Feb. 1 (AP)Jerry Martin launched a successful defense of his Ski Flying classic crown with jumps of 453 and 443 feet in the opening round today at Copper Peak.

title: Two Pairs Of Athletes Lead Golf
description: LAS CROABAS, P. R., Feb. 1Merlin Olsen of the Los Angeles Rams and Jim Wynn of the Los Angeles Dodgers shared the first round lead in the $30,000 American Airlines golf classic with Jeff Burroughs of the Texas Rangers and Bob Anderson of the Denver Broncos today at El Conquistador Club. Each duo carded a net 57.

title: Antiques: The Mysteries of Art Deco
description: Art deco is still a jigsaw puzzle, the pieces of which are being fitted together at a far slower pace than the public acceptance of this style.

title: Bracelet With a Cause
description: A $3 bracelet with the initials E.R.A. and a nickel silver finish that doesn't give the wearer a green wrist is proving to be a best seller among the nation's feminists.

title: Excerpts From Mansfield Response to State of Union Address
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1Following are excerpts from the remarks of Mike Mansfield, the Senate Democratic leader, delivered tonight in a nationally televised response to President Nixon's State of the Union Message:

title: Rabbi Daniel L. Davis, 70, Dies; Led Reform Synagogue Group
description: Rabbi Daniel L. Davis, former director of the New York Federation of Reform Synagogues, died Thursday at his home in Ghent, N.Y. His age was 70.

title: Woods Puts Shot 704, Indoor Mark
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1 Worldclass athletes in a dozen events took part tonight in the 11th annual San Francisco Examiner Games at the Cow Palace, with a field of five sub4minute milers entered in the final event of the program.

title: Pension Plan Improved
description: The United Steelworkers of America and the three major aluminum companies reached agreements yesterday that reduce the normal retirement age from 65 to 62 and provide costofliving supplements for workers who retire. Page 34.

title: Campus Notes Students See a Shift From Drugs to Drink
description: Some college students see shift nowadays from soft drugs, like marijuana, to aldohol. The change, they say, is occurring at the same time liberalized administrative polidles' make alcoholic beverages easier to obtain on campus.

title: Trucker Protest Slowing Gasoline Deliveries Here
description: DETROIT, Feb. 1The spreading fuel protest by independent truckers was seriously disrupting the shipment of fruit, produce, meat and steel today, forcing some distributors and plants to close and threatening others with shutdowns next week.

title: JEFFERSON EHRLICH
description: Jefferson Ehrlich, a consulting patent attorney with Standard, Inc., formerly with the American Telephone & Telegraph Company, died Thursday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Canada OilExport Cuts Seen
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Donald S. MacDonald, Canada's Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources, predicted today that Canada would reduce its exports of crude oil to the United States in the next two years and prohibit massive American investment to extract oil from the tar sands of Alberta.

title: Market Place: Capital Gains: Honing the Ax
description: Investors have made many futile attempts in the past to get Congress to reduce capital gains taxes.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: State Fish and Game officials have asked six research laboratories to determine what has caused cataracts more than 200,000 fish at the state's fish hatchery Hackettstown. The epidemic led to the destruction 175,000 yearling brown trout in the last two weeks the Charles O. Hayford State Fish Hatchery. The fish represent onethird of the total the hatchery raises annually to stock New Jersey waterways.

title: New Security Steps Taken After Thefts From College
description: In a recent 60day period at Bronx Community College, City Controller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday, the following items were stolen:

title: Notes on People
description: Vice President Ford, who has been criticized by commentators for seeking help from White House speechwriters, has hired a speechwriter of his own, Milton Friedman, a former Washington newsman who served briefly in 1972 as press secretary to Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York.

title: State Unit Proposes Regulations To Bar Residences in Flood plain
description: TRENTON, Feb. 1The State Department of Environmental Protection announced today regulations governing the protection, use and development of land along the state's floodprone river basins that include a ban on construction of any residence in the so  called floodways area.

title: BridgeportChester Bridge Opens, Replacing Ferry
description: BRIDGEPORT, Feb. 1  The nation's largest cantilever bridge, 43 stories high and nearly four miles long, opened today between here and Chester, Pa., ending 200 years of ferry service on the Delaware River.

title: Books of The Times
description: COLLECTED POEMS. By Paul Goodman. 465 pages. Random House. $12.95.

title: Reginald Berkowitz Dies; Builder at Canaveral, 75
description: COCOA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 1 Reginald Berkowitz, a retired builder, died yesterday from the effects of a stroke he suffered last June. He was 75 years old and lived here.

title: Pompidou: I AngloSaxons
description: PARISGeneral de Gaulle, with the suspicion of a haughty sniff, used to refer to les AngloSaxons when talking of England and America. However, his successor, President Pompidou, does not favor that generic term and avoids asperity when mentioning, the Englishspeaking nations. Indeed, although there are evident policy differences between Paris and Washington, and others, less visible, with London, these disagreements are faced on the basis of courteous friendship.

title: State's Potential in Raising Of Beef Is Termed Major
description: ALBANY  A picture of New York State as a potential major beefproducing area has been outlined by farm experts of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets here and at the College of Agriculture and Life Sciences at Cornell University.

title: MSGR. J. D. OSTERMANN
description: Msgr. Joseph D. Ostermann, pastor emeritus of St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church, Kingston, N. Y., died Tuesday at the Frances Schervier Home, Riverdale. His age was 79.

title: Helen Gourlay Proves a Point in 3 Sets
description: FAIRFAX, Va., Feb. 1Can a 24yearold baseline tennis player from Detroit, having missed a year to have her baby, beat a 27yearold Australian who is trying to come back after 10 months and an operation for a pinched nerve in her elbow?

title: NIXON PREDICTS SHARP INFLATION WITH LITTLE GROWTH IN ECONOMY; SEES BETTER TIMES LATER IN YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1President Nixon and his Council of Economic Advisers predicted today severe inflation in the months immediately ahead, with little or no economic growth, but foresaw better times in the second half of the year.

description: ORANGE, Jan. 28It's all in the family so far as the basketball coaching jobs are concerned at Our Lady of the Valley High School.

description: Le Chambertin, a restaurant with one of the more interesting cellars in the city, is about to offer an adventure for experienced wine buffs.

title: Prints of 20thCentury Latin America
description: The exhibition Latin American Prints From the Museum of Modern Art, currently on view at the Center for InterAmerican Relations, 680 Park Avenue at 68th Street, is more than a goodwill gesture toward what are traditionally referred to as our good neighbors to the south. Comprising some 100 graphic works on loan from the Modern's extensive holdings of pints, the show is a surprisingly broad and diverse survey of the graphic styles of LatinAmerican artists from the beginning of the century to the present.

description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 1  Following are excerpts from a declaration on the state of the Common Market, as issued in English by the Commission of the European Economic Community:

title: Trucker Protest Slowing Gasoline Deliveries Here
description: Thousands of motorists in the metropolitan area, their fuelgauge needles quivering dangerously close to E, were denied their first tankful of February's gasoline allotments yesterday by picketing independent truck drivers who were protesting the fuel squeeze on their industry.

title: Concert
description: When a piece of music happens to interest Pierre Boulez enough to engage his attention fully, the New York Philharmonic's musical director can inject his own brand of excitement into a concert. When he is less than absorbed, the result can be nebulous and ultimately unsatisfying, in spite of the polish and intellectual penetration that he achieves in almost any performance.

title: Ceeltics  Win by Point
description: HERSHEY, Pa., Feb. 1 (AP) John Havlicek scored 24 of his gamehigh 30 points in the second half tonight and the Boston Celtics beat Philadelphia 76ers, 106105, scoring their 19th consecutive victory over the 76ers in NBA action.

description: PARIS, Feb. 1Europe's economic prospects look brighter than they did a few months ago because oil is now flowing more plentifully.

description: This analysis is based on reports obtained from more than 250 bookstores in 110 communities of the United States. The figures in the righthand column do not necessarily represent consecutive appearances.

title: School Election May Divide Lakewood
description: LAKEWOODA progressive, but controversial, superintendent of schools and a bitter schoolbusing controversy are becoming the sole issues in a Board of Education election that may racially polarize this community. The election is scheduled for Feb. 13.

title: Aluminum Workers Reach Accord With 3 Companies
description: The Aluminum Workers International Union and the three major aluminum companies agreed yesterday on 40month contract agreements similar to ones worked out the day before between the companies and the United Steel Workers of America.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Workers Fight in Madrid
description: MADRID, Feb. 2 (AP)The police were called today to break up fistfights between about 4,000 workers at the Standard Electric plant here. Large groups of workers for or against a strike clashesd in the plant, which was closed until further notice.

title: Nixon Drives to Maryland For Weekend With Family
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., Feb. (AP)  President Nixon drove to his Camp David retreat in the Maryland mountains today to spend the weekend with his family, the White House reported.

title: Sackcloth Season for 2 Big Apparel Makers
description: Jonathan Logan, Inc., New York, and Levi Strauss & Co San Francisco, are a continent apart geographically and maybe even more so in style. But these companies, among the biggest in the nation's apparel industry, do have something in common  and they are not happy about it.

title: G. O. P. Is Facing the Loss of One to 3 Congressional Seats
description: TRENTON  Crippled by the political implications of the Watergate scandal and badly split by Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr.'s conservative campaign for Governor last year, New Jersey Republicans are looking toward this year's Congressional elections, with increasing concern and mounting trepidation.

title: Movies
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. IN awarding The Exorcist an R rating, the Motion Picture Association of America's Review Board could only have been rewarding Warner Brothers for forking out some $10million on the film, when its original budget was reportedly only $4million. However, by permitting children under 17 to attend the film when accompanied by adultsas required by the R rating the board certainly wasn't thinking about the youngsters and the possibility of traumatic damage to them from the movie's unremitting and violent assault upon the emotions.

title: Drag Racing: Overwhelming Assault on the Senses
description: POMONA, Calif., Feb. 2Watching a drag race is a brief but sensuous experience.

title: Cubans in Puerto Rico Discover Both Warmth and Resentment
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 2Last Sunday night, about 700 Cuban exiles attended a banquit here to commemorate the birthday of Jose Marti, Cuba's foremost national hero.

title: DISPUTE STILL SHUTS LUTHERAN SEMINARY
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 2Amid bitter recrimination and partisan churchwide crusading, Concordia Seminary of St. Louis remains closed in a theological standoff between conservatives and moderates in the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod.

title: PETTY APARTHEID IS BEING REDUCED
description: CAPETOWN, Feb. 2  The Johannesburg City Council has announced extensive measures to eliminate petty apartheid, or racial discrimination not imposed by national law.

title: Sandler Is Publisher of Race Daily
description: Triangle Publications, Inc., announced yesterday the appointment of Michael Sandler as publisher of Daily Racing Form.

title: Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: The Region In Summary
description: The segregated schools of northern cities, unlike those of the pre1954 south, are produced by social practice rather than laws, particularly by segregated housing. Last week a Federal judge in Brooklyn decided that the only way to undo the segregation in one junior high school was to reshape the housing practicesand a number of other municipal activities as wellthat in his view made the segregation inevitable.

title: Shecky 2d In Upset at Gulfstream
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., Feb. 2For the second straight time, Shecky Greene went down to a stunning defeat at Gulfstream Park as Cheriepe outfinished him in the $35,000 added Spring Championship Handicap today.

title: State Study Warns Of Wide Drug Use
description: TRENTONProponents of stricter controls over the distribution of amphetamines and barbiturates have received new evidence of widespread abuse among users of the drugs.

title: Dave Anderson Arum and Ali
description: By its nature, boxing does not attract divinity students or ethics professors to manipulate the gladiators. With its big money, and even with its small money, boxing appeals mostly to hustlers and schemers. To them, a conflict of interest is almost a commandment:

title: AGENCY IS CRITICAL OF PENN CENTRAL
description: The Tristate Regional Planning Commission, in a report to the Federal Government on combating the rail freight service crisis in the Northeast, sharply criticizes the Penn Central and its maintenance of a major route across the Hudson.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Miss Hirshberg to Wed
description: PATERSON, N. J., Feb. 2 Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hirshberg have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diana Hirshberg, to Bruce Ackerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Ackerman of New York. Miss Hirshberg and her fianc are students at the University of Maryland.

title: ARTILLERY KILLS 15 IN PHNOM PENH
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 2insurgent troops resumed their shelling of this densely populated city and its environs today, killing 15 civilfens and wounding 71.

title: Miss Carolyn Schaperkotter Betrothed to A. Ross Wollen
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., Feb. 2Miss Carolyn Schaperkotter plans to be married on May 26 to A. Ross Wollen, an alumnus of the University of Virginia Law School, from which the future bride will graduate the following day. The ceremony will be in the university chapel in Charlottesville.

title: Perth Amboy Gets A Bilingual Center
description: PERTH AMBOYA bilingual center for Spanishspeaking adults will be opened here tomorrow by Middlesex County College.

title: News of the Stage
description: It's been a long time since winsome, blond teenage singer made her screen debut in the Charles R. Rogers film Song of the Open Road. But now, 30 years later, after 20 movies and stints that included skipping nimbly across the screen with Fred Astaire, Jane Powell is making her Broadway stage debut.

title: A Slave Dancer Born in Brooklyn
description: When she was 7 years old, Paula Fox wrote her first story, a tale so bloody that its horrified author resurrected all the corpses at the end. Now 50, Miss Fox has just won the coveted Newbery Medal for children's literature for The Slave Dancer, a novel dealing with the horror of the slave trade.

title: Speedway Lures Fans With Computerized Car Pool
description: The possible benefits are staggering: meaningful relationships with persons sharing a common interest, helping the economy, romance, saving gasoline. What will Yankee ingenuity think of next?

title: A restless yawing between extremes
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif. With the weathered grayness of an Eastern college town in winter, the pinched and unfashionable block runs into the glare of the Pacific Ocean on the line between Santa Monica and Los Angeles. One colorless twofamily Cape Cod house has no names on the chilly porch's two saltcorroded mailboxes. The upstairs couple are Jane Fonda and her husband of just over a year, radical leader Tom Hayden. Driving a dented station wagon which is often loaned to fellow workers at the Indochina Peace Campaign offices three doors down the street, Jane brings 5yearold Vanessa, her daughter by French film director Roger Vadim, home from her experimental public kindergarten. Trailing the vibrant child to the porch, the tall, lithe actress, wearing a suburban paisleyprint blouse and black slacks, moves with a tensed grace despite the two heavy bags of groceries in her arms. She enters the apartment of the friendly young couple downstairs and turns on a small television set. Oh, boy, a cartoon! Vanessa squeals. Wow, Jane says, grinning. She leaves the girl there and unlocks the door to her own steep, redpainted stairway, leaving the door open for fresh air despite the death threats she's received in recent months from people who didn't like her calling some returned American P.O.W.'s hypocrites, liars and war criminals.

title: Red Army's Soccer Team To Face American Sides
description: Moscow's Red Army team will arrive tonight from the Soviet Union to play three games indoors. The first game will be held in Toronto Thursday night against the North American Soccer League AllStars, with the second game in Philadelphia next Monday night (Feb. 11) and the last game in St. Louis two nights later (Feb. 13).

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: Scientist Makes 600Mile Tape of Sea Mammal Talk
description: FREMONT, Calif.In the twilight of a distinguished scientific career spanning 50 years, Dr. Thomas C. Poulter spends most of his days listening to the voices of sea mammalsthe clicks, honks, barks and screeches that most species use to find their way around in the world's oceans.

title: Pamela Bush Sets May 26 Bridal
description: RYE, N. Y., Feb. 2Miss Pamela Mason Bush, the editorial director for WNACTV, Channel 7, a Boston Columbia Broadcasting System affiliate, and Robert Eastin Eubank, a vice president with L. T. Industries, an Andover, Mass., marketing and distributing company, plan to marry here May 26 in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: The Price of Loyalty
description: The Loyalists lost the Revolution, but they seem to be winning the Bicentennial. Within a year at least three books on the Loyalists  the two on review here and Mary Beth Norton's The BritishAmericanshave been published. All are sympathetic accounts. And there are more to come.

title: Skylab Astronauts Correct A Short in Wiring of Apollo
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 2 (UPI)The Skylab 3 astronauts, nearing the end of man's longest space flight, found and corrected today a minor problem in the Apollo spaceship that is to return them to earth next Friday.

title: Lefkowitz Investigating Complaints on Deliveries of New Cars
description: Louis J. Lefkowitz, the New York Attorney General, has begun an investigation into charges that automobile dealers in the state are promising delivery of vehicles, particularly small cars, in three days to five weeks at a time when the average period for delivery four to six months.

title: County Supers on Defense
description: TRENTON  The state's 21 county superintendents of schools find themselves in the uncomfortable position of having to justify their existence, all because of some remarks made recently by Governor Byrne.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1974

title: Jewish Family Service Names Executive Director
description: The Jewish Family Service, a 100yearold agency affiliated with the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, has named Sanford N. Sherman as its executive director. The announcement was made by Louis L. Lowenstein, president of the agency's board of directors.

title: Students Facing Curtailed Easter
description: HILLSBOROUGH TOWNSHIP  Many New Jersey publicschool students, including those in this Somerset County township, face the prospect of a shortened Easter vacation or an extended school year unless the state's Commissioner of Education decides to, reduce the number of school days required by law.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE PRESIDENT, in his State of the Union Address, said he would recommend a budget of $304.4billion for fiscal 1975, up $29.7billion from the current year with a deficit of $9.4billion.... Agriculture Department reported a 9 per cent rise in the farm price index for the month ended Jan. 15, signaling a further increase in retail food prices.

title: Bearded Collie Finally Passes Muster at American Kennel Club
description: The bearded collie's bark has been heard at 51 Madison Avenue, home of the American Kennel Club. The board of directors of that organization has authorized the addition of the breed to the miscellaneous class at shows held on or after June 1.

title: N. F. L. Faces Difficult Task of Signing 442 Players Chosen in Last Week's Draft
description: The scouting reports have been put away and now National Football League dabs face the task of signing the 442 athletes chosen last week in the annual college player draft. The following is capsule evaluation by United Press International of each club's draft.
