description: McNamara, exA's manager, to pilot Padres. Page 2 Strongmen outdo runners in Examiner meet. Page 3 Late goal by Islanders ties Canucks, 22. Page 5 N.F.L. teams hope to get what they'll pay for. Page 6 Bearded collie new addition to A.K.C. shows. Page 9 Track seeks to lure fans with carpool service. Page 9 Miss Hamill out of shadows in figure skating. Page 21

title: Boston College Triumphs Over Fordham by 7464
description: Despite a 19point secondhalf performance by Darryl Brown, Fordham lost to a superior Boston College basketball team yesterday, 7464, before a crowd of 1,400 and a regional television audience in the Rams' Rose Hill Gymnasium.

title: Headliners
description: Flap In the Press Galleries

title: FRANK W. KUNZE
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Feb. 2 Frank W. Kunze, a silk importer for more than half a century, died yesterday in Nassau Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived here.

title: Swiss Had 81 Jobless in '73
description: ZURICH, Switzerland. Feb. 2 (Reuters)  Switzerland had only 81 unemployed last year, a record low, out of a working population of three million, official statistics published here show.

title: New and Recommended
description: FICTION AND POETRY

title: Expos Sign 3 More
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 2 (UPI) The Montreal Expos signed Ken. Singleton, Ron Hunt and Bob Stinson today, bringing to 21 the number of players signed.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Dr. Richard F. Spark's comments on Fat Americans (Jan. 6) were a fantastic blend of medical rhetoric and baloney. He ought to be forced to eat his words.

title: McNamara Is New Padres Manager
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2 (UPI)John McNamara, who helped mold the Oakland A's into a world championship ball club only to be dismissed by Charley Finley in a moment of pique, gets his second chance tomorrow when the San Diego Padres will name him their manager.

title: Notes: Jersey Outlaws Gas Cans in Cars
description: THE New Jersey state police and Turnpike Authority have warned that under state law and turnpike regulations it is illegal in New Jersey to carry gasoline in automobiles anywhere except in gasoline tanks. Anyone caught carrying containers of gasoline is subject to fine and imprisonment.

title: The Life and Mind Of John Dewey By George Dykhuizen. Illustrated. 429 pp. Carbondale and Edwardsville: Southern Illinois University Press. $15.
description: The Life and Mind of John Dewey is the first biography of Dewey since his death in 1952. George Dykhuizen, who is a philosophy professor at the University of Vermont has spent many years mining the available, widelyscattered source materials, and the result is something that was badly needed, a comprehensive, richlydetailed, meticulously ac curate account of Dewey's career as philosopher, reformer, and sage. General readers may find Dykhuizen's approach to Dewey uninspired; students of Dewey, on the other hand, will note that, however flat the prose, it is highly suited to conveying a vast amount of information with impressive lucidity, they will be grateful for Dykhuizen's impartial completeness: just about everything is here. This is a scholarly book which, like its subject, is going to have a long and useful life. It is not a major assessment of Dewey's place in our culture, but it is an indispensable first step toward such an assessment.

title: Steelworkers Report Rise Of 300% in New Members
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 2 (UPI) The United Steelworkers of America says the 1.4 millionmember union added 27,418 new members in 308 new units during 1973, a 300 per cent increase over the 9,000 recruits added during 1972.

title: Manhattan Victor On Bucci's Basket
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 2 Manhattan College scored its. sixth straight victory on the road tonight, rallying from 14 points down in the second half to edge Canislus, 8079, on a basket by George Bucci with six seconds to play.

title: Architecture
description: THE last column in this space added up the score on planning and urban design in New York in the critical decade from 1964 to 74, and this one proposes to do the same for preservation. These two sides of the urban coin provide equally remarkable chronicles of achievement, with this city now in a position of acknowledged national preeminence in dealing with the physical environment.

title: Gasoline Pinch Is Felt At Both Ends of Pump
description: James McPartlin's family has owned the Mobil station at 10th Avenue and 53d Street since 1928, when his father gave up tickettaking on a trolley car and decided he would prefer to pump gasoline.

title: L.I. Loses Ranking As No. 1 In Potatoes
description: ALBANY  Long Island, which has long ranked an one of the nation's leading potatoproducing areas, was surpassed last year by the blossoming potatogrowing areas of upper New York State.

title: Coast Proposal Advances
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 2 (UPI) California Assembly has approved a measure banning pay toilets in publicly owned buildings.

title: Projects Widened By Reform Jews To Aid the Young
description: The major institutions of American Reform Judaism are augmenting various educational and religious projects to meet an increasing demand by young families for stronger stress on rituals and customs in homes, synagogue liturgy and Jewish history.

title: Miss Ragsdale to Wed
description: LAKE CITY, S. C., Feb. 2Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Smith Ragsdale Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Humphrey Ragsdale, to Charles Ernest Reutter 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reutter Jr. of Rye, N. Y., and Hyannisport, Mass. The wedding is planned for May. The bridetobe is a graduate of Mount Vernon College in Washington. Her fianc graduated from Georgetown University.

title: Lutheran Is Organizing a Parish in Forked River
description: FORKED RIVERA prominent 53yearold Lutheran theologian and seminary president from the Midwest has given up the academic life in favor of grassroots missionary work in this popular retirement area near Barnegat Bay.

title: MINORITIES DROP IN U.S. COLLEGES
description: For the first time since the effort began in the middle nineteansixties to expand higher educational opportunity, there has been an apparent decline in the proportion of blacks entering the nation's colleges and universities.

title: SPOTLIGHT No. 1 Futures Broker
description: The commodity futures business is coming out of the back rooms of many Wall Street brokerage houses, with sharp and tough traders busy piling up profits never seen before.

title: Cappelletti Has Day
description: UPPER DARBY, Pa., Feb. 2 (UPI)More than 3,000 persons paraded for two miles today to honor the Heisman trophy winner, John Cappelletti, back home to this Philadelphia suburb. The threehour event honored the Penn State star and his family.

title: Papuans Blend Traditions and Laws
description: PORT MORESBY, Papua New GuineaWhen a tribesman in Papua New Guinea is killed, accidentally or in a fight, custom demands that the death be avenged by the killing of the offender. Alternatively, the victim's fellow tribesmen may kill a relative of the offender or a member of his tribe.

title: DR. FRITZ ACKERMANN
description: Dr. Fritz W. Ackermann, a retired general practitioner in Laurelton, Queens, died yesterday in Booth. Memorial Hospital, Flushing, Queens. He was 84 years old and lived at 10420 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: SUIT SEEKS TO VOID NIXON POCKET VETO
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) In a second legal challenge to President Nixon's use of the pocket veto while Congress is in recess, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts has filed suit in Federal District Court to revive a mass transit bill.

title: New Sounds at an Old Music School
description: For nearly 55 years now, through the Charleston and the twist, through the missile crisis and men landing on the moon, amidst Teapot Dome and Watergate, little feet have been wiping off their shoes on the welcome mat outside the Diller Quaile School of Music. Angela Diller and Elizabeth Quaile, who founded the school in a small studio on West End Avenue, are long since gone, but their contributions to musicianship live on.

title: Air Traffic Slump Raises Question of Jetport Need
description: Air traffic at the jetports serving the metropolitan area has in recent weeks slumped to the lowest level in more than eight years, because of flight cutbacks due to jet fuel shortages, sluggish airline business and increased use of highcapacity jumbo jets.

title: What's New in Theater?
description: LORELEI, a musical with music by Jule Styne, lyrics by Leo Robin, Betty Comden and Adolph Green and book by Kenny Solms and Gail Parent, Anita Loos and Joseph Fields, got 4 favorable reviews (Lewis, Bergen Record; Gayer, UPI; Woodruff, WMCARadio; Scudder, WINSRadio), 11 mixed (Barnes, Times; Watt, News; Watts, Post; Gottfried, Women's Wear; Raidy, Newhouse Newspapers; Glover, AP; Harris, WCBSTV; S. Klein,WNEWTV; Probst, WNBCRadio; Clurman, Nation; Hewes, Saturday Review/World) and 5 unfavorable reviews (Wallach, Newsday; A. Klein, WNYCRadio; Gill, New Yorker; Simon, New York; Stasio, Cue).

title: Tito Is Visiting Nepal
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Feb. 2 (Reuters)President Tito of Yugoslavia arrived here today for a threeday state visit.

title: Warren Leaves Hospital
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2 (AP)Former Chief Justice Earl Warren was released from Daniel Freeman Hospital today, a week after he was admitted for treatment of coronary heart disease. Mr. Warren, 82 years old, who retired from the Supreme Court in 1969, was in good condition when he left the hospital to continue resting at the Beverly Hills home of his daughter and soninlaw, a hospital representative said.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was: 11017

title: CHINA INTENSIFIES IDEOLOGICAL DRIVE
description: PEKING, Feb. 2 (Reuters)Peking's official newspaper called on the nation today to wholeheartedly join in the ideological campaign symbolized by the slogan Criticize Lin Piao, criticize Confucius.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed hire are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: PANEL ASKS STUDY OF CITY PLANNING
description: A state commission charged with examining the structure o New York City's government has proposed a thorough review of the complex process o?? municipal planning that would go to the heart of a crucia question: how much can neighborhood participation be encouraged without causing endless delays in projects designed to benefit the city as a whole.

title: Miss Jane Goldfajer Bride of Surgeon
description: Miss Jane Goldfajer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Goldfajer of Elberon, N.J., was married here last evening to Dr. Charles Scher, son of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel L. Scher of Mamaroneck, L.I. Rabbi Irving Koslowe performed the ceremony at the Regency.

title: J. P. Westerlund to Wed Jan Theil
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Feb. 2 Miss Jan Louise Theil, a fashion designer, and J. Paul Westerlund, who is with the customer inquiry control department of Hayden Stone Inc., will be married March 2 in St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Eastchester.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: MidIsland K.C. allbreed and obedience match, Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L. I.; entries from 8:30 A.M.; judging, obedience 10, breed 11.

title: Reportage as anesthesia
description: A couple of summers ago John Gregory Dunne, a skilled journalist who has acquired a certain reflected celebrity as husband of and occasional collaborator with Joan Didion, fell into a royal blue funk. He became obsessed with his own death, with his imagined inability to father a child, with his failure to work at a remotely efficient pace; he began to drive aimlessly across California and beyond, drifting in a sea of selfpity. Then, during one of his wanderings, he passed a billboard: On brown field there was a picture of an enormous roulette wheel and a goldlettered legend that said simply, with a Delphic absence of apostrophe: VISIT LAS VEGAS BEFORE YOUR NUMBERS UP. He did, and Vegassubtitled A Memoir of a the result.

title: Sunday Observer Boneless Sunday
description: More tales for bright kids only: As long as Old Mother Hubbard kept a bonefilled cupboard for her poor dog the two lived so happily that the dog often said, Surely we are living happily ever after, just as fairytale characters do, and our lives must therefore be a fairy tale.

title: Coops Lift Rent to Pay Fuel Bills
description: Some find their oil bills to be double those of last year. Others have just been hit with a 7.8 per cent acrosstheboard increase for steam. Throughout the city, coop boards are tightening their belti as they reluctantly vote monthly maintenance  or rent increases as high as 15 per cent.

title: Letters: Another Famous Son of Galena
description: To the Editor: Seth S. King's article about Ulysses S. Grant and Galena, Ill., A Frontier Town With Strange Echoes of San Clemente (Travel Section, Jan. 20), fails to mention one other notable American, apparently a failure like the young Grant, who settled briefly in the town in the 19th century. Like Grant, he too was without a suitable profession  in his case a result of the Depression of 1837  and he was trying to get a new start in the West.

title: A Shorter Speed Week At Daytona
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 2 (AP)Auto racing's elite, including five $1million career winners, a racing movie actor and at least two former stars embarking on comebacks, will compete at Daytona Beach next week in an energy  shortened Speed Weeks program.

title: Impact Of New Capital Outflow
description: Controls on the outflow of American capital, first imposed under President Kennedy more than a decade ago, were removed by the Nixon Administration last week in an unexpected and gratifying move. During Its contentious life, the capital controls program served various official purposes and produced farreaching international change. The end of the program will have equally significant effects.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Ed Jones, the 6foot8inch Tennessee State defensive end and No. 1 draft choice of the Dallas Cowboys, tells why he quit basketball in high school: I was the largest guy on the court and I always had four fouls in the first half because the referees picked on me. I couldn't stand sitting on the bench.

title: Cutting Voltage May Not Save As Much Current as Expected
description: The savings from the 5 per cent voltage reduction imposed by Consolidated Edison from Jan, 14 to last Thursday midnight may be overrated, acto a recent technical analysis.

title: Mrs. King Wins Amid Disputes
description: FAIRFAX, Va., Feb. 2There were slim pickin's today in the Virginia Slims of Washington tennis tournament. With the semifinals of the $50,000 women's tennis event divided into afternoon and evening sessions, a spectator had to buy a $5 ticket to see Mrs. Billie Jean King defeat Rosemary Casals and a $6 ticket to see Kerry Melville beat Helen Gourlay in the second match.

title: JEANNE DE MARE
description: Jeanne de Mare, a lecturer on modern music, who was a granddaughter of G. P. A. Healy, 19thcentury American painter, died Friday at her home, 1356 Madison Avenue. Her age was 90.

title: P.S.C. Report Calls for Stringent EnergyConservation Steps by Con Edison
description: ALBANY, Feb. 2The Public Service Commission today proposed a series of energyconservation measures in Consolidated Edison's service territory, including a ban on any new electric heating in buildings in New York City and Westchester County.

title: Half Past Winter
description: Now, to paraphrase the Song of Solomon, the winter is half past, and in another six weeks the flowers will begin to appear on the earth, the time of the singing of birds will have come. Not many birds in midMarch, but some. And they certainly will include the voice of the turtle, for the turtledove is one of our yearround birds. Song sparrows and whitethroats will be singing by then, of course, and there may be redwinged blackbirds. There may be robins back from the South.

title: Bolivian Official Says Plotters Hope to Incite Military Revolt
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 2The Bolivian Minister of the Interior said last night that attempts had been made to use the political unrest here to divide the armed forces and provoke a coup d'tat.

title: Pompidou II: Middle East
description: PARISIt seems obvious President Pompidou regards the new Middle East situation that has developed since the October war as justification of France's longrange policy. His view, communicated by various channels to Israeli leaders, is that this policy indeed represents Israel's ultimate salvation, not in terms of specific details but as a general basis.

title: Nixon at New Low in Poll 26% Approve His Efforts
description: President Nixon's popularity in office has touched a new low, one year after reaching an alltime high, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: The Camera Missed the Mood in the House
description: WASHINGTONA Republican leader In Congress was wondering aloud last week, the day before President Nixon was to deliver his State of the Union Message, if some new shock might be in store. The President was virtually alone at Camp David, writing the address, and rumors of potential resignation were making vaporous trails through the Capitol.

title: Epilogue
description: James Earl Ray has won the right to contest his guilty plea in the 1968 slaying of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. The Sixth United States Circuit Court of Appeals accepted Ray's contention that he was given improper legal advice and remanded his petition to the United States District Court in Nashville for a review that could lead to new trial.

title: News of the Camera World
description: REGISTRATION is now going on at the Camera Club of New York, 37 East 60th Street, for 10 evening courses that will begin Feb. 25. Included in the courses offered, all of which will meet for eight weeks, are two courses in color slides, (one beginner and one advanced), several classes in fundamentals, one on candid portraiture, a studio workshop, one on advanced techniques, one on selling photographs, one on darkroom shortcuts, and a field trip course that will meet on Saturday mornings. Each course will cost $55, with registration for each class limited to keep classes small. Those interested can write to the club at the above address for a brochure and registration form, or they can register weekdays at the club from 2 to 6 P.M. For more information call

title: Con Ed Curbs Urged
description: The Public Service Commission yesterday proposed several energyconservation measures in New York City, and Westchester County, including a ban on new electric heating in buildings. Page 32.

title: Mayor Barbara Impellittiere Of Cold Spring Plans Nuptials
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, N.Y., Feb. 2Mayor Barbara A. Impellittiere of the Village of Cold Spring has become engaged to Roy Edward Flowers Jr., recreation director of the Town of Philipatown, which includes the Village of Cold Spring.

title: Black Judge Named By Virginia Assembly
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 2 (UPI) The Virginia General Assembly has elected Willard H. Douglas, 41 years old, the first black man to serve as a fulltime judge in Virginia.

title: Aye on Growth Nay on Controls
description: WASHINGTONTwo themes permeate the Administration's economic message. They are not headline grabbers. Yet they may make the report remembered long after the rightness or wrongness of its forecast for 1974 has been forgotten.

title: Cycling Group ReElects Black
description: Harvey C. Black of Newark, a member of the Oldtime Athletes Association Hall of Fame, has been elected president of the Eastern Cycling Federation, Inc., for a second consecutive term.

title: Well, My Tweed Sport Coat Hasn't Changed
description: UNIVERSITY Park, Pa.  From where I sit in my second floor office at Penn State, I can look out and see hundreds of determined students tentatively making their way through the newly fallen snow to early morning classes.

title: Photoengravers and Papers Reach a Tentative Contract
description: A tentative agreement on new twoyear contract between the Photoengravers Union and The New York Times and The Daily News was reached early yesterday, it was announced by Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board.

title: How's a Girl Get to Be a goddess?
description: THIS is my Hollywood chapter because it is no good to write an actor's book without a Hollywood chapter. Even you never went there. Which is not my case; I been.

title: A fine specimen of the powerand profitof the press in Middle America
description: DUBUQUE, Iowa. There are 1,761 daily newspapers in the United States, but in the national consciousness, only 129 of them count. These are the powerful city papers with more than 100,000 circulation; their names are usually known throughout the land, and they reflect the popular image of American newspapers as metropolitan thunderers whose armies of reporters can cause the nation to leap out of lethargy. They are hated and cultivated by Presidents, and their histories are studied with seminarian reverence in every school of journalism.

title: This Kid Has Got To Be Kidding
description: JANUARY is a terrible month for new movies but it does give one a chance to catch up on assodated matters. For some time I'd been wanting to talk to Christopher Arnoll, the pseudonym for the fictitious Long Island boy who, in July, 1972, when he was 10, wrote a furious guest piece for The Times on the Image of the Child in Film. When I finally located Christopher by telephone at his parents' home in Wantagh, L. I., hardly recognized the voice. It had begun to change, something that I soon realized was a source of neither satisfaction amusement to him.

title: Jaws
description: The jaws are a white killer shark's; their maulings keep a Long Island resort in terror. Like that shark, this first novel by Peter Benchley  third in the line of writing Benchleys survives by steady motion: to still it for close scrutiny is to sink it. But Jaws keeps its pace; it is a fluid entertainment.

title: The Screen:'Superdad' Is Typical Exercise by Disney
description: The latest Disney feature, "Superdad," is a typically scrubbed, bouncy exercise, in which an anxious, blundering father tries to separate his college-age daughter from her lively young cronies, only to have her mix with some weirdo hippies. Lovereal family love and a faithful, home-town suitorconquers all.Some of this generation-gap exercise is quite funny, starting with the performance by Bob Crane as the father, although he tends to squeal and overact a bit. Kathleen Cody and Kurt Russell are so charming as the young sweethearts that one wonders why papa was determined to separate them. Barbara Rush does nicely as the mother, and Judith Lowry is briefly hilarious as a pool-playing, motorcycle-riding octogenarian.The picture opened yesterday at the Radio City Music Hall.

title: The Only Thing He Doesn't Do Is Dance
description: WHAT kind of dancing is this? All you can see are green hands vibrating, while behind them on the dark stage, a huge lixminous painting of brown and gold shapes seems to be coming apart and reforming. Occasionally the dancers reveal themselves wholly  pale and eerie, pulsing with life.

title: SCHOOL UNIT ASKS NEW AID FORMULA
description: ALBANY, Feb. 2A special state task force on school financing today proposed a reshuffling and simplification of the formulas the state uses to compute aid to local school districts.

title: Music
description: TOMORROW evening the Philadelphia Orchestra will be playing Arnold Schoenberg's A Survivor from Warsaw, and during the course of the year there will presumably be many more tributes to the composer. For this is the centenary of his birth; he was born on Sept. 13, 1874. In many respects he is more alive now than he was in his own time. For although his musicor, at least, most of his musichas never really entered the repertory, his theories have made him the dominant force in Westem music of the second half of the 20th century. The avantgarde of the period following World War II seized upon Schoenberg and also the music of his two pupils, Alban Berg and Anton Webern, and a new era in music was shaped.

title: Quake Felt in Alaska
description: PALMER, Alaska, Feb. 2 (UPI)A moderate earthquake shook south central Alaska early today, the Palmer Observatory reported. A spokesman said the quake, which measured 5.1 on the Richter scale, was felt strongly in Anchorage, Palmer and other communities.

title: May 4 Wedding Set By Miss Mandeville
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Feb. 2 Mr. and Mrs. Hubert Turner Mandeville have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Meredith Mandeville, to James Edward Hollis 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hollis Jr. of Providence, R. I.

title: Alva Benjamin See Jr. To Marry Nancy Gay
description: PLAQUEMINE, La., Feb. 2 Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Price Gay have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Dicks Gay, to Alva Benjamin See Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., who is director of special gifts at the Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center in New York.

title: WEISBERG IS TEAMED WITH DAVID AMRAM
description: Max's Kansas City, Park Avenue South, unveiled an unusual bill on Wednesday, right in the middle of Dylan week. There was David Amram, a musician who is just as likely to compose a classical symphony as work in a conventional jazz group (he has done both) followed by Tim Weisberg, flutist firmly locked into his amplification.

title: Depot Is Bombed in Belfast; Fireman and 2 Others Hurt
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 2 (AP)  Terrorists today bombed one of Belfast's main rail terminals, the Great Victoria Street Station, wounding a fireman and two ambulance attendants, police officials said.The terminal is now burning fiercely, a police spokesman said. Police officials believe the bombers were members of the outlawed Irish Republican Army. The 14story Europa Hotel also was damaged in the explosion.

title: Soviet Double Standard
description: Moscow's complaint that the West is organizing ideological subversion of the Soviet Union by publishing Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's criticism of the secret police and prison camp system is replete with irony. It illustrates again the difficulty of achieving in practice the freer exchange of information and ideas to which the Kremlin has paid lip service at the Geneva Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe.

title: Numismatics
description: CAN you pick the winners? Three of the 12 design sketches shown above will become part of this country's circulating coinage starting the latter part of next year or early in 1976 (depending on how fast the Mint can produce the new coins and how extensively they are hoarded). Unless some additional programs are announced by Congress or the President, these coin designs will retain their status as the nation's principal recognition and commemoration of the 200th anniversary of the American Revolution.

title: Television The Second Season Is SecondBest
description: MOST network executives, It should be stressed, are fairly reasonable and even intelligent in their nonpublic existences. But put them in front of an audience, arm them with the hyperbole of a nicely paid speech writer, and the rhetoric bubbles like a Lawrence Welk routine. Consider these remarks delivered recently before a group of broadcasters and advertisers. The name of the executive, or his network, doesn't matter. The same speech could have been, in fact has been, made by executives at all three of the commercial networks:

title: Paper in Phoenix Sells Shares for $1 And Earns $35,000.
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 2 An Arizona newspaper has achieved what is believed to be the first successful public stock offering by any paper whose origins date back to the press revolution of the late nineteensixties.

title: Stephen Krause to Wed Miss Edington
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 2 Mrs. Thomas Augustus Edington has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Katherine Hoffmann Edington, to Stephen John Krause, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Krause of Everett, Wash.

title: American Perspective
description: The United States is a nation adrift. From almost any vantage point, thoughtful citizens have difficulty gaining a steady perspective on the country's problems and prospects.

title: Miss Susan Ford Is Married To Capt. Michael C. Veysey
description: WINNETKA, III., Feb. 2Miss Susan Ford, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William F. Ford, was married here this evening to Capt. Michael Charles Veysey of the Marine Corps, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Veysey of Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: Spectacular Earnings Made in 4th Quarter
description: The soaring profits that oil companies have been announcing in the last two weeks have lifted their industry into the highest circle of profitability, largely on the wings of one of the most spectacular fourth quarters that any industry has ever reported.

title: The Oldest, Safest and Cheapest Way to Ski May Still Be the Best
description: IT is 25 years ago and I am a boy at boarding school, standing in the woods that fringe an upland field in New England. My back is braced against the trunk of a large pine, and above me the wind moans through green boughs. The rest of the world, lying under a twofoot blanket of snow, is defined in blacks and whites. Rabbit tracks pass nearby; they and the marks my skis have left are the only signs of life, save perhaps for the pale wisp of wood smoke rising from a farmhouse chimney across the valley. There is safety and peace here, and the kind of glorious solitude that only a boy at a boarding school can fully appreciate.

title: The Symmetrical Family
description: In the common idiom of sociology the family, marriage, communities, regionalism and religion are forever dyinggoing into eclipse, tumbling into crisis and disappearing from theoretical schemes that run so far ahead of their time that society may never catch up with them. More fortunate are bureaucracy, science, technology, sex, the executive branch of government and rationality itself these, wisdom tells us, are rising, proliferating, differentiating and diffusing like amebae in the primordial biological soup. A large number of sociologists earn their keep by periodically announcing the decline of the first group, while an equally large contingent makes its reputation discovering the rise of the second.

title: Newark Eyeing Airport Gap
description: NEWARK  The city is looking hungrily at the $400million redevelopment program at Newark International Airport and Port Newark, for it hopes that some of that apparent prosperity will rub, off.

title: The Dollar's Almighty Again
description: WASHINGTONSunt lacrimae rerum. An untranslatable phrase of Virgil's, roughly meaning: It's a vale of tears.

title: The special pain of the late 20th century
description: President John F. Kennedy suffered from it for 25 years. Senator Edward Kennedy has suffered from it since 1964. Richard M. Nixon suffered from it before he became President, and still does. Representative Wilbur Mills has only just gone back to work as chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee following months of incapacity and, finally, surgery. Senator Barry Goldwater is a sufferer. In the entertainment world, Joan Sutherland, Elizabeth Taylor and Don Ameche have been its victims. The world of sport is a battlefield strewn with casualties, while Jack Nicklaus is one of the walking wounded who has succeeded in spite of it.

title: Mrs. Rita M. Rentschler Remarried
description: Mrs. Rita Mitchell Rentschler of New York, widow of George A. Rentschler, former chairman of the BaldwinLimaHamilton Corporation, producers of locomotives, was married in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church here yesterday morning to Allerton Cushman, a retired investment banker of Paradise Valley, Ariz.

title: Zoning a Denville Problem
description: DENVILLE Half of this township's 15 square miles is still undeveloped, and the zoning of the open areas is growing as a topic of concern and debate among the residents. Some would like the undeveloped sectors to remain untouched, while others see Denville becoming the business center of Morris County.

title: LACK OF GASOLINE WORST EVER HERE
description: A gasoline gapwith January allocations exhausted and February deliveries blocked or delayed by a truckers' strikeleft motorists across the metropolitan area with little or no fuel yesterday in what one Federal official called the worst day of the energy shortage thus far for drivers.

title: In Talking About Israel, Civility Please
description: Before I say anything critical about Israel and some of her supporters, let me first say that I believe Israel has a right to exist free of fear. I believe that the United States as, in a sense, Israel's creator, has an enduring moral obligation to guarantee that safety even, if necessary, to the extent of taking up arms in the defense of Israeli soil.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Those of us who live in the area of Henry Kibel's building [Rerfting Starts After Uproar on Height, Jan. 20] do not share his grief. Rather, we only wish that the city had meted out to him as much inconvenience, annoyance and contempt as Mr. Kibel has given the public.

title: Ranks Closed, Eyes Right Under Wilson
description: For the last 15 years, the Republican party in New York has been a wholly owned subsidiary of Nelson Rockefeller. As a strongwilled governor, he was the de facto party leader and as a multimillionaire, he was also the party's chief angel. Yet, in the last six weeks since Mr. Rockefeller stepped down as Governor, the Party has entered a new era with little of the upheaval mat might be expected when strong leader gives up the reins of power.

title: A Court Scolds Alabama Judge, Then Drops Contempt Charge
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 2 An Alabama state circuit judge faced a contempt proceeding here this week over his handling of a criminal case and was reportedly lectured sternly by appellate judges before the proceeding was dismissed.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving The

title: Marichal, Jones Tie For Lead
description: LAS CROABAS, P.R., Feb. 2Juan Marichal, Boston Red Sox pitcher, and Deacon Jones, San Diego Chargers' defensive lineman, shot a record net 56, 15 under par, today and tied for the 36hole lead with firstround coleaders Jeff Burroughs and Bob Anderson in the $30,000 American Airlines golf classic at the El Conquistador Golf Club.

title: News of the Screen
description: Now that the American Film Theater has gotten over most of the pains of introducing its first subscription series of eight movie versions of noted plays, such as O'Neill's The Iceman Cometh and Chekhov's Three Sisters, it is preparing to start production of a second series. The program will have five features, the first of which is tentatively scheduled to begin filming in May.

title: CAIRO EMBARKING ON LIBERALIZATION
description: CAIRO, Feb. 2The Egyptian Government has embarked upon a policy of trying to create a better economic and psychological climate in the country in the wake of, the October war.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Scott of Suns Out With Broken Arm

title: Barbara Hatch Engaged to Wed A Ph.D. Student
description: TENANTS HARBOR, Me., Feb. 2Mrs. Rutherfurd L. Hatch has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Barbara Sherman Hatch, to William Bert Spillman Jr. of Boston, son of Mr. Spillman Sr. of Miami and the late Mrs. Spillman.

title: Tri Jet Wins By Head at Santa Anita
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 2 (AP)Tri Jet came on in the stretch under the urging of Bill Shoemaker to catch Forage and win by a head in the $59,000 San Pasqual Handicap at Santa Anita today. A stablemate, Susan's Girl, was third, three lengths back.

title: Bicycle Trips to Beach
description: Because of the gasoline shortage, bicycles will be allowed on the Wantagh Parkway from Merrick Road to Jones Beach State Parkway on Sundays from 9:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. until March 31. Park facilities, including shuffleboard, paddle tennis and the skating rink, will also be open on these Sundays.

title: Nicklaus, With a 201, Leads by 6
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 2Jack Nicklaus put together a solid, threeunderpar 69 today, and opened up a seemingly insurmountable sixstroke lead after the third round of the $220,000 Hawaiian open golf tournament. His total was 201, 15 under par.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Investor uncertainty over when the oil embargo would end and some discouraging economic reports combined to weaken the stock market last week.

title: OVERSEAS FORCES GET OIL SUPPLIES
CONGRESS SEEKING TO HELP STUDENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  Efforts are under way in Congress to make it easier for middleclass college students to get loans under a Federal program whose use has declined sharply despite rising enrollments and educational costs.

title: Environmentalists Honored With First Tyler Awards
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2 (AP) Three eminent environmentalists have been presented the first Tyler Awards for their work in conservation and ecology protection.

title: Borg Beats Moore In Final at Oslo
description: OSLO, Norway, Feb. 2 (AP) Bjorn Borg, the 17yearold Swedish star, won the men's title for the second straight year in the Scandinavian open indoor tennis championship, with a 26, 64, 64, 61 victory over Ray Moore of South Africa today. The winner, who is a professional, earned $2,650.

title: Home Improvement
description: MODERN interior and exterior paints that are sold for home use these days are greatly improved over the formulations that were available two or three decades ago, but there are still many do's and don't's that should be observed if disappointments are to be avoided, and many tricks of the trade that can save time and effort for doityourself home painters.

title: 2 Directories List Education Courses
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I.The Nassau Association for Continuing Education has compiled two directories of courses to be offered by its 43member school districts during the spring semester. One directory lists all 668 courses offered and the other lists only the 128 occupational courses.

title: Iris Krummen Has Nuptials
description: DENNIS PORT, Mass., Feb. 2Miss Iris Marie Krummen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Edward Krummen of Bluffton, Ind., was married here late this afternoon to James Leland Crider 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Crider Jr. of Darien, Conn. The Rev. David Brogan, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the beach home of Bertram R. MacMannis Jr., a friend of the bridegroom.

title: South African Coal Locomotive Reprieved by the Shortage of Oil
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 2 (AP)  The oil shortage has come to the rescue of South Africa's old coalburning railroad locomotives.

title: Change Unchanging at Stony Brook
description: STONY BROOK, L.I.  In the 11 years since 400 acres of fields and farmland outside this early American village became known as a campus only one aspect of life at the burgeoning state university has remained unchanged: change itself.From dawn to dusk, one semester after another, the din of jackhammers, the roar of bulldozers and the whining of massive cranes merged into a cacophony that could almost serve as a theme song for this growing institution that some experts predict will, by the end of the decade, be the most prestigious in the 72campus state university system.

title: The ordeal of Meyer Levin
description: Injustice collector, Litigious Levin, a loser, a freak, incompetent dramatist, troublemaker, hopeless paranoiac, redbaiter, Yid. These are only a smattering of the names Meyer Levin has others calling him in his disturbing, strangely involving new book, The Obsession, which is part autobiographical followup to his earlier In Search, part therapy, part Kafkaesque brief for the obsessed (to be obsessed, he points out, doesn't necessarily mean one is wrong), and part the injusticecollecting of a possibly paranoid, definitely troublemaking, constantly complaining tower of tsouris.

title: ChurchCommunist Talks Stir Bologna
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, Jan. 27The Roman Catholic Church and the Communist party are groping for a new relationship here in the largest Communistgoverned city in Western Europe.

title: SYRIANS REPORT A GOLAN VICTORY
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 2 (Reuters)  Syria said tonight that she had inflicted heavy losses on Israeli forces in renewed clashes in the Golan Heights.

title: Ann Havens, Colorado Alumna, Married to Alan McIlvain Jr.
description: GLADWYNE, Pa., Feb. 2Miss Ann Havens and Alan McIlvain Jr. were married here this afternoon by the Rev. Warren H. Davis Jr. in St. Christopher's Episcopal Church.

title: McCarthy's 4:15.8 Wins Iona Mile
description: Gene McCarthy, who ran in the shadow of Mark Belger his last two outings, regained his confdience yesterday in the Iona College Schoolboy meet, held at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: Late Goal By Islanders Gains Tie
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Feb. 2 (AP)Bobby Nystrom set up Ed Westfall's goal in the first minute, then scored with less than six minutes to go tonight, lifting the New York Islanders into a 22 National Hockey League tie with the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Oil Is a National Problem, But Seriousness Varies
description: The hardship of the energy shortage has not fallen evenly on the nation. Some sections are more affected than others; some industries are particularly hard hit. New York Times correspondents were asked to assess the effects of the crisis in each region. Their reports follow.

title: A Winner Comes Back
description: WHATEVER the merits of music competitions, they do put a spotlight on the winner. His achievement will be to his everlasting credit and will in all likelihood be remembered no matter what happens to his career. Agustin Anievas made a splash in 1961 by winning the Dimitri Mitropoulos International Piano Competition, which was held in the Metropolitan Opera House. He had the bad luck to make his debut in Carnegie Hall the following year when the newspapers were on strike. He moved to Europe in 1965 and has not played in New York very often since then, although a couple of recordings, major ones, have been released here in the past two years. He is returning for two recitals in Tully Hall, the first one tonight, the second on Feb. 28, and it is a safe bet that on the strength of a 12 yearold award he will draw audiences eager and curious to see how he's doing.

title: A Child Prisoner Is Freed at 40
description: A graying 40yearold man walked out of Greenhaven Prison last week, free on parole for the first time since 26 years ago when, at the age of 14, he was sentenced to life imprisonment for the murder of an 8yearold child.

title: 2 Tracks Scratched
description: Rockingham Park in Salem, N.H., and Suffolk Downs inside of Boston, canceled their racing schedules yesterday because of bad weather. A spokesman for Suffolk Downs said races would be held today if the snowstorm cleared sufficiently.

title: Episcopal Diocese Gets First Black Bishop
description: The first black priest in the Episcopal Diocese of New York to attain the rank of Bishop was consecrated yesterday in a ceremony rich In ancient liturgy and tradition.

title: Truck Driver Is Injured In Bus Crash in Queens
description: The driver of a panel truck was injured seriously yesterday when he crashed into the rear of a Transit Authority bus at, an intersection in Jamaica, Queens, shortly after 2:30 P.M., according to the police.

title: SHOP TALK
description: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFSThose boutique buffs who like to patronize entertaining places should be delighted by the shops along that stretch of Route 9W called Sylvan Avenue. A halfdozen old houses have been spruced up and converted into dozens of boutiques; all are worthy of investigation for their variety of merchandise and the services they offer.

title: Controller of Nassau Prefers Raw Oysters to Pearls
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I.  M. Halstead Christ, the Nassau County Controller, buys his seafood by the bushel. He has to. When he prepares clam chowders, oyster scallops and stews he has to have more mollusks than the recipes call for because he has a habit of eating them before they reach the pot.

title: Venezuela Guarantees Oil To Central American States
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 2 (Reuters)Venezuela today guaranteed preferential oil supplies to Central American nations to counter shortages they are suffering as a result of the Arab oil cutback, but refused to lower her prices.

title: Bergen Institutes Antismoking Drive
description: HACKENSACKThe Bergen County Health Department is offering smokingcessation courses in cooperation with the Bergen County chapter of the American Cancer Society and the local adulteducation schools in Fair Lawn, Old Tappan, Tenafly, Paramus and Palisades Park.

title: Schools Are Urged To Convert To Metrics
description: TRENTONIt Thomas Jefferson had had his way the United States would have used the metric system for its weights and measures, instead of the English system now in use.

title: Walter GranvilleSmith Jr., Esty Company Officer, Dies
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Feb. 2Walter GranvilleSmith Jr., who retired in 1965 as vice president in charge of media planning at William Esty Company, Inc., advertising, died yesterday in Port Chester. He was 68 years old and lived here.

title: World News Briefs
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 2 Seven South Korean university students were sentenced to prison terms ranging from five to ten years by a special courtmartial here today for violating a presidential decree banning criticism of the Constitution.

title: Priorities In Budget Revised By Beanie
description: Brooklyn is delighted that the Mayor has decided to give attention to the beautiful park resources throughout the city, said John Hayes, deputy borough president of the borough.

title: Bigger Beach for Public at Sandy Hook
description: SANDY HOOK  At least 50 per cent more of the Sandy Hook beachfront will be made available to the public this year, a result of the Federal Government operating the elongated, historic acreage as part of the Gateway National Recreation Area.

title: Proper names
description: ACROSS

title: 49ers Name Woman, 26, To Key Post
description: Robin Mitchell has struck it rich with the San Francisco 49ers.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Art A Fast Sequence of Forms Changing Color and Shape
description: THERE is nothing like the acquisition of a new technology for inducing the illusion that art has some radical new, function to perform. Novelty of means leads, naturally enough, to great expectations about new ends. Yet artnot our ideas about it, but the experience itselfis not easily dislodged from its traditional functions. Radical change in the way art addresses itself to our emotions is not as easily accomplished as the propaganda emanating from new art movements always assumes. The instrument may indeed be as uptodate as the Pentagon's new missiles, but the experience  what actually impinges on the mind of the observeroften remains hostage to familiar associations. The new technology may be little more than a machine for the mass production of cliches.

title: Traffic Deaths Cut 1,000 in '73; Big Portion Linked to Gas Crisis
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (UPI)The National Safety Council says that about 1,000 fewer persons were killed in traffic accidents in the United States in 1973 than in 1972 and that the largest portion of the reduction came during December, when the energy problems reached their peak for the year.

title: House Election Is Watched for Impact of Watergate
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Feb. 2Like it or not, this gritty, old steel town has become a barometer for Republican electoral fortunes in 1974.

title: Kathleen Goodness To Marry June 15
description: The Rev. Donald R. Goodness, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Ascension, and Mrs. Goodness have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Mary Goodness, to Herbert Wheatley Plimpton Jr., son of Mr. Plimpton of Boston and Mrs. Jane Zimmerman Plimpton of Brookline, Mass. of Mr. Plimpton of Boston and Mrs. Jane Zimmerman Plimpton of Brookline, Mass.

title: ELECTRICITY COST JUMPS IN FLORIDA
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 2Soaring prices of Venezuelan oil, used in the generating plants of Florida's major public utilities, are pushing power bills toward a level that local and state officials say will create economic hardship for both residential and commercial customers.

title: Counties Turn to Computers
description: NEWARK  The use of countygovernment computers by municipalities is spreading throughout New Jersey. For example, Essex is the latest county to make its computer facilities available to local administrations.

title: Maria Wiglesworth Plans Bridal
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 2The engagement of Miss Maria Monette Wiglesworth to Jeffrey Porter Hemmings, both of New York, has been announced by the parents of the prospective bride, Mrs. Gilbert Wiglesworth of Lexington and William Goodloe Wiglesworth Jr. of Cynthiana.

title: ADDISON E. KIRK
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Feb. 2  Addison Erwin Kirk of Stonington, fatherinlaw of L. Patrick Gray 3d, former. acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, died last night at Lawrence Memorial Hospital. He made his home at Findlay Way in Stonington, with Mr. Gray.

title: Michigan Papers Merging
description: COOPERSVILLE, Mich., Feb. 2 (AP)Several Western Michigan weekly newspapers will merge into a single publication next week, Clinton Beckwith, owner of the Journal Publishing Company, has announced. He said he had purchased The Ravenna Times and FruitportSpring Lake Clipper from Rogers Publishing, Inc., and would merge them with his TriCounty Observer based in Coopersville.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Prof. S. M. Menshikov's article depicts the American economy as experiencing considerable difficulties, some of which can only be relieved by increased trade with the Soviet Union (Point of View, Soviet Survey of U.S. Outlook, Jan. 6).

title: Essex Group Fights Zoning
description: SOUTH ORANGEMunicipal laws designed to limit a town's population growthsocalled exclusionary zoning have attracted a new opponent.

title: A Book Lover's Bookstore
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I. Sooner or later most of the book lovers on Long Island come to Oscar's Literary Emporium here.

title: Where black and white folks meet
description: The New Orleans Black Jazzman. By Jack V. Buerkle and Danny Barker. Illustrated. 244 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $7.95.

title: Repression in Belgrade?
description: An acid test of academic freedom is developing Yugoslavia, endangering the international reputation for intellectual tolerance in which the Belgrade Communist leadership has taken justifiable pride for many years.

title: The State of Latin Radicalism
description: In August, 1967, the Organization of LatinAmerican Solidarity proclaimed in Havana that the only way to overcome imperialism and establish socialism on the continent was through armed struggle. LatinAmerican radical leftists, led by Cuba's Premier Castro, openly condemned the Soviet Union and the classic Communist parties for their reformist tactics.

title: The Brooklyn Gang Rumble That Never Happened
description: The two plainclothes men had been sitting in the 1968 Chevrolet hoping to surprise the team of muggers who the previous night had pushed a stick into a victim's eye, When five youths approached the car.

title: Operation Snowmaker Is Designed to Cover the East
description: LAKE HARMONY, Pa., Feb. 1 Maintenance crews at New England ski areas awaited zero weather last night before climbing the slopes to turn on the snow guns. At Jay Peak in Vermont the temperatures this morning fell to two below. The theme was Operation Snowmaker all over the East. Here in Pennsylvania's Poconos artificial snow was spouting out of snowmakers by the wee hours of the morning.

title: Music In Review
description: Oboe Well Played By Virginia Brewer

title: This Week in Sports
description: Boxing

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
Environmentalists Foresee '74 As Toughest of Recent Years
description: WASHINGTON  Although the environmental vote has been steadily gaining impetus in campaign poltics since 1970, some of its leaders foresee 1974 as the toughest year yet.

title: New Orleans Superdome Rises as a Monument to Spectator Sports
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 2The Superdome will be remembered as the last great monument to American folly, the host at a dinner party said the other night.

title: Fire Toll in Japan at 2,000
description: TOKYO, Feb. 2 (UPI)Fires killed nearly 2,000 people in Japan last year, the Fire Defense Agency has reported today. The agency said 1,858 died in 72,461 fires. It said 56,148 houses were destroyed with property damage amounting to $109.7million.

title: Joan M. Scheer Plans Bridal in August
description: EAST HILLS, L. I., Feb. 2 Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Scheer have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Meryl Scheer, to Joel William Abramowitz, son of Abraham Abramowitz of Shoreham and Mrs. Helen Abramowitz of Fort Lee, N. J. An August wedding is planned.

title: The World In Summary
description: Acting under its interpretation of the terms of the ceasefire accords reached in Paris more than a year ago, the United States is financing much of the war that is still going on in Indochina.

title: Entering The Arena
description: Nixon, Congress Prepare Carefully For the Struggle

title: Three Artists, Three Different Terrains
description: THE big paintings in William Allan's first New York show (at the Whitney Museum) bear the unmistakable stamp of the feisty breeding ground of Fink art, the northern California. Not that his meticulously rendered landscapes share the conscious crudities or guttiness that inform California Funk, nor its playful eroticism. But like many of the San Franciseo area painters, he is interested in wordplay and visual puns, and also in the allegorical juxtapositon of manmade relics with nature. The most impressive example is his cosmically titled Shadow Repair for the Western Man (Allan is interested in the notion of repair, both physically and metaphysically, and organized a quirky show around it at a San Francisco gallery a couple of years ago). A vast panorama of snowy peaks set off in the foreground by a giantoid pair of empty jeans and work boots atop a broken chair, its message, seems to be an assertion of man and his fragile works against an indifferent universe.

title: PANEL ASKS STUDY OF CITY PLANNING
description: A state commission charged with examining the structure of New York City's government has proposed a thorough review of the complex process of municipal planning that would go to the heart of a crucial question: how much can neighborhood participation be encouraged without causing endless delays in projects designed to benefit the city as a whole.

title: Once it was a threat to the Americanism of wealthy Jews, the Judaism of religious Jews and the socialism of poor Jews
description: Ever since October, 1973, with the outbreak of the Yom Kippur war, it has become clearer and clearer that something new has happened to the Jews of America: they have all been converted to Zionism. Now if, in the words of a sardonic old quip, a Zionist is a Jew who lives in the Diaspora with his bags eternally packed; or if, as David Ben Gurion once insisted, only a Jew who intends to settle in Israel is entitled to call himself a Zionist, no more than a few thousand American Jews are today or ever have been Zionists. If, however, Zionism means supporting the idea of a sovereign Jewish state in Palestine, then most American Jews have been Zionists at least since the end of World War H. Most, but by no means all. Once upon time there were antiZionist Jews in America, there were nonZionist Jews in America, and there were Jews in America indifferent to the whole issue of Jewish statehood. What the Yom Kippur war has revealed is that many who were formerly hostile or indifferent to Israel have by now either become Zionists or have simply faded away

title: JESUITS URGE ITALY TO COUNTER MAFIA
description: ROME, Feb. 2An influential Jesuit magazine charged this week that Italy's lawenforcement system was scandalously powerless in the face of Mafia crimes.

title: Climber's Body Sighted

Mr. Keddy, one of six men in mountain climbing group, had become stranded on an isolated rocky ledge yesterday and apparently died of exposure. Officials said the body could not be recovered until the winds subside.

title: They Won't Boo Loudon Any Longer

A singersongwriter who pokes fun at Jesus, carries on about dead skunks and writes lullabies that begin shut up and go to bed takes some getting used to.

Hughes, the reclusive billionaire, appears to have made his peace with the governing political party in the Bahamas and will be permitted to live here while fighting his legal battles with the United States and various persons suing or investigating him, from there.

title: Just This Side of Non Existence

It has been modest in scale, but more could hardly be asked of a museum with cramped quarters and a massive permanent collection to maintain on display. Beyond that, the avantgarde of recent years has been so various, fragmented and controversial that any museum bent on presenting it to the public deserves credit, not to say sympathy.

description: BOSTON, Feb. 2 (AP)  Edward M. Kennedy Jr., 12yearold son of the Democratic Senator from Massachusetts, has been hospitalized for tests and treatment aimed to prevent recurrence of bone cancer.

title: The Democrats Reply

His legislative shopping list, shorter but not markedly different from Mr. Nixon's, included national health insurance, reform private pension plans, nofault automobile insurance, an increase in the minimum wage, and the strengthening of education and housing programs.

title: An Eastern Dreamer Inc Pursuit of A western Monster
description: The first look I had at Yoshio Kou, the Japanese dreamer and wheelerdealer who led a team of his countrymen to Scotland last fall to find the Loch Ness monster, he was gazing out from the terrace in front of the rustic stone facade of the Glenurquhart Lodge Hotel at the changing shadows and silvers of the surface of the loch. His fine black hair fell far below his shoulders, and his expression was benevolent, selfconfident, peaceful and the authority in the chiseled features, especially the proudly prominent ridgebone of the nose, gave him something of the dignity of a Sioux brave. He was totally untroubled about his chances for success (My belief in the monster is only 5050, he says). Kou and his merry men have now returned to Japan, where they are readying a newfangled diving capsule for another search this

Nusbaum of the New York City Civil Court. The children are named Marc Clifford and Frederick Lawrence.

title: New Rutgers Classes Set
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  Don M. Gottfredson, dean of the newly formed Rutgers University School of Criminal Justice, has never worked as a policeman and is morally opposed to the death penalty. But his school, which is scheduled to open with a graduate program in Newark next fall, is not geared to the average patrolman on the beat.

title: Whatever Shirley Thinks, Shirley Says
description: THIS time, she asserts, prim as nuns once were, this time she's going to be charitable. Shirley Knight Hopkins (back when she was just plain Shirley Knight) used to give interviews that kept libel lawyers on Seconal; but now she enters the Plaza's Palm Court as if intimidated, and practically the first thing she says is, Really, I mustn't do in my colleagues any more. At 36, she still resembles one of the virginal, Aryan debutantes who drank tea here when there were still virginal debutantes, when tea was something you drank. I don't think I need any more enemies in the arts, do you? she adds, smiling like Joan Fontaine.

title: Toby Rosenberg Engaged
description: LYNN, Mass., Feb. 2Mr. and Mrs. Paul Rosenberg have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Toby Rosenberg, to Dr. Lawrence S. Ross, a resident in medicine at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center in New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene T. Ross of West Orange, N. J.

title: Think Metric, Or You'll Be Kilometers Behind Shortly
description: Slowly, slowly, 2.54 centimeters by 2.54 centimeters, the United States is inching toward formal adoption of the metric system of weights and measures. Conversion to metrics would replace the random charm of our present customary system, which is based on such folklore as a Saxon king's girth, with decimal rationality.

title: Sale of Natural Gas For a Record Price Approved by F.P.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) The Federal Power Commission announced yesterday it had authorized the Souther Natural Gas Company, a major gas supplier in the Southeast, to purchase natural gas at the highest price on record.

The Chamber Symphony of New Jersey, a selfgoverning, 40member professional orchestra, will join the Summit Chorale in a program beginning at 8 o'clock, and it will play what its founder and musical director, G. L. Nair, views as a showcase introduction for a projected initial season of 30 concerts next year.

title: Discovering The Present
description: Harold Rosenberg is the premier sociologist of the art world. No one has a better eye for the social and psychological stakes people have in their art world roles. His active refusal to play along, rather than the conservatism of his opinions about art, best explains why he is not taken seriously among New York art critics.

title: News of the Realty Trade

title: Maplewood Acts On Garage Sales
description: MAPLEWOODThis community has adopted an ordinance requiring approval by the Township Clerk before garage sales of personal property can be held. Exceptions are charitable, cultural, educational or governmental organizations.

title: Historical Hobby Turned Into Books
description: CENTER MORICHES, L. I. Ten years ago August Stout Jr. suddenly realized that his hobby was interfering with his business. The old pictures of the Moriches that he had started collecting shortly, after moving to the area In 1935 were crowding out his real estate listings.

title: Official Denies Any Intent To Sell Wheat Back to the U.S.
description: A Soviet trade official denied yesterday that the Soviet Union intended to sell wheat back to the United States.

title: Design: A landmark exhibition at the Whitney
description: Whether it is called innocent or primitive or naive or even amateur, the work of those untrained and often unknown artisans we have come to categorize as folk artists constitutes a crucial chapter in the history of our native visual culture, and we have been remarkably late in recognizing its importance. Only since the Depression years of the nineteenthirties have these humble products of indigenous sensibility and skillquilts and pottery and painted furniture and hooked rugs and tavern signs and weather vanes been seriously studied and collected and admired, and even today, when the effigies of distant African tribesmen and the carvings of obscure Pacific islanders are a regular part of our basic courses in art appreciation, American folk art is not always given its due.

title: Dance
description: ALTHOUGH Fancy Free does not have its official 30th birthday until April 18, American Ballet Theater won't be in New York then, and the other night at the City Center 55th Street Theater the ballet had what was virtually an advance birthday party, with Jerome Robbins, Leonard Bernstein and Oliver Smith all at hand in the audience. Fancy Free has become a signature work with Ballet Theater, even though its success that April night 30 years ago at the old Metropolitan Opera House was almost totally unexpected.

title: A Parents' Group Is Teaching Religion at Home

title: Maureen Laflin Wed to R. A. Cantlin Jr.

title: The Golden Shadow
description: There is no doubt about it, wrote Thomas Mann in 1936, the moment when the storyteller acquires the mythical way of looking at things ... that,moment marks a beginning in his life. And with this gem of book to back me up, I would add: the moment the listener, in this case the young adult reader, is confronted with such a storyteller, this moment must mark a beginning of a deeper insight into the dark recesses of man's fantasy life.

title: Spying in the White House Said to Have Begun in '70

Conway Felton 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Conway Felton Jr. of Pride's Crossing. The wedding is planned for Aug. 24 at Salter's Point in South Dartmouth.

description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Feb. 2Mack Calvin, an allstar guard, insists that the Carolina Cougars have no intention of rolling over for the New York Nets or any other club because of Billy Cunningham's absence.
