description: Although Yale University's controversial Vinland Map, showing America as discovered by the Vikings hundreds of years before Columbus, may have been forged, it has nevertheless rekindled debate about who got to the New World first, as well as who made the map.

title: $19.40 Jolly Johu Wins Burch Stakes at Bowie
description: BOWIE, Md., Feb. 2The Rolling Ridge Farm's gray colt, Jolly Johu, made an early lead stand up all the way today to win the $28,350 W. P. Burch Stakes. With Ben Feliciano In the saddle, Jolly Johu beat eight rivals in the sixfurlong sprint for 3yearolds, his nearest pursuer being Instead of Roses of the Sam Son Farm.

title: Steal My Name and You Got Trash
description: (In a recent letter to the Book Review Donald Barthelme complained that two stories he didn't write had appeared under his name.) Arthur Garfield Sharke Esq. Sharke, Sharke & Mako 23 Wall Street New York, N. Y. Dear Artie:

title: A Quartet of Women
description: WOMEN are still not too common on stamps  not counting reproductions of works of art  and the appearance of four at one time is rare enough to be an occasion of note.

title: Barton Sloop Looms as Race Victor
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 2Country Woman, a 34foot Petersondesigned sloop from Chicago, is the unofficial and disputed overall winner of the first race of the 1974 Southern Ocean Racing Conference, a 101mile contest from St. Petersburg to Anclote Key and return.

title: New Health Units Have Empty Beds
description: ST. JAMES, L. I.A latecomer to the field of health institutionsthe health related facilityis being underut??llized in Suffolk County because not enough people know its purpose, according to a state health official.

title: Food: For a winter's night
description: Like juniper berries and sauerkraut or nutmeg and spinach, one of the great food pairings is a fine roast pork with pured lentils. We offer here two roasts of pork and a recipe for the lentils. The first pork recipea soaringly good dish cooked with mustard requires a specialty item called caul or lace fat that is rarely found in supermarkets. It is available in fine butcher shops, however, particularly those that specialize in pork products. Two of these in Manhattan that come readily to mind are G. Esposito, 500 Ninth Avenue, and Carmine Castaldo, 85 Mulberry Street.

title: Ballet: Ashton's Redone Patineurs
description: The unannounced refurbishing of Frederick Ashton's Les Patineurs has been one of the most gratifying aspects of the present American Ballet Theater season at the City Center 55th Street Theater. For years Ballet Theater's production of this British classic had been worthy but smudgyaccurate enough in its outline, but damagingly and irritatingly blurred in its detail. It was tone deaf.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
Paul Pyonin to Wed Karen Schottenfeld
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 2Mr. and Mrs. Alvin C. Schottenfeld have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Schottenfeld, to Paul Pyonin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Pyonin of Union.

title: Stars Lose To Rangers; Vickers: 2
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn.,Feb. 2The New York Rangers won their fifth straight game tonight, beating the Minnesota North Stars, 31, before a capacity crowd of 15,375 at Metropolitan Sports Center.

title: Stamps Skiing Anyone, or Tennis Anyone, or...
description: THERE may not be much snow around here, or gas to get to where there is snow up north, but in Scandinavia there is snow and a new issue from Sweden attests to it.

title: Bridge
description: Close attention to trivial detail is as much the mark of a bridge expert as it is of a famous detective. Inside the house, announced R. Austin Freeman's Dr. Thorndyke, whose application of science and esoteric knowledge to detection outdid Sherlock Holmes, I expect to find a cigaretteor possibly a cigar which has been trodden on, some wholemeal biscuits, possibly a wooden vesta, and perhaps even the missing hat.

title: BRAZIL COURTED BY ARAB NATIONS
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 27 The Arab countries are engaged in a discreet courtship of Brazil, with offers of more oil, trade and investment, if the Brazilians join their camp of friends.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: The Book Review welcomes letters from readers. Letters for publication must include the writer's name and address. Because of the large volume of mail we regret that we cannot acknowledge or return letters.

title: Photography
description: AT the Witkin Gallery through Feb. 17, two West Coast art photographers who have exhibited widely elsewhere are having their first oneman shows in New York. Oliver Gagliani, the more striking of the two, shows blackandwhite prints, all entitled Untitled, in which various objects mysteriously glow white out of a surrounding darkness. The objects include a curtained window, an upright piano, a pattern of cracks in a wall, a ceiling covered with garish wallpaper and a grassy field streaked with sunlightbut the photographer's interest is clearly not in the objects themselves so much as in the mysterious glowing effects

title: The Siege of Atlanta, 1864
description: The scope of this book is much larger than the title indicates. It begins with secession and concludes with the inception of Reconstruction; and it recounts briefly the history of Georgia and Atlanta from their origins to 1866. Fifteen of the 20 chapters, however, are devoted to the war in Georgia, 18641865, and the major emphasis is on Atlanta. In portraying the conquest of Georgia the author gives about equal attention to invaders and invaded. His principal sources are the published memoirs, diaries and letters of warriors and civilians; and by skillful shifts of focus from Federals to Confederates and from fighting line to home front, he permits eyewitnesses to unfold the drama in which they are involved. In portraying Federal activities, the author makes excellent and abundant use of the experiences recorded by generals, especially Sherman, by subordinate officers, such as James Connolly, and by common soldiers, including Elisha Stockwell and Theodore Upson. In presenting the Confederate side, he draws heavily on the comments of Generals Bragg, Johnston and Hood, and on the narratives of Capt. Thomas Key, Lieut. Andrew Neal, Sgt. John Hagan, Pvt. Sam Watkins, Kate Cumming, Mary Gay, S. P. Richards and members of the Jones family whose letters comprise Children of Pride.

title: CONGRESS WEIGHS TELEVISING ITSELF
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2After years of isolation and indecision, Congress is finally making a serious study of permitting radio and television to broadcast part or all of Senate and House sessions.

title: Hearing Planned On Fluoridation
description: TRENTON  The state's Department of Environmental Protection, which seeks to adopt rules calling for mandatory fluoridation of New Jersey's public water supplies, will hold an open hearing on the matter on Feb. 28. The hearing will take place in the War Memorial Building here, beginning at 10 A.M.

title: No Change Expected This Year in State Law on Election Campaigns
description: ALBANY, Feb. 2Two key electionlaw experts have agreed that there is little likelihood of enacting major reform of the electioncampaign laws in time for this year's state contests.

title: Another mad housewife
description: A ripped and crumpled family photograph decorates the dust jacket of this new and fifth novel by Sue Kaufman, author of Diary of a Mad Housewife. Another book about the breakdown and impossibility of marriage/family/parenthood? Not so. This is yet another book about the plight of the housewifeno feminist tract, but a mocking portrayal of female ineffectuality. Impossible, even irresponsible in 1974? Almost. Funny at least? Scarcely.

title: Joan R. Wilson Has Nuptials
description: NATICK, Mass., Feb. 2Miss Joan Ramsay Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ramsay Wilson of Greenwich and Old Lyme, Conn., and James Ballard Brooks of Wellesley, Mass., were married here this afternoon by Justice of the Peace Sara L. Johnson at her office.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: The business of trading Government bonds has had a certain allure for Wall Street in recent years. Everybody took note when Salomon Brothers reported $55million in total profits in 1971, and brokers beset with a profits squeeze began to figure that securities firms should start trading Governments.

title: MORE SNOW IS DUE IN THE CITY TODAY
description: Sleet, freezing rain and snow fell on the metropolitan area yesterday and was expected to continue through this afternoon, with the accumulation of snow expected to be less than an inch.

title: Two Tanks In Every Tent
description: WASHINGTONThe political and economic consequences of the energy oriels at home are obviousunemployment now at 4,700,000 and going up; prices and inflation increasing  but the longrange consequences in the world at large are even more disturbing.

title: Gardens
description: WINTER snowbirds (Floridian expression for migrating vacationers) are heading South. When they alight, they find tropical flora in complete contrast to the bleak scene they left back home.

title: ShotPut Takes Spotlight In Track Meet on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2The shotputters upstaged the traditionally more glamorous runners and jumpers at last night's San Francisco Examiner Games as George Woods raised his world indoor record to 70 feet 4 inches, and the three strongmen involved don't see any reason why they can't keep their new share of the spotlight.

title: Egypt's Top Editor Is Ousted by Sadat
description: CAIRO, Feb. 2Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, one of Egypt's most powerful political figures for the last 20 years, has been abruptly relieved of his posts as chief editor and chairman of the board of Al Ahram, the country's most influential newspaper.

title: George E. Olson Fiance Of Miss Sarah Williams
description: BURTON, Wash., Feb. 2The engagement of Miss Sarah Gilmore Williams to George Edward Olson has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Andrew M. Williams, parents of the future bride. Her flanc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Olson of Arlington.

title: KILLINGS STIR FEAR IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2In little more than two hours last Monday night four persons were killed and another person was seriously wounded in a shooting spree that brought uncharacteristic alarm to this city that takes pride in its coolness.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiary unless otherwise indicated:

title: Two U.S. Bankers Among 179 to Die In Sao Paulo Fire
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Feb. (AP)Investigators today began going through the wreckage of a bank building here where fire yesterday left at least 179 people dead, including two American bankers.

title: Kathleen Effler Engaged
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Feb. 2Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Ct Effler have announced the: engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Ann Effler to Lieut. John Bradley Marvin, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Everett D. Marvin Jr. of Norman, Okla. The future bridegroom graduated in 1972 from the United States Military Academy and is stationed at Fort Bragg, N. C.

title: GUERRILLAS SEIZE GREEK FREIGHTER
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sunday, Feb. 3  Three gunmen seized a Greek freighter in the port of Karachi yesterday and said they would blow up the ship and kill two hostages unless the Greek Government freed two Arab terrorists who are under sentence of death.

title: CHINA BIBLIOGRAPHY ISSUED BY STANFORD
description: After 10 years' work and at a cost of $750,000, the Stanford University Press has published the first comprehensive bibliography covering works about China since the beginning of the Manchu dynasty in 1644.

title: Look at What Forecasters Do Right
description: The failure of most economists to foresee the outburst of inflation during 1973 should not obliterate their forecasting achievements in other respects.

title: Gateway Planners Focus on Riis Park
G. Joseph Runde Will Marry Nan Smith
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 2Mrs. Powers Smith has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Nan Marie Smith, to G. Joseph Runde, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald J. Runde of East Dubuque, Ill.

title: The Tsodilo Hills in Botswana Are Called The World's Greatest Outdoor Art Gallery
description: HOW does a safari widow spend her time in the bush while her husband goes off in pursuit of wild game? If she happens to be in the wilds of Botswana in southern Africa, she can find a Kalahari Bushman guide and tour the Tsodilo Hills, which contain more than 2,000 Stone Age rock paintings.

title: Yacht Trophy Makes Race Worth Winning
description: When David Swing Starring decided to donate a trophy to the Pequot Yacht Club of Southport, Conn., to go to the winner of the annual Faulkner Island race, he wanted something different. He got it.

title: Jean M. Buist Fiancee of Jeffrey Algatt
description: SPARTA, N. J., Feb. 2Miss Jean Morford Buist and Jeffery Raymond Algatt plan to be married June 29.

title: Kerr on The Seagull and Bread
description: SOMEHOW or other there seem to be a few more symbols in The Seagull than there once were. When the various people who are in mourning for their lives reassemble in Act Fourafter Trigorin has seduced and abandoned Nina and everyone has been away for a year or twoone of the first things they notice is that the old outdoor stage on which young Konstantin, used to give his performances has never been taken down. It's raining now, and the tattered structure can scarcely be made out across the lawn. But there it is, standing in bad weather like a Skeleton, its curtains blowing in the wind. How did Chekhov know that our theaterwhich is very much hiswould come to this? Well, he was a farseeing man.

title: How the Oil Companies Pay Taxes
description: At a time when public attention has been directed towaro the oil industry's earnings performance, Congress, the press and the general public are asking questions about the taxes it pays.

title: Austin Peay Is Upset By L.I.U. in Overtime
description: James (Fly) Williams, the ghetto basketball star, came home yesterday to show the skills that had helped put Austin Peay University on the national basketball map. But although he scored 31 points and grabbed 12 rebounds, his team was upset in overtime, 90.88, by Long Island University at Madison Square Garden.

title: MORE SNOW IS DUE IN THE CITY TODAY
description: Sleet, freezing rain and snow fell on the metropolitan area yesterday and was expected to continue through this afternoon, with the accumulation of snow expected to be less than an inch.

title: Charmed Circle
description: When it comes to Gertrude Stein and Company, we all curse our bad luck in being born too late to be part of the astonishing artistic revolution in modernism that took place in the years 190014 and whose nerve center was the salon at 27 Rue de Fleurus, presided over by two California Jews. Reading about it is like leafing through a wellthumbed album of our cultural and artistic beginnings; we shake our heads in wonder and disbelief at the profligate riches of a Golden Age. There they are: Picasso in his monkey suit, with his piercing black eyes, looking like a satyr; Matisse, the very model of an imposing middleclass Frenchman; Marie Laurencin and Apollinaire; the art dealers  Kahnweiler, Vollard and Sagot; the bit players, gobetweens like H. P. Roch, author of Jules and Jim, who knew everybody in Paris and introduced the Steins to Picasso; and later on  in the twenties  Hemingway, Fitzgerald and Sherwood Anderson.

title: Hearings on Ferry Resume Feb. 20
description: GREENPORT, L. I.Hearings on a second ferry service linking eastern Long Island to Connecticut will resume in Washington on Feb. 20, David Allard, administrative law judge of the Interstate Commerce Corn mission announced last week.

title: The People of Flanders Achieve Status in LanguageThe Dutch They Speak
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 2  Inhabitants of Flanders, the northern part of Belgium, praise, the glories of their Flemish culture, which, include Van Eyck, Rubens and the graceful architecture of the cities of Bruges, Ghent and Brussels.

title: What's Doing in the SKI COUNTRY
description: GETTING THERELeave your car at home if you are worried about gasoline and travel instead by bus, train or plane, but remember that these do not provide doortodoor service; you may have to thumb a ride from the nearest stop to your inn and from there to the slopes. Hunter Mountain in New York's northern Catskills has chartered. about 100 buses that make neighborhood stops on weekends in New York City's five boroughs and Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester Counties. Call Hunter at 5182634223. Harry Vallin, the proprietor of New York's four Scandinavian Ski Shops (2127578524), sends buses to the Catskills and New England on weekends and some weekdays. The Killington, Vt., ski area (8024223333) has lots of information on buses arriving there from many northeastern points. Amtrak's nightly train from Washington to Montreal, via New York, Hartford and Springfield, makes stops close to many Vermont ski centers. The coach fare from New York to Waterbury, Vt., is $16, one way. Call Amtrak at 2127364545. Allegheny Airlines runs five daily flights from New York to Burlington, Vt., the gateway to some of the Northeast's best ski country. The oneway fare, including tax, is $38.64, and Allegheny's number is 2127373200. Vermont's Bromley, Stowe, Mount Snow and Stratton areas and the five centers in New Hampshire's Ski 93 country (Cannon, Loon, Waterville Valley, Temple and Mittersill) all provide shuttle bus service to and from skiers' lodgings. Powder Ridge, Conn. (2033493454) sells a combination liftboat ticket for $19.50 for Long Islanddwelling skiers. They are transported across the Sound by boat on Sundays and are met by bus at Bridgeport. The boat departs Port Jefferson, L. I. at 7:30 A.M.

title: Saving Money on Men's Clothes
description: Everyone loves a bargain and purchasers of men's clothes are no exception. So what's the story?

title: Peters Valley Shop Being Refurbished
description: PETERS VALLEY  The Crafts Shop here will be closed for refurbishing until March 30. The shop offers for sale articles produced by craftsmen who live and work in this village in western Sussex County.

title: Golan: Fouled by the Wars
description: JERUSALEMThe flat, basaltblack plateau is littered with the debris of war. Twisted, burnedout wrecks that once were tanks or armored personnel carriers are scattered like corpses in the rocky fields. Coils of rusted barbed wire line the roads. Small red triangular signs warn of mines. Here and there stand the shattered, roofless remains of a stone house or building.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: CHAPPAQUIDDICK, Mass. Carry a Danforthtype anchor in your fourwheeldrive vehicle, and if you also have a winch you'll never have to worry about being stuck on the beach.

title: The Munroe women's choices
description: Fashion: All in the family

title: Boyle Trial March 25
description: MEDIA, Pa., Feb. 2 (AP) The murder trial of the former president of the United Mine Workers, W. A. Boyle, has been scheduled for March 25 in this Philadelphia suburb. Mr. Boyle is accused in the stayings of Joseph A. Yablonski and Mr. Yablonski's wife ands daughter.

title: Recordings
description: THERE'S a strange schizoid look these days to RCA's classical product (as the trade calls it). On the one hand this label has recently released such notable and valuable issues as the complete Rachmaninoff recordings, Messiaen's Visions de l'Amen played by Peter Serkin and Yuji Takahashi, Verdi's I Vespri Siciliani and Berio's Recital I; on the other hand one notes such weird items as Eleanor Steber at the Continental Baths (RCA ARL 10436), the Yellow River Concerto (RCA ARL 10415) and Barry Morell Sings Bellini (RCA ARL 10135)party records if you're in a charitable mood, examples of corporate cynicism if you're not.

title: WALL STREET
description: In the five years since they peaked out as an investment group, railroad stocks have traveled along a bumpy roadbed. Mounting labor costs and erratic profit performance have been among the negative factors.

title: Red Smith
description: Frank Graham Jr. has a piece in the January issue of the magazine Audubon about the calamitous decline of the herring fishery along the coast of Maine and its effects upon the state's sardine canning industry. A week or so ago when the FrazierAli fight was making headlines, Nelson Bryant referred to the Graham piece in his column in The New York Times. Now, mention of fishing does not automatically make one think of prize fighting unless you hark back to the days of Benny Bass and Kingfish Levinsky, but this time the juxtaposition of Bryant's column and a story on boxing brought to mind Bud Leavitt's tale of the Tigers and the Sardines.

title: A new examination of Christian theology
description: Although she uses language that may intimidate uninformed laity and clergy and that may outrage the uncritical, orthodox religious adherent, Mary Daly's book may well be the good news for modern womanand man. She is postulating a new theology and she goes immediately to the point: The roles and structures of patriarchy have been developed and sustained in accordance with an artificial polarization of human qualities into the traditional sexual stereotypes.

title: TIES TO PRESIDENT VEX MAYORS UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  At a reception here Thursday, Richard J. Daley, the longtime Mayor of Chicago, and Coleman Young, Mayor of Detroit for one month, engaged in a rather lively debate about how city leaders should deal with the Nixon Administration.

title: Beanie's In House Work Policy Is Debated
description: Three weeks ago the head of a labor union representing 5,000 Civil Service workers stood up at a Board of Estimate meeting in City Hall and wrung from Mayor Beame and his top lieutenants a basic commitment.

title: 2 Americans Speed Skating Point Leaders
description: DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 2 (AP)Sheila Young and Peter Muller led a strong American delegation today in the opening events of an international skating meet run in conjunction with the Swiss national sprint championships.

title: Short Courses Are Scheduled
description: THE various botanic gardens and horticultural societies in the metropolitan region conduct short courses for gardeners on wide ranges of topics. Class titles follow with the details where to obtain information on registration and fees.

title: PRAGUE '67 DEATH IS LAID TO ARABS
description: LONDON, Feb. 2A Czecho slovak intelligence officer who defected to the United States five years ago has cast new light on the mysterious 1967 death in Prague of Charles H Jordan, a prominent American Zionist. The defector is now living in the United States under an assumed name.

title: Curacao: To Like the Place You Have to Accept the Pace
description: IMIGHT have sensed that Curacao was not exactly a vacation paradise when, lured by an advertisement offering an eightday airfarehotel package for only $208, I dropped into a travel agent's office. Curacao? she said ??s she studied the ad. Well, all right, but the beaches are nicer on Aruba.

title: Dr. Lazar Schonfeld Dead; Former Rabbi of Hungary, 93
description: Dr. Lazar Schonfeld, chief rabbi of Hungary and a former broadcaster for the Voice of America,; died Friday in Maimonides Hospital, Brooklyn. He Was 93 years old and lived at 934 46th Street, Brooklyn.

title: Turning Off the Lights Does Save Electricity
description: It's just a myth that turning a light on and off uses up a lot of electricity, according to Consolidated Edison Company calculations in the current energy shortage.

title: On the Waterfront, Local Boards Sift Builders' Plans
description: Development plans that will have a major effect on the city's 400 miles of waterfront are moving gradually toward fulfillment, shaped in part by the attitudes of community planning boards.

title: Group Learns Art of Fighting City Hall
description: By MURRAY SCHUMACH

title: Barzilauskas and Browne To Bolster Jets at Tackle
description: Carl Barzilauskas and Gordon Browne don't figure to be names on the roster of one of the teams in next season's Super Bowl, but they could help provide a new and improved look for the Jets and their new coach next fall.

title: Clean  Water Bill Gains in Congress
description: Although a major Congressional hurdle was cleared last week for a bill that would provide $24million to clean up New York's waterways and to replenish eroded sections of the Rockaway beachfront, sources in the Federal and city governments expressed fears that the money might never be spent.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The profession of politics is at best inadequately rewarded despite adjustments in recent years. Government is big business, and yet the compensation chief executives of our major corporations receive shows that we are not rewarding our public officials adequately.

title: ALICE M. EVERSMAN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)  Alice M. Eversman, music critic for The Washington Star from 1932 to 1953, died yesterday in a Fairfax, Va., hospital. She was 88 years old.

title: Cemetery Becoming a Dump
description: A 314yearold cemetery in Jamaica, Queens, has become a dump.

title: How to succeed in nature
description: Sir Peter Medawar begins his foreword to these volumes with the phrase, Niko Tinbergen is one of the grand masters of ethology; and it can only have been a few months after this was written that his judgment received the strongest possible endorsement when Tinbergen joined Medawar in the topmost circle of scientific achievement by being awarded a share of the Nobel Prize for biology in 1972, along with two other eminent ethologists, Konrad Lorenz and Karl Von Frisch. The foundation and buildingup of the doctrine known as ethology is indeed one of the most important and encohraging developments in biology in the last few decades, and almost all their colleagues are likely to feel that the three new Nobel Prize winners have amply earned the honor. That does not at all imply that all biologists accept at face value everything that the selfstyled ethologists have to offer; if they could do so, it is unlikely that anything so universally acceptable would have much bite in it. In fact, as Medawar also points out, Ethology is a controversial and rather

title: Wottle Wins Mile Run At Cleveland
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 2 (AP) Dave Wottle, an Olympic gold medal winner, barely outlasted Eamonn Coghlan, a Villanova University sophomore, tonight in winning the onemile run at the Knights of Columbus indoor track meet. Wottle's time was minutes 3.9 seconds.

title: The Constitution Doesn't Spell Out the Right
description: The Iowa Law Review published an article not long ago called Pot, Prayer, Politics and Privacy: The Right to Cut Your Own Throat in Your Own Way. The title illustrates jurists' strenuous but still fruitless effort to define the right to privacy that President Nixon in his State of the Union address promised to protect.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: City Increases Return on Funds

title: Nixon Drives to Maryland For Weekend With Family
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., Feb. (AP)  President Nixon drove to his Camp David retreat in the Maryland mountains today to spend the weekend with his family, the White House reported.

title: Eschenbach Expresses The Human Experience
description: THE hour was fairly latenearly 11 P.M.when Christoph Eschenbach, the German pianist, telephoned: I'm sorry frit. calling so late, he said, speaking in a soft Luise (Hello, Flo!) Rainer accent. My plane was horribly delayed, ... it only just landed ... I've just gotten to my hotel ... tomorrow will be so frantic ... I'll just shower and change, grab a taxi, and come straight to your apartment now. Is that all right? We can talk far into the night!

title: It's Down the Drain for Rheingold
description: Adolph Boos watches as gallons of foaming beer gush onto the floor of the Rheingold plant in Brooklyn. By the end of the week, 62,000 gallons of beer had gone down the sewer as company officials prepared to close the 119yearold brewery. They said the brewery had lost $9million last year and could no longer operate profitably. Mr. Boos and 1,500 other employes are being laid off.

title: TRANSIT UNION SET FOR WAGE TALKS
description: The Transport Workers Union, bidding for substantial pay increases and protection against further rises in the costofliving, is planning to open negotiations with the New York City Transit Authority on Feb. 5.

title: Police SelfDefense
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 2 (UPI)The United States Court of Appeal for the Eighth Circuit ruled yesterday that a police officer may use a quick punch in the stomach and a few slaps in the face to subdue a violent prisoner. The court upheld a Greene County, Mo., Federal court ruling dismissing a police brutality complaint by a convicted rapist against two deputy sheriffs.

title: Smaller Colleges Now Big on Art
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR  In addition to the betterknown art galleries at Princeton and Rutgers Universities, a number of smaller colleges in New Jersey have established galleries that, like the others, also are open to the public.

title: Seton Hall to Get An Expanded Pub
description: SOUTH ORANGEAn aplication by Seton Hall University's Student Government to enlarge the facilities of its campus pub has been approved by this Essex County town.

title: Article 1  No Title
U.S. AIDES WORRIED BY TRUCK PROTEST
description: The Federal energy chief, William E. Simon, and three Cabinet members last night termed the shutdown by independnt truckers a serious threat to the nation's economic wellbeing and safety, appealing to the nation's Governors for their personal assistance to restoring order and commerce.

title: FIRING IS INTENSEON GOLAN HEIGHTS
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 3Israelis and Syrians exchanged tank and artillery fire throughout the day today while Israelis and Egyptians were preparing for a mutual pullback of forces and weapons from the Suez Canal zone tomorrow.

title: Mrs. David Is Married to S. P. Salzman
description: GREAT NECK, L.I., Feb. 3 Mrs. Marilyn Jean Bzura David of Bayside, Queens, was married here this after noon to Stanley P. Salzman, a member of the New York law firm of Friesner & Salz man. Rabbi Robert Widom performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom.

title: Snobbery About One's Address Remains Alive in the City, and in Some Old Familiar Aspects
description: The new upper middle class of Manhattan has a different life style from its elders, so they say. On closer examination, though, perhaps it's not very different.

title: 5 Indicted in Equity Funding Collapse Change Pleas to Guilty Before Trial
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 3Five; lof the 22 persons indicted for fraud in the collapse of the Equity Funding corporation of Americaincluding the former second highest officer  have changed their pleas to guilty as the criminal litigation has moved closer to trial.

title: FIRING IS INTENSE ON GOLAN HEIGHTS
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 3Israelis and Syrians exchanged tank and artillery fire throughout the day today while Israelis and Egyptians were preparing for a mutual pullback of forces and weapons from the Suez Canal zone tomorrow.

title: ELIZABETH STARTS FUEL RATION PLAN
description: The mayor of Elizabeth, N.J., a city surrounded by oil refineries, yesterday proclaimed state of emergency and ordered service stations, starting today, to sell gasoline to vehicles with evennumbered license plates on evennumbered dates and oddnumbered plates on oddnumbered dates.

title: $2.4Million Pledged to Palsy
description: A record $2,424,624 was pledged to United Cerebral Palsy during a nationwide telethon that began at 10 P.M. on Saturday and ended at 7 P.M. last night. The program, here on WORTV, had Dennis James and Jane Pickens as masters of ceremonies and Paul Anka as talent host, with many other entertainment stars participating.

title: Grenada Begins a Week Of Independence Events
description: ST. GEORGES, Grenada, Feb. 3 (AP)A oneweek program of independence ceremonies opened today amid growing tension over the impasse between Prime Minister Eric Gairy and his opponents.

title: Nixon Legislation on Cash for Poor Expected to Go to Congress by Spring
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The Nixon Administration plans to propose in March a sweeping program of cash assistance to the nation's poor that would replace, not merely reform, present housing and welfare systems.

title: U.S. Expands Swap Pact With Italy to $3Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) Reflecting the growing strength of the dollar in world money markets, the Government announced today an expanded $3billion currency agreement with Italy.

title: JUDGE PROPOSES ECONOMY COURT
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 3  Th?? American Bar Association wa?? urged today to back the crea?? tion of an economy court. The public could afford to tak?? their civil disputes there, pro?? ponents say, because no privat?? lawyers would be permitted to practice in the court.

title: BEAN PRESENTS A FUELOIL PLAN
description: Mayor Beanie said yesterday that he had asked the Federal Energy Office to divert at least 800,000 barrels of domestic crude oil daily to Caribbean refineries to produce fuel oil to make up a 25 per cent shortage in fuel for heating large apartment buildings and institutions here.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: Mayer Downs Graebner
description: TOWSON, Md., Feb. 3 (UPI)Alex (Sandy) Mayer, 22, defeated Clark Graebner, 62, 61, today to win the $20,000 Baltimore international tournament. The 30yearold Graebner, an alumnus of five Davis Cup teams, could not match the methodical placements of his amateur opponent.

title: SENSITIVE PLAYING BY HANANI, CELLIST
description: There were few grounds for complaint at Yehuda Hanani's Tully Hall recital Saturday night. The young Israeliborn, Juilliardtrained cellist is an accomplished technician, a scrupulous musician, and on this particular occasion, a sensitive although somewhat reserved interpreter.

title: JACKIE KANNON, 48, COMEDIAN, IS DEAD
description: Jackie Kannon, the nightclub comedian who rose to fame with an act in his Rat Fink Club in the early nineteensixties, died Friday night, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 320 Central Park West, Friends gave his age as 48.

title: News Summary and Index MONDAY, FEBRUARY 4, 1974
description: International Israelis and Syrians exchanged tank and artillery fire throughout the day while Israelis and Egyptians were preparing to pull back forces and weapons from the Suez Canal zone today. At nightfall, military headquarters in Tel Aviv said there were no Israeli casualties in the day's fighting, and no estimate of enemy losses was given, in accordance with policy. [1:1.]

title: Robert Kinderman and Wife Crash Victims in Pagopago
description: Robert H. Kinderman, a retired vice president of the Allied Chemical Corporation, and his wife, the former Loraine E. Loewe, died Saturday in Pagopago, American Samoa, of injuries suffered in Thursday's crash of a Pan American jetliner. The 61yearold couple, former residents of Morristown, N.J. living in Sun City, Ariz., were on a vacation trip.

title: Pop Music: Nassau Host To Great Folk Revival
description: The wave of musical nostalgia rolls onnow folk music, heavy vogue of the early nineteensixties, gets its chance. A Great Folk Revival unveiled itself Saturday at the Nassau Coliseum on Long Island with a large cast of veteran performers who appeared before a small audience and American Broadcasting Company television cameras. The show will be screened as a latenight music special Wednesday at 11:30.

title: Arafat Condemns Seizure
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 3Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, today condemned the seizure of the Greek ship in Karachi.

title: A.P.I., the Oil Lobby
description: The taxexempt American Petroleum Institute, with a budget of $15.7million and reserves of $7.6million, is intensifying its efforts to influence state and Federal legislation in behalf of the oil industry, particularly the major oil companies. Article appears on Page 43.

title: Canadiens Win by 41 From Wings
description: DETROIT, Feb 3 (AP)Murray Wilson scored two goals on assists from Henri Richard and Claude LaRose to pace the Montreal Canadiens to a 41 National Hockey League victory today over the Detroit Red Wings in a nationally televised game.

title: Wooden Is in a Tense New World as U.C.L.A. Finds Winning a Little More Difficult
description: John Wooden's usual calm and unemotional coaching style of recent seasons is undergoing some changes. Though for the most part the University of California, Los Angeles's basketball coach is still able to sit with his legs crossed and a rolled up program in his hands, there have been a few times this season the Bruins have forced him to show more than his usual concern. It comes with having to win close games.

title: Judith Blegen Stars As Nygaard Leads Mozart's Pastore
description: Jens Nygaard is one of this area's more adventuresome musical entrepreneurs. But nothing he has done recently can have surpassed the concert version of Il Re Pastore that he and his Westchester Chamber Orchestra offered yesterday afternoon. The concert took place at the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association at 54 Nagle Street in Washington Heights, but it deserved major midtown exposure.

title: Leafs Tie Sabres, 33
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 3 (UPI) Rick Kehoe scored an unassisted goal in the middle of the third period tonight to give the Toronto Maple Leafs a 33 tie with the Buffalo Sabres.

title: LEGAL AID PROGRAM FOR INDIGENT JEWS
description: The American Jewish Congress has begun pilot projects around the country to bring legal aid to poor and aged Jews.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Bronx received its first mobile hospital emergency room yesterday for the treatment of casualties at the scenes of explosions, fires, multiple car wrecks and other disasters. The hospital on wheels, the fourth in the city, will parked at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Canter, whose own emergency room will staff the van when needed.

title: Energy Crisis: Town Hungry for Gasoline
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass.  It is 6:45 A.M., 29 degrees, pitch black, and there are 14 cars lined up at the pumps of Ron's Shell Station. Gus and Frank are in constant motion around the two islands, thrusting a hose into another tank as soon as each car pulls out. Their coffee mugs, long cooled, stand untouched on top of two of the pumps.

title: Baraka Constructing a Spiritual, Economic and Political Base for a Worldwide Nation of Blacks
description: NEWARK, Feb. 3In this predominantly black city, the black nationalist Committee for a Unified Newark has an eye on black unity, a foot in controversy and a hand in almost everything.

title: CHASE SUBSIDIARY SIGNS SOVIET PACT
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 3  The Chase World Information Corporation, a subsidiary of the Chase Manhattan Bank, signed an agreement with the State Bank of the Soviet Union Saturday for exchanging business information useful for the promotion of Soviet trade with the West.

title: A.P.I., the Oil Lobby
description: The taxexempt American Petroleum Institute, with a budget of $15.71million and reserves of $7.6million, is intensifying its efforts to influence state and Federal legislation in behalf of the oil industry, particularly the major oil companies. Article appears on Page 43.

title: Theater: A Bare Lear
description: It was a bare Lear that opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music yesterday afternoon. The Actors Company from Britain was giving the world premiere of David William's staging of King Lear. Unfortunately, the scenery and costumes were delayed in transit. The British troupe decided that the show must go on even if the scenery and costumes couldn't, so the actors, dressed in casual sweaters, performed against bare curtains.

title: Some Harlem Gasoline Stations Stay Open to Protect Property
description: A handful of gas stations in Harlem were open yesterday, not to sell gas, but to guard against vandalism.

title: Mrs. King Victor by 60, 62
description: FAIRFAX, Va., Feb. 3Culminating a fivestar performance in the Virginia Slims of Washington tennis tournament, Mrs. Billie Jean King zipped through Kerry Melville of Australia, 60, 62, today and won $10,000.

title: Gilbert Scores 2 for Record But Stars Tie Rangers, 5 to 5
description: The New York Rangers and Minnesota North Stars, a bit pooped from a game the night before, a 1,000mile flight and a 3 A.M. bedtime, scrambled to a 5.5 tie last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Mariner 10 Will Send CloseUp Pictures of Venus
description: PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 3On Tuesday morning, shortly before 7 A.M. Eastern daylight time, if all goes well the first closeup pictures of Venus, earth's nearest, planetary neighbor, should begin reaching a giant antenna at Goldstone, Calif.

title: Nixon Back in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UPI) President Nixon arrived here tonight from Camp David, Md., by car with Mrs. Nixon and their daughter, Mrs. Edward P. Cox.

title: Rev. Joseph F. Maguire, Led Queens Interracial Panel
description: The Rev. Joseph F. Maguire, administrator of St. Pius Roman Catholic Church, Jamaica, Queens, since 1969, died Friday of a heart attack in the rectory. He was 53 years old.

title: TAX BREAKS FOR OIL ARE CALLED FAILURE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP)A Senate study has found that tax breaks granted to the petroleum industry as an incentive to further exploration are inefficient in stimulating new supplies of oil. It estimates that the tax breaks cost the Treasury more than $1.5 billion a year in revenues.

title: GOV. SHAPP URGES TRUCK TIEUP HALT AND VOWS RELIEF
description: WASHINGTON, Monday, Feb. 4  Gov. Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania, chairman of the MidAtlantic Conference of Governors, asked independent truckers yesterday to declare a 45day moratorium on their strike and promised quick governmental action to relieve their hardships.

title: L.I. Physician's Trial Raises Problem of a Doctor's Relationship With a Dying Patient
description: The Mineola trial of Dr. Vincent A. Montemarano in the death of Eugene Bauer brings to public attention once again the unusually complex problems concerning the doctorpatient relationship during the treatment of the endstages of a chronic illness and in the moments just before death.

title: Solzhenitsyn Angrily Answers Charge of Informing on Friend
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 3Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn today angrily reacted to charges that he had informed on the school, friend with whom he had exchanged the correspondence criticizing Stalin that led to their arrests during World War II.

title: Oil Industry, Through A.P.I., Intensifies Lobbying Efforts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 With oil prices, taxes and profits under the most intense scrutiny in decades, the industry's richest trade association, the American Petroleum Institute, is intensifying its efforts to influence state and Federal legislation and public opinion.

title: Trying to Explain to a Young Son Why His Father Must Go to Jail
description: WASHINGTONTo an 8yearold, jail is a scary word, said Egil Krogh Jr. You can't be too analytical. You talk about right and wrong. You try to explain that his father has to go to jail to make clear what is right.

title: Poking Around in Cornflakes in Londonderry
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern IrelandOn Boxing Day the family in No. 14 noticed that the key to their front door had been removed from the lock, shortly after a British Army foot patrol had passed. On New Year's Eve, shortly after another foot patrol passed, the key to No. 16 was missing, and also to our house, No. 8.

title: Joint Action on Oil
description: The Administration's offer to discuss emergency sharing of energy resources at next week's Cabinetlevel Washington conference of the oilconsuming countries provides the essential element that up to now has been lacking in efforts to achieve a significant cooperative action program.

title: INDIA TO CUT BACK ON OIL PURCHASES
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 3India is planning a major reduction in imported oil this year, a move that will stall economic advancement.

title: John Gans, Ship Executive And Kennel Official, Dies
description: John Gans, a retired shipping executive and past president of the German Shepherd Dog Club of America, died Saturday in Staten Island Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 170 Howard Avenue, Grymes Hill, S. I.

title: Woman Teaches How to Save Bread While Making It
description: SUMMIT, Feb. 3It's an oldfashioned concept that has adjusted to the world of today, Judith Mischel said as she kneaded dough in her comfortable kitchen here. With bread prices soaring, and the gasoline shortage affecting shopping trips, breadmaking seems to have an increasing fascination, she said. Mrs. Mischel, who learned to make bread when her husband refused to eat commercially made loaves, now teaches classes limited to six students. The classes begin on the first Monday of each month.

title: LATE CITY EDITION
description: Weather: Partly cloudy, cold today; clearing tonight. Sunny tomorrow. Temp. range: today 1525. Sunday 2223. Additional details on Page 57.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TOURISM Westbeth is an artists community housed since 1970 in the massive, nononsense former Bell Telephone Labs, on the Hudson River at West Street between Bank and Bethune Streets. In it are 384 apartments inhabited by artists, dinners, film makers, writers. It has a community room used as a cabaret, several exhibition galleries, a print workshop and a theater where dance is performed. It's home, but a creative one, something that is reflected in the way this onetime science center has been converted for art.

title: Dutch Overcome Oil Crisis With Good Weather and New Supplies
description: THE HAGUE, Feb. 1The winter has been the mildest in years, and so the Dutch are saying, with the nearest thing to a wicked leer they can muster: Allah is punishing the Arabs.

title: SpeedSkate Title To Dutch Woman
description: ALMA ATA, U.S.S.R., Feb. 3 (PUI)  Mrs. Atje KeulenDielstra of the Netherlands won the European women's speed skating championship today for the third time by placing first in three of four events.

title: Flames, Flyers in Tie
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 3 (AP) Gary Dornhoefer's seventh goal of the season in the middle of the third period, a shot from the right faceoff circle, lifted the Philadelphia Flyers to a 22 tie with the Atlanta Flames tonight in the N.H.L.

title: U.S. and City Investigating Fraudulent Burial Scheme
description: City and Federal agencies are investigating a suspected bodysnatching scheme here by undertakers who may be engaged in payoffs to morgue employes and in fraudulent, inflated billing of public agencies for funeral expenses.

title: ANALYSTS WATCH U.S. REFINANCING
description: Overshadowing this week's entries in the corporate and taxexempt bond markets is the massive $4.05billion refinancing offering of Treasury notes and bonds that will take place over a three day span starting toCredit morrow. MoneyMarkets market analysts are keenly inter ested not only in the volume involved and how it fits into the existing market but also in the impact it will have on rates.

title: LEGAL
description: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN by Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., that on January 28, 1974 it issued and filed with the Public Service Commission amendments to its Electric Rate Schedule PSC No. 8Electricity applicable to its customers within the City of New York and the County of Westchester, to become effective on and as of February 28, 1974.

title: Teachers at State Colleges Threaten to Strike Today
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 3Union negotiators for nearly 2,800 faculty members at eight state colleges and officials of the State Department of Higher Education continued roundtheclock talks here tonight in an effort to avert a strike set for tomorrow morning.

title: Fuel Shortage Revives Connecticut U. Campus
description: STORRS, Conn., Feb. 3By persuasion and a scattering of parking and carpooling privileges, and by generous portions of weekend entertainment, the University of Connecticut is helping to save fuel in these times of crisis and may also be saving a style of campus life that was believed to be all but lost as much as a generation ago.

title: Four Hell's Angels Seized in Beating Of a Coast Man
description: Four members of the Hell's Angels motorcycle gang were arrested early yesterday in lower Manhattan on charges that they had severely beaten a 22yearold man who reportedly lid undercover work for Federal agency against the gang on the West Coast.

title: Personal Finance: The Tax Preparers
description: This year roughly 80 million people will file Federal incometax returns, but some 40 million of them are expected to turn to someone else to fill them outthus generating a business conservatively estimated at $500million a year.

title: The NoFault Society
description: WASHINGTONNofault auto insurance has gone into effect in many states; no longer will drivers, insurance companies and attorneys be haggling in toocrowded courts about who was to blame for wrinkling that fender. The companies will pay up without a fight and the only people to suffer from the new system, we are told, are the lawyers.

title: Monzon, Napoles to Let Fists Talk
description: PARIS, Feb. 3 (AP)  Carlos Monzon arrived here today and immediately engaged in a terse television talk with Jose Napoles, the challenger for the Argentine's middleweight boxing crown.

title: JOHN A. M'GLINN JR., CAMPBELL OFFICIAL
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3  John A. McGlinn Jr., executive vice president and a director of the Campbell Soup Company since 1969, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Gladwyne. He was 62 years old.

title: Beck Wins Drag Race Top Prize
description: POMONA, Calif., Feb. 3Gary Beck, driving an unpainted, Milodonengine dragster, thundered down the quartermile strip today at 243 miles an hour in 5.04 seconds, winning the fuel category at the annual Winternationals.

title: Trucking of Florida's Crops To the North Starts Again
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 3  The outlook for movement of Florida's citrus and vegetable crops improved this weekend as drivers of petroleum trucks started rolling again and the men who drive the food to market headed North in nearnormal numbers.

title: What He Really Meant
description: WASHINGTON Mr. Speaker, Mr. President, my colleagues in the Congress. We meet here tonight at a time of great challenge...

title: Marray (the K) Leaving Weekend Radio Shows
description: Murray (the K) Kaufman, who was one of the city's most prominent disk jockeys in his heyday in the nineteenfifties and sixties announced on radio station WNBC last night that his regular weekend shows were being discontinued.

title: Hussein and Heath Talk
description: WENDOVER, England, Feb. (AP)King Hussein of Jordan traveled to Chequers, the country estate of Prime Minister Heath, today for talks about the Middle East and the world energy crisis. Hussein is to leave for the United States later this week.

title: GORDON HOLLINGWORTH
description: BOSTON, Feb. 3 (AP)Gordon (Bucky) Hollingworth, a former hockey player with the Chicago Black Hawks and the Detroit Red Wings of the National League, died after long illness Saturday at the New England Medical Center. He was 40 years old.

title: Indonesia to Lift Oil Output
description: JAKARTA, Feb. 3 (Reuters)  Indonesia will raise her annual oil production by 8 per cent within the next five years to 720 million barrels from 529 million, Mining Minister D. Mohammad Sadli said today.

title: What Is Subversive?
description: Alongside the famous cases of the Chicago 7, the Gainesville 8 and the Camden 28, the overdrawn early campaign of the Nixon Administration against socalled domestic subversives continues to touch the lives lesser known people in farflung parts of the country.

title: Skate Title To Dutch Woman
description: ALMA ATA, U.S.S.R., Feb. 3 (PU1)  Mrs. Atje KeulenDielstra of the Netherlands won the European women's speed skating championship today for the third time by placing first in three of four events.

title: Rebuilding the House
description: Resentment over the gradual erosion of Congress' role as originator of policy and initiator of legislation has at last led to a hard bipartisan look at the workings of the committee system in the House of Representatives and a plan for its rearrangement and reform.

title: TV: 2 C.B.S. Surprises
description: Two specials tonight on the Columbia Broadcasting System network are surprising. An animated version of Hans Christian Andersen's The Little Mermaid, which has ripe potential as children's entertainment, is only adequate. On the other hand, still another Mitzi Gaynor showcase, usually flashy stuff with the star outgrimacing baby Shirley Teinple, is very tasty indeed. Both Miss Gaynor and her format have becomingly toned down.

title: Bulls Post No. 8
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 3 (UPI) Jerry Sloan hit on 11 of 14 shots and equaled his season high of 25 points tonight as the Chicago Bulls ran their winning streak to eight games with a 10894 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers. It was the eighth consecutive game in which the Bulls had held their opponents below 100 points.

title: 12 BRITISH SOLDIERS KILLED IN BUS BLAST
description: BATLEY, England, Monday, Feb. 4 (AP)  An explosion ripped through a bus on highway near the Yorkshire town of Batley early today and killed 12 soldiers, the police said.

title: GOV. SHAPP URGES TRUCK TIEUP HALT AND VOWS RELIEF
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3Gov. Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania, chairman of the MidAtlantic Conference of Governors, asked independent truckers today to declare a 45day moratorium on their strike and promised quick governmental action to relieve their hardships.

title: An Oil Scandal Strains Italian Cabinet
description: ROME, Feb. 3An oil scandal that seems linked with the ways political parties in Italy get their funds is straining the sevenmonthold Government of Premier Mariano Rumor.

title: Heath Sets Talks Today On Miners' Strike Vote
description: LONDON, Feb. 3 (Reuters)Britain was awaiting today an expected call for .a national coal strike but was still hopeful that one final attempt at an accord might keep the miners at work.

title: About New York The Face Is Alive and Well in Jersey
description: There Is now Lauren Hutton, who models for Revlon, and is beautiful, and there is Marisa Berenson, who models, acts, summers in St. Tropez and once was called The Queen of the Scene by Newsweek. In the recent past, there have been Jean Shrimpton, Suzy Parker, Verushka and China Mechado, and then, of course, there was Christina Paolozzi, who made cultural history by posing nude for Harper's Bazaar in 1962.

title: Fatigued Phnom Penh Awaits Foe's Next Push
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 3The two million people in this fatigued city, most of them refugees from the war that has raged in the countryside and chewed at the city's fringes for nearly four years, are doing what they have done since the war beganwaiting nervously for the next attempt by enemy troops to choke them off or to penetrate the city itself.

title: Vietnamese Renew Battle Along Cambodian Border
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 3 (Reuters)The South Vietnamese command today reported heavy fighting in Quang Duc Province along the Cambodian border.

title: Horses & Equipment
description: REG. BAY Thorobred Gelding, 7 yrs old, 16.3, eligible for 1st year green & amateur owner. 516 CU 54876; 516 CU 54643, 516 9310933 (Barn).

title: Rev. Dr. Lawrence McMaster, Presbyterian Synod Head, Dies
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 3The Rev. Dr. Lawrence W. McMaster, executive of the United Presbyterian Synod of the Covenant, which covers the central states, died here yesterday of a heart attack. He was 44 years old and formerly lived in Cedar Grove, N. J.

title: ASTRONAUTS TAKE A WALK FOR FILM 2 Extol a Pretty Country on Final Stroll in Space
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 3 (AP)Two Skyjab astronauts took a stroll in space today to unload film from an array of telescope cameras and recover thousands of photos of the sun, distant stars and the comet Kohoutek.

title: Islanders Turned Back by Seals, 4 to 2
description: OAKLAND, Feb. 3The trick of coming from two goals behind, used successfully by the New York Islanders for victories at Chicago and Los Angeles last week, eluded them tonight as they lost to the California Golden Seals, 42. Still the Islanders headed home with the most successful road trip of their two years in the National Hockey League.

title: Bishops in Bolivia Criticize Measures To Restrain Unrest
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 3 The Roman Catholic Church today strongly criticized the Bolivian Government's economic policies and the measures it is using to put down political unrest. It was the second such criticism in a week.

title: JAWORSKI DENIES WHITE HOUSE GAVE ALL NEEDED DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, contradicting President Nixon's assertion in the State of the Union address last Wednesday, said today that he neededand had formally requestedmore tapes and documents than the White House had yet given him.

title: SUPPLY AND COST WORRY BUSINESS
description: The economy will find no relief from critical shortages and record price increases until it is freed from price controls, E. F. Andrews, chairman of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Management, said over the weekend.

title: City Cited by Levitt On Overbilling State For Prisoners' Care
description: ALBANY, Feb. 3State Controller Arthur Levitt said today that New York City had overcharged the state $4.2million in prisonermaintenance costs, by continuing to bill the state for prisoners who had either been released from city custody or been transferred to state institutions.

title: Letters to the Editor Of Impeachment, the President and a Look Ahead
description: T the Editor: With Section 2 of the 25th Amendment now having been successfully utilized, it is perhaps worthwhile to explore the possibilities of Section for use during a Presidential impeachment trial.

title: Advertising: The National Star
description: The National Star, the new national weekly newspaper for people who find their local dailies too intellectual, makes its debut this week with what is said to be the largest promotion budget in newspaper history.

title: Francie Larrieu Sets Pace as Women Steal Track Spotlight in Record Fashion
description: Francie Larrieu believes in vibrations, which is why she managed to lower her world indoor record in the mile last Saturday night in Seattle.

title: U.S. May Equalize Prices of Horne Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The Federal Energy Office announced today a plan to equalize the differences paid by homeowners for domestic and for imported heating oil in the Eastern part of the country.

title: Irate Families Cut Back As Prices of Food Go Up
description: Shoppers across the nation are reacting with anger and frustration to sharply climbing food prices and the dire predictions of worse days to come.

title: Music
description: Year in and year out, and with no fanfare, Frederic Waldman presents generous servings of seldomperformed music of quality with his Musica Aeterna forces at the Metropolitan Museum, and his program Saturday night included three examples of it.

title: Hodge Paces Bruins
description: BOSTON, Feb. 3 (UPI) Ken Hodge of Boston scored three goals in a game for the fourth time in his career as the Bruins beat the Pittsburgh Penguins, 54, tonight to maintain their 8point lead in the N.H.L., East.

title: HERMAN ZARIN
description: Herman Zarin, a retired lawyer who had handled tax matters for the cosmetics and entertainment industries and numbered among his clients Elizabeth Arden and Billy Rose, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 315 Eighth Avenue.

title: La Salle Defeats Temple by 7854
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 (AP)Joe Bryant scored 22 points and Bill Taylor 18 today leading La Salle to a 7854 basketball victory over Temple.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Kugler Accused on Bias Cases

title: U.S. and City Investigating Fraudulent Burial Scheme
description: City and Federal agencies are investigating a suspected bodysnatching scheme here by undertakers who may be engaged in payoffs to morgue employes and in fraudulent, inflated billing of public agencies for funeral expenses.

title: Bullets' 2dHalf Spree Topples Celtics 11299
description: BOSTON, Feb. 3 (UPI)Kevin Porter scored 16 points in the third period today and Elvin Hayes chipped in with 10 as the Capital Bullets defeated the Boston Celtics, 11299.

title: Brazil's Influence Grows, Unifying South America
description: MONTEVIDEO  When Simon Bolivar struggled to liberate the Spanish colonies in South America, the Great Liberator dreamed of two nations on the continent. He never imagined that the Spanish and Portuguese halves of South America could ever be united.

title: A Bad Day for Driving, Which Few Could Do Anyway
description: Car owners who had to abstain from driving yesterday for lack of gas could console themselves that they probably would not have enjoyed it much anyway.

title: Gunmen Free 2 Hostages On Greek Ship in Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 3Two hostages who had been held aboard a Greek freighter for more than 30 hours by three guerrillas were freed tonight after the gunmen received assurances that Athens would lift the death sentences imposed on two Arab terrorists there.

title: NoFault Gives Claimants New Arbitration Method
description: Superintendent of Insurance Benjamin R. Schenck said yes terday that new arbitration procedures under the state nofault insurance law would enable claimants to write to the American Arbitration Associaition to state their dispute and request arbitration.

title: Ramirez Upsets Gottfried
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 3 (AP)  Unseeded Raul Ramiriz of Mexico won the Dayton pro tennis tournament today with a 61, 6.4, 76 victory over second  seeded Brian Gottfried of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Ramirez had eliminated the topseeded player, Jaime Fillol of Chile, in the semifinals.

title: FULBRIGHT FACING A STRONG CONTEST
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.Gov. Dale Bumpers is said to be seriously considering opposing Senator J. W. Fulbright in his bid for a sixth term this year.

title: Sao Paulo, With 189 Dead in Fire, Faults Its Own Outdated Laws
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Feb. 3 Officials are raising their voices in protest against this city's inability to protect its six million inhabitants against fires, even in such modern structures as the bank building in which at least 189 people were killed last Friday.

title: Bernard Botein Dies
description: Bernard Botein, a leader of the New York bar and former Presiding Justice of tilt Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court for Manhattan and the Bronx, died yesterday. Page 32.

title: Held in Painting Theft
description: BROCKTON, Mass., Feb. 3 (AP)  A Brookline man has been ordered held in $25,000 bail following his arraignment on charges stemming from the alleged theft of paintings from a Brookline home. Philip Stevens, 56 years old, was arraigned yesterday in Brockton District Court after he allegedly attempted to sell the paintings to an undercover agent, the police said.

title: De Vicenzo Wins Seniors
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 3 (AP)Roberto de Vicenzo put together five straight birdies in the final round today to win the Professional Golfers' Association Seniors' tournament by three strokes.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Nicklaus Wins by 3 In Hawaii
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 3 (AP) Jack Nicklaus turned back the challenge of youthful Eddie Pearce with a twounderpar 70 and cruised to a threestroke victory today in the $220,000 Hawaiian open golf tournament.

title: Capital Revisions
description: Mayor Beame's $1.7billion capital budget differs some relatively small, but by no means insignificant, details from the budget proposed early last month by the City Planning Commission. Although he trimmed $140 million from the planners' estimates, most of the saving merely reflects deferred funding for projects which the Mayor believes will not reach the construction stage during the new fiscal year.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: Page

title: Irate Families Cut Back As Prices of Food Go Up
description: Shoppers across the nation are reacting with anger and frustration to sharply climbing food prices and the dire predictions of worse days to come.

title: Horsey Set, Oblivious to Gasoline, Steps Into the Winner's Circle
description: The ski industry has been experiencing exquisite agony from the energy crisis, and such sportinggoods businesses as outdoor camping that are linked to automobile transportation are trembling with uncertainty.

title: Shell Sees Tighter Gasoline Squeeze This Month
description: The Shell Oil Company, which supplies 15 per cent or the gasoline used by New York, New Jersey and Connecticut motorists, predicted yesterday that its retail gasoline sales for this month would be off from last month's levels by 5 to 7 per cent.

title: BAD DAY TO DRIVE; FEW CAN ANYWAY
description: Car owners who had to abstain from driving yesterday for lack of gas could console themselves that they probably would not have enjoyed it much anyway.

title: CONCERN ACQUIRES THE DUNHAM CHAIN
description: TRENTON, Feb. 3What is believed to be New Jersey's oldest and largest privately owned Department store, the 119yearold S. P. Dunham & Co., has been sold in a multimilliondollar transaction.

title: Results of Nearby Horse Shows
British Football Results
description: By Reuters

title: Anderson, Burroughs Win Golf
description: LAS CROABES, Puerto Rico, Feb. 3Jeff Burroughs, 22yearold Texas Rangers outfielder, and Bob Anderson, 26, Denver Broncos back, shot a net 60, 11 under par, and won the $30,000 American Airlines golf tourney at El Conquistador Club today.

title: OIL CONCERNS TOLD NOT TO DISCRIMINATE
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 3 (AP)The chief counsel for the Federal Energy Office told major oil companies today that they faced criminal or civil prosecution if they discriminate against independent gasoline dealers in their allocations.

title: JAWORSKI DENIES WHITE HOUSE GAVE ALL NEEDED DATA

title: Miss Schwartz Wed to Pianist
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 3 Miss Frances J. Schwartz, daughter of Mrs. Lucille Schwartz and the late David J. Schwartz of Fort Worth, was married here this afternoon to Donald Paul Sosin, son of Dr. and Mrs, Gene Sosin. Cantor William Wolff performed the ceremony at the Schwartz home.

title: Recovery of Body Delayed

Baxter State Park officials said the body of Tom Keddy, 26 years old, of Wekefield, Mass., would have to remain on a ledge 500 feet from the summit of milehigh Kathandin because it was too dangerous to attempt to bring it down.

title: Transplant Patient Dies
description: PETOSKEY, Mich., Feb. 3 (AP) Robert Smutz, who received a new heart last September at University Hospitals at Madison, Wis., died today in his sleep, family members said. He was 47 years old. Mr. Smutz had returned to his Petoskey home Dec. 16 after undergoing the heart transplant surgery on Sept. 12. The cause of his death was not disclosed.

title: Baraka Building Foundation for Black Nation
description: NEWARK, Feb. 3In this predominantly black city, the black nationalist Committee for a Unified Newark has an eye on black unity, a foot in controversy and a hand in almost everything.

title: RHEINGOLD AGREES ON VACATION PAY
description: Rheingold Breweries agreed yesterday to give $2million in accumulated vacation pay to 1,500 employes thrown out of work by the closing of the Rheingold plant in Brooklyn, but several hundred brewers sitting in at the plant vowed to continue their protest until they could win further concessions from the company.

title: Greece Silent on Arabs
description: ATHENS, Feb. 3The Greek Government, in announcing the release of two hostages taken by guerrillas aboard a Greek freighter in Karachi, did not mention the two Arab terrorists under sentence of death here, whose release the guerrillas had sought in exchange for the hostages. However, qualified sources said that Greece had pledged not to execute the Arabs.

title: On Legislative Needs and Public Confidence
description: WASHINGTONA little more than a quarter of a century ago, President Harry S. Truman was struggling with the lowest popularity rating any President had experienced in the publicopinion polls. Members of his own party were suggesting that he resign or that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower be drafted to replace him as a Presidential candidate in the upcoming Presidential race. But Mr, Truman won the nomination and won the election. And just recently a respected Republican, Sen. Barry Goldwater, said that Mr. Truman might rank as one of our very best Presidents. agree.

title: Two of Wilson's Most Experienced Aides Are Emerging as Top Political Strategists in His Bid for Full Term
description: Two veterans of politics and government who date back to the DeweyTaft era are emerging as Governor Wilson's top political strategists. The two, Harry J. O'Donnell, the Governor's press secretary, and L. Richard Guylay, whose title is special assistant for policy planning, are already planning the broad outlines of the Wilson bid for a full fouryear term this November.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
Amtrak Stuck in Queens By Fallen Power Lines

title: Solzhenitsyn Angrily Answers Charge of Informing on Friend
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 3Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn today angrily reacted to charges that he had informed on the school friend with whom he had exchanged the correspondence criticizing Stalin that led to their arrests during World War II.

description: MOSCOW, Feb. 3  The curtain rises on Arkady Raikin, the Soviet Union's leading comic, in maroon pajamas, lolling on a bed the size of a putting green, too lazy to go to work.
