description: To the armed forces and police of Chile: This area has been liberated by the United Nations and we are free. Keep out.

title: MORE '73 TAXPAYERS GIVING FOR CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) Some taxpayers who passed up a chance last year to earmark $1 of their taxes for financing Presidential campaigns are showing more interest this year, the Internal Revenue Service said. About 13 per cent of the returns already filed this year carry the authorization.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: EDISON, Feb. 3For the last few years, Coach John Sacchi of Middlesex County College has been using his recruiting pitch for high school wrestlers throughout the state: You can get a good lowcost education and wrestle at a lot of schools but here you can get a good lowcost education and wrestle for a national contender.

title: 4 Seized in Thefts Of Costly Fur Hats From Hasidic Jews
description: Four men have been arrested in robberies of expensive, widebrimmed fur hats from Hasidic Jews in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn, the police reported yesterday.

title: COSTA RICA VOTES FOR A NEW LEADR
description: SANJOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 3Some 750.000 Costa Ricans voted today for a new Presididates.

title: South Africa Blacks Go Home to Misery
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Feb. 3 (Reuters)  Mori than two million people, almos a tenth of South Africa's popu lation, will have been uprooter and moved around the country by the time that the white Gov. ernment's plans to create inde. pendent black tribal homeland: are complete.

title: Shell Sees Tighter Gasoline Squeeze This Month
description: The Shell Oil Company, which supplies 15 per cent of the gasoline used by New York, New Jersey and Connecticut motorists, predicted yesterday that its retail gasoline sales for this month would be off fr'm last month's levels by 5 to 7 per cent.

title: FORD IS BUILDING A PLANT IN SPAIN
description: MADRID, Feb. 3  Energy, crisis or no energy crisis, the, Ford Motor Company is proceeding with its plans for one of the biggest industrial invest ments ever made in Spain.

title: Books of The Times
description: KARL MARX. His Life and Thought. By David McLellan. 498 pages. Illustrated. Harper & Row. $12.50.

title: Gorman Loses Final To Nastase
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 3 (AP)Topseeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania, losing his service just once, routed secondseeded Tom Gorman, 62, 63, today and won the singles final in the Fidelity World Championship Tennis tournament.

title: Woeful Waste
description: If the Beame administration is long on the economics of budgetmaking, it is short on esthetics. It proposes now to emulate the Environmental Protection Administration and put concrete waste containers with advertisements on their sides in Central Park. The idea is to save $100,000 by eliminating standard baskets.

title: Fabienne Serrat Captures Giant Slalom World Title
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 3  What was left of a French ski team weakened by disputes was strong enough today to finish first and third in the opening race of the world Alpine championships.

title: Black Colleges Conference
description: The United Negro College Fund said yesterday that leaders in the corporate, foundation and education worlds would convene in Atlanta next month to plan the future of black colleges. A threeday conference will begin March 24.

title: Screen: 'Road Movie':Story of Truckers Is Stolen by Woman
description: Independent truckers have problems. They have to pay off traffic managers to get loads. They have to pay off highway cops when their rigs are overweight. They have to pay off bank loans, and they consider themselves lucky just to be able to keep up the interest payments.Gil (Robert Drivas) and Hank (Barry Bostwick), the independent truckers in Joseph Strick's "Road Movie," have all these problems in spades, but they are not destroyed by the big hauling firms, the banks, the unions or the cops. They are destroyed by a small, furious, frizzy-wigged, highway hooker named Janice (Regina Baff), because they are men."Road Movie," which opened yesterday at the Plaza, was directed by a man (Mr. Strick) and written by a woman (Judith Rascoe) and although their consciousnesses are raised, they're also terribly tangled. "Road Movie" seems to be two separate movies that have had an unprofitable collision. It starts as a neon-beautiful pseudo-documentary about the perils of independent trucking in America today, then slowly evolves into a self-conscious metaphor for the role of Woman in Our Society.Janice, beautifully played by Miss Baff (who received great notices this season when she played in "Veronica's Room" on Broadway), is a first-rate character, a desperate, lonely, bitter woman who, in the course of the film, decides that she's degraded herself for the last time.However, when she walks out on Gil and Hank, after they've rudely kicked her out, she just doesn't slam the door, she undoes the brake on their rig, with results that are so calamitous they have no relation to trucking or anything else. It has the effect of turning the first third of the movie into so much landscape reportage."Road Movie" is the first film that Mr. Strick has made in years not based on a work better left in its original medium ("Tropic of Cancer," "Ulysses," "The Balcony"), and he should be encouraged to pursue this original bent. He's good with actors, and even though he's inclined to beat us over the head with visions of America the Ugly, those visions are undeniably accurate.The real subject of the film is Janice, which is, I suspect, the way the screenplay was written, though it's difficult to tell from all the early footage devoted to the independent trucker, highway life and America's roadside architecture. In her own gum-chewing way, Janice (who is the first woman I've ever seen to hide her money in her wig) is as much of a revolutionary as Nora Helmer. I'd have liked to know more about her than "Road Movie" ever tells us, although Miss Rascoe, a novelist and short story writer, gives her larger heaps of exposition to recite than can be conveniently handled on film.Mr. Drivas and Mr. Bostwick are convincing as two different grades of male chauvinist pig, but the film belongs to Miss Baff's Janice who, in addition to Nora Helmer, also reminds me of an angry Minnie Mouse. It has something to do with the little skirts that Janice wears, the slightly knobby knees and the awareness that underneath the fury there was once, very long ago, a sweet, cheerful, bright-eyed drudge.The Cast

title: Helgi Tomasson Stars in Divertimento
description: In Helgi Tomasson, the New York City Ballet has one of the best classical male dancers in the world today. No wonder then that George Balanchine chose him as the dancer upon whom to create one of the most unusual and poetic male solos in the Balanchine repertory.

title: Why Nobody's Paying Much Attention to Spring Couture
description: PARIS, Feb. 3  So by spring, we're all going to be skulking around in 1930's pleated shirtdresses during the day, switching into flowering garden party numbers in the late afternoon and changing into glamorous goddess gowns at night, right?

title: 4 WOMEN KILLED IN EAST SIDE FIRE
description: Four women died last night in a fire that swept through two stories of a tenement on the Lower East Side. Seven firemen and a police officer also needed treatment for smoke inhalation, the Fire Department reported.

title: The High Price of RiceSurvival FoodHits Those Who Can Least Afford
description: From the food stores of Chinatown to the bodegas of Spanish Harlem, they complain about rice prices and no wonder: Today a bowl of rice costs nearly twice what it did last May.

title: Senator Hughes Asks Public Military Spy Hearings; Breaks With Stennis on Closed Session for Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 Senator Harold E. Hughes called today for public hearings by the Senate Armed Services Committee into published allegations that military officers participated in a spying operation inside the White House for 15 months in 1970 and 1971.

title: Rolseth Captures Ski Jump Honors
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Feb. 3Trygve Rolseth, a 19yearold Norwegian business administration student at the University of Vermont, withstood a fall today and won the Metropolitan skijumping championship.

title: Trailing of Nixon Brother Reported to Senate Panel
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 3Investigators for the Senate Watergate committee have reportedly learned that the Secret Service was ordered to keep F. Donald Nixon, the President's brother, under physical surveillance during the first term because of mounting concern within the White House that his business dealings might embarrass the President and harm his chance for reelection in 1972.

title: Bridge: Deal Requiring Unusual Plan Recalled at Champion's Death
description: Until seven years ago, when it moved to Greenwich, Conn., and later to Memphis, the American Contract Bridge League had its home in New York City. Until 1967, therefore, there was a nucleus of enthusiasts who worked for the league on weekdays and played in tournaments here on weekends. Prominent among this group was Peggy Adams, a former national women's team champion, who died here last week.

title: SYRIAN PRESSURE SEEMS TO STEP UP
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 3 Syrian armed forces appear to be increasing their attacks on Israeli positions on the Golan Heights while political leaders here debate whether to join Egypt in Geneva when the peace talks there resume.

title: Claudette Colbert BroadwayBound
description: WASHINGTON Miss Colbert, the stage manager called from the wings, you're on.

title: 1,200 Bid Canterbury Godspeed
description: More than 1,200 worshipers crowded into the sanctuary of St. Thomas Episcopal Church yesterday to bid Godspeed to the Most Rev. Michael Ramsey, Primate of All England and 100th Archbishop of Canterbury. The 69yearold Anglican prelate ended a sixday visit here as guest of Trinity Institute, a New Yorkbased church organization. He will be the main speaker at the institute's threeday conference at Grace Cathedral in San Francisco beginning today before returning to England.

title: MAURO PELLICCIOLI, DA VINCI RESTORER
description: BERGAMO, Italy, Feb. 3 (AP) Mauro Pelliccioli, one of Italy's leading art restorers, died here yesterday. He was 87 years old.

title: Ferry Still Held
description: SINGAPORE, Feb. 3 (UPI)Four Arab and Japanese guerrillas sat for the fourth straight day today in their comman deered ferry in Singapore harbor.

title: Dr. William M. Whitelaw, Professor of History, Dies
description: PAWLING, N.Y., Feb. 3Dr. William Menzies Whitelaw, who retired in 1955 as chairman of the history department of American International College in Springfield, Mass., died here today at the age of 83. He lived in Carmel.

title: Bernard Botein, 73, Dies; Former Presiding Justice
description: Bernard Botein, Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division for Manhattan and the Bronx from 1958 to 1969 and a principal figure in the city's legal establishment, died last evening at Lenox Hill Hospital after a threeday illness stemming from a heart ailment. He was 73 years old.

description: QUEBEC, Feb. 3 (AP) Alain Caron got three goals, including the gamewinner four minutes into the final period, as the Quebec, Nordiques scored a 53 victory over the Jersey Knights tonight in the W.H.A.

title: 358 ExOfficers Reported In Defense Contract Firms
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UPI) Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that 358 retired military officers from the rank of major land up, including 30 generals and admirals, were now employed by private concerns that receive defense contracts.

title: Droves of Children Get Measle Shots in 3 Cities
description: PATERSON, Feb. 3  Eightyearold Rodney Cole grimaced in anticipation as Dr. Alfonse Brancone placed the gun against his arm this afternoon. A moment later the physician fired measles vaccine into the boy's right arm. It jerked ever so slightly, and then he smiled in relief.

title: Tough Cop Falters: How Rizzo Has Slipped
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3  Francis Lazzaro Rizzo emerged from South Philadelphia's Little Italy with a force that shocked the city's liberal community, up from the ranks of the hyphenated Americans with a pledge to keep the lid on taxes, take the handcuffs off the police, throw out the phony politicians and make the nation's fourth largest city livable again for the decent, hardworking little guy.

title: Bonspiel Is Taken By Caledonian No. 1
description: MT. HOPE, N. Y., Feb. 3 The New York Caledonian Curling Club No. 1 rink, skipped by Ernest H. Slaybaugh, won the 19th Cuthbertson bonspiel in an allCaledonian final at St. Andrew's Golf Club today.

description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 3 The New York Nets waited for the largest crowd of the home season, 14,516 fans in the Nassau Coliseum, to play one of their worst games of the American Basketball Association campaign today.

title: Penalty Costly To Barton Sloop
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 3  Bob Barton's sloop Country Woman, was penalized for equipment violations and dropped from first over all and first in Class E today by the St. Petersburg Yacht Club race committee overseeing the St. PetersburgAnclote Key race. Country Woman was placed fourth in fleet and third in class for the first event of the 1974 Southern Ocean Racing Conference competition.

title: A Seat Belt Kills Infant On Flight to Pagopago
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 3 (AP)The 16monthold daughter of an airline flight inspector strangled in a seat belt aboard a jetliner just before it landed here last night, the police reported.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UPI) The Government published rules today under which a consumer could get his money back if he was stuck with a product that had been banned as hazardous.

description: MIAMI, Feb. 3 (AP)Sandra Palmer sank a twofoot birdie putt on the fifth hole of a suddendeath playoff with Kathy Whitworth today to capture the Burdines invitation golf tournament.

description: TULSA, Okla., Feb. 3 (AP)The oil industry has earmarked a record $19.5billion to find and produce more oil in this country, the Oil and Gas Journal says in tomorrow's issue.

title: Red Smith
description: O. J. Simpson, landslide winner of the Hickok Award as Professional Athlete of 1973, will be stuffed with shrimp Leone and mounted in a Tiffany setting of adjectives today at a ceremonial luncheon. Attracting almost nine times many firstplace votes as Hank Aaron, the runnerup, and piling up more than twice as many points, the Buffalo Bills' slasher ran off and hid from a field that included Nolan Ryan, George Foreman, Billie Jean King, Secretariat and other choice and master spirits of this age. Never since the award was established had any individual so dominated the voting, and past winners form a distinguished company, indeed. (Some would be mentioned here by name, but no reliable list is within reach of this typewriter; in the Guinness Book of Records the only listing under hic is hiccoughing. Jack O'Leary of Los Angeles hicked 160 million times from June 13, 1948, to June 1, 1956.)

title: Ruling on Farah Union Is the Latest Step in a Clash of Two Cultures
description: EL PASO, Tex., Feb. 2Willie Farah, one of the nation's top manufacturers of men's pants, was caught up this week in another round of his longrunning battle with the Government, labor unions and the Roman Catholic Church over whether his eight factories should be unionized.

title: Highlights of the Budget

title: Soviet Criticizes U.S. Proposal For Small NATO Nuclear Arms
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 4  The newspaper Pravda charged today that the smaller atomic weapons, proposed for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization violated the spirit of the agreement on preventing nuclear war signed last June by President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader.

title: Record Is for Quarter
description: HONEYWELL, Inc., manufacturer of a wide variety of computer systems and industrial control systems, achieved record sales and earnings for the fourth quarter and for all of 1973, according to results issued by the company yesterday.

title: VATICAN DIPLOMAT ON VISIT TO POLAND
description: ROME, Feb. 4A Vatican diplomat flew today to Warsaw for a threeday visit as an official guest of the Polish Government.

title: Strike Hardens Attitudes at Modern
description: The lengthy strike at the Museum of Modern Art has been over for slightly more than two months, and the bitterness of the first days back  when sharp words were exchanged between the staying and the stayouts  has abated enough for business to resume as usual.

title: Jones and Moraites Acquitted of Fraud
description: NEWARK, Feb. 4Former State Senator Walter H. Jones and former Assembly Speaker Peter Moraites were acquitted today of charges that they conspired during a 1968 bank merger to hide improvement bank loans approved by Mr. Moraites years earlier.

title: U.S. ASKS SWISS HELP IN TRACING 2MILLION
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4 (AP)  The United States Attorney has asked Swiss atuhorities to help find $2million that officials allege was transferred abroad illegally in 1970 by sinceresigned officers of the Equity Funding Corporation.

title: PHARMACY SCHOOL TO CLOSE IN JUNE
description: The Columbia University College of pharmaceutical Sciences, the secondoldest pharmacy school in the country, announced yesterday that it had lost its accreditation and would have to close for lack of funds.

title: Sao Paulo Tightening Laws After Fire
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Feb. 4The Mayor of Sao Paulo announced today that a new and stricter building code would be ready next month as one answer to the bank fire last week that cost at least 189 lives.

title: Senators at Hearing Call For Stockpiling of Wheat
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UPI)  Senators in an agricultural subcommittee, listening today to a new round of predictions and denials of possible $1aloaf bread prices, urged the Administration to prevent future wheat shortages by supporting proposals to create grain stockpiles.

title: New Cultural Revolution Is Proclaimed by Peking
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 4In a loud and insistent chorus, broadcasts and editorials in China are proclaiming a largescale renewal of the Cultural Revolution under the active direction of the nation's aging leader, Mao Tsetung.

title: The Gnomes of Panama Are Creating A Mushrooming Latindollar Market
description: PANAMA CITYWhether one's dollars are hot or cold, an increasing number of friendly bankers in this new tropical Switzerland are waiting to receive themwith interest instead of a service charge.

title: Codd Swears In Rookies
description: Police Commissioner Michael Codd presided yesterday at his first swearing in, inducting 101 rookies, including 12 women, in the Police Academy.

title: Japanese Export Rise Linked to Price Gains and New Confidence
description: TOKYO, Feb. 4A sharp rise in Japan's exports last month, the highest in nine years, was partly a result of steep price increases and partly a consequence of renewed confidence among Japanese businessmen after the oilshortage scare here late last year.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MIAMI, Feb. 4 (AP)An attorney who helped lead the successful fight to eliminate local television blackouts of National Football League games sued the Miami Dolphins today in United States District Court, charging the Super Bowl champions with having violated antitrust laws by requiring season ticketholders to buy seats to preseason games.

title: Top Soviet Industrialists Told to Learn From West
Worried Drivers Swamp Stations Selling Gasoline
description: Anxious motorists overwhelmed gasoline stations in the metropolitan area yesterday, with many stations running out of supplies early in the day, while dealers hoped incoming deliveries under February allocations would restore calm by midweek.

title: Last Year's Major War Over Elimination of Programs Abates
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4A year ago on Federal Budget day a major war was joined between President Nixon and the majority in Congress over the President's desire to cut back or even eliminate a set of Congressionally enacted programs he thought were no longer doing much good. Now, a year later, there is peace of sorts in the new budget. As often occurs at the end of wars, it is anything but total peace, but the climate is at least less hostile. It is difficult to say who won this conflictor, more precisely, who will win. For many areas are still in dispute and unsettled.

title: Former City Detective Given 15Year Sentence for Rape
description: James Farley, a former New York City detective with four citations, was sentenced to 15 years in prison yesterday in State Supreme Court for the admitted rape at gunpoint of two young West Side women. Justice Burton B. Roberts concurred with a request by Assistant District Attorney Leslie Snyder that Mr. Farley undergo, further psychiatric treatment stemming from a 12year sentence for three rapes in Queens and another rape case pending in Suffolk County.

title: Drug Linked to Defendant In Drew AutoDeath Case By JOAN COOK
description: MORRISTOWN, Feb. 4  An expert from the state police laboratory testified that traces of barbiturates had been found in blood samples taken from John Ellmers approximately five hours after his car killed two young girls and injured third near the Drew University campus in Madison last June 14.

title: Singapore Refuses Guerrillas a Plane to Escape
description: SINGAPORE, Feb. 4 (UPI)The Government of Singapore turned down a proposal from four hijackers today to end a fiveday stalemate by exchanging their three hostages and a ferry boat they have seized for a getaway airplane.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Preventing a team's reserve players from becoming disillusioned can be one of the more challenging aspects of coaching, especially when the team is winning. But such a problem seems to have been averted at St. Anthony's of Jersey City, which is rated among the top 10 schoolboy basketball teams in the state.

title: Is It a Boon for Secretaries Or Just an Automated Ghetto?
description: The whole office is talking about it: The Boss and The Secretary are getting a very businesslike divorce. It's the best thing for The Company, they say.

description: A Bulgarian trawler captain pleaded guilty here yesterday and was fined $20,000 for fishing illegally in the coastal waters of the United States.

title: Nixon and Brandt Reviving Talks on Troop Costs'
description: BONN, Feb. 4  President Nixon and Chancellor Willy Brandt agreed last week to start their governments talking again about what amounts to West German payment of the costs of keeping American troops here.

title: Oquendo, Bethea Draw
description: Angel Oquendo of Puerto Rico and Tom (The Bomb) Bethea of New York, fought to a 10round draw last night at the Felt Forum. Oquendo, 31 years old, weighed 176 pounds and Bethea 172.

title: PROF. DOROTHY KINNEY
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Feb. 4Mrs. Dorothy Witmer Kinney, assistant professor of history at Central Connecticut State College, and the wife of Dr. Charles B. Kinney Jr., president of Nattatuck Community College in Waterbury, died today of cancer at her home here. Her age was 57.

title: The Screen: Osborne 's Obsessive Luther:The Cast
description: Doubt and dogmatism coincide almost as often as ham and cheese: When conviction wavers, a remorseful skeptic can wax more righteous than ever. John Osborne's characterization of Martin Lutheras a masochist ravaged by uncertainty, who was also able to stand the 16th-century church on its spiritual earis a sympathetic portrait of an authoritarian. Luther's own self-hatred appears as fuel for his determination to reform the church, and to convince Christians that no one can be saved by "good works," but only through individual faith. Yet he wallowed in the suspicion that his own sins couldn't be forgiven.At the same time, this Luther remains disconnected from events: When the peasants who backed him and his doctrines began to fight for the abolition of serfdom, he encouraged the lords and princes to kill them off. And he, who had been racked by infinite religious and personal guilts, seemed unmoved by the subsequent slaughter. Mr. Osborne's, Luther resembles a motorist who precipitates casualties for others: While he drives undamaged, other cars pile up and crash behind him.The American Film Theater's adaptation of the Osborne "Luther," which opened yesterday at selected theaters, does preserve most of the obsessions that blazed through the original. Understandably, the play was cut for the filmed version. However, some of the fiery Osborne language has been ironed out in Edward Alhalt's screenplay. Many strong metaphors and rhythms are lost, and part of the anal imagery has been purged. The Brechtian aspects of the play have been muted, and we're left with a conventional religious drama  hardly what the playwright wrought. Also, various key lines have vanished from certain scenes, only to pop up in others, and a minor character has been converted into a ponderous narrator. No doubt, clarity was intended. Clich is the result.When Stacy Keach's tonsure is bowed to the floor of a chapel or when he rolls up his eyeballs toward heaven, he doesn't persuade us of his devoutness. When the script demands reverence, his fixed eyes recall his catatonic performance in "End of the Road." But when he doesn't have to be worshipful, there's some fine acting afoot. He catches the focus of fanaticism, the hesitation and the doubt that permeate a defiant ego, the pleasure in pain. And he's gifted at sudden illness: when he bites his lip, we can sense the anguish in his gut. One of the best scenes is his confrontation with his father (Patrick Magee, who's very goodas are Alan Badel as Cajetan and Hugh Griffith as Tetzel). The mutual hostility and disappointment of father and son mingle with their concern for each other, their distress at getting on badly.The sensitive camerawork by Freddie Young concentrates on individuals at the peak of their most personal emotions within the stony ecclesiastical set. Yet the problem of filming a play recurs as it has in most of the American Film Theater's productions. In "The Iceman Cometh" and "A Delicate Balance," it was absolutely right to keep the camera indoors, within the set. However, in "Luther," the off-screen yells and screams of embattled peasants fail to convey the rebellion that's taking place. A few shouts and one portable corpse don't suffice for the whole Reformation, and it's worth wishing that there had been a crowd scene or two. Without any evocation of the outside world, it's hard to believewithin the context of this moviethat Luther had much of an impact, or that Protestantism was more than a hiccup in the span of history.

title: The Real New York Ranger
description: His position as a hockey player always seemed to have a letter missing. Instead of right winger, it should be right swinger. Outside the New York Rangers dressing room, Rod Gilbert, in a vested beige suit, had his sable coat on one arm and his blonde date on the other. He was do his way to II Vagabondo for dinner and then to Duncan's for a few drinks. He was celebrating. With 731 points (292 goals, 439 assists), he had emerged Sunday night as the leading point scorer in Ranger history. But he didn't need an excuse to move through the big city. That's his style, Most of his teammates, with their wives and children, understandably have preferred to settle in the Long Island suburbs, somewhat similar to their small Canadian home towns. Rod Gilbert's bachelor apartment is in the midst of the East Side action. He knows all the girls but he knows the guys on Wall Street and Madison Avenue, too. He grew up in Montreal and he's there occasionally in the offseason but more than any other Ranger, he's thought of as a New worker.

title: REACTOR HAZARDS CITED BY BRITISH
description: LONDON, Feb. 4A highlevel committee appointed by the House of Commons said today that Britain should not try to shore up her energy resources with a standard type American nucleartype reactor because of possible safety hazards.

description: Governor Wilson will appoint Richard H. Kuh, a Manhattan lawyer and a Democrat, today to succeed the retiring Manhattan District Attorney, Frank S. Hogan, high state sources reported last night.

title: Notes on People
description: It's been an active year, Chief Judge John J. Sirica of the United States District Court in Washington said, but apparently an exhilarating one as well, for the judge, who will turn 70 on March 19, has no plans to retire. He'll be forced as a septuagenarian to give up his job as Chief Judge, but he'll continue as a judge handling whatever cases he's assigned by the new Chief Judge.

title: West German Payments
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Feb. 4 (AP)  West Germany's basic surplus narrowed to a preliminary 10.21 billion marks in 1973 from a surplus of 14.53 billion in 1972, the Bundesbank reported today.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Subsequent to a recent column that detailed the ins and outs of harvesting scallops in Long Island waters, numerous letters arrived from readers about the extraordinary nonuse of the reddish, arcshaped coral that is part and parcel of scores of scallop dishes served in other countries.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) President Nixon has nominated Rear Adm. Owen Slier to be commandant of the Coast Guard, the White House announced today.

title: Surgery Repairs Young Twins' Heart Defect
description: Marie and Michelle Treeon, 4yearold twins from Old Bridge, N. J., who were born with the same heart defect, underwent successful corrective surgery yesterday at Babies Hospital of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York City.

title: PRICES DECLINE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices fell sharply on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market yesterday as investors stayed on the sidelines because of a lack of any favorable economic news.

title: Fishing Captain Fined $20,000; Bulgarian Owners Pay $105,000
description: A Bulgarian trawler captain pleaded guilty here yesterday and was fined $20,000 for fishing illegally in the coastal waters of the United States.

title: LIPMAN'S PIANISM CLARIFIES WORKS
description: A piano recital could hardly offer up more solid satisfaction than the one played by Samuel Lipman Sunday afternoon at Hunter College. The program was one of substance and Mr. Lipman's performances did it full justice.

title: HALDEMAN LINKED TO MILK DONATION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Herbert W. Kalmbach, formerly President Nixon's personal lawyer, has testified that he was instructed by H. R. Haldeman, then the President's chief of staff, to accept $100,000 from the dairy industry in 1969.

title: HELEN WILSON
description: RHINEBECK, N. Y., Feb. 4Helen Louise Wilson, a sculptor of modern abstract bronzes, died Friday at the Ferncliff Nursing Home. She was 85 years old and lived at 69 Morton Street in New York.

title: Anaconda Advances
description: Sharply higher profits were reported yesterday by four metals producers, including the Anaconda Company, the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., the National Steel Corporation and the Kaiser Steel Corporation.

title: Are you missing the fun and money in plate collecting?
description: NORTHBROOK, Ill.A successful art dealer this Chicago suburb has announced a new, easy way start collecting rare porcelain plates with the potential of becoming heirlooms of the future with exceptionally high resale value.

title: A TRAIN CARRYING 400 IS STALLED
description: An Amtrak train from Boston with 400 passengers aboard was stalled by an accident in Queens at 10:50 Sunday night within sight of the Manhattan skyline and was not pulled into Pennsylvania Station until 6:25 A.M. yesterday.

title: Mariner 10 Set to Lift Part of Veil From Venus
description: PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 4Mariner 10 is plunging toward Venus for what, tomorrow, is expected to be one of the most hectic hours of planetary observation from a spacecraft. The spacecraft will attempt to perform more experiments and take more pictures than has yet been attempted in a comparable time on a space mission.

title: 9,4BILLION DEFICIT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 President Nixon sent Congress today his $304.4billion budget, a budget his assistants say will be busted with more spending if necessary to check a slump in the economy.

title: Chase Bank Plans Office And Big Loan for Egypt
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday that it intended to establish a representative office in Cairo soon. The office was described as the first direct American banking representation in Egypt since the Suez war of 1956.

title: TERRORIST BOMB KILLS 11 IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Feb. 4The most deadly terrorist attack in Britain since the present wave of violence started in Northern Ireland in 1969 left 11 dead today and moved the Government to an urgent study of, new measures to counter frisky Republican Army attacks here.

title: Black Political Leaders Taking Closer Look at Power
description: It didn't do us any good, that's for sure, Bruce Llewellyn said the other day. People are going to be thinking that all blacks have got a skeleton in their closets somewhere.

title: Recital
description: To give a successful song recital in a space as large as Avery Fisher Hall, a singer must have all of the standard virtues, plus another that might be identified as generosity. It was that feeling that Jessye Norman conveyed throughout her program on Sunday afternoon when she appeared on the Great Performers series at the Lincoln Center hall.

title: Wife of Alioto Is Reported Missing
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 4Mrs. Angelina Alioto, the wife of Mayor Joseph L. Alioto of San Francisco, was reported missing today, two weeks after being last seen by her family in Palm Springs, Calif.

title: Long Island Press Now 10c
description: The Long Island Press raised the newsstand price of its weekday paper yesterday from nickel to a dime, attributing the increase to constantly rising production and distribution costs. The price of the Sunday paper remains 30 cents. The Press sold for a nickel for 24 years.

title: MEDICAID DENIAL BY STATE UPHELD
description: TRENTON, Feb. 4 (AP)The Appellate Division of Superior Court ruled today that the state's Medicaid program does not have to pay for abortion or other medical services performed out of the state unless the medical facilities have been approved beforehand by New Jersey officials.

title: S.E.C. SUING GLOBUS ON BROTHEL SCHEME
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 4 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit today to prevent a West German business group from selling stock in a house of prostitution to Americans.

description: On the bench, in the bar associations, before courtreform organizations and even in a novel, Bernard Botein practiced and advocated equal justice for the poor. He was part of the legal establishment in this citya former presiding justice of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court and a president of the Bar Associationbut he used his enormous prestige to shake it up.

title: Market Place: Regional Banks Point to Results
description: It never pays to suggest, as New Yorkers are wont to do, that everything is done better in the Big Apple than elsewhere, That's because the elsewheres write in to argue the point.

title: Women's School Bill Offered
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) A bill aimed at insuring equal educational opportunity for women was introduced today by Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois. The measure would require state and local efforts to eliminate traditional sex roles in vocationaleducation programs and in selection of text and library books.

Big6 Mayors Hold Their Fire In Annual Offensive for State Aid
description: ALBANY, Feb. 4Shunning the usual televised strut of solidarity up the Capitol Hill toward the state coffers, the new version of the Bix Six Mayors entered a postLindsay phase today with a demure request of Governor Wilson for extra state aid.

title: ELECTION CALLED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 4Prime Minister John. Vorster today called general election for April 24, one year earlier than required by law.

description: Tentative assessments of the city's taxable real estate have risen to a record $40.1billion, an increase of $1.6billion over last year, Finance Adminis. trator Richard Lewisohn said yesterday.

title: AMOCO LOWERING PRICE OF GASOLINE
description: The wholesale price of Amoco gasoline was cut yesterday by 2 cents a gallon. The action marked the first price reduction for gasoline announced by an oil company since the Arab oil embargo against the United States and production cutbacks began in October.

title: Recycling Buildings
description: The growing list of shortages now seems to embrace almost everything, including common sense. But that commodity has been in scarce supply for a long time in the building field. Probably nothing has been more wanton in waste and illogic than the prevailing notion that you tear down solid old buildings and replace them with shoddy new ones. This has been called progress.

title: Saudi Arabia and Kuwait Give Syria Pledge on Oil Embargo
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 4 (AP)Saudi Arabia and Kuwait have given Presidetn Hafez alAssad of Syria firm pledges to continue the oil embargo against the United States, Beirut newspapers reported today.

title: DR. STEPHEN HYMER, ECONOMICS TEACHER
description: Dr. Stephen H. Hymer, a professor of economics on the graduate faculty at the New School, was killed Saturday when a car in which he was a passenger skidded into a stalled truck in Shandaken, N. Y. He was 39 years old.

title: White House Says Evidence It Gave Jaworski Doesn't Support Dean
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4The White House stated categorically today that evidence given to Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, did not support sworn testimony by John W. Dean 3d implicating President Nixon in the Watergate coverup before last March 21. Mr. Dean is a former White Howe counsel.

title: Vandy Tops Alabama for S.E.C. Lead
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Feb. 4 (AP)Lee Fowler, a 6foot6inch senior, dropped in two free throws with eight seconds left tonight to give Vanderbilt a 6765 Southeastern Conference basketball victory over Alabama and the league lead.

title: New jersey Briefs
description: Three men, allegedly caught trying to sell a large quantity of heroin to an undercover agent, were arraigned Newark and ordered held in lieu of bail ranging from $200,000 to $600,000 each. The men, arrested last Friday, were identified as Mario Perna, 44 years old, of Scarsdale, N.Y.; Anthony Graziano, 33, and Ronald Lorenzo, 28, both of Staten Island. They were arraigned before Judge Lawrence Whipple in United States District Court. Acting United States Attorney Jonathan Goldstein said the three had been arrested while attempting to sell about 8 kilograms (16.6 pounds) of pure heroin in Fort Lee, N.J. The socalled street value of the narcotic was estimated at $6million.

title: Knights Beaten
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Feb. 4 (AP)  The line of Frank Hughes, Andre Hinse and Larry Lund accounted for 11 points including four goals, and led the Houston Aeros to a 71 romp over the Jersey Knights in a World Hockey Association game tonight.

title: DECLINE BUDGETED IN U.S. BORROWING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 President Nixon's budget forecast today a decline in the new fiscal year in combined market borrowing by the Treasury and Government agencies, but it conceded that agency borrowing in particular, was rather unpredictable.

title: Syria Reports Heavy Toll of Foe's Guns
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 4 (Reuters)  Syrian and Israell artillery and tanks shelled each other today for the ninth consecutive day along the Golan Heights front.

title: KUNII'S LARGE VOICE IS SENSITIVELY USED
description: Toshiaki Kunil, a baritone who appeared Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, has had an unusual career, and that career was not always happily reflected in the program he presented. Mr. Kunii was born in Japan and had training in voice and piano. But then, as a teenager, he became a pop singer, touring worldwide. In 1969 he gave that up and began to study serious music, first in Puerto Rico, and now in New York.

title: Budget Doubles the Funds For Checks of Food Plants
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI)The Government program aimed at food manufacturers who repeatedly turn out filthy or contaminated products would receive twice as much money under the fiscal year 1975 budget.

title: President's Watchword Is to Act With Caution, in Uncertain Times
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Federal budgets nearly always make dull reading. The one presented to Congress today was no exception. If anything, it was chiller than most, and for understandable reasons. President Nixon, at this uncertain juncture in his life and the nation's, obviously does not feel adventurous or provocative. His watchword, if one reads the budget correctly, is proceed with caution.

title: Baltimore Teachers Strike; Return Is Ordered by Judge
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 4 (AP)Teachers here struck the nation's eighth largest public school system today after five days of intense negotiations failed to produce a contract agreement.

description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company remained the world's largest corporate money maker as it reported yesterday 1973 net earnings of $2.99billion, up 18.2 per cent over its 1972 high of $2.53billion. Page 49.

title: People and Business
description: The STP Corporation, the Floridabased automobile parts company, continues to have trouble with its starting lineup. Carl W. Stursberg, who has been president since last August, quit yesterday to return to his private investment activities. He continues as a director and consultant of STP.

title: TRUCKERS' TIEUP CUTTING SUPPLIES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Consumers in many parts of the country began to feel the effects today of the fiveday independent truckers' work stoppage and the Nixon Administration acted to halt the spreading shutdown by proposing to Congress a joint resolution to speed financial relief to the truckers, who are seeking a rollback in diesel fuel prices.

title: DoubleDecker Buses Returning
description: The doubledecker bus, a venerable New York institution that vanished 21 years ago, is coming back  with a British flavor.

title: Judge Rules President Lacks Authority to Halt Florida Canal
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. Feb. 4 (AP)  A Federal judge ruled today that President Nixon had no authority to order a permanent halt in construction of the CrossFlorida Barge Canal.

title: Cosmos Shift Home Base To Randalls Island Field
description: The New York Cosmos switched their home soccer base yesterday from Hofstra University to Downing Stadium on Randalls Island. During the last two seasons at the Hempstead, L.I., collegiate facility, the Cosmos had averaged about 6,000 fans a game.

title: Rationing of Gasoline Is Spotty in Elizabeth
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 4 The East Coast's first mandatory gasoline rationing went into effect here todaywith decidedly mixed results.

title: Ralston Is Critic Defends Ashe, al of Connors, Smith on Cup
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4 (AP)Dennis Ralston, striking at critics of the United States setback in the Davis Cup, wants another chance to restore United States tennis supremacy. And he hits out at Jimmy Connors.

title: Another Is Linked to Killings of Police
description: A witness said yesterday that a man on trial in another court in the slaying of two other police officers in May, 1971, was near the spot on the Lower East Side where Officers Gregory Foster and Rocco Laurie were killed in January, 1972.

title: Truckers' Revolt
description: The strike of independent truckers that has brought violence in at least seventeen states and the threat of nationwide economic dislocation is the most serious manifestation yet of an energy crisis that has been compounded by Federal bumbling.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz puts tax reduction at the end of the list of things that ought to be done to counteract a recession, one develops this year, as many economists expect.

title: Summoner of President
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4When Gordon Stanley Ringer became head of the Los Angeles office of the State Attorney General's office in 1967, he engaged in a long series of acrimonious memorandums with a staff member, a Deputy Attorney General of a liberal bent of mind, on matters ranging from where lights should be placed, to the location of staff offices, to the length of staff members' hair.

title: Briefs on Energy
description: LISBON, Feb. 4 (UPI)Portugal raised the price of gasoline today, from $1.45 to $2.13 a gallon for premium and from $1.30 a gallon to $1.84 for regular.

title: Grace Plans Trinidad Plant
description: W. R. Grace & Co. and The Government of Trinidad, and Tobago said yesterday the had agreed in principle to form a joint venture company, Trinidad Nitrogen Company, Ltd., to construct and operate a 1,200tonaday $55million anhydrous ammonia plant at Point Lisas, Trinidad.

title: 4 Die in Brooklyn Mosque In Shootout by 2 Factions
description: Four men, including a Muslim minister, were killed and a fifth was critically wounded last night in what police described as an apparent shootout between two rival Muslim factions in the Ya Sin Mosque in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Postal Union Chief Seeks Reopening of Negotiations
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 4Moe Biller, the president of the 25,000member Metro Area Postal Union, called today for the reopening of contract negotiations for nearly 2,000 workers at the New York Bulk and Foreign Mail Center here in view of the bad faith displayed all around by management in dealing with the issue of shift times.

title: Mr. Nixon Discovers Privacy
description: Skeptical chuckles may have seemed In order when Richard Nixon promised In his 1974 State of the Union Mesage a major initiative and a cabinetlevel review on the matter of privacyparticularly on safeguarding information stored in computers by interlinked Federal and state criminal justice agencies. Mr. Nixon, after all, had wiretapped his own staff and his Administration had failed since 1970 to take such a major initiative, despite the repeated requests of Congress that it do so.

title: Dilemma of a MiddleAged Rabbi
description: PHILADELPHIA  Recently I prepared a eulogy for a woman who had been brutally murdered by marauding youngsters. The killing had racial overtones and the eulogy required a carefully prepared text. No amount of editing could (or should) have disguised the tragic racial hatred that led to her horrible end; graffiti left by the murderers left no doubt about their motives. I was caught in a struggle between discreet silence and incendiary honest outrage.

title: Violence in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 4A man was shot dead and nine persons were injured by bombs today in a spasm of violence on the streets of Belfast.

title: People in Sports: Ryan Signs; Aaron Hits His 40th Birthday
description: Nolan Ryan, who used to soak his talented right hand in pickle brine to toughen his finger tips, signed a contract yesterday that reportedly placed him in the $100,000 salary class. The 27yearold Ryan, traded by the Mets to the California Angels after the 1971 season, established a major league record by striking out 383 batters last season. Ryan also pitched two nohitters last season and compiled a 2116 wonlost record.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Five Southwestern states were accused today by the United States Civil Rights Commission of failing to educate MexicanAmerican school children.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI)  The Administration today asked Congress for a $235.9million supplemental appropriation for the Postal Service to make up for the revenue lost when Congress delayed an increase in postal rates.

At the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue and 75th Street. Running time: 63 minutes, This film has not been classified. Through Wednesday.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: SLIPPAGE Coenties Slip, near Manhattan's lower tip, used to run right into South Street, between the old Seamen's Church Institute and Jeanette Park, where sailors and drifters lolled and drank and looked across the street to the river, where barges used to tie up, and you could see the bargewives cleaning and tending their windowboxes. It was a maritime prospect that was infiltrated in the nineteenfifties by many painters, sculptors, writers and actors.

Judge Signs Order for Nixon Testimony in Trial
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4A California state judge ordered President Nixon today to appear and testify in behalf of three of his former aides who are under indictment here for the burglary of the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

description: The four quarterfinal candidates matches have thus far followed a consistent course: no contender who has fallen behind has been able to recoup.

title: American Bar Group Opposes a News Shield Law
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 4  The American Bar Association went on record today against proposals before Congress that would permit newsmen to refuse to identify confidential sources of information when asked by investigators, prosecutors or judges.

title: HARRY T. ROHS
description: Harry T. Rohs, who retired as oil and utility editor of The Wall Street Journal in 1966 after an association of more than 40 years with the publication, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 601 East 20th Street.

title: World Food Aid Program Hurt By Prices and Tight Supplies
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 4  United Nations officials warned today that the World Food Program was facing major problems in its efforts to help poorer countries.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Conferees Agree on Plan To Roll Back Oil Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4A HouseSenate conference reached agreement today on a plan for rolling back oil prices as a substitute for the highly controversial windfall profits provision of the stalled Energy Emergency Act.

title: A.E.L. to Sell Liners
description: American Export Lines, subsidiary of American Export Industries, Inc., plans to sell to Atlantic Far East Lines, Inc., the Constitution for $2.5million and the Independence for $2.9million, if Federal legislation is enacted to permit their use in foreign flag service. If such legislation is not enacted the Independence would he sold for $2.5million and would be scrapped.

title: New Influenza Vaccine Will Be Tested on Humans
description: The National Institutes of Health is planning to sponsor limited trials, using human volunteers, of an experimental influenza vaccine developed by doctors at Mount Sinai School of Medicine of the City University of New York, scientists from both institutions reported at a meeting here yesterday.

title: JAMES H. DURAND
description: James Harrison Durand, a partner in the New York law firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae since 1971, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 6 Amherst Road, Chatham, N. J. He was 39 years old.

title: MackellTrial Witness Tells of Phony Holdup Tale
description: A prosecution witness in the trial of Thomas J. Mackell, the former Queens District Attorney, admitted yesterday that he had carried out a plan, in part arranged by two police officers, to report a phony holdup on a Brooklyn street in 1971.

title: Walton: '73's Top Amateur
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4 (AP) Bill Walton, U.C.L.A.'s twotime basketball player of the year, won the 44th James E. Sullivan Award today as the nation's outstanding amateur athlete for 1973.

title: Vietcong Free 2 Americans And Briton on Quaker Team
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 4 (Reuters)Two American woman and a Briton working for a Quaker medical team have been released after being held for 12 days by the Vietcong, a British Embassy spokesman said today.

title: Study Says South Imposes Heavy Tax Onus on Poor
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 4  The South, with nearly half the 20 million persons regarded by the Federal Government as below the poverty level, imposes an unusually heavy tax burden on the poor, according to a new study.

title: South Vietnamese Are Said to Occupy Two More Islands
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 4 (AP)Small South Vietnamese forces have landed on two more islands in the disputed Spratly archipelago in the South China Sea, military sources said today.

title: Squires Defeated As Gervin Sits Out
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 4 (AP)Ron Boone pumped in 24 points to lead the Utah Stars to a 105.98 American Basketball Association victory tonight over the Virginia Squires, who were playing without their top scorer..

title: Laurence Gomme, ExHead Of Antique Booksellers, 91
description: Laurence Gomme, first president, in 1949, of the Antique Booksellers Association of America, died Saturday in White Plains Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived at 125 Brown Road, Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Warship Stands By in Grenada Crisis
description: ST. GEORGE'S, GRENADA, Feb. 4  A British frigate steamed into the harbor here today to join in independence celebrations and also to stand ready for the possible evacuation of Britons, Canadians, and United States citizens should independence bring civil war to this 133squaremile Caribbean island.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: Military
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4  Defense spending will rise by $6.3billion in the coming year, partly to keep up with inflation and partly to start the development of strategic weapons to keep ahead of the Russians.

title: Education
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4President Nixon's budget proposes a tiny increase in spending for education, and relatively modest steps toward Administration goals for restructuring Federal school aid.

title: CULTURAL ACTIVITIES TO GET MORE U.S. AID
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) President Nixon's new budget request would increase support of cultural activities through the National Foundation on the Arts and the Humanities by an estimated $95million for the fiscal year 1975.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: CATTLE FUTURES SHOW PRICE DROP
description: Prices of nearby cattle futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange were down the centapound daily limit yesterday. With transportation becoming more difficult to obtain because of the truckers' strike, cattle are moving more slowly from producer to packer and even more slowly from packer to retailer.

title: Highlights of the Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Following are highlights of President Nixon's budget for the fiscal year 1975:

title: Rheingold Closing Delayed As Union Prepares Appeal
description: The onagain, offagain closing of the Rheingold Brewery in Brooklyn was postponed yesterday until midnight Friday when the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit extended a previous stay.

title: Byrne Address Starts Bicentennial Observance
description: TRENTON, Feb. 4New Jersey opened a 10year celebration of the nation's bicentennial today with a proclamation and address to a joint session of the Legislature by Governor Byrne.

title: 24 Face Ouster in Chicago
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) An administrative law judge for the United States Civil Service Commission recommended today the removal of 24 employes of the city of Chicago for violating the Hatch Act. The act imposes limits on partisan political activity for Federal employes and state and local employes whose activities are federally funded.

title: TRUCKERS' TIEUP CUTTING SUPPLIES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Consumers in many parts of the country began to feel the effects today of the fiveday independent truckers' work stoppage and the Nixon Administration acted to halt the spreading shutdown by proposing to Congress a joint resolution to speed financial relief to the truckers, who are seeking a rollback in diesel fuel prices.

title: Gnomes of Panama
description: PANAMA CITYWhether the dollars are hot or cold, an increasing number of friendly bankers in this new tropical Switzerland are waiting to receive themwith interest instead of a service charge on numbered and ordinary accounts. Details on Page 53.

title: Castro Is Now Supporting Soviet Policy Against China
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 4 Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba, putting his full support behind Soviet policy agains China, joined Leonid I. Brezhnev today in pledging to counteract divisive tendencies in world Communism and to make it their central task to strengthen the might and unity of the Communist movement.

title: GOV. BYRNE WINS POWER TO RATION SALE OF GASOLINE
description: TRENTON, Feb. 4The New Jersey Legislature gave Governor Byrne emergency powers tonight to deal with the state's worsening gasoline crisis, including the right to impose a rationing program involving alternate day purchasing and minimum and maximum sales at the pump. The Governor had requested these powers only today.

title: As in Old Days, Pewter Has Its Chance to Glow
description: The glow of pewter may soon upstage the glitter of stainless and silverplate on tabletops across the nation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: On Mr. Nixon's Address and the State of the Presidency

title: O.J.'s Goal: Super Bowl in Two Years
description: Even in street clothes, O. J. Simpson has learned how to run through a stacked defense without losing his balance.

title: ROBERT MOORMAN CIVIL ENGINEER, 69
description: Dr. Robert B. B. Moorman, emeritus professor of civil engineering at Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, now part of the Polytechnic Institute of New York, died of a heart attack Saturday in Sun City, Ariz. He was 69 years old and had lived in Brooklyn until his retirement last year.

title: Resorts International Stock Held as Collateral Freed
description: Resorts International, Inc., said yesterday that the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court, reverseing a lower court decision, has freed Resorts International common stock held by the Bank of Commerce. The stock and other assets had been pledged on a $1million loan by Huntington Hartford, an heir to the, founders of the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company.

title: Stock Prices Plunge by 22.44 on Dow As Concern on Energy Crisis Grows
description: Growing investor concern over the energy crisis and the economy sent the stock market sharply lower yesterday in continued light trading.

title: JUSTICE DEPARTMENT ASKING $2.1BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) The Justice Department hopes to spend $2.1billion in the fiscal year 1975, adding $168million to its 1974 outlay to hire more antitrust lawyers, strengthen consumer protection and expand the Federal prison system.

title: New Haven Cafe Cars Get Mixed Notices
description: A Connecticut commuter stood with briefcase in hand yesterday shivering in the morning darkness, as the 7:22 approached the platform of the Norwalk station.

title: Milburn to Hurdle Into Pros After Friday Meet Here
description: Rod Milburn says he has paid my dues to amateur track and field, but it doesn't mean that the incomparable Olympic champion will get off easy in his final amateur high hurdles race before becoming a professional.

title: KNICKERBOCKER NOW A.C. LOGAN HOSPITAL
description: Knickerbocker Hospital was renamed Arthur C. Logan Memorial Hospital yesterday in honor of the late surgeon and civic leader.

title: 9.4BILLION DEFICIT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 President Nixon sent Congress today his $304.4billion budget, a budget his assistants say will be busted with more spending if necessary to check slump in the economy.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION REPORTED STEADY
description: Steel production for the week ended Feb. 2 remained unchanged from a week earlier at 2.9 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The production index was also unchanged at 118.9.

title: Ambivalent Budget
description: President Nixon's budget for fiscal 1975 is poised between the steady as you go creed long championed by Secretary of the Treasury Shultz and the doctrine of activism as you like it once associated with Mr. Shultz' predecessor, John B. Connally.

title: Donovan Dealing Braves Into Playoffs
description: Newspapermen in Detroit still refer to Ed Donovan as the basketball robber. They still have not forgiven the Buffalo Braves' general manager for stealing Dave DeBusschere from the Pistons for Walt Bellamy and Howard Koming when Donovan was the Knicks'general manager. Before long basketball people in Los Angeles, Chicago and Houston may also have a notsofond description for the National Basketball Association's master trader. It was from those league cities that Donovan collected three small, quick forwards who have helped put the Braves into the playoff picture.

title: Caso Emphasizes Inflation and Energy
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 4Concern over inflation, environmental problems and the energy shortage was voiced today by County Executive Ralph G. Caso in his State of the County report.

title: NEW HIGH REACHED IN SILVER BULLION
description: LONDON, Feb. 4 (UPI)Silver bullion hit a new high in London today in what dealers described as a flight from paper money in the face of the continuing world energy crisis.

title: Business Briefs
description: Expansion Continues in World Trade

title: Bache Deal Held in Doubt For duPont Walston Units
description: DuPont Walston, Inc., the brokerage firm, disclosed last night that Bache & Co., Inc., may have broken off talks for the acquisition of 13 duPont Walston branches.

title: Money
description: Monday, February 4, 1974

title: GOV. BYRNE WINS POWER TO RATION SALE OF GASOLINE
description: TRENTON, Feb. 4The New Jersey Legislature tonight gave Governor Byrne emergency powers tonight to deal with the state's worsening gasoline crisis, including the right to impose a rationing program involving alternate day purchasing and minimum and maximum sales at the pump. The Governor had requested these powers only today.

title: Budget Maker Switched From Millions to Billions
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 When Walter D. Scott left the investment banking company of Lehman Brothers, Inc. last spring to become associate director or the Office of Management and Budget, his annual income dropped from six figures to five. The sums involved in Mr. Scott's daytoday decisions. however, went from millions of dollars to billions.

title: Rev. William Kenealy, ExDean Of Boston College Law, Is Dead
description: BOSTON, Feb. 4 (AP)  The Rev. William K. Kenealy, dean of the Boston College Law School from 1939 to 1956 and an outspoken proponent of racial equality, died yesterday in St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Brighton. He was 71 years old.

title: Music: Virtuoso Pianism by Anievas
description: As he began, so he ended. Agustin Anievas started his piano recital in Tully Hall On Sunday night with the Brahms Paganini Variations and ended it with Liszt's Paganini Variations. Liszt composed a set of six Etudes on the Paganini caprices for solo violin, all of which were played by Mr. Anievas, and the sixth of the set is a set of variations on the famous 24th Capricethe one used by Brahms (and a dozen or so other composers).

title: Barnard Clerks End Strike
description: A sevenday clerical workers' strike has been settled at Barnard College, and the clerks are due back at work at 8:50 A.M. today. A spokesman for District 65 of the Distributive Workers of America, the union that called the strike, said the workers would get a 14.9 per cent wage increase and improved fringe benefits over the period of a twoyear contract. The strike involved 75 employes, but some other unions honored the clerks' picket lines.

title: SOUTH KOREA BANS A JAPANESE DAILY
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 4 The South Korean Government today banned the distribution in this country of a leading Japanese daily newspaper, Asahi Shimbun, on the ground that it had published articles unfriendly and unfair to South Korea.

title: BREAK BY EXAIDES AND NIXON DENIED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4John J. Wilson, attorney for both John D. Ehrlichman and H. R. Haldeman, declared today that there was no break between his clients and the White House, where they were formerly top assistants to the President.

title: Harvard, Boston U. Win
description: BOSTON, Feb. 4 (AP) Harvard's Bob Goodnow scored on a penalty shot to break a 33 tie and send the Crimson off to an 116 victory over Boston College tonight in the opening round of the Beanpot hockey tournament. Bill Bucicton's two first period goals helped Boston University to a 61 triumph over Northeastern.

title: Atomic Development New Sources of Energy Sought In Expanded Funding for A.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4  The Atomic Energy Commission, which hopes to become the leading Federal agency on energy research and development, was one of the big winners this year in the President's budget.

title: 19 Injured on Mississippi
description: DESTREHAN, La., Feb. 4 (UPI)A tugboatbarge collided with a Mississippi River ferryboat before dawn today injunng 19 passengers.

title: Program Notes
description: Among the victims of what appears to be a minor revival of China's Cultural Revolution are two Austrians named Schubert and Mozart and a German named Beethoven, charged with having written music calculated lead unwary young Chinese down the slope to revisionism, worship of the West and even to capitalism.

title: For Love of the Rangers, He's Jack of Many Trades
description: In the combat zone where Saul Maslow works at Madison. Square Garden, he has been struck twice on the face and head (16 stitches for the first injury) by flying hockey pucks; in the previous Garden, at 50th Street, he collected a lapfull of shattered safety glass three times. As what is rather ungenerously called a minor official, Maslow receives no hazard pay; indeed, he receives no pay at all. His remuneration for this labor of love consists only of a blue New York Rangers blazer and the pride and pleasure he derives from being a part of professional hockey.

title: SUSPECT IN SLAYING SEIZED AFTER CHASE
description: Two mounted police officers in Harlem recognized a passerby last night from a wanted poster in their police precinct, chased him at full gallop for half a block and arrested him after one of the officers wrestled him to the ground.

title: Mexican Army, Amid Rumors, Insists It Steers Clear of Politics
description: MEXICO CITYIt's impossible for us to know what's going on in the army, a Mexican politician said. There are lots of wild rumors, but we have no way of judging them.

title: ETHICS RULE ASKED ON VELEZ'S 2 JOBS
description: The Human Resources Admin istration has asked the city's Board of Ethics to decide if a newly elected City Councilman who heads an antipoverty organization in the South Bronx is in a conflict of interest.

title: Income for Poor
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Implementation of President Nixon's budget, and his other recent policy statements in the areas of housing and welfare, would set the nation on the road to providing a guaranteed annual income for its poorer citizens.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: SOUTH ORANGEA twoyear reassessment effort has upgraded property values in this Essex County suburb by about 75 per cent, or to approximately $250million from about $142million.

title: CANADA SUGGESTING $8 OIL PRICE BY 1976
description: TORONTO, Feb. 4 (AP)The Canadian Government is suggesting that the wellhead price for Canadian crude oil be phased upward to $8 a barrel by 1976, Energy Minister Donald MacDonald said at news conference today.

title: A. T. & T. 1973 Net Is Up 18.2% to Record
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company report for 1973 issued yesterday showed that the giant utility was still the world's biggest money maker.

title: Gunmen Who Held Greek Ship Seek Libya Entry From Cairo
description: CAIRO, Feb. 4 (Reuters)Three gunmen, flown here from Pakistan after they had released two hostages on a Greek freighter, underwent questioning at Cairo Airport today while being treated as transit passengers.

title: Assembly Votes to Repeal Surcharge on Income Tax
description: ALBANY, Feb. 4The Assembly voted today to repeal the 2.5 per cent state incometax surcharge.

title: The Tank Topper's Fall
description: Carnoski had always seemed like the man most likely to succeed until the gasoline crisis began.

title: Pay Rise Plan for Congress Stirs Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Within the next 30 days, members of Congress will face an election year dilemma: whether or not to vote themselves a sizable pay increase.

title: Robbers Slay 2 in 2 Boroughs And in Each Case Get Nothing
description: The assistant manager of an allnight Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurant in the South Bronx was shot and killed in a predawn holdup by two gunmen, and a 68yearold widow was fatally shot by a lone robber on Manhattan's East Side at midafternoon, the police reported yesterday. In both instances, the slayers fled emptyhanded.

title: New Phone Rates Asked To Replace Message Units
description: The New York Telephone Company proposed yesterday new system for charging for calls in the metropolitan area that would do away with message uhits.

title: MINERS IN BRITAIN BACK STRIKE 81%
description: LONDON, Feb. 4The coal miners' union announced today that its members had voted overwhelmingly for a strike to support their pay demands. At the same time, Prime Minister Heath and trade union leaders failed in the latest effort to find a peace formula.

title: BILLY REED, 60, DIES; RAN THE LITTLE CLUB
description: Billy Reed, a Broadway dancer who became a choreographer and later owned and operated the Little Club from 1946 to 1965, died of a heart attack yesterday at Lexington Avenue and 53d Street. He was 60 years old and lived at 200 East 57th Street.

title: Rheingold Closing Delayed As Union Prepares Appeal
description: The onagain, offagain closing of the Rheingold Brewery in Brooklyn was postponed yesterday until midnight Friday when the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit extended a previous stay.

title: STUDENT DISORDERS ERUPT IN NIGERIA
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 4Student disorders erupted over the weekend at four of Nigeria's universities, and here at Lagos five policemen were taken captive and held on the university grounds.

title: RUSSIAN, BRAZILIAN PLAY TO CHESS DRAW
description: Viktor Korchnoi of the Soviet Union and Henrique Mecking of Brazil played to a draw last night in Augusta, Ga., in the longest game thus far in the quarterfinal matches for the world chess championship. Their game, The Associated Press reported, went 100 moves and took more than 11 hours.

title: Rockefeller Names First Panels Of Critical Choices Commission
description: Former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller announced yesterday the membership and overall objectives of the first three of six projected study panels of his newly formed Commission on Critical Choices for Americans.

title: New Cultural Revolution Is Proclaimed by Peking
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 4In a loud and insistent chorus, broadcasts and editorials in China are proclaiming a largescale renewal of the Cultural Revolution under the active direction of the nation's aging leader, Mao Tsetung.

title: Annual Meeting Postponed
description: The Dynamics Corporation of America announced yesterday that its annual meeting sched uled for February 15 has beer postponed to May 3. The corn. pany, operating under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, is seeking to secure corn mitments from financial insti tutions to finance an arrange ment with its creditors.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
MRS. WILLIAM ROBINSON
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Feb. Mrs. Marguerite Luddy Robinson, widow of William E. Robinson, who was board chairman of the CocaCola Company and a former publisher of The New York Herald Tribune, died Saturday at St. Mary's Hospital.

title: DONALD BRODIE, 83, FOUNDATIONS' AIDE
description: FALMOUTH, Mass., Feb. 4Donald M. Brodie, a retired foundations officer, died yesterday at his home in Racing Beach. He was 83 years old and also lived at 240 Central Park South in New York.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Israel Electric Company has placed an order valued at about $30million for four 390,000kilowatt utility boilers to be supplied by Babcock & Wilcox Canada, Ltd., a subsidiary of the Babcock & Wilcox Company. It is the third major order the Israeli company has placed with the Canadian company in the last five years.

title: TIMES CO. SHOWS DROP IN PROFITS
description: The New York Times Company showed a fourthquarter decline in net income despite higher revenues, but profits for the year 1973 were up 29.5 per cent from 1972 on a revenue gain of 8.2 per cent, according to yesterday's preliminary annual report.

title: Shortage of Steel Pipe Believed To Curb Drilling Activity in Oil
description: The drilling of hundreds of oil wells in the United States has been delayed because of a shortage of tubular steel, according to the independent producers who do most of the nation's drilling.

title: KUWAIT PRESSED TO CUT OIL PRICE
description: PARIS, Feb, 4  The British Petroleum Company and the Gulf Oil Corporation are pressing Kuwait to reduce the price of crude oil, according to specialists in London and the Middle East.

title: A. T. & T. No. 1 Earner
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company remained the world's largest corporate money maker as it reported yesterday 1973 net earnings of $2.99billion, up 18.2 per cent over its 1972 high of $2.53billion. Page 49.

title: ALBANY UNIT ASKS TUITIONAID PLAN
description: ALBANY, Feb. 4The Select Committee on Higher Education today announced an in terim plan to implement a program to subsidize tuition costs for students attending private or state colleges and universities throughout the state.

title: Theater: Bad Habits
description: Terrence McNally's new play Bad Habits is good news. It opened at the Astor Place Theater last night and it is really funny. It is a play  or rather two playlets  about therapy, and only goes to prove that laughter is the best medicine.

title: Recent Past Successes Mark Islanders as Team of Future
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 4The New York Islanders were flying high in more than one sense today as they left here to return home from the most successful road trip of their twoseason history.

title: TRUSTEES OF B. & M. SEEK CONTINUATION
description: The trustees of the bankrupt Boston & Maine Railroad said yesterday they intended to seek permission of the United States District Court in Boston to continue the reorganization of the railroad under Section 77 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Class War Over Tuition
description: Many of the cures currently prescribed for colleges' fiscal troubles threaten to turn higher education into an instigator of class warfare. The irony in this prospect is that for nearly three decades American higher education has been a major force for the eradication of class differences and hostilities. It has notably narrowed the gap, both in aspirations and opportunities, between haves and havenots, between privileged and underprivileged youths.

title: Advertising: Media Competition
description: One thing the four major media associations surely don't want in this time of shortages, threatened shortages and rumored shortages is an advertising shortage.

title: Bridge: In Which Jean Besse Shows The Power of His Genius
description: Any attempt to nominate the greatest world champion of all time would produce sharp debate. But there could be no debate at all if the attempt was to name the greatest player who has never won a world or global title.

title: Gromyko Begins Meeting With Kissinger and Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 They Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrel A. Gromyko, began an infensive round of talks with President Nixon and Secretary of State Kissinger today, focusing on the Middle East and a range of SovietAmerican issues.

title: Japanese Export Rise Linked to Price Gains and New Confidence
description: TOKYO, Feb. 4A sharp rise in Japan's exports last month, the highest in nine years, was partly a result of steep price increases and partly a consequence of renewed confidence among Japanese businessmen after the oilshortage scare here late last year.

title: Spending This Year Above Estimate of a Year Ago
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Government spending for the year we are now in, fiscal 1974, which still has five months to go, is now expected to be 2.2 per cent larger than the Nixon Administration predicted a year ago. In dollars, the underestimate amounts to $6billion.

title: For Love of the Rangers, He's Jack of Many Trades
Rationing of Gasoline Is Spotty in Elizabeth
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 4 The East Coast's first mandatory gasoline rationing went into effect here todaywith decidedly mixed results.

title: Helpern Says an Injection Caused Montemarano Patient's Death
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 4 Dr. Milton Helpern, who retired recently after 19 years as Chief Medical Examiner of New York City, testified today that Eugene Bauer had died as a result of an injection of potassium chloride.

title: Shultz Asserts Average Oil Profits In 1973 Were the Highest in 11 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz submitted to Congress today an analysis of the profits of 22 large oil companies that rebutted the contention of oil industry leaders that their profits in 1973 were high only when compared with those of epressed years.

title: Recent Past Successes Mark Islanders as Team of Future
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 4The New York Islanders were flying high in more than one sense today as they left here to return home from the most successful road trip of their twoseason history.

title: Vietcong Accuse Saigon Of Sabotage on Pact
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 4 (Reuters)  A Vietcong military spokesman accused South Vietnamese Government negotiators today of once more sabotaging the agreement on prisoner releases.

title: Budget Reflects Impact Of the Watergate Case
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 4President Nixon's budget proposals for the fiscal year 1975 contain a substantial increase in the White House payroll, much of it, reportedly, to pay the legal staff handling the complex Watergate litigation.

title: FOOD TALK
description: Who says a Valentine's message has to be on a card? Not the Picture Pie Company, which is selling such things as breads and pastry disks adorned with messages for Valentine's Day.

title: PINE MODIFYING PLAN ON WALSTON
