description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7We can see the end of the tunnel, Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., the White House chief of staff, said of President Nixon's troubles in a recent interview.

title: Vietcong Prisoners Flown To Exchange Site by Saigon
description: BIEN HOA, South Vietnam, Friday, Feb, 8 (Reuters)Seventy two Vietcong civilian prisoners were flown by helicopter from Bien Hoa Air Base to the Communistheld town of Loc Ninh today to start the resumption of prisoner exchanges which have been stalled since last July.

title: Dartmouth, Host, Leads Ski Carnival
description: HOLDERNESS, N.H., Feb. 7 (AP)Brant McDougall, a Middlebury College freshman from Erie, Pa., won the crosscountry event, but Dartmouth moved into the team lead today in the opening event of the 64th Dartmouth Winter Carnival ski meet.

title: U.S. Plan to Set Up Island Base Is Chilling Relations With India
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 7  Plans by the United States to establish a permanent naval and air base in the Indian Ocean have abruptly chilled AmericanIndian relations.

title: Liguori Hopes to End 5Race Losing String Tonight
description: When we last left Marty Liguori, he was running the fastest indoor miles of his careerand losing each time in the final few strides.

title: CAMBODIA REPORTS GAINS ALONG BASSAC
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 7 (AP)The Cambodian command said today that Government troops had made gains on both banks of the Bassac River southeast of Phnom Penh.

title: An Armenian Restaurant With a Nonstrolling Musician
description: Having made some objections recently to musicians in restaurants, I might best begin gin a report on Dardanelles, an Armenian restaurant at 86 University Place between 11.th and 12th Streets, by saying that the young man playing an oudand an electric oud at thatadded appreciably to a very enjoyable suppertime.

title: ARCHIBALD M'VITTIE
description: BEDFORD N. Y., Feb. 7C. Archibald McVittie, a stockbroker with Sterling Grace & Co., died yesterday at his home on Baldwin Road here. His age was 73.

title: Notes on People
description: When the Irish march up Fifth Avenue to observe St. Patrick's Day this year, they'll be led by Paul O'Dwyer, City Council President, It was announced yesterday that Mr. O'Dwyer had been unanimously elected by the 240 organizations that will participate in the event to serve as grand marshal of the annual parade, the 212th in the city's history.

title: Carey Says He Plans Detailed Report on Net Worth and Income
description: As part of his drive for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, Representative Hugh L. Carey said yesterday he would, offer a detailed report on his net worth and sources of income and feels all public officials and candidates should do the same.

title: Miss Proell Wins Downhill Title
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 7When she's on skis, Annemarie MoserProell doesn't listen to her husband's warnings about going too fast.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.8 billion tonmiles, 1.9 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings during the same period totaled 531,688 cars, 0.8 per cent above the corresponding week last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 4.2 per cent above last year.

title: ATMOSPHERE IS SAID TO EXIST ON MERCURY
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 7  A Soviet astronomer said today that he had concluded that an atmosphere existed on the planet Mercury on the basis of spectrographic readings made throuugh a telescope as Mercury passed in front of the sun last Nov. 10.

title: Janne Evert Ousted
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 7 (AP)Rosemary Casals of San Francisco eliminated The hometown favorite, Jeanne Evert, 76, 64, in a $50,000 pro tennis tournament tonight.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The widow of a fireman who was struck by a train and killed while responding to a fire in a tunnel of the Penn Central at 96th Street and Park Avenue was awarded a $400,000 settlement by a jury yesterday in a negligence claim against the Fire Department and the railroad.

title: MRS. MARK HONEYWELL
description: WABASH, Ind., Feb. 7 (AP) Eugenia Honeywell, president of Nixon Newspapers, Inc., and the widow of a Wabash industrialistphilanthropist, Mark C. Honeywell, died today in a fire at her home. She was 77 years old.

title: BYRNE SEES SIMON ABOUT EXTRA FUEL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 Governor Byrne of New Jersey net for an hour today with William E. Simon, director of the Federal Energy Of fice and the two then argued in front, of newsmen, in the glare of television lights, over what exactly had been resolved.

title: Flyers Rally to Win
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 (AP)  Terry Crisp's eighth goal of the season at 14:12 of the final period lifted the Philadelphia Flyers to a 54 comback victory tonight over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Line of Idling Cars Tested For Gasoline Consumption
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) Tests by Consumers Union have shown that a milelong line of idling sixcylinder cars burns up 150 gallons of gasoline every hour. The nonprofit product testing organization reported that idling eightcylinder cars burned an estimated 67 per cent more gasoline.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Newark Archdiocese's request to avert the closing of the Stella Wright publichousing project was termed a late and sad appeal by Earl Phillips, director of public housing of the Newark Housing Authority. Mr. Phillips said today that the authority would have welcomed support from the archdiocese for any legitimate effort to keep the project from financial collapse.

title: Note Says Terrorists Hold Miss Hearst
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 7The Symbionese Liberation Army, which has boasted of killing an Oakland school superintendent, declared today that it had abducted and still held Patricia Hearst, 19yearold daughter of a San Francisco newspaper president and editor.

title: Nader Group Says System Cleaned Up Exhaust From Pinto
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP)  A research group sponsored by Ralph Nader reported today that it had equipped a Ford Pinto with a system that not only cleaned up its exhaust fumes but also improved gasoline mileage by 15 per cent.

title: Nixon Tells His Lawyers To Consult Panel Counsel
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7Lawyers for the White House and the House Judiciary Committee will meet soon, at President Nixon's initiative, to discuss the extent of White House cooperation with the committee's investigation of Mr. Nixon's conduct in office.

title: TIMES PRINTERS GET NEGOTIATION REPORT
description: Members of The New York Times chapel of Typographical Union No. 6 endorsed a resolution last night urging the union and its negotiating committee to take whatever action is necessary to secure a just and equitable contract.

title: East and West Far Apart At Talks on Cuts in Force
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The Soviet bloc and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have advanced widely divergent proposals at the European talks on mutual force reductions under way in Vienna, making earlys progress highly unlikely.

title: McCaffrey & McCall Planning to Go Private
description: McCaffrey & McCall, which went public in the fall of 1969, is now planning to go private.

title: Opposition Leader Arrested as Grenada Becomes Independent
description: ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada, Feb. 7As skyrockets flared and steel drums resounded, this tiny Caribbean island attained independence today, but not in the harmony for which its leader had voiced hope. A young leftist organizer was arrested, and the house of another antiGovernment activist burned to the ground.

title: SENATE PANEL VOTES MAJOR HOUSING BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) The Senate Banking Committee approved today a housing bill authorizing several hundred million dollars more than President Nixon is seeking in this field.

title: Ziegler Called to Testify
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) President Nixon's press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, was called today to testify before a grand jury investigating the Watergate affair.

title: John D. Rockefeller 3d Gives $10Million in Art to Asia Society
description: John D. Rockefeller 3d will give his collection of 300 objects of Asian art, worth between $10million and $15million, along with funds for a new building to house it, to the Asia Society, a cultural and publicaffairs organization he founded in 1956.

title: To the Children, Cute Is an Offensive Word
description: In no time at all, Julia Hendricks, a fastthinking, fasttalking 10year old at P.S. 41, can rattle off a whole list of complaints about adult attitudes toward childrenhow they be little them in everyday dealings and how they portray young people as if they were so dumb.

title: PRICE OF GASOLINE RAISED BY SUN OIL
description: The Sun Oil Company announced yesterday that it had raised its price for gasoline by 3 cents a gallon. At the same time, the company said that it had increased prices for kerosene and No. 1 and No. 2 heating oil, including home heating oil, by 4 cents a gallon. Sun Oil left its prices for diesel fuel unchanged. The increases, which became effective yesterday, apply to all customers in Sun Oil's marketing area. The company attributed the higher prices to increased costs for crude and imported oil. Sun Oil is the fifth major producer to announce price changes this week.

title: Exchange Is Suspended
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7 (Reuters)  California Commissioner of Corporations Brian Van tamp announced today the suspension of the license of the West Coast Commodity Exchange. The suspension was requested by officials of the exchange due to a sudden decline in funds, Mr. Van Camp said.

title: Mount Vernon View
description: George Washington always delighted in showing visitors to Mount Vernon the beautiful view up and down the Potomac River that could be seen from his doorstep. In 1961 Congress passed a law to preserve the Maryland shoreline across the river in order to keep the scenic view much as it was in Washington's time. This area now known as Piscataway Park.

title: Rockets Down Tams
description: DENVER, Feb. 7 (AP)Steve Jones and Byron Beck left the bench tonight to spark a thirdquarter rally that gave the Denver Rockets a 10594 victory over the Memphis Tams.

title: Insurer Stock Suspended
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today that trading in securities of the Republic National Life Insurance Company of Dallas be suspended through Feb. 16. It said there was a lack of adequate and accurate financial information on the company.

title: Sydney Steel Buys U.S. Coal
description: SYDNEY, Nova Scotia, Feb. 7 (Canadian Press)The Sydney Steel Corporation has ordered 100,000 tons of coal from the United States at an estimated cost of $4million, company officials said. The order was placed yesterday in an attempt to avert serious disruptions at the plant because of a breakdown in the delivery of local coal.

title: Business Briefs
description: Shultz Weighs Capital Gains Taxes

title: ENOCH POWELL SAYS THAT HE WON'T RUN
description: LONDON. Feb. 7  Enoch Powell, one of the most controversial members of the House of Commons, asserted today that he would not run for reelection because it was an act of gross irresponsibility for Prime Minister Heath to have called general elections at this critical time.

title: Pennsy Reduces Losses; Pan Am Shows '73 Deficit
description: Airline Included Credit

title: 6 Clerics Sentenced By Seoul as Critics Of the Constitution
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 7 A special courtmartial at the South Korean Defense Ministry sentenced six Protestant ministers to imprisonment today for violating a recent presidential decree banning criticism of the nation's Constitution. Four of them received 15year terms and the two others 10year terms.

title: DepartmentStore Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $739million, up 12 per cent from the yearearlier $660million. Total retail store sales were about $9billion, up 9 per cent from last year's $8billion.

title: Note Says Terrorists Hold Miss Hearst
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 7The Symbionese Liberation, Army, which has boasted of killing an Oakland school superintendent, declared today that it had abducted and still held Patricia Hearst, 19yearold daughter of a San Francisco newspaper president, and editor.

title: HUSSEIN ATTEMPTS TO QUIET SOLDIERS
description: ZERQA, Jordan, Feb. 7King Hussein met with officers and men of the restive Jordanian Army here today in an effort to answer their questions about rising prices and alleged inequities in the military pay scales.

title: Jury to Get Findings In Hidden Oil Case
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday took the first step that could lead to criminal indictments of four oil companies and their executives on charges of contriving to create a shortage of home heating oil in the New York area.

title: U.S. Agrees to Yield Sovereignty of Canal to Panama
description: PANAMA, Feb. 7  The United States and Panama today concluded an agreement on the principles that will guide the negotiation of a new Panama Canal treaty, eventually transferring sovereignty over the waterway to the Panamanians.

title: Off Off Broadway Shows
description: It is advisable to telephone theaters for schedules and prices before going to a show. Most if not all, theaters accept Theater Development Fund vouchers.

title: Unscrambling New York
Ervin Says He's Told to Expect New Indictments on Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. of North Carolina, chairman of the Senate Watergate committee, said today that he had been told to expect a number of indictments in the Watergate case this month and that many would, be settled by guilty pleas.

title: DEADLOCK BROKEN IN WORLD TRADE
description: GENEVA, Feb. 7  Negotiators from 86 nations today broke a deadlock that had stalled for more than three months the preparatory phase of experts to ease trade barriers.

title: BURLINGTON HEAD MAY LEAVE EARLY
description: Charles F. Myers Jr., chairman of Burlington Industries, Inc., the textile industry's largest company, told the annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., yesterday that he was considering early retirement.

title: BROWN NOT PICKED IN COURT LINEUP
description: A witness in the trial of Henry Brown, accused of murdering Police Officers Gregory W. Foster and Rocco P. Laurie on the Lower East Side two years ago, failed to identify Mr. Brown in an unusual courtroom lineup.

title: CONTRACTS SIGNED ON WALSTON OFFICES
description: DuPont Walston, Inc., which plans to go out of the securities business, said yesterday that it had signed contracts with 11 member firms of the New York Stock Exchange to take over 62 of its 138 domestic offices.

title: Cancer Society Steps Up Drive On Growing Smoking Problems
description: The American Cancer Soiety, distressed by the soaring lung cancer rates, the recent increase in percapita cigarette consumption and the growing numbers of teen  agers and women who are taking up smoking, announced yesterday a steppedup effort to combat the smoking problem.

title: Panama Canal in Brief
description: The Panama Canal, built 60 years ago, remains one of the world's engineering wonders. It continues to serve as a vital shipping link, used annually for 120 million tons of ocean freight.

title: COPPER FUTURES DECLINE 3C LIMIT
description: Reports that the General Services Administration plans to sell about 89 million pounds of surplus Government copper at prices of 80 cents a pound and more depressed copper futures yesterday. The sale is a result of an auction for which bids were submitted earlier this week.

title: Volcker Deputy Named To Fill Treasury Post
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7President Nixon named Jack F. Bennett today as Under Secretary of the Treasury, the department's fourthranking position, which has been vacant for more than a year.

title: Six Westchester Cities Form A Conference for Joint Action
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 7 Westchester's six cities banded together today in a Conference of City Mayors to see if cooperation was better than competition in solving what were essentially common problems.

title: WILSON ATTACKS BANKS' SEX BIAS
description: ALBANY, Feb. 7Governor Wilson today asked the Legislature to prohibit discrimination against women in credit transactions, including loans, mortgages and dealings with creditcard companies.

title: The Pop Life
description: One homily usually accepted in the pop life states that deadly doldrums settle upon the business right after the New Year's Day celebrations smoulder out.

title: Red Smith
description: Judging by the profusion of programs on the air, the subject that grabs more television viewers than any other is not football (with or without clowns In the broadcast booth), or the emergency ward, or cowboys or cops and robbers. It is wildlifeanimals, birds, fish. Maybe a oneshot production like a Super Bowl or World Series gets higher Nielsen for a few hours, but in the long run Alan Page hasn't got the boxoffice clout of Marlin Perkins, nor Raquel Welch in a bikini the sex appeal of JacquesYves Cousteau in his bathysphere.

title: BEAME ASKS SHIFT IN RENT CONTROLS
description: Mayor Beame, accused by opponents during his election campaign of being too close to realestate interests, yesterday urged state legislation on apartIntent rents and landlordtenant relations that was certain to be fought vigorously by landlords here.

title: End of Truck Tieup?
description: Restraint has scarcely been a mark of the independent truckers whose strike over high fuel prices has disrupted the national economy, but they will be outdoing themselves in irresponsibility if any substantial number persist in defiance of the tentative agreement worked out by their negotiators and top Federal officials.

title: AGATHA YOUNG DIES; AUTHOR, TEACHER, 75
description: Agatha Young, an author of novels and a teacher of fine arts, died last evening at her home here. She was 75 years old and lived also at 1185 Park Avenue, New York City.

title: U.S. School Aid Restored; City Agrees to Drop Suit
description: City school officials agreed yesterday to drop their suit to cover nearly $1million in Federal grants withheld from a Brooklyn district. They acted after the Department of Health Education and Welfare indicated it would restore most of the funds.

title: Kheel Criticizes Port Authority For Move to Raise PA TH Fares
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey was accused yesterday of moving again to raise PATH fares to 50 cents from 30 despite the opposition of Governor Byrne of New Jersey, the Jersey Legislature and half of the authority's own commissioners.ing bodies and community groups in localities served by PATH helped block a similar fareincrease proposal last year, and these groups are rallying again for a new fight.

title: ROCKWELL HALTS LOCKHEED STUDIES
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 7 (Reuter)  Rockwell International has discontinued its studies of a possible affiliation with the financially troubled Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: CARL W. KALTENBACH
description: EASTCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 7 Carl W. Kaltenbach, founder in 1930 and president since then of the Eagle Machine and Tool Company, Inc., died yesterday in a Mount Vernon nursing home. He was 74 years old and lived at 4 Santa Monica Drive.

title: HOFFA DENIES BAR ON ROLE IN UNION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7James R. Hoffa contended today that neither President Nixon nor former Attorney General John N.

title: Amex and OTC Lists Edge Up In Continued Lethargic Trading
Byrne Assigns Top Aide To Faculty Labor Talks
description: TRENTON, Feb. 7Governor Byrne has assigned Lewis Kaden, his chief counsel and an experienced labor mediator, to the prolonged contract negotiations between the bargaining agent for the faculties of the eight state colleges and the State Department of Higher Education.

title: MANY SIOUX VOTE FOR TRIBAL HEAD
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., Feb. 7 The second snowstorm in three days piled drifts across the rural roads of the huge Pine Ridge Indian Reservation today but the Oglala Sioux went to the polls in large numbers to select a president.

title: Going out Guide
description: GALLERY Artists Space is a fairly new SoHo Gallery, at 155 Wooster Street, at the corner of Houston (674 2950), three flights up, It's funded currently by the New York State Council on the Arts and its aim in life is to exhibit works by artists who are not affiliated with galleries. Not content with only that, it is going to be doing other things as well.

title: Kuwait to Accept 4 Singapore Guerrillas
description: KUWAIT, Friday, Feb. 8Kuwait accepted a Japanese Government appeal yesterday, to allow four guerrillas to fly here from Singapore in exchange for the release of Japanese diplomats held hostage here.

title: DECLINE SLOWS IN CREDIT RATES
Tagariello a Hit Close to Home
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 33

title: Statement by U.S. and Panama on New Canal Treaty
description: PANAMA, Feb. 7 (Reuters) Following is the text of a joint statement of principles signed here today by Secretary of State Kissinger and Foreign Minister Juan Antonio Tack of Panama:

title: Arline Judge, Dancer and Star Of Thirties Movies, Dies at 61
description: HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 7 (UPI) Arline Judge, a film star of the nineteenthirties, was found dead today in her apartment near Sunset Strip. She was 61 years old. Sheriffs deputies said she apparently died of natural causes.

title: Ohio Becomes 33d State To Pass Rights Amendment
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 7 (AP)Ohio became today the 33d state to ratify a constitutional amendment that would assure women equal rights under the law.

title: U. S. Hires Concern to Monitor Pipeline's Environmental Effect
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 7The Federal Government has committed itself to seeing that installation of the oil pipeline across Alaska causes a minimum of environmental damage.

title: G.M. TO EMPHASIZE SMALLCAR OUTPUT
description: DETROIT, Feb. 7The chairman of the General Motors Corporation, Richard C. Gerstenberg, said today that G.M. was considering manufacturing new small cars at its main Buick, Oldsmobile and Pontiac plants in Michigan, all of which have been hard hit by the slump in bigcar sales resulting from the energy crisis.

title: Claims Thrown Out Against Turner Concern
description: ORLANDO, Fla. Feb. 7 (AP)A federal bankruptcy judge has thrown out 80,000 claims against Glenn W. Turner's embattled cosmetics cocern, Koscot Interplanetary, Inc.

title: Treasury Bond Issue Raises $300Million
description: The Treasury yesterday borrowed $300million by selling 20year bonds at terms that gave investors a yield of 7.45 per cent.

title: Jane Powell, Soft and Smiling, Takes Over as Irene
description: Remember all those Jane Powell movies, such as Three Sailors and a Girl, Small Town Girl, The Girl Most Likely and of course Seven Brides for Seven Brothers? There she was last night, years later, making her Broadway debut in Irene and looking . . . like the same smiling, happy girl (and if the women's movement objects to that word, it may as well object to all of Irene).

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: Las VegasEzra Davis, 145 pounds, Las Vegas, knocked out Ramon Torres, 145, Phoenix, rounds.

title: Joseph Reilly, '6062 Chairman Of American Exchange, Dies, 67
description: CAPE CORAL, Fla., Feb. 7Joseph F. Reilly, who served as board chairman of the American Stock Exchange from 1960 to 1962, and as president pro tern in 1961 and 1962, died yesterday at Lee County Memorial Hospital. He was 67 years old and had made his home here since his retirement in 1969.

title: BYRNE SEES SIMON ABOUT EXTRA FUEL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 Governor Byrne of New Jer sey met for an hour today with William E. Simon, direc for of the Federal Energy Of flee, and the two then argue?? in front of newsmen, in the glare of television lights, over what exactly had beer resolved.

title: Stan Smith Holds Off Young Foe
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 7 (UPI)  Stan Smith struggled into the quarterfinals of the $50,000 World Championship Tennis tour stop here by beating an 1[09]yearold British Davis Cup player, Chris Mottram, 36, 76, 63, today.

title: Country Urged to Prepare For Rationing on Full Scale
description: ALBANY, Feb. 7 (UPI)Cailog oddandeven gasoline allocation programs an interim step, Robert H. Binder, an assistant United States SecreGary of Transportationdesignate, said tonight the country should be prepared for fullscale rationing.

title: Two Policemen Slain in Oakland
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 7 (UPI)Two policemen were shot to death today in a junior high school conference room by a young man before he was wounded critically in a apartment where he had taken refuge with two hostages, according to the police.

title: Reserves of Money Tightened in Week
description: If the Federal Reserve recently intensified its effort to make money easier to borrow, there was little evidence of such a move in the weekly banking statistics released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Many measures of money and bank reserves tightened.

title: BRITISH ELECTIONS CALLED BY HEATH FOR MONTH'S END
description: LONDON, Feb. 7  Prime Minister Heath, taking his struggle with Britain's coal miners to the voters, ordered Patllament dissolved today and called a general election for Feb. 28.

title: David Rockefeller, On Return, Sees Mideast Ending Embargo
description: If nothing is done to make adjustments, the present energy crisis could precipitate a worldwide depression, David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, said here yesterday.

title: Advertising: Bitter With Sweet
description: Sugar. It isn't just good flavor, it's good food, a discontinued advertising claim of the Sugar Association, has been found without substantiation by a panel of the National Advertising Review Board.

title: How the Fuel Crisis Affects Colleges
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 7The fuel crisis in New Jersey appears to be developing into distinct influence on students choice of colleges in the state and how those colleges manage to help students wend their way to the campus once they are enrolled.

title: Truckers Reach Accord, Leaders Ask Strike End
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7Negotiators for independent truck operators called today for an end to the truck strike after reaching agreement with the Government on concessions that included a surcharge on freight rates.

title: LAW AIDES MEET AS OLD FEUD DIES
description: NEWARK, Feb. 7Jonathan L. Goldstein, acting United States Attorney, and William F. Hyland, the State Attorney General, met today to discuss mutual cooperation in solving a number of problems, starting with the energy crisis.

title: Bridge: There Are Times to Apply, And to Neglect, Safety Plays
I Hate to Say I Told You So, but...
description: As a matter of taste, I have daintily refrained from writing an article such as this for years. After all, the tackiest of fellows is the one who says, I told you so. Imagine trainer Lucien Laurin, after Secretariat and Riva Ridge demonstrated their unquestionable class, crowing to his earlier critics that he had known all the while that his barn housed the best racing duo in the land. Such things are not done in civilized company.

title: Antioch Lowers 197475 Tuition by $150
description: In an extraordinary action at a time of Increasing cost pressures for private colleges, Antioch College has lowered tuition for the coming year at its campus in Yellow Springs, Ohio.

title: Big Board and N.A.S.D. Backed By S.E.C. on Joint Stock System
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The Securities and Exchange Commission gave the green light today to plans of the New York Stock Exchange and the National Association of Security Dealers to provide a joint stock clearance and settlement system.

title: Woman, 71, Plunges to Death
description: Anna Robson, 71 years old, of 390 Kings Highway in Brooklyn, fell or jumped to her death yesterday shortly after 7 A.M. from her sister's fourthfloor apartment at 315 East 68th Street near Second Avenua in Manhattan, the police reported.

title: On a Scale of the Ancient Epics
description: In the exhibition of Tapestry from the Fourteenth to the Sixteenth Century, opening today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, we are confronted with art on the scale of the ancient epics, Allegorical romance is combined with heroic design. History, theology and legend are transformed into prodigious feats of pictorial representation. The eye is filled with scenes of dramatic action, spiritual revelation and the lyrical evocation of nature, and the mind struggles to embrace a mode of expression in which multiple levels of meaning and almost inconceivable complexities of craftsmanship are joined in a comprehensive vision of human and celestial existence.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE EXTRAORDINARY MR. WILKES: His Life and Times. By Louis Kronenberger. 269 pages. Illustrated. Doubleday. $10.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: The Lead Pellets of Doom
A.B.C., Citing Imbalance, Cancels a Cavett Show
description: A taped program of the Dick Cavett Show featuring the radical spokesmen Tom Hayden, Abbie Hoffman, Jerry Rubin and Rennie Davis was barred from airing by the American Broadcasting Company last night and replaced by a 1972 rerun. An A.B.C. spokesman said the network felt that a discussion of controversial issues by the guests was not balanced by opposing viewpoints from Mr. Cavetta condition they said was established by contract last December as a fairness precaution since the show was shifted to a biweekly schedule.

title: TAX OFFICIAL SEIZED ON BRIBERY CHARGE
description: A tax examiner in the Brooklyn office of the State Department of Taxation and Finance was arrested yesterday on bribery charges, according to a spokesman for Eugene Gold, the Brooklyn District Attrney.

title: Renaming of Mrs. Norton And Other Blacks Pressed
description: A campaign urging the reappointment of Eleanor Holmes Norton as chairman of the City Cornmission on Human Rights is one of the signs of growing concern among blacks over the failure, so far, of Mayor Beame to fill several toplevel posts that have been held by blacks.

title: Jury to Get Findings In Hidden Oil Case
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday took the first step that could lead to criminal indictments of four oil companies and their executives on charges of contriving to create a shortage of home heating oil in the New York area.

title: Costa Rica's Man in the Shadow
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 7  As the margin of Daniel Oduber's lead in Sunday's Costa Rican elections began to slip the other day, one Opposition politician said with genuine sympathy, Poor Daniel; he wanted so badly to be President.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
3 PARKWAY STATIONS ARE SHUT EARLIER
BIG BOARD PRICES POST MODEST GAIN
description: Stock prices eked out a small advance yesterday in slow trading as political and economic uncertainties continued to keep investors on the sidelines.

title: Nixon Sounds a Warning On RawMaterial Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7President Nixon told Congress today that nations supplying the world with important raw materials other than oil will have a much harder time than the oilproducing countries in radically raising world prices.

title: SIMON WEIGHS CUT IN CRUDE OIL PRICE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7William E. Simon, the Federal energy administrator, is considering a rollback of socalled uncontrolled crude oil prices to persuade Congress to delete a mandatory rollback provision from the pending Energy Emergency Act.

title: Film: Rocha's The Lion
description: THE LION HAS SEVEN HEADS, directed by Glauber Rocha; written by Mr. Rocha and Glanni Amica (French and Portuguese with English subtitles); made by Claude Antoine and Glanni Barcelloni for Polifilm. At the First Avenue Screening Room, 61st Street. Running time: 103 minutes.

title: WILSON PROPOSES VOLUNTARY PLAN ON GASOLINE SALE
description: Governor Wilson called yesterday for a voluntary statewide program starting Monday in which drivers with oddnumbered license plates would buy gasoline on oddnumbered dates and those with evennumbered plates would do their buying on evennumbered dates.

title: Rockefeller's Views
description: David Rockefeller, chairof the Chase Mahatian Bank. said here yesterday that if nothing is done to make adjustments, the present energy crisis could precipitate a global depression. Page 39.

title: Priorities for Ecology
description: WASHINGTONAnyone who thinks about health as a public problem knows that an outbreak of bubonic plague is a greater threat than a superbundance of acne. He knows, too, that an epidemic of German measles, because of its effect on pregnant women, is to be taken far more seriously than much loss of teeth in old people.

title: China Assures Intellectuals Who Conform
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 7Chinese intellectuals are being called on to make conscientious efforts to transform their world outlook by taking part in the mass movement to condemn Confucius, who for 2,500 years has been the model of what a Chinese intellectual should be. They are also being assured that the movement will deal gently with them so long as they stay in step.

title: Workers Face 4Day Week
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Feb. 7  The Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. has cut its whitecollar personnel to a fourday work week next week, reflecting the impact of the independent truckers strike. The cutback will affect 1,000 office workers here and 700 in Chicago.

title: CHILE'S BIG PARTY CRITICIZES JUNTA
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 7 In what appears to be the first serious split among antiMarxists in Chile since the downfall of the Marxist government, the country's largest party has accused the ruling military junta of violating human rights, mistreating the working class and trying to suppress all politicalparty activity.

title: Mindszenty Denies Retiring Voluntarily
description: VIENNA, Feb. 7Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty said here today that he had not voluntarily given up either his archbishop's office or his title as Roman Catholic primate of Hungary.

title: People in Sports: Sauer Faces Curve on Road Back
description: George Sauer Jr.'s return to professional football has run into a legal snag. Sauer quit the New York Jets before the 1971 National Football League season, calling the sport dehumanizing.

title: Sluggish Enrollment a Problem In Prepaid Group Health Plans
description: Some of the health leaders who were instrumental in the passage of the national legislation on health maintenance organizations agreed yesterday that sluggish enrollment and the tendency of plans to offer too many benefits were the greatest difficulties to overcome in implementing this prepaid group health insurance program.

title: CHILE'S BIG PARTY CRITICIZES JUNTA
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 7In what appears to be the first serious split among antiMarxists in Chile since the downfall of the Marxist government, the country's largest party has accused the ruling military junta of violating human rights, mistreating the working class and trying to suppress all politicalparty activity.

title: John D. Rockefeller 3d Gives $10Million in Art to Asia Society
description: John D. Rockefeller 3d will give his collection of 300 objects of Asian art, worth between $10million and $15million, along with funds for a new building to house it, to the Asia Society, a cultural and publicaffairs organization he founded in 1956.

title: Heath Taking His Biggest Gamble
description: LONDON, Feb. 7British politicians got a threeweek campaign off to a quick start today, uttering an expected flood of words, welcoming the challenge, boasting of confidence and offering panaceas. The election called today by Prime Minister Heath is one that few of them really wanted now, although most felt it was inevitable. It will be one of the most bitter struggles in modern political history here, fought against the bizarre background of industrial strife, deep divisions in society and threatening economic chaos.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: The City That Lost Its Magic
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7This used to be known as the enchanted city on the Potomac and some poetic minds still so regard it, but lately it has lost some of its old shine and spirit and has settled down, at least temporarily, into a mood of frustration and disenchantment.

title: FRANK MASTERS SR., BRIDGE DESIGNER, 90
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 7 Frank M. Masters Sr., a bridge designer whose company designed many wellknown bridges in this country, died today in Polyclinic Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived here.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 9, 1974

title: Money
description: Friday, February 8, 1974

title: Revolt on the Highways
description: Dissidents among this country's striking truckers seem bent on forcing a brutal collision between the national interest and their own. Instead of accepting the reasonable agreement worked out between the White House and negotiators for the independent owneroperators, many strikers are denouncing the pact and seeking to intensify their chokeoff of essential deliveries.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time
Afternoon Paper Dropped
description: BOSTON, Feb. 8 (AU)The Boston HeraldAmerican published its last afternoon editions today, becoming a morningonly newspaper. The HeraldAmerican said it eliminated its two evening editions because circulation dropped while costs rose. This leaves Boston with one afternoon newspaper. The Boston Globe.

title: Out of the Shadows
description: Arguing that a legislator should not be allowed to cast a proxy any farther than he casts his own shadow, Majority Leader Thomas J. Cults persuaded the City Council the other day, over the protests of some of his own closest supporters, to adopt a longsought reformabolition of proxy voting at Council sessions.

title: Oil Squeeze Dims Paris Only a Little
description: PARIS, Feb. 8The winter has suddenly turned mild, with even some sparkling, springcolored days to chase away the January grays.

title: Dartmouth Takes Lead In Carnival
description: WATERVILLE VALLEY, N. H., Feb. 8Dartmouth's alpine skiers vaulted the Big Green into a dominating lead with consistent skiing here today as the Dartmouth Winter Carnival moved through three of four events.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: N.C. State Wins, 9854; 15th in Row
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 8 (AP)Monte Towe triggered an early 212 spree over five minutes with seven of his gamehigh 21 points, and led secondranked North Carolina State to a 9854 victory over Georgia Tech, tonight. It was North Carolina State's 15th straight victory.

title: STOCKS DECLINE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Erasing a slight gain held early in the day, prices dropped for most of the session on the American Stock Exchange to close lower in slightly steppedup trading. Prices were also down in the overthecounter market in increased trading.

title: New England Shoe Maker Given Large U.S. Loan
description: One of the largest loans of its kind has been granted to a New England shoe manufacturer by the Department of Commerce to enable it to diversify its product line and recover from import competition that cut its business in half.

title: Commission Chief Seeks New Games To Spur Lottery
description: TRENTON, Feb. 8 (AP)The continued failure to increase ticket sales may force the New Jersey Lottery Commission to trade its present weekly and daily lottery games for new contests.

title: IRANIANS SEEK LINKS TO U.S. OIL CONCERNS
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 8Nanouchehr Eghbal, chairman of the National Iranian Oil Company, said today it was Inegotiating with a number of American oil companies for refining and distribution of oil in the United States. He did not disclose the names of the companies involved.

title: A Short Story by Franz Kafka
description: The Bucket Rider

title: PETROSIAN'S LEAD IN CHESS CUT TO 21
description: PALMA DE MALLORCA, Spain, Feb. 8 (AP)Lajos Portisch of Hungary beat Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union today in the 10th game of their quarterfinal world chess championship match.

title: Byrne Will Request More Aid for Cities In Budget Message
description: TRENTON, Feb. 8Governor Byrne promised today to seek additional state funds to help New Jersey's hardpressed cities, but acknowledged that we can't give them all the aid that they need.

title: McKellen Takes Lead In Figure U.S. S kating
description: PROVIDENCE, Feb. 8 Though admittedly worried about trailing in the event, Gordie McKellen kept his cool and moved into the lead today in the men's division of the national figure skating championships at the Civic Center.

title: Hawks Win As Esposito Stars, 30
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 8 (UPI)Chicago's goalie, Tony Esposito, recorded his seventh shutout of the season and lowered his goalsagainst average to 2.00 per game tonight as the Black Hawks beat Atlanta, 30, in a National Hockey League game.

title: 20 SENATORS OFFER AN ARMSCUT PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8A group of Senators set the stage today for a Congressional debate on the Administration's armscontrol policies by introducing a resolution calling for mutual reduction of strategic arms by the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: PRIME RATES CUT BY MAJOR BANKS
description: Several major banks, including the Bank of America the nation's largest, and the First National City Bank, larg est here and No. 2 in the country, lowered the interest rate they charge on loans to large corporations.

title: Briefs on Energy
description: LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP)The Burmah Oil Company has found another oilfield in the North Sea that may eventually produce half the crude oil Britain is now using, London newspapers reported today. The Daily Mail said experts believed the field could produce 266 million barrels of crude a year. The strike was made 110 miles northeast of the Shetland Islands, four miles from British Petroleum's Ninian field, where a major find was reported in January.

title: CHARLES SMITH, AIDE OF ROCKEFELLERS, 51
description: Charles B. Smith, a business associate of Laurance S. Rockefeller and the Rockefeller family since 1961, died Thursday of cancer in Memorial Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived in Princeton, N. J.

title: Music: Case of the Curious Cadenza
description: This cadenza is a curiosity. It is also wildly inappropriate to the music. What with its sophisticated harmonies and a kind of piano layout that belongs to a different world from Mozart's, it gave the impression of a fright wig on the head of a beautiful girl. One could only wonder at the mental processes that went through Mr. Eschenbach's mind in selecting this cadenza.

title: Ulster Villages Bombed
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 8 (Reuters)  Bombs wrecked utility wires and grocery store in the border villages of Crossmaglen and Colloville in Ulster today. Gun battles were reported in the area. A British army spokesman said, but security forces were not involved. No casualties were reported.

title: To Women, Insurance Companies Are at Fault on Many Things
description: The clocks on the towers of the giant insurance companies are usually accurate, displaying today's time. But, as many insurance company executives and agents themselves concede, the picture of American life that their companies have seems to date back to the turn of the century.

title: Business Activity Set a Record Pace For State in 1973
description: ALBANY, Feb. 8  The state's index of business activity  a key indicator of the health of New York's economy  reached a record high in 1973 despite the energy crisis, the state's Department of Commerce reported today.

title: Canal Zone Americans Debate Change
description: BALBOA, C.Z., Feb. 8  A decade of negotiations on a new Panama Canal treaty has divided the 12,000 American civilians living in the 550squaremile zone that runs along both sides of the waterway.

title: White House, Prosecutor Seek Accord on Evidence
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8James D. St. Clair, President Nixon's lawyer, met today with Leon Jaworski, the Watergate special prosecutor, in an attempt to resolve an apparent dispute over access to White House tape recordings and documents.

title: A Look at Why City Brewery Industry Went Flat
description: Friday, April 6, 1933, was a cloudy, topcoat kind of day in New York. A chill breeze cut through the crowd at Fifth Avenue and 34th Street, but no one there noticed. It was a great occasion. They had gathered to watch former Governor Alfred E. Smith accept the first legal beer in the city since the start of Prohibition 16 years before.

title: Crossings of the France To Be 6 Days to Cut Fuel
description: The French Line announced yesterday that its flagship, the France, would slow down on its transAtlantic sailings this spring and summer to conserve fuel. The ship will make the Atlantic crossing in six days instead of five.

title: Nets' Game Is Snowed Out
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 8The New York NetsIndiana Pacers scheduled basketball game at Nassau Coliseum tonight was postponed when the Pacer squad was unable to travel from Newark Airport because the snowstorm.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Shuffling into his defensive assignment not long ago, Ernie DiGregorio pointed at Calvin Murphy of the Houston Rockets and shouted:

title: Javits Asks Fund to Provide Jobs if Recession Comes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, proposed today the creation of a $4billion Government fund to provide public service jobs if a recession develops this year.

title: Army Moving Brooklyn Facility To Bayonne Military Terminal
description: The sprawling Brooklyn Army Terminal, a harbor landmark since the end of World War I, is about to be phased out as a military shipping installation, with its facilities being shifted to Bayonne.

title: RATIONING SYSTEM WORKS IN OREGON
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 8A gasoline rationing plan similar to the one requested in New York and mandated in New Jersey has been in effect here in Oregon for three weeks, and from all indications it has worked extremely well.

title: DISPOSAL OF WASTE ON LAND FORESEEN
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 8 (AP) The Reserve Mining Company said yesterday that it could develop plans within three months for an onland disposal system for taconite wastes that it now dumps into Lake Superior.

title: Oil in the Sacrifice Trap
description: The oil companies' present public relations problem probably flows from President Nixon's call for the nation to make sacrifices, which he issued when he proclaimed the energy crisis last fall.

title: A Czar Is Born
description: The Energy Czar; Mr. Simon, Gave a speech on the Energy Crunch And then, said Reliable Sources, Walked all the way home for his Lunch. They're chicken breasts, Cooed his Czarina, Kutlets a la Kiev, of koursYou just cook a fryer On top of the dryer. Dear, Will you be needing the horse?

title: Lottery Termed Bad Bet And Poor State Business
description: ALBANY, Feb. 8Not only are fewer and fewer people buying state lottery tickets, but those who buy tickets are gambling at the worst odds offered by almost any other form of gambling, legal or illegal, according to new criticism of the setup.

title: Indian Voting Rights
description: At a superficial glance, the suit brought by the Justice Department against the State of Arizona on behalf of 24,000 Indians living in Apache County seems a rather routine affair.

title: The Miners Say No
description: By refusing to postpone the nationwide coal miners' strike during the threeweek election campaign, the National Union of Mineworkers has given an additional push to an already dangerous polarization of Britain. In rejecting Prime Minister Heath's appeal for a delay, the union may also have enhanced the chances of victory for the Conservative Government on Feb, 28.

title: Notes on People
description: The deposed King Constantine of Greece learned yesterday that the Greek Government had annulled his sale of 630 acres of land at Tatoi, the royal family's private estate 16 miles north of Athens.

title: SubMinimum
description: For millions of the working poor, the Federal minimum wage of $1.60 an hour tends also to be the maximum wage. The Government's failure to raise that statutory pay floor through six years of inflation has had a crushing effect on the living standards of these families at the foot of the income ladder.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Listing of Prices for Transactions in Commodity Futures
I.R.S. Gets Data on Phone Calls By Times's Washington Staff
description: The Internal Revenue Service has secretly subpoenaed and received from a Washington telephone company records of evefy toll call that was made from The New York Times bureau in the capital from June, 1973, to last month.

title: I.B.M. FILES APPEAL OF AWARD TO TELEX
description: DENVER, Feb. 8 (AP)The International Business Machines Corporation filed its formal appeal today of a $259.5million damage award a Federal judge ordered its to, pay its computer competitor, the Telex Corporation.

title: Saigon Reports Many Killed In Central Highlands Battle
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 9 (AP)Reinforced South Vietnamese troops supported by an armored column battled North Vietnamese forces 14 miles southwest of the Central Highlands capital of Pleiku, the Saigon command reported today.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Ira Seret is leaving town, but before the native New Yorker gives up his East Side apartment and goes to Afghanistan to live there's the little matter of some 200 18thcentury tent hangings that he wants to sell.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MADISON TOWNSHIP, Feb. 8John Somogyi, once one of the best high school basketball players in New Jersey, must now sit on the bench and watch others struggle to do what once came so easily for him.

title: Man and 2 Children Killed In Fire in Adirondack Home
description: LONG LAKE, N. Y., Feb. (AP)A fire destroyed a twostory frame house last night, killing a man and his two children and injuring his pregnant wife.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The National Football League, responding to charges by the Players Association, denied yesterday that it planned to unilaterally cut off life, medical and dental insurance benefits to its players. Bill Curry of the Houston Oilers, president of the National Football League Players Association, charged yesterday that the owners had unilaterally canceled players' insurance and that the move could jeopardize overall contract negotiations, which are supposed to begin March 16.

title: Hundreds Are Stranded On CarClogged Roads
description: Martin Kutner didn't make it home to Glen Cove, L.I., last night and the Indiana Pacers didn't make it to the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale for their scheduled game with the New York Netsbut not for lack of trying.

title: SHULTZ OPPOSED TO OIL REPRISALS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8An angry Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz denounced today suggestions that the United States retaliate against the Arab oil embargo by controlling American exports and cutting foreign aid.

title: Rep. Moss Tells Treasury to End Agnew Guard
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 Representative John E. Moss demanded today that the Treasury Department withdraw the Secret Service detail now assigned to Spiro T. Agnew, the former Vice President.

title: Excerpts From Watergate Tapes Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8Following are excerpts from Judge Gerhard A. Gesell's ruling today on the Senate Watergate committee's subpoena of Presidential tape recordings:

title: Business Briefs
description: DETROIT, Feb. 8 (AP)Disruptions of parts delivery by striking truckers and weak consumer demand is causing a substantial drop in domestic auto production this week, according to Automotive News.

title: Space Officials Criticize TV's Lack of Coverage
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 8 (UPI)Space officials and the wives of astronauts criticized television networks today for not having provided live coverage of the Skylab 3 splashdown.

title: Rheingold: Deals Brew For Its Sale
description: Mayor Beame will meet Monday morning at Grade Mansion with representatives of the Rheingold Corporation; its parent, Pepsico, and a group of businessmen headed by Jerry Finkelstein, which has expressed interest in buying the Rheingold Brewery in Brooklyn.

title: MOTORISTS BEGIN A GRIM WEEKEND
description: The grimmest weekend of the gasoline shortage so far began for thousands of metropolitanarea motorists in the predawn darkness yesterday.

title: SUSSMAN SUIT GOING TO A 3JUDGE PANEL
description: TRENTON, Feb, 8 (AP)  A Federal judge decided today to recommend a special threejudge panel to review a novel court suit in which the controversial State Consumer Health Director, Dr. Oscar Sussman, has charged that his superiors tried to muzzle him.

title: Long Doubts Nixon Tax Fraud On Deduction for Gift of Papers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UPI) Senator Russel B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, said today that President Nixon was probably not guilty of fraud when he accepted the advice of legal and accounting aides in claiming tax reductions hat he was not entitled to take.

title: Norfolk Group Agrees to Buy Squires
description: NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 8 (UPI)A group of local businessmen announced today the signing of an agreement to buy the troubled Virginia Squires franchise in the American Basketball Association.

title: Court Blocks Ervin Panel On Request for 5 Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8Judge Gerhard A. Gesell of the United States District Court dismissed today a suit by the Senate Watergate committee to obtain five White House tapes on the ground that the blazing atmosphere of the committee's hearings might prejudice rights of potential defendants, including President Nixon.

title: Smith Upset By Ramirez In Florida
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 8 (AP)Raul Ramirez of Mexico upset Stan Smith in today's quarterfinals of the World Championship Tennis tour stop here.

title: WINE TALK
description: White wine with fish; red with meat. Right. Well, not always. Not even in Paris.

title: PreciousMetals List Gains As Stocks Continue Slide
description: The stock market was essentially a study in weakness yesterday as price declines ranged from former glamour favorites to more recent popular sectors such as the oils and oilrelated issues.

title: A Look at Why City Brewery Industry Went Flat
description: Friday, April 6, 1933, was a cloudy, topcoat kind of day in New York. A chill breeze cut through the crowd at Fifth Avenue and 34th Street, but no one there noticed. It was a great occasion. They had gathered to watch former Governor Alfred E. Smith accept the first legal beer in the city since the start of Prohibition 16 years before.

title: A Campaign Starts in Congress To Keep Panama Canal Control
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (Reuters)  Congressional supporters of continued American control of the Panama Canal mounted a campaign today against the agreement to eventually transfer sovereignty to the Panamanians.

title: Milburn Lowers World Hurdles Record at Garden
description: Rod Milburn set another world record, Francie Larrieu and Byron Dyce scored impressive victories, and Marty Liguori went flat last night at the United States Olympic Invitation track meet.

title: High School Notes
description: A group of more than 70 high school students who work on school publications visited the New York Stock Exchange this week.

title: ELIZABETH HAILS STATE RATIONING
description: ELIZABETH, Feb. 8Officials here welcomed the news that the rest of the state will begin rationing gasoline on an alternateday system similar to that enforced here since Monday.

title: Assistant Gets Backing For U.S. Attorney's Post
description: Republican leaders in Brooklyn and Nassau and Suffolk Counties are recommending Edward Thompson Jr., for appointment as United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York in an open show of support that makes him the current frontrunner for the job.

title: Plan Is Dropped to Narrow Heating Oil Price Spread
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8John C. Sawhill, the deputy administrator of the Federal Energy Office, said today that the agency had dropped a proposal published last week for narrowing the spread between heating oil prices being charged by various retail distributors.

title: Nixon Speaks on Radio Today About Transport
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)President Nixon will make a radio broadcast live from the White House at 3 P.M. tomorrow on transportation initiatives for the nation, the White House announced today.

title: U.S. AUTOS SHOW GAINS IN CANADA
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 8In sharp contrast to the performance of the United States automobile industry, the Big Four manufacturers in Canada had a good January, with total sales of passenger cars in this country 15.9 per cent higher than in January of last year.

title: Sports News Briefs.
description: The National Football League, responding to charges by the Players Association, denied yesterday that it planned to unilaterally cut off life, medical and dental insurance benefits to its players. Bill Curry of the Houston Oilers, president of the National Football League Players Association, charged yesterday that the owners had unilaterally canceled players' insurance and that the move could jeopardize overall contract negotiations, which are supposed to begin March 16.

title: Celtics Wallop Knicks, 12597; Injury Sidelines DeBusschere
description: BOSTON, Feb. 8  The Knicks forgot tonight they were the best defensive team in the National Basketball Association. They let the Boston Celtics do what they do bestrunand were battered, 12597, at the Boston Garden.

title: FOREIGN SECURITIES
description: (In U.S. Dollars) Price in dollars are valid only for stocks accompanied by Validation Certificate.

title: Wobbly Skylab Astronauts End 84Day Orbital Flight
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 8Wobblylegged but cheerful, the Skylab 3 astronauts returned this morning from 84 days in orbit around the earth, man's longest space flight. Except for a linkup between United States and Soviet spacecraft planned for next year, the Skylab mission that ended today was the last scheduled flight by American astronauts until a two  stage shuttle rocket now being developed begins operations in 1979 or later.

title: Army Takes Over in Upper Volta
description: OUAGADOUGOU, Upper Volta, Feb. 8 (Reuters)  The army seized power in the West African nation of Upper Volta today, although Gen. Sangoul Lamizana, head of state for eight years, will apparently remain President.

title: Oil Crisis in Western Europe Causes Inconvenience but Little Suffering
description: LONDON, Feb. 8In a gesture that symbolized the mood in many European countries, Sweden's Trade Minister, KjellOlof Feldt, tore up his gasoline ration card with a flourish last week as rationing in Sweden ended after only 22 days.

title: DONALD C. M'GRAW, PUBLISHER IS DEAD
description: Donald C. McGraw, former president of McGrawHill, Inc., the huge publishing concern, died Thursday at Bethesda Memorial Hospital in Boynton Beach, Fla., a company spokesman announced yesterday. He said the cause of Mr. McGraw's death, at the age of 76, had not yet been determined.

title: The Energy Crisis: For Blacks, a Disproportionate Burden
description: About the only certainty in the energy crisis Situation is that black people will bear a disproportionate burden of the sacrifices and penalties. We will suffer this latest crisis disproportionately because we are disproportionately poor, because we are concentrated in the most vulnerable sectors of the labor force and because there is little concern or planning for lessening the impact of the energy shortage on poor people and black people.

title: Cancer Found Electronically
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 A university scientist has discovered an electronic method of detecting cancer. Dr. Raymond V. Damadian, professor of biophysics at the State University's Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn, was granted a patent this week for the apparatus and method. As Dr. Damadian explains, radio signals distinguish cancer tissue from normal tissue. Atoms from the cancer cells serve as transmitters, sending signals with distinct wavelengths.

title: Surging Inflation Impedes Malaysia's Growth
description: KUALA LUMPUR, MalaysiaThe price of progress for developing countries in Asia has included inflation and industrial unrest, for wages have failed to keep pate with the rising cost of living, and workers have seen their own expectations unrealized, despite national economic gains.

title: Formula Two Race Off
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 8 (AP)Orgaunizers of the Belgian Formupla Two Grand Prix. scheduled to be held June 23 at Zolder; announced today the event was canceled because a United States oil company sponsoring the race is revising its policy of support to auto sport. The company was to have not more than half the organization costs or $65,000.

title: EGYPTIANS DECIDE ON 3 MAJOR STEPS
description: CAIRO, Feb. 8  President Anwar elSadat has shelved plans to revise his Cabinet and will continue as his own Premier until every inch of Israelioccupied Egyptian territory has been recovered, the authoritative newspaper Al Ahram said today.

title: Most Truckers Still Idle; Confusion on Pact Is Wide
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 Most of the striking independent truckers apparently remained off the nation's highways today despite optimistic statements by Administration officials that overtheroad freight traffic would be back to normal soon.

title: New Quotas Placed on Exports Of Certain Petroleum Products
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) The Commerce Department placed new quotas today on exports of certain petroleum products, to bring a halt to big increases in exports of petroleum items that are needed at home.

title: Formula Two Race Off
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 8 (AP)Orgaunizers of the Belgian Formupla Two Grand Prix, scheduled to be held June 23 at Zolder, announced today the event was canceled because a United States oil company sponsoring the race is revising its policy of support to auto sport. The company was to have not more than half the orgvozation costs or $65,000.

description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 8 AP)Gov. Philip Noel submited to the General Assembly ??o day a record $424.5million ??udget, that would allow a re??uction in business taxes in ??opes of attracting industry ??o Rhode Island.

title: Harvard Business School Is Declared Off Limits For Military Officers, With R.O.T.C. Fight Blamed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8The Defense Department has ruled that military officers can no longer attend the Harvard Business School. The official Pentagon explanation is that the school does not offer a unique program of study.

title: Guerrillas Free Japanese, Go to Yemen
description: KUWAIT, Feb. 8Five Palestinian guerrillas who seized the Japanese Embassy here flew to Aden in Southern Yemen today after releasing their Japanese diplomatic hostages in an operation that angered public opinion here.

title: Plan Is Dropped to Narrow Heating Oil Price Spread
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8John C. Sawhill, the deputy administrator of the Federal Energy Office, said today that the agency had dropped a proposal published last week for narrowing the spread between heating oil prices being charged by various retail distributors.

description: TRENTON, Feb. 8Governor Byrne announced a mandatory statewide gasoline  rationing program for New Jersey today, imposing a systeni based on alternateday purchasing that will begin Monday.
