Yancey's Stunning 61 for 204 Earns 3Shot Lead
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 8A 61 by Bert Yancey 11 strokes under parupstaged a flock of other spectacular rounds today and left him leading the pack with 204 in the Bob Hope Desert Classic, which has two days to go in its 90hole golf competition.

title: In Phnom Penh, Take Any Road to the. War
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 8  Take a road, any road, out of Phnom Penh and in 5 to 10 miles, or even less, you will find the commonplace of war.

title: OilIndustry Tax Burden Termed Largest in U.S.
description: The oil industry bears a larger total domestic tax burden per dollar of sales than the rest of American industry, according to a study released yesterday by the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation.

title: Antiques: Action Banks
description: Most of the penny gobblers that mechanical bank collectors vied for this week at PB 84, 117 East 84th Street, were acquired reportedly by the late Joseph Revson, a Revlon, Inc., founder, long before the prices for these cast iron collectibles began to skyrocket.

title: British Miners Reject Appeal; To Strike Now Despite Election
description: LONDON, Feb. 8  Leaders of Britain's coal miners decided today to go ahead with their national strike Sunday, rejecting an appeal by Prime Minister Heath to postpone it until after the election later this month.

title: Retailers Seek to Stimulate the Sale of Men's Apparel as Prices Rise
description: DALLAS, Feb. 8Retailers of men's apparel are somewhat concerned that their customers may not be in buying mood. So they're going all out to come up with new ways of stimulating sales in a year of rising prices and an uncertain economy.

title: Army Installation In Brooklyn to Go To Site in Bayonne
description: The sprawling Brooklyn Army Terminal, a harbor landmark since the end of World War I, is about to be phased out as a military shipping installation, with its facilities being shifted to Bayonne, N. J.

title: Ouster of Mindszenty Followed Grave Reflection, Vatican Says
description: ROME, Feb. 8The Vatican said today that Pope Paul's decision to remove Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty as an archbishop and hence as primate of Hungary had followed prolonged, mature and grave reflection.

title: Nitze Scheduled for Key Pentagon Post
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8In a move that may affect the balance of influence on national security issues within the Administration, President Nixon is expected to nominate Paul H. Nitze to a high Pentagon post next week.

title: Braves Halt Bull Streak, 106 to 101
description: BUFFALO, Feb 8 (UPI)Matt Guokas scored only 6 points, but they were key baskets in Buffalo's 106101 victory over Chicago tonight. The Braves ended the Bulls' 10game winning streak and notched their third triumph in a row.

title: CAMBODIA REPORTS KILLING 120 REBELS
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 8 (UPI)Cambodian Government forces said they strengthened their positions south of Phnom Penh today, routing rebels from two strategic points and killing more than 120 of them.

title: DAMON G. DOUGLAS
description: Damon G. Dauglas, board chairman of the Damon G. Douglas Company, Newark building contractors, died in a nursing home Wednesday at the age of 75.

title: RATIONING SYSTEM WORKS IN OREGON
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 8A gasoline rationing plan similar to the one requested in New York and mandated in New Jersey has been in effect here in Oregon for three weeks, and from all indications it has worked extremely well.

title: Spadework by Bonsai Dealer Helps in Return of Brooklyn Trees
description: A quickwitted bonsai dealer in Manhattan's flower district yesterday helped the Brooklyn Botanic Garden recover $7,000 collection of patiently tended miniature trees stolen earlier in the week.

title: Grenada Chief Reports Evidence of Plot
description: ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada, Feb. 8Prime Minister Eric M. Gairy said today that evidence of a plot to assassinate him had been found in the home of an opposition leader.

title: State Intercedes in Development Of West Side Renewal Project
description: State and city officials announced an agreement yesterday under which the state rather than the city will guide the development of seven the sites, involving 1,500 apartments, in the West Side Urban Renewal Project.

title: Saigon Frees 200 Prisoners In First Exchange in 6 Months
description: BIEN HOA, South Vietnam, Feb. 8  The Saigon Government released 200 prisoners tolay in a resumption of the 3risoner exchange that had been suspended for six months.

title: SEVERAL ASSISTANTS QUIT JUSTICE. DEPT.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)  The director of the Justice Department's think tank and almost all of his professional staff members are resigning.

title: Release of 2 May Be Kidnapping Price
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 8The Federal Bureau of Investigation agent directing the search for Patricia Hearst said today that it is logical to speculate that the next demand of the kidnappers will be to exchange men now in jail for her release.

title: A Sofa That Can Be a Mile or So Long
description: A 180foot sofa? Certainly, if that's what you want. Or the same style, but measuring only 18 or 27 or 36 inches? Certainly, if that's what you want.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 31

title: Gillette Unit Is Expanding
description: BOSTON, Feb, 8 (AP)The Gillette Company announced yesterday that its West German subsidiary, Braun, A. G., would build a $7million to $9million factory in Ireland. The factory, to be constructed about 35 miles southwest of Dublin, will make pocket and table lighters. Between 250 to 300 persons would be employed at the factory when it is completed this fall, the company sad.

title: R0USSEL TRADING HALTED IN PARIS
description: PARIS, Feb. 8  The Paris Stock Exchange has temporarily suspended trading in shares of the RousselUclaf Company, one of France's top pharmaceeutical enterprises, while discussions continue over a holding company by by Farbwerke Hoechst of West Germany. It would be the most important FrenchGerman commercial marriage in years and create a new international giant.

title: Golf Upsets Oust Baugh, Whitworth
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 8 (AP)Kathy Whitworth and Laura Baugh were the biggest firstround casualties today as the $100,000 Ladies Profession) Golfers Association tournament started with match play.

title: BUSINESS IN STATE SETS RECORD PACE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 8  The state's index, of business activity  a key indicator of the health of New York's economy  reached a record high in 1973 despite the energy crisis, the state's Department of Commerce reported today.

title: BYRNE ANNOUNCES MANDATORY PLAN OF GAS RATIONING
description: TRENTON, Feb. 8Governor Byrne announced a mandatory statewide gasoline  rationing program for New Jersey today, imposing a system based on alternateday purchasing that will begin Monday.

title: Radford Says He Had Instructions to Pilfer Papers
description: DENVER, Feb. 8Navy Yeoman 1st Cl. Charles E. Radford, publicly named as the key Figure in alleged military snooping activities, declared today that he had been specifically Instructed by two admirals to lifer topsecret documents from the White House.

title: Napoles, Monzon In Big Top Tonight
description: PARIS, Feb. 8In the middleweight title fight tomorrow night, Carlos Monzon, the champion, is expected to come out punching, Jos Napoles, the challenger is expected to come out thinking, and Alain Delon, the promoter, is expected to come out ahead.

title: Smith Upset By Ramirez In Florida
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 8 (AP)Raul Ramirez of Mexico upset Stan Smith in today's quarterfinals of the World Championship Tennis tour stop here.

title: U.S. Drops Hospital Review Plan That Was Opposed by Doctors
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has abandoned its proposal to require a review by a hospital committee before any Medicaid or Medicare patient could be admitted to a hospital in a nonemergency situation.

title: Screen: Walking Tall
description: Walking Tall, which opened yesterday at the New Embassy 46th Street and other theaters around town, comes to Manhattan as much a phenomenon to be analyzed as a film to be reviewed.

title: Bridge:
Kuwait Oil Auction: Lower Bids Seen
description: KUWAIT, Feb. 8A large auction of Governmentowned crude oil to be held here this month is being watched for indications of whether a downturn has been reached in Persian Gulf prices.

title: Wobbly Skylab Astronauts End 84Day Orbital Flight
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 8  Wobblylegged but cheerful, the Skylab 3 astronauts returned this morning from 84 days orbit around the earth, man's longest space flight. Except for a linkup between United States and Soviet spacecraft planned for next year, the Skylab mission that ended today was the last scheduled flight by American astronauts until a two  stage shuttle rocket now being developed begins operations in 1979 or later.

title: Frank Wallace Marries Louise Cowper
description: Miss Louise laRoque Cowper, director of merchandising and promotion for the Scandinavian Mink Association, was married here last evening to Frank Edward Wallace, president of Corellen, Ltd., an importexport textiles firm. The Rev. Lawrence Prast performed the ceremony in the Chapel of the Beloved Disciple of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: AIDE TO MOM TELLS OF INQUIRY
description: A detective assigned to investigate a $4.4million confidence racket operated by Joseph Ferdinando admitted yesterday that he had deliberately withheld from his official reports the names of investors within the Queens District Attorney's office.

title: Most Truckers Still Idle; Confusion on Pact Is Wide
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 Most of the striking independent truckers apparently remained off the nation's highways today despite optimistic statements by Administration officials that overtheroad freight traffic woujd be back to normal soon.

title: Huge Gasoline Cache Found in Closed Filling Station
description: TOMS RIVER, Feb. 8 (AP)A New Jersey Representative lifted the lids off four underground tanks in an abandoned filling station today and uncovered 26,800 gallons of gasoline.

title: JOSEPH F. MONTAGUE, STOMACH SPECIALIST
description: SUN CITY, Ariz., Feb. 8Dr. Joseph F. Montague, an authority on intestinal and stomach disorders and author of many books on medical subjects, died Wednesday at Boswell Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Garrison, N.Y.

title: Constructing a Calder Is a Labor of Love
description: WATERBURY, Conn., Feb. 8Like a monster intent on devouring Waterbury, a giant orange creature perches menacingly above Interstate 84 here.

title: U.S. Goals Ambitious for Oil Parley
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8Senfor American officials said today that they hoped next week's Washington energy conference would lay the groundwork for eventual cooperation between oil consumers and producers, resulting in adequate oil supplies at reasonable prices with a good return to the producers.

title: Detergen Elements Are to Be Itemized Under F.T.C. Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission proposed today that detergent makers be required to list all ingredients and their functions on packages so that consumers would know what they were buying and what it was supposed to do.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CHURCHLY A long time ago, the rich called the Fort Greene area of Brooklyn home. They built comfortable houses and spacious churches, among them the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church at 85 South Oxford Street, at Lafayette Avenue (MA 57515), near historic Fort Greene Park.

title: Dance: Don Quixote
description: Don Quixote, George Balanchine's richly theatrical pageant for the New York City Ballet, returned Thursday night for a weeklong run at the State Theater. As usual, there have been a few changes from the previous year's production.

title: New High Reached By Gold in London; Dollar Shows Gains
description: LONDON, Feb. 8 (UPI)Buyers in France, West Germany and the Middle East flooded London's gold market today with orders, pushing the metal's price to a new high of $145 an ounce.

title: Snow Curtails OTB; Florida Bets Taken
description: Yesterday's snowstorm forced cancellation of racing at six tracks in the Northeast and put a severe ednt in the activity of the Offtrack Betting Corporation.

title: Tuition Is Up at Bates
description: LEWISTON, Me., Feb. 8 (AP) The cost of going to Bates College will rise $400 to $4,350 next year, Thomas H. Reynolds, the president, announced today. The figure includes tuition, room, board and fees.

title: Shier Puts Her Country On the Map
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 8Liechtenstein, a halfhour ski ride from its eastern to western borders, found a place in the ski world today while the United States continued to close its position.

title: Yancey's Stunning 61 for 204 Earns 3Shot Lead
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 8A 61 by Bert Yancey 11 strokes under parupstaged a flock of other spectacular rounds today and left him leading the pack with 204 in the Bob Hope Desert Classic, which has two days to go in its 90hole golf competition.

title: DR. THEODORE T. ODELL
description: GENEVA, N. Y. Feb. 8Dr. Theodore Telleffen Odell, professor emeritus of biology at Hobart College, who retired in 1965 after 44 years as a teacher, died today at his home here. His age was 77.

title: First Woman Conductor Signed by City Opera
description: Judith Somogi will become the first woman conductor of the New York City Opera when she makes her podium debut with the company at the New York State Theater at the March 17 performance of Gilbert and Sullivan's The Mikado. She is also scheduled to conduct the work in four subsequent performances.

title: Manhattan Five Here Tonight
description: Just two nights after scoring their seventh triumph in a row, an 8073 overtime victory over St. Joseph's of Philadelphia, the Manhattan Jaspers return to Madison Square Garden tonight in the opener of a college doubleheader against Fairfield University.

title: Soviet Matmen Rout U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 8 (Reuters) The Soviet Union defeated the United States, eight matches to one, in a freestyle wrestling meet in Minsk today, Toss, the Soviet news agency, reported.

title: 2d Show Pits Avery's Art Against European Works
description: The Figure: Milton Avery and the European Masters, the exhibition on view at the Borgenicht Gallery, 1018 Madison Avenue at 79th Street, is the second installment in the gallery's program of pitting the works of the lateand I think, great American painter against the works of Avery's European contemporaries. Last year, the gallery mounted a similar show of Avery's brusque, seemingly primitive but very sophisticated stilllites exhibited in the company of similar works by Brague, Gris, Vuillard and Bonnard, others.

title: Michigan House Approves  Return to Standard Time
description: LANSING, Mich. Feb. 8 (UPI) The Michigan House of Representatives voted today to take the state off daylight saving time after this season and return to standard time Oct. 27.

title: FRANCEIRAQ DEAL ON OIL IS REPORTED
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. (AP)A Beirut newspaper, An Nahar, reported today from Baghdad that France and Iraq were negotiating a billiondollar oil deal.

title: PinStriped to Core
description: Henry C. Wallich is a gentle man. Mildmannered, cigarsmoking, pinstriped to his core, the 59yearold Yale University professor is not one to shake the rafters or upset the establishment at the central bank of the United States.

title: Rules Due to Aid Women in Sports
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 8 (AP)The Federal government expects to issue regulations that will help women in sports, according to Peter E. Holmes, director of the Office of Civil Rights.

title: Sydney Breese, Engineer And Designer, Dies at 90,
description: Sydney S. Breese, an engineer, who had designed automobiles, airplanes and training torpedoes, died Jan. 30 in Sarasota, Fla. He was 90 years old and formerly lived in Southampton, L.I.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Food costs in the metropolitan area rose ninetenths of 1 per cent in December as a result of marked increases in the prices of milk, eggs, dried beans and rice, the United States Department of Labor reported yesterday. The rise in the cost of those items, however, was partly offset by lower prices for meats, poultry, fresh fruits and vegetables.

title: EGYPTIANS DECIDE ON 3 MAJOR STEPS
description: CAIRO, Feb. 8  President Anwar elSadat has shelved plans to revise his Cabinet and will continue as his own Premier until every inch of Israelioccupied Egyptian territory has been recovered, the authoritative newspaper Al Abram said today.

title: SHULTZ OPPOSED TO OIL REPRISALS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8An angry Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz denounced today suggestions that the United States retaliate against the Arab oil embargo by controlling American exports and cutting foreign aid.

title: Rabbi Miller New Chairman Of Jewish Presidents' Unit
description: The election of Rabbi Israel Miller as chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations was announced yesterday.

title: Pop Music: FolkRock's Ethel Mermani
description: Joni Mitchell has in previous performances stood, flaxenhaired and frail, alone in the spotlight. On Tuesday at Avery Fisher Hall, however, she threw this sedate image aside as she crashed into her first song, backed by the L. A. Express group, a jazzrock unit dominated by the tough saxophone (both tenor and soprano) of its leader, Tom Scott.

title: State Bicentennial Celebration Opens In Former Capital of Crown Colony
description: BURLINGTON, Feb. 8 This former capital of the Crown Colony of West Jersey ignored heavy snow today and harked back 200 years to commemorate the establishment of a committee of patriots who helped foment the American Revolution.

title: Screen: Walking Tall
description: Walking Tall, which opened yesterday at the New Embassy 46th Street and other theaters around town, comes to Manhattan as much a phenomenon to be analyzed as a film to be reviewed.

title: New Jersey Briefs Measles Outbreak in State Worsens
description: The outbreak of measles in New Jersey is getting worse, with 159 new cases reported this week, the State Health Department reported. Last week there were 57 new cases. The total of cases since last Sept. 1 is 860.

title: Roberto Out of Shape
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 8 (UPI)Phil Roberto, trying to return to a regular spot in the St. Louis Blues' lineup after serious arm surgery, voluntarily reported to the Blues' Denver farm team today to play himself into shape. Roberto returned to the Blues' lineup seven games ago but was used sparingly by Coach Jean Guy Talbot. He had one goal and one assist in the seven games.

title: President of Oglala Sioux Is Reelected
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., Feb. 8Richard Wilson, a 40yearold plumbing contractor, was reelected president of the Oglala Sioux Indian tribe yesterday, defeating Russell C. Means by 1,709 votes to 1,530.

title: VENEZUELAN OIL CUT BY 2 MISHAPS
description: More than a third of Venezuela's 1.5millionbarreladay refining capacity was put out of operation yesterday following seperate accidents at two major installations.

title: Israeli Quintet Boasts Fighting Spirit
description: Some players on the Israeli national basketball team were sitting in a hotel room in Spain last Octber during the European championships when someone turned on a television set and they discovered their country was at war.

title: Market Place: High Yields on Small Account
description: A writer who believed herself to be unsophisticated in finance approached a financial man recently and said:

title: The Insane Ones
description: Several years ago when riots and arson were breaking out unpredictably in Newark, Detroit and other cities, there were alarming predictions of a new kind of civil war. Police departments in some cities were reportedly buying machine guns, helicopters and even tanks and armored vehicles to combat violent action that might be initiated by secret revolutionary groups.

title: Gigi Run Ends Tomorrow
description: Gigi, the Alan Jay Lerner Frederick Loewe musical based on the novel by Colette, will end its run at the Uris Theater tomorrow after 103 performances. The show costars Alfred Drake, Arlene Francis, Maria Karnilova and Daniel Massey.

title: South Korean Premier Defends Jailing of Critics
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 8Premier Kim Jong Pil of South Korea asserted today that the imprisonment of political critics who advocated the restoration of democratic rule here was justified to prevent social disorder and chaos.

title: Dana Latham, 75, Former Head Of the Internal Revenue, Is Dead
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 8 (AP) Dana Latham, United States Commissioner of Internal Revenue from 1958 to 1961, died of a heart attack Wednesday at the age of 75.

title: Peking Says the High Tide of Its New Campaign Is Still to Come
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 8  New pronouncements from China today declared that the high tide of the new ideological drive is still to come and that what has been seen so far is just the beginning.

title: Nixon Tapes Going to Mitchell Judge
description: Federal prosecutors disclosed yesterday that they had obtained two new White House tape recordings for the judge in the trial of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans.

title: People and Business
description: The election of Felix Kaufman as president of the Institute of Management Consultants, announced here yesterday, may close a rift between two substantial parts of the consultant industry, and certainly reflects changed attitudes, observers agreed.

title: HalfGallon Gas Price Seen
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) Motorists soon may find the price of gasoline posted on gasoline pumps for a halfgallon instead of a gallon, if a recommendation of the National Bureau of Standards is followed. Many gasoline stations are faced with problems because their gasoline pumps can list prices no higher than 49.9 cents a gallon.

title: Why Reds Got Under the Bed
description: LONDONThere is much talk about Reds and Communists in England today but though an employers' organization labeled this country's coal strike with a slogan in a booklet called Reds Under the Bed, the problem posed by the confrontation looming is certainly not just a Kremlin ploy. And the British masses have a sufficiently high standard of tolerance to know this.

title: Wilkins Charges Lack of Policy On Housing Could Peril Nation
description: Roy Wilkins, president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said yesterday that a nation with more than 70 per cent of its population in urban centers, inner cities and suburbs will collapse without a Government policy on building for the great bulk of that population.

title: Cavett Calls Canceled Show Harmless
description: Dick Cavett, expressing astonishment that the American Broadcasting Company had canceled his program with radicals leaders of the nineteensixties at the last moment Thursday; night, said he would not agree to the network's proposal that he edit the 90minute program down to allow for an additional 30 minutes of opposing viewpoints, in the spirit of fairness and balance.

title: British Miners Reject Appeal; To Strike Now Despite Election
description: LONDON, Feb. 8  Leaders of Britain's coal miners decided today to go ahead with their national strike Sunday, rejecting an appeal by Prime Minister Heath to postpone it until after the election later this month.

title: PRECIOUS METALS POST PRICE GAINS
description: Record prices for gold in Europe contributed to new highs in silver futures contracts yesterday on the Commodity Exchange here. March silver closed at $4.81 an ounce, up the 15 cents daily limit.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Todd Shipyards Corporation reported yesterday the signing of contracts valued at a total of $136million for construction of four 89,700 deadweight ton tankers. Two will be built for subsidiaries of Overseas Shipholding Group, Inc., and the other two for affiliates of Seres Shipping, Inc, The vessels will be built at Todd's Los Angeles division.

title: 3 Found Not Guilty Of Securities Fraud In 4 Seasons Case
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 8A United States District Court jury found three of four defendants not guilty last night in a multimilliondollar stockfraud trial involving Four Seasons Nursing Centers of Amerlica, Inc.

title: IVO C. SAIN
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 8Ivo C. Sain, a retired investment analyst who had been a finance minister in the Yugoslav Government in Exile, died yesterday at his home, 143 Beach Street. He was 76 years old.

title: Hard to Be a Jew Closing
description: Hard to Be a Jew, the musical adaptation of Sholom Aleichem's story, will end its run tomorrow at the Eden Theater, Second Avenue and 12th Street, after 129 performances. The musical was adapted by Joseph Buloff, who starred in it, and David Licht. The music is by Sholom Secunda, the lyrics by Yitzchok Perlov and the choreography by Peearl Lang.

title: Carvers Ply Old Art at National Cathedral
description: WASHINGTONSome people have their faces carved on the sides of mountains. Others are immortalized as equestrian statues. Roger Morigi is a gargoyle.

title: Court Blocks Ervin Panel On Request for 5 Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8Judge Gerhard A. Gesell of the United States District Court dismissed today a suit by the Senate Watergate committee to obtain five White House tapes on the ground that the blazing atmosphere of the committee's hearings might prejudice rights of potential defendants, including President Nixon.

title: Books of The Times  The Brass in Retreat
description: DEFEATED: INSIDE AMERICA'S MILITARY MACHINE. By Stuart H. Loory. Ramdom House. $10.

title: Indian Ocean Base Is Opposed By Australia and New Zealand
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 8 (UPI)  Australia and New Zealand have joined in opposing a BritishAmerican agreement to build up military facilities on the island of Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
description: Cloudy skies and cold temperatures, possibly accompanied by lingering flurries, are forecast today for the Northeast. Cloudy skies will spread from the Middle Atlantic States across the upper lake region to eastern Nebraska. Some snow may develop over the central Appalachians, while showers are expected in central Florida. Cloudy skies will also cover the Tennessee Valley and most of Florida. It will be cold along the Eastern Seaboard and in the Ohio Valley and Northern Plains States. Generally fair and warmer weather will dominate much of the rest of the country.

title: The Stage: Wilford Leach's CORFAX
description: Demons and ghosts haunt the work of Wilford Leach, but there is also an antic side to this innovative playwrightdirector. His latest play, CORFAX (Don't Ask), now running at La Mama, combines his gifts for the gothic and the comic.

title: WORST SNOWFALL OF WINTER TIES UP MOST ROADS HERE
description: The heaviest snowstorm of the winter so far blustered over the metropolitan area yesterday, causing huge traffic jams and hundreds of minor vehicular accidents and prompting the city to declare its first snow emergency in five years.

title: Art: Alice Neel Retrospective
description: Like Chichikov, Alice Neel once remarked, I am a collector of, souls. Judging from the retrospective exhibition of Mrs. Neel's paintings, which opened this week at the Whitney Museum of American Art, I should say that she was more of a collector of faces than of souls. But however one may choose to describe it, the focus of her interest is unmistakable: it is firmly fastened to her subject rather than on the subtleties or strengths of the pictorial medium.

title: Manhattan Five Here Tonight
description: Just two nights after scoring their seventh triumph in a row, an 8073 overtime victory over St. Joseph's of Philadelphia, the Manhattan Jaspers return to Madison Square Garden tonight in the opener of a college doubleheader against Fairfield University.

title: Wallich Is Approved for Fed; Pollack Confirmed for S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (Reuters)  The Senate approved without objection today the nominations of Henry C. Wallich to be a governor of the Federal Reserve Board and Irving M. Pollack to be a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: COUNCIL APPROVES FIREMEN'S RAISES
description: The Cost of Living Council in Washington cleared the way yesterday for the city to pay retroactive salary increases totaling $950 each to more than 11,000 firemen here.

title: MeKellen Takes Lead In Figure U.S. Skating
Securities Top Cop
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 One of the severest critics of the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that one of the best appointments President Nixon ever made was that of Irving Pollack to the S.E.C.

title: WORST SNOWF ALL OF WINTER TIES UP MOST ROADS HERE
description: The heaviest snowstorm of the winter so far blustered over the metropolitan area yesterday, causing huge traffic jams and hundreds of minor vehicular accidents and prompting the city to declare its first snow emergency in five years.

title: Rheingold: Deal Brews For Its Sale
description: Mayor Beame will meet Monday morning at Gracie Mansion with representatives of the Rheingold Corporation; its parent, Pepsico, and a group of businessmen headed by Jerry Finkelstein, which has expressed interest in buying the Rheingold Brewery in Brooklyn.

title: KerrMcGee Increases Its Profits for the Quarter and Year
People in Sports: Wheels Pick Coach Dartmouth
description: The Detroit Wheels of the World Football League are beginning to roll. Yesterday the club named Dan Boisture of Eastern Michigan University as coach. Boisture, coach at Eastern Michigan since 1967, signed a threeyear contract.

title: Fashions Will Aid School
description: FAR HILLS  Despite uncertain temperatures, continuing gasoline shortages and other discouraging facts of life, the Parents Committee at Gill/St. Bernard's School will stage a preValentine's Day fashion showluncheon here Wednesday. It will be held at the Fiddler's Elbow Country Club.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Skylab Success Sparks Talk of Permanently Occupied Station
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 9  Th Skylab program, whose smooth conclusion yesterday began an almost total hiatus in flights by American astronauts for at least five years, has made the idea of continuous occupation of an orbital base more concrete to the directors of American space efforts.

title: R. L. Hersh Fiance Of Jane S. Bergson
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Feb. 9Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Bergson of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Sylvia Bergson, to Robert Leonard Hersh, son of Robert Hersh of Harrison and the late Mrs. Hersh. A June wedding Is planned.

title: The Lass With The Delicate Lied
description: ELLY AMELING is, much like her lieder singing, rather direct, to the point and natural. Much unlike her sister sopranos, Miss Ameling is not fearful of the elementsshe bathes daily in ice cold water and is titillated by the rigors of wintry weather. The singer recently even smoked her first cigarette and liked ita giant NoNo in the vocal community. There is nothing indulgent or pampered about this lady or her art.

title: OnceMilitant Militano Cuts a Quieter Figure
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 9 Last Thursday night, Melissa Militano of Dix Hills, L. I., and Johnny Johns won the pairs event at the United States figure skating championships here and earned a standing ovation at the Civic Center. One of the first to stand was Melissa's brother, Mark, with whom she had won the title the previous year.

title: Warning Is Issued On Sewer Hookups
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I.Residents of the Massapequas were warned last week to be on the lookout for unlicensed plumbers offering ?? hook their houses up to the central sewage lines. Town Supervisor John W. Burke suggested that residents call the town building division at 9225800 from 9 A.M. to 4:45 P.M. before hiring any contractor.

title: Lewis Smith to Wed Miss Bolgar on June 2
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 9Mr. and Mrs. George Bolgar have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marianne Bolger, to Lewis Joseph Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold M. Smith of Paterson. The wedding is planned for June 2.

title: Rangers Fall, 72, to Canadiens
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 9The Montreal Canadiens just about destroyed the chances of the Rangers for second place in the National Hockey League East tonight by rounting the New Yorkers, 72, at The Forum.

title: Building a Common Oil Policy
description: LONDON  As a serious problem for the world, quite apart from the immediate difficulties associated with the ArabIsraeli conflict, the oil crisis has been grossly exaggerated.

title: ITALY MAY LIMIT CARS, MEAT SALES
description: ROME, Feb. 9Italians are talking about little these days besides the Government's new austerity plan, which is bound to hurt them in two sensitive areas: their cars and their kitchens.

title: Soviet Prosecutor Issues a Summons For Solzhenitsyn but Wife Rejects It
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 9  The Soviet state prosecutor's office has taken the first legal step against Aleksandr 1. Solzhenitsyn since the publication of his latest book by issuing a summons for the author to meet with investigators, friends of his family disclosed today.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Harlem Globetrotters will perform their antics Saturday in Madison Square Garden at 10:30 A.M. and 7:30 P.M., with two additional shows slated for next Sunday.

title: Landlord Group to Stop Buying Heating Oil Until Price Is Cut
description: A group of the city's largest realestate operators, managers of an estimated 400,000 apartments, said yesterday that they would stop buying oil to heat their buildings until the price was rolled back to the level of last Dec. 15.

title: U.S. CLIMBERS NAMED FOR RUSSIAN ASCENT
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 9The American Alpine Club has forwarded to the Soviet mountaineering federation the names of a dozen American mountain climbers who will attempt a new ascent this summer of the Soviet Union's third highest mountain, 23,405foot Lenin Peak.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The boom in nonredidential construction slowed down after mid1973 in the major of the country, according to Commercial Construction Markets Survey, a quarterly report published by Sheifman & Associates, a Detroit reearch firm.

title: Sam Goldwyn Always Had the Last Word
description: WRITERS write. Directors direct. Cameramen take pictures. But what in heaven's name does a producer do? And why? If you're, a student of the trade papers you know, first off, that producers fly around a lot. They sky to (or from) the Coast to hold important conferences. Producers also like to grant interviews to discuss future projects and/or industry trends. (What would you like me to tack about? a minor but desperate producer said to me some time ago. I want to sound controversial,) Producers are prone to telephone calls, preferably longdistance ones, and they like to make a big thing out of having all calls held during interviews or important conferences they've flown to (or from) the Coast to hold.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Paperback mysteries: a pyramid traditionally supported by the likes of Rex Stout, Agatha Christie, Mignon Eberhart, Erie Stanley Gardner and Brett Holliday, to name the first that come to mind. And, sure enough, each of those authors is represented in the February paperback listings. In Eberhart's case, it is with WHILE THE PATIENT SLEPT (Popular, 95 cents), a book published as far back as 1930. It has not, alas, aged gracefully. Old house, fog, weeds, creaking floors, the works. Dialogue such as: I shivered suddenly, though I was not cold. One funny passage: The heroine fires a revolver, and The thing made a horrible racket and startled me so that I forgot to remove my finger, and somehow it shot six times without stopping. That's how much Eberhart knows about revolvers.

title: More Teachers Vie for Boards
description: TRENTON When New Jersey voters go to the polls on Wednesday to elect new Board of Education members, they will find fewer incumbents and more teachers on the ballots.

title: Finley Pulls Fast One: A's Sign Hunter Quickly
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 9 (AP)Jim Hunter signed for the 1974 season, the Oakland A's owner, Charles O. Finley, said tonight. No terms were given.

title: TOWN HAIL SERIES RECALLS ITS PAST
description: When Mary Travers, Melba Moore, Tammy Grimes and Blossom Dearie sing Thursday I nightalong with appearances by women of the theater and women athletes  in the last of six National Organization for Women benefits at Town Hall, that forum can be considered to have come full circle in the 80thanniversary year of its founding by six suffragettes.

title: Those Were And Still AreThe Days
description: AMERICA'S in love with a wonderful past. Well, sort of wonderfuland nowhere is the yen for bygone years more intense than on the silver screen. Some of the most sizzling hits of recent months  The Godfather, Summer of '42, The Last Picture Show, American Graffiti, Paper Moon, The Stingwere inspired by other, possibly less decadent decades. And, as the pictures on this page suggest, there's plenty more past in your future.

title: Seoul Indicates It Will Not Permit Kidnapped Politician to Leave Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 9  The chances are not good that the South Korean Government will permit a prominent opposition leader, Kim Dae Jung, to leave Korea as he desires, according to the Foreign Minister.

title: Godfrey Rockefeller Jr. To Wed Miss Strazzulla
description: VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9 The engagement of Miss. Regina Victoria Strazzulla to Godfrey Anderson Rockefeller Jr., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Philip Strazzulla, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. Rockefeller of Gibson Island, Md., and Mrs. Hugh C. Wallace of Greenville, Del., and a greatgreatgrandson of William Rockefeller, who was associated with his brother, John D. Rockefeller, in the organization of the Standard Oil Company.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A woman and three children were killed early yesterday in a fire that destroyed their twostory woodframe home in Bridgeton, N. J. Fire officials in that Cumberland County community said that their men and equipment had no trouble reaching the scene despite a heavy snowfall, but that they had found the house already engulfed in flames.

title: News of the Screen
description: Martin Scorsese, who obviously appreciates crime and New York's Little Italy, which he artistically captured in Mean Streets, will be returning to his native milieu for what he trusts will be a major film. The 31yearold director discloses that he has personally bought rights to The Gangs of New York, the lively history of our town's outlaws by the late Herbert Asbury, published by Alfred A. Knopf in 1928.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Cat Bells Voted in Florida
description: DEERFIELD BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9 (AP)The City Commission has passed an ordinance requiring cats to wear bells. The commissioners adopted the motion after a local Audubon Society member protested that silent cats were decimating the bird population. Any owner who fails to tie a bell to his cars can be fined $25.

title: Rhodesia Is Raising Size of Her Army  To Press Campaign Against Guerrillas
description: SALSIBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 9 (Agence FrancePresse)Rhodesia's white minority Govment has announced that it ill increase the size of its army in the face of continued pttacks by black nationalist guerrillas.

title: Japan's Ruling Party Backs Air Pact With China
description: TOKYO, Feb. 9Japan's governing party agreed today, after bitter and prolonged debate, on a draft of an aviation agreement with China.

title: PEKING IS GRIPPED BY NEW MILITANCY
description: PEKING, Feb. 9Teachers from the French Embassy school are surrounded by an angry crowd after taking pictures of sweepers clearing snow in the old legation quarter. After lengthy questioning by security police, they have the film taken from their cameras and are sent on their way.

title: In Pagopago, It's Time For 38Man Crew. Race
description: PAGOPAGO, American Samoa  It's the racing season in Pagopago.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Stock prices dropped last week as the energy crisis continued to tighten its cold grip on Wall Street. Specific areas of investor disappointment centered on the Arab oil embargo and the work stoppage by independent truckers.

title: Nathaniel, Hall, Brady Win Medals
description: Jim Nathaniel, a 19yearold freshman at Manhattan, and Al Hall, who will he 40 years old in August, won gold medals yesterday in two of the three field events at Columbia University's bubble field house. The competition was the completion of Friday night's Olympic Invitational track meet at Madison Square Garden.

title: Home Improvement Adding Moisture to the Air Helps
description: HOMEOWNERS and apartment dwellers who are obviously concerned with the problem of keeping warm and comfortable without burning any more fuel than absolutely necessary (and learning how to live with lower thermostat settings) often overlook the effect that humidity can have on indoor comfort  and thus on home heating bills in many cases.

title: An Arctic Album: The Faces of Baffin Island
description: The Inuits (Eskimos) of Baffin Island are visited by few Kabloonas (white men), but photographer Janine Wiedel found the warmth of her reception more than a match for the inhospitable climate in this bleak land north of Labrador.

title: Bullets Pin 10875 Loss On 76ers
description: ARGO, Md., Feb. 9 (UPI)  The Capital Bullets outscored the Philadelphia 76ers, 172, in the first six minutes tonight and romped to a 10875 victory In a National Basketball Association game.

title: Wendy Mattmann Has Bridal
description: Miss Wendy Wood Mattmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles T. Mattmann of Glen Head, L. I., was married here yesterday morning to George Edward Read 2d, son of Dr. and Mrs. George Rollins Read of Montclair, N. J. The Rev. Bruce Forbes performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: Jean Enos Bride of G.P. Urban 3d Toria Reeve Is Betrothed
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 9Miss Jean Taylor Enos, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alanson Trask Enos, was married here this afternoon to George Pennock Urban 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Urban ?? of Buffalo and Roschill, Canada.

title: HOFF GIVES SONATA OF DANCE AND FILM
description: One suspects that the choreographer in StevenJan Hoff is becoming subordinated to the theatrical technician. In his concert Thursday evening at Theresa L. Kaufmann Concert Hall, his energies were lavished more on lighting and photography than on imaginative dance design.

title: LeadPoison Cases Declinein Brooklyn
description: The city Health Department has reported that after four years of intensive effort, the total number of leadpoisoning cases for BedfordStuyvesant, Fort Greene, Bushwick and Brownsville sections of Brooklyn has dropped from 1,214 in 1970 to 367 in 1973.

title: We Will Match the Russians, He Says
description: WASHINGTONTwentyfour years ago this month, James R. Schlesinger was graduated from Harvard in the same class as Henry A. Kissinger. At that time a great debate was going on in Washington over whether the United States should send four divisions of troops as an American commitment to the defense of Western Europe.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Fiction and Poetry

title: An American Cousin for Burke's Peerage
description: As a proper Old Harrovian, Jeremy Norman enjoys a spot of deerstalking in Dorsetshire when he is not busy with a family firm, Burke's Peerage, Ltd., which for 150 years has been putting out a who's who in the British aristocracy under the imposing title, Burke's Peerage, Baronetage and Knightage.

title: Penn Wins Polar Bear Track
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 9Pennsylvania captured its fourth straight Polar Bear track meet today, sweeping 11 the 14 events. Penn's triumph in Jadwin Gymnasium, by a score of 84 to 46 to 18 over Princeton and Columbia, respectively, marked only the Quakers' sixth success in the annual contest, which began in 1935.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Last June, the article City Eases Curbs on Oil Burners implied that it would be easier and cheaper for owners to comply with the requirements of the Department of Air Resources because of new engineering criteria for fueloil equipment that were to go into effect July 1.

title: Yale Six 61 Victor
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 9The Yale hockey team broke open a tight game with four goals in the second period today and went on to defeat the University of Massachusetts, 61. The victory ended a fourgame losing streak for the Elis and lifted their wonlost record for the season to 610. Massachusetts is now 79.

title: Sphinxes, Angels, Peacocks in the Moonlight
description: PAINTERS of the Mind's Eye, the large and thoroughly interesting exhibition of Belgian Symbolists and Surrealists, now on view at the New York Cultural Center, 2 Columbus Circle (through March 17), is another of those attempts to relate the onceradical and sometimes shocking movements of the modem period to their historical traditions. The exhibition has been admirably selectedin terms of the quality and interest of the picturesby Francis de Lulle, of the Belgian Ministry of National Education and Culture. It includes some 120 works, many of them borrowed from public and private collections in Europeprincipally, Belgiumamong them unfamiliar works by such littleknown Belgian Symbolists as William Degouve de Nuncques, Fernand Khnopff, Xavier Mellery, Leon Spilliaert and Antoine Wiertz.

title: Andrea Hyde Plans Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Nevins Hyde of New York and Newtown, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Andrea Tilton Hyde, to John Frederick Hagaman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Homer Hagaman of Wynnewood, Pa. The wedding is planned for May 25 in Newtown.

title: Mary Renault and her various personas
description: The drums are beating; the women are chanting.

title: Policeman Is Accused of Killing Girlfriend in Queens
description: An offduty policeman who was once credited with killing a berserk murderer in a gun duel was charged with homicide yesterday for allegedly shooting his girlfriend to death in Flushing Mearow Park.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: TO A CHICKWEED

title: Landlord Warnings Weighed
description: The City Housing Code Enforcement Commissioner John V. Sanderson, has promised to set up an experimental program to determine whether notifying landlords of impending inspections to determine the validity of no heat complaints nullifies the purpose of inspection.

title: News of the Stage
description: The New York theatrical community is being canvassed to determine what kind of theater it would like to see in a hotel scheduled to rise on the West 45th Street sites now occupied by the Morosco, Helen Hayes and Bijou theaters.

title: Gary Schwartz Fiance of Lori J. Traurig
description: MIAMI, Feb. 9Mr. and Mrs. Philip H. Singer have announced the engagement of Mrs. Singer's daughter, Miss Lori Joyce Traurig, to Gary Robert Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Schwartz. Both families live here.

title: It Wasn't All Ponytails
description: YOU may not believe this, but it's true: Ten minutes into the first episode of the new Happy Days series on ABC, my 11yearold son left the living room to go upstairs and read Low's abridgement of Gibbon's Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire. Whether he's precocious or just suggestible, he knows what he doesn't like.

title: Curling: Gentleman's Sport for Women
description: When Mrs. Peyton Duncanson discusses curling, she's not talking about hairdos.

title: The Potential Agenda of the House Inquiry Is Long and Varied
description: WASHINGTONA case can be made for the proposition that President Nixon should be held responsible for the activities of his subordinates and that their crimes are themselves bases for the President's impeachment. But a case can also be made for the opposite argument, and political reality makes it almost certain that if the House of Representatives impeaches the President and if the Senate votes to remove him from office, it will be because of what Richard M. Nixon did himself.

title: Coloring Picasso to Taste
description: As if Satan hadn't found enough work for idle hands in this countryMonopoly, macram, 3D puzzles, needlepoint, graffitiwe are in the clutches of another digital divertissement, coloring books.

title: Schedule of Hearings By Council This Week
description: The following open hearings of City Council committees will be held this week:

title: Movies
description: I'VE felt weird all day long, like I'm standing aside and watching myself. And I look strange. What do you suppose this bump is on the side of my face? I've never had anything like that before. And my eyes feel all squinty. I must look like some guy doing a Bufferin commercial.

title: Notes: White House Offers San Clemente As Convention Site
description: PRESIDENT Nixon is pushing group travel to San Clemente. The package he is offering is use of the conference facilities of the Coast Guard Station that adjoins the Presidential compound and is part of the Western White House complex. The facilities are used frequently by Federal agencies, but they are available to outside organizations, too. What's more, there's no charge.

title: Americans to Paris
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 9 (AP)Four American swimmers, including two Olympic gold medalists, Melissa Belote and Shirley Babashoff, have been invited to compete at an international meet in Paris on Feb. 16 and 17. Also invited were Ken Knox of Indiana University and Washington's Rick Colella.

description: 9 Guerrillas Free After Trip to Aden

title: Fashion
description: The hottest game in town (it's even hotter out of town) is platform tennis, known to its players as paddle. It has been around since 1928, when a group of tennis buffs in Scarsdale built a raised wooden platform so they could play all winter long. From that first platform came today's fastmoving game played with rackets that look like grownup PingPong paddles with holes in them, and orange, spongerubber balls. Now, suddenly, it has become the newest  and possibly scruffiest  status sport around. There's a reason for the scruffiness. Competition is hot and heavy and gear de rigueur is whatever keeps a player mobile, warm and comfortable. Clothing in layers is preferred. It can be peeled off piece by piece as the action gets more furious until a player is often down to a cotton turtleneck in the iciest February weather. Clothes change with the seasons, of course. Winter's knit caps, ear muffs and gloves (there are special gloves just for paddle tennis) give way to Tshirts, jeans and sweatbands. But what makes a status sport after all these years? It's hard to tell. But everybody's playing it.

description: LA COSTA, Calif., Feb. 9 (AP)  Dennis Ralston was renamed captain of the Davis Cup team for 1975 at the United States Lawn Tennis Association meeting today.

description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 9 (UPI)Gunmen, firing from a car, killed two men and wounded a woman outside a pub in a Roman Catholic district of west Belfast late tonight, the police reported.

The Guccis have held up. No doubt they will survive as a monument to their owner, who is in the terminal stages of a disease called remodeling.

title: Just What Is France Up To Now?
description: PARISOnce again, as so often when the late President de Gaulle set the pace, France is marching to a different drummer. Foreign Minister Michel Jobert, almost as visibly ubiquitous as Secretary of State Kissinger, has been flitting about Europe and the Middle East trying to stir up opposition to American policy.

title: The Nation
description: The $304.4billion budget that President Nixon has sent to Congress represents a sharp break with the philosophy of his budget of a year ago, when he insisted on cutting back or eliminating a whole set of Congressionally enacted programs in order to maintain a rigid ceiling on spending. This time he and his advisers are promising compromise and fiscal flexibility, including a readiness to bust the budget if necessary. The reasons for the change are both economic and political.

title: Design
description: The Federal houses of New England rank among America's great architectural treasures. These stalwart clapboard buildings were a step up in sophistication from the saltboxes of the previous century. The Federal style, dating from Revolutionary days to the Victorian era, represented the vitality and new prosperity of a nation just liberated from the status of a colony. It speaks well of their anonymous designers and builders that on the eve of the country's bicentennial the gracious quality of these houses is still sought after. This house was built by a wealthy Massachusetts landowner for his daughter in 1800 (he built another just like it across the street for another daughter.) By the time the present owner bought the house 10 years ago, it was pathetically in need of restoration. He replastered walls, refinished floors, restored the moldings, replaced missing or damaged clapboard until finally the solid charms of the old house were obvious again.

title: MRS. ROBERT M. M'IVER

They will be part of a federally financed experiment designed to increase the capacity of such express service. For almost fifty years, before they were retired in 1953, the doubledeckersthe real ones, with an opentop deckwere a staple of Manhattan life.

title: Roses are red, Some verses are blue; There's plenty of money In I Love You.
description: I have been looking for a valentine to buy for my wife. As usual, the drugstores and gift shoppes are full of them. But one valentine, from American Greetings Corporation, Cleveland, shows a little guy a bow tie walking and talking to himself, saying, I searched all over town trying to find one of those Sweet, Sentimental Valentines to send you. . . . Finally, I asked a sweet old lady in a card shop and she said that they don't make them like that no more! So, I got you this one . . [turn over] . . . BE MY VALENTINE, YOU BIG NUT!

title: What's Doing, in the Florida Keys
description: OVERSEAS HIGHWAY  Key West is about 150 miles from Miami, and twothirds of that distance is covered by the Overseas Highway (U. S. 1), a series of roads, causeways and bridges that link the Keys, a chain of islands that curve out to sea from the Florida mainland. For a relatively straight and level road the Overseas Highway has its share of thrillssome natural and some manmade. It's a gorgeous drive when you're in the delightful gaps between the billboards, trailer courts and motel signs that have proliferated in recent years. Driving along the highway, particularly around sunrise and sunset, with the sky and surrounding waters changing color every minute and the sea birds diving for fish, I've always been seized, mile after mile, by a visual euphoria. The trouble is that a lot of other drivers react the same way, making the crowded, narrow road one of the deadliest in the United States. Experts believe it will take something heavier than a station wagon to cause the collapse of any of the 42 crumbling bridges in the Keys something as heavy, say, as a hurricanebut chunks of concrete falling away can leave holes in the roadway where there's no room to dodge oncoming traffic. But if you're alert to these dangers and go slow, it can be a memorable trip.

title: It Is the Ideal Time for Pedestrians and Joggers
description: Joseph Lehoe is a man who watches figures carefully. He has to, since he is an independent trucker with a $32,000 rig with which he hauls steel from the Akron area. title: Letters to the Editor

title: Schoenberg's Legacy
description: THREE years ago, this column made note of the fact that Arnold Schoenberg's collection of manuscripts, scores, correspondence and memorabilia, with an estimated value of $3million, was being offered not for sale but as a gift to any institution that would establish an appropriate memorial to house it. The conditions included a separate building; a staff consisting of a director, archivist, librarian and secretarial and custodial help; a replica of the composer's study; publications and exhibitions; a continuing program of scholarly research.

title: An unquiet quiet on campus
description: At the end of the sixties the academic world gratefully welcomed the cessation of violence. it assumed that campus problems were finite and political; with their disappearance, we would be back to normal. The academy hoped for tranquillity and, attaining it, confused it with order. Few realized at the beginning of the seventies that an entirely new set of problems had arisen and that their solution depended on values and traditions that were dealt a staggering blow in the sixties. The traditional university was imperfect but equitable. The same cannot be said of today's.

title: Soviet Is Sensitive to China's Claims to Asian Islands
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 9  The territorial dispute between China and South Vietnam over the Paracel and Spratly Islands in the South China Sea has touched a raw nerve in the Kremlin, and suggested some inconsistencies in Soviet foreign policy.

title: 11 Countries Taking Part In U.N. Emergency. Force
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 9 (UPI)A total of 6,396 soldiers from 11 countries are taking part in the United Nations Emergency Force policing the disengagement of Israeli and Egyptian armies on the Suez front, a United Nations spokesman has announced.

title: If Israel can only see the new realities
description: The disengagement after the October war has brought us for the first time to the threshold of a lasting peace. Yet everything depends on whether we seize the chance now, or, as we did after 1967, wake up to the realization that we missed that elusive opportunity. I say our because I believe, and hope to demonstrate here, that the fault for this tragic failure, which has led to the death of over 2,400 Israelis and at least twice as many Arabs, lies with both of us. The three main obstacles we have to surmount if we are going to avoid another disappointment are mistaken perceptions, exaggerated expectations and rigid thinking. There is no doubt that the problems of working out a viable peace exist, but they are not insurmountable, nor should they prove very formidable for the Jewish people, who have had the courage, initiative and creative imagination to transform the state of Israel from dream to reality.

title: Madrid Drops Playboy Fine
description: MADRID, Spain, Feb. 9 (AP) The Supreme Court has ruled That possession of Playboy magazine in the home is not a public scandal here. The court set aside a jail sentence and fine levied on Ramon Gomez Lopez of Madrid after the police, searching for drugs, had found several old copies in his house.

description: His apartment in San Francisco is down near the bay in a quiet, almost contemplative, neighborhood.

title: Bad Habits
description: AS Terrence McNally views humanity in his new comedy, we are all creatures of Bad Habits. They are what distinguish adults from infants. Remove them, and we return to Pablum.

title: Russia for $279, They Told Me
description: SATURDAY, June 23Brezhnev is hugging Chuck Connors. Everyone is smiling. The Russian leader waves goodby and boards the Presidential jet. A new era of friendship in SovietAmerican relations has begun.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Point of View
description: The lines of cars are still at the service stations, and the independent oil dealers are still complaining about their difficulties in securing supplies. But it becomes increasingly clear that under the cover of shortage a monumental shift has taken place in the pricing of a commodity so central to the economy as to alter all facets of our lives.

title: Jason Miller Found Success in Failure
description: COCONUT GROVE, Fla.,Jason Miller, the PulitzerPrizewinning playwright of the Broadway hit, That Championship Season and the creator of the pivotal role of Father Karas in the spectacularly successful film version of The Exorcist, is drinking in the south Florida sunshine.

title: Nancy Scott Is Betrothed
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Feb. 9 Miss Nancy Elizabeth Scott and Fraser McPherson Robson of London plan to be married in October.

title: MOVIE OPENING
description: CRAZY JOE  Carlo Lizzani's film, written by Lewis John Carlino and starring Peter Boyle, Paula Prentiss, Fred Williamson, Rip Torn, Charles Cioffi and Eli Wallach, Friday at the Loew's State II, Orpheum and other theaters.

title: The Extraordinary Mr. Wilkes
description: John Wilkes was all that a politician and a statesman should not be. He liked womenservants, strumpets, women of the town, highclass and lowclass courtesans  indeed anything he could lay his hand on, although he would never have phrased it so modestly. And he gloried in his lust, never tried to hide it, any more than he tried to hide his delight in a bawdy joke. All the public knew, as they knew about his debts. And his debts were monstrous. He borrowed and spent and spent and borrowed. And he never showed the slightest sense of shame. All his voters were aware of his extravagance, as they were of his concupiscence. Even worse, he had no respect for authority  neither the King, nor the Church, nor their ministers, not even Parliament itselfhe scoffed at the lot.

title: BAR REASSESSES KUNSTLER ACTION
description: The Association of the Bar of the City of New York is seeking to withdraw disciplinary charges brought by one of its committees against William M. Kunstler, sources familiar with the situation say.

title: Thieves Like Us By Edward Anderson. 215 pp. New York: Avon Books. $1.25.
description: The copyright date is 1937, but don't you believe it. Or may be you should believe it, because Edward Anderson's novel is sparer, leaner and keener than the decadent presentday variation of crime fiction. It was born in the hardboiled heyday of James M. Cain, Dashiel Hammett, Raymond Chandler and W. R. Burnett, and it rattles through the Depressionblasted Southwest with the pace and authority of a steamdriven freight train on a good roadbed.

title: News of the Camera World
description: THE New YorkPhoenix Schools of Design, 160 Lexington Avenue, is offering two evening courses and one Saturday course in photography, starting Feb. 18. The evening courses will include one on basic techniques, with emphasis on darkroom work, and another for Spanish speaking people which will include techniques and criticism. The Saturday course is entitled Photography for the Family, and is designed to teach photography to parents and children simultaneously. For more information call (212) MU 52973.

title: Music
description: WHEN, a week ago Thursday, the Metropolitan Opera staged, for the first time in its history, I Vespri Siciliani by Verdi, the event also marked a minor milestone, duly pointed out in the program notes by Irving Kolodin. Now the Metropolitan Opera is the only theater in the United States ever to hold in its active repertory the final series of operas by the great Italian composer.

title: Zwilling of Austria Wins World Downhill Ski Title
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 9  The cowbells were quiet today as the Austrian men took three of the four top positions in the downhill race at the world Alpine ski championships.

title: Ancient Title Triumphs at Santa Anita
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 9 (AP)  Laffit Pincay rode Ancient Title to a wiretowire victory in the $130,200 Charles H. Strub Stakes today, and the Gummo gelding became only the third horse to sweep Santa Anita's three races for 4yearolds.

title: No Matter How Spelled, Fittipaldi Tests Editors
description: It is a wellknown secret that most newspaper editors root against Emerson Fittipaldi, especially those whose job it is to fit the Brazilian's cumbersome name into a onecolumn headline after he has won a grand prix. Fittipaldi not only has a long name, but he also has complicated matters by having an older brother whose sole contribution to grand prix racing so far has been to have editors insist upon the initial E in Fittipaldi headlines.

title: Letters: On the Status of Women
description: TO THE EDITOR: I was surprised to read in How French Women ant That WayAnd How to Handle fhem b y Justine DeLacy (Travel Section, Jan. 13) a quotation she attributes to me which does not reflect the content of our brief telephone conservation.

title: Ambassador for Nauru
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) President Nixon announced this week the nomination of Marshall Green, United States Ambassador to Australia, to serve concurrently as envoy to the republic of Nauru, an island state in the Central Pacific that has been independent since 1968 but has never had an Ambassador from the United States.

title: Mrs. Dwight Eisenhower Joins Nixons for Dinner
description: WASHINGTON, Feb: 9 (AP) Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower arrived at the White House this afternoon for an overnight visit. She had planned to arrive last night, and President and Mrs. Nixon had scheduled a dinner party in her honor.

title: Hong Kong Salvage Men Cutting Up the Elizabeth
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 9  (UPI)Metalcutting torches and salvaging tools are slicing into bits the Queen Elizabeth, the luxury liner that now lies rusted in Hong Kong harbor.

title: Monzon Stops Napoles in 7th, Keeps Title
description: PARIS, Feb. 9  Carlos Monzon of Argentina retained his world middleweight boxing title near here tonight by punishing Jos Napoles of Mexico so badly that the was unable to answer the bell for the seventh round.

title: Ross Gains Final At Brooklyn Net
description: Steve Ross reached the final of the Brooklyn men's indoor tennis championship at the Glenwood Racquet Club last night.

title: ATHENS CURBING FOREIGN VESSELS
description: ATHENS, Feb. 9Greece has slammed the door on European shipowners who seek to take advantage of Greekflag privileges to cut the operating costs of their merchant ships.

title: W. Germany Rated No. 1 Again in Show Jumping
description: West Germany, as might be expected, was the premier showjumping nation in the world last year, albeit by a narrow margin over Britain.

title: U.S. Laying Groundwork For SyrianIsraeli Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The United States has begun exchanging ideas with Israel and Syria to find a formula,for the start of SyrianIsraeli negotiations on the separation of their troops and on the issuance by Syria of a list of Israeli prisoners, senior State Department officials said today.

title: Bethesda Fountain Restoration To Mean Closing of Restaurant
description: Parks Administrator Edwin L. Weisl Jr. has announced a rehabilitation project for Bethesda Fountain in Central Park that will remove the restaurant and kiosks from the site and restore the fountain area to its original concept.

title: Fort Tilden Preparing For Closing
description: Fort Tilden, once a key cog in the nation's coastal defense system, is being eased into its final phase of inactivation before its takeover later this year by the Gitteway National Park project.

title: El Dorado, Africa: No Place for U.S. Blacks
description: LOS ANGELESDistance is a great incubator of romantic ideas. The good old days seem to get better as time passes, blossoming on occasion into great or golden eras to which many romantics would have us believe they wish to return.

title: Few Issues in Queens Assembly Race
description: The contest now under way for the 36th State Assembly District seat in Astoria, Queens, is a lethargic one devoid of fiery rhetoric and waged by friends who are betting heavily on their own political clubs to get out their votes in the special election next Thursday.

title: Space Station
description: The safe return of the Skylab 3 astronauts after 12 weeks in orbit was considered so certain that the television networks had decided well in advance not to broadcast the splashdown. However much that decision may have annoyed space aficionados, it was really a public tribute to the high technical achievements of the Skylab program and of previous manned American space projects. It was to minimize danger to astronauts that so much money, ingenuity and time have been spent these past years in incorporating failsafe devices and multiple redundancy into American manned spacecraft. The safety record shows that it has all been worthwhile.

title: Colleges Intensify Recruiting Drives
description: CLIFTONPaul A. Lewis came to Clifton High School the other day, but the event was hardly memorable either to Mr. Lewis or to the school.

title: FUNDS PROMISED FOR SUMMER JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9This is the time of year when the Nixon White House and members of Congress ordinarily square off for their annual battle over funding summer jobs for youths, with the Administration talking of holding the line and legislators pressing for more money.

title: Social Announcements
description: Weddings

title: Peter Wicker Weds Miss Raeburn
description: Miss Victoria Joann Raeburn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Abner Raeburn of New York, was married here yesterday afternoon to Peter Carleton Wicker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carleton Forbes Wicker of Milibrook.

title: NATIONAL TOPICS
description: LAS VEGAS, Feb. 7They came flashy, some in red doubleknit blazers, shrill ties and shiny white shoes. They wandered from hospitality rooms to meetings to drinking receptions, and passed through equipment displays including 27 different automatic carwashing monsters.

title: Decades of Inaction Brought Energy Gap
description: Barely three months ago, President Nixon told the nation their its energy problems had become an energy crisis. Since then, thermostats and speed, limits have dropped obediently, but the initial shock has not fadedonly soured in perplexity, disbelief and cynicism.

title: P.O.W.'s a Year Later: Most Adapt Well
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 9  One year ago next Tuesday, Hanoi began to release 566 Americans who had been prisoners of war. For months they were the country's heroes, and no parade was complete without one of them proclaiming gratitude to his President and loyalty to his country.

title: Now We See How Chekhov Built a Masterpiece
description: TOWARD the very end of Chekhov's The Wood Demon, when three or four couples on a country estate are trying to rearrange the raggletaggle patterns of their lives, there is a flash fire in a patch of woods nearby. The one most immediately concerned is Khruschov, impatient doctor to them all, passionate devotee of forestry, a chap in boots and peasant blouse who likes to help God create by planting birch trees and whose anger is unbounded when he contemplates the loss of so much as a sapling.

title: School Board Candidates Night' Brings Out Both the Hopeful and the Electorate
description: ENGLISHTOWNThe eight candidates running for four seats on the ManalapanEnglishtown Regional Board of Education met at the Clark Mills Elementary School here last Tuesday evening.

title: SEVEN FEARED DEAD IN THE CRASH OF B52
description: MARYSVILLE, Calif., Feb. 9 (UPI) A B52 Stratofortress crashed and exploded on the runway at Beale Air Force Base last night during takeoff. Seven crewmen were presumed dead and an eighth survived with serious burns.

title: A Lavish Colonial Ball With Simple Beginnings
description: STONY BROOK, L.I. Yes, the ball will be lavish. Champagne toast to the king, exotic dishes and a towering birthday cake large enough to feed 200 revelers. And certainly the ball will be elegant, with a titled lord leading the glittering assemblage into the ballroom of a waterfront mansion ablaze with flickering candles.

title: Gen. Raymond Wheeler Dead; Led Army Corps of Engineers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9Lieut. Gen. Raymond A. Wheeler, who was Chief of the Army's Corps of Engineers from 1946 to 1949 and directed the clearing of the Suez Canal for the United Nations after the 1956 Sinai campaign, died yesterday at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center. He was 88 years aid and lived here.

title: Westminster Looms as WideOpen Affair
description: With only one group winner back from last year, the Westminster Kennel Club's 98th annual show promises to be wide open.

title: Government of an Indian State Falls After Food Riots and Charges of Graft
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 9The government of the western state of Gujarat fell today and was put under the control of the central Government tonight.

title: The World
description: In 1966, when Chairman Mao Tsetung set in motion the Cultural Revolution that so profoundly disturbed and reshaped life in the People's Republic of China, he is supposed to have said that more than one such campaign would be necessary to maintain the purity of Chinese Communism. Now there are signs from various parts of China that a second is about to get under way, and may have already begun.

title: Port Agency Says Rail Projects Hinge on PATH Fare Increase
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey says that its plans for major rail transit improvements may be brought into doubt and uncertainty if its request for a fare increase on the PATH transit line is denied.

title: Rockefeller Sees Ford ln Strong Position for '76
description: ROCKFORD, Ill., Feb. 4 (UPI) Former New York Gov. Nelsoie A. Rockefeller said today that Vice President Ford was in a very strong position in any competition for the 1976 Republican Presidential nomination.

title: The Dance
description: George Balanchine's Don Quixote, now at the New York State Theater through next Wednesday, is like a promise unredeemed. Nine years ago, when the New York City Ballet first presented it, there was the air to it of an epic in the making. There was a hint of dramatic grandeur to it, and while it still looked unfulfilled, it was the unfulfillment of a magnificent tapestry still only halffinished.

title: Recordings
description: THE Mahler explosion of the sixties appears to be subsiding  how many complete recorded editions of the symphonies can even the most dedicated Mahlerite absorb?  and the composer now gives every indication of settling comfortably into the orchestral reprtory alongside the accepted. classics. Ten years ago recorded pickings were considerably slimmer and we Were just beginning to discover the unfamiliar symphonies; although all of them had found their way onto disks by 1964, there were no really acceptable versions of Nos. 5, 6, 7 and 8. Now the choices

title: Brooklyn Takes C.U.N.Y. Swim
description: Brooklyn College swimmers captured first places in seven of 11 events yesterday and rolled to the City. University of New York championship at the Kingsmen's pool.

title: Friday's Fights
description: 5, Dov Dierassi, Northeastern, 59.

title: The Delicate Dance of the Three Big Powers
description: Whenever the leaders and diplomats of the. Soviet Union, the United States or the People's Republic China meet, the meeting is bilateral, but it is inevitably part of a triangular relationship. In the following story, that relationship is examined from a vantage point in Peking by David Bonavia, the correspondent there of The Times of London. Mr. Bonavia has also reported from Moscow.

title: A pudding of a book full of plums
description: The recent rediscovery ofand appearance of heavily asterisked excerpts fromthe diaries of Evelyn Waugh lends a certain sportive interest to this book of reminiscences by his friends. The comic novelist, as revealed in the diaries, was so gratuitously bitchy, sowell peevish in his perception of those close to him that one feels they could only retaliate in kind. But no, nothing of the sort. While allowing the enfant terrible his flaws, they ooze objectivity, judiciousness, kindness, leniencyeven, if you'll pardon the expression, devotion. (If he was often noisy and obstreperous, writes Peter Quennell, the biographer and critic, of their days at Oxford together, I cannot recollect that he was ever illtempered. He loved his friends and while he still had money to burn, he was a lavish host and the source of unusually generous presents.)

title: A Guide to Filing Income Tax Properly...
description: The following section is designed to help you prepare your tax return, which must be filed by April 15. Emphasis has been placed on recent changes in the law, on court decisions interpreting it and on advice that goes beyond what is found in official instruction material.

title: If They Are Not for Others, Who Will Be for Them?
description: HOUSTONThe first drafts of the winds of change are whispering through rile house of the,law. They are not strong, but they are enough to make some of the nation's lawyers, traditionally secure in their assumptions about their profession, uncomfortable.

title: A Baby Is Burned to Death As Candles Replace Lights
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 9 (UPI)  An infant girl was burned to death here and her 4yearold sister was critically injured when candles set a crib ablaze in an apartment where electricity had been cut off.

title: Dill Lowers Mark In 300Yard Dash
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Feb. 9 (AP)Marshall Dill of Michigan State set a world record for the 300yard dash tonight in the Spartan Relays with a time of 29.3 seconds, breaking his record of 29.5 set here two years ago.

title: Stennis Hears Yeoman's Story; Praises Him for Forthrightness
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) A Navy yeoman who has acknowledged secretly removing documents from Henry A. Kissinger's files and delivering them to the Pentagon told his story today to Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi. But Yeoman 1st Cl. Charles Radford refused to comment publicly about the meeting.

title: Long Mobilization Starting to Strain Lives of Israelis
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 8For David Friedman it has meant a fourmonth disruption that has gravely jeopardized the future of a small metalworking business he has painstakingly built up over eight years.

title: McKellen Retains Title In U.S. Figure Skating
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 9 In successive, startling freestyle performances, Gordon McKellen of Lake Placid, N. Y., won the championship, and Terry Kubicka of Cypress, Calif., finished second this afternoon in the national figure skating championships at the Civic Center.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 9 (UPI)Zelmo Beaty, the Utah Stars' center, is suing the American Basketball Association team and its controlling company, Mountain States Sports, Inc., for $1.2million.
