Beaty's attorneys, Daniel L. Berman and Stephen G. Crockett, filed the suit yesterday in Third District Court and said it was expected to be served on team officials Monday.

title: Television
description: A FUNNY thing happened to me on the way to join the hallelujah chorus for The Autopiography of Miss Jane Pittman. CBS'S twohour, miliondollar, madefortelevision movie about a fictional 110yearold American black woman, whose memories span black history from the civil War to the civil rights movement of the 1960's, was ??eralded as black history as we had not seen it before. I read the fullpage ad for the Gospel according to Pauline Kael (. . .quite possibly the finest movie ever made for television) and Rex Reed (One of the most profound . . .experiences in the history of film. ..) and Judith Crist (. . .the finest new film of the moment. . .). And after five years of television reviewing, during which I learned to stop worrying and love Buddy Ebsen, I was ready for the Epiphany.

title: Miss Perkins Betrothed
description: WINNETKA, Ill., Feb. 9Miss Elizabeth Perkins, a senior at Wellesley College, and David Edward Hill, a senior at Dartmouth College plan to be married. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Donald Sheldon Perkins, parents of the bridetobe, whose fianc is the son of Dr. Robert John Hill, an orthopedic surgeon, and Mrs. Hill of Altoona, Pa. Mr. Perkins is board chairman of the Jewel Companies of Chicago, retailer in diversified fields.

title: Lisa M. Stevens Plans Wedding in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. George O. Stevens Jr. of Syracuse and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lisa Marie Stevens, to Michael Ellis Coles of Dover, N. J., son of Mrs. Samuel M. Pullman of Boca Raton, Fla., and W. S. Coles of Chaparral, N. M.

title: Dried Flowers Bloom As a Bridal Bouquet
description: OLD TAPPANFor those fathers of the bride who might complain about investing so much in a few hours of fanfare, with lasting returns limited to fond memories and a yellowed gown, Barbara Beach offers some solace.

title: Mepham's Belger Snaps 2 Meet Marks in Track
description: Mark Belger, a track star for Mepham High School, has alternated his distance this winter between 1,000 yard and one mile. But yesterday, Belger ran both, events and won them in record time in the Long Island Coaches Scholastic indoor meet at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: Suburb Ponders Compatibility Of Black Quota and Integration
description: OAK PARK, Ill., Feb. 9Can and should a suburb, ostensibly in the cause of integration, discriminate?

title: Smallness Called Key To Dowling Programs
description: OAKDALE, L. I.  To survive in an era of big, public higher education a small private college has to have something special going for it. Dr. Allyn P. Robinson, president of Dowling College here, thinks that, its very smallness is what makes his fouryear liberal arts college different.

title: Gauging Profits
description: In their efforts to justify high earnings for 1973, oil companies have made much of their rate of return. They're using some terms that roll lightly off the tongue but, left unexplained, can fall like lead weights.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  One day, soon the Government is likely to issue list of peoducts from European Common Market countries. It will mean the United States intends to raise tariffs on these products July 1.

title: Best Seller List
description: Based on reports from more than 250 bookstores to 110 communities throughout the United States. Weeks are not necessarily consecutive.

title: Camden Setting Up Poetry, Arts Center
description: CAMDENThis city's participation in the nation's Bicentennial celebration in 1976 will include the creation of an international center for poets and the related arts.

title: ELECTION PROBLEM OP G.O.P. ASSAYED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9Republican leaders have begun to confront publicly a crucial question: how to win in 1974 and 1976 despite President Nixon's precipitous decline in popularity.

title: Rebuilding Delayed in Japan Of Frank Lloyd Wright Hotel
description: NAGOYA, Japan, Feb. 9 (Reuters)Mounting costs and shortages of materials are delaying the reconstruction of the old Imperial Hotel designed by Frank Lloyd Wright.

title: Headliners
description: Brother Nelson may no longer be governor, but David and John D. Rockefeller 3d have a way with them that tends to keep the name in the household vocabulary. David has been in Egypt talking with President Anwar elSadat on behalf of the bank of which Mr. Rockefeller is board chairman, Chase Manhattan. Mr. Sadat has a friend there: David Rockefeller and he concluded an agreement for the bank to loan Egypt $80million and for the bank to open a fullservice branch in the freetrade zone of Alexandria. John D. Rockefeller 3d has announced that he is going to give his $10to $15million collection of Asian artabout 300 objectsto the Asia Society, a cultural and publicaffairs organization he founded in 1956.

title: Wetlands Definition Stirring Debates
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I. A twoyearlong battle over a housing development in the heart of this village could help decide which areas are tarred to developers by New York's new Tidal Wetlands Act.

title: Cunningham Slated To Enter Hospital
description: PHILADELPHIA; Feb. 9 (UPIBilly Cunningham of the Carolina Cougars, the American Basketball Association player of the year last season, was, expected to enter Pennsylvania Hospital tomorrow for possible surgery to repair a congenital kidney blockage.

title: Terri Roth Fiancee of Oscar Reicher
description: LAWRENCE, L. I., Feb. 9The engagement of Miss Terri Alice Roth to Oscar A. Reicher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Reicher, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Roth.

title: Nixon's Daughter Asks Free Choice In Women's Lives
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) Mrs. David Eisenhower advocated today the total right of selfdetermination in lifestyle: for women and said she thought the nation might have a female President within 10 years.

title: Mary Burgoyne Bride of Alan Snyder
description: Miss Mary Clare Burgoyne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph J. Burgoyne of Plymouth, Wis., was married here yesterday afternoon to Alan Carhart Snyder, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John I. Snyder of Scarsdale and Shelter Island, N. Y. The Rev, Robert Keck performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: WILSON SEEKING POWERS TO DEAL WITH FUEL CRISIS
description: Governor Wilson asked the Legislature yesterday for broad emergency powers to deal with the fuel shortage, including Standby authority to ration gasoline in any or all parts of I the state and to make mandatory a plan already scheduled to go into effect tomorrow on a voluntary basis.

title: 700Page Swahili Dictionary Is Work of Priest in Zaire
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Feb. 9 (Agence FrancePresse)A 700page, 30,000 word Swahili dictionary  the biggest ever edited in Zairehas been published here, the local news agency reports.

title: The Worst Postwar Crisis
description: LONDONThe silliest modern British election slogan was in 1945 when Winston Churchill, the great victor of World War II, earnestly assured voters that were Clement Attlee's Labor party installed in power it would mean Gestapo rule. This was especially asinine since the mild and upright Attlee had been a member of Churchill's own Cabinet.

title: Ruth Landa Engaged to T. F. Heinegg
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert W. Landa of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Landa, to Thomas, F. Heinegg of Jamaica Estates, Queens, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Heinegg of Delhi, N. Y. The wedding is planned for June 30.

title: The RegionIn Summary
description: The New York Telephone Company has made one of those dryasdust tariff proposals that transcends economics and may affect leisure time, family relationships, even romance. The utility wants to abandon its system of permitting conversations of unlimited length for a single charge within limited geographical zone. Instead, it wants to make short conversations less expensive and long ones more so.

title: The Issue in Britain
description: Through the intransigence of the National Union of Mineworkers and the visceral desire of rightwing Tories, Britain's general election seems destined to be fought superficially on the issue of who runs the country? The real issue is much more complex; and it is one that must be resolved, sooner or later, by every Industrial nation trying to reconcile the requirements of a modern economy with those of a free and civil society.

title: Hotels for Children, Or, Where to Stash The Small Try While Relaxing on Vacation
description: LA TRETOIRE, FranceThe Problem: What to do with the kids during your big European vacation. Old solutions: (1) Schlepp them along where you want to go, so they can have a coughing fit in the cathedral. (2) Schlepp yourself along where they want to go, so you watch the monkeys and lions again. (3) If it's summer, send them to camp, so they can complain about the food and bite the counselors. (4) Dump them on Grandma.

title: A New Gem in Oaxaca's Grown
description: THE first guests  a couple of New Yorkers  arrived on the morning of Thursday, Jan. 24. By Saturday there were about 80, and after the weekend, say 150. By Tuesday the 29th, the day of the big event, there were more than 200 guests from cities all across the United States and various spots in Mexico. The 115 members of the National Symphony of Mexico arrived in a special plane; they played on a platform in the street erected for the occasion while an estimated 2,000 citizens of Oaxaca crowded into the street of the ropedoff city block for a celebration that ended, as a public event, with an enormous explosion of fireworks spraying up into the air like fountain before fading away to leave burning, in red and green fire, the legend, ESPOSOS TAMAYO.

title: Fuel Crisis Could Bring Back Caddie
description: Will the fuel shortage eliminate the use of gasolinepowered cars by golfers as they play a round? Will the caddie, now almost extinct as a bagtoter at most country clubs, be in greater demand? Is the private golf club environment in danger of disintegrating because of inefficient management?

title: Dartmouth, Host, Wins Ski Carnival
description: HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 9Petter Kongsli, a ski jumper reared in Olso, Norway, successfully defended his title in the Dartmouth CollegeWinter Carnival 40meter competition today. But Kongsli's performance wasn't enough to help his University of Vermont team overhaul Dartmouth, which won the team championship for the 36th time.

title: Bruins Beat Flyers, 53; Orr Back, Gets 3 Assists
description: BOSTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) Ken Midge and Carol Vadnets each scored two goals tonight as the. Boston Bruins beat the Philadelphia Flyers, 5.3, in a game between the National Hockey League's divisional leaders.

title: Hood's Sloop Triumphs in Ocean Race
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 9Ted Hood, the complete yachtsman, has won the St. PetersburghtoFort Lauderdale ocean race.

title: Stamps
description: TWO modest 20yen commemoratives have been issued by Japan to mark the first golden wedding anniversary of an emperor in the more than 25 centuries of the Japanese royal line, a line that vies with the Ethiopian royal family for the distinction of being the oldest continuously ruling house in the world.

title: Big Time Yacht Racing Is Going Through Agonies of Change
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 9The St. PetersburgtoFort Lauderdale ocean race, concluding here today and tomorrow, is the first major event of the new season in big time yachting, a season heavy with fermentation. The sport is going through agonies of change, which have to do with continued growth, the spiral of expense, dissatisfaction with the rating rule that sets the time allowance handicaps, and a shift in the social climate.

title: Cussing and yarning and bragging
description: So many snatches of this book have already appeared in magazines and newspapers that just about everyone by now must know that President Truman spent many hours back in 1961.62 talking with Merle Miller for an aborted television series, from which Plain Speaking is adapted, and that during these conversations Truman passed judgment on:

title: How Many OPEC's in Our Future?
description: Beginning in the early nineteensixties the developing countries (virtually all those outside Western Europe, North America, Japan, Oceania, South Africa and the Communist world) began a vigorous campaign in the United Nations for concerted measures to raise the prices of their primary commodity exports.

title: Vote on Refinery Approved
description: BOSTON, Feb. 9 (AP)Both branches of the legislature on Wednesday passed and sent to the Governor a bill to provide for a nonbinding local referendum on whether a refinery should be permitted in the towns of Dracut.

title: Pilot Program Fights Alcohol
description: VERONA  A statefunded program that alms to educate an entire community on the problems of alcoholism is being tested in this North Jersey suburb of 16,000 residents. Eventually, the Verona experience is to serve as a model on alcohol education for communities throughout the state.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Nolan Ryan tells why he insisted on a oneyear contract when he signed with the California Angels for $100,000: I don't think I'm at the point where I've reached my earning potential. I might hinder my earning potential if I got tied into a multiyear contract.

title: They're at the Post at Garden State
description: Barring further snowstorms or a rebellion by the horses, Garden State Park will open New Jersey's thoroughbred racing season on Tuesday.

title: Sakala Is Promoted
description: Richard S. Sakala, assistant athletic director at Columbia University, was named associate director of athletics yesterday. He succeeds Al Paul, who became athletic director.

title: A pudding of a book full of plums
description: The recent rediscovery ofand appearance of heavily asterisked excerpts fromthe diaries of Evelyn Waugh lends a certain sportive interest to this book of reminiscences by his friends. The comic novelist, as revealed in the diaries, was so gratuitously bitchy, sowell peevish in his perception of those close to him that one feels they could only retaliate in kind. But no, nothing of the sort. While allowing the enfant terrible his flaws, they ooze objectivity, judiciousness, kindness, leniencyeven, if you'll pardon the expression, devotion. (If he was often noisy and obstreperous, writes Peter Quennell, the biographer and critic, of their days at Oxford together, I cannot recollect that he was ever illtempered. He loved his friends and while he still had money to burn, he was a lavish host and the source of unusually generous presents.)

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: The News Of the Absurd
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The headlines these days are enough to stun the mind. No wonder people don't trust the newspapers: The news can't be true. The front pages are absurd.

title: Art
description: THE American painter Morris Kantor died on Jan. 31 at the age of 77, His death was not unexpected.

title: Commuter Lines of M.T.A. To Run Normally Tuesday
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has announced that it will provide normal weekday service on Lincoln's Birthday, next Tuesday, on all commuter lines under its control.

title: Power Struggle in Soccer Is Focused on Havelange
description: Juan Havelange, the president of the Brazilian Sports Confederation and a man who made his fortune out of transport and his athletic reputation as a swimmer, probably will be the next president of the International Federation, the world governing body of soccer. The fact that the Soviets, who were thrown out of the World Cup, for refusing to play Chile, are angry at the reigning president, Sir Stanley Rous, plus the support for Havelange by the South American associations shows that the Brazilian has

title: Travelers Rediscovering the Intercity Bus as Energy Troubles Plague the City
description: Before visiting his mother in New England recently, Alfred Eldridge, who lives near Albany took one look at queues of cars backing up at gasoline stations and decided to make the 200mile trip by way of Continental Trailways. It was his first bus trip in 30 years.

title: MORRIS STRASSBERG, A CHARACTER ACTOR
description: Morris Strassberg, a character actor of stage, screen and television, who last appeared on Broadway in 1970 in the revival of Clifford Odets's Awake and Sing, died Friday in South Laguna, Calif. He was 76 years old and had lived in San Juan Capistrano, Calif., for the last three years and formerly in New York.

title: Field Complete For Daytona 300
description: DAYTONA, Fla., Feb. 9 (UPI)Jim Tobin of Hudson, Ill., led 20 more qualifiers today for the 300mile, latemodel race for stock cars, which kicks off Speed Week at Daytona International Speedway tomorrow.

title: S. C. Effler Fiance Of Deborah Carroll
description: WELLESLEY HILLS, Mass., Feb. 9The engagement of Miss Deborah Veronica Carroll, a nurse, with Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals in New York, to Stephen Corry Effler, a staff member of the Legal Aid Society of Rockland County, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James M. Carroll.

title: IS GOD A WOMAN? IS DEBATED HERE
description: As the audience arrived last week for the Town Hall debate on whether God is a woman, two guitarists strummed and sang Ain't She Sweet?

title: Ann Kane to Be Bride
description: BARTLESVILLE, Okla., Feb. 9  Mr. and Mrs. Richard Kane have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Kane, to Laurence Seidman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Seidman of New Rochelle, N.Y. A Feb. 23 wedding is planned.

title: Knicks Lose in Overtime, 103100; DeBusschere May Be Out 10 Days
description: Dave DeBusschere, who will be lost to the Knicks for approximately 10 days, sat on the sidelines with Willis Reed yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden. Neither of the injured Knicks enjoyed what he saw: a 103100 loss to the Buffalo Braves in overtime.

title: Diagramless, 21 by 19
description: ACROSS

title: Following Nixon's Tax Example?
description: A Denver bellhop told a guest recently that he had paid more tax than the President of the United States. But, he added darkly, it isn't going to happen again.

title: Ceiling unlimited
description: ACROSS

title: Woods Sets World Mark Of 722 in ShotPut
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 9 (AP)  George Woods broke the world shotput record three times last night at the 15th Los Angeles Times indoor games, finishing with a 72foot2 inch put that had enough zip to carom the 16pound steel ball over a restraining net and into a screaming crowd.

title: Architecture
description: THERE are still architects who are bullish on New York. Some people would question whether the firm of Davis, Brody and Associates is bullish or masochistic since it builds housing for New York a field in which construction conditions are notoriously hostile. (The architects, Lewis Davis and Samuel Brody, with Alan Schwartzman, the third partner, have a wide and varied practice, but housing is an important part of it.) At present, they have almost 8,000 units completed or going up in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn, under assorted sponsorship for different income

title: Yancey Keeps 3Shot Lead on 69273
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 9  Bert Yancey, pursued by a pride of Young Lions, maintained his threestroke margin by shooting a 69 today in the nexttolast round of the 90hole Bob Hope Desert Classic golf tournament.

title: A Touch of San Francisco On Staten Island's Shore
description: The comparison to San Francisco is irresistible. Staten Island's northeast shore borders the bay, guards the gateway to the sea, nestles in the shadow of a mighty bridge and rises to heights with heartstopping views.

title: Pop: Foghat's Energy Zap
description: IF YOU want to hear the definition of rock and roll circa 1974, play Foghat's third album, Energized (Bearsville BR 6950) with the volume turned up high. From the start, as the guitars barrel, in on Honey Hush, Foghat epitomizes the zap of energy that the best rock provides. Body and mind get totally caught up in music so compelling with its aggressive rhythms and dynamic arrangements that it's a natural high.

title: Marie Kohler, Francis Cabot To Wed in June
description: KOHLER, Wis., Feb. 9Mrs. John Michael Kohler has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marie House Kohler, to Francis Colin Cabot, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Cabot of New York and Cold Spring, N. Y.

title: Theater
description: It is not surprising that the Awaji Puppet Theater of has been designated by the Japanese Government as an intangible national treasure. Presented under the auspiciesof the Asia Society in association with the city Department of Cultural Affairs and appearing too briefly Carnegie Hall in the second of two performances on Thursday, it clearly deserves an equivalent American honorific for visiting artists.

title: Deborah Jane Stang Sets Nuptials in May
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 9 Arnold Stang, the actor, and Mrs. Stang have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Jane Stang, to Robert S. Brody, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred W. Brody of Omaha. The wedding is planned for May 26.

title: The Uneasy Chair  A Biography of Bernard DeVoto. By Wallace Stegner. Illustrated. 464 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $12.50.
description: The failed novelist and the successful critic

title: Growing Caseloads Not the Only Criteria
description: At the Mineola headquarters of the Nassau County Office of Consumer Affairs, 12 indignant women in leotards marched into the street floor office one day straight from a health club that had taken their money and closed suddenly without giving them their full measure of slenderness or their money back. They wanted restitution.

title: Dwindling Enrollments Plaguing Schools
description: PLAINVIEW, L, I.  As school boards begin drafting preliminary budgets for the next academic year, eyes are cast more frequentlyl at dwindling enrollment projections and skyrocketing tax rates. And the resulting debate over school closures is heard at conference tables from Anaheim, Calif. to Montauk, L. I.

title: Fruit Dealer Killed In Harlem Holdup; Gunman Gets $250
description: A fruit dealer, in business at Harlem store for 43 years, was killed and his partner and brotherinlaw was wounded yesterday afternoon by a gunMan who escaped with $250 from the victims' till.

title: Is Budget Deficit Big Enough?
description: WASHINGTON  At noon last Monday, messengers from the White House delivered to Congress four bulky documents.

title: Moscow Seems Reassured on U.S. Interest in Detente After Troubled Period
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 9Secretary of State Kissinger's plans to visit Moscow next month have been welcomed here as a sign that President Nixon will be coming in June for talks with Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: Book as Love Object
description: It happened last summer in Madrid. (I clipped the news item because you never know when the heartmuscle is going to need a massage.) A matador named Diego Bardon refused to kill a bull in the ring. Instead, he turned in his sword to the International Council Against Bullfighting. Bardon explained that what saddened him most about the whole ugly business was the fact that fighting bulls are never mated. It is doubly cruel that the bull should have to die before it ever has chance to make love.

title: Mockrevolutionary, mockpatrician
description: It is impossible to understand the weird British Parliamentary system unless one can envisage it sustained simultaneously by two such men as Harold Macmillan and Aneurin Bevan. Impossible to understand two such men without a feeling for the uniquely flexible institution which contained them both  the superEnglish mockpatrician, the superCeltic mockrevolutionary, equally part of the recondite manners of the House of Commonshow they despised each other, how well they must have got on! The Westminster scene is built on such paradoxes, which has so far been fortunate for us, who are beginning to wonder uneasily about its survival. Those postwar years in which these two men flourished, alternating the government of Britain between Socialism and Conservatism, are enthralling history, for all that betimen them they brought the land so low.

title: In Moscow, They're Fit to Be Tied
description: MOSCOWJust how wide and lively should a proper Soviet necktie be?

title: Cyrus Eaton Meets Castro; Economic Issues Discussed
description: HAVANA, Feb. 9 (Reuters)The industrialist, Cyrus Eaton, long a proponent of better relations between the United States and Communist countries, met Premier Fidel Castro here yesterday, the party newspaper Granma reported today.

title: PRESIDENT OFFERS $16BILLION PLAN ON AID TO TRANSIT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9Stressing the need for better mass transit, President Nixon, proposed today a $16billion, Federal program to improve railroads, subways and bus lines over the next six years.

title: Roberta Fleming to Be July Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Fleming of New York and Little Silver, N. J., have announced the engagement of Mr. Fleming's daughter, Miss Roberta Beverley Fleming, to John W. Ried, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Edward Ried of Fishcreek, Wis. A July wedding is planned.

title: MRS. JAMES BOYD
description: SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., Feb. 9Mrs. Katharine Lamont Boyd, widow of the novelist James Boyd, author of Drums, Long Hunt, Roll River and other novels, died last evening at her home here. She was 77 years old.

title: CUSTOMERS TO GET THEIR FILM BACK
description: Thousands of people all over the Country will soon be getting back snapshots of wedding trips, vacations and children's first steps, for which they had prepaid for processing but which have been lying unprocessed and undelivered at the post office in Rockville Centre, L. I., as a result of the troubles of a mailorder company that has been charged with grand larceny and deceptive business practices.

title: SHOP TALK
description: FORT LEEA former stable overlooking the George Washington Bridge and the Palisades serves as the studio of Paul Ortlip, an artistportraitist whose works include paintings showing the recoveries of Apollo 12 and 17 aboard the aircraft carriers Hornet and Ticonderoga.

title: Paperbacks
description: The new paperback reprint of Gentlemen Prefer Blondes excusably calls' itself a goldenanniversary edition, though we're still a year or so short of the 50th anniversary of the book Herman J. Mankiewicz accurately described in the Dec. 27, 1925 New York Times Book Review as a gorgeously smart and intelligent piece of work. Since then, Lorelei Lee, the blonde from Little Rock, Ark., who confided to her diary that A kiss on the hand may make you feel very nice, but a diamond and safire bracelet lasts forever has gone into American folklore and the Oxford Dictionary of Quotations, has been the heroine of a Broadway play, a silent film, two Broadway musicals with Carol Channing, and a Marilyn Monroe movie. As Anita Loos cheerfully observed to an interviewer last year, She's harder to kill than Rasputin.

title: Chess: The O. Henry in Reverse, A Psychological Strategy
description: In the world championship match in Reykjavik, in 1972, Bobby Fischer treated Boris Spassky to some of the most stunning surprises ever perpetrated in such a contest. Fischer had never had any but unkind words for the classical Queen's Gambit, yet  incredibly  he used it for a brilliant victory in the sixth game. For him to have used the Pirc Defense in game 17 was almost as great a surprise, since he had never tried it before either.

title: Nancy Grant Married to Martin C. Lian
description: WELLESLEY HILLS, Mass., Feb. 9Miss Nancy Virginia Grant and Martin Caspar Lian, who earned master's degrees in education at Boston University, were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Craig Bailey Adams performed the ceremony in the Wellesley Hills Congregational Church.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Game Plan For The Poor
description: The fiscal 1975 budget that Richard Nixon sent to Congress last week does not really reflect the extent to which he is trying to change what has been a restrictive national approach to the treatment of the poor. This is not so much a matter of dollars, although the budget proposed spending $100 billion on income security, an increase of $15 billion over fiscal 1974 and more than twice what was being spent in the first year of the Nixon Administration.

title: Farm Dog Tabbed Best Ridgeback
description: A farm dog from New Hampshire gave his city cousins a lesson in showmanship at the Rhodesian Ridgeback Club of the United States specialty at the Hotel Royal Manhattan yesterday.

title: Naomi Schwartz to Be Bride Of Jay Pasachoff on March 31
description: Naomi Schwartz, who received a doctorate in English literature from Brandeis University, will be married here March 31 to Jay M. Pasachoff, director of the Hopkins Observatory at Williams College and chairman of the Williams astronomy department.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: PRESIDENT NIXON'S budget for fiscal 1975 proposes $85.8billion for defense, an increase of $6.3billion from the current fiscal year.... The Administration has recommended that all wage and price controls, except for petroleum and health care, be allowed to expire April 30.... David Rockefeller, chairman of Chase Manhattan Bank, said the energy crisis would precipitate a worldwide depression if nothing is done to make adjustments.

title: MRS. WILLIAM KIRK
description: Mrs. Ruth Van Voorhis Kirk, a former social worker in Cleveland and New York, and the widow of William T. Kirk, international director of the International Social Service and former executive director of the Motion Picture and Television Fund, died yesterday at Woodland Hills, Calif., where she lived. She was 68 years old and formerly lived in Hartsdale, N. Y.

title: Pentagon Spy Case: Questions Remain
description: WASHINGTONSecrecy and surprise have been as much a part of the Nixon Administration's foreign policy as detente. The high point came in 1971. Henry A. Kissinger, then Mr. Nixon's national security adviser, stunned the world with his secret trip to China. There were secret peace negotiations in Paris with Le Duc The of North Vietnam and secret talks about nuclear disarmament with the Soviet Union.

title: Jo Tully Rosenfeld Plans Marriage
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Feb. 9Mr. and Mrs. Carson Rosenfeld have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jo Tully Rosenfeld, to John Harris Machinist, son of Mrs. Morris L. Levinson of New York and Burton Machinist of Boston. The prospective bridegroom also is a stepson of Mr. Levinson.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Alas, something else to feel guilty about. Instead of a minority feeling guilty about having sex after 65, the majority are now encouraged to feel guilty if they don't (Sex and the senior citizen by Norman M. Lobsenz, Jan. 20).

title: MORTON G. FALK
description: Morton G. Falk, president of the Falk Surgical Corporation here and past president of the New York Surgical Dealers Association, died yesterday of cancer at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale; Fla.

title: People and Business
description: Indepth feasibility studies are under way in connection with a $2.5billion proposal to revitalize the South Broad Street section of Newark, according to Robert F. Notte, executive director of the Newark Housing Authority.

title: Yifter Cuts World Mark For 5,000 by 11 Seconds
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. (AP)Mirus Yifter of Ethiopia clipped more than 11 seconds off the world indoor record for the 5,000meter run tonight at the MasonDixon Games.

title: Harvard Victor Over Cornell, 7463
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 9Harvard, led by Tony Jenkins's 14 points and 9 rebounds, defeated Cornell, 7463, tonight.

title: MAYORS CRITICIZE NIXON '75 BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9  An organization representing the nation's mayors criticized President Nixon's 1975 budget today, contending that it puts more responsibilities on the cities without providing enough money.

title: Sharks Sign Holley
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 9 (AP)The Florida Sharks of the World Football League announced the signing today of a former Tennessee State defensive back, Alex Holley. He was cut by the Kansas City Chiefs after the 1973 exhibition season. He is the eighth player to be signed by the Sharks.

title: Golden Millions
description: The following massdistributed paperbacks are reported by their publishers to have had print orders of 900,000 copies or more in 1973. Because of the peculiarities of the distribution system, sale of 50 per cent of the copies printed is considered satisfactory.

title: Direct Use of The Sun's Energy By Farrington Daniels. Illustrated. 374 pp. New York: Ballantine Books. $1.95.
description: With all the recent foofaraw on the energy crisis, it is to me flatout astonishing that solar energy has received so little journalistic notice. For even before man was steady on his hind legs he worshipped the sun, the ultimate source of everything that moves or is moved upon the earth, energy absolutely nonpolluting and available in abundance for the next six billion years or so.

title: Though Fascinating, Ferns Are Flowerless Many of the world's species are so unusual, they suggest other forms of plant life.
description: THE world's vast wetlantle, prairies, slopes, and mountains provide habitats for about 12,000 species of ferns. These flowerless plants grow virtually everywhere between the hot, timid areas of the equator and the regions of the short polar summers.

title: Hope for Tax Cut Fades
description: ALBANYIn the minds of the Long Island legislators the concept of relief for the property taxpayer is not yet dead in this critical electionyear session, but in the political realities, it does seem to be dying after a good fight.

title: Boston U .'s Hockey Team Converts Chaos to Success
description: How's this as a scenario for a successful college hockey team? After losing a top skater to ineligibility during the previous season, declare two more players ineligible over the summer. Then watch them challenge this ruling in court. A judge reinstates the players on the eve of the first game, but a month later, the school drops the coach for not investigating his skaters with sufficient vigor. Finally bring in a 28yearold assistant to take over this seething mess and see him lose three of his first six contests.

title: Dumping Law Facing a Test
description: TRENTONA court hearing will be held next month to determine the legality of a new state law banning the dumping of any outofstate solid waste in New Jersey.

title: Creighton Ends Marquette Home Streak
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 9 (AP)  Creighton got 25 points from Doug Brookins and 21 from Gene Harmon tonight as the Bluejays rallied from a 142 deficit to upset sixthranked Marquette, 7569. Creighton has an 184 wonlost record and Marqueete is 183.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayBoulder Brook, Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, N.Y. Special, local, junior and children's working hunters; equitation. 8 A.M.

title: State Seeks to Ease Apartment Impact
description: TRENTONIn possible anticipation of a forthcoming decision by the State Supreme Court, a special study commission is pondering a plan to compensate those communities that are required to accept lowerincome apartment projects.

title: Legislative Notes Gas Shortage Plays No Favorites
description: TRENTON  Legislators (and just about everyone else in the State House) were no different than their constituents last week: They had their failures and their successes in coping with the gasoline crisis, with emphasis on failures.

title: Neediest Cases Fund Reaches $1Million for 4th Straight Year
description: For the fourth consecutive year, contributions to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have exceeded $1million.

title: ROANS UNEARTH EARLY PRINCESS
description: ROME, Feb. 9The remains of a woman with rich ornaments of gold, silver, small pearls and large amber beads, found in a seventhcentury B.C. tomb near here, is intriguing experts at the Government's Superintendency of Antiquities, who speak of a Latin princess of the era of Rome's founding.The discovery was made recently in a burial site, near Castel di Decima, 10 Miles south of Rome's center. So far, more than 100 tombs, dating from the eighth to the end of the seventh century B.C., have been unearthed. The grave of the nameless princess is one of the most important finds so far.

title: Samuels Opens Plea For Contributions To Get Governorship
description: Howard J. Samuels, the former chairman of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, announced yesterday that he had begun a directmail appeal to thousands of New Yorkers for financial help in his campaign for Governor.

title: Epilogue
description: For Spiro T. Agnew, the transition from lawyer to novelist seems to have been a successful one, at least financially. The Ladies Home Journal has agreed to pay more than $100,000 for serial rights to his yetuncompleted first novel. The first excerpt is to appear in the May issue. The plot: a United States vice president is deceived by militant Iranian nationalists who wish to force a confrontation between the United States and the Soviet Union. Three women characters also figure in the novel: his wife, his secretary and a woman who is secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. Mr. Agnew has submitted an outline of the book, together with a sample chapter and some character studies, to several hardcover book publishers. An earlier proposal of Mr. Agnew's for a novel was turned down by Random House. Mr. Agnew began his literary activities after his resignation in October as United States Vice President following a nocontest plea to a charge of incometax evasion.

title: Super020 salutations
description: The leaders of the billiondollarayear greetingcard industry are known as The Big Five, No. 1 is Hallmark Cards, Inc., founded a few years before World War by Joyce C. Hall, who, as an enterprising teenager, had come to Kansas City, Mo., to invest his savings in the thriving picture  postcard business. Eventually he switched to greeting cards and began to develop what seemed to be the progressive notion that greeting cards should be folded and stuffed in envelopes, not sent through the mails like common postcards. Mr. Hall has kept Hallmark a private, familyowned company that doesn't share its business statistics with the public. Hallmark's art department is the biggest art department in the world, according to Henry Cooper, executive director of the National Association of Greeting Card Publishers. Three hundred and fifty artists grinding out 12,000 individual designs for greeting cards in a year. Millions of individual items a day are being pumped out of Hallmarkfrom cards to candles.

title: Dance: Why the Kirov Isn't Coming
description: JUST how stupid can the Russian bureaucracy be? It is a quite fascinating problem. As children we read Gogol's The Government Inspector, and as adults we have watched with concern the tortuous processes of Russian diplomacy. But now many people in the West, like myself enormously sympathetic to Russia and Russians, are disturbed by the dangers threatening to dtentethat absolutely essential adjustment between East and Westput up by the obstacles to simple freedom met by people such as Valery and Galina Panov.

title: Booklet to Advise On Saving Energy
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  Tips on how to help conserve energy are being compiled at Cook College, a division of Rutgers University. A new publication, Reduce Your Utility Bills, is being prepared for release soon.

title: Fort Hancock Is Facing Future as a Park
description: SANDY HOOKPlans to finally deactivate centuriesold Fort Hancock in December, announced by the Department of Defense last week, came as no great surprise to most of the 400 Army personnel, 450 National Guardsmen and 200 civilians stationed there.

title: BOLIVIA'S BURDEN: WIDESPREAD WANT
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 9 (AP) The current economic turmoil and violence in Bolivia underline the depressing poverty in which most of the people live. Humberto Averange can speak for many of them.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Education, Space, Psychology, Religion

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Solutions to last week's puzzles
description: [DOUGLAS] FAIRBAIRN: A SQUIRREL FOREVER My friends . . . I'm sure . . . thought my having a squirref was a symptom of something but they just didn't know quite what. (I was forty years old. All kinds of things can begin happening to you when you turn forty, usually none of them any good)

title: He'll Give Us Lots of His Jelly Roll
description: EVEN Jelly Roll Morton, the feisty, braggadoclous New Orleans pianist, composer, band leader, pool hustler and selfproclaimed inventor of jazz, would probably have approved of the plans for a concert at Alice Tully Hall next Saturday evening.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Columbia Defeats Dartmouth, 5351
description: Mark Hardaway sank two free throws with 8 seconds remaining to give Columbia a 5351 victory over Dartmouth last night in the Lions' University Gym.

title: Lumber Costs Dropping As Home Prices Rise
description: After two years of steady increases that saw them rise as much as 70 per cent, lumber prices are dropping sharply, in some cases to a point lower than their levels when the upward spiral began.

title: How Much Is That Pitcher?
description: In the first halfhour of Friday afternoon, seven baseball players notified the Players' Association they were going to binding arbitration on their 1974 salaries. Tomorrow is the last day for making such a decision, and the pace quickened over the weekend as more and more players resorted to this novel expedient. Some of them may still back off. The only prediction that can be made with reasonable safety is that the Oakland A's will lead both leagues in seeking outside help. This is partly because the A's are twotime champions of the world and expect to be rewarded accordingly, and partly because their employer is Charles O. Finley. Charlie, by the way, intends to argue all his cases himself.

title: Informal Rationing
description: It wasn't planned and it wasn't expected, but the states and the cities of the northeast began a desperate, piecemeal and impromptu kind of gasoline rationing last week for two reasons: nobody else was doing it, and chaos was becoming the norm for millions of drivers.

title: LETTER FROM BANGKOK
description: A resident coming back to the Thai capital today after an absence of a few months probably wouldn't notice many very major changes at first glance. The traffic is still among the worst in all of Asia, and the gilded, glittering Buddhist temples still rise improbably beside shopping centers that boast the latest in Western fashions and Japanese electronics. Boatloads of tourists (mostly Japanese these days) still create water jams as they view the famous Floating Market, and the gaudy night streets of bars and massage parlors, legacies of the American effort in Vietnam, are as garish and crowded as ever.

title: Project to Build 2 Power Dams On Carolina River Is Protested
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9God created a beautiful valley through which the New River flows, Stella Anderson told the Public Lands Subcommittee of the Senate Interior Committee. Will we allow all this to be destroyed by drawdown dams?

title: Entries in Pro Track In Nassau on Friday
description: 60Yard DashJeanLouis Ravelomanantsoa, Mel Pender, Jim Hines, Warren Edmonson, Jim Green.

title: Scholarships Honor Jazz Clarinetist
description: MARTINSVILLEThe Pee Wee Russell Memorial Stomp, which has been held at the Martinsville Inn every February since 1970, will reach a significant milestone this afternoon. The first Pee Wee Russell Scholarships, funded with money raised by four previous stomps, will be announced at today's festivities.

title: Laura Simpson Fiancee Of Grover O'Neill 3d
description: KATONAH, N. Y., Feb. 9Mr. and Mrs. William Kelly Simpson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Knickerbacker Simpson, to Grover O'Neill 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Neill Jr. of New York and Nantucket, Mass.

title: 2 Men Are Found Slain Near Factory in Brooklyn
description: Two men were found slain yesterday in the East Flatbush Section of Brooklyn, the police reported.

title: F.B.I. Reports Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) The Federal Bureau of Investigation has reported that nine local and state lawenforcement officers were killed by criminals all through use of firearmsduring January. This compared with 19 killed in January, 1973. The monthly report showed that four were killed in NorthCentral states, three in Southern states and two in Western states.

title: In Glen Ridge, Education Rates High
description: GLEN RIDGEMost residents of this Essex County borough are welleducated and, therefore, are willing to pay for highquality schooling for their children. Taxes are presently the highest in the area  $6.90 for every $100 of assessed valuation but the schools in Glen Ridge are the borough's (and residents') greatest source of pride. I suppose that our tax rate is slightly high, said Mrs. Theresa Reimain, a 15year resident. We put a high standard on education in Glen Ridge, and we don't mind paying for it. Our children are important to us.

title: Istaeli Five Wins Here
description: The Israeli national basketball team scored its third successive victory on its American tour last night by defeating the Long Island City college allstars, 9757, at the Lexington School for the Deaf. The Israelis, playing a 12game tour sch6clule, will play today in Washington.

title: U.S. Steps Up Persuasion As Mote Truckers Return
description: With private persuasion and public optimism, the Nixon Administration intensified its efforts yesterday to win drivers' support for a tentative agreement and end the 10dayold nationwide strike of independent truckers.

title: To Josiah Spaulding Jr.
description: MANCHESTER, Mass., Feb. 9  Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Lowell Reeve of Manchester and Mount Desert, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Victoria Roosevelt Reeve, to Josiah Augustus Spaulding Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Spaulding of Manchester.

title: Henry and Richard and John and Dwight
description: WASHINGTONSince I published a biography of the late John Foster Dulles in November, any number of people have suggested parallels between Dwight D. Eisenhower's powerful Secretary of State and Henry A. Kissinger, who is currently holding up more than his share of the world for Richard M. Nixon. There are striking similarities in the characters and performances of the two Secretaries, but equally striking differences.

title: Suzette McKiernan Married To Harold Davis in Rumson
description: RUMSON, N. J., Feb. 9Miss Eileen Suzette McKiernan of New York, daughter of the late Brig. Gen. William J. McKiernan, U.S.A., and the late Mrs. Lucielle Adams McKiernan, was married here at noon today to Harold Edward Davis of New York and Remsenberg, L.I.

title: LETTERS
description: Security

title: Mrs. Marie K. Johnston Wed Here to Anthony Joseph Peters
description: The marriage of Mrs. Maria Kelly Johnston of Glen Cove, L. L, daughter of William David Kelly of Williston, L. I., formerly of Brooklyn and Sayville, L. I., and the late Mrs. Kelly, to Anthony Joseph Peters, president and chief operating officer of Cushman & Wakefield, Inc., took place here yesterday afternoon.

title: Pollution Violators Are Assessed $768,100
description: TRENTON  The state's Department of Environmental Protection collected $768,100 in penalties last year from violators of the New Jersey airpollution control code.

title: CHILE POLITICIANS FEAR FOR PARTY
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 9Leaders of the Christian Democrats, Chile's largest political party, say that their protest letter to the head of the ruling military junta was drafted only after senior members felt that their party's very existence was being threatened by the Government.

title: Murder in Paradise: The Case of St. Croix
description: ON the morning of Sept. 6, 1972, Josephine Wilmarth arrived in Boston to talk with J. Sterling Livingston about leasing his small hotel on St. Croixone of the three American Virgin Islands. That afternoon, Ishmael Labeet and his companions stormed onto the dining terrace of the Fountain Valley Golf Club on St. Croix and gunned down eight persons. Ever since, nothing has gone quite right for Josephine and Bob Wilmarthor for anybody else in St. Croix's tourist industry.

title: Numismatics
description: EDUCATION and youngsters are hopefully an inseparable combination in numismatics, and this week there are reports of events that should add to the solidarity of that combination.

title: Island Water Table Is Rising
description: MINEOLA, L.I. The ground water has begun to rise to normal levels on Long Island, according to a Federal report, and some homeowners who bought in the dry midnineteensixties are having to pump it out of their basements,

title: Strike Planned in Germany
description: BONN, Feb. 9 (UPI)Leaders of the West German Office Workers' Union, demanding a 15 per cent wage increase, said today that their members would go on strike Monday. Leaders of other unions, including railway, postal and police employes, said approval of a work stoppage had won overwhelming approval.

title: Home Repair Clinic
description: Questions from readers about home repair problems should be addressed to: Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N.Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered in this column:

title: From Space, A Rounded View of The Earth
description: When men first left the earth for space, they looked back: for orientation, sometimes for reassurance and, more often, simply to enjoy the view. They found, too, that the view could be revealing: Early photographs from orbit helped to revise maps of the remote Tibetan plain and provided clues for discovery of more oil and gas in North Africa. But in those heady days, when space flight was novel and surrounded by glamour, man's sights were set not on the earth, but on the moon, the faraway planets and space itself, the new ocean.

title: Book Ends
description: O AMERICA. A funny thing happened to Alistair Cooke's America on the way to best sellerdom: its publisher, Knopf, got caught short of books during the Christmas rush and had to borrow 45,000 from the Literary Guild. All's well now, insists Tony Schulte, executive vice president: a third printing of 100,000 (ordered in November but delayed by paper shortages) will be ready Feb. 15; 170,000 copies have been sold, there are 40,000 new orders, a fourth printing of 50,000 will be ready in April and there is talk of a fifth printing. We think the demand is going to be terrific all year, Mr. Schulte said.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: On OTB
description: To The Editor: A recent article in The Times (Jan. 10, 1974) reported, on the basis of what was described as a Police Department white paper, that there has been a rise in betting with organized crime which may be the result of the creation of the OffTrack Betting Corporation.

title: Jobs Are Awaiting the Unskilled Elderly
description: HACKENSACK  For the Unskilled, elderly job hunter, the market offers companion, babysitter and housekeeper positions for women and a variety of handyman tasks for men.

title: Chris Evert Outclasses Miss Casals
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 9 (UPI)  Chris Evert, playing flawlessly in a chill wind, routed Rosemary Casals, 6.0, 61, in a semifinal of the $50,000 women's tennis tournament today.

title: Citizen Croup Asks Legislature To Name ElectionLaw Panel
description: A bipartisan citizens' advisory committee on electionlaw reform urged the Legislature yesterday to establish this year a state election law commission with strong powers to enforce campaignfinancing limits and a code of faircampaign practices.

title: INVESTING
description: Now the silver bulls are stampeding through the futures markets.

title: Schools In Summit Seek to Aid Minorities
description: SUMMITA program designed to combat isolation of Minority groups in both the Summit school system and the community itself has been drafted by the town's public school administrators.

title: Gray Promoted by I.R.S.
description: Elliott H. Gray, director of the Manhattan District of the Internal Revenue Service since June, 1971, has been promoted to commissioner of the North Atlantic region, the service announced yesterday. The region includes the six New Englang states and New York. Mr. Gray succeeds John J. Flynn, who retired.

title: Music in Review
description: An unusually promising pianist named Marian Hahn made her New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night as winner of one of the Concert Artists Guild's Madeleine Malraux Awards.

title: A Youth Mistaken for a Mugger Is Shot in West Side Poolroom
description: A 15yearold youth was shot in a poolroom yesterday on the if per West Side by a neighborhood man who apparently Mistook him for one of three youths who he said mugged him last week, the police said.

title: Lucy, Lucy, Lucy, Lucy, Lucy...
description: MONDAY

title: Who Who But an Owl?
description: The jays and the crows seem to possess the open countryside now, and there is a note of arrogance in their calls. Up in the woods the ruffed grouse hold their own, to be sure, but they are quiet. And the lesser birds, those that come down to patronize the freelunch feeders, only chitter and chirp, and their talk seems to be only among themselves.

title: Golden Gate Fee Raised
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9 (UPI) Motorists will pay 75 centsan increase of 25 cents  to cross the famed Golden Gate Bridge after March 1. The Golden Gate Bridge District voted to raise the toll yesterday.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Beach Debate
description: The lengthy debate over whether to allow development within the Assateague National Seashore, a long, narrow barrier beach off the MarylandVirginia coast, will be brought to a close if lation sponsored by Senators Charles McC. Mathias Jr. and J. Glenn Beall Jr., Republicans of Maryland, wins Congressional approval.

title: Voter Choice of a Political Party Reaches New Low in Gallup Poll
description: Voter identification with a partisan political party is at the lowest point in the 34 years such readings have been taken by the Gallup Poll.

title: Spicer Brook First
description: BOSTON, Feb. 9 (AP)Spicer Brook led wiretowire today to beat Israeli Jet by two lengths at Suffolk Downs. The winner raced the .six furlongs in 1:11 35 and paid $7.80, $5 and $3 for $2 across the board. Israeli Jet returned $6.20 and $3.60 and Copper Moon paid $2.20 to show.

title: Dr. Nancy McKee Is Engaged To Wed Arthur John Condliffe
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Lawfence McKee of North Bay, Ontario, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Nancy Hunt McKee, to Arthur John (Toby) Condliffe, son of Mrs. Jane Rosenthal Condliffe of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Vineyard Haven, Mass., and John C. Condliffe of Union City, N. J.

title: Top Arab Talks About Syrian Front Indicated
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 9President Anwar el  Sadat of Egypt and several other Arab leaders, including President Hafez alAssad of Syria, were reported today to be planning an early conference to discuss the tangled issues holding up a disengagement of Israeli forces on the Syrian front.

title: KENNETH E. BERGIN
description: Kenneth Edward Bergin, a partner in the law firm of Weil, Lee & Bergin and a specialist in corporate law, died Friday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 46 years old and lived at 276 First Avenue.

title: The Nelsons Have Child
description: NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 9 A daughter was born Wednesday to Mr. and Mrs. Robert Nelson of Greenfield Hill, Fairfield, in the Norwalk Hospital. Mrs. Nelson is the former Miss Nanci Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Martin of Southport. Her husband is circulationsalesdevelopment manager of The New York Times. The child, the couple's second daughter, has been named Jessica.

title: William Reidy to Wed Miss Halleran
description: Mrs. Arthur J. Halleran of Manhattan has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marcia Halleran, to William Reidy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Reidy of Riverdale, the Bronx. A May wedding is planned.

title: PROF. EDWIN SCHUCK OF COLUMBIA LAW, 57
description: Prof. Edwin G. Schuck, law librarian and professor of law at the Columbia Law School, died yesterday at his home, Fairmount Road, Ridgewood, N. J. after a long illness. He was 57 years old.

title: More Zoning Tests Confront Hunterdon
description: CLINTON TOWNSHIP Nearly two years ago, mary residents of rural Hunterdon County were shocked to learn that the Suburban Action Institute, an organization seeking to end exclusionary zoning practices in New Jersey, was planning to build a 2,000unit housing complex on a horse farm in Readington Township. The project, it was said, would double the farming community's population.

title: THEATER OPENINGS
description: FASHION  Tomorrow, McAlpin Rooftop, 6:45. A musical adapted from Anna Cora Mowatt's play by Anthony Stimac; music by Don Pippin; lyrics by Steve Brown.

title: Campaign Styles Change During Energy Shortage
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The political campaign motorcade, a fivetoten car caravan that traveled from town to town with banners flying, is becoming a thing of the past.

title: Mary B. Conley Wed to Physician
description: Miss Mary Bradwell Conley, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Conley of New York and Westhampton Beach, L. I., was married here at noon yesterday to Dr. Daniel Clifton Baker 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Baker Jr. of Demarest, N. J.

title: Civil Suit Involving Libyan Land Tract Reopened in Philadelphia on New Data
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10ly discovered evidence and a dramatic shift in testimony nave brought about the re ripening of a civil suit here in rolving allegations of bribery and deception in a dispute over a lage tract of what may be oilrich land.

title: Advertising: N.A.R.B. Is Scored
description: The first consumerist study of the twoyearold National Advertising Review Board charges the industry's first selfregulation organization with slowness in processing complaints, lack of leadership, inadequate public representation and with intentionally keeping a low profile.

title: The Theater: Hilarious Hot Ice
description: Hot Ice, the apt title of Charles Ludlam's enticing new Ridiculous Theatrical Company show, now playing at the Evergreen Theater, is a crime comedy. It is not about a jewel robbery but about a frozencorpse caper.

title: More Truckers Back After Protest
description: Independent truckers wheeled their rigs onto the nation's highways in increasing numbers yesterday, but in some areas striking drivers defied President Nixon's pleas to return to work.

title: Pop Music: Loudon Wainwright 3dQuirky, Parodistic and All Performer Sings Fisher Hall Concert
description: Loudon Wainwright 3d is best known as a songwriter, and legitimately so. His work uses humor in a most unusual way: It is funny, but it can be disturbing, thoughtprovoking and freshly innocent, too. And Mr. Wainwright manages to dress his quirky texts in appealing music. He is a Martin Mull with Randy Newman's pretensions, and a more effective musician than both of them together.

title: Scaramouche Takes Lead In Southern Ocean Races
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 10Scaramouche, an impressive new 55foot sloop from Sturgis, Mich., is the leading yacht in the Southern Ocean Racing Circuit standings on the basis of two completed races in the series of six.

title: Asia Games: I.O.C. Backs China Entry
description: GENEVA, Feb. 10The International Olympic Committee bowed today to world political devalopments by accepting the exclusion of Taiwana member in good standingfrom next September's Asian Games in favor of China, a nonmember.

title: Photoengravers Ratify 2Year Pact With Papers
description: Members of Photoengravers Union 1P yesterday ratified a new twoyear contract with The New York Times and The Daily News, at a meeting in the New York School of Printing, 439 West 49th Street.

title: Iraq Reports Attack by Iran on Frontier
description: BAHRAIN, Feb. 10Iraq said tonight that a frontier clash early today with Iranian forces backed by heavy artillery and armor left 70 Iranians dead and wounded and caused 23 Iraqi casualties.

title: Recital
description: Judging from the number of young people in the audience for Martha Argerich's recital at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon and by the quality of frenzy in their ovations, the Argentine pianist could become a cult figure hereor figurine, since she is deceptively frail in appearance. Her program, in the hall's Great Performers series, consisted of standard virtuoso material, but she played it with an appealing musicality as well as tremendous technical facility.

title: Reuss to Offer Amendment On a NoConfidence Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) A Constitutional amendment that would permit Congress to vote no confidence in a President and call a special election will be offered in the House by Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Fletcher of The Times Is Honored 10th Time
description: For the 10th year in a row, Walter R. Fletcher of The New York Times has been honored by the Dog Writers' Association of America. At the organization's annual dinner last night at the Statler Hilton Hotel, he received two scrollsfor the best dog column of the year and the best news reporting. Both were for newspapers with more than 150,000 circulation.

title: Yeoman and Admiral
description: Millions of Americans with past experience in the armed services will shake their beads in disbelief over the testimony of Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, Chairman the Joint Chiefs of Staff, that Yeoman 1st Cl. Charles Radford, acting on his own initiative, collected secret White House papers for clandestine transmission to the Pentagon's top brass.

title: Dee Judged Top Yorkie In First Visit
description: Mrs. Frank Hattori, a Seattle realtor, flew into New York Saturday night with her Yorkshire terrier, Ch. Clarkwyn Double Eagle. Yesterday she watched the 6pounder win the national specialty at the Stotler Hilton Hotel.

title: The Energy Conclave ...
description: The major oilconsuming nations meeting in Washington today have no attractive alternative to cooperation, even if some have been hedging their bets by seeking in part to go their own way. It is this reality that lends hope to the proposals for joint action made by the United States, despite the reservations expressed, on French insistence, by West Europe's ninenation Common Market.

title: Serving of Drinks on Airline at Issue in Kuwait
description: KUWAIT, Feb. 9The National Assembly, Kuwait's lively parliament, was in an uproar this week over whether Kuwait's national airline should, continue to serve alcoholic drinks on its flights.

title: Quis Custodiet?
description: WASHINGTONThe original indictment of the Watergate burglars came down on Sept. 15, 1972. The next day George McGovern called it a whitewash. Who ordered this act of political espionage? he asked. Who paid for it? Who made the $114,000 contribution that went through the Nixon campaign committee to one of the accused? The questions not even raised in the indictment, he said, were staggering.

title: 63 and an Activist, She Hopes to Become an Episcopal Priest
description: Pauli Murray tends to charge ahead when she thinks something ought to be done.

title: 31 Left Homeless in 2 Fires
description: CHELSEA, Mass., Feb. 10 (AP)Thirtyone persons were deft homeless and an estimated $425,000 in damage occurred here yesterday in two predawn fires, the fire officials said.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 37

title: Radford Contends Moorer Knew A bout His Snooping
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10Yeoman 1st Cl. Charles E. Radford contends that he has sufficient information to persuade the Senate Armed Services Committee that Admiral Thomas H. Moorer knew the yeoman was funneling eyes only White House documents to the admiral's Pentagon office.

title: Arms Talks: Problems
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.In May, 1972, President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev signed the first two agreements ever to impose limitations on strategic weapons, One was a treaty on antiballistic missiles; the other was an interim agreement on offensive weapons.

title: 3 Britons Hurt in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 10 (Reuters)Three British soldiers were injured, one seriously, in gun battles with guerrillas today near the border village of Crossmaglen, 40 miles south of Belfast.

title: Help for Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 10  William E. Simon promised today that emergency supplies of gasoline would be directed within the next two weeks to Connecticut, according to Gov. Thomas J. Meskill and Representative Robert H. Steele.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DUTCH TREAT Broodje is a pleasant place that specializes in a popular Netherlands sandwichit used to he in a holeinthewall on West 47th Street, but now has moved to more commodious though far from spacious quarters at 246 East 51st Street (8327188). It's on the ground floor of an old building, has two rooms open for lunch (noon to 4 daily) and keeps one of them, with some blue Dutch tile dcor and for a multitude of maybe 30, open several nights a week.

title: A True Tempest of Humanity and Wit
description: The New York Shakespeare Festival is itself again, and last night at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater it came up with a remarkably satisfying, rich and strange production, of Shakespeare's The Tempest.

title: State Energy Office Is Opening Today With Skeleton Staff Braced for Snarls
description: TRENTON, Feb. 10  The State Energy Office will open here tomorrow with a skeleton staff of five persons, headed by Richard W. DeKorte, Energy Administrator.

title: Personal Finance: Estate Ruling Costly to Legatee
description: Thomas W. Helms, a wealthy Virginian, decided several years ago to write his own will and to leave his wife a considerable amount of stock. The wording he used, however, turned out to be very expensive.

title: PartTime Political Jobs Cost State $2Million a Year
description: The state is spending more than $2million a year for 18 boards, commissions and authorities, most of whose members are political appointees who do little work for the state.

title: Con Ed May Switch To Bimonthly Billing
description: Consolidated Edison is exploring a return to bimonthly billing because the present monthly system has produced a heavy volume of customer complaints about projected usage and considerable arrears in payments, a spokesman said last night.

title: Norwegian Wins Speed Skate Title
description: INZELL, West Germany, Feb. 10 (AP)Sten Stensen of Norway won the world speed skating championship today when the defending titleholder Goeran Claeson of Sweden, faded in the decisive 10,000meter race.

title: Plan to Eliminate Grade Crossings Lags
description: CHATHAM, N. Y., Feb. 10 Jack Mesick, the Mayor of this upstate village, stood at the railroadcrossing barrier here the other day, counting freight cars as they clattered across the tracks on Main Street.

title: Small Points Of Coalition Worry Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 10 The quiet, patient people of this languorous capital on the banks of the Mekong River seem no more concerned about the prospects of getting a new national coalition government than a family expecting the return of a longabsent and not particularly successful relative. It will be interesting to renew the acquaintance, but there is no need to make a fuss just yet.

title: The Beame Technique
description: When the current generation of New York politicians talks of how a Mayor should do his job, the man who gets the ritual public praise is Fiorello H. La Guardia, but the man they cite in case after specific case is Robert F. Wagner. He was infuriatingly noncommittal, they say, but he knew the territory. So it was with a mixture of exasperation and respect that a city Councilman, when he was asked how Abraham D. Beame was measuring up, replied, I feel like I've been in a time capsule. All those Wagner faces turning up.

title: Oil Parley to Open Today; Limited Results Expected
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10Delegates from the world's leading oilconsuming countries agreed today on an agenda for the Washington energy conference beginning tomorrow.

title: On Emancipation
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22, 1862President Lincoln announced today his intention to free the slaves in those states still in rebellion as of Jan. 1, 1863. White House aides referred to the press handout as an Emancipation Proclamation and characterized it as a major statement. A fictional roundup of comment follows:

title: A. Heald Marries Mrs. Rankin
description: The marriage of Mrs. Deborah M. Rankin, a business writer with The Associated Press, to Lawrence A. Heald, a systems engineer with the International Business Machines Corporation, took place at the bride's apartment here yesterday afternoon. Khoren Arisian, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony.

title: 2 Towns Sue to Bar New Drivein Zoo
description: JACKSON TOWNSHIP, Feb. 10Great Adventure, Inc., the company constructing a giant drivein zoo and amusement park here, has been sued by two Monmouth County municipalities that are trying to compel it to cease work.

title: Ration Plans at a Glance
description: New YorkUnder a voluntary plan, motorists with evennumbered license plates will buy gasoline on evennumbered dates and those with oddnumbered plates on oddnumbered dates. A plate with letters only is considered an odd number. In months with 31 days, only the oddnumbered group would get gasoline on the 31st. There is no mandatory minimum purchase, though motorists are asked not to go to stations until their tanks are least halfempty. The system applies equally to all outofstate cars.

title: Election NonReform
description: Failure of the state legislative leaders to push through Albany the needed election law reforms in time to affect this year's political campaigns would be an affront to the people's intelligence.

title: In 185th Year, Coast Guard Goes Coed
description: CAPE MAY, N. J., Feb. 10 The recruits of Sierra Company 89 at the Coast Guard Training Center here are out of bed at 5:15 every morning, puffing through calisthenics and running a mile, Then there is mopping and sweeping, shoeshining, dismantling rifles, drilling and hours of technical classes.

title: Dr. Fritz Zwicky, Astronomer, Jet Propulsion Expert, 74, Dies
description: PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 10 (UPI)  Dr. Fritz Zwicky, astronomer and inventor who was last working on the research of exploding stars, died Friday night of a heart attack in Huntington Memorial Hospital. His age was 74.

title: Former Aide Enters Race Against Dominican Chief
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 10 (UPI)Former Vice President Francisco Augusto Lora became the fourth publicly announced candidate for president here today. His, main opponent in the May 16 election will bePresi dent Joaquin Balaguer, running for a third consecutive fouryear term. Mr. Lora served him as vice president from 1966 to 1970.

title: BOY, 2, DIES IN FALL INTO CAVEDIN WELL
description: MIAMI, Feb. 10 (UPI)  A 2yearold boy fell into a 25footdeep, cavedin irrigation well in a tomato patch in southwest Miami today and suffocated after being trapped under loose dirt for two hours.

title: CHARLES P. M'CARTY, EXST. PAUL MAYOR
description: ST. PAUL, Feb. 10 (AP)Charles P. McCarty Jr., who served as St. Paul's mayor for one term, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 53 years old.

title: LITTLE HOPE SEEN FOR 35CENT FARE
description: Mayor Beame and Dr. William J. Ronan, the head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday that they saw nothing in President Nixon's transportation program to save the 35cent fare.

title: Bellevue Inmate Hangs Himself After 3d Transfer in 3 Months
description: A 23yearold inmate in the psychiatric prison ward at the Bellevue Hospital Center hanged himself with a bedsheet yesterday from one end of a bed that he had stood on its end while several other inmates looked on, city officials reported.

title: Peak Grain Crop Planned; Could Check Beef Prices
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 10American farmers expect to plant the largest corn and wheat crops in history this spring, as well as a soybean crop only slightly smaller than last year's recordbreaker.

title: Skylab 3 Crew Termed In Fine Medical Shape
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 10  The Skylab 3 astronauts were reported today to be walking well with only a trace of vertigo, cating like pigs and performing medical tests with flying colors.

title: BUYERS IN SPAIN INSIST ON VALUE
description: MADRID, Feb. 10The consumer society has developed in this onceimpoverished country to the point where consumerism has become big business.

title: Poiret, Dead 30 Years, Once Again a Celebrity
description: The name to drop in the fashion capitals of the world these days is Paul Poiret. He's the man who, if he did not invent the couture, devised all the extravagances connected with it: the parties, the promotions, the publicity and the perfume.

title: Heykal Said to Attribute Ouster to Rift on Nixon
description: Mohammed Hassanein Heykal says he was dismissed as editor of Egypt's most prestigious newspaper because of his expressed doubts about President Nixon's influence in the Middle East, according to Time magazine.

title: FOR ROCKEFELLER, THE OLD QUESTION
description: ROCKFORD, Ill., Feb. 10Nelson A. Rockefeller had just told a group of reporters what he had been telling others recently: That he will make no decision on whether to seek the Republican nomination for President until the latter part of 1975.

title: Thoeni Sweeps Slalom
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 10Some of the reckless competitors plowed into photographers, others knocked down officials and poles, but the most daring skier of them all todayGustavo Thoeni of Italymade it safely to the finish line and his second gold medal of the world Alpine championships.

title: Effects of Oil Crisis Are Severe in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 8 The first thing that strikes the visitor after several months' absence from Korea is the leap in prices. The taxicab from the airport to the hotel that once cost $2.50 has become $3.25. A meal that was $1.75 is now $2.28. A gallon of gasoline, formerly 60 cents, is now $1.80. A newspaper headline reports price increases on industrial products ranging from 7 to 57 per cent.

title: OIL CRISIS SPURS UNITY IN MARKET
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 10  After the nine Common Market foreign ministers agreed last Tuesday on a joint position for the oil conference in Washington, the President of the market's commission, Franois  Xavier Ortoli of France, told them: The United States has pushed into achieving more unity on oil in two hours than we have achieved in the last 10 months.

title: Opera: Sparkling Otello
description: It was past six o'clock at the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday afternoon and time for everyone to clear out so that the house could be gotten ready for the evening performance, but most of the matinee audience was reluctant to leave.

title: U.S. Reported Equipping Jordan With Missiles
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 10The United States is equipping the Jordanian Army with sophisticated antitank missiles of the sort used by Israel during the October war, reliable sources said today.

title: Brown Needs a Second Miracle for First Ivy Title
description: Brown University's basketball brochure is less pretentious than most. Even if the Bruins wanted to invest the money and compete in the field of bigger and better brochures, they could only fill them with a history of losing seasons.

title: ...a Common Approach
description: This common approach is the essential requirement, rather than formal institutional machinery for consumer cooperation, which the Nine oppose. Common programs in the framework of existing institutions and arrangements for continuing highlevel political supervision the whole enterprise are the key requirements. Nor do the Nine oppose the basic American strategy of seeking to alter the supplydemand outlook by internationally agreed measures to reduce consumption, increase conventional energy supplies and spur research.

title: B VIRUS FLU SHUTS RURAL SCHOOLS
description: The influenza B virus is rampaging across the country hitting mainly children and causing school closings in many rural areas, the National Center for Disease Control has reported.

title: Despite a Big Constituency Across the Country, Wallace Keeps a Low Profile on Current National Issues
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 8 Gov. George C. Wallace went on statewide television for 10 minutes Wednesday evening to voice his sympathy for striking truck drivers and to urge Washington to solve the problems of diesel fuel price and supply in a hurry.

title: Major Housing Bill to Aid Poor Approved by Senate Committee
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Most Federal housing laws would be rewritten, by a $9billion omnibus housing and comntuniy development bill that the Senate Banking Committee has approved.

title: 3,147 Dogs in Westminster Show Today
description: The dog show fancier is an ingenious person.

title: RODINO PREPARED TO SUMMON NIXON; CITES HOUSE VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee said today that committee members would be shirking our responsibility if President Nixon was not personally summonedif deemed necessaryto answer questions on his conduct of the Presidency.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: America's 50 Safest Cities by David Franke (Arlington House, New Rochelle, N. Y., $8.95.)

title: Bucks Top Celtics, 9586; AbdulJabbar: 28 Points
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 10 (AP)  Kareem AbdulJabbar scored 28 points and retrieved 21 rebounds today to lead the Milwaukee Bucks to a 95.86 National Basketball Association victory over the Boston Celtics.

title: F. B. I. Seeks Pair Reported at Scene
