description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10The Federal Bureau of Investigation today linked two more persons to the kidnaping of 19yearold Patricia Hearst.

title: ALCOHOLISM SEEN AS SOVIET SCOURGE
description: MOSCOW, Feb, 10The Soviet Union is fighting a losing battle against its most persistent social problemdrunkennessa prominent Russian literary weekly suggests.

title: 260,000 MINERS STRIKE IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Feb. 10Britain's 260,000 coal miners abandoned the coalfields today in the first day of a strike that threatens devastating consequences for the national economy.

title: Corena Leads New Cast In Met Barber of Seville
description: Apart from Fernando Corena's worn but winning Bartolo, the cast of principals for the Metropolitan Opera's Barber of Seville on Saturday evening was entirely new; Rosalind Elias, Leo Goeke and William Walker were singing the roles of Rosina, Almaviva and Figaro for the first time in their careers at the Met, and Giorgio Tozzi took on Basilio for the first time this season.

title: QADDAFI BIDS PEOPLE IMPOSE ARAB UNITY
description: TUNIS, Feb. 10 AP)  The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el Qaddafi, today denounced Arab leaders who he said obstruct Arab unity, saying they should be swept aside by revolutions of the people.

title: Red Smith
description: It must have been comforting to Richard Nixon to assured, even as his popularity reached an alltime low in the polls, that no matter how the liberal press or House Judiciary Committee might feel about him, the latchstring would be out when the baseball parks reopened in April. Moreover, by inviting him to throw out the first pitch at the opening game in Cincinnati, Baltimore or Anaheim, Bowie Kuhn made it clear that Mr. Nixon would not be expected to pay his way in. This is no small consideration to a man who deducts a department store finance charge of $1.24 on his income tax return.

title: Most Restaurants Are Cleaner Than They Used to Be, Health Officials Report
description: The woman had arrived first. She was alone at a banquette table in the dining room of a famous midtown hotel when the man arrived. As he sat down beside her, he noticed her arm resting on the wainscoting behind his head.

title: Byrne Releases Reserves
description: TRENTON, Feb. 10Governor Byrne said today that he would release for public consumption a sixmilliongallon on emergency gasoline reserve that he controlled in the hope that this and the mandatory gasoline rationing program that begins tomorrow in New Jersey would end panic buying at service stations.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1974

title: Nils Olofsson Is Dead at 67; Wrestling's Swedish Angel
description: MYTON, Utah, Feb. 10 (UPI) Nils Phillip Olofsson, wrestling's Swedish Angel, died at his home yesterday. He was 67 years old.

title: ExLindsay Aide Takes Post
description: Thomas B. Morgan, who was press secretary to former Mayor John V. Lindsay, has been named vice president and assistant to the publisher of New York magazine, it was anInounced last night. Clay Felker, editor and publisher of New York, said Mr. Morgan would edit, write and assist in developing new publishing enterprises for the magazine. Mr. Morgan, who is 47 years had been a magazine journalist for 20 years.

title: Events Today
description: Film

title: JOHN WHITE DIES; A TIMES REPORTER
description: John W. White, an author and The New York Times correspondent in Latin America from 1931 to 1941, died Friday at his home in Hamburg, N. Y. His age was 84.

title: Nixon Will Fly South For 3 Public Events
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI)President Nixon will fly to Florida Wednesday for a series of public appearances in the South and a vacation in the sun at his Key Biscayne villa, White House aides said today.

title: RESTUDY WEIGHED ON GAS PRICE RULE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10Rhetorically waving a flag of neutrality, Representative Torbert H. Macdonald has hinted that he might hold hearings on amending the Natural Gas Act to let natural gas prices rise at the wellhead.

title: JERSEY MAN HELD IN FOUR SLAYINGS
description: A 24yearold Air Force veteran shot and killed his parents, an elderly woman neighbor and a 2yearold boy and wounded the child's mother yesterday morning in a 90minute shooting spree in Sussex County in the northwestern corner of New Jersey, according to the County Prosecutor.

title: LESSER CALENDAR OF FINANCING SET
description: With the Treasury Department's $4.05billion refinancing auctioned and behind them, credit markets this week are facing what amounts to a comparatively moderate corporate and tax  exempt calendar. An estimated total of $615  million of new corporate issues is scheduled to be marketed, including, on Thursday, $300  million of Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company AAArated debentures due 2014.

title: I.T.A. Gets Signed Pact From Jipcho
description: The International Track Association announced the signing of another amateur superstar yesterday, Ben Jipcho of Kenya.

title: KORCHNOI LOSS CUTS LEAD IN CHESS TO 21
description: Henrique Mecking of Brazil won his first point in the quarterfinals of the world chess championship yesterday when Victor Korchnoi of the Soviet Union resigned without resuming play in the adjourned 12th game of their candidates match in Augusta, Ga.

title: Two Down, 38 Berths to Go in Daytona Qualifying
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 10Hershel McGriff got up at 7 o'clock this morning, went for a mileandahalf run on the beach, switched to a 1974 Dodge, posted the fourth fastest time in trials for next Sunday's Daytona 430 (ne 500) and won 20 tires. It was a good morning for a 46yearold driver who had been retired for 15 years.

title: Gromyko to Visit France
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 10 (UPI)Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko will pay an official visit to France Friday through next Monday at the invitatation of the French Government, Tass, the official press agency, said today.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Nader Calls Fuel Scarcity Contrived
description: EDISON, Feb. 10A cartoon in the current New Yorker magazine depicts a wife at the breakfast table saying sternly to her husband over her portion of the paper, William E. Simon says you cannot continue to live your wastrel ways. While Mr. Simon may have made the consumer feel guilty about wasting energy, the truth is that the consumer uses less then 25 per cent of the total energy in this country, the Government about 5 per cent and industry and commerce the remaining 70 per cent, Ralph Nader told an enthusiastic audience of 1,500 here last week.

title: Arrested in Theft Of Million in Goods At Bronx Terminal
description: Nine men, including the ??wner of a supermarket in Queens, were arrested yester??ay in what the police said ??as the breakup of a ring reponsible for the theft of a ??ilion dollars worth of prod??ce from the Bronx Terminal Market in Hunts Point.

title: WILLIAM C. ALLEN
description: MISSION VIEJO, Calif., Feb. 10 (AP)William C. Allen, a photographer for The Associated Press for 30 years, died Thursday of a heart attack at the age of 60.

title: A Xeroxian Index of Doctoral Esoterica
description: In front of Philosophy Hall at Columbia University stands Rodin's The Thinker. It is university dogma that the Thinker is puzzled because he is trying to find a topic for his doctoral dissertation.

title: Ceremonies Mark The 127th Birthday Of Thomas Edison
description: EDISON, Feb. 10Wreathlaying ceremonies commemorating the 127th birthday tomorrow of Thomas A. Edison were held in the Menlo Park section of Edison Township today on the site of the inventor's first large research laboratory.

title: Agreement on Pact Averts Strike at 8 State Colleges
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 10 An agreement was reached here today in contract talks for faculty members at eight New Jersey state colleges, averting a strike set for tomorrow.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 37

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The fuel crisis has stirred up enough concern and aggravation for car owners, especially those of us whose cars are essential to our livelihood.

title: SYRIA AND ISRAEL RESUME SHELLING
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 10Syrian and Israeli artillery exchanged fire today after having been silent for four days, the military headquarters here announced.

title: LOCALITIES WORRY ABOUT A BIG SNOW
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 10Three typical New Jersey communities, this city, the borough of Highland Park and East Brunswick Township, reported today that they had enough gasoline on hand to run plow trucks and sandspreaders for a storm like last Friday's. But they were not so sure they could cope with a storm of more than 24 or 36 hours. As they pondered the situation, more snow was forecast for the state.

title: Behavioral Differences Stressed in Women's Management Training
description: In the role of Prof. Henry Higgins in My Fair Lady, Rex Harrison wondered why a woman can't behave like a man. These days, corporations obliged by law to hire and promote women into their previously allmale organizations often ask the same question.

title: Unions Slowing German Public Services
description: BONN, Feb. 10Unions representing West Germany's public employes, in a fight for higher wages, announced today a twoday slowdown in mail deliveries and a halt in trash collection and streetcar and bus service.

title: 7 IN CHURCH ROBBED OF CASH AND JEWELS
description: Two holdup men entered a church in Queens last night and, at gunpoint, robbed seven persons of cash and jewelry, the police said. Although the minister had managed to slip away for help before the holdup began, the men had fled before the police arrived.

title: Thomas F. Healy, 89, Dies, Built Collection of Prints
description: Thomas F. Healy, who built the T. F. Healy Collection of old prints and illustrations, died Saturday in St. Joseph's Hospital, Yonkers. He was 89 years old and lived at 561 West 141st Street.

title: Terence O'Neill Weds Barbara Kane
description: Miss Barbara Mary Kane, daughter of Mrs. Patrick Kane of Rye, N.Y., and the late Mr. Kane, was married here yesterday afternoon to Terence Patrick O'Neill, a New York restaurateur. Msgr. John Barry performed the ceremony in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A taxi driver was shot to death in an apparent robbery in Harlem early yesterday, the first medallion driver slain in the city since July. The police reported that Carlton Elliott, 40 years old, of the Bronx, was found slumped over the wheel of his cab on West 129th Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, at about 2 A.M. by local residents, who called the police. His wallet was gone but a safe the cab was not forced, the police said.

title: MRS. H. G. WELLINGTON
description: Mrs. Elizabeth Dutton Wellington, widow of Herbert G. Wellington, a former governor of the New York Stock Exchange and founder of Wellington & Co., investment hankers, died yesterday in her Upper East Side home. She was 79 years old.

title: Palestinians to Discuss Future of Gaza Strip and West Bank
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 10The leadership of the Palestinian guerrilla movement is to meet soon to consider forming a government in exile that would seek to take control of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip in the event that Israel agrees to evacuate them.

title: PartTime Political Jobs Cost State $2Million a Year
description: The state is spending more than $2million a year for 18 boards, commissions and authorities, most of whose members are political appointees who do little work for the state.

title: Bruins Win As Esposito Gets No. 47
description: BOSTON, Feb. 10 (UPI)Phil Esposito scored his 47th goal and 52d assist of the season tonight to lead the Boston Bruins to a 4.0 victory over the Minnesota North Stars in a National Hockey League game.

title: Lessened Prosperity Seen
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10Two major new analyses of the impact on the world economy of sharply higher oll prices have concluded that, for the United States, all depends on how the other industrialized countries react and how the new money flows involved are handled.

title: STATE AND JERSEY START RATIONING OF GASOLINE TODAY
description: Service station owners and motorists in New York and New Jersey braced for confusion today with the beginning of plansvoluntary in New York, mandatory in New Jerseyfor restricting gasoline purchases to alternate days.

title: F. Herbert Prem, 83, Dies; Lawyer, ExTrack Star
description: F. Herbert Prem, a leading admiralty lawyer, a counsel of and a former partner in the firm of Bigham, Englar, Jones & Houston, 99 John Street, died Thursday in New York Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 137 East 36th Street.

title: Iraq Reports Attack by Iran on Frontier
description: BAHRAIN, Feb. 10Iraq said tonight that a frontier clash early today with Iranian forces backed by heavy artillery and armor left 70 Iranians dead and wounded and caused 23 Iraqi casualties.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: State Treasurer Richard C. Leone said $244million of the $302million Hackensack sportscomplex bondissue funds had been invested and should yield about $17.4million in interest.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE SIGHTSEER. By Geoffrey Wolff. 272 pages. Random House. $6.95. In Geoffrey Wolff's The Sightseer, ideas are more alive than people. The author has a classy imagination, luxurious with metaphorsbrilliant, uptotheminute metaphors about the relation between life, death, love, art, truth and urgent things like that. He tries manfully to persuade his characters to embody these issues and in some scenes he succeedsbut more often not. This doesn't mean that The Sightseer is a failure. Though it is not a wellmade novel, it is a provocative speculation. Its form is like one of those advanced, openended courses given at certain colleges, in which the instructor fails to distinguish between his chosen discipline and his autobiography.

title: Alfred Mercier, 73, Dead; Canadian News Executive
description: QUEBEC, Feb. 10 (Canadian Press)  Alfred Mercier, a prominent Canadian newspaper executive, died here early today at the age of 73. Mr. Mercier, who took over management of Quebec Le Soleil in 1937 when it was at a low ebb, developed the daily into one of the most successful and technically advanced in the country. He was active in newspaper associations in Canada, including The Canadian Press, and was a former president of the national news cooperative.

title: $407,276 IN GRANTS TO GO TO COMPOSERS
description: A new program to benefit composers, opera librettists and translators has been started by the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Rail Service Restored
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 (AP) Full service on Penn Central's main East Coast rail line was restored today, after yesterday's derailment of 15 freight cars at Frankford Junction in North Philadelphia.

title: About New York A Sampling of Real Goldwynisms
description: Garson Kanin was talking about Samuel Goldwyn, and he was talking with authority. After all, he had first met Mr. Goldwyn, who died just the other day, in 1937. The great producer had stared at him for a long time, and then he said, Sidney Howard tells me you're a real clever genius. A Goldwynism, Mr. Kanin had thought, I've heard my first Goldwynism.

title: Jazz Group Hails Return of Clarinetist
description: MARTINSVILLE, Feb. 1.0 Bobby Gordon, a thin, wistfully shy jazz clarinetist who was one of the brightest stars on the New Jersey jazz scene before he moved to California two years ago, made a triumphant return to his old stomping grounds last night.

title: The Screen:' Last Detail' a Comedy of Sailors on Shore
description: "The Last Detail" is one superbly funny, uproariously intelligent performance, plus two others that are very, very good, which are so effectively surrounded by profound bleakness that it seems to be a new kind of anti-comedy. It's a good movie but an unhomogenized one."New" is perhaps a poor word to use in connection with the film. Like the recent "Cinderella Liberty," which was also based on a novel by Darryl Ponicsan, "The Last Detail" considers the lives of career United States Navy sailors with a gravity that recalls the atmosphere of the late nineteen-forties and fifties, when World War II was still freshly won, Korea was being brought to a close, and Ike was going to throw the rascals out of Washington. In the years that preceded the political and social upheavals of the nineteen-sixties and seventies, ignorance still possessed some innocent charm.It doesn't any more. It seems frivolous and a bit scary. So much so that I suspect that Hal Ashby who directed "The Last Detail," and Robert Towne, who wrote the screenplay, may have thought of their leading character, who is 20 years behind the times and only vaguely aware of the fact, as a lot more representative of many American lives today than the rest of us would care to think.This character, remarkably played by Jack Nicholson, is Signalman First Class Buddusky, a 20-year Navy man of hilarious and often unwarranted self-assurance. Buddusky and Gunner's Mate First Class Mulhall (Otis Young) are assigned to escort from Norfolk, Va., to the naval prison in Portsmouth, N. H., an 18-year-old sailor sentenced to eight years in the brig for trying to steal $40 in polio contributions."The Last Detail" is the chronicle of this journey, which takes the better part of a week and dramatizes the increasing desperation of Buddusky as he tries to show the young prisoner his (Buddusky's) idea of a good time. There's a desolate beer party in a Washington hotel room, where Buddusky gets the kid drunk for the first time and tries to cheer him up. "Think of it this way," he says in effect, "you'll get two years off for good behavior."In New York they crash a Nichiren Shoshu prayer meeting and wind up at a Village party where Buddusky tries to make out with a pretty, intensely serious young woman by talking about the romance of the sea, while she would prefer to talk about President Nixon or race relations.In Boston, on their last day, Buddusky and Mulhall escort the young prisoner to a sleazy whorehouse where they introduce him to the wonderful world of sex by paying his tab. This experience, with a girl who manages simultaneously to be dimly sweet and a no-nonsense professional, is what finally unhinges the prisoner who, until then, has more or less accepted his fate.Mr. Nicholson dominates the film with what amounts to an anthology of swaggers optimistic, knowing, angry, foolish and forlorn. It's by far the best thing he's ever done. If anything it's almost too good in that it disguises with charm the empty landscape of the life it represents.Mr. Mulhall, by being black and playing a man who is as reflective and steadfast as Mr. Nicholson is errant, is the one person who gives the movie a contemporary look. In World War II, black sailors seldom got out of the galley.Randy Quaid, who had a small role in "The Last Picture Show," is a marvelous foil for Nicholson as the ever-polite prisoner who, for a long while, refuses to share Buddusky's rage at the injustice of his sentence. Early on, he has admitted to Buddusky that he had had a scrape with the police before entering the Navy. Asks Buddusky professionally: "Was it in the nature of a felony or a misdemeanor?" Says the kid: "It was in the nature of shoplifting."Mr. Ashby persists in making comedies ("The Landlord," "Harold and Maude") that are never as funny as the treatments he gives them would have you believe. "The Last Detail" is his most interesting and contradictory so far. You'll laugh at it, not through your tears but with a sense of creeping misery.

title: Breed Honors Captured By English Fox Terrier
description: Ch. Sunnybrook Spot On, who has won 18 groups and eight best in shows since coming from England six months ago, was named best of breed yesterday in the fox terrier specialty of the Associated Terrier Clubs at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: Blazing Banner Best Irish Setter
description: Three glamorous longhaired dogs triumphed in national specialties at the Combined Setter Clubs of America convention yesterday at the Statler Hilton Hotel.

title: Harlem Boy Douses Fire But a Baby Brother Dies
description: A 4yearold Harlem boy put out a fire set by his 3yearold sister, but not soon enough to prevent the death of their infant brother early yesterday, fire officials reported.

title: Gasoline juggler John S. Edwards
description: ALBANY, Feb. 10For the last 10 days, a spare man in a tweed jacket has been worrying about running out of gasolinenot his own, but the millions of gallons that have been entrusted to his care, first under t h e F e d e r a l emergency allocation program and now under Governor Wilson's statewide rationing plan.

title: Ethnic Battle on Selecting Tenants Apparently Over
description: A bitter, ethnic dispute over tenant selection that has kept a new public housing project on the Lower East Side vacant for two years has apparently been resolved.

title: Provincial Capital in Cambodia Lives Almost Untouched by War
description: BATTAMBANG, Cambodia, Feb. 10 (Agence FrancePresse) The bustling markets and tranquil residential areas of this provincial capital in western Cambodia could almost make one forget that this is a country at war.

title: Inventory Control Urged By Menswear Retailer
description: DALLAS, Feb. 9Edward R. Stern, the new president of the Menswear Retailers of America, is very specific when it comes to defining his major goal this year.

title: Bridge: French Connections Help Make Slam Missing 3 Aces
description: A claimant for the badluck award of 1973, but generally voted most unlikely to succeed, is Rene Bacherich, who helped France win two world team titles and is reputed to be one of the slowest players on record.

title: PANEL ASKS GOAL OF FREER TRADE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10A panel composed almost entirely of former high government officials proposed today a new objective for the United States to seek in the forthcoming international trade negotiations.

title: 260,000 MINERS STRIKE IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Feb. 10Britain's 260,000 coal miners abandoned the coalfields today in the first day of a strike that threatens devastating consequences for the national economy.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Feb. 10Reggie Jones, the Newark boxer who was defeated in the 1972 Olympic semifinals in a decision booed 'round the world, is now a professional. He began his new career on Jan. 17 with a fourthround knockout of Carlos (Boomer) Stevens before 1,600 fans in North Bergen's Embassy Hall.

title: RODINO PREPARED TO SUMMON NIXON; CITES HOUSE VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee said today that committee members would be shirking our responsibility if President Nixon was not personally summonedif deemed necessaryto answer questions on his conduct of the Presidency.

title: Steel Makers Overseas Expect Record Quarter
description: PARIS, Feb. 10  The steel makers are profiting, as well as suffering, from the energy crisis, and even with threats of a drop in industrial production, many steel companies are looking forward to a record first quarter.

title: Joins Climbing Expedition
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 10 (UPI)Marty Hoey, 22 years old, a University of Washington student, will join the first American mountainclimbing expedition to the Soviet Union's Pamirs this summer. She is a Mt. Rainier guide.

title: How to Break the Nutrition Habit
description: PITTSBURGHAfter a deceptive threemonth lull, meat prices have again begun to climb. Choice grades of cattle have gone up 20 per cent in recent weeks and now sell for over $50 a hundredweight, just a few dollars short of the record prices reached last August.

title: Peace Corps or Africa: Who Benefits More?
description: MOPTI, MallJamie Wickens has begun to worry about something more abstract than the snakes, diseases and the heat that sometimes take a toll of the chickens he raises.

title: A CONTEMPT CURB IS URGED BY BAR
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10The Supreme Court has been urged by one of the nation's most prestigious legal groups to abolish the summary contempt power by which judges can send unruly lawyers and witnesses directly from the courtroom to jail.

title: STATE AND JERSEY START RATIONING OF GASOLINE TODAY
description: Service station owners and motorists in New York and New Jersey braced for confusion today with the beginning of plansvoluntary in New York, mandatory in New Jerseyfor restricting gasoline purchases to alternate days.

title: U.S. ENCOURAGES GASOLINE OUTPUT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI)The Federal energy administrator, William E. Simon, announced today that the nation's oil refiners could begin producing more gasoline if they had stockpiled enough home heating fuel to last the winter.

title: JERSEY MAN HELD IN FOUR SLAYINGS
description: A 24yearold Air Force veteran killed his parents, an elderly woman neighbor and 2yearold boy and wounded the child's mother yesterday in three shooting incidents spread over 90 minutes and 25 miles of Sussex County in the northwestern corner of New Jersey, according to the County Prosecutor there.

title: Questions
description: The members of the Senate Watergate committee have repeatedly tried to arrange a meeting with President Nixon at the White House. Since Mr. Nixon has consistently turned aside those requests, Senator Weicker, Republican of Connecticut, has now propounded eleven written questions to him that probe many of the outstanding factual issues in dispute in the Watergate scandals.

title: Dr. J, Newlywed, Helps Nets Triumph
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 10 The newlywed jokes started early when the New York Nets took the floor today against the Memphis Tams. The grapevine had sprea?? the word quickly around Nassau Coliseum that ?? wedding, in?? had been held. And when the milliondolla. ?? to make the starting lineup, you could almost hear the fans snickering over what married life was doing to their high, scoring idol.

title: Gail Denenberg Wins Golf on 71
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 10 (AP)Gail Denenberg of Middletown, N.Y., hot a twounderpar 71 and won the $100,000 women's classic golf tournament today.

title: Recital
description: Judging from the numbe?? young people in the aud?? ence for Martha Argerich' recital at Avery Fisher Ha?? Sunday afternoon and b?? the quality of frenzy in the?? ovations, the Argentine plan ist could become a cult figure hereor figurine, since sheis deceptively frail in appearance. Her program, in the hall's Great Performers series, consisted of standard virtuoso material, but she played it with an appealing musicality as well as tremendons technical facility.

title: Skylab 3 Crew Termed In Fine Medical Shape
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 10  The Skylab 3 astronauts were reported today to be walking well with only a trace of vertigo, eating like pigs and performing medical tests with flying colors.

title: Rangers Win, 42
description: Well, that's more like it. The New York Rangers bounced back last night from their Montreal mortification to beat the St. Louis Blues, 4.2, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Financial Solution Urged For Private Universities
description: LINCOLN, Ill., Feb. 10Dr. William J. McGill, president of Columbia University, warned today that it was absolutely necessary to the nation's future to find longterm solutions to the financial troubles of private universities within 10 years.

title: BIG ENERGY DEAL SET BY FRANCE AND IRAN
description: PARIS, Feb. 10 (UPI) France and Iran announced yesterday that they had signed a $5billion energy agreement, which the French Finance Minister, Valry Giscard d'Estaing, said was the biggest since the start of the oil shortage.

title: 7 SERVICEMEN KILLED IN MIDAIR COLLISION
description: COLORADO Springs, Feb. 10 (UPI)  Seven servicemen aboard an Air Force jet trainer were killed last night when their plane collided with a larger military jet and exploded in midair over a farmer's pasture.

title: Peak Grain Crop Planned; Could Check Beef Prices
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 10American farmers expect to plant the largest corn and wheat crops in history this spring, as well as a soybean crop only slightly smaller than last year's recordbreaker.

title: Oil Parley to Open Today; Limited Results Expected
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10Delegates from the world's leading oilconsuming countries agreed today on an agenda for the Washington energy conference beginning tomorrow.

title: Stage Unites Two Jones Generations
description: Nineteen years ago, James Earl Jones, then a 24yearold fledgling actor, came to New York from Michigan and watched his father, Robert Earl Jones, play the role of Joe Mott  a secondary character in The Iceman Cometh. He had come seeking two goals. One was work in the theater, the other was to get to know his father, from whom he had been separated since birth.

title: Navajos Who Pay No Tax Seek County Role in Arizona
description: ST. JOHN's, Ariz., Feb. 10  In the southern half of Apache County, the rallying cry has become no representation without taxation.

title: World Sugar Prices on a MerryGoRound
description: The international sugar merrygoround that helped carry the wealthier nations toward the brass rings of plenty and prosperity is whirling out of control.

title: Sports Today
description: BOWLING

title: Goldin Sees a Need to Cut Back On School and Hospital Building
description: City Controller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday that important projects such as school and hospital construction would have to be cut from Mayor Beame's $1.7billion capital budget because of a depletion of the city's borrowing power.

title: Green, With 65 for 341, Wins Desert Golf by Two Strokes
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. Feb, 10Hubert Green, the 27yearold golfer from Birmingham, Ala., who acknowledges that his name is not exactly a household term, took a step toward making it one today by winning the Bob Hope Desert Classic.

title: Hagerty in Hospital
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 10 (AP)James Hagerty, the late President Dwight D. Eisenhower's press secretary, suffered a minor stroke before being hospitalized two weeks ago, his son Bruce said today. Mr. Hagerty, who is 64 years old, is vice president for corporate relations of the American Broadcasting Companies, Inc. He was listed in satisfactory condition at Lawrence Hospital.

title: Jonathan Seagull Joins China's Enemies
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 10 Now that it is open season again in China for shots at the decadent, bourgeois West, ideological hunters there have turned their sights on that feathery mystic, Jonathan Livingston Seagull.

title: Canada Trade Surplus Up
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 11 (Canadian Press)Canada's merchandise trade surplus was $1.9billion in 1973, a rise of nearly $500million from 1972, Statistics Canada said today.

title: KISSINGER OFFERS 7POINT PROGRAM ON WORLD ENERGY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11Secretary of State Kissinger proposed a sevenpoint program of cooperation with other nations today as part of a truly massive effort by oil consumers and producers to overcome the world energy crisis and preserve the international economic order.

title: Yale Devises a Sickle Cell Anemia Test in Infants
description: A research team at Yale University School of Medicine has developed and successfully used a new test to detect sickle cell anemia in newborn infants. Such testing for the sometimesfatal disease has not been possible with existing screening methods.

title: British Rail Slowdown Is Halted Until Election
description: LONDON, Feb. 11The railroad engineers, whose slowdown tactics and sporadic oneday strikes have caused trouble for millions of commuters in London and southeast England, decided today to work normally until the general election on Feb. 28.

title: Byrne Opposes PATH Increase In an Apparently Decisive Move
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 11Governor Byrne will intervene in Interstate Commerce Commission hearings here tomorrow to urge that a proposed increase in PATH fares from 30 to 50 cents be rejected.

title: Illinois Guardsmen Go Home
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 11 (UPI)Gov. Daniel Walker deactivated today the 1,200 National Guardsmen he called out five days ago to help control violence on the highway during the strike of independent truckers. He said he had made the decision to send the guard home after checking with the police and weighing stations and being told that truck trafific was close to normal in Illinois following the weekend settlement of the dispute.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Plaza Turning Back Clock to 1907New Look
description: The Plaza Hotel's Green Tulip, a 1971 attempt to transform he hotel's traditional Edwardian Room into a trendy eatery with pink and green furniture and fake Tiffany glass, is about to be returned to its original state.

title: CHRYSLER PROFIT DROPS IN QUARTER
description: DETROIT, Feb. 11  The Chrysler Corporation today reported, a 12 per cent drop in earnings for the last three months of 1973, reflecting problems brought on by the energy crisis.

title: Israelis Wins 4th in Row
description: WASHINGON, Feb. 11 (UPI)The Israeli National basketball team trounced Catholic University, 9370, yesterday for its fourth straight victory on a North American tour. The Israelis outscored Catholic, 244, in the first seven minutes of the second half. They employed an intricate zone defense and used a fullcourt press to force Catholic into repeated turnovers.

title: Prices of Gold and Silver Reach Records in Europe
description: LONDON, Feb. 11  Gold and silver prices climbed sharply in extremely active trading today, reflecting widespread uncertainties about international currency values and the likelihood of continued inflation throughout the industrialized world.

title: The Pardoning President
description: President Lincoln's generosity of spirit can be found most notably in his treatment of Confederate prisoners and Union deserters. He took his role as Commander in Chief seriously, yet even during the war's fury bent military rules to save lives and rehabilitate men. In messages to Congress and the people, he pointed out that his proclamation of amnesty was amply justified by the Constitution.

title: For Migrant Workers in West Germany, Rail Station Is Social Club
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Feb. 4On Sundays the vast hall of the Frankfurt railroad station looks like a Balkan village under a roof. Its inhabitants are migrant workers, the displaced and lonely alien servants of Western Europe's economic boom.

title: Few Fans Attend Practice for Daytona 450
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 11There'll be a lot less of them this year, those speed freaks who follow the cars as closely as a slipstream.

title: In the Paperback Field, It's Getting to Be a Woman's World
description: When Helen Honig Meyer was a fledgling publishing executive in the 1920's, her family was afraid that strange men might make advances at her when she went on business trips. And so, she recalls, My sister said I should wear my glasses in the train because they made me look ugly.

title: Mrs. Sheehan Is Named to Cabinet Post by Byrne
description: TRENTON, Feb. 11Mayor Patricia Q. Sheehan of New Brunswick was nominated by Governor Byrne today to be Commissioner of the State Department of Community Affairs.

title: Film: 'Thieves Like Us':Production by Altman Illuminates an Era The Cast
description: When Bowie, a 21-year-old country boy serving a life term for murder; Chicamaw, a surly, one-quarter Indian, and T-Dub, an aging bank robber with a game leg, escape from the Mississippi state prison farm, they simply amble away across a field to freedom. The time is the mid-nineteen-thirties and the local newspapers, ever alert to the possible appearance of a new Bonnie and Clyde or Barker gang, report the break in the most extravagant and flattering terms.Throughout their short careers as bank robbers, Bowie, Chicamaw and T-Dub barely muddle through while the newspapers strain to create bigger-than-life myths. But Bowie, Chicamaw and T-Dub aren't very bright. Old T-Dub, who's supposed to be the most professional member of the trio, is so swept off his feet by his love for a frumpy beautician with burnt-blonde hair that he puts his real name on the license when he marries her.Robert Altman's "Thieves Like Us," which opened yesterday at the 68th Street Playhouse, is such an engaging, sharply observed account of a long-lost time, and of some of the people who briefly inhabited it, that I hope it doesn't get confused with other films that seem, superficially anyway, to have covered the same territory.I think of Arthur Penn's "Bonnie and Clyde" and Nicholas Ray's "They Live by Night" (1949), which, like "Thieves Like Us," was also based on Edward Anderson's 1937 novel. As fine as they were, this one is also an original work, limited only by the opportunities offered by the subject, and the style Mr. Altman has elected to work in.There's nothing elegiacal about "Thieves Like Us." Its feelings are expressed tersely. It seems to have been stripped down like a stock car, as if excess verbiage were another form of chrome finish. Nor does one get any feeling of victims cornered by society, which was one of the marks of the Ray film and a carryover from those thirties movies that possessed social consciences.The screenplay by Calder Willingham, Joan Tewkesbury and Mr. Altman closely follows the events and the tone of the Anderson novel, which was, of course, written in its own time, without being aware that it was, in effect, a historical novel.Like the Anderson prose, the film is lean, uncluttered, even though Mr. Altman's method is full of irony and contrasts. The radio is constantly commenting on the action, whether it's a ripely acted love scene from "Romeo and Juliet," which we hear as Bowie and Keechie, his girlfriend, from the roadside filling station, are making their first awkward attempts to have sex, or a wildly inappropriate "Gang Busters" program we hear as the bank-robbing trio is carrying out one of its capers.Bowie and Keechie are beautifully played by Keith Carradine, another talented son of John Carradine, and Shelley Duvall, the wide-eyed Houston girl who was one of the few delights in Mr. Altman's "Brewster McCloud." I would have thought that young love, especially doomed young love, was virtually impossible to simulate in movies these days, but these two succeed with immense humor and the kind of tact that denies easy sentimentality.All of the performances are quite special. Bert Remsen, who has been in other Altman films, though I must admit I don't remember him, is fine as T-Dub. John Schuck, as Chicamaw, is extraordinary in what I take to be the film's key scene when, near the end, after Bowie has improbably been able to spring him from prison, he turns on Bowie furiously for having succeeded in a plan that Chicamaw thinks Bowie is too dumb to have brought off.Society doesn't destroy these men. The Depression may have given them a push into their chosen professions, but they are, at heart, so self-destructive that I'm not at all sure they wouldn't have wound up much the same had they been farmers."Thieves Like Us" is not so perverse and witty as "The Long Goodbye," nor is it so ambitious as "McCabe and Mrs. Miller," but it is a more perfectly integrated work. It is full of things to think about, that hang in the memory like the details of a banal crime story on page 32, which, though read quickly, won't go away. Somehow you know that this happened.

title: Mackell's Defense Says Ludwig Testified to Avoid Prosecution
description: Defense lawyers sought yesterday to undermine the testimony of Frederick J. Ludwig, who asserted last week that former Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell had attempted to limit an investigation into a confidence racket in which members of his staff had invested money.

title: New York Tests System
description: A spokesman In Albany for the State Fuel and Energy Office, which is administering New York's voluntary sales program, said that early reports on the plan's first day gave reason for hope.

title: Secretariat's Lagging Fertility: The Attitude Is Wait and See
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11 (UPI)Secretariat has technically failed to pass his fertility test, but so far it has not bothered Mrs. Helen (Penny) Tweedy, Secretariat's owner, or the 31 other shareholders who paid $6.08million for breeding rights. Nor is it expected to affect his breeding career.

title: College, School Results
description: Colleges

title: Waldie Files for Governor
description: MARTINEZ, Calif., Feb. 11 AP)  Representative Jerome Waldie, a leader of the Congressional drive to impeach President Nixon, filed today as a Democrat candidate for governor in the June primary.

title: Steel Production Fell 2.1% in Week To 2,838,000 Tons
description: Steel production for the week ended Feb. 9 slowed down and totaled 2,838,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was a decline of 2.1 per cent from the preceding week and produced a production index of 116.3. By contrast output for the week ended Feb. 2 was 2.9million tons and an index of 118.9, the same as the preceding week.The weekly production figures follow:

title: Byrne's Environment Bill Allows Suits on Pollution
description: TRENTON, Feb. 11Fullfilling a campaign pledge to the state's environmentalists, Governor Byrne today introduced a citizen'srighttosue bill that is considered to be the most important piece of environmental legislation that will come before the Legislature this year.

title: Wilson Expanding Unofficial Campaign
description: ALBANY, Feb. 11  Governor Wilson's unofficial campaign will be stepped up next week and will spread into upstate areas, with fundraising visits scheduled for the benefit of Republicans in Rochester and in Utica. Thus far, Mr. Wilson, maintaining his political habit of decades, has been attending the numerous unsensational civicgroup outings here and in the metropolitan New York area that have contributed over the years to his reputation as a thorough professional.

title: March of Dimes Girl Dies
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 11 (AP) Lori Ann Wagner, 13 years old, blonde who sang her way into the hearts of millions as the 1966 March of Dimes poster child, died Saturday of kidney failure. She traveled more than 30,000 miles in 1966, appearing on dozens of telethons and in a movie with Sammy Davis Jr.

title: Yugoslavia Shows Surplus
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 11 (Reuters)Yugoslavia's balance of payments surplus was $330million last year, about the same as in 1972, according to the final figures released by the national bank. Reserves amounted to almost $1.7billion.

title: L.I. Supply Tight
description: MANHASSET, L.I., Feb. 11 Patricia Roth forgot. Her mind was wandering to such matters as work or family, neglecting the only vital issue in the metropolitan area these dayswhether her license plate ended in an odd or even number.

title: Raw Sewage Threat to Potomac Blocked
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 Only action by the Environmental Protection Agency last week prevented an outpouring of raw sewage from the District of Columbia into the Potomac River.

title: Lawyer Charges Agencies Twist Ecology Legislation
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10Federal agencies have developed a repertoire of devices for twisting environmental laws to fit their own purposes, a leading environmental lawyer cautioned colleagues this weekend.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11Alice Roosevelt Longworth, that irrepressibly witty combination of grande dame and enfant terrible, will celebrate what she calls her goddamn birthdayher 90thtomorrow in the cluttered mansion where she has lived to a tidy old age for nearly 50 years, and where a maid still draws the curtains at dusk.

title: Dresser Industries Is Offering $144Million for Jeffrey Galion

John V. James, president of Dresser, said the directors of both companies had approved a letter of intent to negotiate a takeover agreement.

title: EXREP. MERROW, OF NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: WOLFEBORO, N.H., Feb. 11 (AP)  Former Representative Chester E. Merrow, who served 20 years in Congress, died today in Huggins Hospital after a long illness. He was 67 years old.

description: The charisma of Digger Phelps, the basketball coach, and the charm of Notre Dame is at work again.

description: A weakening stock market shows up clearly in the charts studied by Wall Street's technical analysts. These men peer at as many as three dozen different indicators, ranging from oddlot short sales to trends in margin debt.

description: CHICAGO, Feb. 11The long period of indecision over choosing a superintendent of Chicago's police force, plagued by scandal and deteriorating public confidence, ended today with the selection of Deputy Superintendent James M. Rochford.

description: A 58yearold gypsy cab driver was shot to death last night in the Mott Haven section of the South Bronx after what the police said was a holdup attempt.

title: Year of Impeachment
description: Sooner or later, those in Congress and in the country who resist the case for impeachment of President Nixon will have to ask themselves the climactic questions: How much evidence is enough? What more is needed? The moment is rapidly approaching when the move to impeachment will require not new factual disclosures, but a dispassionate and convincing statement of the evidence already on record, and its real meaning for the Constitution and citizens of the United States.

title: P.S. 179 PARENTS DECRY CONDITIONS
description: Parents of children enrolled in Public School 179, a decrepit, 75yearold building at 140 West 102d Street, continued their campaign yesterday for a new school to replace one they contend is unsafe.

title: Elevator Kills Bronx Youth
description: Wilbur Neal, 15 years old, of 300 East 138th Street, the Bronx, was crushed to death last night while playing in an elevator shaft in his apartment building, the police reported. They said the youth apparently had been playing on top of the elevator when he slipped and fell between the car and the wall as the elevator began to move.

title: Vanderbilt Tops L.S.U. By 9188
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 11 (AP)Joe Ford and Butch Feher hit clutch free throws in the final 30 seconds of play tonight to give Vanderbilt a 9188 basketball victory over Louisiana State, the only team to mar Vandy's record this year.

description: ALBANY, Feb, 11The Republican majority in both Houses of the Legislature pushed through a measure today changing the date of the primary elections from June to September as Democrats argued that the measure was designed to help Governor Wilson win election to a full term.

title: Jersey Hails Plan
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 11It was like old times along Gasoline Alley todayalmost.

description: Construction of a privately financed horsebackriding facility with a 150horse stable, an outdoor instruction rodeo ring and an allweather indoor riding ringis to start next month in Willowbrook Park on Staten Island.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11 (AP)Dick Williams, who resigned as manager of the Oakland A's last fall, was formally barred today by a Federal Court from working for any other professional baseball team during the next two seasons.

title: Theater: Zany and Dirty
description: Tom Eyen is one of the zanier and dirtier of our playwrightsindeed his aptly named The Dirtiest Show in Town became the toast of the depraved and deprived in two continents. Now at the Truck and Warehouse Theater, Thursdays through Sundays, he is offering something called 2008 (A Spaced Oddity).

description: Most independent truckers appeared yesterday to have ended their 11day shutdown in protest against diesel fuel prices. But some pockets of resistance were reported. Details on Page 21.

Controls End on Stevedoring And Marine Terminal Work

description: Vince Matthews has given up climbing fences to train, but he has not given up the idea of reclaiming his spot as the No. 1 quartermiler in track and field.

description: ALBANY, Feb. 11A State Public Service Commission examiner today recommended a $126.9million interim electric rate increase for Consolidated Edison customers.

title: Chess: A Pair of Bishops Can Give Opponent a Royal Flushing
description: Bernhard Horwitz (1807 1885), a leading player of his day and an important theoretician who coauthored Chess Studies; or Endings of Games with Josef Kling, discovered that two bishops on adjacent diagonals aimed at a king position constituted a weapon of terrible power. Today we take that for granted, but the German master's contemporaries, if they took any stand on the question at all, generally favored the knight.

title: New Test Allows Viewing of Heart Attack Damage
description: A test that allows doctors for the first time to see the precise area of muscle destroyed by a heart attack in a living patient has been developed by a team of Harvard researchers.

title: Lefkowitz Is Studying The Financing of Irene
description: Louis J. Lefkowitz, New York State Attorney General, an. flounced yesterday that his office would conduct an investigation into the finances of the Broadway musical Irene.

title: Shell Kills 2 Boys
description: PITKIN, La., Feb. 11 (UPI)One of two boys playing with a 150mm, shell last night, fumbled the explosive. It fell, exploded and killed them. The victims were identified as Jerry D. Blanchard, 13 years old, and Crawford Willis Jr., 12, both of Pitkin.

description: Newt Summary and Index, Page 35

title: No Program on Rents
description: Mayor Beame's plea to the state for restoration of the city's authority to tighten rent controls would have more force if coupled with evidence that he had a credible plan for making existing controls more equitable or more effective in preserving and improving local rental housing.

title: News Club Admits Women
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11, (UPI)  The Pen and Pencil Club of Philadelphia, the oldest newspaperman's club in the United States, voted today to accept women members.

title: LIBYA TAKING OVER 3 U.S. OIL CONCERNS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 11Libya announced today that she was completely nationalizing three American oil companies in a severe blow to American interests in the Arab world, the Tripoli radio said.

title: Confucius, Target of Chinese Drive, Helped Provide Revolution's Ideology
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 11When Mao Tsetung was 10 years old, he tried to run away from home because he hated the drudgery of learning the Confucian classics by rote. By a conventional Freudian analysis, that incident 70 years ago might be called the starting point for the movement Chairman Mao has called into being to eliminate the last traces of Confucian influence in China.

title: Treasury Bills Rose At the Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11Yields on United States Treasury bills rose slightly in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of those shortterm securities.

title: Contract Awards
description: Standard Telephone and Cables, Ltd., a subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, announced yesterday receipt of orders valued at about $67million for one cable under the Atlantic and two under the Pacific Oceans.

title: Americans Losing Ardor For Investment in Korea
description: SEOUL, South KoreaThe bloom has gone off American investment In South Korea.

title: WHOLESALE PRICE OF SUGAR RAISED
description: Sugar refiners announced yesterday an increase of $1.40 per 100 pounds on the price of wholesale cane refined sugar in all marketing areas east of the Rocky Mountains, effective immediately. This was the second, ?? crease in a week and followed a rise announced on Feb. 4 of $1.15 to $1.80 per 100 pounds. Refiners in the East and Southeast raised the industrial price to $17 per 100pound bag, while in the Gulf, Southwest and Chicago areas the price rose to $18 a bag.

title: KISSINGER OFFERS 7POINT PROGRAM ON WORLD ENERGY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11Secretary of State Kissinger proposed a sevenpoint program of cooperation with other nations today as part of a truly massive effort by oil consumers and producers to overcome the world energy crisis and preserve the international economic order.

title: The Oldest Source
description: The rays of the sun are man's oldest and most dependable source of energy. They are also the cheapest. It is astonishing that oil had to reach its current inflated price in order to compel serious attention to solar energy.

title: Francis J. Ludemann, 71, Dead; ExHead of Manhattan Savings
description: PATTERSON, N. Y., Feb. 11 Francis J. Ludemann, who retired last year as chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Manhattan Savings Bank, died yesterday in Putnam Community Hospital, Carmel. He was 71 years old and lived here.

title: Theater Center Is Buying O'Neill Home
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Feb. 11The Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Center in Waterford will buy the Monte Cristo cottage where Eugene O'Neill spent summers here as a boy and young man.

title: HELEN M. TOTTY
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 11 Helen M. Totty, a noted rose grower and former director and secretary of the Horticultural Society of New York died today at her home, 41 Elm Street. She was 76 years old.

title: AudioVisual Spending by U.S. Cited as Potential for Abuse
description: The Federal Government spent $375million in the fiscal year 1972 on audiovisual materialsincluding television and radio spots and motion pictures and the two agencies most involved were the Pentagon and the United States Information Agency, according to an interagency study panel's report released yesterday by the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy.

title: Metals and Other Commodities Surge
description: The prices of gold and silver bullion for immediate or future delivery were bid up to historic highs on both sides of the Atlantic yesterday by nervous buyers fleeing from paper money and securities.

title: Prices of Gold and Silver Reach Records in Europe
description: LONDON, Feb. 11  Gold and silver prices climbed sharply in extremely active trading today, reflecting widespread uncertainties about international currency values and the likelihood of continued inflation throughout the industrialized world.

title: Lincoln's Birthday
description: Today is Lincoln's Birthday. Schools will be closed in New York, most of Connecticut and parts of New Jersey. Banks and most government offices in all three states will be closed. There will be regular mail deliveries and Federal offices will be open. Stock exchanges will be open and many stores will hold special sales. In the city, there will be no garbage collections and alternate side of the street parking regulations will be suspended.

title: Filth Avenue Arms Dealer Slain By Bandit, Who Takes 5 Pistols
description: The coowner of one of the country's most highly regarded arms outfitters, A. Theodore Tonkin of the Continental Arms Corporation, was shot dead in his Fifth Avenue gun showroom yesterday by a holdup man who escaped with five pistols and hundreds of rounds of highpowered ammunition.

title: Recital: Leontyne Price
description: It was Leontyne Price's birthday (her 47th, by most available references) and the audience at her Carnegie Hall recital on Sunday night had come in a worshipful mood, From the soprano's first sweeping entrance onstage to begin the event with a Handel aria, to the program's final group of spirituals, Miss Price could do no wrong, to judge from the cheers.

title: China Absent as Hanoi Opens Parley Attended by Russians
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 11 (Agence FrancePresse) China was conspicuously unrepresented today as the North Vietnamese tradeunion federation opened its third congress with delegations from the Soviet Union and other Communist countries as well as nonCommunist countries in attendance.

title: Quiet, Rural Sussex County, the Scene of 4 Slayings, Is in Shock
description: SANDYSTON TOWNSHIP, N.J., Reb. 11The chirping of winter birds and the faint tinkle of a delicate oriental bell today gave no hint of the violence that had erupted in a little red cottage here.

title: More Cunningham Tests
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., Feb. 11 (AP)The Carolina Cougars of the American Basketball Association said tonight that tests on Billy Cunningham to determine If a second kidney blockage operation was necessary had been inconclusive. More tests will be taken tomorrow.

title: Byrne Opposes 20c PATH Fare Rise; Move Apparently Resolves the Issue
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 11 Governor Byrne will intervene in Interstate Commerce Commission hearings here tomorrow to urge that a proposed increase in PATH fares from 30 to 50 cents be rejected.

title: First Budget Hearing Outside City Hall Held in Bronx
description: Mayor Beame and other city officials squeezed onto a makeshift dais in the Theodore Roosevelt High School auditorium in the Bronx yesterday and made a minor bit of municipal history  conducting the first city budget hearing outside of City Hall.

title: City Rewards Gilbert With Key, And He Announces Engagement
description: The Mayor nearly unhinged the publicrelations scenario by failing to show up, but Rod Gilbert saved the dayhis own day at City Hall. The New York Rangers' $175,000  a  year bon vivant announced his engagement to marry Miss Judy Preston of Tallahassee, Fla.

title: Substantial Raises Sought For 8,000 at Macy Stores
description: Local 1S of the Department Store Workers Union is seeking a substantial pay increase and a costofliving escalator clause for the 8,000 employes it represents in six R.H. Macy & Co. stores in the greater New York area.

title: Bill to Pay Campaign Cost Urged by Byrne in Trenton
description: TRENTON, Feb. 11Governor Byrne asked the Legislature today to approve the public financing of gubernatorial elections and thus eliminate the threat of political corruption in campaigns for Governor in New Jersey.

title: Advertising: A Growing Market
description: The scene yesterday was similar to that of hundreds of other advertisinggroup meetings held at New York hotels each year a cocktail party, a luncheon, seminar speeches and the inevitable questions and answers.

title: MRS. PERCIVAL WHITE
description: Mrs. Pauline Arnold White, widow of Percival White, with whom she was associated in the Market Research Company of America and later in the firm of White & Arnold, died Feb. 4 in Northern Westchester Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived on Shad Road West in Pound Ridge, N. Y.

description: Three major real estate operators denied yesterday that they had agreed to stop buying oil to heat their buildings, until the price was rolled back to the level of last Dec. 15.

description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11B. Gerald Cantor, an investment banker and art patron, has donated 127 sculptures by Auguste Rodin to three American art museums, it was announced today.

description: The Plaza Hotel's Green Tulip, a 1971 attempt to transform the hotel's traditional Edwardian Room into a trendy eatery with pink and green furniture and fake Tiffany glass, is about to be returned to its original state.

title: Arabs Reported to Plan Summit Talk This Week
description: CAIRO, Feb. 11 (Reuters) A sixnation Arab summit meeting is expected to be held in Egypt in the next two days to discuss Arab political action and the disengagement of Syrian and Israeli forces, informed sources said here tonight.

title: Jersey's Start Successful
description: TRENTON, Feb. 11Although nearly half of the service stations in the state were closed for most of the day because of low fuel supplies, those that were open proclaimed the first day of New Jersey's mandatory rationing program a success.

title: Gulf to Challenge Law Forcing Concern to Sell Some Crude Oil
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 11 (AP) The Gulf Oil Corporation said today it would challenge in court a Federal law that is forcing Gulf to sell part of its crude oil.

title: Earlham College Fills Post
description: RICHMOND, Ind., Feb. 11 Franklin W. Wallin, 49 years old, has been named the 10th president of Earlham College, the 127yearold Quaker institution announced today. Mr. Wallin, who will assume the post Aug. 1, is president of the Institute for World Order, Inc., in New York City, and has been on leave from his posts as dean and provost at Colgate University. He will succeed Landrum R. Bolling, who resigned last July to become executive vice president of the Lilly Endowment, Inc.

title: Now Cadillac Is Seen Ready to Go Compact
description: DETROIT, Feb. 11The Cadillac division of the General Motors Corporation will introduce a compact luxury car for sale as a 1976 model, according to auto industry sources.

Thus far, Mr. Wilson, maintaining his political habit of decades, has been attending the numerous unsensational civicgroup outings here and in the metropolitan New York area that have contributed over the years to his reputation as a thorough professional.

title: Notes on People
description: President Nixon plans to appoint John W. Warner, Secretary of the Navy, to be director of the National Bicentennial Commission, according to sources in the Pentagon. The newly established agency is charged with coordinating all plans, at the national, state and local levels, for celebrating the nation's 200th anniversary.

title: Most Truckers Are Back After 11 Days of Protest
description: Despite pockets of resistance from some drivers, the majority of independent truckers appeared yesterday to have abandoned their protest shutdown against higher fuel prices.

title: INSURGENTS KILL 139 IN PHNOM PENH
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Tuesday, Feb. 12In the worst shelling yet of this crowded capital, the Communistled insurgents rained artillery fire yesterday afternoon on civil. ians in crowded market and housing areas, burning out one entire neighborhood.

description: The $85,000 Bowling Proprietors Association of America's United States open bowling tournament got under way at Madison Square Garden yesterday and after the first 80man contingent had completed the first eightblock, Bill Spargo of Detroit, Mich., was the leader by five pins.

title: ShortHaired Pointer Wins Sporting Group at Garden
description: The topwinning sporting dog in America in 1973, Ch. Gretchenhof Columbia River, a German shorthaired pointer, became the first finalist in the 98th Westminster Kennel Club show, which opened a twoday run in Madison Square Garden yesterday.

title: Jersey Gasoline Plan Cuts Tension and Long Lines
description: New Jersey's mandatory plan for limiting gasoline sales to alternate days for alternate groups resulted in shorter lines and somewhat less tension at service stations yesterday, but New York's voluntary system produced spotty compliance and mixed reactions.

title: Nixon and Snooping
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 There seems to be little question that a military spying operation took place Inside the White House throughout much of 1971. Secretary of State Kissinger, Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Yeoman 1st CI. Charles E. kadford all have agreed that at least some documents were funneled from the White House to the Pentagon, although there is significant disagreement among them about how much important material was pilfered.

title: U.S., Discounting Peril, Backs SewageSludge Dumping Off L.I.
description: A Federal official, while conceding that some sewage sludge might be drifting up on the beaches of Long Island, said yesterday that the Government had tentatively decided to continue to allow the dumping of the sludge at sea because there was no other way to dispose of it now.

title: MRS. WILLIAM ROBBINS
description: Mrs. Christine Chapman Robbins, wife of William Jacob Robbins, botanist on the staff of Rockefeller University and former director of the New York Botanical Garden, died Saturday at New York Hospital. Her age was 84 and she lived at 301 East 66th Street.

title: Simon Sees Energy Quest Cutting Petroleum's Value
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The United States told the oilproducing countries today that the value of petroleum in the ground will fall over the next decade. One reason, William E. Simon, the United States energy chief, said in a speech to the international oil conference that opened here, is that the United States is developing new energy sources that will make it an exporter of fuels in the nineteeneighties.

title: Excerpts From the Opening Address by Secretary Kissinger at the International Oil Meeting in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11Following are excerpts from the prepared text of Secretary of State Kissinger's address today at the opening session of the international oil conference:

title: DEMOCRATS UNITE IN COAST ELECTION
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 11A Democratic party that is united and in focus on the governorship election this year was plainly visible beneath the maneuvering of candidates seeking endorsement at the convention of the California Democratic Council here this weekend.

title: Earthquake on Coast
description: PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 11 (UPI)  A mild earthquake rumbled through Pasadena and other nearby cities early today but apparently caused no damage. The tremor registered 3.5 on the Richter Scale.

title: 2 BIG BANKS CUT KEY RATE TO 9%

title: Markets Open Today
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges will be open today on Lincoln's Birthday, but will be closed on Feb. 18, Washington's Birthday. The New York Commodity Exchange, Coffee and Sugar Exchange, and the Cocoa Exchange will be closed today and Feb. 18. The New York Mercantile Exchange and Cotton Exchange will be open today but closed Feb. 18. Banks here, in the state and in New Jersey and Connecticut will be closed both holidays.

title: Liner Spruced for Sail to Doom
description: The dark and chilly public rooms of the doomed cruise liner Caribia, deserted for years, came back to life the other day.

title: G.M. Finds More Drivers Are Using '74 Safety Belts
description: DETROIT, Feb. 11 (UPI)Because of the starter interlock system on 1974 model cars, 55 per cent of their drivers are using safety belts, a General Motors Corporaton survey showed today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Tomorrow, Feb. 13

title: LIBERAL IS ELATED AT CONSERVATIVES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11A leader of the national campaign to impeach President Nixon discussed the issue with some conservatives at lunch today and found them talking like liberals.

title: Simon Sees Energy Quest Cutting Petroleum's Value
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The United States told the oilproducing countries today that the value of petroleum in the ground will fall over the next decade. One reason, William E. Simon, the United States energy chief, said in a speech to the international oil conference that opened here, is that the United States is developing new energy sources that will make it an exporter of fuels in the nineteeneighties.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Not too many people care passionately about clothes these days. Galanos does. Not only how they are made, what they are made of, how they look. All that's important, of course. But up there, where the atmosphere is rarefied and the emotion is intense, more is required. Caring is not enough. Any body can make a pretty dress. Well, almost anybody.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 35

title: Retail Sales in Rebound After December Slump
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11Retail sales rebounded last month after a sizable drop in December, preliminary figures from the Commerce Department disclosed today.

title: Mizell Declines to Run
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., Feb. 11 (UPI)  Representative Wilmer Mizell, Republican of North Carolina, citing family responsibilities, announced today that he would not seek the nomination for the seat now held by Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. a Democrat. Mr. Mizell said he would seek reelection to the House of Representatives from the Fifth District.

title: The Opera: La Gioconda
description: NEWARK, Feb. 10Outside Italy, Amilcare Ponchiela's La Gioconda has enjoyed an erractic popularity. It crops up periodically in this country, especially when there is a leading soprano willing and able to sing the title role. But it hasn't been heard at the Metropolitan Opera since 1968, and is but rarely performed in Britain, France and Germany.

title: SCOUT AND FATHER DIE DURING CAMPOUT
description: GRANGER, Utah, Feb. 11 (UPI)  Danny Page and Danny McAllister were the closest of friends and the two highestranking Boy Scout in their troop when they set out on a weekend campout designed to teach them emergency preparedness.

title: Canal Talks Could Trip Panama Chief
description: PANAMA, Feb. 10The Panama Canal issue, long a political asset for Brig Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera and his Government, now has the makings of a political liability, in the judgment of some of his close advisers, businessmen, Panamanian students and foreign diplomats.

title: Violent Inmates Are Isolated at San Quentin
description: TAMAL, Calif., Feb. 8The yard that is hidden behind the towering inner wall here at San Quentin Prison is nearly empty and everywhere there is the kind of quiet that usually sets the place on edge, but now there is not even the slightest hint of alarm. Up on the gun walks, behind the rolls of rusted barbed wire, the sharpshooters who sit in isolation watch now without their highpowered rifles. And down below, in the shack with oval windows the guards who always say that the time to worry in a prison is when the joint grows quiet, sip coffee and relax with an endless string of digarettes.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Elusive Snowshoe Rabbit
description: OPPENHEIM, N.Y.  Several wellseasoned hardwood logs were blazing in the fieldstone fireplace of George Tiedman's hunting camp in the foothills of the Adirondacks when Ed Feldmann of Albany and arrived there in early afternoon.

title: Examiner Supports A 9% Con Ed Raise
description: ALBANY, Feb. 11A State Public Service Commission examiner today recommended a $126.9million interim electric rate increase for Consolidated Edison customers.

title: LOOPHOLES SEEN INBAR ONWHALING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11An environmentalist organization has accused the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration of allowing illegal actions that further threttten endangered whale species despite an official Government policy of seeking a moratorium on commercial whaling

title: F.T.C. CITES CASES IN CURRENT DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission, announcing the disposition of 23 cases around the country involving misleading advertising, said the cases demonstrated the agency's commitment to monitor advertising on the local level.

title: City Health Post Is Filled
description: Dr. Pascal James Imperato, director of the Bureau of Infectious Disease Control and principal epidemiologist in the city's Health Department, was named First Deputy Health Commissioner yesterday. Dr. Imperato, a physician who is 37 years old, holds a master's degree in public health and tropical medicine.

title: Liner Spruced for Sail to Doom
description: The dark and chilly public rooms of the doomed cruise liner Caribia, deserted for years, came back to life the other day.

title: HANDICAPPED GET HEAD START ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The Office of Child Development has moved to put into effect a law that would allow thousands of handicapped children to participate in Project Head Start for the first time.

title: Harlem Woman Plunges 7 Stories and Survives
description: Deborah Walker, 21 years old, plunged seven stories from the roof of her East Harlem apartment building to a concrete ramp last night and lived, the police reported.

title: ADDONIZIO'S SON, 19, SEEKS PUBLIC OFFICE
description: NEWARK, Feb. 11 (UPI)Thomas C. Addonizio, the 19yearold son of former Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio, obtained nominating petitions today and said he would run for a City Council seat in the May 14 election. His father is in prison.

title: The $10,000 PoleVault Feud
description: The world outdoor pole vault recordholder has challenged the world indoor pole vault recordholder to a winnertakeall jumpoff, with the prize, in the range of $5,000 to $10,000, to be put up by the individuals themselves.

title: Lincoln's Birthday
description: Today is Lincoln's Birthday. Schools will be closed in New York, most of Connecticut and parts of New Jersey. Banks and most government offices in all three states will be closed. There will be regular mail deliveries and Federal offices will be open. Stock exchanges will be open and many stores will hold special sales. In the city, there will be no garbage collections and alternate side of the street parking regulations will be suspended.

title: In Ohio, Old King Coal Is Coming Back
description: ATHENS, OhioA gray stone farmhouse stands, lonely, in a field of brown and black muck, alien to what surrounds it.

title: GIRARD L. SPENCER, INVESTMENT BANKER
description: Girard L. Spencer, a limited partner in Salomon Brothers, investment bankers, since his retirement in 1967 as head of its government bond department, died Sunday at his home, 200 East 66th Street. He was 75 years old and had a home also in Tyringham, Mass.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The New Jersey Public Utilities Commission has set up a hotline telephone fore consumer complaints on utility mergencies, or other problems involving electricity, gas, water or solid waste collection. The number  (201) 6482350  will be answered round the clock, seven days week, but the commission stressed that it had to be used only for emergencies during nonbusiness hours and then only if satisfication could not be obtained by calling the utility first.

title: New York's Legislature Votes To Shift Primary to September
description: ALBANY, Feb. 11The Republican majority in both houses of the Legislature pushed through a measure today changing the date of the primary elections from June to September as Democrats argued that the measure was designed to help Governor Wilson win election to a full term.

title: 69% in Poll Give Congress A Rating of Poor to Fair
description: The Harris Survey reported yesterday that 69 per cent of Americans gave Congress a poortofair rating, according to The Associated Press. The lowest mark was for handling of inflation.

title: Study Finds Program for Handicapped in Disarray
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Feb. 11  Although almost $5billion a year is spent by Federal, state and local governments to help handicapped youth, a twoyear study by the Rand Corporation has found that the programs lack direction and coordination. Morever, the study shows that the programs fail generally even to identify those eligible for aid and inequitably serve those they find.

title: Putting Out a Fire
description: The Federal Cost of Living Council decision to reject the city's challenge of the moderate wage increases awarded to New York firefighters by a compulsory arbitration panel is right on the merits; it is also a valuable contribution to longterm labor peace in the municipal civil service.

title: LIBYA TAKING OVER 3 U.S, OIL CONCERNS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 11Libya announced today that she was completely nationalizing three American oil companies in a severe blow to American interests in the Arab world, the Tripoli radio said.

title: WEYERHAEUSER LIFTS EARNINGS
S.E.C.Proposed Rule Covers Short Sales and Registration
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed a new rule today prohibiting manipulative short sales of securities during the period when registration statements covering secondary offerings of the same class of security are pending.

title: Hospital Cuts Charges For Exceeding Controls
description: FORT PIERCE, Fla., Feb. 11 (AP)Fort Pierce Memorial Hospital is cutting service charges to pay back $86,000 that the Cost of Living Council says the hospital owes the public.

title: An Alley Cat at the Dog Show
description: He was roaming among the green seats in Madison Square Garden, high above the barking and bustling in the show rings below. His long, black hair was dirty and unkempt. His body was strong, and his face marked with the grim reminders of many street fights.

title: Dean Martin Jr. Indicted
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI)  Dean Paul Martin Jr., arrested by Federal agents Jan. 18 because of his collection of eight machine guns and an antitank gun, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury at Los Angeles for unlawful possession of firearms, the Justice Department reported. The 22yearold son of the television and movie comedian has been free on $5,000 bail since his, arrest by agents of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms.

title: Questions About That Spy Ring
description: Curiouser and curiouser grows the case of the young Navy yeoman who is accused of having stolen secret White House documents and passed them along to high Pentagon officials, including the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Adm. Thomas H. Moorer.

title: Dave Anderson
description: He's 36, an age when most men are content to jog, if that. But he's still a sprinter who shares the world indoor records at 50, 60 and 70 yards. When the International Track Association begins its second year of pro meets at the Nassau Coliseum Friday night, Mel Pender will be there with his reputation as the fastest starter. He'll also be there with his portfolio of psychology. Sprinter's psychology.

title: Industrialists Offering Cash to Miners
description: LONDON, Feb. 11  A group of British industrialists have offered to end the twodayold coal strike by paying, for a limited period, the extra money that the Government, which runs the mines, has refused.

title: Fifth Avenue Arms Dealer Slain By Bandit, Who Takes 5 Pistols
description: The coowner or one of the country's most highly regarded arms outfitters, A. Theodore Tonkin of the Continental Arms Corporation, was shot dead in his Fifth Avenue gun showroom yesterday by a holdup man who escaped with five pistols and hundreds of rounds of highpowered ammunition.

title: Market Averages
description: Monday, February 11, 1974

title: Gasoline Plans at a Glance
description: New YorkUnder a voluntary plan, motorists with evennumbered license plates will buy gasolines on evennumbered dates and those with oddnumbered plates on oddnumbered dates. A plate with letters only is considered an odd number. In months with 31 days, only the oddnumbered group would get gasoline on the 31st. There is no mandatory minimum purchase, though motorists are asked not to go to stations until their tanks are at least halfempty. The system applies equally to all outofstate cars. Dealers are asked to display a green flag if they are selling gasoline, red if they are not.

title: Sports News Briefs
