description: BRISBANE, Australia, Feb. 11 (Reuters)Tony Mundine, Australia's world middleweight title contender, took another stride toward the title tonight with a sixthround knockout over Manuel Fierro, a Mexican national who was born in the United States.

title: N.B.C. Chooses Saturdays For Major News Shows
description: The National Broadcasting Company has designated the Saturday evening hour at 7 P.M. for an extensive schedule of news programs that will begin on Sept. 14.

title: Trenton School Election Is Postponed to March 5
description: TRENTON, Feb. 11  The Appellate Division of State Superior Court today ordered this city's school board elections to be held next month within the city's 87 general election districts, rather than within the 27 school districts that were struck down as unconstitutional last week.

title: Stocks Slump as Trading Dips
description: The stock market finished at its lowest point in almost two months yesterday as prices slumped in continued light trading.

title: Senator Church Lists Income
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, listed today his and his wife's annual income as approximately $64,000. He said that they paid about 30 per cent in taxes.

title: 50 Big Leaguers Seek Arbitration
description: The Oakland A's, who have led the major leagues the last two seasons on the field, led them off the field as well yesterday as baseball's revolutionary salary arbitration hearings began.

title: Ad Review Board Gives Report
description: From the latest activity report of the National Advertising Review Board: three companies agreed to modify or discontinue certain ads and nine others had their ads reviewed and found acceptable.

title: Gorman Is Toppled, Van Dillen Scores In Toronto Tennis
description: TORONTO, Feb. 11 (AP)Australia's Ray Ruffels produced the first upset of the $50,000 Toronto international tennis tournament today, defeating secondseeded Torn Gorman of Seattle, 76, 16, 63. The event is part of the World Championship Tennis circuit.

title: Books of The Times
description: MY GREEN AGE. By Edward Weeks, 342 pages. Illustrated. AtlanticLittle, Brown. $10.

title: Two Presidents, and Eras of Troubles
description: WASHThGTON  Abraham Lincoln once told a Chicago audience that being President was no bed of roses, which indeed it wasn't. Mr. Lincoln was probably the most unpopular and reviled President up to his day. The press was almost unanimously against him, and in political circleseven in his own party many thought the country could not survive unless he was removed from office. Accusations of scandal and sinister motives against him and his Administration were commonplace.

title: BYRNE REVAMPING SPORTS AUTHORITY
description: TRENTON, Feb. 11Governor Byrne moved today to strengthen his control of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition with bill to a double the number of members that he would appoint.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Solzhenitsyn Disregards 2d Summons
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 11 Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn today refused to honor a second summons from the state prosecutor's office and told the authorities to learn to obey the law yourselves before asking citizens to abide by it.

title: ACTION REVIEWED ON BIAS CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11John H. Powell Jr., the new chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, says that he plans to review a recently adopted strategy of bringing sweeping charges against unions, companies and entire industries as a way of combating job discriminaton.

title: Judge's Feb. 4 Order for Nixon To Testify Is Still in the Mails
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11 (AP) A state judge said today he was speechless when he learned that an order he issued last Monday seeking, to subpoena President Nixon to appear in his court had not yet reached Washington by mail.

title: Wallace Faction Works to Elect Delegates to Party Convention
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 8 Seemingly alone amid the major factions of the Democrat is party, the followers of Gov. George C. Wallace are organizing to try to elect delegates to the party's first offyear convention In Kansas City in December.

title: I.O.C. Rule Disallows College Pro
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Feb. 11A professional in one sport is a professional in all sports as, far as the Olympic Games are concerned and Lord Killanin, president of the International Olympic Committee, said today he saw no likelihood of any change in this rule.

title: BYRNE PROPOSES ELECTION REFORM
description: TRENTON, Feb. 11Governor Byrne asked he Legislature today to approve the public financing of elections for Governor and thus eliminate the threat of political corruption in campaigns for Governor in New Jersey.

title: Marinduque Mining Plans A 5for4 Split of Shares
description: Directors of the Marinduque Mining and Exploration Corporation said yesterday they recommend that stockholders approve a 5for4 stock split at the annual meeting March 1 at Manila.

title: Jersey Gasoline Plan Cuts Tension and Long Lines
description: New Jersey's mandatory plan for limiting gasoline sales to alternate days for alternate groups resulted in shorter lines and somewhat less tension at service stations yesterday, but New York's voluntary system produced spotty compliance and mixed reactions.

title: I.O.C. Rule Disallows College Pro
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Feb. 11A professional in one sport is a professional in all sports as far as the Olympic Games are concerned and Lord Killanin, president of the International Olympic Committee, said today he saw no likelihood of any change in this rule.

title: FIGHTING FLARES ON GOLAN HEIGHTS
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 11Heavy artillery exchanges were reported today from the Golan Heights front, and military spokesmen here said an Israeli woman and a policeman had been killed and five soldiers wounded.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Four years ago, a 5foot6inch freshman came off the bench in the second half attempting to save Memorial High of West New York from defeat in a sectional game in the New Jersey schoolboy basketball tournament.

title: 4 Men Seized Here In Theft of the Bug That Bagged Them
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were listening to monitored conversations of four men and were watching them through a hidden television camera. Things were going according to plan  but suddenly the plot took an unexpected turn.

title: MILITARY DOMINATES UPPER VOLTA REGIME
description: OUAGADOUGOU, Upper Volta, Feb 11 (UPI)President Sangoul Lamizana appointed a Cabinet dominated by military men today.

title: Bridge: Players Landing in the Soup Should Consider the Depth
Scene of Sussex Slayings Shows No Hint of Violence
description: SANDYSTON TOWNSHIP, N. J., Feb. 11The chirping of winter birds and the faint tinkle of a delicate oriental bell today gave no hint of the violence that had erupted in a little red cottage here.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BRISBANE, Australia, Feb. 11 (Reuters)Tony Mundine, Australia's world middleweight title contender, took another stride toward the title tonight with a sixthround knockout over Manuel Fierro, a Mexican national who was born in the United States.

title: Ritchard Narrator For Gypsy Baron in Concert Version
description: When the Metropolitan Opera staged Johann Strauss's The Gypsy Baron about 15 years ago it wasn't much of a success, but evidently there are lots of people who still love this everfresh operetta: Town Hall was packed to the rafters for a concert performance conducted by Thomas Scherman on Sunday afternoon.

title: Miss Hearst's Father Says He Is Frightened by Silence
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 11 (AP)  The father of the newspaper heiress, Patricia Hearst, kidnapped one week ago, said today he was frightened by the silence of her captors but refused to believe she was dead.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: LEGAL CHALLENGE PLANNED BY GULF not think it was the Intent of Congress.

title: MOST TRUCKERS END 11DAY STRIKE
description: Despite pockets of resistance from some drivers, the majorsty of independent truckers appeared yesterday to have abandoned their protest shutdown against higher fuel prices.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, Feb. 11, 1974 Potation flied by:

title: WHOLESALE PRICE OF SUGAR RAISED
description: Sugar refiners announced yesterday an increase of $1.40 ?? 100 pounds on the price ?? wholesale cane refined sugar in all marketing areas east off the Rocky Mountains, effective immediately. This was the second in crease in a week and followed a rise announced on Feb. 4 of $1.15 to $1.8?? per 100 pounds. Refiners in the East and Southeast raised the industrial price to $17 per 100 pound bag, while in the Gulf Southwest and Chicago area?? the price rose to $18 a bag.

title: SHOP TALK
description: There is a new booklet available on the basics of sound diets and, while it's only 32 pages, quite an imposing array of talent went into assembling it.

title: Union Extremists Become British Issue
description: LONDON, Feb. 11  The focus in these early days of Britain's election campaign is on the extremists in trade unions, an issue bitterly debated today in the opening news conferences by Prime Minister Heath and the Labor party challenger, Harold Wilson.

title: Japanese Envoy Feted At Oregon Trade Talks
description: PORTLAND, Ore.Standing beside the speaker's table in the Benson Hotel, Susan and Peggy Takiyoshi faced the American flag and sang The StarSpangled Banner. The guest of honor, Japanese Ambassador Takeshi Yakusawa, and the crowd of 250 joined in strongly.

title: Fern Andra, Producer and Star Of German Silent Movies, Dies
description: AIKEN, S.C., Feb. 11 (AP)Fern Andra, who produced and starred in German films of the silent era, died in a nursing home here on Friday. She was 180 years old and the widow of Sam Edge Dockrell, who had been commandant of the Putnam Phalanx, a historic militia unit in Hartford.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Retail Sales Off in Britain
description: LONDON, Feb. 11 (Reuters) The seasonally adjusted index of the volume of British retail sales in January has been provisionally estimated at 110, a 2.5 per cent drop from the December level, the Department of Trade and Industry said here today.

title: Savings Bank Deposits Off
description: Savings banks in New York State had a savings outflow of $72million in January. It was the first January drop in deposits since a fall of $261million in the first month of 1970.

title: 2 U.S. Newsmen in Soviet Held Three Hours by Police
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 11Two American correspondents were held by the police for more than three hours today after photographing a demonstration by ethnic Germans demanding the right to emigrate to West Germany.

title: Botanical Garden Will Erect a SolarHeated Building
description: A $2million research, educational and administrative building that will derive most of its energy for heating, cooling and hot water from the sun, will be erected by the New York Botanical Garden at its Cary Arboretum in Millbrook, N. Y.

title: Thomas Hayashi, Partner In Corporate Law Firm
description: Thomas Toshio Hayashi, a senior partner of Whitman & Ransom, corporate law firm of 522 Fifth Avenue, died Saturday at New York Hospital. His age was 56 and he lived at 7252 141st Street, Flushing, Queens.

title: For a National Debate on Military Policies
description: Defense Secretary Schlesinger has wisely welcomed the idea of a great national debate on the Nixon Administration's new military policies. The increased defense budget the President has just submitted should make that debate a certainty, at least within the confines of the Congress.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State Kissinger proposed a sevenpoint program of cooperation with other nations as part of a truly massive effort by oil consumers and producers to overcome the world energy crisis and preserve the international economic order. His opening speech to the 13nation energy conference in Washington evoked mixed responses from the foreign ministers. [1:8.]

title: Jersey Hails Plan
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 11It was like old times along Gasoline Alley todayalmost.

title: IRAN CALLS FIGHT AN AGGRESSION
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb, 11 (Reuters)An Iranian military spokesman said today that border fighting yesterday with Iraqi forces had left 41 Iranian soldiers dead and 81 wounded.

title: 20th Century Fund Orders Government Secrecy Study
description: The Twentieth Century Fund announced yesterday its sponsorship of an 18month study of the problem of balancing the Government's need for secrecy in the interests of national security and the rights of citizens to information about Governmental activities.

title: WILSON APPOINTS L. I. PROSECUTOR
description: ALBANY, Feb. 11Governor Wilson today appointed Henry G. Wenzel 3d as District Attorney of Suffolk County for the rest of this year.

title: REPORTERS PANEL WILL SUE A.T. & T.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press has decided to sue the American Telehone and Telegraph Company to prevent lawenforcement agencies from obtaining newsmen's telephone records without their knowledge.

title: Basketball Rankings
description: The United Press International's board of coaches major college basketball ratings, with number of first place votes in parentheses, wonlost records, and total points:

title: Politics and Gasoline
description: Politicians in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are as confused and angry over the gasoline shortage as most motorists, but they have an added problem. They are being blamed for the long lines and the short fuel supplies at gasosoline stations. As a result, they are caught in a dilemma. On the one hand, they are confronted with what several politicians referred to as the ugly mood of the populace. We haven't got an insurrection but it's not far off, said Arthur Bergmann, the chief deputy county executive in Suffolk County.

title: ROCKET DESTROYED ON IGNITION FAILURE
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 11 (AP)An $18million Titan  Centaur rocket was blown up in space today when its upper stage failed to ignite soon after it was launched from the Kennedy Space Center.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: EXHOUSING AIDE DRAWS 3 YEARS
description: Denouncing Louis A. Reiter, the former director of the scandalridden $135million Municipal Loan Program, as a shakedown artist, Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts yesterday imposed a threeyear jail sentence and $11,000 fine.

title: Orr Visit To China Rejected
description: PEKING, Feb. 11Chinese authorities have turned down a proposal that Bobby Orr and six other National Hockey League players visit Peking in the spring to coach players on China's national and provincial teams.

title: Boy, 16, Murdered In Belfast Ambush; 5 Youngsters Hurt
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 11A 16yearold boy was shot dead and five youngsters were injured by hooded gunmen who ambushed a car here today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Grand Jury Hears Nassau Prosecutor

title: Strikes Cripple Transit in German Cities
description: BONN, Feb. 11Millions of West Germans were delayed in getting to work today as striking public service employes paralyzed masst transit in most cities.

title: Bethlehem Steel Plans Increase Of $180Million in '74 Outlays
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday it estimated its 1974 capital expenditures may approximate $450million against $270million in 1973. The company added that depreciation would be about $215million in 1974 compared with $196million in 1973.

title: Board of Education to Request $2.6Billion Budget for '7475
description: The Board of Education approved yesterday an expense budget request of $2.6billion for 197475, after adding funds to provide for an experimental program to help children with learning disabilities.

title: Impact of Devaluation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 11A year ago today, the United States formally devalued the dollar for the second time in 14 months. Two things stand out in the 12 months following that move.

title: Kettles Stops Tillman
description: Art Kettles of Asbury Park, N. J., unleashed a vicious body attack and stopped Jack Tillman of Mobile, Ala., in the sixth round of their scheduled 10round welterweight bout at the Felt Forum last night. Kettles weighed 146 pounds and Tillman 145.

title: ANTONIONI REPLIES TO CHINESE CRITICS
description: Sitting in a Rome rooftop restaurant last week, Michelangelo Antonioni shrugged off continuing Chinese Government attacks on his television documentary, China. He quietly explained: They are obviously upset because it wasn't a propaganda film, but absolutely no prior conditions were imposed on the production. If they had been, I wouldn't have done it.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: JAZZ A planeload of New Orleans jazz talent is arriving in town, and the cargo is going to be displayed at Carnegie Hall, 57th Street and Seventh Avenue (CI77459), at 8 tonight. Among the goodies coming in are Ronnie Kole with trio, Louis Cottrell and the Heritage Jazz Band, the Onward Brass Band and Blanche Thomas and Mr. Kole's Lamplighter Marching Club. This is a onceonly MardiGras show here, and it is being wrapped up as a benefit for the Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center.

title: U.S. Bar to Soviet Ships in San Diego Stirs Port Officials to Seek an Inquiry
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 11  Officials of the Port of San Diego are seeking a Congressional inquiry into the Government's refusal to allow Soviet merchant ships to enter the harbor and naval base here.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mayor Beame urged that New York State voters be given the opportunity on next November's ballot of deciding whether they want to spend $20million a year, for possibly up to 50 years, on an additional 10,000 publichousing apartments.

title: Orr's Proposed Visit To China Is Rejected
description: PEKING, Feb. 11Chinese authorities have turned down a proposal that Bobby Orr and six other National Hockey League players visit Peking in the spring to coach players on China's national and provincial teams.

title: People and Business
description: BroadwayHale Stores, Inc., whose chain includes such famous names as The Emporium; Holt, Renfrew; NeimanMarcus and Bergdorf Goodman, decided yesterday to change its own name for the first time since 1951. The new appelation, Carter Hawley Hale Stores, Inc., will more closely identify the company's principal executives  Edward C. Carter, board chairman, Philip M. Hawley, president and Prentice C. Hale, executive committee chairman.

title: Basketball Rankings COACHES' POLL
description: The United Press International's board of ?? major college basketball ratings, with number of first place votes in parentheses, wonlost records, and total points:

title: E.P.A. Tests Tied to Sales Decline for Japan's Mazda
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11 The Mazda, the Japanesebuilt small car powered by the revoIutionary rotary enginewhich promised an edge over piston engines in the battle to reduce pollutionrode into the American automobile market in 1970 with seemingly perfect timing. Sales soared.

title: Hackensack Talks Resume
description: Hackensack, Feb. 11 (AP)Hackensack's firemen met with city officials today in an attempt to resolve their labor dispute. The firemen have been without a contract for more than two years.

title: Beame Asks State Funds For LowIncomeHousing
description: Mayor Beanie urged yesterday that the state spend additional $20million a year, for possibly up to 50 years, to subsidize the construction of an additional 10,000 lowincome, publichousing apartment units.

title: British Architect and Official Get 5 Years in Bribe Case
description: LEEDS, England, Feb. 11 (UPI)A former international architect and a senior civil servant were sentenced today to five years in prison in a case involving gifts by the architect to influence the civil servant's conduct.

title: Technicals Help 76ers Top Hawks
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 11 (AP)Tom Van Arsdale scored 35 points tonight to spark the Philadelphia 76ers to a 11695 National Basketball Association victory over the Atlanta Hawks.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Hark! Said Mr. Lincoln
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 115:03 P.M.There was a note on my desk. Meet me in Lafayette Square at midnight, it said. It was signed A. Lincoln.

title: PRICES DECLINE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange plunged yesterday in stepped tip trading. Prices also fell in the overthecounter market but volume was up somewhat.

title: Flames Set Back Islanders
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 12  One of the most flamboyant plays in hockey occurs when the goalie leaves his net to race an opposing forward for the puck. If the goalie loses the race, it's almost a sure goal, so it takes experience and good judgment to venture away from the crease.

title: Research Study Finds More Than $24Million Is in the Hands of Political Candidates and Committees
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 At the turn of 1974, with formal political election activity at a standstill, more than $24million was piled up and waiting in party and candidate treasuries, a bipartisan research and lobbying group reported today.

title: Demand for Silver Coins Sends Futures Prices Up $100 a Bag
description: A frenzied rush to buy silver coin futures sent prices up the daily permissible limit of $100 for a bag of $1,000 face value on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday.

title: Japan Gets Tightening Of Monetary Controls
description: TOKYO, Feb. 12 (AP)Finance Ministr Takeo Fukoda said today he would selectively tighten monetary controls to squeeze out any excess liquidity that may remain in Japan's economy.

title: INDIANS ON COAST UPHELD IN FISHING
description: TACOMA, Wash, Feb. 12Federal District Judge George H. Boldt ruled here today in a longawaited decision that Washington State fishing regulations were unlawful when applied to 14 western Washington Indian tribes.

title: Colombia Looks to Queens For a Key to Her Election
description: In Chapinerito, it's a friendly election campaign. The only party that may stir up trouble is Emilia.

title: Transcript of Tape Recording of Patricia Hearst's Voice Broadcast by Radio Station KPFA
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 12 (UPI)Following is a transcript of a tape recording of Patricia Hearst's voice as broadcast today by Berkeley radio station KPWA. The recording was sent to her father Randolph A. Hearst, the publisher, by the Symbionese Liberation Army.

title: ABRAHAM KRANTZ
description: Abraham Krantz, who had operated a realestate business in Bronxville for 45 years, died yesterday at his home, 3800 Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx. He was 85 years old.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Soviet Trials Unfair, Author Says in Gulag
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 12Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn today made available a 1968 section of his vast study of the Soviet penal system, contending that even in recent years it has been impossible to get a fair trial in cases involving state or ideological interests of Soviet leaders.

title: SQUIRE CHARGED WITH EYECUTION
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 12 A jury in Middlesex County Court here was told today that Clark D, Squire, a 35yearold alleged member of the Black Liberation Army, executed Trooper Werner Foerster of the state police in a shootout on the New Jersey Turnpike near here last May 2.

title: ALBERT BROWN
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 12Albert Brown, a retired advertising executive, died yesterday at his home here. He was 70 years old.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Cleveland Plays Mahler With Superlative Style
description: Anyone who harbored suspicions that the Cleveland Orchestra might go into serious decline after the death of its musical director, George Szell, must have had those qualms soothed at Carnegie Hall on Monday night. Lorin Maazel, who is in his second season as Mr. Szell's successor, led the orchestra in a concert that left no doubt that Cleveland still has one of the world's magnificent symphonic ensembles.

title: Jersey Gives Exemptions
description: TRENTON, Feb. 12While most New Jersey motorists struggle with the rules of the state's new mandatory gasoline sales restriction program, few are carrying printed stater cards that exempt them from any restrictions.

title: Sacred Bugs
description: When Big Brother listens, it is illegal to take away his hearing aid. That seems the only tenable conclusion to be drawn from the experience of Paul Castellano and three business associates who discovered a telephone bug and a television camera secretly installed in their office. When agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, angered at finding themselves cut off, learned that the camera had been destroyed and the bug removed, they arrested the four men on charges of conspiracy and theft of Government property.

title: Knicks Win As Braves' Rally Fails
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 12  Butfalo's fourthquarter lightrling didn't strike the Knicks a secand time in two games.

title: 2 in Plane Crash Identified
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 12 (UPI)Two men who were lost when their twinengine air taxi crashed Sunday off the island of St. Thomas were identified today as George Cooper of Newburgh, N. Y., the pilot, and Bernard Eusebe of St. Thomas. The North Cay Airways plane was flying to St. Thomas when it disappeared.

title: Notes on People
description: President Nixon will nominate Carla Anderson Hills, Los Angeles lawyer, to be assistant attorney general in charge of the Justice Department's civil division, White House press secretary Gerald L. Warren said yesterday. Mr. Warren said that Mrs. Hills will be the first woman to hold the rank of an assistant attorney general since Woodrow Wilson appointed Annette Abbot Adams and Mabel Walker Willebrandt in the early twenties.

title: Killing of Alabama Prisoner Is Disputed
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 12A newspaper publisher who is serving on an ad hoc citizens committee hearing grievances of Alabama prison inmates said today that the leader of a prison riot was not shot to death, as prison authorities have contended, but was stabbed to death, probably after the riot had been quelled.

title: Dance
description: For the third and new program of its run through Sunday at the Lyceum Theater, the Alvin Nickolais Dance Theater lat night presented Somniloquy, Foreplay and Scenario. All three works were created, in the fullest sense, by Mr. Nikolais, and this particular bill may be the best of the season.

title: San Clemente Concerned For Safety of Nixon Bust
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Feb. 12 The safety of an $8,000 bronze bust of San Clemente's leading citizen, Richard M. Nixon, has become a matter of growing concern, and considerable bickering, among some of the President's West Coast neighbors and fellow townsmen.

title: Dtente and Dissidence
description: THE HAGUEThere are two theories about the effect of dtente on dissident opinion in Communist East Europe. One estimates that as tensions slowly ease and there is a relative increase in contacts between that area and the West, the amount and degree of dissent against prevailing authoritarian rule will lessen because the political system itself will become relatively softer.

title: Democrats Are Favored In Special Queens Races
description: The contests for a State Senate seat and for an assembly seat in special elections in Queens tomorrow have developed into a captains' war, with the regular Democratic organization favored to retain both seats.

title: 2D INDICTMENT SEEN IN INQUIRY ON HUGHES
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 12Government sources here said today that they expected work to be completed by the end of the week on a new indictment naming Howard R. Hughes in an alleged stock fraud case.

title: Mets Sign Harrelson, Koosman
description: Bud Harrelson and Jerry Koosman signed their contracts yesterday, leaving the New York Mets with 11 players unsigned.

title: 91 Shot Wins as Garden State Opens
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Feb. ha 12Garden State Park opened the earliest racing season ever in this state today with an upset in the Betsy Ross, a sixfurlong sprint for 3yearold fillies worth $26,600.

title: Rhapsody Turns 50 On 42d St.
description: Fifty years ago yesterday Olin Downes, then music critic of The New York Times, went to Aeolian Hall here to listen to a new work by a young American composer. In his review he wrote:

title: NET UP 14% IN '73 AT GENERAL TEL
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation reported yesterday highs in telephone revenues, manufacturing sales and net income for 1973.

title: Library Can Seat 1,200
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo. (UPI)The new $3million general library at the University of MissouriKansas City can seat 1,200 people.

title: Cosmos 632 Launched
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 12 (AP)The Soviet Union launched today Cosmos 632, the latest earth satellite in the unmanned Cosmos series, Tass, the official press agency, reported. Tass said that the satellite was functinning normally. The secrete Cosmos series covers a wide variety of Soviet experimental satellites, from weapons systems to weather forecasting equipment.

title: About New York
description: A young woman who frequently poses for a promment artist wandered into a gallery the other day to see an exhibition of the artist's paintings. While she was there, a man walked up to her in some agitation and asked if the portrait of a nude on the opposite wall wasn't in fact a portrait of her. She said it was, and the man said that he had once bought it, but that he had been unable to meet the payments to the gallery, and so he had returned it. He said he had missed it ever since.

title: Business Briefs
description: DENVER, Feb. 12 (UPI)Four major petroleum companiesthe Atlantic Richfield Company, Ashland 011, Inc., the Oil Shale Corporation and the Shell Oil Companytoday submitted a joint bid of $117million to develop vast tracts of buried oil shale in western Colorado.

title: PROFITS DECLINE AT GOODYEAR TIRE
description: The two leaders of the rubber and paper industries  the Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company and the International Paper Company  reported results yesterday for the final quarter and all of 1973. International Paper showed sharply higher sales and earnings for. both periods, while Goodyear Tire & Rubber had lower earnings despite record sales.

title: 54 HURT IN BLAST OF FREIGHT CARS
description: ONEONTA, N. Y., Feb. 12Five derailed freight cars carrying liquid propane gas blew apart here today in a series of thunderous explosions that sent parts of the cars hundreds of feet through the air and left 54 persons, most of them firemen, injured from burns and fractures.

title: MANILA REPORTS SAVAGE FIGHTING
description: MANILA, Feb. 12The Government said today that there had been savage fighting between Government battalions and hundreds of Moslem rebels in the last week in the large Sulu and Cotabato areas in the far south. Casualties are believed heavy on both sides and it was reported that the number of displaced civilians could reach half a million.

title: Corporate Bond Prices Edge Up As Holiday Cuts Trade Volume
description: Corporate bond prices were marked up slightly yesterday, but most of the credit market was closed for Lincoln's Birthday and the increases weren't considered significant.

title: MAURICE PARKER
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 12Maurice Parker, lawyer and real gestate developer, died late yesterday at the Shadyside Hospital here. He was 57 years old, and a resident of Pittsburgh.

title: U.S. Jury Studying VoteSiphon Case
description: A Federal grand jury in the Eastern District of New York has begun investigating the alleged Republican votesiphoning scheme for possible violaitons of the mail fraud statutes, sources close to the investigation said yesterday.

title: Axes in the Groves of Academe
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.In a recent television film, Tom Courtenay, playing a missionary priest, inadvertently antagonized a remote Indian tribe by praising education as a bridge to the outside world. Within a year, though, the priest had come to share the tribe's feeling that ethnic and cultural solidarity more than compensated for totemism, ignorance, poverty and disease. So when he was stricken by one of those painless terminal diseases so popular since Love Story, he put out to sea in a fishing boat to die, and was buried a member of the tribe.

title: A Watergate Wife Tries to Look Ahead
description: LOS ANGELESGail Nicholas Magruder is a slender woman of 35 with soft brown hair and hazel eyes. These days the eyes are more likely to be thoughtful than to sparkle the way they did the day five years ago, when she and her husband stood on the balcony of a magnificant beach house in Malibu, guests of honor at a farewell party.

title: Vietnamese Are Continuing Their Prisoner Exchange
description: Feb. 12 (UPI)South Vietnam and the Vietcong continued prisoner exchanges today.

title: Electricity Bills Rise 12.7% Because of Added Oil Cost
description: The Consolidated Edison Company announced yesterday that its average residential customer would pay $2.23 more this month, or 12.7 per cent, more than in January, for the same amount of electricity because of sharply increased costs of the oil the utility burned.

title: General Signal Unit Closes
description: MANCHESTER, Conn., Feb. 12 (AP)  The Iona division of the General Signal Corporation of New York will phase out operations over the next six months because of continued heavy operating losses. according to a spokesman. The closing will effect 440 local employes, the spokesman said.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The wining New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Gas Station Throws in Towel, Is Serving Everybody in Line
description: Sal Teta, partner in a Mobil service station near Borough Hall, in downtown Brooklyn, emerged from the second day of oddeven gasoline sales yesterday with an upset stomach and a deep distaste for being an enforcement officer for the new voluntary system.

title: Udall's Mother Dies
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 12 (AP) Mrs. Louise Lee Udall, mother of Representative Morris K. Udall, Democrat of Arizona, and former Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall, died, yesterday. She was 81 years, old.

title: Anna Q. Nilsson, Swedish Star In Many Early Films, Dies at 85
description: HEMET, Calif., Feb. 12 (AP) Anna Q. Nilsson, Swedishborn film actress, died yesterday in Hemet Convalescent Hospital, where she had been living for about a year. The hospital gave her age as 85 and said there were believed to be surviving relatives in Sweden.

title: Amid Ashes in Phnom Penh, Stunned Survivors Go On
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 12In a leveled place where several hundred wooden nouses on stilts once stood, dazed people wandered through the drifting ashes today, searching for missing relatives who are probably dead. When they found bodies they moaned as they burned them on little pyres on the spot because they own so little that they cannot afford to take their dead to pagodas for proper Buddhist cremation.

title: Wilson to Seek Increase In State Gasoline Supply
description: Governor Wilson said yesterday that he would fly to Washington today to appeal to William E. Simon, the Federal Energy Office administrator, for more gasoline for the state's motorists.

title: Rangel Says the Black Caucus in Congress Grows Sophisticated
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12Shortly after he was elected chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus recently, Representative Charles B. Rangel said he received a visit from a black representative of the Gulf Oil Corporation.

title: U.S. Agency Finds No Excessive Profit In Soviet Grain Deal
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12The General Accounting Office has found no evidence of excessive profits for grain companies in the big 1972 wheat sales to the Soviet Union, but those deals did give the concerns opportunities to make unusual profits on other business, the agency says in a report to be released tomorrow.

title: Books of The Times
description: A WOMAN IN ME SKY. By James Hanley. 224 pages. Horizon Press. $6.95.

title: GREATER FREEDOM PROMISED IN SPAIN
description: MADRID, Feb. 12Premier Carlos Arias Navarro today promised Spaniards wider and freer participation in government and union affairs than they have known in the 35 years since the Civil War.

title: A PLOT TO KILL PERON REPORTED
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 12The Argentine police announced tonight that they had foiled a terrorist attempt to assassinate President Juan D. Pern, his wife and the visiting President of Uruguay, Juan M. Bordaberry.

title: Five Cars of Amtrak Train Derail in Nebraska
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) Five cars of a San FranciscotoChicago passenger train derailed tonight, sending about 17 passengers to the hospital, Amtrak said. The derailment took place at 7:40 p.m. 33 miles west of McCook, Neb.

title: 7 RUSSIANS MAKE FORCIBLE ARREST OF SOLZHENITSYN
description: MOSCOW, Wednesday Feb. 13Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the dissident novelist, who once declared he was prepared to face even death to promote the cause of truth, was forcibly Arrested yesterday by a team of Soviet police agents.

title: British Miners Unmoved by Industrialists' Offer
description: LONDON, Feb. 12A plan to tempt Britain's striking coal miners back to work by supplementing their wages with private donations was rejected today by the National Union of Mineworkers.

title: Gulf Oil Profit Rose 153% in 4th Quarter
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation yesterday announced operating results for 1973. The report indicated a 153 per cent gain in fourthquarter earnings. Net income for the full year climbed to $800million, ending a fouryear slide in profitability.

title: Iraq Asks Meeting Of Security Council On Border Clashes
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 12 (UPI)Iraq has asked for an urgent meeting of the Security Council to deal with the border dispute with Iran that brought fighting this week, a United Nations spokesman announced today.

title: Subpoena for President Finally Arrives; Was Mailed From California 8 Days Ago
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 12 (AP)A subpoena ordering President Nixon's appearance in a Los Angeles court finally got to the right place today the clerk of the District of Columbia Superior Court.

title: ERVIN UNIT DECLINED TO CHECK ON SPYING
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 12Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. said here tonight that his Senate Watergate committee had received information about spying activities allegedly conducted by the office of the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, but had acceded to a White House request to refrain from investigating them.

title: Phone Services Under Scrutiny
description: Over a span of 40 years the New York Telephone Company had built a structure of rates and services that had prompted little close examination or criticism, Rates had been fairly stable, and there seemed little need for consumer pressure. In 1969, all that changed, as service in New York City and the surrounding area became increasingly erratic, New and urgent questions arose as businesses lost customers as a result of poor phone service and as residential users encountered long delays in getting dial tones, reached wrong numbers too often, got faulty bills and in general leveled a barrage of complaints.

title: Kissinger as Economist
description: Secretary of State Kissinger, whose critics accuse him of not knowing much economics, had a solid and sophisticated economic brief for this week's energy conference in Washington. Mr. Kissinger is generally hailed as a disciple of such masters of political expediency as Machiavelli, Metternich and Bismarck. But he went before the current congress of wary and apprehensive ministers from major oilconsuming nations as a student of the Italian economist, Vilfredo Pareto (18481923)author of the concept that optimum economic efficiency is attained when no one can he made better off without making someone else worse off.

title: It's an Energy Crisis Every Day for Vickie Seller
description: Vickie Seller, a pintsized girl with flaming red hair, let out a mansized yell yesterday when her black and white Siberian husky, Ch. Lobo Rey, took the bestofbreed ribbon.

title: Eaton Says U.S.Cuba Ties Could Be Resumed Soon
description: Cyrus S. Eaton, who was a guest of Premier Fidel Castro last week, said yesterday that he believed relations between Cuba and the United States could be resumed cmickly if Secretary of State Kissinger were to take up the matter with the Cuban leader.

title: Reluctant to Take Summons, Motorist Compounds His Woe
description: Daniel Chiarellio did not want to accept a traffic summonse last night, the police said but his reluctance proved costly.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Advertising: Valentine Sending
description: Tomorrow is Valentine's Day. Last December, Federal and New York State banking officials made it clear that they would mot tolerate discrimination by banking institutions against women in making loans. Put them both together and what have you got?

title: I.R.S. to Yield Data
description: The Internal Revenue Service agreed to return to the telephone company records of 2,500 toll calls from the Washington bureau of The New York Times that the agency had subpoenaed on the ground that it was investigating an information leak. Details on Page 25.

title: McGovern Assails Plan to Phase Out Food Assistance
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) Senator George McGovern today that an Agriculture Department plan for phasing out direct food assistance could work hardships on undernourished Americans.

title: Follmer at 40 Takes a Whirl at Stock Cars
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 12The 39yearold gumchewing star with the ninthgrade education was teaching the 40yearold collegeeducated rookie how to get around Daytona Speedway today.

title: Order or Isolation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12The United States has now placed before the other major industrial nations of the world both a generous offer and a clear warning.

title: Soviet Trials Unfair, Author Says in Gulag
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 12Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn today made available a 1968 section of his vast study of the Soviet penal system, contending that even in recent years it has been impossible to get a fair trial in cases involving state or ideological interests of Soviet leaders.

title: Nixon Muses on Vilification of Lincoln
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12President Nixon placed a wreath at the Lincoln Memorial today and, in a speech that seemed to draw a comparison to himself, said that the Civil War President, despite vilification, had the character to stand tall and strong and firm no matter how harsh or unfair the criticism might be.

title: McCord Asks to Testify On Nomination of Silbert
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12James W. McCord Jr., one of the original defendants in the Watergate trials, has written to the Senate Judiciary Committee requesting to appear at any hearings on the nomination of Earl J. Silbert to be United States Attorney for the District of Columbia.

title: Pistons Win 7th in Row, 113 to 106
description: DETROIT, Feb. 12 (AP)Willie Norwood and Dave Bing combined for 51 points tonight as the Detroit Pistons beat Kansas CityOmaha, 113106, for their seventh straight National Basketball Association victory.

title: Market Mixed in Slow Trading
description: A late technical recovery yesterday enabled the stock market to erase many of its earlier losses and finish the session mixed in continued slow trading.

title: Kubelik Quits Met As Music Director
description: Rafael Kubelik, the first music director in the Metropolitan Opera's history, resigned that past yesterday, effective immediately.

title: Christopher T. Emmet Is Dead; Writer on Totalitarianism, 73
description: Christopher Temple Emmet, a political writer who was active in the opposition to both Nazi and Communist total. itarianism, died Monday at Doctors Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 901 Lexington Avenue.

title: Sports News Briefs
Official of Aramco Sees Saudi TakeOver Possible
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) An official of the Arabian American Oil Company said to day that Saudi Arabia hasn't approached us at all with a demand that American Oil companies give up their shares in the consortium for a likely price of $1.5billion.

title: Blacks Sign Accord to Buy Atlantic City Radio Station
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 12 (AP)A group of black residents signed an agreement yesterday to purchase radio station WLDB, a National Broadcasting Company affiliate in this resort.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: System Is Scored in City
description: New York City's motorists were out in force again yesterday in their quest for gasoline, and neither the drivers nor the station operators appeared see great indications that the new saleslimit system was doing much to ease the problem of long lines at stations.

title: U.S. Agency Finds No Excessive Profit In Soviet Grain Deal
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12The General Accounting Office has found no evidence of excessive profits for grain companies in the big 1972 wheat sales to the Soviet Union, but those deals did give the concerns opportunities to make unusual profits on other business, the agency says in a report to be released tomorrow.

title: GlassedIn Terminals Rising on the Hudson
description: The old, old sea, as one in tears,

title: AMBULANCE ARRIVES LATE, AND MAN DIES
description: A Brooklyn man who collapsed on a streetcorner on the Lower East Side died yesterday after more than half an hour passed before an ambulance responded to an emergency police radio call.

title: Corporation for Public Broadcasting Rules Out Setting Up Fourth Network
description: The idea that public television might become the fourth network in the United States has been officially demolished, supplanted by a radically new system, going into effect July 1, under which each local station would select and pay for national programs It wants.

title: Williams and a U.S. Energy Chief Clash As Panel Is Told of Bleak Job Outlook
description: TRENTON, Feb. 12Elected officials, labor and industry spokesmen, educators and private citizens today portrayed for a United States Senate labor subcommittee a bleak and apparently worsening employment situation in New Jersey as a result of the fuel shortage.

title: Indianapolis Mayor Seeking G.O.P. Bid to Oppose Bayh
description: RICHMOND, Ind., Feb. 12 (UPI)Mayor Richard G. Lugar of Indianapolis announced tonight that he would be a candidate for the Republican Senatorial nomination at the state party's convention June 21 to oppose Senator Birch Bayh, a Democrat.

title: DELEGATES FAIL TO REACH ACCORD AT ENERGY TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12The 13nation energy conference failed to reach agreement today because of a sharp dispute between France and her eight Common Market allies on how to respond to the American call for joint efforts by oil consuming and oilproducing countries to deal with the energy crisis.

title: The Truck Settlement: Complex, Difficult Negotiations
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 The apparently successful Government effort to end the work stoppage by independent truckers was, by all accounts, one of the most complex and difficult labor negotiations in history. To begin with, the negotiations did not involve labor in the usual sense. The truckers who stopped work to obtain more fuel at lower prices are smallbusiness men who own their own rigs and whose income derives from leasing their property as well as selling their services.

title: The Theater: Mahagonny at Yale
description: NEW HAVENWhen Bertolt Brecht's and Kurt Weill's The Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny was first presented in Leipzig in 1930, it provoked riots. The New York premiere, offBroadway, 40 years later, provoked critical distemper and seemed, finally, to confine the work to the category of obdurate masterpiece.

title: Colombia Looks to Queens For a Key to Her Election
description: In Chapinerito, it's a friendly election campaign. The only party that may stir up trouble is Emilia.

title: Ervin, Visiting Yale, Delights Students With His Wit
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 12Like a freshman anxious to get to classes on time, Senator Sam Ervin Jr. marched briskly in the cold winter air from classroom to classroom at Yale University today, sharing his wit, wisdom and wisecracks with enthralled students.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: More than 10 per cent of the 400,000 employes on the municipal payroll live outside of New York, City Council President Paul O'Dwyer said yesterday. He said he would press for legislation to require all newly hired workers live inside the city.

title: Pollution Imperils Italian Pine Groves Famed for Beauty
description: ROME, Feb. 16Pine forests all along the coast, a celebrated feature of Italian scenery, seem fated to die.

title: The Distant Planets
description: It will take months and probably years for scientists to puzzle out all the implications of the flood of data about Venus that Mariner 10 has radioed back to earth. It is already evident that information of importance has been received.

title: Wilson Campaigns in Industrial BeltCrowd Is Big
description: LUTON, England, Feb. 12 From early afternoon two enormous television vans were drawn up before the College of Technology. In the assembly hall within, Labor party workers were lifting chairs and rearranging the stage under the direction of a B.B.C. man.

title: Football FieldSize Ice Cube Used as ManMade Pier for Docking at American Base in Antarctica
description: An ice cube with its top surface as large as a football field has been fabricated in Antarctica and, after a succession of mishaps and crises, has proved a successful ship dock.

title: Meskill to Ask Rationing
description: HARTFORD, Feb, 12With gasoline stations continuing to run dry and with frustration and anger among motorists growing. Gov. Thomas J. Meskill prepared today to ask the General Assembly in joint session tomorrow to endorse a plan for restricting gasoline sales in the state and to give him extraordinary powers to cope with the shortages.

title: Ryan First to Win Joe Cronin Award
description: BOSTON, Feb. 12 (UPI)The American League announced today the creation of a Joe Cronin Award for singular achievements over the course of a season and named Nolan Ryan, the California Angels pitcher, the first recipient.

title: Interdependence on Oil
description: Whatever the immediate fruits of the Washington energy conference, the impressive case for international cooperation made by Secretary of State Kissinger in his keynote provides a base for restoring economic sanity to a world that is coming close to inflationary disaster.

title: Suspect in Brooklyn Shootout Arrested by Richmond Police
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 12The police yesterday arrested a man who was reported to have confessed to having participated in a shootout a week ago in which four persons were killed at the Ya Sin Mosque in Brooklyn.

title: President Criticizes Newspaper
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) President Nixon, after attcnding the 90th birthday party Of Alice Roosevelt Longworth, said tonight that she had kept young by not being obsessed by the Washington scene.

title: Earnings of Ford Tumbled 76% in Final '73 Quarter
description: DETROIT, Feb. 12The Ford Motor Company said today its earnings declined 76 per cent to $57million in the last three months of 1973 from $240million a year earlier. The company said the quarter's earnings were down because of reduced bigcar sales resulting from the energycrisis, a strike at a Canadian subsidiary and expenditures to convert plants to small car production.

title: GREATER FREEDOM PROMISED IN SPAIN
description: MADRID, Feb. 12Premier Carlos Arias Navarro today promised Spaniards wider and freer participation in government and union affairs than they have known in the 35 years since the Civil War.

title: Samuels Joins Race For Governorship
description: Howard J. Samuels, who has been unofficially running for Governor since the last gubernatorial election, formally announced his candidacy yesterday for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.

title: Pennsy Asks for U.S. Aid
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 (AP)  The Penn Central Transportation Company has asked for $11.1million from the Federal Government. The company says it needs the money to keep its railroad running.

title: A.B.C. Gets Year Option To Buy Smithville Town
description: The American Broadcasting Company, Inc., announced yesterday that it had obtained a oneyear option to buy the Historic Towne of Smithville in sourthern New Jersey for more than $9million.

title: Ervin, Visiting Yale, Delights Students With His Wit
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 12Like a freshman anxious to get to classes on time, Senator Sam Ervin Jr. marched briskly in the cold winter air from classroom to classroom at Yale University today, sharing his wit, wisdom and wisecracks with enthralled students.

title: Ford Plans Midwest Tour
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) Vice President Ford will make a threeday speaking tour in the Middle West beginning tomorrow, with appearances scheduled at London, Ky., Chicago and Omaha.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
description: Generally sunny skies and milder temperatures are forecast today for most of the Northeast; cloudy skies will cover portions of northern and western New England and the lower lake region. Fair and mild weather will prevail from the Middle and South Atlantic States to the Central and Southern Plains States; warmer temperatures will extend from the central Appalachians to the central Gulf Coast. Cloudy and colder conditions will cover the upper Mississippi Valley and Northern Plains States; flurries are forecast for northern sections of Michigan and Wisconsin and in North Dakota. Scattered showers are expected in the Rockies, while skies will clear along the Pacific Coats.

title: GOLD IS STEADY IN LONDON TRADING
description: LONDON, Feb. 12The rush to buy gold and silver continued in heavy trading on the European bullion markets today amid reports of speculation from the Middle East and massive accumulation by American investors.

title: Albany Steamroller
description: A gross act of selfinterest has provided a dismaying initial demonstration of the way in which Governor Wilson intends to exercise his newly inherited dominance in Albany.

title: Theater: Birth of the Black Musical
description: The Negro Ensemble Theater opened its new season with a musical last night, and it is all at once surprising, exciting and bewildering. But then it is very many things all at once.

title: Gulf Oil Profit Rose 153% in 4th Quarter
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation yesterday announced operating results for 1973. The report indicated a 153 per cent gain in fourthquarter earnings. Net income for the full year climbed to $800million, ending a fouryear slide in profitability.

title: Electricity Bills Rise 12.7% Because of Added Oil Cost
description: The Consolidated Edison Company announced yesterday that its average residential customer would pay $2.23 more this month, or 12.7 per cent, more than in January, for the same amount of electricity becaute of sharply increased costs of the oil the utility burned.

title: Wilson to Seek Increase In State Gasoline Supply
description: Governor Wilson said yesterday that he would fly to Washington today to appeal to William E. Simon, the Federal Energy Office administrator, for more gasoline for the state's motorists.

title: Freight Derails in Tunnel
description: DETROIT, Feb. 12 (AP)Twentytwo cars of a 67car freight train derailed today in the DetroitWindsor railroad tunnel under the Detroit River, but no one was injured. A tank car loaded with chlorine gas was of major concern for a time, but it did not leave the tracks and officials of the Chesapeake & Ohio Railway said that it had not ruptured. Environmental specialists examined the chlorine car to make certain it was not leaking.

title: Laver Wins In Struggle; Ashe Victor
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, Feb. 12 (UPI)Rod Laver and Roger Taylor had to struggle to win, but Arthur Ashe had little trouble as they advanced to the third round of the $50,000 Astor Cup tennis tournament, a World Championship Tennis circuit event.

title: Mary Graham Bonner, Dies; Author of Children's Books
description: Mary Graham Bonner, an author of books for children, died yesterday at her home, 706 Riverside Drive. Her age, was about 83, according to associates.

title: 3 A's Hurlers, Finley in Arbitration
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12 (AP)The Oakland A's owner, Charles O. Finley, walked into an arbitration hearing room today to face onethird of his team's pitching staff.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
A Signal, Perhaps, From Havana
description: WASHINGTONThere is the nagging thought here that Washington may have missed a signal indicating that Fidel Castro's Government may be ready to seek an end to the United States' 13year boycott of Cuba.

title: People and Business
description: The gloom seems to be getting gloomier for 1974's economic outlook. Yesterday two leading forecasters said that the shrinkage in gross national product expected by the experts this quarter may last through the first halfor longer.

title: Miss Bumbry Makes History at Newark Theater
description: NEWARK, Feb. 12Grace Melzia Bumbry, who sang La Gioconda with the Opera Theater of New Jersey here Sunday night, was the first black singer to appear in a major role with the company in its eight years of existence istence. She will repeat the performance tomorrow evening at the Memorial Auditorium in Trenton.

title: Court of Appeals Upholds Law On Naming of Narcotics Judges
description: ALBANY, Feb. 12The State Court of Appeals today upheld, 6 to 1, the constitutionality of a law appointing up to 68 Court of Claims judges who would then serve as Supreme Court justices to try narcotics cases under the state's stringent drug Paws.

title: LAWSUIT IS DROPPED AGAINST EHRLICHMAN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12A lawsuit charging the former Presidential aide, John D. Ehrlichman, with tapping the telephone of Mary Jo Kopechne's roommates is being withdrawn.

title: German Service Unions To Extend Their Strike
description: BONN, Feb. 12West German public service employes announced today that they would continue their twoday strike beyond its original deadline of midnight, but negotiations in Stuttgart for higher wages for two million postmen, bus drivers, trash collectors and minor functionaries continued into the evening.

title: Dead Souls
description: The knocking at the door, so long expected, has finally come. The misnamed security agents, whose mission is to spread fear and insecurity throughout the populace, have knocked on the door of Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's apartment in Moscow. They have dragged him away as his wife and her mother cried out in protest, desperately, hopelessly. The knocking and the cries can be heard around the world.

title: Bliss to Run G.O.P. Parley
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) Ray Bliss, the former chairman of the Republican National Committee, will chair the Midwestern Republican Leadership Conference in Chicago March 2930, the committee announced today. The conference will discuss a number of research projects for the 1974 election campaign, the committee said.

title: Mrs. Chisholm Predicts Nixon Will Quit in April
description: BOULDER, Colo., Feb. 12 (AP)  Representative Shirley Chisholm predicted tonight that President Nixon would resign most reluctantly by next April.

title: Canucks Hand Blues 6th Straight Defeat, 32
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 12 (UPI) Bryan McSheffrey and John Gould scored in a 14second span of the second period tonight to give the Vancouver Canucks a 32 victory over the St. Louis Blues, who lost their sixth straight game in the National Hockey League.

title: Corporate Profile
description: When an executive of the Gulf Oil Corporation was asked why the company has its headquarters in Pittsburgh, the terse (but not unfriendly) reply was, Why not?

title: Byrne Attacks Bid For 50c PATH Fare
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 12Un??er sharp attack by Governor Byrne, commissioners of the Port Authority of New York ??nd New Jersey agreed today ??o consider on Thursday ??hether to withdraw a request or an increase in PATH tube rain fares from 30 to 50 cents.

title: Pan Am Chief Hits U.S. Policy On Allocation of Domestic Fuel
description: In a bitter attack on Federal energy policy, William T. Seaveil, chairman of Pan American World Airways, said yesterday ??hat Pan Am was drafting lawsuit aimed at forcing the federal Energy Office to allo??ate priceControlled domestic ??et fuel to international air??ines.

title: Uncovered Midriffs Go Beyond the Beach
description: A wellturned pair of ankles is certainly no handicap and there's obviously no need to fret if your shoulders are smooth and your bosom shapely.

title: New Constitution Approved By the Cabinet in Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 12 (UPI)The caretaker Cabinet of Thailand has given initial approval to a new constitution and sent it to the National Assembly, where extensive debate is expected.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Of Vietnam, America and the Impossible Peace

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Unemployment Benefits Extended

title: BYRNE ASSAILS BID FOR 50C PATHFARE
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 12 Under sharp attack by Governor Byrne, commissioners of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey agreed today to consider on Thursday whether to withdraw a request for an increase in PATH tube, train fares from 30 to 50 cents.

title: U.S. Newsman Injured
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 12 (UPI)Denis Cameron, a freelance journalist and photographer, suffered burns yesterday while covering an artillery attack, on Phnom Penh's southwestern area. Mr. Cameron, a United States citizen, suffered burns on both his legs and his right arm, officials at the Calmette Hospital here said. He was to be flown to Bangkok. for treatment, officials said.

title: Wounded Knee Trial Opens With Revolt Warning
description: ST. PAUL, Feb. 12The Wounded Knee trial opened here today with dramatic statements from the two defendants, Russell C. Means and Dennis J. Banks, that Indians are ready to revolt against having their heritage and traditions crushed by an unfeeling Federal bureaucracy.

title: German Says Market Split Cannot Be Papered Over
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12West Germany's Finance Minister said today that there could be no papering over of the fundamental conflict within the European Common Market that has checked progress at the conference of major oilconsuming nations here.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: HENRY SWARTZ
description: Henry Swartz, who graduated from New York University Law School in 1906 and practiced corporate law here until his retirement four years sago died yesterday at the age of 90 in Veterans Administration Hospital, East Orange, N.J.

title: I.R.S. WILL RETURN PHONECALLS DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12The Internal Revenue Service agreed today to surrender records of 2,500 toll calls from the Washington bureau of The New York Times that the agency had subpoenaed on the ground that it was investigating an information leak.

title: People in Sports: Frazier Wants A Title Shot, But Not Quarry
description: Should Joe Frazier take on Jerry Quarry now that Muhammad Ali has pulled out of his date with the white hope from California?

title: N.B.A,'s Mounting Casualty List
description: National Basketball Association players are hurting. Through yesterday, 43 players, 22 per cent of those in the league, had missed a total of 550 games. The toll will grow higher, because some of the injured are skielined for the season.

title: CONSUMER AGENCY IS CRITICAL OF ADS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) Members of the Consumer Product Safety Commission say they believe publishers should try to verify the safety of the products advertised in their publications.

title: 7 RUSSIANS MAKE FORCIBLE ARREST OF SOLZHENITSYN
description: MOSCOW, Wednesday Feb. 13Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the dissident novelist, who once declared he was prepared to face even death to promote the cause of truth, was forcibly arrested yesterday by a team of Soviet police agents.

title: U.S. Protests the Detention Of Two Newsmen in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 12 (Reuters) The United States Embassy here today protested the detention of two United States reporters and accused the Soviet Union of violating the United StatesSoviet consular agreement, an Embassy spokesman said.

title: Heath Begins With Tour Northwest of London
description: BLETCHLEY, England, Feb. 12  For Prime Minister Heath it was a day of speeches, handshakes, smiles, much praise from his admirers, a few jeers from his critics and a complaint from an old woman who said she was hungry.

title: German Pointer Is Best at Westminster
description: It took Len Carey of Fallbrook, Calif., exactly 10 minutes to name a German shorthaired pointer, Ch. Gretchenhof Columbia River, best in show last night before a cheering crowd of 11,000 as the Westminster Kennel Club's 98th edition ended a twoday run at Madison Square Garden.

title: A TwoWay IncomeTax Trim Wins Unanimous Backing in State Senate
description: ALBANY, Feb. 12In anelectionyear show of support for lower taxes, the Senate today unanimously passed a bill to suspend the 2.5 per cent state incometax surcharge for a second year and to increase the personal exemption to $700 from $650.

title: Wilson Hires 2 More for Publicity Aid
description: ALBANY, Feb. 12Piecing together his campaign team, Governor Wilson has hired two more political professionalsHarold Harris, a publicrelations specialist familiar with both city Democrats and past Rockefeller campaigns, and James R. Carberry, who was a speechwriter for Mayor John V. Lindsay.

title: NANCY PIERCE GIVES REFRESHING RECITAL
description: Nancy Pierce, a cellist from Iowa who currently plays in the New York City Opera orchestra, gave a most refreshing recital Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. In a location where one all too often encounters underdeveloped talents and overdeveloped pretensions, Miss Pierce simply grade music  and, along with her most able and sympathetic accompanist, Zita Carno, she made it very well indeed.

title: The Unanswered Questions at the Met
description: The short release issued yesterday by the Metropolitan Opera, announcing the resignation of Rafael Kubelik as music director, left several major questions unanswered: Will the position of music director be kept in the Metropolitan Opera's table of organization? If so, who will succeed Mr. Kubelik? Will Mr, Kubelik conduct the operas for which he had been scheduled next season?

title: Park Visitors Decline
description: GRAND CANYON, Ariz., Feb. 12 (UPI)The National Park Service said its figures showed that the Grand Canyon National Park, usually near the top among the nation's outdoor tourist attractions, suffered a 39 per cent drop in January attendance, primarily because of fuel shortages.

title: Inflation's Uncertainty Haunts Consumers
description: If consumers were certain that substantial inflation, of say 6 per cent annually, were here to stay, they would go out and spend money faster than the experts are predicting for this year.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 13, 1974

title: WARWOOD E. MASON
description: Capt. Warwood E. Mason, a retired executive of American Export Lines, now American Export lsbrandtsen Lines, died Monday in Orange Memorial Hospital in East Orange, N. J. He was 73 years old and lived at 334 West 85th Street, New York.

title: Ash Calls Energy Crisis One Time Phenomenon
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 America's energy crisis is manageable, it's one time and it's short term, Roy L. Ash, director of the Office of Management and Budget, asserted today.

title: Simon Orders Ban On Discrimination In Sale of Gasoline
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) William E. Simon, administrator of the Federal Energy Office, prohibited service station owners today from discriminating against motorists by selling gasoline only to regular customers or by selling large amounts in advance.

title: Party Set for Beame on QE2 Protested by Hotels and Unions
description: Mayor Beame sounded what appeared to be an abandon ship signal yesterday to campaign fundraisers who were planning a birthday salute for him aboard the Queen Elizabeth 2.

title: Hearst Kidnappers Asking Food for Poor
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 12The Symbionese Liberation Army today asked Randolph A. Hearst, the newspaper executive, for more than $230million worth of free food for the poor as evidence of good faith in negotiating the release of his kidnapped daughter, Patricia.

title: Blacks' Protest on Aide Imperils Byrne Harmony
description: TRENTON, Feb. 12A major racial dispute involving several of New Jersey's most prominent Democratic leaders threatened today to undermine Governor Byrne's nomination of Mayor Patricia Q. Sheehan of New Brunswick as Commissioner of the State Department of Community Affairs.

title: Air Force, Overstrength, Is Dropping 425 Officers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI)  The Air Force announced today that it would force 425 officers, mostly reserve Captains, out of the service to meet a Congressionally imposed ceiling on its officer strength.

title: Red Smith
description: In a small stall outside the main arena in Madison Square Garden, a bull mastiff slept deeply, secure in the knowledge that there wasn't a Baskerville on the premises. Not far away, a St. Bernard dozed. The intelligent droop of his jowls made him look like Sam Ervin in a fur coat. In the section given over to Lhasa Apsos, a wire cage bore the name of its tenant, Ch. Shyr Lyz Mieh Bieh Tu, but the cage held only a pair of woman's shoes. A booth nearby was also unoccupled and a sign explained why: Ch. Rgyal KhetsaPo is in town but busy with five golden boys sired by Ch. Potala Keke's Tomba Tu, whelped Jan. 16, 1974. Therefore she is unable to attend the Westminster Kennel Club show. However, she invites inquiries about her beautiful sons. A beautiful Lhasa Apso is a blob of silky hair that hangs straight down like a portiere.

title: A Beame Campaign Aide Is Named to Head WNYC
description: A former coworker of Mayor Beame's son Bernard, who was his father's campaign manager, was appointed yesterday as head of the Municipal Broadcasting System.

title: John Russell Is Named An Art Critic by Times
description: John Russell, art critic of The Sunday Times in London since 1950, has been appointed to the staff of The New York Times as an art critic, it was announced yesterday by A. M. Rosenthal, managing editor. Mr. Russell will take up his duties in New York on April 1, joining Hilton Kramer, who was recently appointed chief art critic.

title: FOUR ARAB STATES SEEK JOINT POLICY
description: CAIRO, Feb. 12Informed sources said today that a fournation meeting of Arab leaders would begin in Algiers tomorrow, with topics expected to include Egypt's intention to resume formal diplomatic relations with the United States soon.

title: Providence Beats Brown In 2 Overtimes, 7573
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 12 (AP)Marvin Barnes, playing with four personal fouls, scored on a 22foot jumpshot with 5 seconds left in the second overtime period tonight to lift nationally ranked Providence College to a 7573 victory over Brown, its crosstown rival.

title: Mother, 16, Accuses Housing Agency of Bias Against Youths
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12 A suit has been filed on behalf of a 16yearold girl and her 9monthold son, charging that they were denied admittance to lowcost public housing because the mother was still legally a child.

title: Chrysler Working On Plans to Make New Small Models
description: DETROIT, Feb. 12  The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it was working on plans for new small cars for the 197677 model years.

title: They Find It a Challenge Tracking Down Nonsexist Films Rated C for Children
description: Feminists to film distributor: Do you have any children's films about heroines?

title: TV: Alcoholic's Evasions and Agony
description: The Morning After, tonight's 8:30 movie on the American Broadcasting Company network, is about an alcoholic and, true to the lifestyle of any alcoholic, it is drenched in cliches. The problem of alcoholism is devastatingly real, but the subject of alcoholism in fiction rarely gets beyond domestic melodrama. The Morning After touches most of the familiar bases.

title: Solzhenitsyn Bars Aid To Judges or Jailers
description: MOSCOW, Wednesday, Feb. 13Obviously anticipating action against himself in his final day or two of freedom, Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn prepared the following statement vowing never to cooperate with authorities who tried to interrogate, try or imprison him:

title: Padres' Sale Is Official
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12 (AP)  The sale of the San Diego Padres to Ray A. Kroc, chairman of the McDonald's hamburger chain, was pronounced official today by the National League president, Charles (Chub) Feeney.

title: WILSON SIGNS BILL TO SHIFT PRIMARY
description: ALBANY, Feb. 12Governor Wilson tonight signed into law the bill moving the state's primary election to September and setting state political conventions forward to June.

title: MILLIONAIRE BUYS SILVER CONTRACTS
description: Nelson Bunker Hunt, the 48yearold son of H. L. Hunt, one of the nation's wealthiest oil men, has apparently been buying silver contracts for many months.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 13, 1974

title: NONPUBLIC SCHOOLS UPHELD ON SOME AID
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 (UPI)A threejudge Federal court upheld today the constitutionality of Pennsylvania state aid to nonpublic schools in the form of auxiliary services and loans of instructional material.

title: ISRAEL PULLS OUT MORE SUEZ UNITS
I.R.S. to Yield Data
description: The Internal Revenue Service agreed to return to the telephone company records of 2,500 toll calls from the Washington bureau of The New York Times that the agency had subpoenaed on the ground that it was investigating an information leak. Details on Page 25.

title: INFLATION FRETS JAPAN'S PREMIER
description: TOKYO, Feb. 12Japan's top newspaper executives today bluntly accused Premier Kakuel Tanaka and his cabinet of fail. ing to stop the nation's spiral. ing inflation.

title: Women's Caucus Planned
description: An organizing convention of the New York State Women's Political Caucus, billed as the state's first women's political convention since 1848, will be held Friday night, Saturday and Sunday at the White Plains Hotel in White Plains. The agenda includes workshops on lobbying and running for office and a dinner honoring women officeholders throughout the state.

title: Kubelik Quits Met As Music Director
description: Rafael Kubelik, the first music director in the Metropolitan Opera's history, resigned that post yesterday, effective immediately.

title: Two Doctors Debate the Benefits of Exercise in Treatment of Patients With Heart Disease
description: To exercise or not to exercise to prevent another heart attack?

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and ?? Page 42

title: Bridge: A Bad Trump Break Can Test Player's Mettle and Control
description: Keeping one's head in the face of a bad trump break is vitally necessary in tournament play. Marietta Passell of Yonkers, who will be one of the United States representatives in the world women's pair championship in Las Palmas, the Canary Islands, in May, was in full control on the diagramed deal.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary end Index, Pip 41

title: Banks in Indonesia Venture
description: PARIS, Feb. 12 (UPI)Crdit Lyonnais, France's ranking business and deposit bank, said today it would participate with three European associates in the creation of the Private Development Finance Company of Indonesia. The partners are Banco di Roma Holding, Luxembourg; Lloyds and Bolsa International Bank, Ltd.; and the Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale.

title: Excerpt From Gulag Archipelago on Law in Soviet Union Today
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 12Following is an excerpt from the seventh section of The Gulag Archipelago, 191856, made available by the author, Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, before his arrest today. The translation is by The New York Times.

title: MOSCOW IS URGED TO FREE AUTHOR
description: As the news of Alexsandr I. Solzhenitsyn's arrest spread to Europe and the United States, writers and publishers responded with letters and cablegrams yesterday asking Soviet leaders to free him.

title: Nixon Muses on Vilification of Lincoln
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12President Nixon placed a wreath at the Lincoln Memorial today and, in a speech that seemed to draw a compariston to himself, said that the Civil War President, despite vilification, had the character to stand tall and strong and firm no matter how harsh or unfair the criticism might be.

title: Hearst Kidnappers Asking Food for Poor
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 12The Symbionese Liberation Army today asked Randolph A. Hearst, the newspaper executive, for more than $230million worth of free food for the poor as evidence of good faith in negotiating the release of his kidnapped daughter, Patricia.

title: John C. Fraser Dies at 46; Executive at New York Life
description: John Chisholm Fraser, a vice president and actuary of the New York Life Insurance Company, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief illness. He was 46 years old and lived at 145 East 27th Street.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Party for Beame On Ship Protested

title: DELEGATES FAIL TO REACH ACCORD AT ENERGY TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12The 13nation energy conference failed to reach agreement today because of a sharp dispute between France and her eight Common Market allies on how to respond to the American call for joint efforts by oil consuming and oilproducing countries to deal with the energy crisis.

title: Panther Chief of Security Was Paid F.B.I. Informer
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 11  Court testimony has revealed that the Black Panther party's chief of security here on the night that its leader, Fred Hampton, was slain in a predawn police raid was a paid Federal Bureau of Investigation informer.

title: GARRETT DISCOUNTS FEARS BY BROKERS
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 12Stockbrokers should not fear price competition in the commission rates they charge customers, Ray Garrett Jr., chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said here today.

title: Contract Awards
