description: DOWNEY, Calif., Feb. 12 (UPI)  The Rockwell International Corporation announced today selection of the Aerojet Liquid Rocket Company of Sacramento for a $25million subcontract for space shuttle work. Rockwell's Space Division developing the shuttle orbiter and integrating the complete system for the National Space Agency. Under the subcontract Aerojet would design and produce the orbital maneuvering system engines for the shuttle. The orbiter is the payload carrier for the shuttle  the first reusable space transportation system. The goal of the program is the development of a versatile, workhorse space transport system that will bring about a major reduction the cost of space operations.

title: Tocks Island Squatters Win Reprieve From Eviction by Army Engineers
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 The 40 squatters and their children who live on Federal land near Tocks Island have received orders from Federal courts here and in Scranton, Pa., that amount to at least a temporary reprieve from earlier eviction decisions.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: RAZING AND RAISING Cities hang around until long after what they were has completely changed, a sametitle, differentshow sort of business. In the early nineteen  sixties Jane Jacobs wrote a book called The Death and Life of Great American Cities, a seminal work that prescribed changes in the citysurvival approaches that were prevalent.

title: COURT REINSTATES PRUDENTIAL PENSION
description: NEWARK, Feb. 12 (UPI)A retired 80yearold executive has been awarded more than $12,000 in back pension payments from the Prudential Insurance Company, and the concern has until Feb. 22 to show cause why the payments should not continue.

title: Bardel Quits City Agency To Join Lehman Subsidiary
description: William G. Bardel said last night that he had resigned as director of the Mayor's Office for Midtown Planning and Development to become a vice president of the Lehman Realty Corporation, a newly created subsidiary of Lehman Brothers, the Wall Street investment concern.

title: MATHEWS'S DANCERS MINE THE PICTORIAL
description: Fred Mathews and his dancers are an accomplished group with more physical skills than rewarding choreography. Their program Monday evening at the Cubiculo was marked by a pli and sway calmness that was enjoyable but left little trace in the mind afterward.

title: Samuels in Governorship Race; Assails Wilson and Rockefeller
description: Howard J. Samuels, who has been unofficially running for Governor since the last gubernatorial election, formally announced his candidacy yesterday for Democratic gubernatorial nomination.

title: Prices Raised 12% On Packaging Film By American Can
description: The American Can Company announced yesterday that it was raising prices on all meatpackaging films and laminations by 12 to 20 per cent, effective with new orders placed after March 1 and on shipments of April 1. The company said this was the first price increase on the product in 10 years and was due to higher costs of petrochemicalbased materials. American Can added that similar price increases were anticipated in all other petrochemicalbased packaging materials.

title: Governor Presses Simon For Increase in Gasoline
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13Governor Wilson recited Latin and statistics today in his quest for Federal emergency gasoline allocations for New York Sate. But the Governor also did something on his own to help the state's hardship areas by allocating 3 per, cent of the New York February total of 357million gallons of gasoline to these are as an emergency allotment.

title: Irish Five to Play Fordham Tonight
description: Notre Dame's coach, Dick (Digger) Phelps, one of the few men in the last 10 years who can boast of coaching a team to victory over the University of California, Los Angeles, will try tonight to pick up his first triumph in three attempts over a soso Fordham team in Madison Square Garden.

title: BIG IRISH PLANT SET BY ALCAN ALUMINUM
description: Alcan Aluminum, Ltd., of Canada announced yesterday plans to build an 800,000tonayear alumina plant in Limerick, Ireland, at a cost of $250million.

title: Israeli Religious Party Pulls Out Of Talks on Entry Into Cabinet
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 13The National Religious party, traditional partner of the Labor party in government coalitions, tonight broke off negotiations on entering Premier Golda Meir's next cabinet.

title: EARNINGS RAISED BY B. F. GOODRICH
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company and Uniroyal, Inc., two major rubber producers, reported yesterday increased sales and earnings for the fourth quarter and all of last year.

title: Villanova Students Protest Visitingban and Suspensions
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13  More than 500 Villanova University students marched from the school's field house to its main administrative building today and sat down in protest against what one spokesman called the closeminded stance of the administration.

title: Escher Prints Given to National Gallery
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13The National, Gallery of Art accepted today a large collection of prints by the late Dutch printmaker M.C. Escher from Cornelius van Schaak Roosevelt, a local collector and friend of Escher for almost 20 years. The gift, announced by J. Carter Brown, director of the National Gallery includes impressions of more than twothirds of Eschers prints. It will comprise, along with the gallery's present holdings in the Roosevelt collection, the most important Escher study collection oustide the artist's own bequest to The Hague.

title: HOSPITAL IN MIAMI HAS MANY CRITICS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 The new medical facility in Miami that President Nixon will dedicate tomorrow has been the subject of public debate there for years.

title: 5 BIG BANKS LOSE IN APPEAL ON TAX
description: ALBANY, Feb. 13The State Court of Appeals ruled today that five of the largest commercial banks in New York City would have to pay three years' worth of state sales and use taxes that they held represented a discriminatory levy.

title: ARABS DELAY TALK ON EMBARGO'S END
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Feb. 13The Arab oilproducing countries today abruptly called off meeting that was to have considered the lifting of the oil embargo imposed against the United States and the Nether. lands.

title: Contract Awards
description: Gould, Inc., has received a contract from the United States Navy valued at $83.8million for Mark 48 torpedoes.

title: Chess: Ockham's Razor Should Be Used to Avoid Close Shaves
description: The chief principle of defense is economy of means. Nothing will fuel a mating attack better than excessive pawn moves to drive away the attacking pieces, since each pawn advance loosens the king position it was designed to protect.

title: WITNESS HAS ALIBI FOR 3 IN SLAYINGS
description: A witness testified that at the time Police Officers Gregory P. Foster and Rocco W. Laurie were slain two years ago on the Lower East Side he was working on a Florida tomato farm with three men who have been identified as suspects in the killings.

title: Soviet Spacecraft Fails to Orbit Mars, but a Second Succeeds
description: The latest Soviet campaign to explore the planet Mars with four unmanned spacecraft suffered a setback this week when the first of two craft apparently designed for an orbital mission failed to go into orbit. The second succeeded.

title: Sunday Newspaper Planned
description: KINSTON, N. C., Feb. 13 (UN) The Kinston Daily Free Press announced today that it would begin publishing a Sunday morning newspaper beginning March 3.

title: Novel Viewed as Origin Of Symbionese Name
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13 (UPI)The Symbionese Liberation Army may have borrowed its name from a 1959 novel about an uprising in Chicago's black ghetto.

title: GALLUP POLL FINDS MOST STILL USE CAR
description: Despite the gasoline shortage and the inconvenience of long lines at filling stations, American commuters have yet to show much movement toward using alternative means of transportation to work, the Gallup Poll reported yesterday.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: SAMUELS BEGINS HIS 4TH CANDIDACY
description: Seventeen of the state's 62 Democratic county leaders announced yesterday their support for Howard J. Samuels as he formally opened his drive for the party's gubernatorial nomination.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Most people assume cool is a mod word that didn't exist until recently. But it was part of the black vocabulary at least 50 years ago. That's when Cool Papa Bell got his nickname.

title: 55 and Plenty of San Provide Happy Respite
description: The weather was pleasantly warm and sunny yesterday, providing a pleasant respite from last week's snow, but the high temperature of 55 degrees, reached at 4:10 P.M., was still nowhere near a record for the date.

title: U.S., Britain and Germany Offer to Welcome Author
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the Soviet writer Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn would certainly be welcome to reside in the United States if he desires.

title: ARABS DELAY TALK ON EMBARGOES END
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Feb. 13The Arab oilproducing countries today abruptly called off a meeting that was to have considered the lifting of the oil embargo imposed against the United States and the Netherlands.

title: Ford Doubts That Nation Will Need Gas Rationing
description: LONDON, Ky., Feb. 13 (UPI)The nation is probably over the hump that would require gasoline rationing, Vice President Ford said today at a news conference here.

title: People and Business S.E.C. Appoints New Enforcement Director
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday that Stanley Sporkin would be the new director of its division of enforcement, succeeding Irving M. Pollack, who was sworn in yesterday as a member of the regulatory agency.

title: MARTIN M. BROWN, BUILDING EXECUTIVE
description: LAWRENCE, L.I., Feb. 13 Martin M. Brown, retired president of Mutual Construction Corporation and of BrownTurner, Inc., died Sunday at his home here. He was 75 years old.

title: Saigon Antigambling Drive Ousts Police and Officials
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 13 (Reuters)Several policemen and military and administrative officials in the Saigon area have been dismissed because of connections with gambling, the Saigon radio said today.

title: HARRY LEBAU
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 13 Harry Lebau, executive director of the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association here from 1926 to his retirement in 1963, died yesterday in the Elizabeth General Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 828 Linden Avenue.

title: A Judge Summarizes Westminster Dog Show: It's an Endurance Contest
description: Len Carey called it an endurance contest. He was the judge who named Dr. Rich. and P. Smith's German short. haired pointer, Ch. Gretchen. hof Columbia River from Hayward, Calif., as best of 3,146 dogs as the Westminster Kennel Club's 98th edition ended a twoday run at Madison Square Garden late Tuesday night.

title: PRISON IS DAMAGED IN NEVADA PROTEST
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Feb. 13 (UPI)  Inmates caused about $3,000 damage at the medium security Nevada State Prison yesterday after making demands relative to the store and transfer of inmate property.

title: Parkway Lanes Closed Today
description: The Transportation Administration announced yesterdays that the southbound lanes of the Henry Hudson Parkway, from 96th to 79th Street, would be closed today for resurfacing. The closing will begin at 10 A.M. and end at 3 P.M. Motorists can exit at 96th Street and use Riverside Drive to the 72d Street entrance of the parkway.

title: HELMS WILL ANSWER WATERGATE QUERIES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) Ambassador Richard Helms has agreed to return from Iran to be questioned in secret ses sion by Senate Watergate committee invesigators, the panel's minority counsel, Fred D. Thompson, said today.

title: ARTHUR H. SAMISH, A COAST LOBBYIST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13, (AP)Arthur H. Samish, the superlobbyist who once described himself as the boss of California, died yesterday at 1St. Mary's Hospital. He was 75 years old.

title: THE TIMES SEEKS A NOSTRIKE WRIT
description: ALBANY, Feb, 13Lawyers for The New York Times asked the State Court of Appeals today to reverse an Appellate Division ruling and reinstitute a permanent nostrike injunction against New York Typographical Union No. 6.

title: Text of the Communique of the Washington Energy Conference
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13Following is the text of the communiqu issued today at the conclusion of the 13nation energy conference here. Italics, supplied by The New York Times, identify the paragraphs that are rejected by France.

title: ART DEALER ROBBED IN BROOKLYN HOME
description: Two masked gunmen raided the Brooklyn home of an art dealer last night, stole over $50,000 worth of cash, jewelry and paintings, and then fled leaving the dealer, his wife and 3yearold son and a business associate tied hand and foot with adhesive tape across their mouths, the police reported.

title: Market Place: Economist Calls Prognosii Dim
description: Every shopper knows that inflation was severe last year; alarming rises in supermarket food prices seemed to occur almost daily.

title: State Colleges' Faculties To Get 6% Pay Increases
description: TRENTON, Feb. 13  An acrosstheboard salary increase of 6 per cent, plus benefits considered crucial by the faculty members' bargaining unit, has been negotiated in contract between the state and the union for the faculty and academic staff of the eight state colleges.

title: Satellite Launched on Coast
description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Feb. 13 (UPI) A satellite employing a Titan 3 Agena combination was launched today from this West Coast missile site. No other details on the launching were disclosed by the Air Force.

title: Bridge: Federation Moves to Block Cheating at World Tourney
description: Accusations of cheating, public or private, wellfounded or not, have bedeviled international championships with increasing frequency in the last two decades. It is now likely that the World Bridge Federation will take action to ensure that the 1974 world team championship in Venice will be free of cheating and free of accusations of cheating.

title: Ways to Cut Inflation Termed Elusive by Cost Council Head
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) John T. Dunlop, director of the Cost of Living Council, said today he didn't think any Western government, including the United States, knew how to control inflation.

title: Stage: Rainbow Jones
description: RAINBOW JONES, a musical. Book, music and lyrics by Jill Williams; directed by Gene Persson; musical director and vocal arrangements by Danny Holgate; musical staging by Sammy Bares; setting by Richard Ferrer; costumes by James Berton Harris; lighting by Spencer Mosse; production sane manager, Kate Pollock. Presented by Rubykate, Inc., in association with Phil Gillin and Gene Bambic. At the Music Box, West 45th Street.

title: Japan Shows Deficits In Payments and Trade
description: TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 14 (Reuters)Japan had a record deficit of $1.93billion in her balance of payments for January, the Finance Ministry. announced today. The trade balance showed a deficit of $740million, the first trade deficit in three years, the ministry said.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: PHONECALL DATA RETURNED BY I.R.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 The Internal Revenue Service surrendered today telephone records of the Washington bureau of The New York Times that were secretly subpoenaed last month, but not those of the home telephone of a Times reporter, David E. Rosenbaum.

title: U.S. APPROVES SALE OF GOLCONDA STOCK
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 13 (AP) The Federal judge overseeing the affairs of the crippled WestgateCalifornia Corporation has approved the sale of its stock in the Golconda Corporation, Chicago.

title: Reid Pledges to Eliminate SeldomShow State Jobs
description: Charging that when Nelson A. Rockefeller was Governor he played old politics with state jobs, Representative Ogden R. Reid, a Democratic gubernatorial contender, pledged yesterday that if elected he would eliminate seldomshow state jobs and patronage at Surrogates' Courts.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI)  The Internal Revenue Service has charged that the United States Gypsum Company, a key defendant in a pricefixing suit, owes the Federal Government more than $20milion in back taxes, according to United States Tax Court records.

title: SHORTTERM COST OF MONEY DROPS
description: Shortterm interest rates moved downward yesterday, nudged lower by the Federal Reserve, and longterm rates rose as a mammoth $2billion worth of fixedincome notes and bonds was offered to investors in the credit markets. The Federal Reserve twice came into the money market and injected reserves into the banking system by purchasing Treasury bills temporarily from Government securities dealersan action interpreted to mean the monetary authorities want the money supply to faster.

title: A Protest by Veterans
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13 (UN)  Fifteen protesters, five of them uniformed Vietnam veterans in wheelchairs who spent the night in Senator Alan Cranston's ofice, complained to the Senator today about care at Veterans Administration hospitals. In a meeting with Senaltor Cranston and Mr. Marc J. Musser, head of the V.A. hospital program, the protesters said treatment at the hospials was an outrage and a national disgrace.

title: Solzhenitsyn Exiled to West Germany And Stripped of His Soviet Citizenship
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 13  The Soviet Union deported Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn to West Germany today and issued a decree stripping him of his citizenship for performing systematically actions that are incompatible with being a citizen.

title: Music: Lincoln Tribute
description: The Cooper Union chose an unusual program for celebrating Abraham Lincoln's birthday Tuesday night at Town Hall. Unusual? Well, let's say bizarre: Litany, a fragmentary work by Szymanowski; Chichester Psalms by Bernstein and Psalmus Hungaricus by Kodly. The three choral works, sung in Polish, Hebrew and English, respectively, were performed with great verve by the Concert Orchestra and Choir of Long Island under the successive leadership of Joseph Rescigno, Richard Kapp and Laszlo Halasz.

title: BONN WAS NOTIFIED JUST BEFORE EXILE
description: BONN, Feb. 13The West German Government spokesman, Rdiger, von Wechmar, said today that Bonn had no knowledge of Soviet plans to send Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn to West Germany before today and had not been involved in any secret deal with Moscow to get him out of the Soviet Union.

title: Solzhenitsyn's West German Host
description: Heinrich Bll, who is host to Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn in West Germany, is a prolific writer of novels, short stories and plays and was awarded a Nobel Prize for literature in 1972.

title: Republican Plans Challenge Of Pennsylvania Defeat
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Feb. 13 (AP)Harry M. Fox, Republican, says he will challenge his narrow defeat in a special Congressional election by John P. Murtha, Democrat.

title: U.S. Skiers' Poor Effort Follows Earlier Pattern
description: The dismal showing by the United States team in the recent world skiing championships at St. Moritz, Switzerland, came as a surprise to many persons. They had expected at least one of the four flying Cochrans  Marilyn, Barbara, Bobby and Lindyto win a medal. But when the meet had been completed, Austria topped the list with eight medals, France was next with four and Italy and little Leichenstein had three apiece.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: Consumers' ClassAction Bill Argued
description: ALBANY, Feb, 13A bill that would allow aggrieved consumers to join together to bring lawsuits was supported today by consumer groups as long overdue and attacked by business and banking spokes. men as leading to the potential blackmail of large corporations.

title: CARACAS TAKEOVER IN OIL IS SCHEDULED
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 13 (Reuters)Foreign oil company holdings in Venezuela will revert to the state within two years after the new government is installed next month, Presidentelect Carlos Andres Perez said today.

title: City Official Loses Job And Gets It BackFast
description: While riding to work yesterday in his chauffeurdriven limousine, Joseph B. Klein learned for the first time in morning newspaper accounts that John J. Walsh had replaced him as chairman of the City Board of Standard and Appeals. He ordered his driver: To City Hall, quick.

title: MESKILL REQUESTS ALLOCATION RIGHT
description: Connecticut joined New York and New Jersey yesterday in attempting to wrestle with the gasoline crisis on a statewide basis, but stopped short of setting up a mandatory rationing plan.

title: LeftWing Peronists Deny Role in Plot
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb, 13Leftwing Peronist leaders today vigorously denied any involvement in what was described as a plot to assassinate President Juan D. Pern, his wife, Isabel, and Juan M. Bordaberry, President of Uruguay, who paid a state visit to argentine yesterday.

title: Spiro Agnew, V.I.P.
description: More than four months after Spiro Agnew left the nation's second highest office in disgrace, the former Vice President is still chauffeured and chaperoned by Secret Service agents. Even though the General Accounting Office has told Congress that this costly and pretentious entourage has no authorization under existing law, Mr. Agnew this week embarked on a vacation trip to California accompanied by a detail of agents and by others assigned from West Coast headquarters. The cost for such V.I.P. protection since Mr. Agnew's resignation by now is well in excess of $100.000.

title: Egypt, Syria, Algeria and Saudi Arabia Open Talks
description: ALGIERS, Feb. 13The leaders of Algeria, Egypt, Syria and Saudi Arabia gathered here tonight to try to align divergent positions on Israel and on Arab oil policy.

title: Germans Acclaim Writer At Heinrich Bill's Home
description: LANGENBROICH, West Germany, Feb. 13  Clutching a bouquet of daffodils he bought on his arrival at the Frankfurt airport, Aleksandr I, Solzhenitsyn arrived in this tiny farming village in the Eifel hills at 7:10 tonight and was kissed on both cheeks by his host, the novelist Heinrich Bll.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Simon Requests Ash Keep CottonPickin' Hands Off
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13William E. Simon, head of the Federal Energy Office, took a verbal swing today at Roy L. Ash, director of the Office of Management and Budget, and in so doing exposed to the nation a personality clash that has had Washington tongues wagging for weeks.

title: Net of R.J. Reynolds Lifted Mainly by Higher Tobacco Profits
Books of The Times
description: THE PARTNERS. By Louis Auchincloss, 254 pages. Houghton Mifflin, $6.95.

title: HOUSE VOTES FUNDS TO TRY SOLAR HEAT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI) A fiveyear, $50million program to experiment with solar energy to heat and cool homes and business places was approved today by the House.

title: Challenge and Response
description: The Washington energy conference has made significant progress toward reestablishhig unity and purpose among the United States, Canada, Western Europe and Japan in the face of the grave threat to the world economy posed by the Arab oil embargo and the extortionate price increase put through by all members of the oilproducers' cartel.

title: Notes on People
description: Hayley Mills, whose earnings were handsome in the years she was a child actress in such Walt Disney films as Pollyanna, has been ordered by the House of Lords to part with part of the money. Miss Mills had contended that her father, the actor John Mills, had set up a special trust fund to protect her income when she was young, and that she should not now have to pay taxes on income from the trust. An appeals court overruled British tax officials who contended Miss Mills should pay a tax, but a committee of the House of Lords yesterday reversed that ruling. Now the 27yearold Miss Mills will have to hand over about $112,500.

title: LEBANON SEEKING CALM ON BORDER
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 13 Worried over possible reprisals by Israeli, Lebanese officials are raising anxious demands that an end be put, once and for all, to Palestinian commando shooting and raiding across the southern border into Israel.

title: GETTY IS CUTTING PRICE OF FUEL OIL
description: The Getty Oil Company announced yesterday price decreases in its Eastern region of 1.3 cents a gallon on fuel oil and diesel fuel. The price of gasoline was unchanged; it had been raised by 4 cents a gallon earlier in the month.

title: Fuel Shortage Hits India Steel Industry
description: NEW DELHI, Feb, 13India's steel industry, vital to the country's economic development, has been crippled by a fuel shortage and transport bottlenecks aggravated by labor strikes.

title: One Defendant Dropped From Suit by McGovern
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 13 (AP)One of eight defendants was dropped today from a $51.2 million damage suit filed Jan. 29 in the name of Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Steelers to Appeal for Price Increase

title: MESKILL REQUESTS ALLOCATION RIGHT
description: Connecticut joined New York and New Jersey yesterday in attempting to wrestle with the gasoline crisis on statewide basis, but stopped short of setting up a mandatory rationing plan.

title: REVIEW ORDERED ON CITY TAX UNIT
description: Mayor Beame announced yesterday that he had ordered full review of Tax Commission procedures in an attempt to eliminate abuses in the assessment of the city's $40billion in taxable real estate uncovered last year by the State Commission of Investigation.

title: Teleprompter Cancels Plan For Newark Cable System
description: The Teleprompter Corporation said yesterday that it had canceled plans to build a cable television system in Newark. The company said it would write off its Newark investment of some $2.15 million in its 1973 results.

title: Chicago and the Big Apple: Tale of Two Cities
description: CHICAGOTo some outsiders, New York City means getting coshed in Central Park, soot and dirt, being elbowed off the curb by crowds, cringing under the withering glowers of headwaiters and paying twice what something is worth.

title: HUSSEIN STRESSES TIES WITH ARMY
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 13  King Hussein has devoted the last six days to a continual round of meetings in the field with the officers and men of the Jordanian Army in a lowkey campaign to reinforce their, loyalty to the throne.

title: A U.S. COMPROMISE ON TRANSIT HINTED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 13 President Nixon opened the door today to eventual support of a compromise allocation of masstransit subsidies that would improve chances of averting an increase in New York City's 35cent fare.

title: Pro Bowlers Strike Out The Archie Bunker Image
description: Archie Bunker absentmindedly wipes his right hand across the front of his bowling shirt, leaving dirt marks just under the pocket where Joe's Garage is embroidered in red thread. Then he sticks his pudgy fingers into the new bowling ball he got for Christmas.

title: Kuh Is Sworn In
description: Richard H. Kuh, Manhattan's new District Attorney, said yesterday that he would establish, as soon as is feasible, regional offices around the borough so residents could more easily complain about crime.

title: Study Finds Maldistribution of Cardiologists
description: A Federally sponsored manpower study, released yesterday, has found both a shortage and a maldistribution of cardiologists to diagnose and treat the vast array of complex medical problems arising from heart diseasethe nation's No. 1 killer.

title: Legislator Asserts Crime Rose At Willowbrook School in 1973
description: ALBANY, Feb. 13  State Senator Frank Padavan charged today that the State Department of Mental Hygiene had failed to carry out specific security measures recommended by the state police for the Willowbrook State School of Staten Island and that serious crimes at the institution had increased.

title: Braves Rout 76ers With Hot 2d Half
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 (UPI)Bob McAdop paced a balanced attack with 30 points tonight as the Buffalo Braves pulled away in the second half for a 129106 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers in the National Basketball Association.

title: U.S., Britain and Germany Offer to Welcome Author
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the Soviet writer Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn would certainly be welcome to reside in the United States if he desires.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Feb. 5.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 43

title: Crisis Foreseen in South Korea as Park Clamps Down on Foes
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 9 To his supporters, President Park Chung Hee of South Korea is a strong, determined leader. They say, as Premier Kim Jong Pil put it, that he is the only one who can promise us the people and the nationa bright future.

title: Three Injured Seriously In a Wild W.H.A. Game
description: ST. PAUL, Feb. 13, (AP)Mike Antonovich scored twice tonight to lead the Minnesota Fighting Saints to their eighth victory in their last 10 starts with a 74 World Hockey Association triumph over the Edmonton Oilers.

title: PROFESSORS ASSAIL DEBATE SUPPRESSION
description: An arm of the American Association of University Professors assailed yesterday attempts by college students and teachers to suppress research and debate on the question whether heredity is a major factor in intelligence.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MONTVALE, Feb. 13A 12yearold boy ventured up to the counter and asked, Do you have any more Mickey mantle's for 50 cents?

title: Suspect in GunStore Killing Slain Here
description: A suspect linked by ballistics tests to the shooting death of a Fifth Avenue gun merchant on Monday and to the wounding of a policeman the day before was shot and killed yesterday when he returned to a hotel room that had been staked out by the police.

title: 40 Million Rural Americans Feel Pinch Of Sharply Higher Cost of Propane Gas
description: JACKSON, Ga., Feb. 12A year ago, 75yearold Mrs. Lillian Williamson was taking about $30 a month out of her $153 Social Security check to pay for the bottled propane gas that fuels the little space heater that fights back the winter chill in her weathered, linoleum floored house.

title: MRS. FANNIE E. SEIFERT
description: Mrs. Fannie Fisen Seifert, an interior designer who carried on her own bu3iness in Forest Hills, Queens, for many years, died of cancer yesterday in Parkway Hospital. She was 75 years old, the widow of Nathan Seifert, a salesman, and she lived at 6864 Yellowstone Boulevard in Forest Hills.

title: Loss of Revenue by Pikes A Worry to Bond Buyers
description: BERGENFIELD, Feb. 13 Gasoline shortages are biting so deeply into travel on the metropolitan area's major turnpikes that Wall Street analysts for the first time are beginning to worry about the longterm stability of the toll roads.

title: Justice Department Sets Up 2 Units to Deal With Fraud
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI) The Justice Department an nounced today that it was setting up two new units to deal with increasing mortgage frauds and other frauds including sophisticated schemes that reach into foreign countries.

title: LASER Assists Computer
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing (3M) Company introduced yesterday what it said was the first computer output microfilm system using a laser to record information. 3M said its Laser Beam Recorder could record highquality symbols on both microfiche cards and roll microfilm, forming a latent image that is developed by heat without the use of liquid chemicals.

title: Pike Revenue Losses Worrying Bond Buyers
description: BERGENFIELD, Feb. 13 Gasoline shortages are biting so deeply into travel on the metropolitan area's major turnpikes that Wall Street analysts for the first time are beginning to worry about the longterm stability of the toll roads.

title: Gasoline Shortage Hurting Sales of Stores in Suburbs
description: The gasoline shortage is beginning to affect shopping in suburban stores sharply in the metropolitan area.

title: Alexander's May Open Sunday as Test of Law
description: Alexander's, Inc., one of New York's largest retailers, plans to open its five stores in the city Sunday in what it hopes will be a test case of the state's blue laws, according to authoritative trade reports yesterday.

title: STATE'S SURPLUS SOUGHT FOR CITIES
description: ALBANY, Feb. 13The Big Six Mayors, as well as heads of dozens of organizations, told members of the legislative finance committees today that the state's fiscal position was extremely sound and that more money should be allocated to cities.

title: Union Carbide to Expand
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday it would spend $4.3million to expand its lowdensity polyethylene plant in a suburb of Melbourne, Australia. Lowdensity polyethylene is used to make packaging films.

title: Air Force Chief Pleased
description: Air Force Secretary John L. McLucas says the service is getting a higher standard of recruit and is completely satisfied with the all volunteer force.

title: HOWARD E. STERNAU
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 13Howard E. Sternau, a partner in the publicaccounting firm here of Sternau & Shulman, died yesterday at his home, 15 Midchester Place. He was 68 years old.

title: $2,000 IN CASH FOUND IN SAFE COSTING $20
description: A safe purchased for $20 six months ago turned out to hold $2,000 in cash and $213,315.60 in negotiable bonds yesterday after the buyer, a professional mover, asked a Queens locksmith to open it to see what was inside.

title: LAWYERS TO BRIEF INQUIRY ON NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13Members of the House Judiciary Commited are expected to receive at a staff briefing tomorrow their first direct evidence of President Nixon's willingness to cooperate with the panel's impeachment inquiry.

title: Attack on Illegal Aliens Under a Federal Inquiry
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 13 (UPI) Federal agents have begun an inquiry into the robbery, rape and unprovoked attack of nine men and seven women from Mexico and Central America who crossed the United States Mexican border illegally.

title: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE
CORRECTION
description: In Monday's issue of The New York Times it was reported incorrectly that Lundy's Restaurant in Sheepshead Bay was closed. The restaurant was closed for a time last fall, hut has since reopened.

title: Veterans' Pension Aid to Widows Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) The widows of many veterans received smaller pension checks from the Veterans Administration Feb. 1 because of a provision in the Social Security law that took effect a year ago. Other widows lost their pensions entirely.

title: Music: Exciting Debut
description: It is a clich that some musicians would have been outstanding no matter on what instrument they chose to perform. It is a clich that must be applied to Grace SungEn Wong, a 24yearold American who lives in New York. She is a harpist, and in her local debut recital in Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night, as part of the Carnegie HallJeunesses Musicales series, she established herself as above all an exciting musician.

title: Bronx Landlords Demand City Approve Rent Rises
description: The Bronx Realty Advisory Board, whose members are landlords of 750,000 Bronx residents, gave the city until Saturday to approve rent rises that the owners say are needed to make up for increased Iabor costs.

title: AGNEW ON COAST FOR BENNY FETE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP)  Former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew is in California, reportedly to attend the 80th birthday celebration of Jack Beeny, the comedian, this weekend and to spend some time with Frank Sinatra, the singer, in Palm Springs.

title: Fuel Costs Passing To Bus Commuters
description: Commuters in the New York metropolitan area who travel to work by buses that cross state lines will have to pay higher fares as a result of recent rises in the cost of the diesel fuel the buses use.

title: STROLLER GETS PART OF BANK THUGS' LOOT
description: A passerby got part of the loot yesterday morning when four robbers, fleeing after holding up the Astoria branch of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company at 2121 Broadway, dropped some of $29,054 they had stolen.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Public Utility Commission ordered Atlantic City to close its landfill garbage dump within 30 days for operating without required permits. A spokesman for the P.U.C. said the order had been issued because the dump, which takes some 60 truckloads of refuse daily, has operated in violation of the Solid Waste Act since 1970.

title: Byrne Moves for Repeal of Covenant Curbing Port Authority Transit Aid
description: TRENTON, Feb. 13  Governor Byrne announced today he would ask the Legislature on Friday to repeal a 1962 covenant on bonds issued by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, that precludes the bistate agency's involvement in masstransit projects that could lose money.

title: Golenpaul of Information Please Dies
description: Dan Golenpaul, the creator of Information Please, the famous radio quiz show that had many imitators over the years, died last evening at his home, 30 East 65th Street. He was 73 years old and had been ill for some time.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: Sacramento, Calif.  Jean Mateo, 161 pounds. Stockton, Calif., outpointed Carlos Salinas, 164, San Jose, Calif., 10 rounds.

title: FUND DISCLOSURE BACKED BY WOMEN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13A group bf women who will run this fall for public offices ranging from Governor of Texas to member of Congress from Brooklyn all pledged today to make public their income tax returns and all details concerning the financing of their campaigns.

title: SILVER FUTURES RISE DAILY LIMIT
description: Prices of all silver bullion futures, except the current delivery, were bid up the daily limit of 15 cents an ounce once again here yesterday.

title: Byrne Seeks End of Curbs On Port Agency in Transit
description: TRENTON, Feb. 13  Governor Byrne announced today the would ask the Legislature on Friday to repeal a 1962 covenant on bonds issued by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey that precludes the bistate agency's involve ment in masstransit projects that could lose money.

title: Gas Fells 21 Firemen
description: APOPKA, Fla., Feb. 13 (UPI)  Twentyone volunteer firemen were overcome by chlorine gas fumes last night while fighting a blaze at the Jellystone Park Campground. Three were in serious condition.

title: 12 NATIONS AGREE ON ENERGY GOALS; FRANCE DISSENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13The United States and 11 other major oilconsuming nations overrode strong French objections today and agreed on the need for a comprehensive action program to deal with the energy crisis.

title: OIL CRISIS BRINGS A DIVERSIFICATION
description: Toray Industries, one of Japan's largest producers of plastics and fibers, has begun a wide diversification to offset the effect of the shortages in petrochemicals and energy, Kizo Yasui, chairman, said here yesterday.

title: People in Sports: AliQuarry Off Again After Being On Again
description: After Muhammad Ali reportedly changed his mind three or four times in the same day, the onagain, offagain fight between All and Jerry Quarry was called offagain, At least, there'll be no Madison Square Garden news conference today to announce the bout that was penciled in for May 13, erased and then reported set as late as yesterday.

title: Brooklyn Man Saves Girl, 2, From Drowning
description: A 2yearold Brooklyn girl found lying unconscious and face down in her bathwater last night was revived by a passerby identified by the police as Carmine Tinerono, 50, of 285 Cozine Avenue, in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: FISHING JURISDICTION EXTENDED BY OREGON
description: SALEM, Ore., Feb. 13 (UPI) Oregon has extended its jurisdiction over coastal fishing activities to 50 miles offshore despite a worning by its Governor that such a limit would be unenforceable.

title: SIR LESLIE MUNRO, DIPLOMAT, 72, DIES
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Feb. 13 (UPI)  Sir Leslie Munro, former president of the United Nations General Assembly, died today at his Hamilton home, 80 miles from here. He was 72 years old.

title: Fairleigh to Charge Only Half Tuition For Siblings and Spouses of Students
description: RUTHERFORD, Feb. 13 Fairleigh Dickinson University's board of trustees approved today a payment plan under which brothers, sisters, husbands or wives of fulltime students in the school will be charged only half tuition.

title: Penguins Turn Back Wings, 53
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb, 13 (UPI)John Pronovost scored two goals tonight as the Pittsburgh Penguins defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 53, in a National Hockey League game.

title: Bonn Ends Impasse in Strike, Offering Service Workers 11%
description: BONN, Feb 13 (UPI)The West German Cabinet agreed today to an 11 per cent wage increase for public service employes, ending an impasse in the strike that has crippled they country's transportation ands mail system for three days, a spokesman said.

title: Selling Drive Hailed As Army Tops Goal For National Guard
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) The Army National Guard climbed back to its authorized strength last month for the first time since the draft ended.

title: Aramco Terms Reports On Saudis Speculation
description: The Arabian American Oil Company said yesterday that various statements had been made by Saudi Arabian officials to the effect that the existing plan for the Saudis to take over 51 per cent of Aramco no longer represented a viable objective. But the company said that news reports saying that the Government would shortly demand 100 per cent ownership were based on speculation.

title: The Birthday Party
description: By ironic coincidence, a report that hotel interests were protesting plans to hold a fundraising birthday party for Mayor Beame aboard the Queen Elizabeth 2 appeared in this newspaper yesterday on the same page with a progress report on a huge current project to modernize three Hudson River passenger terminals.

title: Fuel Costs Passing To Bus Commuters
description: Commuters in the New York metropolitan area who travel to work by buses that cross state lines will have to pay higher fares as a result of recent rises, in the cost of the diesel fuel the buses use.

title: Army to Appeal Ban On Discharge Codes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI)  The Army says it plans to appeal a Federal court ruling that bans the 25yearold Army practice of coding honorable discharges to indicate that some soldiers are troublemakers.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits testified at a Federal hearing here yesterday that the city's subway system was not safe enough because of inadequate emergency evacuation procedure, crippling noise levels and crime on the upsurge. He told a Federal Railroad Administration hearing officer that riders therefore are not getting their 35 cents worth,

title: 12 NATIONS AGREE AT ENERGY PARLEY ON NEED FOR PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13The United States and 11 other major oilconsuming nations overrode strong French objections today and agreed on the need for a comprehensive action program to deal with the energy crisis.

title: Gas Rationing Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) The Young Americans for Freedom announced a campaign in opposition to plans for gasoline rationing today. The group's chairman, Ronald F. Docksai, told a news conference that some 200 members around the country would write letters and lobby their congressmen.

title: Dissident Russian Writer in Exile
CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: PRICES ARE MIXED IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday on increasing hopes for a?? early relaxation of the Arab oi?? embargo but with many of these balanced by renewed fears of further cuts in Arab oil output In the overthecounter market, prices dropped in steppedup trading.

title: Nonesuch Records Turns 10, Spins On
description: Ten years ago today, on Valentine's Day of 1964, an unknown new record company named Nonesuch announced its first releases. Since then, Nonesuch has issued some 400 high quality, budgetpriced records and has established itself as perhaps the most adventuresome classical label in this country.

title: Indian Critics See Rot in Government
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 13A wave of bitter and emotional allegations involving corruption, rot and disillusion with democracy has struck the Indian Government.

title: Roberts Terms Mackell's Reputation Very Good
description: Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts, who had been expected to testify as a strong witness for the state's case against Thomas J. Mackell, the former Queens District Attorney, yesterday described Mr. Mackell's reputation for truth and honesty as very good.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: MRS. NORMAN P. AUBURN
description: AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 13  Mrs. Kathleen Montgomery Auburn, the wife of Dr. Norman P. Auburn, former acting president of. Polytechnic Institute of New York in Brooklyn and, president emeritus of the University of Akron, died today. She was 65 years old.

title: TV: Expert Advisers
description: There was nothing unusual about homosexuals figuring prominently in the plot of Tuesday evening's Police Story. Homosexuals are no longer rare oddities on television series. In this case, the unusual took place off camera. Members of the Gay Media Task Force in California were recruited by the producers as consultants on the episode's script.

title: Jipcho Not Afraid of Indoor Bugaboos
description: Professional track is keen on Kenya. To begin its second season, the International Track Association was assured yesterday of another recordholder from that country in its lineup when Ben Jipcho flew here from Nairobi to match strides with his countryman, Kipchoge Keino; Jim Ryun and other milers tomorrow night at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Grant Deadline Extended
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI) The Office of Education today extended to April 1 the deadline for needy college students to submit applications for basic educational opportunity grants. Based on the financial need of the student and his family the grants have been averaging $260. The deadline was extended from Feb. 1 to accommodate potentially eligible students who may not have been aware of the grants being offered this year for the first time, the agency said.

title: News Summary and Index THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 14, 1974
description: International

title: Arts to Get Long Week in Albany
description: ALBANY, Feb. 13Amyas Ames, chairman of Lincoln Center, said today that organizations across the state would wage a massive lobbying effort for passage of the full $30.5million for the arts sought in Governor Wilson's budget.

title: Mideast Using Oil Funds To Spur Industrialization
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 12 Using vastly increased earnings from oil exports and bargaining power from the world's hunger for oil, the producer nations of the Middle East are making great strides in the negotiation of deals that will industrialize their nations and give them a new share of world trade.

title: Advertising: For Public Health
description: Two major announcements dealing with advertising and health were made yesterday. The first concers a new publicservice campaign by the Advertising Council, while the second involves a new syndicated television series called Today's Health.

title: Van Brings a Possibility of Food Stamps to Aged
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 13  A mobile unit today began an effort to enroll elderly Hudson County residents and other eligibles in the food stamp program, with a visit to the Duncan Gardens development, a cluster of 12story, red brick, buildings at 320 Duncan Avenue, off Route 19 here.

title: Court Impounds Oil Cited in Lefkowitz Complaint
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice yesterday ordered a temporary embargo on the unsold remainder of one million barrels of homeheating oil that the state charges was diverted and hidden by four oil companies as part of a scheme to gouge residential consumers.

title: Louisiana's Gov. Edwards: Cajun With a Populist Tinge and Much Ambition
description: MARKSVILLE, La., Feb. 8The difference is felt as soon as the mail boxes say Le Bland instead of Johnson. The suspicion and reserve that are considered proper in Mississippi and Tennessee melt away. Waitresses greet the stranger with How you been, Cher? instead of What'll you have?

title: Paultz's 30 Points Lead Nets to 123117 Victory
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 13 Billy Paultz put on a show for his father, Bill Sr., and his mother, Sophie, tonight in the Nassau Coliseum, scoring 30 points to lead the New York Nets to a 123117 victory over the Virginia Squires.

title: U.S. Supplies of Gasoline Feb. 8 Above Feb. 1 but Below '73 Level
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI)United States supplies of gasoline as of Feb. 8 were up from the preceding week and down from a year ago, the American Petroleum Institute said today.

title: More Law Schools Are Sprouting Here as Popularity of the Profession Increases
description: For several weeks last fall, The Paper Chase, a comedy about a naive Midwesterner grinding his way through his first year at Harvard Law School, was among the 10 most popular films in the country.

title: Personal Finance
description: You tell the banker you need $3,000 for some worthwhile purpose. He says O.K. and reminds you that he charges 5 per cent, discounted. When the loan papers arrive, you discover that in order to get the $3,000 you need, you have to borrow considerably moreand pay all of the interest in advance.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 43

title: Kodes Upset by Dibley; Roche Shows Old Form
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, Feb. 13 (AP)Colin Dibley, the hardserving Australian, upset secondseeded Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia, 36, 63, 64, in the second round of the $50,000 World Championship Tennis Circuit tournament today.

title: Walston Expects End Within 90 Days
description: DuPont Walston, Inc., the big Wall Street firm that announced 24 days ago that it was quitting the securities business, will be defunct within 90 days, according to Walter E. Auch, its president.

title: Health Insurance Groups Call Services Mandated by New Law Too Expensive
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 Federal health officials, who are now writing the regulations to implement the new Health Maintenance Organization Assistance Act, have run into a conflict with the administrators of many of the programs that served as models for the law.

title: AUTO SALES DOWN 25% FOR FEB. 110
description: DETROIT, Feb. 13United States auto workers reported yesterday that for the first 10 days of February they sold 145,594 cars, off from last year's total of 218,785. The daily rate in eight selling days was 18,199, compared with 24,310 in nine days last year, a decline of 25.1 per cent.

title: 3 Bronx TeenAgers Held In Slaying of Cab Driver
description: Three teenagers were arrested yesterday in the slaying of a 57yearold cab driver Monday in the Bronx during an attempted robbery.

title: Donohue Finds Retirement a Tough Road to Follow
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 13Mark Donohue sat down wearily, a bad cold and selfdoubt having eaten away his energy over the last few days. He still doesn't look as if he'll be 37 ears old next month, but he says he feels it, and the way he says it, you know it's true.

title: Do Something!
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13Confronting the demon of economic downturn, President Nixon extended his arms, flashed the ancient thumbsup sign, and pronounced the mystic incantation: There will be no recession.

title: SIOUX LAND LOSS IS CITED AT TRIAL
description: ST. PAUL, Feb. 13  An Indian land officer testified under crossexamination in the Wounded Knee trial today that Sioux Indians no longer owned all the lend ceded to them by the Federal Government in the Indian Treaty of 1868.

title: REINECKE CONFERS ON LEGAL STATUS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 Lieut. Gov. Ed Reinecke of California is in the capital confirming with the Watergate special prosecutor's office to determine if he is going to be indicted.

title: Knicks Beat Bulls With Rally, 89  80
description: We had cement in our shoes, said Bill Bradley of the Knicks. If we had played the whole game the way we did in the first quarter, we'd be in the East River,

title: 1972 Death of Harry Gold Revealed
description: Harry Gold who served 15 years in Federal prison as a confessed atomic spy courier for Klaus Fuchs, a Soviet agent, and who was a key Government witness in the Julius and Ethel Rosenberg espionage case in 1951, died 18 months ago in Philadelphia without any public announcement, The New York Times has learned.

title: Charles F. Beck, Headed SchoolMuseum Program
description: Charles F. Beck, an art teacher, who had been in charge of the schoolmuseum program of the Board of Education, died Tuesday at the Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center. He was 68 years old and lived in Cooks Falls, N.Y.

title: Pass Through
description: In the absence of any adequate governmental program for a fair sharing of the sacrifices made necessary by the energy shortage, many groups are immunizing themselves against the pinch of higher fuel costs by simply passing along the extra charges to their customers.

title: Basketball, Hockey Standings
description: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n

title: Gold and Silver Prices Lower On London's Bullion Exchanges
description: LONDON, Feb. 13 (UPI)Profit taking pushed gold and silver prices lower today, in trading on London's big bullion exchanges. The dollar rose against four major European currencies, but declined slightly against others.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Syracuse Ends Manhattan Streak at 8
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 13Dennis DuVal, Syracuse's allAmerica guard from Westbury, L.I., scored 30 points tonight and helped the Orange to a 7670 basketball victory over Manhattan at Manly fieldhouse.

title: Four at Interpublic Win Robert E. Healy Awards
description: The first Robert E. Healy Awardnamed for the honorary chairman and former head of the Interpublic Group of Companies from 1967 through 1971were presented to four executives of the organization at a luncheon yesterday.

title: Europe's Nine Support Algeria's Call for a Special U.N. Session
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 13The nine European Common Market countries today endorsed Algeria's call for a special session of the General Assembly on raw materials and economic development.

title: Lawyer, a Swiss, Will Meet Solzhenitsyn for First Time
description: GENEVA, Feb. 13  Fritz Heeb, the Swiss lawyer who handles Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's affairs in the Western world, will see the author tomorrow in West Germany. The meeting, announced by the lawyer's secretary at his office in Zurich, will be their first.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DANCE New Yorkers will get their first look this week at Stimmung, the work that opened in Brussels in late 1972 and that is a collaboration of Maurice Mart, the choreographer, and Karlheinz Stockhausen, the contemporary composer. Stimmung will be done today and tomorrow at 8 in Carnegie Hall, 57th Street and Seventh Avenue (CI 77459).

title: Native Son
description: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn is a Russian born and bred. His imagination is possessed by the landscape of his native land with the sweep of its vast plains, its dense marshes and deep forests, its changing aspects from arctic North to warm Crimea. His conscience as a man and as an artist is engaged by the history and sufferings of this generation and of earlier generations of the Russian people, their groping for liberty, their capacity for stoic endurance, their courage.

title: Horses Pouring In For Big it Opening
description: Activity began at Aqueduc yesterday in preparation fo the earliest thoroughbred racing season in New York State history. The campaign will open a week from Monday at the Big A and wilembrace 262 racing days. Besides Aqueduct, the sport will he presented at Belmont Park and at Saratoga.

title: ELMER W. SILVER
description: HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Feb. 13

title: HEARINGS MANDATED ON MISSING IN ACTION
description: A threejudge Federal court ruled here yesterday that the armed services must give notice to next of kin and an opportunity for a hearing before persons missing in action are reclassified as dead.

title: Washington Lottery Voted
description: OLYMPIA, Wash., Feb. 13 (UPI)  The Washington State Legislature has passed a lottery bill, clearing the way for the state to become the ninth in the nation to legalize the contest.

title: Nixon Termed in Excellent Condition
description: MIAMI, Feb. 13  After a twomonth delay, President Nixon underwent his annua physical examination today and his doctor declared him to be in excellent condition, showing neither emotional not physical signs of the strait that he has been under for the last year.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Miss Woodward Out of Dance

title: CON ED INCREASES WILL VARY WIDELY
description: Consolidated Edison's increased fuel costs will mean more than twice as much of an increase in electric rates this month for the average residential customer in Westchester County and Staten Island as for the one in the Bronx because they use more electricity.

title: Dividend Is Increased By Gull and Western
description: Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., raised yesterday the regular quarterly dividend on its common stock to 20 cents a share, up from 18 cents.

title: Caliber Fund Inquiry Involves Possible Forgeries
description: City Investigation Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta has turned over evidence to District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx of possible forgeries in the handling of campaign contributions to State Senate Joseph L. Caliber, according to sources close to the investigation.

title: Fuel Costs Passing To Bus Commuters
description: Commuters in the New York metropolitan area who travel to work by buses that cross state lines will have to pay higher fares as a result of recent rises, in the cost of the diesel fuel the buses use.

title: The Power and the Glory
description: BOSTON, Feb. 13  In Leningrad past April 1 met a Soviet systems analyst. He was a clever and a supremely confident man, who saw himself as an engineer not only of computers but of human souls; He foresaw the day of a new Soviet man, with his psychological drives all channeled into socially useful activity.

title: Consumer Notes
description: The average supermarket, with perhaps 8,000 or 10,000 items on the shelves, can be a confusing place, even for the experienced shopper. Some companies compete not only against one another, but also against themselves.

title: EXTENSION ASKED IN AID TO JOBLESS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  The Administration proposed today legislation for a $1billion contingency program that would extend unemployment insurance benefits to workers who lose their jobs in areas of high and persistent unemployment.

title: Hearst Plans Counteroffer to Kidnappers
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 13The Symbionese Liberation Army's multimilliondollar ransom demand was rejected by Patricia Hearst's father today as impossible to meet. He promised to present a counteroffer in 24 to 48 hours.

title: Mideast Using Oil Funds To Spur Industrialization
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 12 Using vastly increased earnings from oil exports and bargaining power from the world's hunger for oil, the producer nations of the Middle East are making great strides in the negotiation of deals that will industrialize their nations and give them a new share of world trade.

title: Suit on Rothko Estate Starts Today
description: More than two years after it was initiated, the Mark Rothko case, possibly the most discussed art lawsuit since the painter James McNeil Whistler sued the critic John Ruskin for libel in 1878, goes en trial here today in Surrogate's Court.

title: Expulsion by Soviet Highly Unusual Step
description: The forcible exile of national from the Soviet Union, as happened to Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn yesterday, is highly unusual step without apparent basis in existing Soviet law.

title: Consolidation of Matters In MCI Suit on A.T.&T. Set
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit here has ruled that all matters pertaining to the suit of the MCI Communications Corporation against the American Telephone & Telegraph Company must be consolidated and heard by the Court of Appeals in Philadelphia, it was learned yesterday.

title: The Ghost of Malthus in South Asia
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J.  The world must await with exceeding apprehension the first test case of what happens when the resources and economy of a vast segment of the world stop supporting a growing population even at subsistence level. The test case will surely be India and Bangladesh, and also will involve most other South Asian countries Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Nepal and the Maldives. The quality of life in this region has already begun to decline, with the fabric of society unraveling. And no man has been wise enough to think of a solution.

title: Soccer Enthusiasts Flock to Theater TV
description: Don't use my name, I don't want to get fired, an elementary school teacher whispered inside the Academy of Music Theater on East 14th Street yesterday afternoon.

title: Dog Fanciers Honor Fletcher of The Times
description: For the first time in its two decades, the Dog Fanciers Club has made an award. It honored Walter R. Fletcher of The New York Times yesterday with a plaque and a citation that said:

title: Hearst Plans Counteroffer to Kidnappers
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 13The Symbionese Liberation Army's multimilliondollar ransom demand was rejected by Patricia Hearst's father today as impossible to meet. He promised to present a counteroffer in 24 to 48 hours.

title: HENRY CHANIN
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 13Henry Chanin, former national tournament bridge player, died here yesterday at, Good Samaritan Hospital. His age was 76, and he lived here.

title: BYRNE TO ASK RAISES FOR AIDES IN CABINET
description: TRENTON, Feb. 13 (AP) Governor Byrne announced today that legislation would be introduced Friday to provide all members of his cabinet with raises.

title: Midseason Correction Lifts A.B.C. to Second Place
description: The American Broadcasting Company television network, which has been lagging seriously in the ratings from September to January, has significantly improved its competitive position with several programs that were introduced at midseason.

title: Cable Car Crash Hurts 4
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13 (UPI)The city's only new cable car had its first collision yesterday  with a municipal railway busand four persons were injured.The car was built last spring to celebrate the 100th annversary of cable car service.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Bob Kovner is General Manager of Los Angeles Sample Division of WILLCOX & GIBBS (WGAMEX)ADVT.

title: Frankie James, Gladys Feldman Of The Ziegfeld Follies, Dead
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Feb. 13  Mrs. Frankie James Spitz, who broke into show business in George M. Cohan's 45 Minutes from Broadway at the age of 14, died today at her home here. She was 72 years old.

title: Judge Bars Pay Rollback For Policemen in Nassau
description: Judge Walter J. Bruchhausen of Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday signed a temporary restraining order enjoining the Cost of Living Council from lowering to 5 per cent the 7 per cent increase that went into effect on Jan. 1 for the 4,000 policemen in Nassau County.

title: Germans Acclaim Writer At Heinrich Mll's Home
description: LANGENBROICH, West Germany, Feb. 13  Clutching bouquet of daffodils he bought on his arrival at the Frankfurt airport, Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn arrived in this tiny farming village in the Eifel bills at 7:10 tonight and was kissed on both cheeks by his host, the novelist Heinrich Boll.

title: Turning Point for U.S. Education
description: For reasons ranging from the calendar to red tape to Watergate, 1974 is shaping up as a turning point for the Federal role in education.

title: Foreman Divorce Clouds Title Bout
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 13 (AP) George Foreman, the world heavyweight boxing champion, testified in court today that his appearance here for a divorce action might force him to call off his scheduled title fight with Ken Norton March 26 in Caracas, Venezuela.

title: Further Cuts in Oil Output Are Considered by Kuwait
description: KUWAIT, Feb. 13 (AP)Kuwaiti authorities are considering a further sharp slash in oil output, according to a high official.

title: TROOPER RECALLS SHOOTING ON PIKE
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 13 James M. Harper, a 29yearold state trooper, described today the shootout on the New Jersey Turnpike near here last May 2 in which one trooper was killed and he was wounded. Clark D. Squire, identified by the police as a member of the alleged Black Liberation Army, is on trial for murder in connection with the killing.

title: JERUSALEM POLICE SEIZE 12 IN BLASTS
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 13 (UPI) Officials said today that they police had arrested 12 men, including two members of Rabbi Meir Kahane's militant Jewish Defense League, in connection with the firebombing, this week of three Christian institutions.

title: Governor Presses Simon For Increase in Gasoline
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13Governor Wilson recited Latin and statistics today in his quest for Federal emergency gasoline allocations for New York State. But the Governor also did something on his own to help the state's hardship areas by allocating 3 per cent of the New York February total of 357million gallons of gasoline to these areas as an emergency allotment.

title: British Miners Refuse to Allow More Coal for Power Stations
description: LONDON, Feb. 13 (AP)Striking coal miners announced a complete ban on replenishing dwindling coal stocks at Britain's power stations today and other unions said they would go along by refusing to transport coal.

title: LAWMAKERS FACE RESIDENCY TEST
description: Some Republican state legislators are being shadowed to their real homes, which are outside their legislative districts, Mathew J. Troy Jr., the Queens Democratic leader, said yesterday.

title: ABDUL ASSIZ SUABI, ISRAELI HEALTH AIDE
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 14Deputy Minister of Health Abdul Assiz Suabi, who held the highest Israeli political office attained by an Arab, died today of a heart attack. He was 48 years old.

title: Hearst Scores Saxbe Kidnapping View
description: HILLSBOROUGH, Calif., Feb. 14Offhand remarks made today at a news conference by Attorney General William B. Saxbe were described by Randolph A. Hearst as damn near irresponsible when considered against the effort to negotiate the release of his kidnapped daughter, Patricia.

title: Text of Jaworski's Letter to Senate Panel on White House Refusal to Yield Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14Following is the text of a letter from Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, to Senator James O. Eastland, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, informing him of the White House's refusal to provide tape recordings and other data. Both Mr. Jaworski and the White House declined to release the White House letter on the ground that it was confidential.

title: Max Schaffer, 83, Who Operated Hubert's Museum, Arcades, Dies
description: Max Schaffer, who for many years operated Hubert's Museum, which included the wellknown flea circus, and other penny arcades on 42d Street, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, at St. Clare's Hospital, He was 83 years old and lived at the Mayflower Hotel, Central Park West at 61st Street.

title: STORMKING ACTION DELAYED BY P.S. C.
description: ALBANY, Feb. 14  The state's Public Service Commission refused today to ratify the $200million contract that the Consolidated Edison Company had signed with a consortium of three construction companies to build the controversial pumpedstorage generating plant at Storm King Mountain in CornwallonHudson. But the commission indicated it would reconsider the matter later.

title: Argentine Guerrillas Promise to Step Up Attacks
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 14In an, underground news conference, leaders of the most important leftist guerrilla group Argentina vowed today to step up their attacks against the military and threatened to kill an army officer kidnapped last month.

title: Regina L. Ross Is Bride of Derek Cohn
description: Miss Regina L. Ross and Derek Cohn were married here yesterday evening at the Carlyle Hotel by Rabbi Ronald Sobel of Temple EmanuEl.

title: OTB Proposal for Connecticut Draws 32 Approval at Hearing
description: Sentiment in favor of a working agreement on offtrack betting between Connecticut and the New York Racing Association, Yonkers Raceway and Roosevelt Raceway prevailed at the open hearing on the subject held yesterday.

title: Big Board Head Warns On Impact of Fee Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 The head of the New York Stock Exchange said today that exchange markets will be dismantled in short order after brokerage commissions become fully competitive next year unless Congress mandates the trading of stocks on the floor of registered national exchanges.

title: Where Congressmen Serve Voters and Seek Votes
description: Sometimes this place seems like a menagerie, Mrs. Francine Siedlecki, who heads the staff at Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal's district office in Flushing, Queens, said the other day.

title: City Notes First Case Of Siphon Pneumonia
description: The city's first documented case of chemical pneumonia caused by swallowing gasoline during siphoning from a car was reported yesterday by the Department of Health.

title: Kibbee Decries Cuts in CommunityCollege Budgets
description: ALBANY, Feb. 14  Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, the City University Chancellor, warned today that unless $11.1million in state aid was restored to the city's communitycollege budget, most major programs for disadvantaged students would be dismantled anti cutbacks in career programs would be necessary.

title: Lyn Seltzer, City Aide, Marries Miss Miller
description: Miss Jacqueline Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Hudson Miller, was married here yesterday noon to Lyn Seltzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Seltzer of West Orange, N. J. The Rev. Melvin Hawthorne, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: Bridge: Inexperienced Players Get A Chance in Tourney Here
description: After a lapse of several years, the Greater New York Bridge Association has decided to revive its special programs for the inexperienced tournament player.

title: Liver Cancer Alert Declared to Protect Plastics Workers
description: As physician for the B.F. Goodrich chemical plant in Louisville, Ky., Dr. John L. Creech Jr. examines all employes returning to work after an illness. He was struck recently by the large number of serious liver ailments among the workers, compared with patients he saw in his private surgical practice.

title: Solzhenitsyn, Pondering Future, Plans Swiss Visit
description: LANGENBROICH, West Germany, Feb. 14Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, spending his first) day in exile, consulted today with Russian friends and with his Swiss lawyer about what to do next. The lawyer said tonight that Mr. Solzhenitsyn would go to Zurich tomorrow, but did not say how long he would stay.

title: Hussein Said to Urge an Israeli Pullback To Western Edge of the Jordan Valley
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 14King Hussein has proposed that Israel abandon her positions along the Jordan River and withdraw to the western edge of the Jordan Valley as the first stage in an IsraeliJordanian settlement, according to authoritative Government sources here.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space, working group on remote sensing of the earth and task force of the working group10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Abrams Cites Intelligence Gained From Soviet Arms in Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, the Army Chief of Staff, said today that one of the most impressive lessons of the October Middle East war was that Soviet military equipment had surprisingly extensive means of defending against chemical, biological and radiological attack.

title: Ideas on Oil Money Offered by Shultz
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 The United States made public today a long list of ideas and suggestions for dealing with the purely financial problems raised for the world by the huge increase in the price of oil.

title: Liver Cancer Alert Declared to Protect Plastics Workers
description: As physician for the B.F. Goodrich chemical plant in Louisville, Ky., Dr. John L. Creech Jr. examines all employes returning to work after an illness. He was struck recently by the large number of serious liver ailments among the workers, compared with patients he saw in his private surgical practice.

title: Title Giant Slalom Races Put Off
description: The national giant slalom championships, scheduled to have been held at Vermont's Stratton Mountain next Wednesday and Thursday, suddenly found themselves without a home yesterday. The reason? Lack of sufficient snow at that resort's higher elevations.

title: Bejart Makes a Ritual of Stimmung
Milk Group's Aid to Nixon Reportedly Hidden in '72
description: At least $200,000 in contributions for Republican Congressional condidates was diverted in 1972 to the Finance Committee to Reelect the President as part of an elaborate scheme to launder money promised by milk producers for President Nixon's campaign, according to Congressional sources.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters

title: CONCEALING DATA LAID TO MACKELL
description: The assistant United States Attorney in charge of the Federal investigation into a confidence racket masterminded by Joseph Ferdinando suggested to a jury yesterday that Thomas J. Mackell and two codefendants had concealed their knowledge about the scheme from him.

title: Patronage Plunder
description: The pay is excellent$30,000 to $40,000 or more. The work, if any, is minimal. Qualifications are practically nilall that is required is the right political connections.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: OneYear Minimum for Parole Upheld

title: 20th in Row for Pitt
description: PITTSBURG. Feb. 14 (AP) Billy Knight and Lew Hill scored 17 points each and four others scored in double figures tonight as seventhranked Pittburgh, streaking to its 20th consecutive victory, drubbed Cleveland State, 10655.

title: BOYS WILL ENROLL AT HUNTER SCHOOL
description: Hunter College agreed yesterday to admit boys to its allgirl high school for the first time since the facility was opened for intellectually gifted young women 105 years ago.

title: Fishermen Keep Boats Docked In Bid to Raise Price of Whiting
description: MIDDLETOWN TOWNSHIP, Feb. 14  A Hose organization of fishermen from Ocean County to Great Neck, L. I., kept their boats docked today in and effort to raise the price of whiting in the New York metropolitan area.

title: FOUR ARE INDICTED IN SECURITIES CASE
description: Four men, including a former Swiss bank official, were indicted here yesterday on charges of securities violations and mail fraud in the sale and distribution in 1969 of stock in Training With the Pros.

title: LATE CITY EDITION
description: Weather: Mostly sunny, cold today cloudy and cold tonight, tomorrow. Temp. range: today 1325; Thursday 3047. Additional details on Page 66.

title: NATURE OF INQUIRY ON NIXON AT ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  Attorneys for the White House and the House Judiciary Committee have avoided a confrontation but are in apparent disagreement about the fundamental nature of the committee's inquiry into whether President Nixon should be impeached.

title: Hotels for Mental Cases Protested on West Side
description: The Upper West Side, often a turbulent test tube for social experiment, is again in process of eruptionthis time on the subject of housing of released mental patients in hotels.

title: Turkey Tells U.S. She Will Resume Opium Cultivation
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 14 (UPI)Turkey has notified the United States that it will resume cultivation of the opium poppy, banned 13 months ago at Washington's request, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: NIXON IS HECKLED IN MIAMI ADDRESS
description: MIAMI, Feb. 14While President Nixon spoke today at a St. Valentine's Day dedication of a hospital center, a chorus of voices at the rear of the crowd shouted intermittently, Impeach Nixon Now.

title: Greevy, Noll Gain Court Tennis Final
description: BOSTON, Feb. 14Tom Greevy and Eddie Noll reached the final of the United States professional court tennis singles championship today at the Boston Racquet and Tennis Club.

title: TV: Apple's Way and Search for Human Values
description: Reports, reliable and unreliable, have it that the television schedule next fall will be stuffed with human values, courtesy of this season's success of The Waltons. In fact, the inevitable duplication race has already begun, most notably with Apple's Way, which just happens to be produced by the same people who bring you The Waltons week after inspirational week.

description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 14The original idea was to decide the best automobile racer in the world tomorrow, be he a grand prix driver or stockcar demon. The way it looked today, the best driver is a retired one.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Feb. 14Larry Schiner, the basketball coach at Jersey City State, got a Valentine two days early, and it made him happy. But he said today he would be even happier if he is presented with his 100th coaching victory before the season's end.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
Two Cheers for France
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14At critical points in American history, beginning of course with Lafayette, some Frenchmande Tocqueville, Pierre L'Enfant, Paul Valery, Jean Monnet or some other prophetic geniusalways seems to turn up in Washington to guide us through our troubles, and the latest of these is Michel Jobert, the lean, ironic and highly intelligent envoy of the Pompidou palace and Government.
