title: DEMOCRATS NEAR KENNEDY WILL RUN
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Feb. 14Among the rich Democratic liberals here who fueled the antiwar politics of 1968 and 1972, the word is being passed this week that Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts is indeed running for President in 1976.

title: Music: Siegmeister Symphony No. 4
description: Elle Siegmeisters Symphony No. 4, heard at its first New York performance Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall with the Cleveland Orchestra conducted by Lorin Maazel, is a long (32 minutes), ambitious, wideranging, solidly crafted piece of work. It calls upon the full resources of the modern orchestra; it ranges about in mood, and it tries to fuse a variety of different styles.

description: HILLSBOROUGH, Calif., Feb. 14Offhand remarks made today at a news conference by Attorney General William B. Saxbe were described by Randolph A. Hearst as damn nears irresponsible when considered, against the effort to negotiate; the release of his kidnapped daughter, Patricia.

Like everything else at Morgan Library, this description turns out to be a discreet understatement that only obliquely suggests the true magnificence of the experience awaiting visitors to this survey of Great Acquisitions of Fifty Years: 19241974.

description: HONG KONG, Feb. 14New attacks from China against bourgeois works of music have singled out a piece performed by the Philadelphia Orchestra in Peking last September.

title: Solzhenitsyn and the S.L.A.
description: The kidnapping of Patricia Hearst is a particularly vile act in that its perpetrators profess to be acting in the name and on behalf of the poor and oppressed peoples of the world. Theirs is not, however, a revolt or a rebellion against specific conditions; it is not a strike against exploitative employers; it is not a mass movement of protest against economic or social policies, or political action for changed conditions. It is, instead, a cold and inhuman crime, carried out against an abstractly chosen victim, and offering no plausible hope of altering any of the world's numerous injustices and inequities.

title: 'American Moods' Examined in Five Short Films
description: Five short films running from 9 to 32 minutes each and collectively labeled "American Moods," which began a 10-day run yesterday at the Whitney Museum, are as American as apple pie, if not always a treat. The "moods" of these unheralded Americans may be unevenly documented, but they vividly sharpen often blurred visions of aspects of living that stir the mind and, occasionally, the conscience.A viewer's emotions should be affected most by Bruce Davidson's 32-minute, aptly titled, "Living Off the Land." As a muted color study of a father and son who eke out a meager existence as scavengers of a New Jersey municipal dump, it states its facts with unadorned realism while subtly implying the terrible imbalances that exist in our rich society. The grimy, laconic father; his oldest, teen-aged, equally inarticulate son; his wife and four other children emerge as a loving group and as proud citizens coping, without tears, with their dirty lot."Lambing," the 30-minute film by Bob Fiore and Barbara Jarvis, presents with similar dedication a bucolic view of David Hinman, a young New Hampshire shepherd and schoolteacher, and his wife, that personalizes their devotion to sheep and a way of life they love. The focus is on clinical views of births, but the total effect is a pastoral vignette as natural and picturesque as the film's snowy landscapes."Front and Back," a succession of postcards backed by narrations of vacationers' messages, made by Lynne Cohen and Andrew Lugg, is a clever idea that succumbs to redundancy. Another 9-minute subject, "Frank Film," a collage of biographical animations by Frank Mouris, has been shown here previously. And also seen here last year is Joseph Pipher's 25-minute "6344," a moving, yet amusing, record of a Fairfield, Ohio, family and the demolition of their ancestral home.These "American Moods" may make a slightly flawed film package, but it does captivate the eye and ear and is a tribute to the talents of some sensitive and perceptive movie makers.

title: Screen: Japanese 'Death by Hanging':Young Korean Rapist Survives Execution Oshima Work Brings Memory of Godard
description: It begins as if it were going to be a solemn documentary about the horrors of capital punishment. We see the prison buildings in a long shot from the air. The narrator describes the death house as looking like any other ordinary house, situated on a small hill, and we cut to the interior of the execution building.The narrator tells us that the walls are salmon pink (the film is in black and white) and notes that it has toilet facilities only for men. He invites us to watch a typical execution, which is when things go awry. Quite wildly. The heart of the victim, a young Korean convicted of two rape-murders, refuses to stop beating after the hanging. The execution team panics.The prosecutor says that the man cannot be re-executed until he is restored to consciousness, but the doctor, who had intended only to verify death, is without his medical bag.The Roman Catholic chaplain says it would be murder to hang the man again since the man's soul, which is responsible for the crimes, has left the body. Meanwhile the victim comes to and wonders where he is. The doctor is dumbfounded: He's never before heard of amnesia after an execution.For about one-third of its running time Nagisa Oshima's Japanese film "Death by Hanging" is a surprisingly uproarious contemplation of the moral issues involved in capital punishment. The prison officials, prosecutors, chaplain and witnesses argue back and forth and pick at each other with a Lewis Carroll sort of purposeful, cross illogic. Everybody becomes nettled. Someone suggests that they call it a day. "This kind of work has its failures too," he says, but they all stay on to straighten things out, sort of."Death by Hanging," which was made by Mr. Oshima in 1968, was shown at the First Avenue Screening Room last Sunday, and will be repeated there again today and tomorrow at noon and midnight.It is the second Oshima film to open in New York in a week, and though it is less complex than "The Ceremony," which was made in 1972, it is no less schematic. It's the kind of didactic work that only Jean-Luc Godard has ever successfully transformed into film, not because Mr. Godard is such a brilliant political philosopher, which he isn't, but because his brilliance as a film maker is irrepressible.On the basis of these two films, Mr. Oshima is certainly talented as well as hugely concerned and committed to the sort of cinema that plays an active role in its society. As long as "Death by Hanging" sticks to capital punishment, it is, in its absurd way, provocative and entertaining. But the film's interests keep widening, its methods become increasingly, arbitrarily Godardian (read Brechtian), until it reaches a point of total confusion.In order to be able to execute the murderer again, the prison team decides it must convince the man who he is (his name is simply R). They act out charades designed to make R remember. Involved are his identity as a murderer, as well as his identity as a Korean, a people long oppressed by the Japanese. Kafka, Freud and some other weighty presences are evoked by Mr. Oshima as straight editorializing, through Godardian monologues. One of R's problems is that he loved his sister, which doesn't seem to have a great deal to do with legalized murder and capital punishment.Some of it is funny. More of it is tedious, and a lot of it curiously old-fashioned, even though it reminds us of the great Godard films of the mid-nineteen-sixties. Extreme movie styles date more quickly than hemlines.

title: THEODORE C. LINK, CRIME REPORTER
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 14Theodore Carl Link, a veteran investigative reporter for The St. Louis PostDispatch, whose efforts helped to break up the influence of numerous gangs throughout the country, died today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 69 years old and lived in University City, a St. Louis suburb.

title: FEDERN, EXPERTS TO HELP 20 STATES ON GAS PROBLEMS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14The Federal Energy Office said today that it was sending teams of experts to 20 states that have serious gasoline problems, including New York and New Jersey, and that revision of allocation systems might result from their work.

title: For New York, Extra Gasoline
description: The State Fuel and Energy office expects delivery of an extra six million gallons of gasoline to stations in the city, on Long Island and in the Hudson Valley to begin this weekend, but officials said it would make little difference in the persistent shortage.

title: Irving Is Freed on Parole Here; Says He Owes About a Million
description: Clifford Irving, the ersatz biographer of Howard R. Hughes, was freed on parole yesterday after having served nearly a year and a half in Federal custody.

title: Workshops Help Women Discover the Poetry in Themselves
description: They feel they are poets but most of them are too shy to say so. They write their poems when their Children are in school or on typewriters in offices. Poetic perceptions come to them when they are walking down streets, or cooking dinner, or in a Laundromat. Usually their poems are not shown to others because the writers are afraid of ridicule.

title: Two Fined for Streaking
description: ORONO, Me., Feb. 14 (AP)Two University of Maine students have been fined $25 for streaking. The students, Charles McComb of Bloomfield and John Darak Jr. of Stratford, pleaded guilty to charges of indecent exposure yesterday in District Court. They allegedly ran across the campus nude Tuesday afternoon.

title: Market Place:
description: When you call Anixter Brothers, Inc., a Chicagobased wire and cable distributor, and ask for the president, the switchboard operator is the last intermediary with whom you are likely to talk.

title: Nicklaus Leads With 66 in L.A.
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 14 (AP)Jack Nicklaus, picking up where he left off in Hawaii, shot a fiveunderpar 66 and established a twostroke lead today in the first round of the $150,000 Glen CampbellLos Angeles open golf tournament.

title: Soviet Wrestlers Plan Tour of U.S.
description: As part of an exchange program between the Amateur Athletic Union and Soviet Wrestling Federation, the world champion Soviet team will visit the United States in March for a series of six dual matches.

title: Aiken, 81, Dean of the Senate, to Retire
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 Senator George D. Aiken of Vermont, the whitehaired, craggyfaced dean of the United States Senate, announced today that he would not seek reelection this year.

title: Port Authority Drops Plan To Increase PATH Fares
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday abruptly dropped its proposal to raise PATH tube train fares from 30 to 50 cents.

title: U.S. Plans Rapid Action On Oil Parley Decisions
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14The State Department said today that the United States would move with a sense of urgency to carry out the decisions made by the 13nation energy conference on the oil crisis.

title: New Rift Casts Doubt on Outlook for Europe
description: PARIS, Feb. 14The sudden, public spectacle of French isolation from the European community has had the effect here of an explosion set off by a long  flickering fuse. The impact was all the more magnified because the rift was dramatized in Washington, which led one conservative French commentator in Le Figaro to call it the European Waterloo.

title: $2.7Billion Byrne Budget Has No New Tax Levies
description: TRENTON, Feb. 14  Governor Byrne today proposed a $2.7billion state spending program that does not include any new taxes or major new pro grams and is precariously balanced by anticipated revenues that may be undermined by the economic effects of the energy shortage.

title: Leo Flood, Engineer Headed Air Pollution Control Unit
description: Leo P. Flood, former director of engineering of the Department of Air Pollution Control, which is now the Department of Air Resources, died Wednesday at Flushing Hospital. He was 75 years old, and lived at 6162 80th Street, Middle Village, Queens.

title: Deer Sur, Im a Quallified Ph.D.
description: Both as a theater critic and as a Ph.D., I watch the vagaries of the doctorate in American universities. As the owner of a Harvard Ph.D. in comparative literature, I am interested in the development of my stock; as a theater critic, I am concerned with the fate of absurdist farce, the genre to which today's Ph.D. programs belong.

title: Ideas on Oil Money Offered by Shultz
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14The United States made public today a long list of ideas and suggestions for dealing with the purely financial problems raised for the world by the huge increase in the price of oil.

title: Chief at American Airlines To Be Casey
description: American Airlines, Inc., suffered a net loss in the fourth quarter after realizing a profit in the third quarter for the first time in nine months. As a result, the transcontinental carrier's deficit for 1973 climbed to $48million in contrast to a net profit of $5.6million, or 20 cents a share, the year before.

title: U.S. Gypsum Is Fighting I.R.S. Tax Deficiency Bid
description: The United States Gypsum Company said in Chicago yesterday that it had filed a peti tion on Feb. 4 with the United States Tax Court contesting a $22million tax deficiency issued by the Internal Revenue Service. Graham J. Morgan, chairman, said the action by the Government was undue harassment.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1974

title: Official Cleared of Bribery
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 14 (UPI) County Board Chairman Richard C. Nowakowski was found not guilty by a jury to day of a charge of accepting a $275 bribe in 1967.

title: GASTON BERGERY, 81, VICHY AIDE OF PETAIN
description: PARIS, Feb. 14 (AP)Gastonl Bergery, a close aide of Marshal Philippe Petain, leader of the Vichy Government of France during the German occupation in World War II, died Sunday at his home here. He was 81 years old.

title: NIXON IS HECKLED IN MIAMI ADDRESS
description: MIAMI, Feb. 14While President Nixon spoke today at a St. Valentine's Day dedication of a hospital center, a chorus of voices at the rear of the crowd shouted intermittently, Impeach Nixon Now.

title: Soviet Formally Accused Solzhenitsyn of Treason
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 14Friends of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's family reported tonight that before his deportation Soviet prosecutors had presented him with a formal indictment accusing him of treason. The crime carries penalties ranging from 10 years' imprisonment to death.

title: Seoul Reports Attack By North on 2 Vessels
description: SEOUL, Friday, Feb. 15 (UPI)North Korean warships tank a South Korean fishing boat and crippled another in the Yellow Sea today, the South Korean Defense Ministry announced.

title: Meskill on Gas Rules
description: Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut joined restive gasoline retailers in his state and elsewhere yesterday in indicating dissatisfaction with a new Federal order mandating firstcome, firstserved policies at stations. Page 15.

title: Good Start on Panama
description: As Secretary of State Kissinger said, the agreement between the United States and Panama on eight principles to govern negotiation of a new Panama Canal treaty has created a favorable climate for the meeting of American foreign ministers in Mexico next week. Whether it will fulfill Mr. Kissinger's prediction of first step toward a new era in interAmerican affairs will depend on how promptly the treaty can be concluded and ratified.

title: PRICE RECORD SET IN WHEAT FUTURES
description: The price of a 60pound bushel of wheat closed at historic high of $6.115 yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, the nation's largest commodity exchange.

title: I.R.S. Decides Today Whether to Return Reporter's Records
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14The Internal Revenue Service, after consultation with the Department of Justice, said today that it would decide tomorrow whether to surrender the home telephone records of David E. Rosenbaum, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times.

title: Mrs. Frances P. Schofield Married
description: NEWTON, Mass., Feb. 14Mrs. Frances Picker Schofield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Picker of Mamaroneck, N. Y., was married here today to William Josef Mrachek, son of. Col. Harry Josef Mrachek, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Mrachek of Aurora, Colo. Justice of the Peace Edward English performed the ceremony at the Newton City Hall.

title: Energy Talks: Why U.S. Position Won
description: The Washington energy conference did not live up to its advance billing as a probable bomb for the Western alliance or at best a meaningless dud. Instead, it has resulted in startling progress toward the cooperative international programs on energy sharing and development favored by the United Statesand a jarring rejection of the everyoneforhimself line championed by France.

title: Wood, Field & Stream Hunting Snowshoe Rabbit Upstate
description: OPPENHEIM, N. Y.Standing on a knoll, where George Teidman had posted me, I listened to the sweet music of the beagles as they pursued a snowshoe rabbit deep within the snowdraped conifers of the Adirondacks.

title: CARTRIDGE TV NAMED IN A SIXCOUNT SUIT
description: The Independent Investor Protective League filed a sixcount complaint in Southern District Court here yesterday against Cartridge Television, Inc., and companies and individuals connected with it in development of its socalled Cartrivision home color videotape system. The suit seeks a total of $300million including treble damages of $120million.

title: Business Briefs
description: Sharp Drop in U.S. Growth Forecast

title: BRAD BOYLE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 14Edward (Brad) Boyle, director of public information for the State Health Department and a former newsman, died today at St. Peter's Hospital. He was 58 years old.

title: U.S. REPORTS ARMS IT GAVE SAIGON IN '73
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  The United States supplied South Vietnam with 180,412 tons of munitions for ground forces in the eight months following the ceasefire agreement in January, 1973, the Defense Department disclosed today.

title: Faithful Turn Out for Segovia Magic
description: Andres Segovia, who, as everyone must know, is the Colosseum and the Louvre museum of the classic guitar, paid his annual visit to New York on Wednesday night. Avery Fisher Hall was, not unexpectedly, crammed with the faithful, who hung on Mr. Segovia's every twang throughout a recital that increased in interest as it went, climaxing as usual in the encore period.

title: In Connecticut, Defiance of U.S.
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 14  Continuing his defiance of Washington, Gov. Thomas J. Meskill said today that Connecticut would not enforce a twodayold order from the head of the Federal Energy Office prohibiting gasoline station operators from giving preferential treatment to the regular customers. If there is any enforcement it will be Federal enforcement, not state enforcement, the Governor said to 60 station Operators who had gathered at the Capital.

title: Chief at American Airlines
description: Albert V. Casey, president of the Times Mirror Company and man with a background in surface but not air transportation, is scheduled to be named president and chief executive of American Airlines next week.

title: People in Sports: Tug Signs His Contract
description: Tug McGraw, who had hoped to get an escalating threeyear contract with the New York Mets, settled for a oneyear pact yesterday. It Is believed the twitchy, lefthanded reliever will work for $90,000 next season. Last year, at $75,000, McGraw was thought to be the highest paid relief pitcher in baseball.

title: Democrats Win 3 of 4 Contests In Queens and Upstate Races
description: Democrats gained one seat in the Assembly yesterday as they won three out of four Legislature contests in special elections in Queens and upstate.

title: Doctors Use Echocardiography To Probe the Heart With Sound
description: A technique for heartdisease diagnosis that relies on ultrasound rather than the insertion of tubes and chemicals into the heart is now being applied by a few score physicians to overcome the limitations of the Xray and to reduce the dangers associated with heart catheterization.

title: PATTERN EMERGES IN RACE IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Feb. 14The first week of the threeweek election campaign herethe shortest in some 40 yearsended today with the issues clear at least in the political slogans if not in the minds of the voters.

title: Mindszenty Plans to Tour U.S. To Explain His Refusal to Resign
description: VIENNA, Feb. 14  Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty is planning a tour of the United States soon to explain to HungarianAmerican communities and other groups why he refused to resign from his post in the Roman Catholic Church despite personal pleas from Pope Paul VI.

title: U.S. Sets Up Two Units For Fraud Investigations
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI)Home mortgage frauds and financial swindles will get new Federal attention, the Justice Department said yesterday.

title: Brain Receptors for Narcotics Partly Identified by Scientists
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 Scientists at Stanford University have reported partial chemical identification of the specific substances in the brain to which narcotic drugs become attached.

title: PUPILS HERE SHOW A GAIN IN READING
JULIAN CHASE DIES; AUTOMOTIVE EDITOR
description: Julian Chase, a retired automotive editor and author, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 95 years old and lived in Woodbury, Conn.

title: Election Recount Planned
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Feb. 14 (UPI)  The Jefferson County Court yesterday ordered the ballot boxes from a special Congressional election opened in five precincts of the county for a recount Feb. 28. The recount, granted by President Judge Edwin L. Snyder, was requested by Harry M. Fox, Republican, who lost to John P. Murtha Jr., Democrat, by a 242vote margin in the official count of the 12th Congressional District election Feb. 5.

title: Pop Music: Bottom Line Signs On With Dr. John
description: Dr. John officially opened the new Bottom Line club on West Fourth Street on Tuesday to a rockcelebrity crowded audience. On Wednesday he was back to normal (you don't expect musicians such as Johnny Winter and Stevie Wonder to jam with you every night), although normal is hardly something to be applied to Dr. John. He appears on stage wearing a huge feather headdress and Technicolor robes and scattering tinsel over everybody, to point up his New Orleans background.

title: Meskill on Gas Rules
description: Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut joined restive gasoline retailers in his state and elsewhere yesterday in indicating dissatisfaction with a new Federal order mandating firstcome, firstserved policies at stations. Page 15.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 35

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DRAMA The New Federal Theater has become one of the more ambitious and one of the few absolutely free theatrical undertakings in town. Sponsored by the Henry Street Settlement Urban Life Center, it has two theaters at its disposal, one on Grand Street (now being refurbished) and another at 240 East Third Street, where it produces its shows. The company directs its works at themes representing its Lower East Side constituency black, Puerto Rican, Jewish and also affords new playwrights of whatever persuasion a chance to display their talent.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Gains
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 14 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.6 billion tonmiles, 6.1 per cent above a year ago. Carloadings in the same week totaled 521,930 cars, up 5.4 per cent over last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage last week was 0.3 per cent below last year.

title: Petraglia Cuts Davis's Lead To 87 Pins in Bowling Here
description: Dave Davis of Atlanta, bowling at a 229 average for the first 32 games, led the way into the semifinals of the $85,000 United States open tournament at Madison Square Garden  yesterday. Twentyfour bowlers remained in the competition after the field was cut for the second time.

title: KUWAIT RECEIVES OILAUCTION BIDS
description: The Government of Kuwait received bids yesterday from some 40 companies for 75.6 million barrels of oil that the Government is selling by auction. Results of the bidding will not be announced until next week.

title: Payments Improve on 2 Fronts
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: One recalls the nation's state of shock and disbelief in the days immediately following the assassination of President Kennedy and how we turned to the new President for assuranceand received it.

title: I.R.S. '69 RULING ON I.T.T. STUDIED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14A Congressional committee is looking into possible White House influence in a 1969 ruling by the I.R.S. that made possible the takeover of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company by I.T.T. and produced profits of nearly $6million for the multinational conglomerate.

title: Finley's Hockey Franchise On Coast Bought by N.H.L.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14 (AP)Charles O. Finley closed the sale of the California Golden Seals to the National Hockey League today and admitted his venture into the sport turned out to be a failure.

title: Briefs on Energy
description: ATHENS, Feb. 14  Premier Adamantios Androutsopulos announced today that a United States company had struck oil and gas in commercial quantities in the Aegean Sea off the north coast of Greece. One well is already producing 3,000 barrels of crude daily. The Premier said that the discovery was a milestone in the country's economic life, and that there was hope of further strikes. Oceanic Exploration company of Denver made the strike, the first in Greece, a few miles off Thassos Island. Constantine Kypraios, the Industry Minister, told a news conference the deposit would eventually produce about 10,000 barrels a day. At this rate, the well could supply about 5 per cent of Greece's domestic requirements of crude. The first well was yielding also some 40 million cubic feet of gas daily, but no decision had been made on how to use it.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Nixon and Beame Aides to Meet Here

title: Davis Raises Lead to 309 Pins In Bowling Semifinals at Garden
description: Dave Davis won six of eight games en route to a 1,887pin total and moved into a commanding lead last night as the semifinals got under way in the $85,000 United States Open Bowling tournament at Madison Square Garden.

title: GenevaPacific Venture Set
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Feb. 14 (AP)The GenevaPacific Corporation announced today its Alaskan exploration program) has disclosed several significant highgrade copper ore deposits or: the southern flank of the Wrangell Mountains. The mountains are in southeastern Alaska, about 250 miles east of Anchorage.

title: ALEXANDER'S PLAN DRAWS OPPOSITION
description: Opposition was beginning to develop yesterday to the plan by Alexander's, Inc., to open its five New York City stores Sunday even though the chain's management was still maintaining its silence on the proposed opening.

title: Democrats Approve Plan On Choice of Running Mate
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI)  The Democratic National Executive Committee today approved, with a major qualification, a proposal to give future Presidential nominees an extra day to choose running mates or let them turn the job over to the party's national committee.

title: Red Smith
description: George Foreman's divorce case is not the only impediment between the heavyweight champion of the world and his tryst with Ken Norton in Caracas, March 26. Federal Judge Robert F. Peckham in San Francisco is expected to rule soon on a motion to enjoin Foreman from fighting unless he complies with the terms of his contract with George Foreman Associates, Ltd., the backers he no longer loves. This is the socalled Philadelphia group, 10 business and professional men who gave George a $250,000 grubstake when he was comparatively obscure and have, they say, got the short end of the stick in return.

title: Events Today
description: Film

title: Leonard Weinles, Directed F.C.C. Information Section
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) Leonard Weinles, director of public information for the Federal Communications Commission, died today of a heart attack. He was 51 years old.

title: Nets' Balance Downs Cougars, 125108
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 14 Coach Kevin Loughery admitted that it had not taken a lot of ranting and raving at halftime to get his New York Nets to play aggressive defense against the Carolina Cougars tonight at the Charlotte Coliseum.

title: Board of Amex Backs Plan on Rates
description: The board of governors of the American Stock Exchange approved yesterday a program that would permit members to negotiate commission charges directly with investors on securities transactions involving $2,000 or less.

title: Hughes Accused on Bid
description: Documents made public yesterday accuse the Howard Hughes organization of a systematic effort to take over a Texasbased regional airline as part of a grand design to create a new transcontinental airline under the Hughes banner. Page 45.

title: Notes on People
description: The Rev. Eugene J. Boyle, a Roman Catholic priest who is a Democratic candidate for the California State Assembly, has been forbidden to preach in his own pulpit until after the election. The order came from Archbishop, Joseph T. McGurh of San Francisco, who based it on fears that rival candidates night demand equal pulpit time.

title: FARERAISE PLAN FOR PATH DROPPED
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday abruptly dropped its proposal to raise PATH tube train fares from 30 to 50 cents.

title: Ford, on Speaking Trip, Blends Politics and Football
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 14As Vice President Ford's motorcade crept through suburban Tinley Park this morning, Mr. Ford, just out of his car and coatless in the 20degree chill, marched resolutely along the sidewalk shaking hands with some of the 4,000 school children who were lining the route and waving flags.

title: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE
POWERRATE RISE VIEWED AS MODEST
description: TRENTON, Feb. 14The rise in February's electricity bills for New Jersey's residential customers will be far less than the increase anticipated in New York, according to utility officials here, as a result of the greater use of coal by the state's major public utility.

title: High Job Rise Is Seen For Multinational Concerns
description: The Business International! Corporation issued a report yesterday adding to previous research designed to show that American multinational manufacturing companies have a higher domestic job growth rate than the nation's manufacturing companies as a whole.

title: Two Fined for Streaking
description: ORONO. Me.. Feb. 14 (AP) Two University of Maine students have been fined $25 for streaking. The students, Charles McComb of Bloomfield and John Darak Jr. of Stratford, pleaded guilty to charges of indecent exposure yesterday in District Court. They allegedly ran across the campus nude Tuesday afternoon.

title: Soviet Formally Accused Solzhenitsyn of Treason
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 14Friends of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's family reported tonight that before his deportation Soviet prosecutors had presented him with a formal indictment accusing him of treason. The crime carries penalties ranging from 10 years' imprisonment to death.

title: Study Says High Hospital Bills Stem From State's Negligence
description: TRENTON, Feb. 14 (AP) An independent research group has charged the New Jersey Health Department with gross negligence that has resulted in vastly inflated hospital bills and inadequate patient care.

title: Lefkowitz to Ask for Special Oil Inquiry
description: The State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, decided yesterday to ask the Appellate Division to empanel a special grand jury to inquire into possible criminal violations of the state's antitrust laws by major oil companies.

title: P.S.C. Delays Final Action On Storm King Contract
description: ALBANY, Feb. 14  The state's Public Service Commission refused today to ratify the $200million contract that the Consolidated Edison Company had signed with a consortium of three construction companies to build the controversial pumpedstorage generating plant at Storm King Mountain in CornwallonHudson. But the commission indicated it would reconsider the matter later.

title: BIG BOARD PUNISHES 3 BROKERAGE FIRMS
description: Three stock brokerages firms were named in disciplinary actions yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange and consented to penalties that were imposed.

title: Ford Plans SmallCar Production at a Jersey Plant
description: DETROIT, Feb. 14The Ford Motor Company announced today that its plant at Mahwah, N. J., would be converted from production of fullsize cars to two new lines of small cars to be introduced as 1975 models.

title: Way of the World Played With Spirit
description: In the elegant salons and drawing rooms of William Congreve's The Way of the World, which Britain's Actors Company brought to, the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday, cuckoldry is commonplace, even fashionable, yet everyone is censorious. The way of the world is a game, which people play with unequal skill.

title: CITY WEIGHSLOSS OF SCHOOL FUND
description: The ways in which the city's schools would be affected by a $50million cut in Federal funds for the educationally disadvantaged were described here yesterday by Board of Education officials.

title: 3 Trapped in a Crater In Venezuelan Jangle
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 15 (Reuters)  Three members of a scientific expedition were trapped at the bottom of a 250yarddeep crater in the Venezuelan jungle and were unable to climb out, according to a radio rehere port reaching today.

title: HigherEducation Meetings to Be Public
description: Ending a 48yearold custom, the new members of the reorganized Board of Higher Education announced yesterday that the monthly meetings of the board would be open to the public and the press.

title: Actor is Released After 28 Months In Draft Evasion
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 15 (AP) A black actorplaywright who has served nearly 28 months of a fiveyear prison term for draft evasion was released on bond today in Minneapolis.

title: Seeking Bargains Is Simplified
description: Some people just have to spend for ego purposes, says Eric Zuesse, a veteran bargainhunter (and finder), but the real trick in finding bargains is to approach what you want from underthat is, start by looking for the most inexpensive way to satisfy your needs, rather than starting out with the most expensive and scaling down.

title: SOUTHERN U. DEATHS SPUR INQUIRY BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The Justice Department has gone into the Louisiana courts to press an investigation into the deaths of two students at Southern University on Nov. 16, 1972.

title: People and Business
description: Government plans for abandonment of more than 25 per cent of railroad trackage in the Middle West and Northeast will never leave the drawing board, Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana said yesterday.

title: Strange Synthesis in TorresCardia Art
description: The paintings of Joaquin Torres  Garcia (1874 1949) represent one of the strangestand I think most successfulattempts to create a synthesis of conflicting formal tendencies: a persistent love of primitive and folkloric imagery derived from the artist's Uruguayan background (he was born in Montevideo) and an aspiration for the high styles of European modernism. One can gain some sense of the progress of TorresGarcia's development from the small exhibition of his oils on view at Knoedler Contemporary Art, 21 East 70th Street. It includes some 15 paintings, dating from 1928 to 1943.

title: Moscow Sees Oblivion for Solzhenitsyn
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 15  The Soviet press, in a new burst of denunciations, asserted today that with Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn now in the West, foreign reactionaries would lose interest in him and would dump him.

title: STATE AND JERSEY GET GAS BONUSES
description: The regional Federal energy office announced small bonuses yesterday in February gasoline allocations for New York and New Jersey6.1 million gallons for New York and 5 million gallons for New Jersey.

title: Denis Potvin Out With Ankle Injury
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Feb. 15 The New York Islanders, who stopped a threegame losing streak by tying St.Louis last night, will be without Denis Potvin when they meet the Chicago Black Hawks tomorrow night in the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Knicks' Afternoons Are Getting Busy
description: The Knicks had better be wide awake for afternoon games today and tomorrow because they will be going against two of the National Basketball Association's divisionalleading teams.

title: RighttoLife Resolution
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 15 (UPI)The Kentucky House of Representatives approved yesterday a righttolife resolution called on Congress to adopt a constitutional amendment prohibiting abortion.

title: Team Plane Makes Skidding Landing
description: SIOUX FALLS, S. D., Feb. 15 (AP)A twinengine aircraft carrying the North Dakota State basketball team negotiated a successful emergency landing near Sioux Falls today with only one engine working and with the landing gear up.

title: Po TO BE TESTED FOR MEDICAID FEES
description: ALBANY, Feb. 15A pilot project to pay in advance for medical services to Medicaid patients is close to implementation, the State Department of Social Services said today.

title: Disney Workers Recalled
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 15 (UPI)Walt Disney World announced yesterday that it was hiring or recalling more than 500 employes laid off last month when attendance declined at the tourist attraction. Cited were healthy attendance and optimism that Easter visitors would increase.

title: AMTRAK GAINING RAIL PASSENGERS
description: Amtrak, the nationwide railpassenger system, reported yesterday that, because the fuel shortage was causing huge passenger shifts to rails, it now expected to reach in 1975 the passenger loads that had been predicted for the 1977 fiscal year.

title: Bridge: Negative Double Is Employed By Inventor With No Ceiling
description: New ideas in bidding take time to filter across the Atlantic. The negative double, introduced by Alvin Roth in the fifties and standard among American experts for a decade, has only recently found support in Europe.

title: Arbitrator Sets Brett's Pirate Pact
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 15 (AP)  Ken Brett, who had submitted his contract dispute to binding arbitration, was one of two pitchers whose signings were reportd today by the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Stockton, on 136, Leads In Coast Golf by Stroke
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 15 (AP)Dave Stockton of Westlake, Calif., scrambled to his second 68 today and took a onestroke lead after two rounds of the $150,000 Glen Campbell Los Angeles open golf tournament. Johnny Miller and Jim Wiechers, neighbors in Napa, Calif., shared second place.

title: New Pollution Rules Will Give States Right to Cut Construction
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15Any major new construction project that attracts large numbers of automobiles, such as a shopping center, airport or sports arenas will be regulated by the states, under rules issued yesterday by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Arab Envoys Expected to Ask U.S. to Assure Golan Pullback
description: CAIRO, Feb. 15  Ara diplomats here said today that the Egyptian and Saudi Arabian foreign ministers would ask the Nixon Administration over the weekend for assurances that Israeli forces would eventually withdraw from the entire Golan Heights area they occupied in 1967.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and index, Page 33

title: Special Delivery
description: Since President Nixon has already indicated that he will not obey the subpoena issued for his appearance in a California Superior Court to testify on an aspect of the Watergate scandals, delivery of the letter containing the orders may be of minor legal interest. It is nevertheless worth noting that by the time the letter was finally delivered this week, it had managed to stretch the journey from Los Angeles to Washington to a full seven days. In the jet age, this may come close to a record, even for the United States Postal Service.

title: LISTS UP SHARPLY ON AMEX AND 0TC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market rose sharply yesterday in steppedup trading as more and more investors seem to believe that the energy crisis will soon be solved.

title: Chapin Judge Criticizes Pretrial Publicity on Dean
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15Federal Judge Gerhard A. Gesell tried today to calm the rising public debate about the truthfulness of John W. Dean 3d, the former White House counsel and key witness in the Watergate case, and chided lawyers on both sides of the argument.

title: Ford Opposes Election Financing Bill
description: OMAHA, Feb. 15Vice President Ford contended today that the financing of Federal election campaigns with public funds would be a very serious mistake.

title: Kervick Is Sentenced to Prison Hospital
description: TRENTON, Feb. 15Former State Treasurer John A. Kervick, who held the second most powerful office in the state in the nineteensixties, was sentenced here today to a Federal prison hospital on political corruption charges.

title: A Crucial Election in India's Largest State
description: LUCKNOW, India, Feb. 13 Near the sprawling bazaars and beside the peeling Mosques of this state capital, the peasants, the shopkeepers and the rickshaw drivers are busily watching the jeeps swerve toward Mahatma Gandhi Road.

title: Two Women Who Are Greening a Bit of America
description: Martin Rapp, editor of American Heritage magazine, likes green. So does his wife, Samantha, whose father is Alfred Drake, the singer. It's their favorite color, and when they started furnishing their East Sixties apartment, right after their marriage a couple of years ago, they chose for the upholstered pieces a white sofa and chairs covered with a French green and white floral print.

title: Voters in British Town on Fence
description: BOLTON, England, Feb. 15 Despite its 160,000 inhabitants, Bolton never managed to get itself legally proclaimed a city.

title: Case for Data Market Place: Dissemination
description: At a time of deep concern over corporate credibility, it is surprising that more corporations are not augmenting the information in their annual reports with data from the reports that they must file with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: STATE AND JERSEY GET GAS BONUSES
RULE BY MAJORITY ASKED FOR MARKET
description: BONN, Feb. 15West Germany's Foreign Minister, Walter Scheel, said today that France's conduct at the energy conference in Washington early this week was hard to understand, and he suggested that, in the future, decisions of the nine Common Market countries might better be made by majority rule rather than unanimously.

title: Peru Nationalizes 4 W. R. Grace Subsidiaries
description: The Peruvian Government announced yesterday that it had assumed ownership of the industrial properties of W. R. Grace & Co., a now worldwide concern that got its start in Peru as a small shipping business 120 years ago.

title: Art: O'Hara, Poet, Is Honored
description: The late Frank O'Hara (192666), though now widely recognized as a poet (a mammoth volume of Collected Poems was published in 1971), was better known in his own lifetime as an artworld figure. He worked for a time as a critic on the magazine Art News, and he wrote an early book on Jackson Pollock. He also served on the staff of the Museum of Modern Art, where he organized exhibitions of the work of Robert Motherwell, David Smith and Reuben Nakian.

title: Barbarous Attack on 2 Boats Laid to North Korea by Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 15  The Defense Ministry announced today that North Korean gunboats sank one South Korean fishing boat and seized another this morning in a barbarous attack in the Yellow Sea, about 40 miles off North Korea. Twelve fishermen were reported missing and feared drowned, and 13 captured.

title: PPG Asks Court to Prevent Other's Use of Its Secrets,
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 15 (UPI) PPG Industries asked the Allegheny County Common Pleas Court yesterday to prevent the CertainTeed Products Corporation from using PPG secrets for its $100millionayear fiberglass manufacturing process.

title: SUMNER WOOD JR., PATHOLOGIST, DIES
description: WESTFIELD, N.J., Feb. 15Dr. Sumner Wood Jr., director of the experimentalpathology department of the Merck Institute of Therapeutic Research of Merck & Co., Rahway, N.J. was found dead early yesterday at his home, 941 Willow Grove Road. He was 44 years old. The Westfield police and the Union County Medical Examiner were conducting an investigation.

title: A Leap in British Food Prices Adds Fuel to Election Campaign
description: LONDON, Feb. 15The political debate over the cost of living in Britain intensified today as the Government reported a 20 per cent increase in food prices in the last yearthe biggest ever recorded.

title: UTILITY STUDY SET ON PACTS IN STATE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 15  The chairman of the Assembly Committee on Commerce, Industry and Economic Development said today that he would begin an investigation of all publicutility construction contracts in the stateparticularly the one for the Consolidated Edison Company's Storm King plant.

title: 163,039 Seeking City Job Where No Openings Exist
description: The city's Personnel Department said yesterday that a record 163,039 persons had applied for the Civil Service sanitationman's examination at a time when there are no vacancies in the Sanitation Department.

title: Pitcairn Islander Dies
description: GLENDALE, Calif., Feb. 15 (UPI)  Norris Young, a fifthgeneration descendant of the only officer to join Fletcher Christian in the Bounty mutiny, died Sunday on Pitcairn Island, according to radio reports received yesterday. He was 87 years old. The island population now numbers 68 descendants of Bounty mutineers and their Tahitian companions and 10 other persons who have joined the band on the island in recent years.

title: On U.S. Assistance to Parched West Africa
description: WASHINGTONThe continuing drought in the subSahara region of Africa and the hardships it is bringing to the people who live there is one of the great tragedies of our time. It is, as it should be, of concern to Americans and, because of its magnitude and duration, there has been considerable comment on what the Government is doing to help, and how well we are performing our job.

title: Shutdown in Norfolk
description: Some 200 gasoline service station operators in the Norfolk, Va., area closed down yesterday and thousands more around the country threatened to lock their pumps in protest over Federal gasoline allocation and pricing policies and harassment by motorists.

title: Five Are Injured as Car Mounts Sidewalk Near the Flatiron Building
description: Four men and a 22yearold woman were injured at 2:35 o'clock yesterday afternoon when a car went out of control on a Fifth Avenue sidewalk opposite the Flatiron Building.

title: Jews, Denied Exit Permits, Start Soviet Hunger Strike
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 15 (AP)Three Jews began a hunger strike in a Moscow apartment today to protest the refusal of the Soviet Government to let them emigrate to Israel.

title: Death Penalty Upheld
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 15 (UPI)The initiative measure that restored the death penalty for certain crimes in California has been upheld yesterday by Superior Court Judge Morton R. Colvin.

title: Books of The Times
description: XINGU: The Indians, Their Myths. By Orlando Villas Boas and Claudio Villas Boas. Translated by Susana Hertelendy Rudge. Edited by Kenneth. S. Brecher. Illustrated by Wacupid. 270 pages, Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $12.95

title: State Mark Broken in Long Jump
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 15 Belger beat Gene McCarthy for the third time this season, but an unheralded long jumper stole the glory from the milers today in the Nassau County invitation schoolboy meet at the Coliseum.

title: Voters in British Town on Fence
description: BOLTON, England, Feb. 15 Despite its 160,000 inhabitants, Bolton never managed to get itself legally proclaimed a city.

title: BEADLESTON ASKS DELAY ON BUDGET
description: TRENTON, Feb. 15State Senator Alfred N. Beadleston urged today that the Legislature postpone approval of Govergor Byrne's $2.7billion budget until the issue of restructuring the state's system of financing public education is resolved.

title: Bejart Makes a Ritual of Stimmung
description: You'd think the world was in a sorry enough state without having to suffer a new shamanism in the arts. But Thursday at Carnegie Hall, Maurice Bjart as medicine man offered his view of ballet as ritual. He was aided and nearly rescued by Karlheinz Stockhausen's wellknown vocal piece of meditative music, Stimmung. Stimmung is also the title of the ballet, danced by 11 members of Mr. Brjart's Ballet of the Twentieth Century from Brussels.

title: Treasury Bills Fell At the Weekly Yale
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15Yields on United States Treasury bills fell slightly in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities. The sale was held today in stead of next Monday because the money market will be closed then for Washington's birthday.

title: 4 More Representatives Plan To Retire Before Next Election
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The list of members of Congress planning to retire continued to mount today with announcements by four members of the Houseincluding Chet Holifield of California and Edith Green of Oregon, both Democratsthat they would not seek reelection.

title: F.C.C. Urged to Networks More Prime Time
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 15An organization of independent television producers has petitioned the Federal Communications Commission for a stay of the newly revised primetimeaccess rule, arguing that the changes in the rule will constrict the marketplace for nonnetwork shows and will therefore cause the producers to suffer irreparable damage and losses of millions of dollars.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey. daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (Reuters)The Cost of Living Council said today that the sale of all ferrous and ferroalloy scrap metal was now exempt from Phase 4 price controls. The announcement said the exception was made because of market disruptions caused by increasing distortions of price and supply.

title: Unhealthy Rhetoric
description: Polemics are no substitute for an urgently needed rational debate on President Nixon's health insurance proposal. None of the rival plans aims, as Mr. Nixon has hinted, at making physicians work for the Federal Government rather than for their patients. The President's repeated description of the present state of affairs as the best medical care system in the world creates the false impression that the existing deficiencies and inequities in the delivery of health care constitute a normal situation that is not in need of correction.

title: COMINCO SEEKING SHARES OF TARA
description: Cominco, Ltd., a mining company in Vancouver, British Columbia, which is controlled by Canadian Pacific, Ltd., offered yesterday $25 a share for 5.1 million shares of Tara Exploration and Development, Ltd. Tara, which is incorporated in Ontario, operates lead and zinc properties in Ireland. Cominco and Charter Consolidated, Ltd., of London, an investment company, together own the other 1.3 million shares of Tara, or 21 per cent of the 6.4 million shares outstanding.

title: Wurlitzer Fills Vacuum As It Moves to Newark
description: NEWARK, Feb. 15After the Griffith Piano Company closed down here last November after being in business for nearly 60 years, Wurlitzer Music Stores, Inc., one of the nation's largest music chains, took over the old Griffith location at 605 Broad Street and more than a little of As good will.

title: 163,039 Seeking City Job Where No Openings Exist
description: The city's Personnel Department said yesterday that a record 163,039 persons had applied for the Civil Service sanitationman's examination at a time when there are no vacancies in the Sanitation Department.

title: About the Knicks:
description: Dave DeBusschere, recuperating from a heel injury suffered a week ago, will not make the trip to Milwaukee for a nationally televised game tomorrow against the Bucks. He will try running on the heel today and continue tomorrow and Monday. He hopes to return to action Tuesday against the Portland Trail Blazers at Madison Square Garden ... Bill Bradley will play today in his 160th consecutive game. He was last sidelined in February, 1972, for three games with a leg injury ... Bradley is one of three Knicks who have seen action in all 60 games this season. The others who have been free from injuries are Walt Frazier and Phil Jackson ... John Gianelli, who is handling the starting center duties in fine style, will play his 100th game as a pro today.

title: Cities Service Is Reducing Price of Its Propane Gas
description: The Cities Service Oil Company announced yesterday that it was reducing all wholesale and retail propane prices by 4.65 cents a gallon in all areas.

title: Republicans Act to Delay Hearing on Impeachment
description: Republican members of the House Judiciary Committee are seeking to delay or cancel a public hearing set for next week to discuss the fundamental issue of what constitutes an impeachable offense.

title: A Bookie's Dream Bettor Recoups Losses in Court
description: A former stockbroker who became a bookmaker's dream a decade ago by misappropriating hundreds of thousands of dollars and blowing it on the horses and other sports has now become a bookmaker's nightmare by winning a $370,000 coup in State Supreme Court against his old bookies.

title: Shutdown in Norfolk
description: Some 200 gasoline service station operators in the Norfolk, Va., area closed down yesterday and thousands more around the country threatened to lock their pumps in protest over Federal gasoline allocaLion and pricing policies and harassment by motorists.

title: Earnings Rise for Two Big Insurers
Cambodians Say World Ignores Plight
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 15  Cambodian leaders are asking why the world community has remained virtually silent about the terror shellings of Phnom Penh  which have killed or wounded nearly 1,000 people, almost all of them civilians, since the random barrages by the Communistled insurgents began in late December.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Roger Pryor, Screen Actor, Later Ad Executive, Dead
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 15Roger Pryor, a former bandleader and an actor of stage, screen and radio who retired in 1962 as a vice president for broadcasting of Foote, Cone & Belding, Inc., advertising, died Jan. 31 of a heart attack on a trip to Puerta Vallarta, Mexico. He was 72 years old and lived here.

title: SEXTET NOW PLAYS MUSIC OF SY OLIVER
description: Sy Oliver, the trumpeter, singer, arranger and band leader, is even more adaptable than that summary of his talents might indicate. After leading a ninepiece band for several years that has featured, many of the celebrated arrangements he wrote for Jimmie Lunceford and Tommy Dorsey, Mr. Oliver expanded to 18 pieces to play his Lunceford arrangements at the first New York Jazz Repertory Company concert at Carnegie Hall three weeks ago. Now he is at the Royal Box of the Americana Hotel, doing those same arrangements with only six pieces.

title: DAVID L. RISTAU
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 15David L. Ristau of Candeub Fleissig & Associates, cityplanning consultants of Newark, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, while on a business trip in Niagara Falls, N. Y. He was 35 years old.

title: Outlook Here Worse Than Usual
description: The outook for drivers in need of gasoline in the metropolitan area over the holiday weekend appeared yesterday to be even grimmer than usual.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Joseph McGowan, a former schoolteacher, was chafged in Hackensack yesterday with the murder of a Brownie Girl Scout last April in a new indictment that also alleged he had raped the 7yearold girl. Mr. McGowan, 27, of Hillsdale, was first indicted on murder charges on April 24, one day after the body of the girl, Joan D'Allessandro, was found in Harriman State Park in New York.

title: MRS. JANE CHOATE
description: ARDSLEY  ON  HUDSON, N. Y., Feb. 15Mrs. Jane Ann Shirk Choate, a freelance writer, died Monday of a heart attack at her home here. Her age was 52.

title: Dave Anderson
description: The nomads of the bowling tour usually are nonames. Only a few names emerge from the rumble of the alleys. Don Carter is one. Dick Weber is another. Several years ago, Billy Hardwick was a name. Twice upon a time, Billy Hardwick was the bowler of the year, in 1969 and 1963, but now he's not even the bowler of the week. It's like I forgot how to bowl, he says. I'm completely lost. When the finals of the United States open bowling championships are televised from Madison Square Garden Centertoday, 32yearold Billy Hardwick will be watching in his Louisville, Ky., home. He vent there Wednesday after having failed to qualify for the last three days of the tournament. He hasn't won on the tour since 1969, when he won raven tournaments while earning $64,160 in prize money. The next year, he slipped to $21,183. Since then his annual earnings have been minimal$8,918, $5,095 and $7,300.

title: Louis W. Niggeman, 58, Dead; Led Firemen's Fund Insurance
description: Louis W. Niggeman, chairman and chief executive officer of the Fireman's Fund American Insurance Companies, died Thursday on a business trip in Klosters, Switzerland. He was 58 years old and lived in Kentfield, Calif., a San Francisco suburb.

title: IRAQ ASSERTS IRAN SPURRED CLASHES
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 15Iraq accused Iran in the Security Council today of provoking border fighting in an expansionist drive to take control of the Persian Gulf area.

title: No Article
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Miss Larrieu's 4:12.2 World Mark in 1,500
description: TORONTO, Feb. 15 (Reuters)  Francie Larrieu of Sunnyvale, Calif., set a world indoor record for the women's 1,500meter run tonight when she did 4 minutes 12.2 seconds at the Toronto StarMaple Leaf Games.

title: Squeeze on Independents
description: In the last several months, many service station ownersindependent businessmen who have run their small gasoline stations Much like the neighborhood delicatessens of years pasthave found themselves in a squeeze, beset by the shortage of gasoline and by what they consider efforts by large oil companies to drive them from the market place and replace them with heavypumping, highgallonage stations.

title: DELINQUENT LOANS UP 19% IN SURVEY
description: The number of persons not paying their installment loans on time increased by 19 per, cent in November and December, partly because of inflation and the slowdown in the economy.

title: Laver Upset by Taylor in Italy
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, Feb. 15 (AP)Roger Taylor of Britain, advanced to the semifinals of a World Championship Tennis tournament here today by upsetting Rod Laver of Australia, who was seeded first, 75, 61.

title: Lenin Assailed Czarists On Exile Without Trial
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 15  The Soviet Novosti press agency today circulated to foreign embassies and newsmen a translation of a letter in which Lenin vigorously protested the exile of Russian workers by the czarist regime without trial and by administrative means.

title: 163,039 Seeking City Job Where No Openings Exist
description: The city's Pergonnel Department said yesterday that a record 163,039 persons had applied for the Civil Service sanitationman's examination at a time when there are no vacancies in the Sanitation Department.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 1.5 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 223.2 from 221.7 last week.

title: Tenure and Freedom
description: A drive to emasculate the concept of faculty tenure in colleges and universities is gaining ground under the camouflage of a reform movement in search of academic excellence.

title: STANLEY R. MILLARD
description: BOONTON, N. J., Feb. 15Stanley R, Millard, an assistant vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, on an Erie Lackawanna train near Mountain View. He was 56 years old and lived on Decker Lane here.

title: U.S. Urges Gasoline Priorities For Private Cars of Physicians
description: The regional administrator of the Federal Energy Office Gerald J. Turetsky, urged local governments yesterday to make their gasoline pumps available to doctor's cars and other privately registered vehicles that are used for emergency services.

title: U.S. Urged to Adopt Standards To Protect Workers on Plastics
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15Labor representatives and Government and university scientists today urged the Labor Department's Occupational Health and Safety Administration to adopt emergency standards to protect workers exposed to vinyl chloride, a gaseous chemical that is the foundation for much of the plastics industry.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASHES RESUME ON GOLAN HEIGHTS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 15Clashes between Syrian and Israeli forces were reported today on the Golan Heights front after a lull of about two days.

title: 9 Seized With Guns And $16,500 Cash In Motel in Queens
description: Twelve policemen and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, investigating a series of holdups in Queens that had netted more than $110,000 since last December, seized five men and four women early yesterday in a motel near Kennedy International Airport.

title: Donohue's Easy Victory Makes Quitting Tougher
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 15With a lot of regret, Mark Donohue ended his racing career today with an easy victory in a contest intended to decide the greatest driver in the world.

title: Wildcat Well Yields Oil In Venezuela's Maracaibo
description: A wildcat well, said to be the deepest drilled in Latin America, has yielded oil beneath Venezuela's South Lake Maracaibo.

title: MRS. BANUELOS QUITS U.S. TREASURER POST
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UPI) Romana Acosta Banuelos, highestranking SpanishAmerican in the Nixon Administration, has resigned as Treasurer of the United States, Treasury Department officials said today.

title: REUBEN L. PHILLIPS
description: Reuben L. Phillips, music director of the Apollo Theater on 125th Street since 1953, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, in San Juan, P.R., where he was playing alto saxophone in a band with a Sammy Davis Jr. show. He was 53 years old and lived at 144 Lake Street, Englewood, N.J.

title: Cultural Revolution's Spirit but Not Frenzy
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 15Now that the whole of China has come under a barrage of appeals to plunge spontaneously into a movement modeled on the Cultural Revolution, references to Red Guards and Little Red Guards are being heard with increasing frequency.

title: The Screen: 'Crazy Joe'
description: It's only fair, I suppose, that an Italian movie producer should be allowed to participate in the current Mafia boom. Although that nonexistent brotherhood only got going when it got going here, the Mafia does, after all, have its origins in Sicily.Dino De Laurentiis, the man who gave us "The Valachi Papers," now gives us "Crazy Joe," a lumpy, violent, fictionalized biography of the late Joseph (Crazy Joe) Gallo, the flamboyant hood who was gunned down on April 7, 1972, at a clam house in Little Italy. The film opened yesterday at Loew's State 2 and other theaters in the city.At the time of Gallo's murder, his sister is reported to have said that Joe had changed his image, which is why he was shot. The movie, though simple of mind, is a lot more complicated. Joe's movie enemies couldn't give a fig that he liked to hobnob with actors and writers. They don't even seem to mind that he attempts to stun his associates by dropping the names of Camus and Sartre, though the way the movie presents him, his intellectual pretensions do prompt a few giggles.No. According to the screenplay by Lewis John Carlino, which utilizes facts of Joseph Gallo's life as put together in a story by Nicholas Gage, Crazy Joe was rubbed out not because he was a party bore but because he was trying to take over a Mafia family run by his former protector. At least, I think that's the reason. The way the movie presents them, the ins and outs of Mafia family wars are as difficult to follow as pre-World War I Balkan politics, though not quite so fascinating.Nothing in the production helps much. A re-creation of the 1971 Italian-American Day rally in Columbus Circle, where Joe Colombo was shot, is the film's one attempt at spectacle.In life, Crazy Joe was supposed to possess a certain amount of charm, but Peter Boyle plays him as if he were a dim-witted numbers runner. He's such a slob that the casting of beautiful, intelligent Paula Prentiss as his girl becomes one of the minor mysteries of the movie year. Could she have wandered onto the wrong set?Eli Wallach impersonates a Mafia don with as much conviction as is possible in a movie in which the aging process is represented by simply putting more blue into the actor's hair. Rip Torn, another good actor, is seen briefly as Joe's brother.The film was directed by Carlo Lizzani, who seems to have done nothing to offset the weaknesses of the casting and the screenplay, which makes a ridiculous gesture toward black film audiences by inflating Crazy Joe's association with black hoods. Fred Williamson ("Hammer"), plays the black mob chief as if he thought the movie were really about civil rights.As movies go these days, "Crazy Joe" is not very long (100 minutes), but after the first 15 I kept looking at my watch, wishing I could hurry things along to the clam house.

title: Knicks' LineUps
description: AT GARDEN2:30 P.M. Radio, WNBC, 2:30 P.M.

title: Hearst Kidnapping Linked To Two Escaped Convicts
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 15Two escaped convicts were reported today to be providing the leadership for the mysterious Symbionese Liberation Army, the group that kidnapped 19yearold Patricia Hearst.

title: GCE. REPORTS PROFIT ON SALE OF SHARES
description: Reginald H. Jones, chairman and chief execeutive officer of the General Electric Company, reported yesterday that only 3 cents of 1973 pershare earnings came from sales of Honeywell stock, compared with 11 cents in 1972.

title: EDWARD CURRAN, RIGHTWING PRIEST
description: The Rev. Edward Lodge Curran, a Roman Catholic cleric who for many years had supported causes led by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, the Royal Oak, Mich., radio priest; Generalissimo Francisco Franco and the late Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, died Thursday in St. Charles Hospital, Port Jefferson, L. I. He was 75 years old.

title: Solzhenitsyn Is in Zurich In Seclusion With Lawyer
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 15Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn came to Switzerland this afternoon and went into seclusion in the suburban apartment of his lawyer.

title: Four Killed as Auto Strikes Pillar of an El in Brooklyn
description: Four personstwo men and two womenwere killed in Brooklyn early this morning when their car, apparently out of control, struck an elevatedsubway pillar at New Utrecht Avenue and 56th Street in the Borough Park section.

title: G.M. Recalling 1.2 Million Cars Because of Faulty Brake Part
description: DETROIT, Feb. 15 (UPI) General Motors Corporation said today that it was recalling 1.2 million passenger cars and trucks because of a defective brake part that had already resulted in eight minor accidents.

title: Bill to Give Child Custody Voice Gains
description: TRENTON, Feb. 15 The State Senate approved a bill today that would guarantee a child the right to express a choice between living with his mother or father in a legal matrimonial separation proceeding.

title: A Rothko Executor Reports Pressure
description: One of three executors of the estate of the late painter Mark Rothko testified in Surrogate Court yesterday that he had been pressured by the other two executors and their lawyer into agreeing to a contract that is being attacked in the court by Rothko's heirs.

title: Jordan Planning to Modernize Forces
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 13Jordan is planning a major organization and modernization of her armed forces as a result of hard lessons learned during her limited participation in October war, according to liable sources here.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Copper Also Reaches High
description: Scare buying of raw materials by manufacturers and foreign governments sent wheat and copper futures to historic highs yesterday and caused sharp price increases in most other commodities.

title: Collision Course
description: When President Nixon appointed Leon Jaworski special Watergate prosecutor last fall, he authorized Acting Attorney General Robert H. Bork to assure the public that Mr. Jaworski had a firm promise of full cooperation of the executive branch.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED IN THE CAN INDUSTRY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) The nation's four largest can manufacturers and the United Steelworkers of America have agreed on a new threeyear contract covering about 38,000 employes.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES INCREASE BY 3.1% AS OUTPUT DROPS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The Government reported today a huge jump in wholseale prices and a further sizable decline in industrial production in January. The figures, taken with an earlier report of higher unemployment last month, provided probably the worst set of monthly economic statistics in at least a quarter century.

title: 2 SAIGON SOLDIERS RECALL 2 U.S. P.O.W.'S
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 15 (AP)Two South Vietnamese soldiers released from a Vietcong prisoner of war camp said today they were detained during the early stages of their two years in captivity with two Americans.

title: PHILIP NEVILLE, 64, U.S. DISTRICT JUDGE
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 15 (AP) Judge Philip Neville of the United States District Court here, died Wednesday of leukemia at the University of Minnesota Hospital. His age was 64.

title: Gen. Menard Nominated
description: TRENTON, Feb. 15 (UPI)Brig. Gen. Wilfred C. Menard Jr., assistant chief of staff in the State Department of Defense, was, nominated by Governor Byrne today to head the department. He will hold they title of chief of staff.

title: Penn Wins, Stays Tied With Brown
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 15 (AP)Jim Busam, with 18 points, and Phil Brown, with 15, sparked Brown to a 7156 victory over Columbia tonight in an Ivy League game at the Providence Civic Center.

title: Shock Hazard Is Reported In 3,000 Clothes Dryers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UPI) The Consumer Product Safety Commission warned today that about 3,000 gas and electric clothes dryers delivered since last November might have defective timers that could cause fatal electric shock.

title: Paper's Price Goes Up
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) The Washington StarNews announced today that its newsstand price wil go up to 15 cents on Monday. The present price is 10 cents.

title: G.A.O to Halt Funds for Agnew's Guard
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The General Accounting Office notified the Treasury Department today that payments for Secret Service protection of former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew would be cut off after Sunday.

title: G.M. REQUESTS DELAY IN DATA ON GAS USE
description: DETROIT, Feb. 15 (AP)The General Motors Corporation has asked the Environmental Protection Agency to delay the release of 1975model fule statistics until September, apparently for fear it would hurt sales of 1974 cars, The Detroit Free Press reported today.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 33

title: Campus Notes
description: A center for a woman's group on the Swarthmore College campus will open its doors for the first time tonight with a performance by It's All Right to Be Woman, a feminist theater group from New York City.

title: Bernard Gorfinkle Dies; Wilson Bodyguard in '18
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Feb. 15 (AP)  Brig. Gen. Bernard L. Gorfinkle, U.S.A., retired, who was a bodyguard for President Woodrow Wilson at the signing of the peace treaty ending World War I, died yesterday in a Boston hospital.

title: U. S. COMMUNITIES TO MEET RUSSIANS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15About a dozen business executives, including the chairman of General Motors, intend to bring Soviet trade officials to their local communities this month to seek grassroots support for broadened commerce with the Soviet Union.

title: Hearst Kidnapping Linked To Two Escaped Convicts
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 15Two escaped convicts were reported today to be providing the leadership for the mysterious Symbionese Liberation Army, the group that kidnapped 19yearold Patricia Hearst.

title: Continental to Sell 4747's Idled Recently to Save Fuel
description: Continental Airlines said in Los Angeles yesterday that it would sell four Boeing 747 planes that were removed from service last month to save fuel. The planes were purchased by Continental between 1970 and 1972 at a cost of more than $23million each.

title: Antiques: The Big One
description: Thursday night and yesterday morning the scene was just as chaotic as 30 years ago, when Nathan H. Mager and 125 antiques dealers prepared to open the first National Antiques Show at the old Madison Square Garden.

title: MRS. HELEN B. HALE
description: Mrs. Helen Bingham Hale; divorced wife of the late Thomas, Shaw Hale, Who served as a New York district attorney under Thomas E. Dewey, died Wednesday in Roosevelt Hospital of complications; fallowing surgery. She was 75 years old and lived at 116 East 63d Street. Mr. Hale died March 17, 1972.

title: I.C.C. ORDERS AID TO OWNERDRIVERS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today regulations requiring trucking companies to pay the increased costs of fuel for independent truck owneroperators who work for them under contract.

title: 10,000 Dead or Missing In Fighting, Manila Says
description: ZAMBOANGA, the Phillipines, Feb. 15 (AP)  The Government reported today that some 10,000 persons died or were reported missing in fighting over the last 10 days between Moslem rebels and Government troops at Jolo In the Sulu Islands.

title: Rampaging Mob of TeenAgers Wrecks St. Albans Restaurant
description: A mob of about 100 teenagers, including members of youth gangs, rampaged through a fastfood restaurant in St. Albans, Queens, last night, causing an estimated $10,000 in damage, the police reported.

title: Ruling on 1972 MigrantEvictidn Case Nears
description: CAMDEN, Feb. 15Judge Peter J. Devine of State Superior Court here has indicated that he will rule soon on a 17monthold suit brought to test whether farmers can summarily evict migrant workers from labor camps.

title: PUBLIC OWNERSHIP OF ENERGY IS URGED
description: DETROIT, Feb. 15 (UPI)The United Automobile Workers urged today the formation of a public energy corporation to remove the nation's energy supply from a small group of powerful vested interests concerned primarily with profitmaking.

title: Mother Goes Off to WorkButRetieCan. Her Small Child Go?
description: What's a liberated mother to do? If she wants a career and has a family, she automatically faces a quandary: who's, to tend her children eight hours a day, five days a week, yearround, save vacations?

title: 500,000 May Lose Free Student Loans
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The Administration proposed today that the Federal Government cease subsidizing interest on student loans except for those persons most in need.

title: Saigon Cabinet Resigns; But Premier Stays On
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 16 (AP)The South Vietnamese Cabinet of Premier Tran Thien Khiem resigned today in the most sweeping Government change since President Nguyen Van Thieu took office seven years ago.

title: Jipcho Captures 4:03.4 Mile, 2Mile in 8:34 in Pro Debut
description: UNIONDALE, LI., Feb. 15 Ben Jipcho scored an incredible distance double tonight that reaffirmed his status as the world's finest runner of the hour, amateur or professional.

title: Mount Vernon School System Is Struggling With State and Federal Orders to Desegregate
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Feb. 15When Hilda Stevens was a teenager in Robersonville, N.C., she was taken by bus each weekday to W. C. Chance High School in Parmete, three miles away, instead of walking to Robersonville High, three blocks from her home.

title: Donohue's Easy Victory Makes Quitting Tougher
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 15With a lot of regret, Mark Donohue ended his racing career today with an easy victory in a contest intended to decide the greatest driver in the world.

title: Notes on People
description: Judith T. Younger, associate dean of the Hofstra University School of Law, has been named dean of the College of Law at Syracuse University. Mrs. Younger will be the first woman to head a law school in the state. She succeeds Jerome A. Barron, who resigned last July. Mrs. Younger, who is 40 years old, is the wife of Judge Irving Younger of the Civil Court here.

title: 20 Dead in Argentine Floods
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 15 (Reuters)At least 20 people have died and 30 are missing in flooding in 10 provinces of northern and central Argentina, according to an official report issued here today.

title: 500,000 May Lose Free Student Loans
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The Administration proposed today that the Federal Government cease subsidizing interest on student loans except for those persons most in need.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: DELINQUENT LOANS UP 19% IN SURVEY
description: The number of persons not paying their installment loans on time increased by 19 per cent in November and December, partly because of inflation and the slowdown in the economy.

title: WINE TALK
description: This is the time of the year when Wine enthusiasts begin poring over vineyard maps, thumbing through Michelin and the Mobil Guide and generally psyching themselves up for the coming summer trips to the wine country. Gasoline supplies willing, of course.

title: French Leave Tennis Meetings
