description: PARIS Feb 15 (AP)In an angry protest against the new agreement between the International Lawn Tennis Federation and the World Team Tennis organization, the Frehch Tennis Federation walked out of the international ruling body today. The French urged other European countries to de the same.

title: A.T.E. LOSES BID ON MCI CIRCUITS
description: The MCI Communications Corporations reported yesterday in Philadelphia that a United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit had denied an appeal by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to stay a lower court injunction ordering the Bell System to provide circuits connecting MCI customers to A.T.&T.'s network.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: AUDIO The land is rich in radio buffs, folks who regret the day television took over the house. They have clubs and journals and collect old tapes of Fred Allen, Fibber McGee, Jack Benny and The Green Hornet among others. In New York the radiophile cell is called the Radio Library Society, a cadre of about 10 aficionados, who have decided to go public, in an extremely limited way.

title: PENNSY EXERCISING LOAN GRACE PERIODS
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 (AP) Grace periods on $7.8million in payments due on certain conditional sale and equipment trust obligations are being exercised, trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company said today.

title: DRUG ABUSE FOUND RISING AMONG RICH
description: MORRISTOWN, Feb. 15 Uppermiddle and highincome residential areas  rather than lowincome racially mixed large communities  became the focus of narcotics use in Morris County in 1973, according to a new report.

title: A.B.C. Cancels Sex Symbol
description: The American Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that it has canceled the March 5 showing of the television movie The Sex Symbol, whose plot closely follows events in the life of Marilyn Monroe. The filmas fictional actress, played by Connie Stevens, is married to a professional football player and has an affair with a prominent politician.

title: U.C.L.A Upset, 6157, By Oregon State Five
description: CORVALLIS, Ore., Feb. 15 (AP)  Outside shooting by Paul Miller and four free throws by George Tucker carried Oregon State to a 6157 upset over topranked University of California, Los Angeles, tonight.

title: St. Clair's Statement and Excerpts From Ziegler's News Briefing
description: MIAMI, Feb. 15Following are a statement by James St. Clair, the President's lawyer, issued today by the White House, and excerpts from a briefing with reporters this morning by Ronald L. Ziegler on the St. Clair statement:

title: Newman Quits Posts At McCrory Corp.
description: Recent obstacles in the proposed sale of several chains by the McCrory Corporation to Interstate Stores, Inc., resulted yesterday in the resignation of Samuel Neaman as chairman of McCrory, so he could pursue negotiations to become Interstate's president and chief executive officer.

title: Meskill Backs Preferential Sales
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 15  Connecticut's Attorney General, Robert K. Killian, said today that he had been informed by the Federal energy office in Washington that it was unsure about the validity of its order prohibiting, gasoline station operators from giving preferential treatment to their regular customers.

title: Father Under Pressure Randolph Apperson Hearst
description: HILLSBOROUGH, Calif., Feb. 15Although he spol to his questioners, the in pression was that the tall wellgroomed man on the steps was really speaking those who kidnapped his daughter.

title: Seven Players Shoot 70 For Women's Golf Lead
description: NAPLES, Fla., Feb. 15 (AP) Seven players were tied with 70's after today's first round of the $38,000 Naples Lily classic, a Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: Coffee Italian Style
description: MILAN, Italy, Feb. 15 (AP) The Milan Soccer Club today banned its players from lacing their espresso coffee with brandy on Saturday nights. The team said the mixture, a popular afterdinner drink in Italy, might make the players nervous in league matches the following day.

title: The Stage
description: A father's desire to be emulated by his son, a son's desire for individuality are the timeless themes of Michael Smith's new play, Prussian Suite. The father in this instance is King of Prussia, the son is the Crown Prince, but the play is less a tale about monarchy than about love and the absence of love.

title: Limited Peace And War
description: LEYDEN, the NetherlandsIt is probably logical that an era known for limited warsrather than total holocaustsshould also be known for limited peaces rather than utter international tranquility. Therefore, since America has managed to avoid disastrous showdowns with the other superpower, Russia, it should not be excoriated for inability to achieve a more wholesome diplomatic relationship than relative dtente.

title: Dance: Faison Company
description: By electing to create a threeact fullevening work, In the Sweet Now and Now, George Faison joins a small group of modern dancers that includes Alwin Nikolais and Martha Graham.

title: Hill of Princeton To Leave School
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 15 Armond Hill, a former high school allAmerican basketball player and high scorer for the Princeton University team, will be leaving Princeton because of academic difficulties, Samuel Howell, the athletic director, said today.

title: AIDES SAY NIXON STRIVES TO AVOID JAWORSKI CLASH
description: MIAMI, Feb. 15  The White House said today that despite President Nixon's refusal to turn over tapes and documents to Leon Jaworski, the President wanted to avoid another point of confrontation with the Watergate prosecution.

title: MEANT AND WALLACE MEET FOR AN HOUR
description: MIAMI, Feb, 15 (UPI)Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, once described by A.F.L.C.I.O. President George Meany as a bigot, met privately with Mr. Meany this week, it was learned today.

title: London Close Is $148.90
description: LONDON, Feb. 15 (UPI)Buyers flooded European gold markets today, driving prices to Irecords in a flurry of speculative trading. The dollar closed marginally lower in most markets.

title: Negotiations on Dean Book Reported
description: Farrar, Straus & Giroux, the publisher, has nearly cornpleted negotiations toward acquiring the rights to a forthcoming largely autobiographical book by the dismissed White Houe counsel, John W. Dean 3d, a highly placed publishing industry informant reported last night.

title: Mackell Is Denied Motions For Mistrial and Dismissal
description: Defense motions for a mistrial on constitutional issues raised in the trial of former District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens were denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh as the fifth week of the misdemeanor trial ended.

title: Canadiens Overwhelm Wings, 94
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 15 (UPI) Yvan Cournoyer and Frank Mahovlich scored twice apiece for Montreal and the Canadiens got five goals in the first period tonight while defeating the Detroit Red Wings, 94, in a National Hockey League game.

title: Horses & Equipment
description: Horses & Equipment 3995

title: World Trade Reform
description: The energy crisis, coupled with the prospect of shortages in other raw materials, has fundamentally altered the world trade outlook and given new urgency to the negotiations projected for trade reform. These negotiations now must deal not only with the problem of free access to markets, which has been the central concern in the past, but also with the pressing new problem free access to supplies, particularly when restricted by cartels.

title: A.T. & T. to Tell Clients of Subpoenas
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced today that it would begin notifying all customers whose longdistance phone records are subpoenaed by Government investigators in the future unless the investigators raise a formal objection.

title: Couriers Who Didn't Keep Appointed Rounds
description: Following are excerpts from an opinion that Judge Marvin E. Frankel of the Federal District Court here handed down recently in connection with the sentencing of four postal employes convicted of having stolen mail entrusted to them for delivery.

title: U. S. COMMUNITIES TO MEET RUSSIANS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15About a dozen business executives, including the chair man of General Motors, intend to bring Soviet trade officials to their local communities this month to seek grassroots support for broadened commerce with the Soviet Union.

title: Unmitigated Gaul
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15It is difficult to imagine any harder work these days than being a Frenchman. French friends insist, however, that nothing Is easier. All you have to, do is be right when everyone else is wrong. It is a labor, they tell me, that buoys the spirit and leaves the selfesteem refreshed.

title: Nets Turn Back Colonels As Ewing Puts on Show
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 15The University of Cincinnati's Armory Field House is supposed to give the Kentucky Colonels a homecourt advantage, but it failed last night as Julius Erving scored 36 points and the New York Nets soundly beat the Colonels, 115101.

title: Jersey Ponders Source of Bonus
description: TRENTON, Feb. 15Governor Byrne announced today that Federal energy officials had increased New Jersey's monthly gasoline allocations by 2.5 million gallons to make up for gasoline stocks lost due to the pullout of gasoline suppliers from the state during the last two years.

title: Bulls Beat Bucks, 9290, On Sloan's Basket at End
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 15 (UPI)Jerry Sloan hit a jump shot from 17 feet as the final horn sounded to give the Chicago Bulls a tough 9290 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

title: It's No Gold Rush but Klondike Pays Well Again
description: DAWSON, Yukon Territory, Feb. 15After 40 hard years of prospecting for gold in the valley of the Klondike River, Art Fry has finally come upon good times, thanks to the soaring prices in financial capitals thousands of miles away.

title: Inquiry Set on PoliceCar Vandalism in Passaic
description: PATERSON, Feb. 15A Passaic County grand jury will begin an investigation on Feb. 25 into whether Passaic patrolmen vandalized the cars of their superior officers, it was announced today.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 15New Jersey schools begin their annual drive for state indoor track and field honors at the Jersey City Armory tomorrow with the question again being how far Union can go with its shotput crew.

title: Judge Frees a Man Who Spent 22 Years In Prison in Attica
description: Justice Hyman Barshay of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn dismissed a murder indictment against a 41yearold man who had spent 22 years in the state prison in Attica.

title: MITCHELL AND STANS FACE TRIAL TUESDAY
description: A final pretrial conference yesterday cleared the way for former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans to go on trial Tuesday in Federal District Court here.

title: Iowan Finds Small Town A Fertile Business Area
description: IDA GROVE, IowaByron LeRoy Godbersen is well known hearabouts as the inventor of the electric pitchfork.

title: Ranger Golden Boy, Carr, Traded to Kings
description: The Rangers' wouldbe Golden Boy, Gene Carr, ended his career as a New Yorker yesterday and was traded to Los Angeles Kings.

title: Sinatra Plans 9City Tour
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 15 (AP) Frank Sinatra will make 12 concert appearances in nine) United States cities, ??carting in New York's Carne?? Hall on April 8. Mr. Sinatra came out of two years of selfimposed retirement las fall with a television special on the National Broadcasting Company network Nov. 18.

description: Soviet Skater Out of Title Meet

title: First Inventor of the Year Is Chosen
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15Byron B. Brenden, who has been chosen inventor of the year for his achievements in acoustical holography, is about to receive a new patent in the field. Acoustical holography is a method of observing the interior of a solid, whether the human body or something made of metal or ceramics. The new patent, to be issued in a few weeks, covers improved fluidfilled ultrasonic lenses, in which images are created with sound waves.

title: Trooper Tells Squire Trial He Did Not Flee Shootout
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 15A New Jersey state trooper testifying in the murder trial of Clark D. Squire vigorously denied today that he had,panicked and ran away from a buddy in trouble during a shootout on the New Jersey Turnpike last May 2.

title: RHEINGOLD PLANT ISN'T CLOSED YET
description: A further extension was an flounced yesterday in a shut down deadline for the Rhein gold brewery in Brooklyn a negotiations continued to se?? the plant.

title: Chlorine Shortage: Threat to Drinking Water
description: LINCOLN, Neb.The nation faces threat to its safe drinking water that could grow into a serious crisis if steps are not taken soon to head it off.

title: Rangers' LineUps AT VANCOUVER
Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: C.A.B. ASKS CHANGE IN AIRLINE'S CLUB
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15Admirals Club lounges, where American Airlines' V.I.P. passengers have relaxed between flights since 1938, will lose a little of their exclusive aura under a Civil Aeronautics Board order announced this week.

title: A Quiet Albany Session
description: ALBANY, Feb. 15What will become of a supersober legislative session led by a teetotaler?

title: C Bs Jimmy, $20, Scores Upset in Pronto Don Trot
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 15 The richest trotting race at the Roosevelt Raceway meeting, the $25,000 Pronto Don, was won tonight by the longest shot in the field of six, Clarence Carter's C Bs Jimmy. The oddson favorite, Charon, finished last in his quest for an eighth straight victory.

title: Baking Group Wants U. S. to Call a Halt To Exports of Wheat
description: Baking industry spokesmen, predicting a severe wheat shortage by late spring, demanded yesterday that the Department of Agriculture cease further wheat exports and make a public accounting of available reserves.

title: Briefs on Energy
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 15 (AP)Gasoline allocations based on the serial numbers of inspection stickers will replace Pennsylvania's present licenseplatenumber plan, Gov. Milton Shapp said today. After meeting for about two hours with station representatives, Governor. Shapp said he agreed with their request for the switch. The Governor refused to disclose further details of the meeting, saying that a full announcement would be made Monday.

title: DR. PETER BECKETT
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 15 (AP)Dr. Peter G. S. Beckett, former resident psychiatrist at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., died here Wednesday. He was 52 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: United States Treasury agents seized two suspected gunrunners for the Irish Republican Army and a cache of 70 Colt AR15 semiautomatic rifles in a rented van at 39th Avenue and 54th Street in Woodside, Queens.

title: Bonavena Fight Off
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 15. (AP)Oscar Bonavena, the Argentine heavyweight boxer, is suffering from a liver ailment and will not be able to fight Ron Lyle in Denver, Feb. 28, his doctors said today. He was to have left here Monday. It was not known whether the fight would be reset.

title: U. S. Aide Denies Nixon Soviet Policy Has Failed
description: A high Administration official asserted yesterday that Moscow's expulsion of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn in no way represented a failure of President Nixon's policy of improving relations with the Russians as a means of influencing their treatment of Soviet Jews.

title: QUEENS FIRE CANCELS 5 L.I.BOUND TRAINS
description: A smoky twoalarm fire at the Hunters Point station of the Long Island Rail Road caused the cancellation last night of five trains bound for Long Island.

title: Events Today
description: Events Today

title: Music: 1,000 Symphony
description: It was a crowded stage at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night, as it needs must be when Mahler's Eighth Symphony is on the program All those soloistsseven of themand the massed choirs and the expanded symphony orchestra. And, as always happens under these circumstances in Fisher Hall, it was an acoustic mess. The bass all but disappeared, and the sound resembled that of an overcut stereo disk full of inner groove distortion.

title: ROCKETS JAMMED ON SKYLAB'S RETURN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today the third crew of Skylab had spent their last hour in space not knowing if the maneuvering rockets on their return ship would work.

title: Pentagon Predicts Saving
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UPI) The Defense Department estimated today that it would save about $500million a year in manpower training costs by 1977 because recruits for the allvolunteer armed forces were signing up for longer tours of duty. Assistant Defense Secretary William K. Brehm said that this meant the services would need fewer recruits and would spend less time and money training them.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: United States Treasury agents yesterday seized two suspected gunrunners for the Irish Republican Army and a cache of 70 Colt AR15 semiautomatic rifles in a rented van at 39th Avenue and 64th Street in Woodside, Queens.

title: BUCK FREEMAN, 69, BASKETBALL COACH
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 15 (UPI)James A. (Buck) Freeman, coach of St. John's University basketball teams it New York in the nineteen twenties and thirties, and of other teams thereafter, died yesterday at the age of 69.

title: People in Sports: A Dim View Seen by Robinson
description: According to Frank Robinson, of the California Angels, a man highlyplaced in baseball once told him that his five years of coaching experience in the winter leagues didn't count. So, now Robinson, a most valuable player In both major leagues and long considered the prime candidate to become the first black manager in the majors says of that aspiration: I'm no longer seriously considering the prospect.... I just don't think it will happen soon.

title: Friend Lends His Slopes To Williams Ski Carnival
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 15  Jim Kelly, the operator of nearby Brodie Mountain, again proved to be a good neighbor today. He donated the use of his big ski resort to the Williams College Outing Club.

title: MARGARET MARTIGNONI
description: Margaret Martignoni, executive secretary of the New York, Library Association, died of a heart attack Monday in her apartment at 435 East 57th Street. Her age was 65.

title: ExHousing Aide Is Freed On Coercion Attempt Count
description: Charges of attempted coercion were dismissed in State Supreme Court yesterday against William Decker Clarke, a former city housing official.

title: STEELPIPE MAKER INCREASES PRICES
description: The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company said yesterday had raised prices, effective today, on a wide range of tubular products. At the same time it will rescind a surcharge in effect since Jan. 1 Youngstown said it will raise published prices on such oil country products as casing and drill pipe by about 6 per cent and on tubing by about 12 pet cent. Price increases for standard pipe and line pipe will vary according to the finish and method of manufacture.

title: Chapin Judge Criticizes Pretrial Publicity on Dean
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15Federal Judge Gerhard A. Gesell tried today to calm the rising public debate about the truthfulness of John W. Dean 3d, the former White House counsel and key witness in the Watergate case, and chided lawyers on both sides of the argument.

title: MRS. D. JAMES DeWOLFE
description: Mrs. Karen von Maltitz DeWolfe, a former copywriter for Dreher Advertising, Inc., and the wife of D. James DeWolfe, vice president of Kelly, Nason, Inc., an advertising agency, died Thursday at the Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center. She was 31 years old and lived at 2 Beekman Place.

title: G.A.O. to Halt Funds for Agnew's Guard
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The General Accounting Office notified the Treasury Department today that payments for Secret Service protection of former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew would be cut off after Sunday.

title: AIDES SAY NIXON STRIVES TO AVOID JAWORSKI CLASH
description: MIAMI, Feb. 15  The White House said today that despite President Nixon's refusal to turn over tapes and documents to Leon Jaworski, the President wanted to avoid another point of confrontation with the Watergate prosecution.

description: HOUSTON (99)Murphy 8 23 18; Newlin 7 56 19; Smith 3 34 9; Coleman 3 00 6; Tomjanoyich 7 68 20; Ratleft 3 00 6; Kunnert 0 00 0; Mealy 6 35 15; Wohl 3 00 6. Totals40 1926.

title: Delta Set to Get 4 Tristars
description: BURBANK, Calif., Feb. 15 (UPI)  Delta Air Lines has agreed to accept earlier delivery of four Tristar jetliners, the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation said today.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Kennedy Is Saying Privately He Won't Run
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15Senator Edward M. Kennedy is saying privately, to his closest political associates, that it is extremely unlikely that he will run for President in 1976.

title: Danish Group to Build Plant
description: ENFIELD, Conn., Feb. 15 (AP)A Danish concern plans to build a $15million toy manufacturing and distribution complex here, company officials have announced, John M. Sullivan, president of the Brookfieldbased American division of Lego Systems Inc. said plans called for a 400,000squarefoot complex to be built on a 76acre parcel here. It will employ 800 people.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES INCREASE BY 3.1% AS OUTPUT DROPS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The Government reported today huge jump in wholseale prices and a further sizable decline in industrial production in January. The figures, taken with an earlier report of higher unemployment last month, provided probably the worst set of monthly economic statistics in at least a quarter century.

title: PETROSIAN, PORTISCH ADJOURN 13TH GAME
description: PALMA DE MALLORCA, Spain, Feb. 15 (UPI)Lajos Portisch of Hungary and Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union today adjourned the 13th game of their International Chess Federation quarterfinals match after 40 moves.

title: U.S. and City Officials Discuss Transit and Job Aid
description: Mayor Beame and a group of his toplevel aides spent six hours in City Hall yesterday trying to persuade four highranking Nixon Administration figures that New York City urgently needed more Federal money to operate mass transit, to rehabilitate slum areas and to provide jobs for the disadvantaged.

title: Hope of Easing Embargo On Oil Heartens Market
description: Speculation that the Arab oil embargo may end soon or at least be eased enabled the stock market to make sizable gains yesterday in continued light trading.

title: Davis Leads Field of 5 Into U.S. Bowling Finals
description: Dave Davis, who has been the leader since the 24game mark, clung to first place through two sessions yesterday as the final 16 games of match play were completed in the $85,000 United States open bowling tournament at Madison Square Garden. The tourney is sponsored by the Bowling Proprietors of America.

title: MORE BANKS CUT LOAN RATE TO
description: More major commercial banks, following the lead established last week by the Cleveland Trust Company and then, among the biggest banks, by the Bankers Trust Company on Thursday, lowered yesterday the interest rate they charge large corporations for loans.

title: Squeeze on Independents
description: In the last several months, many service station ownersindependent businessmen who have run their small gasoline stations much like the neighborhood delicatessens of years pasthave found themselves in a squeeze, beset by the shortage of gasoline and by what they consider efforts by large oil companies to drive them from the market place and replace them with heavypumping, highgallonage stations.

title: Wilson Gives Deadline For Formal Candidacy
description: Governor Wilson said yesterday that he would formally announce his candidacy for a full term as Governor some time before the June meeting of the state's Republican party.

title: UTILITY STUDY SET ON PACTS IN STATE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 15  The chairman of the Assembly Committee on Commerce, Industry and Economic Development said today that he would begin an investigation of all publicutility construction contracts in the stateparticularly the one for the Consolilated Edison Company's Storm King plant.

title: Schaap Remark Of fends Cooke; WNBC Plans No New Comment
description: WNBCTV will stand by with no further comment than the two public apologies made bf Dick Schaap, the television sportscaster, for making a remark called particularly offensive by Cardinal Cooke, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: Julie Eisenhower Is Doing Very Well After Cyst Surgery
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 15 (AP) Mrs. David Eisenhower was reported in satisfactory condition today and on the road to recovery from emergency surgery performed to halt internal bleeding from an ovarian cyst.

title: BONN CONFIRMS TRUST REPORTS
description: BONN, Feb. 15The West German Government today confirmed press reports that its antitrust office had produced evidence of possible price manipulation by international oil companies.

title: Holiday Closings Monday
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges will be closed Monday, Feb. 18 for Washington's Birthday. All major commodities exchanges will also be closed, as will, banks in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: RumaniaLibya Ties Set
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Feb. 15 (AP)  Rumania and Libya will establish diplomatic relations, the Rumanian press reported today. It said the move was announced in a joint communiqu after President Nicolae Ceausescu ended a visit to Libya. Mr. Ceausescu is the first head of state from a Warsaw Pact nation to visit Libya's antiCommunist leader, Col. Muammar elQaddafi, who has avoided contacts with the Communist bloc.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company received $42million in military contract awards comprising of a $30.5million addition to a previously awarded Navy contract for Phoenix airtoairmissiles and an $115million contract from the Air Force for targetdetection systems for B52 bombers.

title: L.I. Boat Manufacturer Resists the Urge to Expand His Thriving Business
description: ST. JAMES, L.I.By thinking small, one of Long Ialand's few boat manufacturers believes he is making more profits, producing a finer product and beating the energy crisis.

title: U.S. Report Sums Up Main Social Trends
description: The typical American can now expect at birth to live 71.1 years, which is 21.8 years more than at the start of the century. But nonwhites are still likely to die 10 years earlier than whites.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: The name of Israel's flag airline, El Al, is translated roughly onward and upward, but its president, Mordechai BenAti, must sometimes wonder in times of adversity how big a load his 13plane fleet can carry.

title: Watching the Rising Sun
description: Does the prospect of Japanese warriors careering about the globe again send shivers down your spine? If so, you have something to look forward to in Japanese Imperialism Today, from which I cull these quotations:

title: Architecture
description: THIS is probably a sad or cautionary tale. Its outcome may have been decided before this appears In print. It concerns the decision by Grace Church to demolish the Gothic Revival houses on Fourth Avenue, directly behind and connected to the church, for a new building. On a deeper level, it is about the church's struggle for survival, in terms of community and economics, and complex and difficult issues of preservation and urban quality.

title: Queens Retains City Track Title
description: Queens College captured the final two events yesterday to win the City University indoor track and field championship at the Queens College Fitzgerald Gym.

title: Seeking Out the Lipsticks That Mother Used to Wear
description: Any girl who's yearning to look like those snapshots of her mother taken in the 1930's and 1940's can truck on down to the nearest cosmetic counter and find all the dark red lipsticks she wants. But if she's a purist, she might do what Suzanne Lipschutz does: find the actual kind of lipstick mother used to wear.

title: ROMAN DESCRIBES SUBWAYS AS SAFE
description: There have been 295 fatalities in city subway operations since 1968, but only five were passenger deaths resulting from collision, derailment, fire or structural defects of the system, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority reported last week.

title: One Day at a Time
description: Every day now, the countryman will remind you, another day toward spring. If it is bright and sunny, is a bonus day to weigh against the winter averages. If is raw and blustery, full of snow or sleet or torturing wind, it is one more day of winter endured. Either way, it moves us another step toward April. True, April isn't quite violets and fresh garden lettuce, but it isn't icicles and chilblains, either.

description: Western Division

title: Bjoerang Is Leading Title Skate
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 16 (AP) Springlike temperatures slowed down the Olympic speedskating track here today and marred the first day of races in the 1974 world sprint championships.

description: AUTO RACING

title: Spring Arrives This Week As Baseball Pitches Camp
description: Free from playermanagement strife for the first spring in three years, but bothered, like everyone else, by the energy crisis, baseball's major leagues open their spring outposts this week.

title: Leading Entries In A.A.U. Track At Garden Friday
description: 0Yard Dash  Hasely Crawford, Ivory Crockett, Herb Washington, Larry Black, Clifford Outlin, Mike McFarland.

title: Drama Critics Cite Shakespeare Fete
description: MILLBURNThe New Je?? sey Shakespeare Festiva?? at Drew University in Madi?? son and the Paper Mill Play house (the New Jersey State Theater) here in Millbur?? shared top honors in the first awards to be presented by the New Jersey Drama Critics Association.

title: Finch Denied License To Practice in Missouri
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 16 (UPI) Dr. R. Bernard Finch, who spent 12 years in California prisons for the 1959 murder of his wife, today was denied a license to practice medicine in Missouri even though he had passed the required examination.

title: ROCKET SHOT HAILED DESPITE ITS FAILURE
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 16 The deliberate destruction this week of the first Titan 3Centaur rocket will not require another proof flight to qualify the booster for space operations, a project official indicated.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: One of the more useful business tools to come out of Washington is the monthly publication, Economic Indicators, prepared for the Joint Economic Committee of Congress by the President's Council of Economic Advisers.

title: DATA ON FELONIES IN STATE ASSAILED
description: A lenghty state statistical report on the processing of felony cases here is not valid in a quantitative sense, according to the deputy administrator of the agency that made the report.

title: JOHN J. M'GANN
description: John J. McGann, a retired brigadier general of the New York National Guard, who was inspector general from 1954 to 1970 and had been commandant of Camp Smith at Peekskill, N. Y., died Friday at his home, 240 East 52d Street. His age was 70.

title: Crossroads for Chile
description: Five months after overthrowing President Salvador Allende, the ruling junta is approaching a decision fateful for Chile's future and critical for the flagging cause of freedom and democracy throughout the Americas.

title: ARAB CHIEFS SEND 2 TO WASHINGTON TO SEE KISSINGER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16The Egyptian and Saudi Arabian Foreign Ministers arrived in Washington tonight for talks with Secretary of State Kissinger, presumably about the Arab oil embargo against the United States and possible IsraeliSyrian negotiations.

title: On Atlantic Avenue, Near East Delights Abound
description: It is a short walk from Brooklyn Borough Hall to the thousand and one delights of the Near Eastern table. A caravan of shops lines both aides of Atlantic Avenue from Court to Clinton Street and a little beyond. Most carry a similar array of Near Eastern ingredients and delicacies and sell both retail and wholesale.

title: Notre Dame Halts So. Carolina, 7268
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 16 Those streakbreakers from Notre Dame did it again today, as they beat South Carolina's basketball team, 7268, for the Gamecocks' first loss at their Carolina Colisetun in 25 months. Coach Frank McGuite's teams had wen 34 straight attome since losing by 1 point to Marquette on Jan. 9, 1972.

title: His writings are his monument
description: The perional and social life of St. Thomas Aquinas, like that of Plato and Shakespeare, is very imperfectly known, while his works, again like those of the great philosopher and the great poet, present an infinite variety of problems of chronology and interpretation. In the case of all three, their writings are their true monument. No personal letters or memoir of Thomas survives, and none of his faithful secretaries had any great fund of skills or insights of a biographical kind. The century between St. Francis and Dante was full of great men, but only St. Louis found a biographer of genius.

title: Lead Dust Studied as Child Poisoner
description: A comparison of the home environments and levels of lead in urban and suburban children has led researchers at the University of Rochester to question whether the ingestion of paint chips is the major source of lead poisoning in children of poor families.

title: For Leonard Hall, Political Memories
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I.  The man who ran Dwight D. Eisenhower's second, campaign for the Presidency and Richard M. Nixon's first will reminisce on his experiences at 6:30 tonight on Long Island's Channel 21, WLIW.

title: N.F.L. Players' Strike Appears Likely
description: Will there be a strike in pro football this summer? The way the two parties, owners and players, are marching to the negotiating table, the answer has to be probably. Both decry the concept of a strike in lieu of an agreement on a new union contract, but both seem locked into inflexible positions.

title: A secret weapon called immunology
description: For years doctors have known the body is protected by a mysterious natural defense system that acts in the blood to seek out and destroy the army of germs that daily invades our bodies. Since the 19th century doctors have also known that they can mobilize the body's defense system and make a person immune to a disease by injecting himvaccinating himwith a small amount of the germs of that disease. (The word immunity itself arose in the 15th century to describe the exemption from military service of men who had survived the Black Plague and could be drafted as nurses for plague victims.)

title: More Study Is Urged in Fine and Performing Arts in State
description: TRENTON  Recommendations aimed at greatly expanding the teaching of the arts and remedying shortcomings in collegelevel training in the arts throughout New Jersey have been presented to the state's Department of Higher Education by a special committee.

title: WorkRelease Project a Boon to Jailed Veterinarian
description: BEACON, N. Y.Every morning after breakfast, Steven Shaft prepares to leave the minimumsecurity prison here. One of 36 men enrolled in a workrelease program, he and the others must be back in their rooms by 9:30 at night.

title: Hofstra and Cornell Offering Joint Managerial Training Program on L.I.
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I.Hofstra and Cornell Universities will offer a joint management studies program here next month aimed at improving the effectiveness of supervisors, administrators and those about to enter such positions in business, industry and the public sector.

title: ATTACK ON VIETCONG REPORTED IN DELTA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 16 (AP)About 1,000 South Vietnamese soldiers backed by an armored column patrolling the Mekong Delta clashed with Vietcong forces today 50 miles southwest of Saigon, touching off a major battle, the Saigon command reported.

title: CHILE WELCOMES FILMS FROM WEST
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 16 (Reuters)Movie fans in Chile are rushing to see the best Westernmade films of the last three years now that import controls imposed by the late President Salvador Allende Gossens have been relaxed.

title: EVEREST D. HAIGHT
description: Everest D. Haight, who i.etired in 1969 as board chairman of the EZ Mills Corporation, children's knitwear manufacturers, died Thursday in Doctors Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Bedford Hills, N. Y.

title: Spanish Basques Evicted
description: BAYONNE, France, Feb. 16 (Reuters)  The police today evicted a group of 40 Spanish Basque refugees from Bayonne Cathedral, where they had been on a hunger strike for 24 hours.

title: Urban League Announces Winners of Its Top Award
description: The winners of the annual Frederick Douglass Awards presented by the New York Urban League were announced yesterday by John Murray, president of the league.

title: Reaching Soccer Finals Is Big Feat for Aussies
description: Australia was defeated in soccer by England, 170, in 1950, the year the United States beat England, 10. This year, the English and the Americans are out of the World Cup competition and Australia is in it. Australia, along with Haiti and Zaire, is rated by bookies around the world as a 250to1 shot to win the Cup for which 16 countries will compete in West Germany in June and early July. Except for Haiti, which some bookies even rate at 300 to 1, Australia possibly has the weakest team. But for a country where soccer is considered by some as big as rugby is here, making it to the final rounds is no small achirvement.

title: PETROSIAN, PORTISCH TIED 2 TO 2 IN CHESS
description: PALMA DE MALLORCA, Spain, Feb. 17 (UPI)  Lajos Portisch of Hungary beat Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union in the 12th game Saturday to tie their quarterfinal Candidates Match at two victories each.

title: 8 Colleges Offer Study With Travel
description: CRANFORDEducational experiences at eight independent colleges and universities in the state do not stop at the boundaries of their campuses.

title: Dave Anderson
description: For two hours last Thursday night, college basketball at Madison Square Garden was alive and well. Or at least loud and noisy. You carpetbagger, voice in the sidecourt seats kept shouting at Digger Phelps on the Notre Dame bench. You carpetbagger. The voice remembered how Digger Phelps, with three years remaining on a fouryear contract, deserted Fordham in 1971 after a 263 wonlost reccord to become Notre Times Dame's coach. Others also remembered. Digger Phelps was booed loudly, just as he had been cheered three seasons ago when he was guiding Fordham to the best basketball record in its history. One way or another, Digger Phelps creates emotions. Digger Phelps makes things happen. So does Al McGuire, the Marquette coach who will be on display anywhere within 30 rows of his bench the Garden Thursday night.

title: Speed Is of the Essence
description: Burton Turkus is not a doctor, yet when his phone jangled at 3 A.M. he was not startled. Instead, he would cradle the phone into his shoulder and by the time the conversation was over he had finished dressing  suit over pajamas.

title: Princeton Is Most to Guitar Master
description: PRINCETON  John Duarte, one of the world's most celebrated teachers of classical guitar, will conduct master classes at Westminster Choir College.

title: Ann M. Bajart Becomes Bride
description: DELRAY BEACH, Fla., Feb. 16  Dr. Ann Marie Bajart and Dr. John Anthony Schemmer, physicians in Boston, were married here this noon in the St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Francis Flynn, who also celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Gettysburg Flame Quenched
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., Feb. 16 (UPI)  For the first time since World War II, the eternal flame at the peace memorial on the Gettysburg battlefield has been extinguished to conserve natural gas, the National Park Service has announced. John Hutzsky, a Park Service administrative officer, said Tuesday the flame burned 2,400 cubic feet of natural gas a month, enough to heat six apartments provided by the service for its employes here.

title: McKay AllStar Coach
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (UPI)John McKay of the University of Southern California was selected today for the second consecutive year to coach the College AllStars for their July 26 football game against the Miami Dolphins in Chicago's Soldier's Field.

title: Marcel Retains Title
description: PANAMA CITY, Feb. 16 (AP)Panama's Ernesto Marcel, weighing 125 pounds, retained his World Boxing Association featherweight title tonight with a unanimous decision over Alexis Arguello of Nicaragua in a 15round fight. Arguello weighted 122.

title: INFLATION IS FELT BY CITY HOSPITALS
description: Some municipal hospitals have been warned that they will have to impose sharp cutbacks in service in the next four months to try to make up all or part of an anticipated deficit that could reach $13million because of the high cost of food and fuel.

title: Roger Egan to Wed Carol Smith
description: CANTON, N. Y., Feb. 16Mr. and Mrs. John J. Smith have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Ann Smith, to Roger Emmett Egan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger E. Egan of Convent Station, N. J.

title: Lawyer Will Marry Sarah Smoot
description: LAUREL HOLLOW, L. I., Feb. 16  Mr. and Mrs. William S. Smoot of Laurel Hollow and Thomas Island, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah McJilton Smoot, to Frederic Beach Ingraham, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Ingraham of Cold Spring Harbor and Lyme, N. H.

title: Music
description: THE New York City Opera will open its fall season on Thursday, and there will be a new production for the opening, and Beverly Sills will be in it, and she will not be singing the role of a queen. But she will not be leaving England, at least. Her previous operas have seen her as Queen Elizabeth gild Mary of Scotland. Now steels merely a lady named Elvira in Bellini's I Puritani, which takes place in Plymouth during the Cromwell period.

title: The Region/Continued
description: Suburban elementary schools, for years symbols of the youthfulness and vigor of suburbia, are now experiencing declining enrollments in some older metropolitanarea communities, and, as a result, suddenly superfluous schools are closing. The reasons include the fact that the postWorld War II baby boom is over, the present birth rate is declining and other social and economic factors.

title: A Tiny Florida County Undertakes the Struggle Against Too Much Growth
description: STUART, Fla., Feb. 16Stuart was one, of those sunbleached towns on the east coast of Florida that 10 years ago was discovered only by those motorists bound for Miami who had the time to drive leisurely along Highway Al A instead of highballing down the Florida Turnpike.

title: Miss Friedmann, Teacher, Is Bride
description: ROSLYN, L. I., Feb. 18Miss Christine Elizabeth Friedmann, an English teacher at Syosset High School, was married here this morning to Jeffrey Earle LeVeen, a bond broker with Asiel & Co. In New York. The Rev. S. Thomas Minogue performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: PARIS: Few Authentic French Stars Remain
description: THE French cinema is alive, nervous and living mostly at home these days, where it controls 60 per cent of the national market. Its state, both economic and artistic, is unsettled as it struggles to adjust to altered circumstances. But, despite the mournful wails, it appears to be in no mortal danger.

title: Boyle Trial Delay Asked
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 16 (AP)United States District Court here has been asked for a 90day continuance in the Federal conspiracy trial of W. A. Boyle, the former United Mine Workers president. Special prosecutor Richard A. Sprague, in papers filed yesterday, asked that the trial be set back from the scheduled Feb. 25 date to permit Pennsylvania to proceed with its murder trial of Mr. Boyle.

title: New Role for the Seven Sisters
description: LONDON  As energy shortages bring the major oil companies increasingly into the glare of publicity, many observers have come to be. lieve that they have lost their traditional advantages.

title: Schoolboy Sets 1,000Yard Mark
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 16  Ken Murphy of North Salem. High School shattered the 1,000yard run record last night with a nationally ranked clocking of 2 minutes 14.2 seconds in the Section 1 class indoor track championships at the West Point fieldhouse.

title: Frances M. Lugbauer to Wed in August
description: GARDNER, Mass., Feb. 16 Mr. and Mrs. Carl B. Lugbauer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Mary Lugbauer, to Carl Goullaud Mueller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Mueller of Rye, N.Y.

title: The World In Summary
description: Confusion among consumers, which has been a principal factor in allowing the Middle East oil producers to raise their prices enormously, continues to bedevil efforts to cope with the world's energy crisis.

title: Yanks: No Rest for the Defense
description: Just as last year, when a horde of new owners took command, the Yankees will offer a number of new features this season, including a new manager, a new home and Ron Blomberg's new hair.

title: Met College Track Monday Afternoon At Princeton, N.J.
description: 60Yard DashRichard Hardware and William Henderson, Adelphi; Ricky Jones, C. W. Post; Larry Mass, Rutgers; Art Cooper, Rich Treadwell and Kevin Webb, Seton Hall; Butch Carey, C. W. Post; Errol Thurton, Manhattan; Alfred Daley, Seton Hall.

title: Animals at war
description: The train wheels clicked and clacked implacably and my head seemed to be filling with inky black clouds ... a sort of dream crystallized ... the symbols underwent a metamorphosis, changing from symbols into hunted animals....

title: G.O.P.'s Food for Thought
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 16 (UPI)Republicans in Delaware held a Valentine's Day dinner last night and showed that they can still manage to smile about the Watergate affair. The menu for the dinner listed the following offerings: President Nixon's perfectly clear consomme, former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stan's Mexican  laundered lettuce salad, Watergate conspirator James W. McCord's spilled beans, dirty trickster Donald H. Segretti's spaghetti and former White House counsel John W. Dean's crumbled cookies.

title: For Some, No Gas Is a Blessing
description: The shortage of gasoline and home heating oil has meant the closing downtemporarily at leastof many a welloff city dweller's country or weekend home and a moratorium on such energyexpensive diversions as spontaneous jaunts to ski resorts.

title: Drivers in Daytona 500 Begging for Gasoline, Too
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 16The lines at the gasoline station inside Daytona Speedway were longer this week than the ones in town. Some of the best competition at Speed Weeks was for gasoline. The hardest hit were the Grand National stock cars for tomorrow's $275,000 Daytona 500. The National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing, in its effort to make motor racing at least appear to be cutting down fuel consumption, shortened the race to 450 miles and limited competitors to 30 gallons each for qualifying and practice.

title: Computers May Cut Legal Costs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16In an experiment that could drastically reduce the cost of legal services, a group of Chicago lawyers is preparing to turn over some routine but timeconsuming tasks to a computer.

title: It Is Us And ThemAnd Television Is Them
description: BOSTON.

title: Queens in Budget Spotlight
description: That newest road show from City Hallthe first series of boroughbyborough hearings on the Mayor's proposed capital budgetcame to Queens for a oneday stand last week.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market finished mixed last week. Increased buying on Friday erased most of the previous days' losses.

title: Talks Continue Over Sale Of Rheingold to Chock Full
description: Discussions continued over the weekend between Pepsico, Inc., the parent company of the Rheingold brewery in Brooklyn and William J. Black, chairman of Chock Full o' Nuts, who had expressed interest in purchasing the property.

title: Deformed Infant Is Operated On By Court Order Despite Parents
description: PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 16A severely deformed infant boy was reported in fair condition today after a state court ordered an operation to save the child's life over his parents' wishes.

title: The Dakota Finds Repairs To a Landmark Are Costly
description: The Dakota, that somber Victorian chateau whose towers loom above Central Park West at 72d Street, is suffering the ailments of the aged.

title: Fordham Upsets Rutgers, 7069
description: Darryl Brown scored with eight seconds left in overtime to give Fordham a 7069 upset victory over Rutgers last night at the Rose Hill Gymnasium.

title: Diane Ehrbar Engaged To Nicholas Novellino
description: MANHASSET, L.I., Feb. 16 Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Fougner have announced the enagement of Mrs. Fougner's daughter, Miss Diane Colette Ehrbar, to Nicholas C. Novellino, son of Vincent J. Novellino of Cedar Grove, N.J., and the late Mrs. Novellino. A summer wedding is planned.

title: Letters Repeal of Decontrol Will Haunt The City
description: Those individuals who are willing to risk capital today and produce growth in the city's apartment house stock are under severe attack from faddists who do not realize what their actions will mean to themselves, the city and the rentpaying public. Their current outbursts on reducing rental income in this era of runaway inflation and dismal service will put every small property owner out of business.

title: Robert Hurwitz to Marry Bonnie Yablon
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Feb. 18 The engagement of Miss Bonnie Michele Yablon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard H. Yablon, to Robert Hurwitz, son of Mr. and Mrs Harry Hurwitz of New Rochelle, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: A British View of Brooklyn
description: I read A Tree Grows in Brooklyn and that was My image of the area, said King Lear's Fool as he squinted into a dressing room mirror at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and applied the final touches to his pancake makeup. And I, confessed Cordelia, the monarch's daughter sitting nearby, had read Last Exit to Brooklyn.

title: Bill of Sale for the Self
description: We don't happen to have a copy of a C.I.A. secrecy agreement around the officesee In Cold Print on Page 2but we do have a copy of an agreement that employes of the Columbia Broadcasting System, and employes of C.B.S. subsidiaries, are obliged to sign. It is a combination of loyalty oath, indentured servant's contract and bill of sale for the self, and just goes to show what the conservatives have been telling us all along: Anything a government agency can do, private enterprise can do better.

title: Scouting Museum Revises Schedule
description: NORTH BRUNSWICKThe Johnston Historical Museum and Conservation Education Center at the national office of the Boy Scouts of America have a new schedule of operation.

title: New & Novel
description: Kolchak's Gold

title: Oil Users Crank Up
description: WASHINGTON  Are oil prices too high? Can they be reduced without a big fight between the producing and consuming countries? Will producing countries pump enough oil to keep things rolling in the world until new energy sources are found?

title: Program in Passaic To Aid TB Patients
description: PASSAIC  To stem what experts call a rise in respiratory diseases in New Jersey in general, and in the Passaic area in particular, new program has been initiated by the Visiting Health Services of Passaic Valley. It provides posthospital care to patients suffering from tuberculosis and other respiratory diseases.

title: First Woman on Nassau Board Is Making Her Impact Felt
description: MINEOLA, L.I.  Hannah Komanoff of Long Beach is the first woman ever to serve on the sixmember Nassau County Board of Supervisors. She is a Democrat in an overwhelmingly Republican county, sharing just four Demantic votes with Glen Cove Supervisor Vincent Suozzi out of the board's weighted total of 115 votes.

title: Miss Nigosian Fiancee Of Herayr Boghosian
description: HACKENSACK, N.J. Feb. 16  Mr. and Mrs. Anton R. Nigosian of Hackensack and Remsenburg, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Nigosian, to Herayr Boghosian, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stepan Boghosian of Teheran, Iran. A wedding in August is planned.

title: Yale Shares Mat Crown With Cornell
description: Yale and Cornell scored impressive road victories yesterday and finished tied for the Ivy League wrestling. title with 61 wonlost records.

title: LILCO Says Energy Office Shortchanges Utility on Fuel
description: ALBANY  The Lang Island Lighting Company last week said the Federal Energy Office was creating a critical shortage of fuel oil at the utility by; unfair allocations and diversions of needed supplies to other power companies.

title: ISRAELI REFINERY IS DAMAGED BY FIRE
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 16 (Reuters)  Palestinian commandos said here tonight that they had destroyed major sections of the oil refinery at the Israeli port of Ashdod.

title: Planning City Growth
description: A decision that decides nothing has been made is California about a community's right to regulate its growth; but the implications for environmental control are enormous. An ordinance passed by the city of Petaluma, near San Francisco, which would have limited water and sewage facilities to a restricted number of new dwellings a year in the interest of orderly, controlled growth, consistent with the city's capacity to provide the necessary utilities, has been overturned by the courts. The argument is that it violates people's constitutional right to travel and live where they wish.

title: Design:
description: A small, special museum is rapidly becoming Washington's in museum among a small, special public. The Renwick Gallery, located at 17th Street and Pennsylvania Avenue, just next door to Blair House and across the street from the White House, is one of Washington's more delightful architectural experiences. It is the official showcase for the American design, craft and decorative arts collections of the Smithsonian Institution.

title: ARAB SUMMIT IS SAID TO BE SET ON FRIDAY
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Feb. 16 (AP) A fullscale Arab summit meeting is to be held in Lahore, Pakistan, next Friday, informants close to the Libyan President, Col. Muammar elQaddafi, said today. The sources said they had received the information personally from Colonel Qaddafi, who plans to attend.

title: Comic Books Being Used to Teach Black History to Youths
description: I can do more for my people with the newspaper, I must try, young Frederick Douglass says as he begins the career that would make him the leading black abolitionist spokesman in the preCivil War era.

title: Dance
description: THE current New York dance season has so so far, or at least so far as I can see, proved comparatively unilluminating. Jerome Robbins has given the official New York premiere of his Four Bagatelles, we have had a few glimpses of interest from such moderndance companies as those led by Cliff Keuter (whose offbeat reflections upon the kinetic relationship between dance and drama continue to engage me), Dan Wagoner and Manuel Alum.

title: Even Henry Has Woes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18Henry Kissinger is a big guy who is flying high, so next to President Nixon he is the most prominent pigeon in Washington. He keeps circling and dodging, but the flak from his critics is getting a little rough.

title: The truth lies between lechery and loneliness
description: Last year I bought a townhouse and two dogs and moved in with a girl I really loved. It was the first time I'd made a solid commitment to anyone. She decided it wasn't what she wanted, so here I am by myselfa suburban homeowner with two toy poodles and no woman.

title: Marian Woodwell Stoltzfus Engaged to Gerald M. Gagnon
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 16 Mrs. George Russell Webster of Princeton and James Leck Stoltzfus of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marian Woodwell Stoltzfus, to Gerard Malcolm Gagnon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Percival Gagnon of Coudersport, Pa. and Lighthouse Point, Fla. A summer wedding is planned.

title: Brecht and the Barda Good Week.
description: ALL, good r plays create imaginary worlds, but some do it more explicitly than others, No one would think to couple Mahagonny and Tempest If they had not both opened during the: same week (Mahagonny at the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven, The Tempest chez Joseph Tapp at Lincoln Center), but both do addres themselves to the creation of fictional realms that have their own special geographies, moralities, populations, customs, powerralationships, and emotional possibiliries. And of course both of these imaginary worlds, fantastic as they are,, exist to tell us about cer thin aspects of the real world. But in the city of Mahagonny are concentrated impulses of greed and callous self preservation, while the world of The Tempest is dominated by forces of reconciliation, harmony, and love. Both worlds, however, have been well and truly recreated on the stage; it has been a good week.

title: Israelis Say Black Africans Begin to Regret Breaking Ties
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 16 (AP)Foreign Ministry officials here contend that black African nations are beginning to have second thoughts about having broken diplomatic relations with Israel. They forecast that some of the countries may defy Arab leaders and ask Israel to resume suspended aid programs.

title: Middlebury Team Wins Ski Carnival
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 16Paced by John Jacobs who completed a sweep of the two Alpine events, Middlebury College's skiers won the Williams College Winter Carnival competition today for the second straight year.

title: What If the Congress Party Loses in Uttar Pradesh?
description: NEW DELHILike the goddess Lakshmi, the cheerful harbinger of prosperity, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has trooped to her home state, Uttar Pradesh, each week recently to bestow gifts. One day, Mrs. Gandhi opened electronics factory and laid the foundation stones for two textile mills and an irrigation project. Another day she opened a drinking water scheme and then set the foundations for a rail link, two bridges, a transformer factory and a spinning mill.

title: National League: The First Order of business Will Be No. 715 for Henry Aaron
description: Eastern Division

title: Convenience Is Victor at Santa Anita
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 16 (UPI)Convenience, a 6yearold mare, came on with a rush in the stretch today and captured the 32d running of the $57,250 Santa Maria Handicap at Santa Anita as Susan's Girl, the favorite, finished fifth.

title: The Nation
description: The Question Is How to Keep Miss Heartt Alive

title: Impeachment Move Spurs Growing Lobbyist Effort
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16As Marilyn Goldfaden recalls it, she and her husband, Gerald, became lobbyists because of the gasoline shortage.

title: Utah Coach Retires
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 16 (AP)Pres Summerhays, baseball coach at the University of Utah for the last 22 years, retired today. An assistant coach, Tom Kilgore, was appointed to replace the 68yearold Sum merhays.

title: Margaret Duffy Wed
description: MOORESTOWN, N. J., Feb. 16 Miss Margaret Graham Duffy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard A. Duffy of Mount Laurel, was married here this afternoon to Edwin Joseph Guilfoy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Guilfoy of Haddonfield. The Rev. Harold Myers performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church.

title: Doberman Named Best At Hartford
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 16The energy crisis almost cost the topwinning Doberman pinscher in the East from adding to her record today.

title: SUPPORT OF NIXON UP TO 28% IN POLL
description: Public approval of President Nixon's performance in office rose two points to 28 per cent at the beginning of February after falling to a low of 26 per cent in late January, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Monmouth Seeks Funds to Renovate Cultural Center
description: RED BANK  Monmouth County now has its first significant cultural center, a former movie theater that is available to area organizations on almost a fulltime basis.

title: Solar Unit Will Heat And Cool New Center
description: BASKING RIDGE  The Somerset County Park Commission's Environmental Education Center is the first facility of its kind in New Jersey and one of only a handful in the East. And it will record still another first in the spring, when construction is scheduled to begin on its permanent building.

title: MS. by Washington On His Soldiering Is Sold to a Dealer
description: A 10andahalfpage manuscript by George Washington giving a dramatic account of his youthful experiences in war has been sold for the first time since it was set down in 1786.

title: We Have Been a Nation of ConventionGoersFrom the Word Go
description: OFFICIALS of a soap company gathered recently at a Midwestern hotel for a sales conferenceonly to find a rival soap concern holding a similar meeting down the hall.

title: Recordings: Tippett Tames the Tyger and Tends the Lamb
description: IT IS tempting, if ultimately pointless, to proclaim Sir Michael Tippett as England's greatest living composer. First of all the statement doesn't really say much of anything, and secondly. the response outside of Britain is likely to be a puzzled Who? At the age of 69, Tippett is firmly ensconced with Benjamin Britten and William Walton at the top of his profession in England, but elsewhere his music is still largely an unknown quantity.

title: Petty After 5th Crown At Daytona
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. Feb. 16They call him the King and just because his father was also one does not mean Richard Petty inherited the title.

title: Not just for the kids
description: While there is something excruciatingly mundane about dishes made with ground meat and noodles or macaroni (could it have something to do with their lowbudget connotation?), they can also be outrageously good. To achieve this, the meat must be fresh and not too burdened with fat, the pasta must not be boiled to a mush before it is bakedand the whole must be put together with care and respect.

title: Gromyko, in Paris, Signals Better Ties
description: PARIS, Feb. 16FrenchSoviet relations were visibly warmer today as visiting Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko said that he was very satisfied with his talks with President Pompidou.

title: Rockefeller Given A New State Post: He'll Ran His Mall
description: ALBANY, Feb, 16Formel Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, who made the South Mall the pe?? project of his 15 years in office, today was appointed to oversee the mall's completion in his new role as a privatecitizen.

title: World News Briefs

title: F.B.I. Director Promises Regular News Conferences

title: Free Bus Aids Franklin Township's Commuters
description: FRANKLIN TOWNSHIPThanks to a free shuttlebus system that officials of this community established last weekend, commuters whose gasoline tanks have been hovering near the empty mark have been able to reach bus and railroad stations in nearby New Brunswick.

title: Improvement Course for Penalized Drivers Proves Popular
description: LODI  The driverimprovement course given by the state's Division of Motor Vehicles is crowded the year round, and little wonder. The sixhour refresher course is designed as a constructive alternative for those motorists who have accumulated 12 penalty points over a threeyear period: those who do not take the course have their licenses suspended temporarily.

title: THEATER OPENINGS OF THE WEEK
description: FASHIONTomorrow, McAlpin Rooftop, 6:45. A musical, postponed from last Monday.

title: News Summary and Index SUNDAY FEBRUARY 17, 1974
description: The Egyptian and Saudi Arabian Foreign Ministers arrived in Washington for talks with Secretary of State Kissinger, presumably about the Arab oil embargo against the United States and possible IsraeliSyrian negotiations. The two ministers were sent to Washington following a twoday meeting in Algeria, which ended Thursday, of the leaders of Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Syria and Algeria. Mr. Kissinger conferred in Key Biscayne, Fla., with President Nixon before flying back to Washington for the meeting with the Arab Foreign Ministers, Ismail Fahmy of Egypt and Omar Sakkaf of Saudi Arabia. [1:5.]

title: Beaten Boxer, 19, Dies
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 16 (UPI)Ruben Loyola, a 19yearold middleweight boxer, died of a cerebral hemorrhage yesterday after receiving a severe beating Thursday in his third professional bout. He fainted in the dressing room after losing the bout on a decision and never recovered consciousness.

title: Energetic Newsletter Publishers;Their Task Is to Cover Small Area In Big Way
description: WASHINGTONThe energy crisis has been in the headlines only a little more than three months, but already six energy newsletters and special reports are coming out of the nation's capital.

Marcus of New York and Greenville, S. C., and the late Mrs. Sophia Horn Marcus. The Rev. Melvin Hawthorne, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Church Center for the United Nations.

description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 16Lincoln of Jersey City set one record and won four events as it captured the Group III title in the ninth annual New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association indoor relay championships today at the Jersey City Armory.

title: Lovers of Greece, women and Tennessee
description: The Uncorrected World

The wedding is planned for April 28 at the home of the future bride's parents.

title: News of the Screen
description: Having tackled a good deal of what he calls really serious stuff on stage, screen and TV, from Hamlet to his Oscarwinning stint in Judgment at Nuremberg, Maximilian Schell is now ready to take a fling at farce.

title: Music in Review
description: Once upon a timea time that came to an end only this year  there was a famous group of oldmusic performers called the New York Pro Musica. Its death, from natural causes, left a sizable gap in the musical picture. But the ensemble also left, throughout the country, audiences that had been educated to hear old music intelligently, and a sympathetic Milieu in which young musicians could function.

title: What's New In the Theater?
description: BAD HABITS, a play by Terrence McNally, got 9 favorable reviews (Barnes, Times; Watt, News; Raidy, Newhouse Newspapers; S. Klein, WNEWTV; A. Klein, WNYCRadio; Stefan Kanfer, Time; Oliver, New Yorker; Simon, New York; Stasio, Cue), 4 mixed (Watts, Post; Glover, AP; Clurman, Nation; Hewes, Saturday Review/World) and 3 negative reviews (Gottfried, Women's Wear; Wallach, Newsday; Wynne, Bergen Record).

title: North's Duo Advances
description: DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 16Cecil (Mike) North and Mrs. Isabel O'Connell, the defending champions, led the way into the semifinals of the national mixed doubles platform tennis championship today by beating Dwight Lowell and Marjorie Gengler, 64, 79, 63.

title: Nassau P.B.A. Fights U.S. Pay Cutback
description: MINEOLA, L. I.Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso's philosophy of partnership in government suffered a blow last week when the county's Village Officials Association unanimously opposed the contract between Nassau and its police force.

title: Manila Says Jolo Deaths In Recent Clashes Tota 1300
description: MANILA, Feb. 16 (Reuters)Three hundred people have been killed in fighting between Government troops and Moslem rebels on Jolo Island in the southern Philippines, the Government said today.

title: Debra Green to Be Bride
description: ROCHESTER, Feb. 16Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Green of Rochester and Hallandale, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Debra J. Green, to Neal Massa, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Messa of Woodmere, L. I. The wedding is planned for summer.

title: PNEUMATIC BRACE AIDS PARALYZED
description: Extensive tests of a pneumatic nylon brace indicate it may be a real help to paraplegics and other wheelchair patients, according to a research team at Bird S. Coler Hospital on Roosevelt Island. Dr. Maurycy Silber said his tests of the garment, which when inflated enables a patient to stand and walk with the aid of crutches, showed it had many advantages over a conventional metal brace.

title: Times to Increase Newsstand Price Starting on Feb. 24
description: The newsstand price of The New York Times will be increased later this month, subject to favorable rulings by the Cost of Living Council, it was announced yesterday by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of the newspaper and chairman and president of The New York Times Company.

title: Life on a Farm Helps Addicts to Break Habit
description: BRIDGETON  The handpainted sign announces Faith Farm, and not much else distinguishes the old twostory clapboard house from others like it in rural Bridgeton.

title: A good paper and, besides, a fun paper
description: The final issue of The World came out Feb. 27, 1931. I will always remember how inconsolably my wife wept, for she had worked several years on the paper as a firstrate reporter and tennis writer. Everybody I knew Who ever worked on The World was proud to have done so; it lent a mark of distinction, rather the way having served in the Marine Corps is supposed to do. The World was a hard paper to get a job on; but if you didn't make it and then went on to another paperor another callingyou always wished you had made it with The World. Back in the early and midtwenties, such young reporters as were fidgeting in the outlands and daydreaming of New York, read The World every day and read it hard. (Young John O'Hara, fidgeting on the Pottsville, Pa., Journal, was a Worlddevourer.) No need to tell them who Heywood Broun was, or the other stars on that magnificent original page opposite the editorials, OpEd: Deems Taylor, Frank Sullivan, Alexander Woolcott, Laurence Stallings, F.P.A. The Conning Tower, F.P.A.'s column, nurtured a whole star system of its own among its regular contributors, all unpaid, including Dorothy Parker and Samuel Hoffenstein.

title: Australian Yacht Snaps Mast in Trial
description: PERTH, Australia. Feb. 16 (UPI)Australia's hopes for the America's Cup received a setback today when the 12Meter Southern Cross broke a mast during inshore trials off Yanchep, 36 miles north of here.

title: An Energy Crisis Besets Birds, Too
description: BERNARDSVILLE  Each winter, resident New Jersey birds face an energy crisis that can be relieved only by means of emergency supplies of sunflower seeds and suet.

title: Pop: Labelle Has the Sound and the Power
description: ONCE, Patti LaBelle and the Blue Bells, a female quartet, celebrated young impossible love, singing sugar music for slow motion dancing. They sang for urban Bloods, those especially who lived weekend to weekend, housepartying in shadows made real by tiny red and blue lights. Or for those braver hearts who would shuffle endlessly to whatever beat illuminated the fading spirit of a gloomy public dance hall.

title: U.C.L.A. Loses 2d Straight Game, 5651
description: EUGENE, Ore., Feb. 16Oregon, getting brilliant shooting from Bruce Coldren, dealt the University of California, Los Angeles its second straight basketball upset in less than 24 hours, 5651 today. The loss put the Bruins in danger of losing the Pacific8 Conference title for the first time in eight seasons. A crowd of 10,000 watched the regionally televised game.

title: Retailers Reducing Wattage on Voluntary Basis
description: UNIONAbout 8 o'clock at night, Route 22 here blazes with gaudy neon signs. They glow not only from both sides of the busy duallane highway, but also from islands of stores in the middle.

J. He is the New York regional manager of the commercial collection division of Dun & Bradstreet, Inc. The Rev. Paul J. Carey performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Martin.

title: Euonymus, $3.80, Wins Bowie Feature by Head
description: BOWIE, Md., Feb. 16 (AP) Euonymus, a 5yearold mare owned by Mrs. Cary W. Jackson of Baltimore, became a stakeswinner for the first time at Bowie today when she gained a photofinish decisipn in the $23,450 Conniver Handicap.

Miss Quinn is one of in 10 collegians takSports ing driver and trainer instructions as a noncredit, extracurricular activity. Two other womenKay Fagan of Adelphi University and Linda Smith of Stony Brookare also students in Elementary Trotsmanship, taught by the drivertrainer, Lou Miller.

description: Events that presaged both immediate and longterm changes in regional mass transit were in evidence last week.

description: The decision by countries that buy fourfifths of the world's energy imports to bargain collectively with the new oil producers cartel takes the world a long first step toward a negotiated solution to the energy crisis. But the hardest part of the job still lies ahead.

description: Some faces are warm and loving, others, stark and miserable. Some figures reflect the opulence of life, others, the poverty. The people are fat and thin, dark and fair, old and young and they portray a oss section of society.

title: Immies, mibs, glassies, purees, etc.
description: 1948. The block between Field Place and 184th Street on Creston Avenue in the Bronx was jammed with kids hustling marbles. It was The Marble Season. I was out there with my hustle  Hit the marble and get thirty! You set a tantalizing marble against the curb to be shot at from across the street by all comers. If they missed, you got to keep the marble they shot. If they hit, you paid up 30 marbles. Why do I still remember to this day the sight of Freddy Krongold's marble coming at mine like a locomotive? A direct hit. Pay the man his marbles. Was that really 25 years ago?

This time, it is the Nissan Motor Corporation in U.S.A., a nationwide distributor of Japanesemade Datsun cars and trucks, which has moved its Eastern corporate headquartoys and distribution center from Secaucus to Piscataway Township.

title: Movies
description: IF you're looking for a symbol for the present state of the British film industry, none seems more suitable than the only movie shooting in a British studio in the middle of last month. Called Percy's Progress, it's the sequel tb an amazingly limp comedy about a penis transplant.

title: Bridge
description: Playing the game of bridge often requires a fivestage approach. First, you must set a practicable goal, bearing in mind that it may need to be modified in the light of subsequent events. Second, you must assemble all the crumbs of information that may have a bearing on the problem. Third, you must synthesize the information, aiming for as clear a picture as possible of the total situation. Fourth, in the light of this you must plan a course of action that offers the best possible chance of success. And fifth, you must it out.

The index determines prices to be paid for commodities to be supplied to hospitals and other city institutions for the next two weeks. It is based on bids from suppliers to the city:
