title: A oneman redoubt in the cities of the plain
description: Critics, like conductors, tend to relax with the onset of old age. Their pulses beat slower, and they give up trying to set the artistic world to rights. B. H. Haggin, who has been writing music criticism in American journals since 1923, is the fierce exception to this rule. As with his adored Toscanini, the years only make him more impatient and uncompromising, less willing to tolerate the mediocrity, slackness and spiritual wickedness that he sees all around him. In this new collection of his critical writings, taken from the decade up to 1973, he still stands on sleepless sentry duty, glaring out from his oneman redoubt in the heart of the cities of the plain. The world he surveys is not an attractive place, but at least it has a kind of elemental simplicity; the line between virtue and vice is sharply drawn. The good are soon counted; the ungodly are swarming there between his sights whichever way he turns. And any moment now they'll be put to flight. Mr. Haggin writes as though in a constant state of indignantsurprise that pretentious wrongheadness can still be flourishing and hasn't yet yielded to reason and right.

title: U.S.E.T. Coach Is on Tour In Search of Riding Talent
description: The United States Equestrian Team begins a new policyor at least a supplement to its old policytomorrow when Bert de Nemethy visits the Riverside County National horse show. DeNemethy, coach of the U.S.E.T.'s Prix des Nations (jumping) squad for the last 18 years, will spend two days at the show in search of riding talent for this year's European tour.

title: New York Knickerbockers' Statistics
Gazzara, Just Elected to Assembly, Is Planning to Learn on the Job
description: I'm going to be learning on the job, Anthony V. Gazzara said halfapologetically at his victory celebration a few nights ago.

title: Book Ends
description: Heller. Hang out the flags, uncork the champagne, drop the other shoeJoseph Heller has delivered to Knopf an 800page manuscript. It's called Something Happened and it's his longawaited second novel. Long awaited? Well, Catch22 was published in 1961, so it's been 13 years between books. This set us to thinking about previous betweenbooks longevity records. Thomas Pynchon took seven years on Gravity's Rainbow, and then there's J. D. Salinger, whose last book was Raise High the Roofbeams, Carpenters (1963), actually two long short stories; his last novel was Catcher in the Rye (1951). The champion, we've decided, was Herman Melville, who published no novels (three books of poetry, however) between The Confidence Man (1857) and Billy Budd (left uncompleted at his death in 1891 and not published until 1924). Sorry, Heller.

title: Guerrilla Leaders Meet to Discuss a Palestinian State
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 16Leaders of the Palestinian cornmando movement assembled today in Damascus, the Syrian capital, to discuss possible steps leading to the formation of a Palestinian state in territories now occupied by Israel.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Feb. 24Motorsport Club of North Jersey 50mile rally; start at The Clubhouse, Route 46 Westbound, Fairfield, N.J. Registration: noon, first car off 1 P.M. Information: phone John, (201)3850862.

title: The Irish Pub Is A Great Equalizer
description: THE proper way to get drunk in Ireland is to, walk into a pub, order a pint of Guinness stout and take a stool at the bar, staring at the bottles behind it. Before you have finished sipping your first glass, a friendly Irishman will buy you a drink of Irish whisky despite your protests, insisting it is time for you to find out what the real stuff tastes like. By the time you have finished buying him round, and several bystanders who join the conversation follow suit, you will be smashed. (The quickest way to get drunk is to order your own whisky and drink rapidly, but that is antisocial, and no reason to visit Ireland.)

title: Japanese School for Dog Specialists
description: Japan is having a pupulation explosion.

title: Confidential Secretaries: Those KnowItAlls Who TellItNot
description: Confidentially speaking, they don't. They are Rose Mary Woods clams in a babbling brook of Martha Mitchells, silent locks in a chain of chattering links. They are listeners rather than talkers, they are KnowItAils who TellItNot.

title: The impact of planning on a city of suburbs

We're agricultural, industrial, coastal . . . urban as well as suburban and rural. . . . If planning is the panacea for the problems of the country's metropolitan regions, we'll find it out right here.

History books can tell the child how the British won the region from the French, how the settlers came in the 1820's to mine for lead, and how the territory became the 30th state in 1848.

description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 16 (AP)  Mrs. David Eisenhower, reported feeling much better, got out of bed today and took a stroll in a hospital corridor.

description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Mary Fearey 2d Will Be Wed To Stuart Holman Lollis in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morton Fearey of New York and Edgartown, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Senior Fearey 2d, to Stuart Holman Lollis, vice president of marketing at Product Sales Management, Inc., in Cresskill, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: What's Opened At the Movies?
description: THE LAST DETAIL, directed by Hal Ashby from a screenplay by Robert Towne, got 14 favorable reviews (Vincent Canby, Times; Kathleen Carroll, News; Archer Winsten, Post; Rex Reed, News; Frances Taylor, Newhouse Newspapers; Joseph Gelmis, Newsday; Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service; Andrew Sarris, Village Voice; Leonard Harris, WCBSTV; Stanley Kauffmann, NeW Republic; Judith Crist, New York; William Wolf, Cue; Hollis Alpert, Saturday Review/World; Richard Schickel, Time), 5 mixed (Howard Kissel, Women's Wear; Gene Shalit, NBC; Jeffrey Lyons, WPIXTV; Paul D. Zimmerman, Newsweek; Pauline Kael, New Yorker) and 1 negative (Frank Rich, New Times).

title: Kentucky Wins, 6158
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 16. (AP)Kentucky's offense was a little sour, but its defense took up the slack tonight in a 6158 Southeastern Conference victory over Tennessee. So defensiveminded was the game that Kentucky's Kevin Grevey took scoring honors with 16 points and the Wildcats scored only two field goals in the last 11 minutes.

title: 2 LEGAL PROGRAMS FOR POOR IN PERIL
description: Two innovative programs concerned with the legal rights of the poor in Harlem are among those endangered by the impending dismantling of the Model Cities program.

title: Penn Wins, Stays Tied With Brown
description: HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 16 (AP)John Engles, a sophomore, scored 27 points and grabbed 11 rebounds tonight, leading Fenn to a 9670 Ivy League victory over Dartmouth.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
MOST OF CABINET IN SAIGON RESIGNS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 16All but two members of the South Vietnamese Cabinet resigned today at the request of President Nguyen Van Thieu.

title: Solution to Queens Slaying Eludes Police
description: The charred body with the long, green fingernails in box 122 at the Manhattan morgue is labeled case 301  unidentified female, and according to members of the police homicide squad, quite frankly we know very little else about her identity. Despite several promising clues detectives have been trying to identify the body for almost two months without success.

title: City Clears Way for Rise Of Up to 4% in Rents Here
description: Mayor Beame and top city housing officials cleared the way yesterday for landlords to impose average rent increases of 1.8 per cent for 2.5 million occupants of one million rentcontrolled apartments.

title: Court Acts on Plea by Ray
description: NASHVILLE, Feb. 16 (UPI)  Federal District Judge L. Clure Morton has given Warden James Rose of the Tennessee State Prison 20 days to respond to James Earl Ray's charges that he has been denied access to the prison's law library. Judge Morton issued the order in a suit filed by the convicted killer of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: View From Rotterdam
description: ROTTERDAM  The city most sensitive to the Arabs' oil embargo following their war with Israel last October was this, the world's largest port, on which not only Holland but all northwest Europe and Scandinavia depend. Yet, to everyone's surprise, Rotterdam has shrugged off the crisis produced when Middle East petroleum suppliers boycotted the Netherlands for what they called a proIsrael policy.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: China Starts Producing Equipment for Color TV
description: PEKING, Feb. 16 (Agence FrancePresse)  China has started producing a complete range of color television equipment, including receivers, fixed and mobile transmitters and control consoles, the magazine China Reconstructs reports in its latest issue.

title: Gasoline Lack Forces Suburban Change
description: BENSENVILLE, Ill., Feb. 16Directly or indirectly, the nation's energy shortage is prompting serious new studies of suburban transportation systems and a rash of operating transit experiments in little known bur populous suburban communities.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Jorge Ahumada of Argentina, light heavyweight who has won six straight fights (five by knockouts) since arriving here in July, will attempt to extend his streak tomorrow night against Vern McIntosh of Eustis, Fla., in a 10round bout at the Felt Forum. The preliminary bouts will start at 8 P.M.

title: Violence on a Southern farm and in New York City
description: John Yount's second novel, like its predecessor Wolf at the Door, is set in the South; the scene is Sharaw, a small town in Cocke County, Georgia, approximately a decade ago. It is an account of Dan and Beau Jim Early, brothers pursuing their separate dreams and struggling against the barren red clay earth, impoverished rural economy and the narrow perspectives of the Cocke County inhabitants. After a sixyear hitch in the Army Beau Jim returns to his brother's farm intending to enroll at a nearby college on the G.I. Bill and make something of himself. Danstoic, illiterate, completely baffled by anything beyond the immediate world of his daily chores  ploddingly works his destitute farm, sensing that it is his only hope and convinced that no piece of land could be so poor that it was past reclaiming.

title: U.S. Report Perils Rail Freight Lines
description: TRENTONNew Jersey's state and municipal governments are bracing for a battle to save number of rail freight lines that the Federal Department of Transportation regards as potentially excess.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Lou Brock, ready for his 11th season with the St. Louis Cardinals, has figured out when he should retire: There's got to be a, time when the 90 feet to first base looks more like 110 feet. And when that happens, I'll be the first to recognize it.

title: James Glidden to Wed Miss Betts
description: CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Feb. 16Miss Dorothy Brooks Betts, a copywriter with the Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn advertising agency in New York, and James Louis Petigrue Glidden, a copywriter with PrenticeHall, publishers in Englewood Cliffs, N. J., plan to marry in April.

title: CITY UNIT ACCUSED OF INEFFICIENCY
description: ALBANY, Feb. 16The State Controller's Office accused the city's Department of Rent and Housing Maintenance today of not providing an acceptable level of code enforcement for the residents of New York City.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: IN Brooklyn a gasoline station manager carries a pistol in full view on his hip, because he is fed up with arguments and threats from angry, gashungry customers.

title: School Project Aids 17 Cities
description: NEWARK  A special project aimed at helping the residents of 17 New Jersey cities define the financial problems that their school systems might be having, and how to go about correcting inequities in funding processes, is being undertaken by the Greater Newark Urban Coalition.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Dick Francis gets around. The popular British author of mysteries with a horserace motif set his plot in South Africa the last time around. Now he takes us to Norway in his new SLAYRIDE (Harper & Row, $5.95). Quiet Norway, pleasant Norway, where nobody rushes and life moves at a deliberate pace. But even in Norway there can be murder, and the criminals there are no less ruthless than they are anywhere else.

title: A Withlt Traditionalist Educator
description: ENGLEWOOD  Last July, when Eugene Michael Dea came to the Dwight and Englewood Schools as headmaster, he brought with him a reputation of being mod, with it and perhaps even a swinger. Today, his colleagues would agree with Mr. Dea's own appraisal that he is fundamentally a traditionalist in mores and education.

title: Is Gold Reflecting Commodity Costs?
description: Do the record prices being paid for gold and silver reflect last year's surge in commodity costs? Or do they herald further increases in the cost of raw materials?

title: Chess:
description: Al Horowitz was fond of quipping, The pin is mightier than the sword. Untold thousands of games at his favorite hangout, the Manhattan Chess Club, bore out his point. In those cases where the pinned piece is illdefended while the attacker has in reserve units to lay siege to it, there is bound to be loss of material.

title: Pakistan Wins It All
description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Feb. 16 (Reuters)  Pakistan won an international field hockey tournament with a perfect record in six games after beating the Netherlands, 20, in the final game today. Australia beat New Zealand, 21, to take second place.

title: Ashe Conquers Taylor In 3 Sets, Gains Final
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, Feb. 16 (AP)Arthur Ashe defeated Roger Taylor of Britain, 60, 46, 62, to gain the final of the $50,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today.

title: Big Three Track Won by Harvard
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 16The Harvard University track team swept all the field. events today on its way to defeating Princeton and Yale, 73, 59, 15, in the Big Three track meet held at Princeton's Jadwin Gym.

title: PAY IS COMPARED: CITY VS. BUSINESS
description: Pay increases received by city clerical workers here between April, 1971, and April, 1972, Were higher than those recorded for comparable workers in private industry here during the same period according to a Federal survey made public yesterday.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
A Taste of Italy in Bayonne.
description: BAYONNEPart of the D'Elia family is out front, selling to a crowd of customers; the others are in the kitchen in the back, cooking up a batch of pasta fagioli (macaroni and bean soup) in giant aluminum pot's. That's the kind of oldfashioned Italian grocery that Fannie's Renascente Macaroni Company is.

title: Rev. Joel E. Strauch to Marry Catherine Marks McCreary
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 16  Mr. and Mrs. Pierce Newberry McCreary have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Marks McCreary, to the Rev. Joel Edward Strauch, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Paul Elwood Strauch of Danbury, Conn., where his father is minister of the First Congregational Church.

title: Colleen Has Broadway MoonStruck
description: LIKE a Diana baffled by her quarry, Josie Hogan leans her, strong body against a wooden stoop, cradling In her arms the man she loves; because he breathes and talks and drinks, she has not understood until tonight that he's already dead.

title: John C. Garand, 86, the Inventor. Of World War 11 M1 Rifle, Dies
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Feb. 16 (AP)John Garand, inventor of the M1 rifle, died today in the coronary unit at Wasson Memorial Hospital. He was 88 years old.

title: For the V.F.W.'s 75th Anniversary
description: RIGHT after the SpanishAmerican War, a dozen veterans got together in the back of a drug store in Columbus, Ohio. From this meeting eventually evolved one of the nation's major veterans oganizations, the Veterans of Foreign Wars, now celebrating its 75th anniversary.

title: Red Smith
description: Thoroughbred racing returns to New York a week from tomorrow, and not a moment too soon. For weeks and weeks going on eternity, amateurs of the running horse have been faced with Hobson's choice: either pass the days breathing the twiceused air of an Offtrack Betting parlor where loitering is discouraged by jaw, or lie fallow in the bosom of the family squandering money on bread. This is no knock on OTB, which performs a valuable service in keeping the children off the streets, but the municipal poolrooms are comfortless dives that offer neither the sinful attraction of illegal bookie joints nor the fresh air and excitement of the track itself.

title: ROME: Italian Movies Have Become Increasingly Inward Looking
description: WHAT does one do for an encore after Last Tango in Paris? Bernardo Bertolucci, the director of the 1973 movie sensation, is weaving sociopolitical tapestry to show Italian history unfolding from the year 1900 to Fascism and beyond.

title: POLICE ASSAILED BY RESTAURATEU??
description: The manager of a fastfoo?? restaurant in Queens that wa?? heavily damaged during a ram page of 200 teenaged gang members late Friday night sail yesterday that he and other em ployes had made seven separate appeals to the police for help but that they did not respon?? until 45 minutes after the incident was over.

title: Miss Mann Leads Golf By Stroke
description: NAPLES, Fla., Feb. 16 (AP) Carol Mann shot her second straight round of 70, two under par, to take a onestroke lead today after 36 holes of the Naples women's golf classic.

title: To Our Readers
description: Subject to approval under the Economic Stabilization Program, t h e newsstand price of the Sunday New York Times will be increased to 60 cents within a 50mile radius of New York City and on Long Island. Beyond the 50mile radius, the price will be increased to 90 cents. The increases will go into effect with the issue of Sunday, Feb. 24.

title: Sunday Observer
description: This column was originally going to be an essay on sex; but will instead deal with ghosts. In preparation for the sex essay, I was studying Dr. Alex B. Comfort's best seller on the mechanics of the thing The Joy of Sex is the titlewhen a friend pointed out that I had missed the boat. Sex, he said, was done for with the public. The new thing was the supernatural. Movie lines that had once formed for. Deep Throat now stood patiently for The Exorcist. Americans were lost in ecstasies of demons, gurus, poltergeists, Oriental mysticism and religious freakery. Prancing tables, second sight and visitations from The Other Sidethis was the heady fantasy, of America today.

title: Settlements Are Moderate, But Prices and Profits Are Almost Embarrassing
description: In industrialized democracies around the world, labor's scramble to counter higher prices with higher wages is disrupting essential services, worsening inflation and even, as in Great Britain, threatening to topple governments. Only in the United States, traditionally the stormiest of labormanagement battlegrounds, have wage settlements remained moderate while work time lost through strikes has dropped close to an alltime low of one day in 700.

title: Down on the Farm in Iowa, They Fret Over Food Bills
description: THOMPSON, Iowa, Feb. 16 There are two small dogs and, at the last unofficial count, about 15 cats on the Dwight Winkleman grain farm west of here. They are the only livestock the Winklemans own.

title: Percy to Enter Primaries
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (AP) Senator Charles H. Percy of Illinois said yesterday that he planned to enter the 1976 Republican Presidential primaries in Illinois, Wisconsin and Michigan. He said he would also enter five to nine other Presidential primaries.

title: One Dead, Four Wounded In Shootout in Tampa, Ha.
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 16 (AP)One man was killed and four were injured today in a downtown shootout after two Black Muslims scuffled with an offduty policeman working as a store guard, authorities said.

title: Superior Rebounding by Knicks Helps Beat Warriors, 117107
description: The Knicks, who have been missing key players all during the season because of injuries, found an opponent yesterday in the same situation.

title: Philip Rahv, 19081973
description: So he's gone, that dear phenomenon. If no two people are alike, he was less like anybody else than anybody. A powerful intellect, a massive, overpowering personality and yet shy, curious, susceptible, confiding. All his life he was sternly faithful to Marxism, for him both a tool of analysis and a wondrous cosmogony; but he loved Henry James and every kind of rich, shimmery, soft texture in literature and in the stuff of experience. He was a resolute modernist, which made him in these recent days oldfashioned. It was as though he came into being with the steam engine: for him, literature began with Dostoevsky and stopped with Joyce, Proust and Eliot; politics began with Marx and Engels and stopped with Lenin. He was not interested in Shakespeare, the classics, Greek city states; and he despised most contemporary writing and contemporary political groups, being grumblingly out of sorts with fashion, except where he felt it belonged, on the backs of goodlooking women and girls.

title: Aschenbach Wins World Skiing Title
description: FALUN, Sweden, Feb. 16 (AP)East Germany swept the gold and silver medals and the Soviet Union won the bronze today as the 30th world skiing championships in Nordic events opened.

title: ATTACK ADMITTED BY NORTH KOREA
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb, 16  North Korea asserted today that the South Korean boat sun?? by its naval ships in the Yellov, Sea yesterday was a spy ship that violated its coastal waters.

title: It's My FaultI Never Followed the Rules
description: VALENTINA CORTESE, the subject of many Whatever Happened To? games among movie buffs in the last few years, is back, and you'd better believe it. This time the petite Italian actress with the green eyes and the Garboesque cheek bones is spelling her name the right way, and not the Cortesa it was when Twentieth CenturyFox brought her to Hollywood in 1948 and she wound up marrying her costar in The House on Telegraph Hill, Richard Basehart.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Judgment Call
description: To The Editor:

title: New Assistance for Youths in Trouble
description: WEST ORANGEA farreaching system of juvenile justice is diverting scores of youthful offenders in this community from the harshand sometimes lifelongstigma of the criminal courts.

title: W.V. Wills to Marry Miss Caroline Lee
description: Miss Caroline Lee, manager of information services with the Bermuda Government Department of Tourism in Hamilton, plans to be married Aug. 3 in Bermuda to William Vincent Wills, Oceans Systems Technician Third Class U.S.N.

title: Mrs. Florence Marshall Remarried
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16Mrs. Florence Beale Marshall, office manager of Time magazine's Washington bureau, was married here this morning to Charles King Mallory 3d, Deputy Assistant Scoretary of the Interior for Energy and Minerals.

title: STATE WEIGHS RISE IN MEDICAID FEES
description: ALBANY, Feb. 16  State budget officials are considering a significant increase in the fees paid to physicians for treating Medicaid patients.

title: Rockefeller's Daughter Engaged to T. B. Morgan
description: Nelson A. Rockefeller, former Governor of New York, and Mrs. Mary Clark Rockefeller have announced the engagement of their younger daughter, Mrs. Mary R. Strawbridge, to Thomas B, Morgan, press secretary to Mayor John V. Lindsay from 1969 to 1973.

title: A Proving Ground for Policemen and Firemen in Bergen
description: MAHWAHAt the Bergen County Police and Fire Academy here, tradition is something to be remembered and discussed and innovation is welcomed.

title: Curious Yellow Triumphs
Demands Modified by Hearst Abductors
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16 Another tape recording of Patricia Hearst's voice was delivered to her parents today.

title: Billie Holiday Story Is Enacted in Dance By Faison Troupe
description: George Faison stood out as a dancer in the Alvin Alley company, and in the last three years he has formed an exciting, vibrant troupe of his own, the George Faison Universal Dance Experience.

title: 2d Double In 2 Nights For Jipcho
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 16 (UPI)) Ben Jipcho of Kenya posted a double victory in distant events for the second straight night and Rod Milburn equaled an indoor hurdles record tonight in the International Track Association's second meet the season.

title: Susan M. Talbot Wed to Surgeon, Desmond Birkett
description: BOSTON, Feb. 18  In Trinity Episcopal Church here this afternoon Miss Susan Meredith Talbot, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Barbee Talbot of Dayton, Ohio, and Yarmouth Port, was married to Desmond Hyland Birkett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Noel Birkett of Nottingham England. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Frederick Speakman of the Third Presbyterian Church in Pittsburgh, assistedby the Rev. Thomas Kennedy of Trinity.

title: ENGLISH CLASSES ON COAST EXPAND
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16Allan Yee, 7 years old, came here from Hong Kong last month. On Feb. 4, Allan, who does not speak a word of English, started public school in a special oneyear introductory language program.

title: Competitive Devaluation
description: THE GREAT WHEEL  THE WORLD MONETARY SYSTEM. A reinterpretation by Sidney E. Rolle and James L. Bartle. Quadrangle/The New York Times Took Company. 279 pages. $9.95.

title: Kathleen Capers a Bride
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 16  In St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church here this morning, Miss Kathleen Margaret Capers, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ellison Van Meter Capers, was married to Paul Lewis Glebatis, son of Mrs. William Gadomski of Voorheesville and the late John Lee Glebatis. Msgr. Matthew Cox performed the ceremony. The bride's father is chief of surgery at the Vassar Brothers Hospital here.

title: Zullo Formally Enters Connecticut Governor Race
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 16Assuming the role of a longshot from a vitally important but neglected corner of Connecticut, Frank Zullo, a former Mayor of Norwalk, formally opened his campaign today for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: Miss Bergen Sets Nuptials
description: GLEN ELLYN, Ill., Feb. 16 Miss Kathleen Marie Bergen, a consultant in healthcare systems for Kappa Systems, Inc., in Washington, and Alexander Joseph Bastos, economicpolicy advisor to Frank L. Rizzo of Philadelphia, plan to marry here Aug. 3 in St. Petronille Roman Catholic Church.

title: Priscilla Hornblower Fiancee Of William Colt, Air Instructor
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 16  Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Hornblower Jr. have announced the engagement of Mr. Hornblower's daughter, Miss Priscilla Hornblower, to William Whitman Colt, son of Mrs. and Mrs. Zenas Crane Colt of New York and Matunuck, R. I.

title: If You Were Expecting the Waltons in Modern Dress, You Were Wrong
description: IS the way we think we are as entertaining as the way we think we used to be? That's the question facing Apple's Way, a new series created by Earl Hamner Jr., the man who turned his memories of the Depression into the very popular The Waltons. Now Mr. Hamner has come all the way into today. Where the Waltons are a threadbare family eking out a poor but happy existence in Virginia's Blue Ridge Mountains some 40 years ago, the Apples of Apple's Way are as modern as any family jostling for french fries in a McDonald's ad.

title: What's Doing in SAN DIEGO
description: THAR SHE BLOWSIThe annual migration southward of the great gray whales from the Arctic to their calving grounds along the Baja California toast is on this month. It is a nevertobeforgotten sight of 8,000 to 10,000 plunging, snorting mammals parading close to shore. In April, they'll return to the Arctic, but their northward route is farther out to sea in order to protect their young. The, best vantage spot in San Diego is the summit of Cabrillo Monument at the tip of Point Loma. Telescopes are provided, and the National Park Service offers a motion picture and special exhibits dealing with the whale migration. For a closeup view of the giants, so close you can almost reach out and touch their splayed flukes, take any of several whalewatching excursion boats from the Embarcadero (North Harbor Drive). or Mission Bay.

title: Hawks Top Islanders, 40; Esposito Posts 9th Shutout
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Feb. 16 A couple of comparative graybeards, 33yearold Stan Mikity and 31yearold Tony Esposito, took charge of the National Hockey League game tonight as the Chicago Black Hawks beat the New York Islanders, 40.

title: Headliners
description: The Dean Is Leaving

title: Visitor Finds Vietcong Area WarWeary Too
description: TUONG SON, South Vietnam The crowded minibus bumps through the devastated landscape that lines both sides of Route 1 in Binh Dinh Province, on the central coast.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 16 (UPI)George Foreman, the heavyweight champion, said today he would be ready for his March 26 title bout against Ken Norton in Caracas, Venezuela, despite a prolonged divorce proceeding that had interrupted his training schedule.

title: DOCTORS' STRIKE WIDENING IN INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, Feb, 16  I wish I had stayed in my father's business, said Dr. Satish Bhatia, a 28yearold interne at a Government hospital. I would have been much better off.

title: Planning for Bloom
description: Predictable? Prosaic? These are fitting descriptions for beds where the same varieties grow in the same relationship as they always have. They yield a midsummer melange that is colorful, but undistinguished.

title: CLARK CRITICIZBS SCHOOL REZONING
description: Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, a member of the State Board of Regents, has sharply criticized a rezoning proposal for Brooklyn high schools that he said would perpetuate and worsen segregation.

title: Marijuana Penalties To Remain Relaxed
description: TRENTONThe Byrne administration has decided not to tamper with a 1970 law that relaxed the penalties for minor marijuana offenses.

title: On the Stage at Hillcrest High School, All Is Silence
description: They were embryonic birds in a shell, sitting motionless backtoback in a fetal position. Then, slowly, they began to unwind, boneless creatures swaying with fluid grace in a first awakening, their bodies speaking the language of gestures.

title: Miss Downey Married in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16Miss Barbara Jean Downey, executive assistant to Representative Edward I. Koch, Democrat of New York, was married here this evening to assistant United States attorney for the District of Columbia.

title: Art
description: THE exhibition of Masterpieces of Tapestry From the Fourteenth to the Sixteenth Century, now resplendently installed at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is an extraordinary event in two quite different respects. It marks, first of all, a significant change In museum policy. It also offers us a stunning revelation of great art that few of us have heretofore paid much attention. In both rerelects, the consequences are bound to be salutary.

title: Form Holds In Squash Racquets
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 16 Vic Neiderhoffer, seeking a third straight United States singles squash, racquets championship, reached the tournament quarterfinals today by defeating Gordon Greenburg of New York, 159, 157, 158, at the United States Naval Academy.

title: Long Weekend Worsens Gasoline Situation Here
description: Desperation and impatience mounted among motorists in the metropolitan area yesterday on what some called the worst day yet for gasoline seekers.

title: An Activist for Queens Greeks
description: One of the most influential men in Queens has little personal wealth but a ready access to banks. He holds no political office but is treated with defence at City Hall.

title: It's Hard to Leave The Bronx
description: THE critics, legion in their praise, say there is an undeniable keyboard giant lurking within the frail, wispy Murray Perahia. But the pocketsized pianist from The Bronx, full of all the insecurities of a young artist about to begin a Major Career in Music, doesn't quite know whether he wants, or is ready to deal with, the kaleidoscopic demands of the international bigtime. At 26, he looks 16 and undernourished. His enormous, dark, plaintive eyes and long, stringy, shaggy dog haircut bespeak an unsure personality. But there is nothing unsure about Perahia the musician.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Fiction and Poetry

title: BLOC ACTS TO EASE STRIPMINING BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16Nixon Administration officials have joined lobbyists for the coal mining and electric utility industries in an attempt to thwart House passage of a bill imposing the first Federal en vironmental restrictions on strip mining.

title: Law Group Calls for liar Stricter Safeguards on Radiation From Plutonium
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16In a move with major implications for the nation's nuclear energy program, the National Resources Defense Council has called for a drastic tightening of regulations dealing with the radioactive element plutonium.

title: Mitsui
description: The House of Mitsui, an Asian business dynasty that combined Krupp industrialism with Rothschild financial skills, taught the lessons of capitalism to a reluctant Japanese aristocracy. Now, with John G. Roberts's comprehensive and always fascinating study of the family and its businesses, we in the West learn of the tremendous power their private money wielded over the public affairs of that nation.

title: Finish lines
description: ACROSS

title: Cabinet to Courtroom: The MitchellStans Trial
description: For the first time since the Harding Administration scandals half a century ago, men who once wielded national power as Cabinet officers have, been summoned to court this week as defendants in a criminal trial.

title: Copter Over White House Is Shot Down by Guards
description: WASHINGTON, Sunday, Feb. 17  Executive Protection Agency police shot down a stolen helicopter early today over the south grounds of the White House, Secret Service officials said.

title: L.I. Car Pool Is Computerized
description: HOLTSVILLE, L. I. A computer is helping 3,300 employes of the Brookhaven Internal Revenue Service Center here to cope with the problem of how to get to work during the gasoline shortage.

title: What the Flesh on Real Humans Looks Like.
description: PHILIP Pearlstein, long acknowledged by nearly everybody as one of America's foremost realist painters, has recently emerged as one of America's foremost artists, a figure of major influence and importance. No sudden personal breakthrough is responsible for this; Pearlstein has been pursuing more or less the same, style for a decade. The change his come not in his art, but in the climate of the art worldthe relative decline of abstract painting, the fragmentation of the avantgarde and the resurgence of realism.

title: Kenneth Saler to Marry Paula Roseman
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Feb. 16Announcement has been Made by Mr. and Mrs. Arnold D. Roseman of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Paula Beth Roseman, to Kenneth I. Saler, son of Mrs. Earl Winthrop of Hallandale, Fla., and Morton Saler of Lower Merion, Pa.

title: Toll in Argentina Flooding Put at 35 Dead, 200 Lost
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 16 (Reuters)At least 35 people have died and more than 200 are missing today in flooding in 11 provinces of northern, western and central Argentina, according to reports reaching the capital.

title: Jersey Marinas Buoyed By BulkFuel Advantage
description: The gasoline shortage for automobiles in New Jersey is about as severe as anywhere. What is the fuel outlook on the Jersey shore for boats this season? One optimist spoke yesterday. He was Representative James J. Howard, Democrat of New Jersey, who attended the opening of the 21st annual Jersey Coast Boat Show in Convention Hall, Asbury Park. Howard, who is from Spring Lake, said he believed that there would be ample fuel for boatmen this season. He is chairman of a Congressional subcommittee dealing with energy and therefore in as good a position as anyone to know.

title: WALLACE CHARGES LEADERSHIP FAILURE
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Feb. 16 (AP) Gov. George G. Wallace of Alabama said today that the energy crisis had been caused by a failure of leadership.

title: E. P. A. Approves Cyanide To Curb Coyotes in Texas
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI) The Environmental, Protection Agency belatedly has approved experimental use of cyanide to kill coyotes in Texas and said similar approvals might be granted soon for several other states.

title: Paulette Steinberg Planning Marriage
description: MARGATE, N. J., Feb. 16Miss Paulette Steinberg, a senior at Smith College, and David Aaron Kessler, a student at the Harvard Medical School, plan to marry in August. Their engagement has been announced by Paul Steinberg, father of the bridetobe and a realestate broker here.

title: Historic Hopewell Lives in New Book
description: HOPEWELLReaders who have longed for a recipe for witch yeast, or wanted a biography of John Hart, a New Jersey signer of the Declaration of Independence, or needed instruction in the use of a flyswitcher, now have at their disposal a reference work that sheds light on these and other facets of New Jersey history.

title: Hot Ocean Defies Hunt For Energy
description: NILAND, Calif., Feb. 16The world's largest known reservoir of geothermal power, a vast hot ocean beneath California's Imperial Valley, has defied three years of costly efforts to convert it into electricity.

title: They mold the images of the candidates
description: Theodore H. White, who may have begun it all with The Making of the President, 1960, has some regrets.

title: New Queens Senator Is Aiming at a Role on Investigative Committees
description: John J. Moore has wasted no time in staking his claim to the 14th State Senate District seat and making his preferences for committee assignments known in huddles with Queens Democratic leaders.

title: Nuptials for Katherine Caldwell
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Feb. 16 Miss Katherine Edmondson Caldwell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bryan Caldwell, was married here this noon to Kevin Michael Graham of Bethlehem, son of Mrs. Edward Lawrence Graham of Southhold, L.I., and the late Mr. Graham.

title: HALF OF DEALERS TO GET GAS MARKUP OF CENT A GALLON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 Faced with rising protests and threatened shutdowns of gaspline stations, the Federal Energy Office authorized today a penny per gallon price increase for retail dealers whose fuel allocations have been reduced by 15 per cent or more.

title: What If the Labor Party Wins in Britain?
description: LONDONIn the 29 years since World War II, the Labor party has been in power here only about 11; it is now making a desperate effort to try to redress that balance against the bizarre political background of a coal miners' strike, a threeday workweek, soaring prices and rising skepticism and apprehension among the voters.

title: Those Fanatical Fans of Foreign FlicksWhere Are hey Now?
description: TOMAS GUITIERREZ ALEA'S Memories of Underdevelopment broke the house record when it was shown for one week last year at the First Avenue Screening Room here. The Cuban film received some of the most enthusiastic reviews to be given any foreign film in years, yet it died when it was moved over to continue its initial engagement at the posher Beekman Theater. Business improved when the movie played in Greenwich Village and it is currently being shown with good if not sensational results in several theaters in and around New York on a doublebill with Karoly Makk's small, fine Hungarian film, Love.

title: W. Howard Keenan Jr. Fiance Of Miss Pamela H. Carmichael
description: CHAGRIN FALLS, Ohio, Feb. 16Mr. and Mrs. Donald S. Carmichael of Hunting Valley have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Hastings Carmichael, to W. Howard Keenan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Keenan of Houston. A June wedding is planned.

title: Ain't Nothing Like The Real Thing
description: BOTH Aretha Franklin and Maggie Bell look straight at you from their album covers and those direct gazes are just like their singingopen and honest. One of them, Miss. Franklin, is the undisputed queen of soul Music and probably the fines singer in America today. The other, Miss Bell, is still an unknown factor on the American scene, even though this vibrant Scottish lady has already won just about every music poll there is to with in Britain.

title: RONAN DESCRIBES SUBWAYS AS SAFE
description: There have been 295 fatalities in city subway operations since 1968, but only five were passenger deaths resulting from collision, derailment, fire or structural defects of the system, the Metropolitan Trans; portation Authority reported last week.

title: Miss Pamela Potter Is a Bride
description: READING, Pa., Feb. 16Miss Pamela McCauley Potter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Sturgis Potter, was married here this noon to Dr. Ralph Milton Reeves, son of Mrs. W. Ralph Reeves of LaGrange, Ga., and the late Mr. Reeves. The Rev. Charles Sutton performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church, assisted by the Rev. Dr. W. Paul Thompson.

title: Baccalaureate Captures Gulfstream Race on Turf
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., Feb. 16 (AP)  Baccalaureate raced to a 1length victory today in the $73,000 Canadian Turf Handicap at Gulfstream Park, taking the lead at the head of the stretch and drawing away.

title: Times to Increase Newsstand Price Starting on Feb. 24
description: The newsstand price of The New York Times will be increased later this month, subject to favorable rulings by the Cost of Living Council, it wag announced yesterday by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of the newspaper and chairman and president of The New York Times Company.

title: ADOLF ARNDT, DIES; WEST GERMAN JURIST
description: BONN, Feb. 16Adolf Arndt, a leading member of the Social Democratic party since the founding of the West German Federal Republic in 1949 and a noted jurist, died in Kassel Wednesday. He was 69 years old.

title: TV SPOTS' IMPACT ON VOTER STUDIED
description: Like soap advertisements, televised political commercials have great, impact on voters with low poltical Interest who, before television, ignored most efforts at political persuasion, according to a study by the Citizens' Research Foundation of Princeton, N. J.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: U.S. and Germany Donate Funds in African Drought
description: ROME, Feb. 16The United States and West Germany have each contributed $1million toward an emergency relief fund for droughtstricken areas in Africa, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations has announced.

title: Camera world
description: THE Polaroid Corporation has introduced new blackandwhite film pack which not only gives the usual fully developed print in 30 seconds, It also gives a fully developed and usable negative suitable for enlarging or making additional prints. Like the print, the negative is fully developed outside the camera, without need for a darkroom, in just 30 seconds.

title: Hardworking Moggy and beautiful Alice
description: Any book that serves to remind the children of affluence that their Hondas and nose jobs are not dispensed by benevolent providence as part of the natural order of creation must surely commend itself to parents who remember the. Depression, however dimly, and still more to grandparents who may have had their heads busted on a picket line.

title: RAYMOND J. QUINN
description: Raymond 3. Quinn, who retired in 1972 as executive vice president of Thomas M. Quinn & Sons, funeral directors, with chapels in Brooklyn, Queens and Nassau County, died Thursday in Bay Harbor, Fla., where he lived. His age was 70.

title: A Skier's Notes on the MindBody Problem
description: THERE are five of us together breathing deeply and sprawled like pale, hairy animals across the pine decks of a sauna bath. The man beside me Is rubbing a yellowpurple welt on his calf as he speaks. The sauna seems to disembody voices, and so I catch only a few of his words: Fresh powder ... carving butter ... hot sun ... the trail was practically empty ... the Matterhorn disappeared.

title: State Says AutoExhaust Checks Will Conserve Gas
description: TRENTON  Contrary to initial warnings that it would generate widespread public opposition, plus other predictions of chaos at state inspection stations, New Jersey's mandatory automobileexhaust tests have tentatively been adjudged a success.

title: Dr. Horace Kallen, Philosopher, Dies
description: Dr. Horace M. Kallen, philosopher and educator, who was founder of the New School for Social Research, died yesterday in Palm Beach, Fla., while on vacation. He was 91 years old and lived in Oneonta, N. Y.

title: Most Influential Four?
description: THE year 1946 was important for chamber music in America because it saw the formation of the Juilliard Quartet in New York and the Fine Arts Quartet in Chicago. Because of geographical separation, the Midwest ensemble is probably not as familiar to New Yorkers, although it has made an enormous number of recordings and plays here frequently. It is, in fact, giving a threeconcert Bartk cycle in Carnegie Recital Hall this season. The second concert will take place next Sunday, with Bartk's First and Third Quartets sharing the program with Lutoslawski's Second Quartet, not a new work but one rarely played.

title: Rutgers Herd Aids Beef Study
description: NORTH BRUNSWICKOf all the animals at the Rutgers University Agricultural Experimental Station here, one steer stands out for two reasons. First, it has a human name, Pete; the others have names like 836 and 840.

title: Rainbow Springs to Close
description: DUNELLON, Fla., Feb. 16 (UPI)Rainbow Springs, one of Florida's oldest tourist attractions, will close next Friday because of the fuel shortage and declining tourist traffic. The closing of the 50yearold tourist attraction, which has averaged 8,000 visitors weekly, will leave 100 persons jobless.

title: U.S MOVES TO NAME WISCONS IN JUDGE
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 16The Nixon Administration began moving this week to fill the oldest Federal judicial vacancy in the country and thus to break a logjam in Wisconsin Republic politics.

title: The Summer After the Funeral
description: The English writer Jane Gardam arrived on the literary scene recently with twoboots published almost simultaneously: A Few Fair Days, for slightly younger children, and A Long Way From Verona, set during World War II. Both were eminently readable, witty, perceptive, vivid and consequently highly praisedjustifiably I think.

title: Mrs. Moore Rewed Here
description: Mrs. Leslie Ann Moore, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Oliver Moore of New York and East Hampton, L. I., was married here yesterday afternoon to Alexander Shoumatoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas, Shoumatoff of Bedford, N. Y. The Rev. Bryant Kirkland performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Direct Flight Takes Title At Ox Ridge
description: DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 16Irene Jaffe, a 17yearold student at the Thomas School in Rowayton, Conn., rode Direct Flight to the regular working hunter championship today at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club indoor horse showbut she's looking to bigger and better things.

title: Teenage Girl Sets Mark
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 16 (AP)Jonie Hutley of Portland, Ore., 17 years old, set an American women's indoor record in the high jump today at the Oakland Invitational track meet. She jumped 6 feet  inch and became the first American woman to clear 6 feet.

title: The World
description: Britain Tottering Toward the Crucial Vote

title: Chatham Antiques Show Set
description: CHATHAM  The threeday run of the annual Chatham Antiques Show opens on Tuesday, and, despite the gasoline shortage and its accompanying inconveniences, at least 34 dealers are scheduled to take part.

title: Humanities Unit Awards $123,436 In Grants
description: NEW BRUNSWICKThe New Jersey Committee for the Humanities has made grants, totaling $123,436, to 19 institutions and organizations in the state. The money will enable the recipients to conduct the committee's current program on The Work Ethic: Changing Attitudes and Public Policy.

title: Minnesota Rink Wins Title Curling
description: MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Feb. 16 The Virginia, (Minn.) Women's Curling Club rink, skipped by Mrs. Newton G. Hahne, won the 26th annual United States Women's Curling Association championship today.

title: '71 COASTAL LAW DELAWARE ISSUE
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Feb, 16 Delaware's Coastal Zone Act of 1971, widely applauded by environmentalists as protecting the state's entire coastline, is facing strong attack by business, the building trade's and oil interests.

title: Young Lochinvar, With Guitar
description: CHRISTOPHER PARKENING says, no, he doesn't surf. But it's hard to believe. The 26yearold classic guitarist of whom Andrs Segovia has anpounced flatly, He is a great artist, looks like a walking, talking Kodacolor print, the blueeyed blond beach boy who regularly furns up on news magazine covers illustrating the sweetandsour life in California. You almost expect him to quote Rod McKuen potery at you, or hand you a Jesus pamphlet.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Today, Feb. 16

title: Photography
description: THE exhibition at Light gallery through March 2 consists of prints, mostly, recent, by Robert Fichter, a 35yearold teacherphotographer who uses oldfashioned photographic processes in uptodate ways and, like most if not all shows at Light, it is heavy into Art.

title: N.Y.U. to Honor Lewis Rudin
description: Lewis Rudin, executive vice president of the Rudin Management Company, Inc., has been named the 1974 recipient of New York University's Urban Leadership Award, it was announced yesterday. The award will be presented to Mr. Rudin at a dinner given by N.Y.U.'s Real Estate Institute in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel on March 13.

title: Friday's Fights
description: Nassau, BahamasElisha Obed, 152 pounds, Nassau, Bahamas, knocked out Wendell Spencer, 156, Jamaica, 3 rounds.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Detecting Dread Illness at a Hopeful Stage

title: Letters: Are Monsters Really Photogenic?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: In a story in The Week in Review of Feb. 3 dealing with a school segregation suit in Brooklyn, it was stated that the legal action was the first of its kind in New York City. The statement, contained in the judge's opinion, was incorrect; a suit involving Franklin K. Lane High School had been filed earlier.

title: MILITARY PAYROLL CAUSING CONCERN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 Congress and the executive branch are becoming increasingly concerned about the rise in the Defense Department's civilian payroll, which has grown to nearly $15billion a year.

title: LETTERS
description: Quibbling

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Pharmacists Warn On Poisoning Peril
description: Pharmacists Warn

title: 3 HIJACK A TRUCK; LOSS MAY BE$ 250,000
description: SOMERSET, Mass., Feb. 16 (AP)  Three heavily armed men hijacked an armored truck at a supermarket tonight, later abandoned it and fled in a car with money taken from the truck, the state police said.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE WHOLESALE PRICE INDEX in January rose 3.1 per cent from the December level to 150.4 per cent of the 1967 average. Higher costs for food as well as fuel and industrial commodities helped cause the second sharpest increase on record, exceeded only by the rise of 6.2 per cent last August.... Industrial production fell 0.8 per cent in January to 125.7 per cent of the 1967 base period.

title: Joblessness Is Threatening the Tranquillity of Otherwise Serene Garfield
description: GARFIELD  An unemployment rate of about 8.2 per cent, resulting principally from the closing of two rubbergoods factories in nearby Passaic and a depressed economic situation in most of South Bergen County, is threatening the tranquillity of this otherwise serene community.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: A.J.C. TO PROTECT OBSERVANT JEWS
description: The American Jewish Congress yesterday announced the start of a new program to protect the rights of observant Jews against discrimination by private employers and governmental action.

title: West German Team Wins Bobsledding
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 16 (AP)The world championship team of Wolfgang Zimmerer and his brakeman, Peter Utshneider, both of West Germany, won the International Diamond Trophy twoman bobsledding championship today.

title: McFall, Talking for Democrats, Criticizes Nixon's Transit Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP A spokesman for Congressional Democrats said toda?? that President Nixon's transportation proposals may indicate helpful changes in polic?? but fall short of a massive broadbased assault on our nation's basic transportation problems.

title: AROUND THE
description: The Long Island Rose Society, an affiliate of the American Rose Society, conducted a poll of its membership last fall to determine the members' favorite varieties. The results are fascinating for what they tell of tastes and growing habits on Long Island.

title: Martin Easy Victor In Junior Tennis
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I. Feb. 16Billy Martin of Palos Verdes, Calif., the nation's No. 1 junior, had an easy opening match in the Port Washington junior tennis tournament today, routing Randy Hirschfield of Great Neck, 60, 60 The annual tournament drew ranking players from many states.

title: KNIGHTS OF MALTA DISAVOWS U.S. UNIT
description: ROME, Feb. 16The Rome headquarters of the Knights of Malta, the ancient humanitarian Roman Catholic fraternity, has challenged the right of a New Yorkbased group to use its name and invoke its traditions.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTONGiven the economic dislocations and the personal hardships that the gasoline crisis has caused in New Jersey, it was only a question of time before legislation was introduced here that would make the state's major oil refineries public utilities and thus bring them under the control of the Board of Public Utility Commissioners.

title: Soares Disputes Reason for Dismissal
description: Following the December 6 dismissal of Leon Abbott of Boston University, AI Soares, the Brown University coach, was unexpectedly dismissed last week by Andy Geiger, the Bruin athletic director.

title: Solzhenitsyn Goes Downtown in Zurich
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 16Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn ventured into a bustling Western city today for the first time in his life. He bought eyeglasses, a ballpoint pen and paper, said it was time he got back to work and ended the day by seeing a film drawn from his novel The First Circle.

title: Sutton Names Woman Aide
description: The appointment of Mrs. Jolie Brockman Hammer as deputy borough president of Manhattan was announced yesterday by Borough President Percy E. Sutton. Mrs. Hammer, who formerly was a special assistant to the President of the City Council, had been an executive assistant in Mr. Sutton's office since Jan. 1.

title: Nixon Names Legal Chief For Defense Department
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Feb. 16 (UPI)President Nixon today nominated Martin R. Hoffmann to be general counsel to the Defense Department, where he has served since May as special assistant to the Defense Secretary and his deputy.

title: Music
description: Smetana's Trio in G minor was the nearest thing to a novelty in Friday night's concert in Alice Tully Hall by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center.

title: Roger Baldwin, at 90, Is Hopeful About the World
description: OAKLANDRoger N. Baldwin, who founded the American Civil Liberties Union in 1920, looked into the past and talked about the future in a recent interview at his home here. He concluded, after a warm and wideranging chat, that the condition of the human race was getting better all the time.

title: Schedule of Hearings By Council This Week
description: Following is the City Council's schedule of meetings open to the public this week:

title: INVESTING POINT OF VIEW
description: I am the first President since Harry Truman who hasn't owned any stocks since ever I've been President. I'm the first one who hasn't had a blind trust since Harry Truman. Now that doesn't prove that those who owned stocks or had blind trusts did anything wrong. But I felt that in the Presidency it was important to have no question about the President's personal finances, and I thought real estate was the best place to put it.  President Nixon, in his news conference of Nov. 17, 1973.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Waiting for justice8th floor: homicides; 9th floor: addicts; 10th floor: suicidals
description: Inside the Tombs a suicide is called a hangup, and the cry of hangup is heard on the average of once a week in the cellblocks, breaking the monotony of the prison routine. The A officer in charge of the floor unlocks the panel box on the bridge, pulls some levers and cracks the cell open. The suicide watch, volunteer inmates who are paid 20 cents a day to patrol the tiers, cut the man down. A hangup usually wets his bedsheet to keep it from ripping and ties to crossbars above his head. A house doctor is summoned and if resuscitation efforts fail, an autopsy determines the cause of death as asphyxia by hanging.

title: The journalist needs courage, ingenuity and skepticism
description: In the winter of 196263 The New York Times was tinavailable for nearly four months to Washington policymakersor to anyone else, for that matteras a result of an extended strike. The Times's absence was keenly felt by those of us in the foreignaffairs bureaucracy; we approached each morning's take of cables with none of our usually clear sense of the hierarchy of importance we should attach to what we were about to read.

title: FalseAdvertising Curb Due
description: TRENTON  A number of New Jersey merchants may soon find it a bit tougher to attract customers.

title: Mets: Faith, Hope and McGraw
description: For the second time In five years, the Mets go to spring training this week as chainpions of the National League. For the second time in five years, does anybody believe that what happened last autumn really happened?

title: Kosygin Affirms Solzhenitsyns May Go
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 16Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin today Pub licly reaffirmed the Kremlin's commitment to let the family of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyr leave the Soviet Union but left some doubt about whether his archives could be sent abroad

title: Riding Mowers Recalled
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 16 (AP) The Huffman Manufacturing Company has recalled four series of 24inch riding mowers produced In 1973, The company said that some models had a problem with the cutting blade that made it impossible to disengage the blade drive.

title: The Sufferings Of a Soviet Dancer
description: Following are excerpts from a letter of April 5, 1973, from the Soviet ballet dancer Valery S. Panov to Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington, received in translation. Mr. Panov was dismissed as a principal dancer in Leningrad's Kirov Ballet Company after he applied to go to. Israel. His wife, Galina Rogozina, a ballerina, was demoted and later left the company. In mid1973, the authorities let it be known that the Panovs could leave soon if they stopped encouraging further attention in the West to their situation. But Mr. Panov's request to leave with his wife was officially rejected in September and again early this month. The Congressional drive to link freedom of emigration for Soviet citizens to extension of trade concessions by the United States has been led by Senator Jackson.

title: Rangers Pin 94 Setback On Canucks
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Feb. 16In an era when the national objective is conservation of energy, the New York Rangers emerged as the model of thrift here tonight:

title: T. J. Ervin Fiance of Christine Thurber
description: ROCHESTER, Feb. 16 Mrs. Harold C. Passer has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Christine L. Thurber, to Thomas J. Ervin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald M. Ervin of Jamestown. A May wedding is planned.

title: Wyckoff Combats Drugs With Talk and Friendship
description: WYCKOFF  This affluent community in western Bergen County is combating drug abuse and antisocial behavior Among public school students by sponsoring daylong discussions on how to be friends.

title: The Tavern  At the Ferry
description: King Charles II, as a quick way out of a debt, gave William Penn a parcel of land in the New World. Penn called the parcel Pennsylvania and offered it to the good and oppressed of every nation as an asylum at 40 shillings an acre.

title: Jipcho Rescues First '74 Pro Track Meet From Embarrassment
description: A handful of safety pins held a tiny International Track Association badge to Ben Jipcho's white Kenya jersey Friday night at the Nassau Coliseum. It seemed to symbolize where professional track and field had pinned its hopes for a successful second season.

title: MOBILE UNIT AIDS KIDNEY PATIENT
description: PETOSKEY, Mich., Feb. 16The nation's first traveling artificial kidney center, a mobile hemodialysis unit, has logged 6,500 miles through sparsely populated northern Michigan since November to treat victims of kidney failure.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: The Book Review welcomes letters from readers: Letters for publication must include the writer's name and address. Because, of the large volume of mail we regret that we cannot acknowledge or return letters.

title: Leonia Chimney Sweep Finds His Job Soots Him Fine
description: LEONIAThere is an old belief that it is good luck to see or touch a chimney sweep. And so it comes as no surprise to Erwin Liverman of Leonia, who is an actor when he is not cleaning chimneys, that more and more people are seeking him out, especially during these days of the energy crisis and increased use of fireplaces.

title: Won't and will take yes for an answer
description: One reads a book of poetry to find a shape of humanity, like or unlike oneself. Readers should find the first book here a terror, the second a mirror, the third a promise.

title: From Maxwell's Plum, A Peach of a Fighter
description: It all started in Maxwell's Plum. A lot of matches begin there. Two people get to talking and sometimes a good thing comes of it.

title: Phnom Penh, Digging Out, Is Shelled 2d Day in Week
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 16AntiGovernment insurgents shelled this city again today, just as the United States Em bassy was holding a ceremony to announce its aid for those who were wounded or made homeless in the shelling last Monday.

title: Noll Captures Title
description: BOSTON, Feb. 16Eddie Noll of the New York Racquet and Tennis Club won the United States professionnal court tennis championship today by defeating Tom Greevy of Tuxedo, N. Y., 64, 62, 62.

title: NIGERIANS IN U.S. URGED TO RETURN
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 16An official Nigerian delegation is touring several American cities this month to inform Nigerians in the United States about the job opportunities back home.

title: Secret Service Agents Guarding Energy Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) William E. Simon, director of the Federal Energy Office, has been assigned Secret Service bodyguards, the Treasury Department and the energy office confirmed today.

title: W.F.L. Meets Monday
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 16, (UPI)World Football League owners will meet Monday for a Business session, Tom Origer, owner of the Chicago Fire team, said today. It is expected that the owners will vote on shifting the Memphis franchise to Portland, Ore.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiary unless otherwise indicated:

title: Fraternity to Admit Women
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Feb. 16 (AP)  National chapters of Phi Delta Kappa, a 90,000member professional education fraternity that has been restricted to male membership, have voted to admit women. Fraternity officials said Wednesday that 381 of the fraternity's 418 chapters voted on a constitutional amendment to open the membership, and that the amendment was approved, 287 to 94.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:
Numismatics
description: IT was only a couple of months, ago that the U.S. Treasury Department announced it was submitting a request to Congress for authorization to switch from copper to aluminum in the one cent coin. Only a couple of months ... and the huckster parade has already begun:

title: Saigon Is Still Holding Times Man's Material
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 16The Saigon Government continued today to retain the notes and film taken from James M. Markham, the Saigon bureau chief of the New York Times, after he emerged from a week's visit to a Vietcongheld area in Binh Dinh province.

title: Stars Down Nets, Notch 13th in Row
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 16 (UPI)  The Utah Stars won their 13th straight American Basketball Association game tonight, beating the New York Nets, 116105.

title: St. John's Five: Sharp, Wins, 9475
description: NIAGARA FALLS, Feb. 16  one of its better performances of the season St. John's swept to a 9475 victory over Niagara today. The Redmen's firsthalf shooting percentage of 75 per cent thrilled a capacity crowd of 3,500 and an Eastern regional television audience on the Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference's TV Game of the Week. Six of St. John's players scored in double figures.

title: Laub Wins Bowling's U.S. Open
description: Larry Laub, off to the fastest start ever in Professional Bowlers Association history, won the $85,000 United States open tournament at Madison Square Garden yesterday, averaging 249 in his three games before a national television audience.

title: STRIKE IN BRITAIN STIRS BITTERNESS
description: FARNWORTH, England, Feb. 16Between the six great conical cooling towers of the Agecroft Power Station, and the silent shafts and conveyor belts of the Agecroft Colliery across the road, six miners, heavily bundled up, stand picket duty around a fire.

title: Home Improvement
description: WITH to a few little touchups and simple repairs, and in some cases cleaning and partial refinishing, many an old picture frame that seems headed for the trash barrel or a forgotten corner of the basement or attic, can Ate, refurbished and given a new lease on lifethus saving many dollars over the cost of buying a new frame or having one custom matte add professionally finished.

title: Hybrids of Municipal and Private Interests
description: It looked like a clearcut victory last week for Brendan T. Byrne, New Jersey's fledgling Governor, when the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey bowed to his wishes to hold PATH fares at 30 cents. But governors of New York and New Jersey have been claiming victories over the bistate agency for decades. They disappear and the Port Authority goes on, its credit ratings unimpaired.

title: Discord Cancels Suffolk Symphony Date
description: An ingry libretto was added to the Suffolk Symphony's beautiful melodies last week and then, the music stopped.

title: Sam Snead, 3 Others Lead in Golf
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 16Sam Snead, who is closer to his 62d birthday than his 61st, shot a 66 today and tied Tom Weiskopf, Dave Stockton and John Mahaffey for the 54hole lead in the Glen Campbell Los Angeles Open golf tournament at the Riviera Country Club. They were at 207, six strokes under par, and Weiskopf, with a 65, had tied a course record.

title: Unspoiled Michigan Area Says Nay to the Navy
description: CRYSTAL FALLS, Mich., Feb. 16The snow here in Michigan's Upper Peninsula is not like bigcity snow. It does not crunch or squish when you step op it. It squeaks.That is how dry the air is, and how cold. Slam a car door and the light fluffiness on the window shatters and disappears as if by magic. Children can roll in snowdrifts and not get wet. Or dirty.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Malcolm Pirnie, Inc., consulting environmental engineers, has leased 41,000 square feet of office space at 2 Corporate Park Drive, in the Cross Westchester Corporate Park, White Plains.

title: Jersey City Rx for Hospital
description: JERSEY CITY  Mayor Frank I Am The Law Hague considered the Jersey City Medical Center his pet project. As such, he often could be seen roaming through the hospital's corridors and wards late at night, checking as to whether doctors and nurses were working, not sleeping on duty.

title: Artillery Fire Is Reported For 2d Day on Golan Heights
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 16 (Ur)Syrian and Israeli forces exchanged artillery fire for a second day along the Golan Heights truce lines today.

title: And Then There Are The Authentic Fakes
description: PARIS IF a painting is not a fake, one assumes that it must be authentic. But authenticity in art is a highly complex, elastic notion. So complex and so fascinating, in fact, that the Louvre has organized a major exhibitionthe first of its kindto illustrate and define the most important aspects of the problem.

title: RUGBY UNION
description: Balh 6, Cheltenham 4. Blackheath 26, Cambridge University 6. Saracens 13, Rosslyn Park 19.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WARSAW, Feb. 17 (AP)Henryk Szordykowski of Poland set a world indoor record for the 1,000meter run today, covering the distance in 2 minutes 20 seconds in meet here, the Polish press agency P.A.P. reported. Szordykowski's time was fourtenths of a second faster than the listed record of 2:20.4 set by Tom Von Ruden of the United States in 1971.

title: Bryant Moves On With Jackson Five
description: Andrew Jackson and Bryant advanced to the quarterfinals of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball playoffs yesterday at Queensboro Community College.

title: A PATROLMAN KILLS BURGLARY SUSPECT
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 17 (UPI)A patrolman shot and killed a burglary suspect early today after he allegedly found him prying open vendingmachine coin boxes at a bar.

title: Poor Getting Cash, Benefits Found to Keep Working
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 17 (UPI) Poor fathers generally continue to work when they receive income supplements, Representative Martha W. Griffiths, Democrat of Michigan, said today in releasing studies of income supplement programs.

title: Treasury Removes Guards for Agnew
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 Secret Service agents will no longer protect former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, the Treasury Department announced tonight.

title: CLOSE RACE SEEN FOR FORD'S SEAT
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 17A special election tomorrow to fill the Congressional seat vacated by Vice President Ford may have developed into a close battle involving President Nixon's standing among orthodox Middle Western Republicans.

title: Sports Today
description: BOXING

title: European Unity: Goal in Danger
description: PARIS, Feb. 17A remarkable advertisement appeared in the weekend issues of themost influential papers of France and West Germany. It appealed to the adherents of the ideal of a united Europe to rally to their cause and reject the doctrine of national independence which directs all policy exclusively in terms of national interest.

title: DAYAN IS TARGET OF RARE PROTEST
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 17  Several thousand demonstrators gathered today outside the office of Premier Golda Meier to demand the resignation of Defense Minister Moshe Dayan as the man responsible for Israel's failures in the October war.

title: STATE SCHOOL FINDS A 4TH PATIENT DEAD
description: WASSAIL. N.Y., Feb. 17 (AP) The body of a severely retarded patient was discovered today, hours after he walked away from a state facility here, officials said.

title: ONE DIES, 11 SAVED AS FISH BOAT SINKS
description: A 51foot fishing boat with 12 persons aboard sank in heavy seas yesterday about a mile northwest of Ambrose Light, claiming the life of the vessel's captain.

title: Survey Is Planned On U.S. Problems Of Puerto Ricans
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb, 17  After two years of planning, the American Friends Service Committee will open a wideranging twoyear study on Wednesday on the effects that United States governmental policies and industrial practices have had on Puerto Rico and Puerto Ricans.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 27

title: Bullets Win A Game But Lose a Star
description: LARGO, Md., Feb. 17 (UPI) The Capital Bullets lost another starter tohight, but won from the Boston Celtics, 9995. Phil Chenier pulled a right hamstring muscle in the second quarter and joined Archie Clark, out with an elbow injury, on the bench.

title: Pedestrians First
description: The forced decline in automobile usage makes this an auspicious time to launch a policeaided drive to return pedestrians to the status of firstclass citizenship.

title: NIXON'S LAWYER SAYS TESTS FIND TAPES AUTHENTIC
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 17  President Nixon's Watergate lawyer, James D. St. Clair, said today that a White Housespbnsored technical review had refuted reports that two subpoenaed tape recordings were not authentic.

title: 3D MARKET CURBS SOUGHT IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17The Senate Securities subcommittee is considering legislation to restrict transactions in listed securities by broker dealers off the floor of registered national stock exchanges.

title: Gasoline for Ocean County fought in a Class Action
description: TRENTON, Feb. 17Ocean County, whose residents have suffered more than most because of the gasoline shortage, may become the first county in the country to get relief under a Federal energy provision invoked by county officials.

title: Callas Cancels Here
description: Maria Callas, who was to have made her first New York appearance in nine years last night, canceled her recital an hour and a half before it was to have begun. The announcement left 2,800 fans milling in the lobby of Carnegie Hall. The official explanation was that the soprano had a cold. Page 32.

title: 3 Men Rob Armored Truck Of $200,000 in Bay State
description: SOMERSET, Mass., Feb. 17 (UPI)The police started statewide manhunt today for three men who robbed an armored truck of at least $200,000 in cash last night, and tried to learn whether the theft was linked to earlier robberies of the same company.

title: TAIPEI EDITOR TO GO TO SAVE MAGAZINE
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 17 The editor of one of Taiwan's bestknown political journals, long controversial for its frequent criticism of Government policy, says he will resign because the authorities have threatened to close the magazine unless he removes himself from the staff.

title: Pianistic Magic Is Woven By Radu Lupu in Schubert
description: As those who have heard him a]e aware, Radu Lupu, the young Rumanian, is no ordinary pianist. As if to prove this conclusively, Mr. Lupu played program Saturday night at Hunter College Assembly Will consisting of Bartk's Out of Doors and Brahms's Six Piano Pieces (Op. 118) for the first half and Schubert's Sonata in B flat (posthumous) for the secdad. He is, you see, a very serious man.

title: Knights Victors, 10.3
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., Feb. 17 (AP)Wayne Rivers, Bob Brown and Mike Laughton scored firstperiod goals, starting the Jersey Knights on the way to a 103 World Hockey Association rout of the Quebec Nordiques tonight.

title: Gas Lines Hurt Liquor Store's Sales
description: ALBERTSON, L.I., Feb. 17 The sign in the window of Dell's Liquor Store reads: Get tanked here. The price is right and there's no limit.

title: PETROSIAN ADVANCES TO CHESS SEMIFINAL
description: PALMA DE MAJORCA, Spain, Feb. 17 (UPI)Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, a former world chess champion, beat Lajos Portisch of Hungary here today to win their quarterfinal Candidates Match.

title: Stars Down Nets, Notch 13th in Row
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 16 (UPI)The Utah Stars won their 13th straight American Basketball Association game tonight, beating the New York Nets, 116105.

title: Hearst, Buoyed by New Message, to Give Food Plan
description: HILLSBOROUGH, Calif., Feb. 17After receiving what has been characterized as an encouraging message from his daughter, Randolph A. Hearst, the newspaper executive, said through a spokesman today that he would announce a plan tomorrow for distribution of free food for the needy.

title: JOHN F. GLYNN
description: John F. Glynn, athletic director of Pius XII High School in Chester, N.Y., died Thursday of a heart attack at St. Anthony's Hospital; Warwick, N.Y. He was 62 years old and was a resident at the school.

title: SOCCER RESULTS
description: NATIONAL CHALLENGE CUP

title: Vice President Home Urged
description: WASINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) Representative Gilbert Gude, Republican of Maryland, said today that he and Representative John E. Moss, Democrat of California, would introduce a bill to provide up to $750,000 for an official home for the Vice President.

title: Sabres Edge Wings
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 17 (AP)Rick Dudley's goal at the 14:26 mark of the final period tonight gave the Buffalo Sabres a 21 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

title: Treasury Removes Guards for Agnew
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 Secret Service agents will no longer protect former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, the Treasury Department announced tonight.

title: 41 for Squires' Eakins
description: NORFOLK, Va., Feb 17 (AP)Jim Eakins scored a careerhigh 41 points to help the Virginia Squires end a fivegame losing streak with a 118113 American Basketball Association victory over the Kentucky Colonels today.

title: Polish Ministers Named
description: WARSAW, Feb. 17 (UPI)Premier Piotr Jarciszewicz named new ministers of culture and agriculture, the Communist party newspaper Trybuna said today. Jozef Tejchma, of the party's Politburo, was appointed Minister of Culture. Stanislaw Wronski, who headed the culture ministry became minister without portfolio. Kazimierz Barcikowski replaced Jozef Okuniewski as Minister of Agriculture.

title: Petty Takes $275,000 Daytona 500 for 5th Time
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. Feb. 17With less than 28 miles remaining in the richest stockcar race in history, Donnie Allison was enjoying a threequarterlap lead and feeling sorry for Richard Petty.

title: 2d Heller Book Due 13 Years After First
