description: With his first novel, Catch22, Joseph Heller became a celebrated author, and it has not been clear during the 13 years since his book came out whether his great success was to remain the past or to serve as prologue.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Bankers Rush to Egypt, But the Masses Are Poor
description: CAIRO, Feb. 17Egypt has become creditworthy, replied the gogetting young American banker when he was asked why so many private investors and Government officials from the United States, Western Europe, Japan and the Arab world were flocking to Cairo to offer loans and solicit industrial orders.

title: Success in City Planning
description: The State Charter Revision Commission report on Planning in New York City includes a good deal of backing and filling and some carefully raised straw men, The main points attackedindependence vs. politicization, centralization vs. decentralization, fragmentation vs. consolidation, and attachment to the executive or legislative branchare the conventional issues of the municipal planning process.

title: Petty Takes $275,000 Daytona 500 for 5th Time
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. Feb. 17With less than 28 miles remaining in the richest stockcar race in history, Donnie Allison was enjoying a threequarterlap lead and feeling sorry for Richard Petty.

title: Jewish Dancer Says Soviet Seeks to Blacken His Name
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 17 (Reuters) Valery Panov, the Jewish ballet dancer, says he believes the Soviet authorities are trying to force him to leave the country without his wife so that they can blacken his name for deserting her.

title: ARTHUR JACOBS
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I., Feb. 17Arthur Jacobs, purchasing and production coordinator of Simes Company, Inc., lightingfixture manufacturers in Queens, died Thursday in Mercy Hospital, Rockville Centre, after a heart attack. He was 63 years old and lived at 7 Cowpath Lane.

title: JEWS LIST CAUSES OF ENERGY CRISIS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17In attempts to head off a potential backlash of antiSemitism arising from the energy shortage, with its link to the ArabIsraeli conflict last fall, several major Jewish groups have put together pamphlets or public statements about the root causes of the crisis recently.

title: Bob Greene Heard in Tribute With Jelly Roll Morton's Music
description: Mr. Jelly Roll has finally made it in New York, 40 years after he left the city in defeat, 22 years after his death.

title: Pistons Never Trail
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 (AP)Bob Lanier scored 14 of his gamehigh 27 points in the third period today as the Detroit Pistons led all the way in a 118107 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: DR. FREDERICK WAUGH
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Feb. 17Dr. Frederick Vail Waugh, retired Government economist, died yesterday in Arlington Hospital. He was 75 years old and a resident of Arlington.

title: Bryant Moves On With Jackson Five
description: Andrew Jackson and Bryant advanced to the quarterfinals of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball playoffs yesterday at Queensboro Community College.

title: Gasoline Shortage
description: The Federal Energy Office has dispatched teams of experts to twenty states to determine how much more acute the shortage of gasoline is in some areas than othersand whether to change the allocation system to even up supplies.

title: Holiday Closings Today
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges are closed today for Washington's Birthday. All major commodities exchanges are also closed, as are banks in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Democratic Chairman Vows To Give Wallace a Voice
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 17 (UPI)  The Democratic National Chairman, Robert S. Strauss, has promised to name a supporter of Gov. George C. Wallace to the Democratic patty's compliance review commission.

title: British Troops in Belfast Battle Mob, Kill Gunman
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 17 (UPI)British troops killed a young Protestant gunman and wounded two others in a shooting battle after a series of clashes here today, the British Army said.

title: Leavening in Spain?
description: Hopes for liberalization in Spain have been disappointed so often over Generalissimo Franco's 35year rule that Premier Carlos Arias Navarro's promise of wider and freer political participation is bound to be received with skepticism. Yet, with General Franco fading into the background at 81, Mr. Arias' modest plans make sense; and he has announced enough of a timetable for his first moves to make it difficult for him to retreat.

title: USE OF ORAL VACCINE FOR CHOLERA BACKED
description: BOSTON, Feb. 17 (AP) Researchers have discovered how intestinal antibodies protect against cholera, and they say this strongly suggests that an oral vaccine would give better protection than the injections now used.

title: ExAddicts Rehabilitate Library and Themselves
description: Five former drug addicts are scrubbing marble walls inside: the main building of the New York Public Library as part of the first general cleaning it has, received since it opened in 1911.

title: 3% More in Poll Oppose Resignation by President
description: While more than 70 per cent of Americans surveyed continue to believe that President Nixon either planned, tolerated or tried to cover up the Watergate burglary, according to the Gallup Poll, the latest sampling found that 49 per cent opposed his possible resignation and that 51 per cent opposed his removal from office.

title: SuperSonics Win, 10687
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 17 (AP) Fred Brown scored 24 points to help the Seattle SuperSonics defeat Cleveland, 10697, tonight in N.B.A. action. Lenny Wilkins led Cleveland with 25 points.

title: Rift in Ethiopian Society May Be Deepened by Famine
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 6Famine is not new to Ethiopia. Although little world attention was attracted, at least 100,000 people died of hunger in the northern and central regions in 1958 and 1959, according to a Western historian.

description: BOXING

title: MRS. HENRY M'CRACKEN
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Feb. 17Mrs. Marjorie Dodd McCracken, widow of Dr. Henry Noble McCracken, former president of Vassar College, died Thursday at Vassar Hospital here. She was 91 years old.

title: Indoor Mile Record Set By Waldrop
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 17 (AP)Tony Waldrop, who rose from obscurity to outrun the cream of America's milers this winter, shattered the world indoor mile record tonight with a time of 3 minutes 55 seconds at the San Diego indoor games.

title: OIL RESERVE SEARCH URGED BY EXPERTS
description: PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 17 (AP)A group of petroleum specialists headed by Harrison H. Schmitt, the geologistastronaut, urged President Nixon and Congress today to begin a five year, $2billion search for new oil and gas reserves.

description: LONDON, Feb. 17Prime Minister Heath was flushed with anger and Harold Wilson was disconcerted by the quesions during separate appear??nces on television Friday ??ight. But neither candidate complained.

title: Still Less Time
description: We publish today a letter from Senator Brooke of Massachusetts commenting on our editorial So Little Time. warning of the imminent danger to remaining unspoiled coastal areas, with particular references to the islands of Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket.

title: Carol Mann Triumphs By 6 Shots
description: NAPLES, Fla., Feb. 17 (AP)Carol Mann fired a threeunderpar 69 today to capture the $38,000 Naples women's golf tournament.

title: A Palace Guard?
description: BOSTON, Feb. 17When a squad of Secret Service agents accompanies Spiro T. Agnew on a vacation trip to Palm Springs, Calif., can we wonder that Americans are cynical about their political system? It is revolting that a penny of public funds should be spent on this impenitent felon as he lives the high life.

title: Muslims Charged in Seven Killings To Go on Trial in Washington Court
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17Jury selection will begin this week in the trial of five selfprofessed Black Muslims charged with the slaying of seven members of a rival Muslim sect, the largest mass murder in this city's history.

title: MACHINISTS, IN POLL, FAVOR RESIGNATION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) Nearly half the members of the machinists union, described by President Nixon as the backbone of the American middle class, think Mr. Nixon should resign, the head of the 900,000 member union said today.

title: 5 Die in Newly Bought Car
description: DAVENPORT, Iowa, Feb. 17 (AP)A Springfield, Ill., couple and their three young children were found dead of carbon monoxide poisoning today in a car they purchased just yesterday. Frank Hines, 41 years old, and his wife, Frita, 26, bought a used 1967 car yesterday in Springfield and drove here with their children, Susie, 3, and twin boys, Michael and Matthew, 7 months, to visit friends. The family was found dead in the car this afternoon with the motor running.

title: Suns Top Blazers
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 17 (AP)Mike Bantom with 22 points and Clem Haskins with 21 led Phoenix to a 112100 N.B.A. victory over the Portland Trail Blazers tonight. It was the third consecutive loss for the Blazers and their 17th defeat in 19 games.

title: L.I.R.R. Train Is Derailed
description: PARMINUDALL, L. I., Fed. 17 (UPI)  One person was slightly injured last night when five cars of a sevencar Long Island Rail Road train derailed here about 1,000 feet east of Merritt Road. The police said they believed someone might have tampered with the tracks. The injured passenger, Jose Guzman, 36 years old, of 1605 North Thompson Drive, Bay Shore, was treated and released at MidIsland Hospital.

title: Syracuse U. Professor's SexEducation Comic Books Aren't Funny to Everyone
description: SYRACUSESome people think that Sol Gordon's comic books are outrageously funny. Others think they are just outrageous.

title: Stars Win With Worsley
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Feb. 17 (AP)Gump Worsley, marking his 850th N.H.L. game in goal, helped the Minnesota North Stars to a 71 triumph over the California Golden Seals today.

title: Nixon to Visit Huntsville On Honor America Day
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Feb. 17 The 140,000 people who live in this NorthCentral Alabama city are accustomed to coming up with answers to complex questions.

description: MONTREAL, Feb. 17 (AP) Gary Dornhoefer and Ross Lonsberry scored unassisted thirdperiod goals, giving the Philadelphia Flyers a 22 tie with the Montreal Canadiens in a brawlmarred National Hockey League game on national television today.

title: Blazers Blank Sharks
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 17 (AP)  Peter Donnelly, the Vancouver goalie, turned in his second consecutive shutout against the Los Angeles Sharks today as the Blazers triumphed, 40, in the W.H.A. Donnelly only had to turn away 18 shots.

title: Ward Paces Crusaders
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 17 (AP) Ron Ward, traded last week to Cleveland, led the Crusaders to a 65 victory over the Chicago Cougars in the World Hockey Association today with three goals and an assist.

title: Captain Dies, 11 Saved As Fishing Boat Sinks
description: A 51foot fishing boat with 12 persons aboard sank in heavy seas yesterday about a mile northwest of Ambrose Light, claiming the life of the vessel's captain.

title: FreeforAll ... TV Shows Real Thing Isn't Kid Stuff
description: In what might have been the bloodiest Sunday on television since peace with honor in Vietnam, Americans Ind Canadians were bombarded yesterday with a hockey marathon that probably left a few million youngsters with the impression that the high stick is more to be desired than a fast skater.

title: Japanese Launch Their 5th Satellite and Take a Major Step Forward in Space Program
description: TOKYO, Feb. 17Japanese scientists, after several years of lobbing satellites into space like farmers heaving pumpkins, rifled one through a keyhole in the sky with nearly perfect precision today.

title: 15 Alexander Stores Open on Sunday; 4 Charged Under State Sabbath Law
description: Alexander's opened its five department stores in the city for business yesterday in a, break with departmentstore tradition and in defiance of the state's Sabbath closing law.

title: Robinson Races to Star Role
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 17 (AP)James Robinson, an Oakland product, stole the show from visiting Soviet track stars, last night at the Oakland invitation meet. He set an American record of 1 minute 18.8 seconds in winning the 600meter run.

title: Personal Finance: I.R.S. and the Innocent Spouse
description: A married woman holding a position of high trust with an important Southern company suddenly began spending large sums of money on a boy friend. Then one day she disappeared.

title: ENERGY BILL VETO LIKELY IN DISPUTE ON OIL ROLLBACK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 Nixon Administration strategists said today that if Congress passed the emergency energy bill, the President would veto it because he feels that its provision for a rollback of crude oil prices is inflexible.

Knicks Go Cold And Lose
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 17In the first 11 minutes 44 seccods of the fourth quarter today, Earl Monroe and Phil Jackson combined for all the Knicks' points against the Milwaukee Bucks. The trouble was that they only totaled 7.

title: Connors Tops Mayer In Final
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 16 (AP)Jimmy Connors proved too tough for Sandy Mayer today in taking the Birmingham international indoor tennis tournament in straight sets, 75, 63.

title: First Statewide Convention Since 1848 Draws 400 Women Political Activists
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 17The first statewide political convention of women in New York in 126 years gave birth today to the New York State Women's Political Caucus.

title: Traffic Light as Fuel Flow Slows to a Trickle Here
description: Traffic was abnormally light and open gasoline stations were scarcer than ever yesterday as motorists in the metropolitan area struggled through one of the worst weekends yet in the energy crisis.

description: To the Editor: As an Englishman who visits the United States regularly, I read your Feb. 6 editorial on the British coal miners' strike with interest. Your statement that the present Conservative Government's rigidity has been a substantial cause of Britain's difficulties may well be true, but I hope you will agree that this stand was necessary in view of the first three of the real causes, which I list below:

The announcement left 2,800 fans milling in the lobby of Carnegie Hall. The official explanation was that the soprano had a cold. Page 32.

title: 49 Cairo Soccer Fans Are Killed in Stampede
description: CAIRO, Feb. 17 (UPI) Thousands of Egyptian fans crashed through iron gates into a stadium today where the national soccer team was about to play. Police sources said 49 persons were killed and 47 injured in the stampede.

title: Indiana Triumphs
description: DENVER, Feb. 17 (AP)  George McGinnis scored 22 points and got 14 rebounds tonight in leading Indiana to a 9392 victory over Denver in an American Basketball Association game.

title: A Teacher's Fight for Right To Shun Pledge to the Flag
description: HENRIETTA, N.Y.It was 8:45 on a snowy morning, and the buses bringing children to Roth Junior High School were a little late. The school, a flat, factorylike building with gleaming halls, began to take on an invisible cheer.

description: A group of Nazi concentraion camp survivors criticized he Senate yesterday for not approving the genocide treaty.

description: The Pacific8 Conference, whose basketball fortunes hive been dominated by U.C.L.A. for a long time, is ganging up on an old foe.

title: 1,000 of the City's 31,000 Policemen Are Out in Radio Cars at Any One Time
New, Confident Nixon
description: MIAMI, Feb. 17  A new selfassurance in the Whit House appears to have dispelle a view of only a month ago that President Nixon was on the verge of resigning. Thus, whit the House Judiciary Committee prepares for the opening of impeachment hearings Thursday, the atmosphere around Mr. Nixon is like that surrounding a can didate who has suffered at manner of reverses but who now feels he can prevail in the end.

title: View From a Parish
description: London's Hyde Park turned out, for me, to be quite a disappointment. expected to hear a lively dialogue between speaker and listener on a whole spectrum of issues. Instead, I found only fruitless confrontation, closed minds on both sidesmountebanks versus hecklers. Has something like this breakdown in communications begun to occur between, New York's Roman Catholic hierarchy and laity, between those who hold the official Catholic position and those who are concerned for the wellbeing of our whole society?

title: Deposit Outflow Reported
description: NEW YORK, Feb. 17 (AP)The Savings Bank Association of New York State said savings banks reported a net deposit outflow of $82million last January. The outflow was concentrated in New York City, where 43 savings banks had a net deposit outflow of $104.6million.

title: College in Utah Teaches Dialect Spoken by MexicanAmericans
description: PROVO, Utah, Feb. 17Border or Chicano Spanish, dialect spoken by MexicanAmericans in the Southwest, is now being taught at Brigham Young University here.

title: Kissinger Meets Envoys Amid Talk of Arab Rifts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17Secretary of State Kissinger met separately today with the Egyptian and Saudi Arabian Foreign Ministers and a Syrian representative while high American officials sought to dampen optimistic speculation about the lifting of the Arab oil embargo against the United States.

title: Bridge: Roth Scores Double Victory In Holiday Tournament Here
description: The mercurial master of the Mayfair, Alvin Roth, scored a double victory here on the opening day of the Greater New York Bridge Association's George Washington Birthday tournament at the New York Hilton Hotel. Roth, whose Mayfair House of Bridge, at 14 East 60th Street, provides for backgammon enthusiasts as well as card players, won the men's pairs with John Solodar of New York and the mixed pairs with his regular partner, Barbara Rappaport of East Orange, N.J., both on Friday.

title: Theft of Helicopter With Seeming Ease Explained by Army
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Feb. 17 (Reuters)How could a young Army private take up an Army helicopter without permission and without being stopped?

title: CITY PEOPLE SEEK RURAL HEALTH AID
description: A growing number of Americans are driving up to 50 miles from big cities to see doctors in small towns for their basic medical care, according to results of a study reported today in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: NIXON'S LAWYER SAYS TESTS FIND TAPES AUTHENTIC
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 17  President Nixon's Watergate lawyer, James D. St. Clair, said today that a White Housesponsored technical review had refuted reports that two subpoenaed tape recordings were not authentic.

title: Soldier Lands a Stolen Copier on White House Lawn
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17A soldier landed a stolen Army helicopter in a hail of shotgun buckshot on the South Lawn of the White House at 2 A.M. today. He was wrestled to the ground by officers of the Executive Protection Service after bouncing the helicopter to a rough landing about 100 yards short of the White House.

title: ABORIGINES ASSAIL AIDE OF WHITLAM
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 17The Labor Government of Australia, which came to power at the end of 1972 promising a better deal for the aborigines, is taking a tough stand in a dispute with aboriginal leaders.

title: Moorer Indicates High Nixon Officials Rejected Plan for a Full Spy Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17Admiral Thomas H. Moorer suggested today that high civilian officials in the Nixon Administration overruled his recommendation for a full investigation of the alleged military spying ad tivities. Such an inquiry, he contended, would have uncovered the entire chain of events regardless of what they were.

description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 17 (AP)Leah Poulos of Northbrook, Ill., became the women's sprint champion in the world speedskating championships today after Tatiana Averina of the Soviet Union was disqualified for blocking another American, Sheila Young.

title: 12 More Die in Campus Crash
description: GREENVILLE, Pa., Feb. 17 (UPI)Two 18yearold Grove City College students died today of injuries received when an automobile ran into a group of 17 students returning to the campus after a fraternity initiation. The deaths of John Curtin of Pittsburgh and Gary Gilliland of New Castle, Pa., raised the death toll in the accident to four. Two other students, Thomas M. Elliot, 18, of Pittsburgh, and Rudolph Mion, 18, of Glenshaw, Pa., died instantly in the accident.

title: To Ranch in West Or Strip for Coal: A Difficult Choice
description: COLSTRIP, Mont.  The ranchers in this rugged southeastern corner of Montana run 25,000 to 30,000 or even 50,000 acres, vast expanses of rolling range sliced irregularly by sharp ravines and marked by frequent outcroppings of weathersculptured standstone.

description: RUTHERFORD, N. J., Feb. Dr. Jerome M. Pollack, a former oilcompany geologist who is now the acting president of Fairleigh Dickinson University, the problems confronting higher education are somewhat, akin to the energy crisis.

title: Shockley and Innis Are Again Denied Forum for Debate
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 17Yale University's Political Union decided this weekend to call off plans for a debate between Dr. William B. Shockley, whose views on racial genetics have stirred considerable controversy, and Roy I. Innis, executive director of the Congress of Racial Equality.

title: Where Vietcong's Roots Go Deep
description: This article is the second in a series by the Saigon bureau chief of The New York Times, who recently spent a week in Vietcongheld territory on South Vietnam's central coast.

title: Rochelle Abelow, Teacher, Marries
description: NORTH WOODMERE, L. I., Feb. 17Miss Rochelle Linda Abelow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron H. Abelow of Oceanside, was married here this evening to Sidney Max Newman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Newman of Riverdale, the Bronx. Rabbi Joshua Schmidmann performed the ceremony at Temple Hillel, assisted by Rabbi Benjamin Blech.

title: Major Bills in Congress
Packages Studied as Toy Industry's Yule Opens
description: The Christmas season begins this week for the nation's toy industry, as the American Toy Fair opens for the 71st year in New York.

title: Argentine Death Toll at 60 in Widespread Flooding
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 17At least 60 people have died and more than 100,000 have been evacuated from their homes in three northwestern provinces of Argentina in the wake of severe flooding.

title: Queens Fire Destroys 117YearOld Church
description: A 117yearold Queens landmark was destroyed by fire early yesterday when flames consumed the church building of St. Mary's Star of the Sea parish at 1920 New Haven Avenue, at the corner of Beach 20th Street, Far Rockaway.

title: Montclair State Wins Mat Title
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, NJ., Feb. 17  Montclair State College won its second Metropolitan Intercollegiate wrestling championship last night, with four firstplace winners, five second places and one third helping to amass 166 points.

title: FreeforAll... TV Shows Real Thing Isn't Kid Stuff
description: In what might have been the bloodiest Sunday on television since peace with honor in Vietnam, Americans and Canadians were bombarded yesterday with a hockey marathon that probably left a few million youngsters with the impression that the high stick is more to be desired than a fast skater.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: 41 for Squires' Eakins
description: NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 17 (AP)Jim Eakins scored a careerhigh 41 points to help the Virginia Squires end a fivegame losing streak with a 118113 American Basketball Association victory over the Kentucky Colonels today.

title: Oil Crisis Disrupts Caribbean Development Plans
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Feb. 14The International oil crisis has struck hard at the Caribbean region's newborn economic community, disrupting development plans, stopping currency convertibility and causing severe shortages of basic consumer goods.

title: McAdoo Hits 38 for Braves
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) The Buffalo Braves, behind the 38 points of Bob McAdoo, defeated the Houston Rockets, 135118, tonight in an N.B.A. game. The Rockets were led by Rudy Tomjanovich.with 28 points and Mike Newlin with 26.

title: Finn in Moscow for Talks
description: MOSCOW. Feb. 17 (UPI)  President Urho K. Kekkonen of Finland resumed talks today with Soviet leaders at a government villa near Moscow, a Find nish source said. Dr. Kokkonen held his first round of talks yesterday with President Nikolai V. Podgorny and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin after arriving in Moscow by train.

title: Washington's Birthday
description: Today is George Washington's birthday, Schools, stock exchanges, banks and post offices will be closed, though most retail and department stores will be open. Refuse collections and alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations are suspended.

title: Georgia Capitol Gets A Portrait of Dr. King
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 17 (UFO A portrait of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., was unveiled in the Capitol today, the first picture of a black man ever to be displayed there.

title: About New York On Saving Ballet at the Box Office
description: Sherwin M. Goldman punched at the calculator on his desk. Sunny weekends in the summer are bad, he said. Selling in advance is impossible, but I figure box office of $100,000 a week, with . . . Mr. Goldman punched at the calculator again. . . . 83 per cent of the seats sold. He beamed. Figures in the performing arts are a nightmare, he said, and beamed again.

title: Barber Wins Ski Jump, Retires Harris Trophy
description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Feb. 17  Hugh Barber, a former Middlebury College star, returned to his home town today determined to retire one of ski jumping's most coveted awards, a huge, silverwinged trophy.

title: NIGERIA IS UNABLE TO SHIP PEANUTS
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 6Nigeria, normally the world's largest exporter of peanuts, will not ship out any peanuts this year, and she will export a minimum of peanut oil and cake.

title: Goldin Proclaiming His Independence Of Beame, but With Cautious Courtesy
description: A bit earlier than had been expected, Controller Harrison J. Goldin has proclaimed his declaration of cautious independence from Mayor Beame, the man whose job it is widely assumed Mr. Goldin aspires to. Mr. Goldin has not come out with fists flailing. Rather, with the innocently regretful air of someone who might have jabbed an elbow intoa fellow passenger in a crowded elevator, he has taken two politically pointed shots at the way things were done in the Controller's office up to Dec. 31, when Mr. Beame ran the place.

title: Callas Abruptly Cancels Recital Here
description: Maria Callas, whose volatile behavior is perhaps as famous as her voice, abruptly canceled her longawaited comeback concert here an hour and a half before it was to begin last night, leaving 2,800 chagrined fans locked out in the cramped, lobby at Carnegie Hall.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FERRY TALE It's not quite the Queen Elizabeth or the France, but the Staten Island ferry has its musicals, zoo. Several days a week, a doubleender casts off from St. George (on the far end) or from Manhattan with an ensemble such as the Stockbaroquers, the Mandolin Brothers, the Orpeus Chamber Ensemble or the Riverside Quintet, giving a bayborne concert in the big cabin on the main passenger deck.

title: Stockton Wins by 2 Shots as Snead's Miracle Fails
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 17Sam Snead, at the age of 61 trying for his first tour victory since 1965, wound up only two strokes behind the winner, Dave Stockton, in the Glen Campbell Los Angeles open golf tournament today. Snead finished tied for second with John Mahaffey, a young Texan 36 years his junior.

title: Solzhenitsyn Prays on Visit To an Ancient Swiss Abbey
description: EINSIEDELN, Switzerland, Feb. 17 (AP)  Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn prayed in an ancient Roman Catholic abbey today.

title: 2,000 in Symphony Hall Cheer Singing Group Formed in Prison
description: NEWARK, Feb. 17The Escorts, seven elegantly dressed young men, brought down the house in Symphony Hall last night as the singing group that had started in the big house in Rahway gave their first fullfledged concert.

title: Where Vietcong's Roots Go Deep
description: This article is the second in a series by the Saigon bureau chief of The New York Times, who recently spent a week Vietcongheld territory on South Vietnam's, central coast.

title: Czech HaircutDrive Seen
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Feb. 17 (Reuters)  Czechoslovak authoritfs have banned public appearances by longhaired male entertainers, apparently as part of an official campaign against western hair styles, the Bavarian State Interior Ministry said today. It added that policemen in Czechoslovakia had also begun stopping longhaired young men in the street, telling them to cut their hair.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1974

title: FOOD INSPECTIONS CENTER OF DISPUTE
description: A jurisdictional tug of war between the city and state has forced thousands of food processors and wholesalers to pay double license fees and has led to a lawsuit against the Health Department by two meat industry organizations.

title: Packages Studied as Toy Industry's Yule Opens
description: Who is there who has not at some time said to himself: I'll give the bigger package as gift, even though it costs the same as the other one, because it looks more impressive.

title: FILIPINO REFUGEES TELL OF REBELLION
description: ZAMBOANGA, the Philippines, Feb. 16Refugees from the fighting between Government troops and Moslem rebels on the island of Jolo arrived here today with stories of lost homes and dead or missing relatives.

title: Coffee Maker Explodes On Jet Carrying Arabs
description: Two stewardesses were slightly injured Saturday night when a coffee maker exploded aboard an airliner carrying Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy of Egypt and Foreign Minister Omar Saqqaf of Saudi Arabia to a conference in Washington.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Arthur Miller is General Manager of the Sewing Equipment Division of WILLCOX & GIBBS (WGAMEX)

title: G.O.P. House Conservatives unite to Influence President
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) Vowing to trim the budget and stop the Administration from tilting leftward, 70 conservative House Republicans have joined forces in an effort to influence President Nixon during his last three years in office.

title: Lynne Patricia Oliver Bride of Arnold Schorr
description: Miss Lynne Patricia Oliver, daughter of Mrs. Valentine Sherry of New York and David Oliver of San Juan, Puerto Rico, was married here yesterday afternoon to Arnold Schorr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Schorr of Hartford. Rabbi Bernard J. Bamberger performed the ceremony at Temple Sharay Tefila.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MONTCLAIR,Raising $12,000 to make a historic trip to England sounds like a difficult task when 25 lacrosse players try to do it by raking leaves, shoveling snow, and painting house numbers on curbs.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Spurred by a sharp increase in the cost of food, consumer prices in the New Yorknortheastern New Jersey area rose 6.3 per cent in 1973, according to the Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics. The rise of prices here, slightly higher than the national average increase of 6.2 per cent, reflected a 13.1 per cent rise in food pricesthe largest jump since 1946, when food prices went up 15.6 per cent. Large increases for energyrelated items, such as fuel oil and gasoline, also were a factor.

title: Howard Meyers Weds Miss Mangeri
description: JAMESBURG, N. J., Feb. 17Miss Rosemary Mangeri, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Mangeri of Jamesburg, was married here this afternoon to Howard M. Meyers of Dallas and New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Meyers of Springfield. The Rev. Chester Mroz, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Bruce Goldman officiated in the Rossmore Community Interfaith Chapel.

title: Soldier Lands a Stolen Copier on White House Lawn
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17A soldier landed a stolen Army helicopter in a hail of shotgun buckshot on the South Lawn of the White House at 2 A.M. today. He was wrestled to the ground by officers of the Executive Protection Service after bouncing the helicopter to a rough landing about 100 yards short of the White House.

title: SENATE UNIT SEES NUTRITION DANGER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17The ability of American families to feed themselves adequately is threatened by inflation and the energy crisis, according to a report of the Senate Select Committee on Nutrition and Human Needs.

title: New Rosenkavalier Cast Offers Opera at Grandest
description: The sets and the conductor of Strauss's Der Rosenkavalier on Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Opera were familiar. Little else about the production was. It was the seasons first Rosenkavalier, and none of the principals had ever before taken on their respective roles at the Metropolitan. Indeed, two of themBrigitte Fassbaender as Octavian and Manfred Jungwirth as Baron Ochs  were making their debut.

title: Rangers Roll Up 94 Rout
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Feb. 17In an era when the national objective is conservation of energy, the New York Rangers emerged as the model of thrift here last night.

title: U.S. SAID TO CHIDE CAMBODIA AIRMEN
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 17  American officials here have been pressing the Cambodian military to provide more aerial protection for Phnom Penh to prevent the kind of artillery attacks that the Communistled insurgents have been inflicting on the civilian population, according to authoritative military sources here.

title: Squatters Appeal Notice
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 (AP)The Tocks Islands squatters have filed notice of appeal on an eviction notice handed down Friday by a Federal judge in Scranton. The squatters have been living in houses and using land the Army Corps of Engineers bought for the longdelayed Tocks Island Dam near East Stroudsburg, Pa.

title: Con Edison Gets Approval I For $150Million Bond Sale
description: ALBANY, Feb. 17 (UPI)The Public Service Commission has authorized two utilities to sell a total of $201million in common stocks or bonds to finance new projects.

title: Theater: New Carousel
description: It should surprise no one that a revived Carousel works beautifully, turning with real charm and luster, on the stage of the Equity Library Theater (6632028), on 103d Street at Riverside Drive. Rodgers and Hammerstein fans who savored the splendor of an outdoor production last summer at Jones Beach can now relish this more intimate version, which snugly projects the show's story, spirit and incomparably luminous score.

title: Morose Campaign in Indian Village
description: CHHAPRAULI, India, Feb. 16The landless men in this dusty village sit beside their Hindu temple at noon, munching barks of sugar cane and sullenly watching the campaign jeeps of the landowners move along the narrow dirt road.

title: Traffic Light as Fuel Flow Slows to a Trickle Here
description: Traffic was abnormally light and open gasoline stations were scarcer than ever yesterday as motorists in the metropolitan area struggled through one of the worst weekends yet in the lenergy crisis.

title: GULAG DEFENDED BY YEVTUSHENKO
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 17  The poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko today, defended Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn for having raised the issue of the Stalinist purges in his latest book and charged that the truth about the past was otherwise being concealed from Soviet youth.

title: U.S. HELPS SAIGON SPY ON PARACELS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 17 (AP)The United States has been helping South Vietnam spy on the Paracel and Hainan islands, but from an apparently safe distance, United States sources here said today.

title: Consumer Parley Disappoints Many
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 17 For many of the more than 400 teachers, home economists, businessmen and government officials concerned with consumer education, the third annual All Eastern Consumer Education Conference was a big letdown. The twoday affair, put on, by the Center for Consumer Education Services, headed by Dr. William L. Johnston, had been designed primarily for teachers, administrators and curriculum workers who are involved in consumer education programs in elementary and secondary schools.

title: Theft of Helicopter With Seeming Ease Explained by Army
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Feb. 17 (Reuters)How could a young Army private take up an Army helicopter without permission and without being stopped?

title: GULAG DEFENDED BY YEVTUSHENKO
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 17  The poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko today defended Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn for having raised the issue of the Stalinist purges in his latest book and charged that the truth about the past was otherwise being concealed from Soviet youth.

title: Scaramouche Maintains Lead For Sailing Title in S.O.R.C.
description: MIAMI, Feb. 17  Scaramouche, the new 55foot sloop from Sturgis, Mich., continued her dominance of the Southern Ocean Racing Circuit by winning the 140mile Ocean Triangle race this weekend. Chuck Kirsch's whitehulled sloop thus maintained her lead in the S.O.R.C. standing with three of the six races in the series completed.

title: Japanese Loan to Syria
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 11 (AP)Japan has made a $100million loan to Syria for a new oil refinery, the Syrian Government announced today. It said that the refinery would be built at the Mediterranean port of Tartus. The loan is Japan's second to Syria since last year.

title: Stars Win With Worsley
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Feb. 17 (AP)Gump Worsley, marking his 850th N.H.L. game in goal, helped the Minnesota North Stars to a 71 triumph over the California Golden Seals today.

title: Two Hurt and 3 Missing As Gasoline Tank Ignites
description: Two women Here seriously burned and three other persons were reported missing yesterday in a Washington Heights fire that apparently started as One of the women was trying to clean and repair a Volkswagen gasoline tank in her apartment.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Givenchy's clothes generally manage to look better in BergdorfGoodman's Nouvelle Boutique than they do in his Paris salon.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Red Smith
description: When arbitration on baseball salaries is completed this week and final awards are made, the public will want to know how many cases were won by the players and how many decided in favor of employers. Some fans may be more interested in Henry Aaron's home run total, Tug McGraw's earnedrun average or Detroit's margin of victory in the American League East, but those figures have little significance compared with the score of the game now going on.

title: Books of The Times
description: MAINE PILGRIMAGE. The Search for an American Way of Life. By Richard Saltonstall Jr. 353 Pages. Illustrated with drawings by Polly Warren. Little, Brown, $10.

title: Bullets Top Celtics
description: LARGO, Md., Feb. 17 (UPI) The Capital Bullets lost another starter tonight, but won from the Boston Celtics, 9995. Phil Chenier pulled a right hamstring muscle in the second quarter and joined Archie Clark, out with an elbow injury, on the bench.

title: RUGBY UNION
description: Bath 6, Cheltenham 4.

title: Knights Victors, 103
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., Feb. 17 (AP)Wayne Rivers, Bob Brown and Mike Laughton scored firstperiod goals, starting the Jersey Knights on the way to a 103 World Hockey Association rout of the Quebec Nordiques tonight.

title: Costa Rica Keeping Her Doors, And Business, Open to Outsiders
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 10  Costa Ricans have no sense of nationality, a young lawyer complained. Worse than that, they like foreigners simply because they're foreigners.

title: The Game of the Name
description: AMHERST, Mass.Here comes John Smith walking toward me. Even though he is but a passing acquaintance, the American greeting ritual demands that I utter a few words (such as nice day or good morning) to reassure him of my goodwill. But what form of address should I use? John? Smith? Dr. Smith? A decision such as this is usually made unconsciously.

title: Washington Slept Here And There, but Fitfully
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP)  As far as comfort is concerned, places that advertise that George Washington slept here were not necessarily firstintheheart of their countryman, the National Geographic Society suggests.

title: Solzhenitsyn Without Tears
description: WASHINGTONI am the first on my block to feel misgivings about Alexander Solzhenitsyn.

title: Kissinger Meets Envoys Amid Talk of Arab Rifts,
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 Secretary of State Kissinger met separately today with the Egyptian and Saudi Arabian Foreign Ministers and a Syrian representative while high American officials sought to dampen optimistic speculation about the lifting of the Arab oil embargo against the United States.

title: Jobless Protection
description: With unemployment rolls climbing under the prod of oil scarcity and business slowdown, there is abundant justification for the extended unemployment insurance benefits recommended by Secretary of Labor Brennan.

title: Wilson and the Gasoline Squeeze
description: ALBANY, Feb. 17  It has been more than a week since Governor Wilson spoke in the face of Federal gasoline strictures and said he nevertheless expected the state to get greater allocation from the Government within a matter of a few days. Since then there have been few minor changes that have provided about an extra halfday's ration for this month, but the verdict is still out on the Governor's request for a larger basic allocation of the fuel.

title: Princeton Eating Clubs Regaining Popularity
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 17 The undergraduate eating clubs at Princeton University are enjoying renewed popularity this year, with more students trying to get into the selective private establishments than in any year since 1969.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A jurisdictional tug of war between the city and the state has forced thousands of food processors and wholesalers to pay double license fees and has led to a lawsuit by meat processors against the city, charging unfair procedures.

title: Conferees to Meet to Revise Mass Transit Subsidy Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) SenateHouse conferees on a mass transit operating subsidy bill plan to try to revise it this week to see whether it can be made acceptable to President Nixon.

title: Profit of Admiral Corporation Plunged in the Fourth Quarter
description: Fourth  quarter earnings of the Admiral Corporation plunged 81.4 per cent below those of the final quarter of 1972, according to a weekend report that included annual results.

title: MRS. FREDRICK STARE
description: BOSTON, Feb. 17  Mrs. Helen E. Stare, a trustee of the New England Conservatory of Music, died yesterday in Peter Bent Brigham Hospital here at the age of 58. She was the wife of Dr. Fredrick J. Stare, professor and chairman of the department of nutrition, Harvard School of Public Health.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Prices Here Up 6.3% in 1973

title: Schoolboy 2Mile Is Won by Crook
description: Steven Crook of St. Anthony's was timed in 9 minutes 19.4 seconds as the won the twomile run by 100 yards and shattered the meet record yesterday in the Long Island Catholic High Schools indoor track championships at the 102d Engineers Armory here.

title: Catholics in Brazil Protest Law Curbing Work With the Indians
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 17Church and state are in conflict here over the right to help the country's dwindling Indian minority.

title: Walter Lippmann's Wife Dead; Learned Russian to Assist Him
description: Mrs. Helen Byrne Lippman, wife of Walter Lippmann, the political journalist, died Saturday of cardiac arrest on her way to a hospital after a sudden illness at their home, 28 East 63d Street. She was 76 years old.

title: Sales of Seeds at Record as Home Gardening Gains Popularity
description: ALBANY, Feb 17  With fewer than four weeks to go before St. Patrick's Day, the traditional planting time for peas in the metropolitan New York area, major seed companies are reporting that orders for vegetable seeds for home gardners are breaking records.

title: Pappin's 3 Goals Help Hawks Win, 41
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (AP)Jim Pappin scored three goals as the Chicago Black Hawks topped the Toronto Maple Leafs, 41, in an N.H.L. game tonight. A Toronto defenseman; Bob Neely, was injured in the first period and hospitalized for xrays.

title: Tenant Groups to Ask Court to Block Rent Rises in Controlled Apartments
description: Angry tenant groups vowed yesterday to seek court action to block rent increases in controlled apartments to compensate landlords for higher labor costs.

title: BEAME AND GIBSON URGE URBAN UNITY
description: The Mayors of New York and Newark appealed yesterday for an end to confrontation politics and new coalition of urban groups, particularly blacks and Jews, to seek increased Federal aid for the cities.

title: Theater: The Freedom of the City, About the Irish
Pistons Never Trail
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 (AP)Bob Lanier scored 14 of his gamehigh 27 points in the third period today as the Detroit Pistons led all the way in a 118107 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: ALLEGHENY LUDLUM SEEKS A PRICE RISE
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 17 (AP)The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, the nation's 11th ranked steel producer, has asked the United States District Court for help in getting a price increase for its stainless steel products.

title: Aeros' Streak Stopped
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 17 Wayne Connelly scored three goals and Jimmy Johnson added two tonight to lead the Minnesota Fighting Saints to a 61 World Hockey Association victory over the Houston Aeros.

title: Opera: Caballe's Mimi
description: Since performing a major operatic role cannot be a pushover even for great stars of vast experience, it is odd that the best of them occasionally venture into assignments that could not be expected to add appreciably to their luster.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 27

title: Jersey Senator Arranges Major Gasoline Purchase
description: The president of the New Jersey State Senate, Frank J. Dodd, said yesterday that he had arranged the purchase of 1.3 million gallons of gasoline for delivery this month to service stations in New Jersey.

title: Newsman Leaving Vietcong Region Is Periled by Artillery and Patrols
description: QUI NHON, South Vietnam The visit to Vietcongheld territory is coming to an end. Late in the afternoon of the last day we go to the market in Lieu An hamlet.

title: Iowa Turkey FeatherDuster Factory Yields to the Aerosol Age
description: MONTICELLO, Iowa, Feb. 11A piece of the past died here the other day. When it passed on, with no fanfare, there was just one person left to cry. I ran the company the last few years, said Mrs. Shirley Hoag Eden, and, well, you see, well, I guess maybe I didn't do a very good job. Or something happened. And she stared at the floor.

title: Gromyko Backs French Stand in Energy Crisis
description: PARIS, Feb. 18  Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko today concluded a threeday visit to Paris, preparing for a FrenchSoviet meeting early next month. He endorsed improved SovietAmerican relations and the French policy of independence in the oil crisis.

title: ROBERT M. BECKET
description: Robert M. Becket, a lawyer with Davis, Polk & Wardwell, who was an adviser and trustee emeritus of The Seeing Eye, Inc., of Morristown, N. J., died yesterday of cancer in St. Luke's Hospital. He lived in the Town House Hotel here and in St. James, L. I.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Fuel Shortage: A Blessing

title: Bottle Bill
description: Following an example already established with encouraging success in Oregon, Vermont and several Canadian provinces, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has resubmitted to the Legislature a bill requiring that all beer, ale and carbonated beverage bottles and cans sold in New York State be made of recyclable material and be sold with a refundable deposit of at least five cents.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Tape recordings of police radio messages made the night Clark Squire allegedly killed a state trooper were admitted as evidence yesterday in Mr. Squire's trial in New Brunswick. Middlesex County Judge John E. Bachman, who ruled that the tapes were admissible, said they were the best possible evidence of what happened that night.

title: Pickets Leave Superdome
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 18 (UPI) Sheet metal workers withdrew picket lines at the $163million Louisiana Superdome today after an apparent settlement of a fourday dispute over the job jurisdictions of various unions. Although contractors and union officials refused to comment, work was expected to resume tomorrow at the stadium, which is scheduled to host the 1975 Super Bowl game.

title: A Poem in a Soviet Magazine Appears to Praise Solzhenitsyn
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 18A leading Soviet youth magazine published a poem today that was construed by some intellectuals here as a tribute to Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn.

title: Power Memorial, Molloy Win Titles
description: Archbishop Molloy and Power Memorial retained their team titles yesterday in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association sectional indoor track championships at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: LATINS SEEKING A COMMON FRONT
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 18 LatinAmerican and Caribbean foreign ministers began meeting in private here today in the hope of presenting a united front in their conference with Secretary of State Kissinger later this week.

title: U.C.L.A. Reign Not Over, Marquette Coach Advises
description: Al McGuire, the Marquette basketball coach who sometimes thinks like an oddsmaker, still likes the University of California, Los Angeles to win the Pacific8 Conference. Press McGuire a little more and he may even bet you that U.C.LA will win an eighth straight National Collegiate basketball championship

title: Iowa Turkey FeatherDuster Factory Yields to the Aerosol Age
description: MONTICELLO, Iowa, Feb. 11A piece of the past died here the other day. When it passed on, with no fanfare, there was just one person left to cry. I ran the company the last few years, said Mrs. Shirley Hoag Eden, and, well, you see, well, I guess maybe I didn't do a very good job. Or something happened. And she stared at the floor.

title: 2 Canadian Works Stand Out in Debut Of Purcell Quartet
description: The Purcell String Quartet, which made its New York debut on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall, was founded in 1969 and has been together in its current configuration for three years. All four members belonged to the Vancouver Symphony, but have now resigned to concentrate on their quartet careers. Based at Simon Fraser University in Vancouver, the group has played in San Francisco and in London, as well as all over Canada.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Brentwood Puerto Ricans Proudly Maintain Heritage
description: BRENTWOOD, L. I., Feb. 18When Cathy Rosario speaks, her firstgraders pay attentionmainly because she speaks in the brisk cadence of Puerto Rican Spanish.

title: Grim Thoughts From the Gas Line
description: From Page One of The New York Times for Feb. 13: The Gulf Oil Corporation yesterday announced operating results for 1973. The report indicated a 153 per cent gain in fourthquarter earnings ... a fourthquarter profit of $230 million, compared with $91 million in the 1972 quarter.

title: Bridge: Roberts Gains a Rare Double In Greater New York Tourney
description: A rare double was achieved during the weekend at the Greater New York Bridge Association's George Washington Birthday Tournament here at the New York Hilton Hotel. John Roberts won both twosession pair championships, following his victory in the open pairs Saturday with Jacqui Mitchell, by capturing the master pairs Sunday with Matt Granovetter of New York.

title: Rohan to Quit Coaching, Take New Columbia Post
description: Jack Rohan, Columbia University's basketball coach for 13 seasons, will leave that post at the end of the current campaign to become chairman of Columbia's Department of Physical Education.

title: DR. FRANKLYN B. THEIS
description: NYACK, N.Y., Feb. 18 (AP)Dr. Franklyn Babbitt Theis, an eye, ear, nose and throat specialist, died yesterday at his home in South Nyack. He was 69 years old.

title: AN EXPERT HINTS AT TAPE ACCIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18An electronics and counterintelligence expert, in a report that has gone to White House lawers, maintains that the 18minute buzzing on the key Presidential tape recording may have been caused accidentally rather than deliberately.

title: Black Judges Becoming A Force in U.S. Justice
description: DETROIT, Feb. 18  When George Crockett Jr. was a 12yearold boy in Jacksonville, Fla., his mother would send him downtown to pay the rent. If you go by the courthouse, she would tell him, walk on the other side of the street.

title: Saigon Announces New Cabinet, But It Indicates Little Change
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 18South Vietnam announced the formation of a new Cabinet today, saying the aim was to improve the efficiency of the Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu.

title: 2 Famous U.S. Liners Are Sold to Tung Group
description: The American Export Lines passenger ships Constitution and Independence, in layup for the last five years, have been sold to the. C. Y. Tung shipping group. The Tunggroup, based in Hong Kong and Taipei, is a large operator of passenger, dry cargo and tanker tonnage. Its United States services are under the trade name of Orient Overseas Line.

title: U.S. SEEKS CHANGE IN EXPORT TRADE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 The United States will seek urgently to negotiate new international ground rules on the use of export subsidies, a high Treasury official has disclosed.

title: Trenton Prison Is Wracked by Tension
description: TRENTONLieut. Donald Fiscor, one of the senior guards at Trenton State Prison, is worried about the riot withinthe sudden, violent explosion inside a man that transforms him into an animal, venting his frustration and anger in a wild fury.

title: Rate at Central Banks Is $42.22 an Ounce
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 18 (Reuters) Common Market finance ministers tonight took a modest first step towards revaluing gold for official settlements between their central banks.

title: Business Briefs
description: Stein Urges Caution on World Inflation

title: Dave Anderson Three Exhibitions for the Braves
description: In brazen defiance of baseball's integrity, the Atlanta Braves have decreed that they will not fulfill their 162game commitment to the National League schedule this year. Instead, the Braves will play 159 games. The other three, their opening series in Cincinnati, have emerged as exhibitions now that Henry Aaron won't be in the starting lineup.

title: Smoldering Tensions Threaten an Eruption at Trenton Prison
description: TRENTON  Lieut, Donald Fiscor, one of the senior guards at Trenton State Prison, is worried about the riot withinthe sudden, violent explosion inside a man that transforms him into an animal, venting his frustration and anger in a wild fury.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Council, by Vote of 311, Calls Impeachment Trial Only Way to Get at Truth
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 18  The A.F.L.C.I.O. renewed today its call for the impeachment of President Nixon, saying that an impeachment trial was the only way the American people can get at the truth.

title: Israeli Monument Stolen
description: HAIFA, Israel, Feb. 18 (Reuters)Thieves have stolen one of Israel's most revered monuments to her 1948 war dead, the bronze representation of an eternal flame dedicated last year in the center of Haifa. The city engineer told police today that the 110pound bronze casting was stolen last night.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Conservation
description: The recent discovery of a grotto off Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula in which sharks were found sleeping, and the use of color signals and sounds by fiddler crabs are just two of the subjects to be aired at the annual symposium of the American Littoral Society March 2 at Hunter College, 69th Street and Park Avenue, starting at 12:30 P.M.

title: City College Policy Stirs History Department Rift
description: City College's history department has become the scene of an academic battle because of disagreements over the curriculum, college policies under Dr. Robert E. Marshak, the president, and how to teach open admissions students.

title: Black Judges Becoming A Force in U.S. Justice
description: DETROIT, Feb. 18  When George Crockett Jr. was a 12yearold boy in Jacksonville, Fla., his mother would send him downtown to pay the rent. If you go by the courthouse, she would tell him, walk on the other side of the street.

title: CONTRACT AWARD
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, Los Angeles, has awarded a $20million contract to the H. K. Ferguson Company, an engineering and construction concern in Cleveland.

title: Wehling Retains World Nordic Ski Title
description: FALUN, Sweden, Feb. 18 (AP)Ulrich Wehling successfully defended his title in the world Nordic ski championships' combined event today and Galina Kulakova of the Soviet Urtion won her third straight title in the fivekilometer crosscountry race.

title: POWER COST RISE TIED TO OIL FIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Senator Frank Church said today that consumers along the Eastern Seaboard were paying an extra $50million a year for power because a dispute between two American oil companies forced an increase in the prices that public utilities paid for petroleum.

title: Market Place: Wall St. Looks For Gold Lining
description: Few brokers on Wall Street believe it to be paved with gold these drab market days, but gold stocks have rewarded their faithful followers with remarkable gains.

title: Hearst Pledges $2Million In Gesture to Kidnappers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18Randolph A. Hearstsaid today that he was ready to put up $2million for food for the poor just to be able to open negotiations to get back his daughter, Patricia.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: GRAVEN IMAGES There are nearly 100 engravings and prints, including Hogarths and old Punch cartoons and illustrations going back to the seventeenhundreds, now on view at Master Eagle Gallery, 40 West 25th Street (WA 48277). This welllighted, roomy gallery is in an unlikely location, on the sixth floor of a large loft building. Take the elevator, and the switchboard operator will let you in, through an ordinary office, where people are taking orders and so on, and you will find your way to the exhibition hall run by the Master Eagle Family of Companies, which works in type, engraving and lithography.

title: News Summary and Index TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1974
description: International The Foreign Ministers of Egypt and Saudi Arabia gave Secretary of State Kissinger a fournation Arab proposal for disengagement of Israeli and Syrian forces along the Golan Heights. After meeting with Ismail Fahmy of Egypt and Omar Saqqaf of Saudi Arabia, Mr. Kissinger told reporters at the State Department that he hoped the Arab proposal would lead to the opening of formal talks on disengagement in Syria. [1:3.]

title: Bargains in Stores and Subways Draw Crowds Here on Washington's Birthday
description: Washington's Birthday, celebrated yesterday four days before the founding President's real birth date, afforded New Yorkers a chance to travel halffare on subways and buses to jammed department stores offering traditional holiday sales. Mass transit was more crowded than expected.

title: Chinese Lecturer Run Over By an IND Train in Queens
description: A 46yearold Chinese lecturer at Columbia University and former foreign correspondent for the Central News Agency of Nationalist China was run over by an IND train yesterday near the Continental Avenue station in Queens.

title: KISSINGER IS GIVE ARABS' PROPOSAI FOR SYRIAN FROM
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The Foreign Ministers of Egypt and Saudi Arabia today gave Secretary of State Kissinger a fournation Arab proposal for disengagement of Israeli and Syrian forces along the Golan Heights.

title: Michigan Democrat Wins In Voting, for Ford's Seat
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Tuesday, Feb. 19Richard F. VanderVeen, a 51yearold corporation lawyer, yesterday became the first Democrat in 64 years to be elected to Congress from the Fifth District of Michigan.

title: The $1.85anHour Mannequins Breathe, But That's About All
description: For several minutes the woman stared curiously at the mannequin in a burgundy velvet gown. Suddenly the mannequin stepped off the pedestal and walked away.

title: Solzhenitsyn's Trusted Lawyer Fritz Heeb
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 16  Six months ago, the Nobel Prize author Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn intimated to Western correspondents in Moscow that if he died or disappeared, whatever of his works that remained unpublished were already in safe hands and would appear outside the Soviet Union.

title: HealthViolations Are Charged Here To 22 Food Outlets
description: The Health Services Administration announced yesterday the names of 22 restaurants and food stores that had violated the health code.

title: NIXON AIDES PUSH HOUSING MEASURE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Amid charges that the Nixon Administration has no housing policy, Administration officials took part last week for the first time in talks aimed at reaching a compromise with Congress on housing legislation.

title: Nixon Assails Distorted View That America Is Sick
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Feb. 18President Nixon, sharing a platform with Gov. George C. Wallace at an Honor America Day rally, told a predominantly friendly crowd of more than 20,000 today that partisanship and distorted reporting in Washington had made it appear that the nation is sick.

title: Paris Accords Exalted In Area Held by Vietcong
description: TUONG SON, South Vietnam The Vietcong military chief of Hoai Nhon District had just completed a threeandahalfhour discourse on the recent and notsorecent history of one corner of Binh Dinh Province.

title: State Faces 33% Cut in Freight Trackage
description: In the midst of the energy shortage, New York State faces the possible loss by abandonment of up to 1,875 miles of rail freight routes, one third of the state's total.

title: British Vote: Why the Leaders Worry
description: LONDON, Feb. 18  Prime Minister Heath moved through Scotland today, campaigning in shopping centers, visiting a club for the elderly and speaking at a rally in Edinburgh. Harold Wilson, his. Labor party challenger, went campaigning in Kent, south of London. In their public statements, they both displayed the expected confidence of victory in this election campaign. But, with 10 days to go before the British vote, neither would appear to have much reason to be overwhelmed by optimism.

title: Oil Leak on Mississippi
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 18 (UPI)A 500foot ship pulled by tugs punctured a crude oil barge today on the Mississippi River, releasing a stream of the oil into the water.

title: Met Mile Captured By Colon
description: PRINCETON,. N.J., Feb. 18  Tony Colon should have been happy today; he won the mile for the second straight year, and Manhattan began its bid foranother indoor grand slam by taking its fourth consecutive Metropolitan intercollegiate track and field title.

title: Hopman High on U. S. Juniors
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Feb. 18The country's biggest indoor junior tennis tournament, with 575 freeswinging boys and girls seeking trophies, ended today and Harry Hopman, the referee, was astounded as well as fatigued.

title: O'Hagan Calls Women Fit for Fire Fighting but Has Qualms
description: Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan says that he sees no physical or mental impediment to a woman being a fire fighter but that he thinks it would be disruptive to the lifestyle that we have in the firehouse.

title: A Room for Children: It Can Cost $207Or It Can Cost $3,200
description: Osgood Perkins was six days old when he was moved earlier this month into his freshly equipped home nursery, a sunwashed room at the top of his parents' red brick house in the Chelsea section.

title: WESTCHESTER PUTS SALE OF GASOLINE UNDER CONTROLS
description: The Westchester County Legislature, meeting on the Washington's Birthday holiday while myriad motorists in the tristate area sought gasoline, voted overwhelmingly yesterday to institute a mandatory oddeven system of gasoline allocation.

title: H.I.P.'s First Ombudsman Picked Secretly by Board
description: The board of directors of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York was disclosed yesterday to have selected secretly its first ombudsman at a meeting Jan. 8more than three weeks before a City Hall news conference at which it was announced that there would be such an ombudsman.

title: Professors Ousted By Lutheran Board In Seminary Dispute
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 18Fortyeight boycotting professors and executive staff members at Concordia Seminary were dismissed today after they ignored an ultimatum to return to their teaching duties.

title: ECOLOGICAL SUITS REPORTED EASED
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18A decade ago, conservationists campaigning against the proposed Storm King power plant on the Hudson River had to struggle to get recognition in Federal Court.

title: LOBBY ORGANIZED BY POOR PEOPLE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 18Representatives of 200 black and Puerto Rican organizations from across the state announced to day the formation of a poor peoples' lobby to press for increased aid to poor communities.

title: Budgetary Shell Game
description: Controller Goldin's charge that New York City's bonding capacity has been seriously and dangerously over committed probably overstates the problem. Nevertheless, his critique of the new executive capital budget does sound a needed warning that the city faces severe restraints on its ability to move ahead with new projects unless it also moves ahead on some overdue fiscal reforms.

title: Veterans Continue Protest
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 18 (AP)  Eleven disabled veterans protesting conditions at Veterans Administration hospitals continued a sitin and hunger strike at the office of Senator Alan Cranston today. The veterans have occupied the offices of the California Democrat for a week.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 35
