description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The Foreign Ministers of Egypt and Saudi Arabia today gave Secretary of State Kissinger a fournation Arab proposal for disengagement of Israeli and Syrian forces along the Golan Heights.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 35

title: U.S. Energy Aide Finds Persuasive Approach Failing
description: Gerald J. Turetsky, the regional administrator here of the Federal Energy Office, says he likes to use persuasion rather. than commands to get Oil companies to shift fuel to where it is needed, but his technique is facing increasing criticism as the fuel falls to show up.

title: His Record Mile Run Surprises Waldrop
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 18 (AP) Tony Waldrop, professing that he is tired of running all these subfour minutes, is the new fastest indoor miler. But he's unimpressed.

title: ASH URGES LIMITS ON FUEL DEMANDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) If motorists want to see those long lines at filling stations disappear this year, they will have to keep limiting their demand for fuel and not backslide, Roy Ash, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said today.

title: Basketball Ratings WRITERS' POLL
description: The top 20 major college teams. Points figured lated on a 201816141210987654321 basis (firstplace votes in parentheses), wonlost records through last Saturday and total points.

title: FEDERALIST COPIES ESCAPED FL00DING
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., Feb. 18 A rare twovolume first edition of the Federalist Papers, which was found here recently, narrowly escaped the flood by the tropical storm Agnes in the summer of 1972.

title: Leader of Peronist Right Wing Killed by Bomb in His Briefcase
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 18A leading figure of the Peronist right wing died this morning when a bomb exploded in his briefcase.

title: Taiwan Sets a 50%, Cut In Import Taxes for Year
description: TAIPEI, Feb. 18 (AP)Taiwan has decided to cut by onehalf for a year the import taxes on 19 industrial items.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The board of directors of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York was disclosed to have named secretly its first ombudsman at a meeting Jan. 8, more than three weeks before a City Hall news conference at which it was announced that there would be such an ombudsman.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: DR. BURTON P. M'HUGH
description: Dr. Burton P. McHugh, an internist at St. Luke's Hospital and at the Isabella Geriatric Home, died in his sleep on Sunday at the home of his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Glenn McHugh, 101 Moulder Trail, Bronxvige, N. Y. He was 41 years old and lived at 103 East 84th Street and in Skytop, Pa.

title: Foreign Oil Companies Find Libya Is Toughest Producer to Do Business With
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Feb. 15Libya, the onetime Cinderella land for Western oil companies, has turned into the toughest country with which to do business on the international oil scene.

title: POWER COST RISE TIED TO OIL FIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Senator Frank Church said today that consumers along the Eastern Seaboard were paying an extra $50million a year for power because a dispute between two American oil companies forced an increase in the prices that public utilities paid for petroleum.

title: Retailer's Critical Speech Stirs Big Mail Response
description: Stanley J. Goodman, chairman of the May Department Stores Co., St. Louis, is still digging out from under an avalanche of mail.

title: Sandman and His Party To Vie at FundRaising
description: TRENTON, Feb. 18Vice President Ford has accepted an invitation by New Jersey Republicans to appear at a fundraising cocktail party for the Republican state finance committee on March 23, the same day Mr. Ford is scheduled to attend a fundraising dinner in behalf of Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., the unsuccessful Republican candidate for Governor last year.

title: John R. Henry Dies at 60; ExOfficer at American Can
description: John R. Henry, who retired in 1971 as vice president and secretary of the American Can Company, died of a heart attack on Sunday at his home, 51 Grace Street, Rye N. Y. He was 60 years old.

title: POLICE EXONERATE OFFICER IN KILLINGS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 18 (UPI)No action will be taken against a police officers who killed a wouldbe burglar yesterday, and who also killed a youth after a highspeed chase, it was announced today.

title: City College Policy Stirs History Department Rift
description: City College's history department has become the scene of an academic battle because of disagreements over the curriculum, college policies under Dr. Robert Marshak, the presirent, and how to teach open admissions students.

title: LongTerm Credit Rates Likely to Move Upward
description: If the results of last week's major new bond sales are a guide, longterm interest rates likely will move upward this week.

title: Stars Win by 121110 For 14th Straight
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 18 (AP)The Utah Stars picked up their 14th straight American Basketball Association victory tonight, a 121110 conquest of the Carolina Cougars.

title: Stage: Vintage Musical
description: Although it is obvious that Off Broadway is enjoying its most productive season in some years, we still needed a good, vintage OffBroadway musical. We got it last night at the McAlpin Rooftop Theater. It is called Fashion, and it is original, impudent and campy in the tradition, but certainly not the style, of Little Mary Sunshine and Dames at Sea. It is a chamberensemble musical of beguiling charm.

title: Knights Top Cougars, 43
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., Feb. 18 (AP)  Gene Peacosh's second goal of the game midway in the third period carried the Jersey Knights to 43 World Hockey Association victory over the Chicago Cougars tonight.

title: COX HAS MISGIVINGS ON MEDIA COVERAGE
description: CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 18 (UPI)Archibald Cox, the former Watergate special prosecutor, said today that part of the press regarded itself as the fourth branch of government and that he had quite a few misgivings about the way the media covered Watergate.

title: Bronx Infant Found Dead In Hot Tub
description: A 10monthold boy was found dead by the police yesterday in a tub of hot water with his 3yearold sister, who was badly scalded, in an apartment in the High Bridge section of the Bronx. The police were responding to a report that a woman had plunged from a window on the fourth floor of the building, at 1008 Summit Avenue.

title: MILK LEADER DENIES FUND WAS FOR NIXON
description: REEDSVILLE, Wis., Feb. 18 (UPI) A $200,000 contribution by Associated Milk Producers Inc. that wound up in President Nixon's reelection fund was intended for Republican Congressmen, the organization's president John Butterbrodt, said yesterday.

title: 10 Collegians in Sulkies to Give Roosevelt Academic Air Friday
description: It was all out for the Collegiate Driving Championship at the Playboy Club yesterday.

title: Paper Says Agnew's Golfing Cost Taxpayers $250,000
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 18 (AP) Spiro T. Agnew spent at least 8250,000 of taxpayers' money to finance his golfing vacations while he was Vice President, The Baltimore Sun said today.

title: WESTCHESTER PUTS SALE OF GASOLINE UNDER CONTROLS
description: The Westchester County Legislature, meeting on the Washington's Birthday holiday while myriad motorists in the tristate area sought gasoline, voted overwhelmingly yesterday to institute a mandatory oddeven system of gasoline allocation.

title: SPRUCE FALLS FILES DEBENTURE OFFERING
description: A final prospectus concerning a $30million offering of 9 per cent sinking fund debentures has been filed with securities commissions in all provinces of Canada by the Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company, Ltd., the company announced yesterday.

title: Italy Asking I.M.F. For a Credit Line Of Billion S.D.R.'s
description: ROME, Feb. 18 (Reuters)The Bank of Italy today confirmed Washington reports that Italy was seeking a standby credit line of one billion Special Drawing Rights, equivalent to $1.2billion, from the International Monetary Fund.

title: THREE FOUND DEAD IN 186TH ST. FIRE
description: A woman and her two children were found dead yesterday in an apartment building damaged Sunday by flames that apparently erupted when a resident tried to repair al gasoline tank in an apartment. They had been reported missing Sunday.

title: Hearst Pledges $2Million In Gesture to Kidnappers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18Randolph A. Hearst said today that he was ready to put up $2million for food for the poor just to be able to open negotiations to get back his daughter, Patricia.

title: Whirlpool Raises Its Earnings 22%; Otis Also Gains
description: The Whirlpool Corporation, the Benton Harbor, Mich., appliance manufacturer, increased its fourthquarter earnings 22.4 per cent over the same period in 1972.

title: Bereavement and a Pilgrimage
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y.When my oldest son, Mike, was killed In Vietnam nearly six years ago I never thought I would visit the nowbleak coastal plains between Quang Ngai and My Lai where he died. Last month I did.

title: Upsets Stir U.S. Tennis First Round
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 18 (AP)Karl Meiler and Erik van Dillen, both seeded players, were upset in firstround action today in the National indoor open tennis championships.

title: Coach Says Brawl Inspired Flyers and Helped Them Tie Game
description: In the aftermath of that benchemptying freeforall between the Philadelphia Flyers and the Montreal Canadiens on Sunday in Montreal, which resulted in 91 minutes of penalties, there are differences of opinion as to who won the various matchups. But everyone agrees the Pier 6 brawl helped the Flyers, who are nicknamed, for good reason, the Broad Street Bullies. They came back with two unassisted goals by Gary Dornhoefer and Ron Lonsberry to make up a twogoal deficit in the third period and tie the game at 22.

title: Conflicts of Interest Are Allegedin Pan Ocean Oil
description: A 25yearold unemployed Brooklyn securities analyst who reads annual reports backwards from the footnotes uphas turned up conflicts of interest involving Dan W. Lufkin, once a top Wall Street official who may run for Governor of Connecticut, and Louis Marx Jr., a (longtime business associate who is the son of the founder of Louis Marx & Co., the toy maker.

title: Impact of Kennedy Library On Environment Considered
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 18 (AP)A Rhode Island consulting concern has been awarded a Federal contract to make an environmental Impact study on the proposed John F. Kennedy Memorial Library.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Mississippi Bank Bolstered
description: GREENVILLE, Miss., Feb. 18 (UPI) Grumbling Mississippi River banks at Warfield Point south of here were bolstered today by the Army Corps of Engineers. John Anderson, a corps spokesman, said that the condition of the banks posed a potential threat to both the mainland levee and the Greenville Lake Village bridge, although no immediate danger was foreseen.

title: March on Leavenworth
description: LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Fob. 18 (UPI) About 135 demonstrators, urged on by the Rev. Phillip F. Berrigan, marched on the United States penitentiary today and presented Federal officials a list of complaints abotit prison conditions, Father Berrigan, Who has Served, time in prison for destroying draft records, was under an order from his parole board not to participate in the march. So he spoke in a city Park where demonstrators gathered before going to the penitentiary.

title: Miss Holder Wed to John C. Straton Jr.
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18Miss Marion Speakman Holder, a teacher at the Spence School in New York, was married here this afternoon to John Charles Straton Jr., a first vice president of Jas. H. Oliphant & Co., New York stockbrokers. The Rev. Samuel M. Lindsay, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Royal Poinciana Chapel.

title: Rome: AvantGarde Parks in Garage
description: ROME  Avantgarde art has literally gone underground  to be specific, to Level B of a new parking garage below the Villa Borghese gardens. Five acres of the huge subterranean structure the entire facility covers an area three times that of St. Peter's Squarehave been set aside for a threemonth exhibition of visual arts with farout theater and films, leftist opinion and some freewheeling panel debates on the side.

title: Heroic Biography of Mahler Labor of Love for French Baron
description: If the parents of Baron HenriLouis de La Grange had prevailed, he would have entered the family furniture business. Instead, the FrenchAmerican scholar finds himself at age 49 a sudden celebrity in the musical world, the author of a longneeded, heroically exhaustive and widely praised biography of Gustav Mahler. How did it happen, this rich boy's Papillonlike escape from an upperclass mercantile trap into the heady realms of music and literature?

title: The British Election and Beyond
description: Enoch Powell, the Tory rebel who has quit Parliament in disgust with his own Government's policies, exaggerates as usual in branding next week's British election a fraud. But it will be Britain's most divisive election in 43 years and it is unlikely to resolve the problem that precipitated it.

description: THE FLOWERING OF AMERICAN FOLK ART, 17761876, By Jean Lipman and Alice Winchester. 288 pages. Illustrated. Viking Press, in cooperation with the Whitney Museum of American Art. $19.95 cloth, $10 paperback.

title: Advertising: Chicken Challenge
description: There's no doubt about it, in the last couple of years Frank Perdue has established himself in these here parts as a multi  media, super chicken salesman. And he's practically had the field to himself as the tough man who makes tender chickens.

title: Exile Is Feared as Next Step For the Soviet Dancer Panov
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 18 (Reuters) Soviet officials threatened today to take tough measures against the ballet dancer Valery Panov unless he left the country immediately without his wife, Galina, she said tonight.

title: Belfast Policemen Refusing to Escort Prisoners to Trials
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 18The police refused to escort prisoners from their cells to their trials here today, throwing court schedules into chaos.

title: $152 an Ounce Touched in Trading in London
description: LONDON, Feb. 18  The price of gold climbed to another record On the London bullion market today amid continuing speculation on a revaluation of the precious metals for monetary purposes.

title: U.S. Drug Center Shifts
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 18 (UPI)The clinical research center here, the only Federal drug addiction center in operation for the last two years, will become a Federal correctional institution tomorrow in a move that has been several months in the making.

title: Ford Urges U.S. Engineers To Meet Energy Challenge
description: CHATTANOOGA, Feb. 18 (AP)Vice President Ford urged American engineers today to develop new ingenuity to solve the energy shortage.

title: 14,325 From New England Moved to Canada Since '66
description: BOSTON, Feb, 18 (AP) Statistics show that at least 14,325 New Englanders have emigrated to Canada since 1966, first because of the Vietnam War and now because of Watergate, according to the Canadian consul here.

description: VENEZUELA TO BUILD COSTA RICA OIL UNIT

title: WHITWORTH SMITH
description: Whitworth M. Smith, Eastern operating vice president of the Railway Express Agency from 1948 to his retirement in 1956, died Saturday at his home, 1360 Midland Avenue, Bronxville, N. Y. He was 81 years old.

title: Chavez Calls 2Day Strike; His Men Clash With Police
description: CALEXICO, Calif., Feb. 18 (AP)  Cesar Chavez today called a twoday strike against Imperial County lettube growers holding contracts with the teamsters union.

title: People in Spoils: Denis Menke, Itinerant, Back With Astros
description: The Houston Astros yesterday got back Denis Menke, the infielder they had traded to the Cincinnati Reds in 1971. Cincinnati, active in the trading market during the offseason, sent Menke to the Astros for Pat Darcy, a 23yearold righthander and a player to be named. Menke, 33, who made the National League AllStar team in 1969 as a Shortstop and the following season as a second baseman batted .191 last season. Before joining the Astros for the first time in 1968, he played with the Braves in Milwaukee and Atlanta.

title: Accord on Rupee Funds Signed by U.S. and India
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 18India and the United States signed today an agreement for the disposal of rupee funds accumulated by the United States through the sale of foods here. The funds had long been a source of contention between the two Governments.

title: Michigan Democrat Wins In Voting for Ford's Seat
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 18Richard F. VanderVeen tonight became the first Democrat in 64 years to be elected from the Fifth Congressional District in Michigan. He won the House seat vacated last year by Vice President Ford.

title: HELICOPTER PILOT SENT TO HOSPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) The Army private who flew stolen helicopter onto the White House lawn yesterday was sent to the Walter Reed Army Hospital's psychiatric center today after Federal, charges against him were dropped.

title: POLICEMAN SEIZED IN THEFT AT STORE
description: A police officer and another man were arrested yesterday afternoon for allegedly shoplifting two records and two tapes from the music department of the Abraham & Straus Department Store, at 9010 Queens Boulevard in the Elmhurst Section of Queens.

title: Cambodian Rebels Blow Up Barge Bound for the Capital
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 18 (AP)Insurgents attacked a 10vessel convoy on its way up the Mekong River to Phnom Penh, blew up an ammunition barge, and killed one seaman and wounded four others, port authorities here said today.

title: Sandman and G.O.P. to Vie At FundRaisings by Ford
description: TRENTON, Feb. 18  Vice President Ford has accepted an invitation by New Jersey Republicans to appear at a fundraising cocktail party for the Republican state finance committee on March 23, the same day that Mr. Ford is scheduled to attend a fundraising dinner in behall of Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., the unsuccessful Republican candidate for Governor last year.

title: SAIGON SAID TO LAND ON 5TH SPRATLY ISLE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 18 (AP)  South Vietnamese forces have occupied a fifth island in the disputed Spratly archipelago in the South China Sea without opposition, informed sources said today.

title: Oregon and Washington Accord Keeps Gas Stations Operating
description: Service stations in Oregon and Washington have ended a threat to close down following tentative approval by regional energy officials of a plan allowing the stations to give preferential treatment to regular customers.

title: Reed Hopes to Rejoin Knicks In Time for N.B.A. Playoffs
description: It looks like I won't be back with the team on March 1, but I'm still hopeful of being ready for the playoffs, said. Willis Reed of the Knicks yesterday. The center and captain underwent surgery for a torn cartilage in his right knee on Dec. 12 and had hoped to return to action during the first week of March.

title: W.F.L. Shifts Franchise to Houston
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (UPI)The transfer of the Memphis franchise to Houston and an exchange of player rights of the New York and Boston franchises were approved by the World Football League today at the second meeting of its board of governors.

title: Notre Dame Five Makes Western Mich. 21 st Victim
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 18 (UPI)Adrian Dantley, a forward, and Gary Brokaw, a guard, teamed to score 15 points in a secondhalf spurt that lifted secondranked Notre Dame from a 3737 halftime tie to an 8568 victory over Western Michigan tonight. The triumph was the 21st for the Irish against one loss.

title: TV RATINGS SEEN NEGLECTING POOR
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb 18A San Francisco television station operator charged today that the rating services do not the rating services do not properly measure the viewing of lower socioeconomic groups and that programs of special interest to ethnic minorities therefore usually fail to meet the commercial criteria that would encourage stations to present more of them.

title: Chess: Grabbed Pawns Line Roads To Both Victory and Defeat
description: To take or not to takethat is the question when there is a loose pawn in the offing Forever shrinking from pawn grabbing means missing some golden opportunities, for the lowly unit garnered is notorious for producing winning end games. On the other hand, pawn snatching at every chance is guaranteed to produce some burnt fingers.

title: Gasoline Sellers Get Premiums Now
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 18 Money, whisky, tobacco and even sex are being offered to gasoline dealers here in exchange for a full tank or some other special treatment at the pumps, but most dealers say they will accept tips only after a legitimate sale is made.

title: Mr. Hbert Sees Crimson
description: Representative F. Edward Hebert has long equated his chairmanship of the House Armed Services Committee with the right to function as a permanent SuperSecretary of Defense. It is therefore not surprising that the Pentagon surrendered when the chairman demanded that the Harvard Graduate School of Businees be declared offlimits to officers in pursuit of advanced management training.

title: ANITA BUSH, FOUNDED BLACK STAGE TROUPE
description: Anita Bush, who as founder of the Anita Bush Stock Company in Harlem in 1915 was a pioneer in the development of the black theater, died Saturday at her home, 385 East 143d Street.

title: Dog Mushing Champion
description: ANCHORAGE; Alaska, Feb. 18 (AP)  Dr. Roland Lombard of Wayland, Mass., has won the Anchorage Fur Rendezvous] World Championship dog mushing crown for the eighth time.

title: Canadian Network Faulted at Hearing For Americanization of Its Airwaves
description: OTTAWA, Feb: 18  The stateowned Canadian Broadcasting Corporation came under public scrutiny today with the opening of a farranging Government hearing on the question of how well its radio and television networks were doing their job.

title: Wild Whoopers Decline to 48
description: AUSTWELL, Tex., Feb. 18 (UPI)Frank Johnson, manager of the Arkansas National Wildlife Refuge, said today that the world's wild whooping crane population had dropped to 48the lowest since 1967but that there was no call for alarm. There is a normal fluctuation in the population of any bird, Mr. Johnson said. In 1938 we had 15, and in 1951 there were only 15.

title: Townships Seeking Status To Qualify for U.S. Funds
description: CHERRY HILL, Feb. 18 Officials of townships in three southwestern New Jersey counties are seeking recognition by the United States Census Bureau so that they may be eligible for Federal funds.

title: Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Portland Trail Blazers, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M.(TelevisionChannel 10 (cable), 7:30 Y.M.) (RadioWNBC, 7:25 P.M.)

title: Consumer Panel Will Open Hearings on Safety of Aerosol Sprays
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 From roach poisons to deodorants to cheese spreads, more than 300 products are available in the form of aerosol sprays, About three billion cans were produced last year.

title: Music Group Finds Fame a Flat Note
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Feb 18The New Rochelle High School Symphonic Wind Ensemble and Chorale has been acclaimed as one of the six best high school music groups in the country. But in its own community it has, so far at least, gone largely unsung.

title: Notes on People
description: The Federal prosecutor who spearheaded the investigation of political corruption that led to Spiro T. Agnew's downfall, George Beall, plans to resign when his fouryear term as United States Attorney for Maryland expires in August. I've never viewed this job as a permanent one, said Mr. Beall. I think it's good to step aside after a while and give someone else a crack at it.

title: DIVIDEND MEETINGS TODAY
description: Brunswick Coro

title: Brown U. Trustees Vote To End Student Expansion
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 18 (AP)The Brown University board of trustees has voted to end student expansion and limit the school's enrollment to the current total of 5,150.

title: Placing Last on Skis Isn't Easy
description: BRAITLEBORO, Vt., Feb. 18Ron Irving, a 21yearold graduate student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, trailed all 549 of his rivals in the annual Washington's Birthday ski touring event today and was happy.

title: 27,000 CAR WORKERS ON A WEEK LAYOFF
description: DETROIT, Feb. 18 (UPI)More than 27,000 auto workers in the United States began a oneweek layoff today as industry executives predicted fewer shutdowns by midMarch if gasolineshortage problems do not worsen.

title: First Auditions, and Then Acting Class
description: The room was filled with aspiring actors from such plates as Cleveland, Washington, Baltimore and small New England towns. I have butterflies in my stomach. feel like I'm on a roller coaster, said one of them, Sue Chappell, an 18yearold from Connecticut.

title: 2 HELD IN RAMPAGE AT FASTFOOD SITE
description: Two teenaged youths were arraigned in Queens Criminal Court yesterday on charges of having participated in the Friday night rampage by 200 gang members at a fastfood restaurant in St. Albans.

title: Taft, Haaren Fives Gain in Tourney
description: Taft and Haaren High Schools advanced yesterday to the quarterfinals of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball playoffs. Taft, 8660 victor over Curtis, will meet Haaren, which beat Franklin D. Roosevelt, 6355, on Saturday at New York Community College in Brooklyn.

title: Maoist Currents Stir Revolt in Sulu Sea Islands
description: ZAMBOANGA, the Philip. pines, Feb. 17In this sunny southern city with its Hispanic verandas and palmlined plazas, everyone has been talking about Maoists since the violent clashes last week on the nearby island of Jolo.

title: Ralph Waldo Gerard Dies at 73; Tied Schizophrenia to Chemistry
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Feb. 18 (UPI)  Ralph Waldo Gerard, professor emeritus of biology at the University of California at Irvine, died yesterday, of complications after heart surgery at Hoag Memorial Hospital. His age was 73.

title: Trial of Mitchell and Stans Starts Here Today
description: Jury selection begins today in the trial of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans.

title: Gen. Manuel Odria, 77, Dies; President of Peru in 194856
description: LIMA, Peru, Feb, 18 (AP)Gen; Manuel A. Odria, President of Peru from 1948 to 1956, died today of a years heart ailment, He was 77 years old.

title: Class Will Tell
description: The resurgent Chinese Cultural Revolution, whose main target is Confucianism, has raised a cloud of speculation about Its political significance. Yet it is not difficult to discern why Maoism is antiConfucianist: Maoist thought stresses social contradictions as a motive force in a continuing revolution; Confucianism emphasized the attainment of order and harmony. Maoism stresses the primacy of the workerpeasant; Confucianism looked to an educated gentry for leadership.

title: AN EXPERT HINTS AT TAPE ACCIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18An electronics and counterintelligence expert, in a report that has gone to White House lawyers, maintains that the 18minute buzzing on the key Presidential tape recording may have been caused accidentally rather than deliberately.

title: Artists' Library of Visual Resources Opened in SoHo Storefront Center
description: A new kind of library, for the use of artists only, has opened in SoHo, the artists' community downtown. Known as the SoHo Center for Visual Artists, its storefront facility at 110 Prince Street houses books, magazines, folios, catalogues and unlike the usual art research library  a wealth of visual materials ranging from posters to samples of paper used in Japanese kites.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: When Iselin High School won its first baseketball game for Ray Neuman five years ago, the team's reaction, as the coach recalls it, was somewhat like winning the seventh game of a World Series.

title: Many Police Commanders Quit in Chicago, ShakeUp
description: CHICAGO, Feb, 18 (AP)Police Superintendent James M. Rochford said today that about half of his top 70 officers had submitted resignations that he had requested.

title: Ahumada Scores Knockout in 5th
description: Jorge Ahumada, relying on every punch in his fistic arsenal, stopped Vern McIntosh at 1 minute 11 seconds of the fifth round in their scheduled 10round lightheavyweight bout last night at the Felt Forum.

title: ARABS COME EARLY TO ISLAMIC PARLEY
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, Feb. 18Arab leaders began converging on this ancient Punjabi city today in advance of an Islamic leaders conference that is set to deal with the Middle East and oil prices.

title: Chess:
description: To take or not to takethat is the question when there is a loose pawn in the offing, Forever shrinking from pawn grabbing means missing some golden opportunities, for the lowly unit garnered is notorious for producing winning end games. On the other hand, pawn snatching at every chance is guaranteed to produce some burnt fingers.

title: 7 RELATIVES SLAIN BY MAN CITING LORD
description: FAYETTE, Miss., Feb. 18 (AP) A construction worker fatally shot his wife and six other relatives today, telling the authorities that he thought he was doing the Lord's bidding, the police said. An eighth relative of the man was critically wounded.

title: MICHAEL AMRPIE, SCIENCE WRITER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18Michael Amrine, noted science writer and public relations counsel to many scientific organizations, died yesterday of lymphoma at the, Clinical Center of the National Institutes of Health. He was 55 years old.

title: Bridge: Roberts Gains a Rare Double In Greater New York Tourney
description: A rare double was achieved during the weekend at the Greater New York Bridge Association's George Washington Birthday Tournament here at the New York Hilton Hotel. John Roberts won both twosession pair championships, following his victory in the open pairs Saturday with Jacqui Mitchell, by capturing the master pairs Sunday with Matt Granovetter of: New York.

title: ROCK CONCERT GIVEN BY ELLIOTT MURPHY
description: Rock concerts are often more interesting extramusically than musically, but the concert Friday evening at the Academy of Music by Elliott Murphy and the New York Dolls pushed that proposition to unnecessary extremes.

title: F.T.C. to Study Drug Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 18 (AP) In a move to determine if the Federal Trade Commission can help consumers save money, the agency is instituting a study of the prices of prescription drugs.

title: John Duffy, Retired Official Of Lehigh Valley, Dies at 91
description: John Duffy, retired vice pres ident of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, died Sunday in a nursing home in Haverford, Pa. He was 91 years old and lived in Point Pleasant Beach, N. J.

title: Music: Arrau's NoNonsense Pianism
description: Claudio Arrau's admirers in this country, while numerous, have never approached their counterparts in England in sheer reverence. Over there, the Chilean artist has largely inherited the unchallengeable status held in the last generation by the uninominal pianist Solomon, if not quite that of Artur Schnabel.

title: Boyle Case Starting
description: MEDIA, Pa., Feb. 18 (UPI)Arguments on pretrial motions Will be heard in Delaware County Court tomorrow in the case of W. A. Boyle, former United Mine Workers president, who is charged in the slayings of a union reform leader, Joseph A. Yablonski, his wife and daughter.

title: Jackson Sees Overriding Of a Veto on Energy Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18Senator Henry. M. Jackson expressed confidence today that the Senate could override a veto of the emergency energy bill, which contains a rollback in crude oil prices, even though he predicted a razorthin margin in a vote scheduled tomorrow.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP)The World Hockey Association's board of trustees approved a settlement agreement today with the National Hockey League aimed at ending a $50million court fight between the leagues.

title: Jewish unit Asks Tax Reforms To Curb Oil Companies' Profits
TEANECK VOTE DUE ON HIGHRISE PLAN
description: TEANECK, Feb. 18  A longsimmering controversy ove plans to construct a highrise office and apartment complex here is expected to take its most significant turn tomorrow night when the Township Council here votes on whether to accept the Teaneck Redevelopment Agency's proposal and make necessary zoning change to accommodate the project.

title: Solzhenitsyn, Still Defiant, Eager to Get on With Work
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 18 (AP)Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn vowed today to continue his work in exile and said he had as much right to live on Russian soil as those who had the audacity to physically throw me out.

title: Pawns and Ploys
description: Syria is acting against its own best interests, as well as in utter disregard of accepted practice among civilized states, in its savage treatment of Israeli prisoners of war as mere bargaining chipsrefusing even to release their names and numbers as a minimal act of ordinary humanity.

title: Brentwood Puerto Ricans Proudly Maintain Heritage
description: BRENTWOOD, L. I., Feb. 18When Cathy Rosario speaks, her firstgraders pay attentionmainly because she speaks in the brisk cadence of Puerto Rican Spanish.

title: Herbert J. Brown, 56, Dies; Lawyer and Aide to P.S.C.
description: Herbert J. Brown, a lawyer and special assistant to the New York State Public Service Commission, died Saturday in Bellevue Medical Center after having suffered a heart attack at his home, 200 East 27th Street. He was 56 years old.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Over the years we have railed against ball park mustard for fine cookery and rallied for imported mustard, preferably Dijon or Dusseldorf.

title: Soviet Plans Missile Tests In Pacific for Next 3 Weeks
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 18 (Reiiters) The Soviet Union announced today that it will launch rockets from its, territory to a point about 2,000 miles east of Tokyo during the next three weeks.

title: Nixon Assails Distorted View That America Is Sick
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Peb. 18President Nixon, sharing a platform with Gov. George C. Wallace at an Honor America Day rally, told a predominantly friendly crowd of more than 20,000 today that partisanship and distorted reporting in Washington had made it appear that the nation is sick.

title: Polaroid Turned a Profit on SX70 Last Month
description: The Polaroid Corporation, which has put $350million into the research and development of the SX70 compact camera in the last six years, has finally crossed the breakeven point on it, with the camera and film realizing a profit last month, the 1973 annual report disclosed yesterday.

title: BYRNE IS RECIPIENT OF BRANDEIS AWARD
description: The selection of Governor Byrne of New Jersey as the 1974 recipient of the Justice Louis D. Brandeis Humanitarian Award was announced yesterday by Mrs. Bea Lerner, New Jersey regional president of the Zionist Organization of America.

title: Advertising: Sharing the Basics
description: All right, let's get down to the basics  how will this weird economy affect those precious agencyclient relationships? Will troubles shared bring the two even closer together? Or will the worries and uncertainties create abrasions that drive them from one another's bosoms?

title: GoldFever Epidemic
description: The price of gold got up to $152 an ounce in London Monday. The gold fever is now feeding on every morsel of news that comes its waythe decision of Common Market finance ministers to study ways of raising the official gold price of $42.22, rumors that United States resistance to an increase in the official gold price has weakened and fresh forecasts by gold bugs that the price will climb to astronomical levels.

title: Anker Fights Cut in Aid to Handicapped
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker said yesterday that the possible curtailment by the state of present tuition grants to children with mental, physical and emotional handicaps would pose a serious burden to the city school system as well as to the parents of these youngsters.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The Securities and Exchange Commission is drafting legisltion creating a municipal securities rulemaking board to publish regulations governing brokerdealer transactions in such securities either by banks or nonbanking agencies.

title: Improving InterAmerican Ties
description: PRINCETON, N. J.As Secretary of State Kissinger flies to Mexico to meet with the foreign ministers of the other American nations, he would do well to reflect on how much interAmerican relations have changed since 1960.

title: SQUIRES JURORS HEAR CHASE TAPE
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 19 Recordings of state police conversations between a headquarters dispatcher on the New Jersey Turnpike and troopers' cars patrolling the turnpike during a shootout last May 2 were played for the jury, here today in the murder trial of Clark E. Squire, a 36yearold alleged member of the Black Liberation Army.

title: 12 INDICTED IN JAPAN FOR OIL PRICE FIXING
description: TOKYO, Feb. 19 (AP)Twelvel Japanese refining companies are suspected of fixing prices and causing a nearly 100 per cent increase in the cost of wholesale gasoline, Japan's Fair Trade Commission said today, disclosing the filing of indictment papers.

title: Dayan Demands Coalition With Rightist Opposition
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 19Defense Minister Moshe Dayan served notice today that he would refuse to join Israel's next. Cabinet unless Premier Golda Meir's party agreed to share power with the rightwing opposition.

title: Drug Laws Called Lacking As Treatment Inducement
description: ALBANY, Feb. 19 The state's strongest new drug laws, contrary to expectations have not increased the number of addicts who voluntarily seek treatment in ??tate rehabilitation programs, the chairman of the Drug Abuse Control Commission told a legislative hearing here today.

title: WILSON ANSWERS JOBLOSS CRITICS
description: ALBANY, Feb. 19In his first riposte at Democratic governorship candidates, Governor Wilson tonight defended the state administration against critics who distort New York's employment figures.

title: Jumbo Jets Roost in Energy Shortage
description: ROSWELL, N. M., Feb. 19  Tumbleweeds brush by them, racing toward Texas. Dust and sand bite into their onceshiny hulks. Jackrabbits sniff their tires.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Mary Lecomte du Nouy, 83, Widow of French Scientist
description: Mrs. Mary Harriman Lecomte du Noy, widow of Pierre Le Comte du Noy, the French scientist long associated with the Rockefeller Institute here and the Pasteur Institute in Paris, died yesterday in Paris. She was 83 years old.

title: In Golan, Intensity of Shelling Seems Guide to State of Arab Affairs
description: MAZRAAT BEIT JINN, IsraeliOccupied Syria, Feb. 19The Israeli soldiers who man the positions near this shellshattered village overlooking the ceasefire line with Syria watch the news each evening on Damascus television. But they say they have a quicker, more reliable guide to events in the Arab world.

title: New Allocation of Gasoline Eases Westchester Waits
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 19Westchester County's mandatory oddeven system of gasoline allocation went into effect today, easing the problems a little at the stations that had gasoline to sell.

title: A.M.A. SUES TO END ALL PRICE CONTROLS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) The American Medical Association asked a Federal court today to order the Cost of Living Council to lift all economic controls on physicians and hospitals.

title: A New Lindy's Opens; Plat du Jour: Nostalgia
description: A new Lindy's opened yesterday at 317 Broadway, a few blocks north of City Hall, where the day ends at 5 P.M. and no one stays to see the stars come out. For those who remembered the old Lindy's, at 51st Street and Broadway, it brought back memories of cheesecake by the delectable pound and showbusiness people by the scrambling dozen.

title: 11 Exposed to Radiation
description: ATHENS, Ala., Feb. 19 (AP) Eleven maintenance workers sustained slight exposure to radiation while replacing a relief valve at the Browns Ferry nuclear power plant last week, Tennessee Valley Authority officials said today.

title: Hijacker's Grenade Rips South Vietnamese Plane
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 20 (AP)A group of Vietnamese tried to hijack a South Vietnamese airliner to Hanoi today, and then exploded a hand grenade when the plane landed at Phu Bai near Hue in northern South Vietnam, airline officials said.

title: Chile Leader Bars Elections
description: RANCAGUA, Chile, Feb. 19 (UPI)Gen. Augusto Pinochet, leader of the Chilean military junta, said today there would be no elections in Chile for at least five years and perhaps longer. General Pinochet made the statement on a visit to the huge Teniente copper mine near Rancagua in central Chile.

title: Kissinger Says Pentagon Got Report on His Secret Trip to China
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19Secretary of State Kissinger has told a Senate committee that he learned in late 1971 that a Navy clerk assigned to his office had pilfered and forwarded to the Pentagon the text of a private report to President Nixon after Mr. Kissinger's secret trip to China

title: New jersey Sports
description: LITTLEFALLS, Feb. 19When John Gerdy flipped 648 points as a freshman for the Passaic Valley High School varsity two years ago, it seemed inevitable, that he would claim the New Jersey career scoring record before his graduation in 1975.

title: NEW LAW ON RAPE SIGNED BY WILSON
description: ALBANY, Feb. 10Governor Wilson signed into law today an act eliminating the need for corroboration to prove the crime of rape. In the Assembly, another measure sought by women'srights advocatesoutlawing credit and banking discrimination  was passed and sent to the Senate.

title: Labor Seeks to End Fight by 2 Unions Of Public Employes
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 19 The A.F.L.C.I.O. Executive Council voted today to appoint a committee to make peace among its warring public employe unions after an exchange of charges between union presidents exploded at a council meeting this morning.

title: Lockheed Aircraft Raised Net 62.1% In Fourth Quarter
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation reported yesterday a profit for the third successive year in 1973 with fourthquarter earnings up 62.1 per cent.

title: High Tokyo Foreign Aide Ousted in Political Dispute
description: TOKYO, Feb. 19 Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira today demanded the resignation of his senior subordinate, Deputy Minister Shinsaku Hogen, in an effort to deflect a mounting attack on himself from aggressive young politicians within the conservative governing party.

title: College Gets $89,000 Grant For a Health Care Project
description: DAVIS, Calif. (UPI)A twoyear grant of $89,000 has been received by the University of California to further develop rural health care demonstration project.

title: Simon Increases Gasoline For 20 States This Month
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19William E. Simon, the Federal Energy Administrator, ordered today emergency allocations of 84 million gallons of gasoline this month to 20 states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To Educate Our Handicapped Children

title: Agency Says Cost Of Market Basket Will Climb in 1974
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP)A market basket of farmproduced food cost consumers a record of $1,537 last year and is headed up again in 1974, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Women Voters Find 11 Men in the League
description: TRENTON, Feb. 19The League of Women Voters today discovered that it had men within its midst, all of them in the chapter in Perth Amboy, where the league women defied the organization's national bylaws by admitting them as members.

title: U.S. and Soviet Renew Arms Talks in Geneva
description: GENEVA, Feb. 19Soviet and American negotiators today resumed their talks on limiting offensive nuclear arsenals, ending a threemonth recess.

title: SIRICA SEEKS END TO TAPES DEBATE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Chief Judge John J. Sirica tried today to end the public debate over findings of the courtappointed panel of electronics experts that is investigating subpoenaed Presidential tape recordings.

title: SOVIET EASES CURBS ON FOREIGN ENVOYS
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 19 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union today relaxed some travel restrictions for foreign diplomats in response to Western demands for greater freedom of movement.

title: MRS. MARK W. MACLAY
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 19Mrs. Marianne Read Maclay, widow of Mark Walton Maclay, admiralty lawyer of New York and Cambridge, Mass., died today at a convalescent home. She was 80 years old and lived at 29 Oenoke Park in Westport.

title: Just the House for a Rich Handyman
description: SMOKE RISE, N. J. It began as the dream house of a health spa tycoon, a striking palazzo out of another era, laden with imported marble and tiles, a stupendous view and the latest gadgets money could buy.

title: 2 Officers Say Bribery Pervaded Narcotics Unit
description: Two New York police officers have given evidence showing that at least half of the detectives assigned to the lite unit charged with arresting major heroin dealers here were accepting large cash bribes between 1968 and 1971, law enforcement sources said yesterday.

title: MITCHELL, SANSGO ON TRIAL HERE
description: Two of President Nixon's former Cabinet members went on trial yesterday on charges that they had obstructed a major investigation and lied about it to a grand jury.

title: Prosecutor Says Representative Brasco Knew Man He Aided Had OrganizedCrime Links
description: Edward M. Shaw, chief of the Organized Crime Strike Force for the Southern District of New York, said yesterday That Representative Frank J. Brasco had been told of alleged organized crime connections of John A. Masiello as early as May, 1968.

title: Tanker Is Coming to Connecticut's Aid
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 19  A tanker loaded with eight million gallons of gasoline, representing 10 per cent of Connecticut's current monthly consumption, is on its way to New Haven, according to the state's energy director.

title: Balloon Is Headed For African Coast On Atlantic Flight
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI)Thomas L. Gatch, sailing along at better than 100 miles an hour, appeared headed for Africa rather than Europe today in his bid to make the first transAtlantic balloon crossing in history. He took off last night at Harrisburg, Pa.

title: A Democrat in Ford's Old Seat Richard Franklin VanderVeen
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 19The last time Dick VanderVeen felt a similar combination of elated disbelief and unreality was in 1948, when he was a secondyear law student at Harvard. He headed the Harvard Young Democratic Club that year, when President Truman confounded the country by upsetting Thomas E. Dewey.

title: Islanders Vanquish Canadiens
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Feb. 19 Unawed by the caliber of the opposition, the New York Islanders completed a 53 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight in the Nassau Coliseum by scoring three goals in the final period.

title: Hawley Is Aboard 4 Winners at Bowie
description: BOWIE, Md., Feb. 19 (UPI) Sandy Hawley, the 1973 North American riding champion, rode four winners today at Bowie, including the heavilyfavored Meforemore in the $8,500 allowance feature.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Nixon announced that Secretary of State Kissinger would go to the Middle East next week to help get talks under way between Israel and Syria. He had nothing to say about the lifting of the Arab oil embargo against the United States, but said that the immediate problem is the disengagement of troops along the Syrian front. [1:1.]

title: Toward Impeachment
description: The nation is moving inexorably toward an impeachment trial of President Nixon. His conviction by twothirds vote of the Senate is by no means certain but his indictment by the House of Representatives sitting as grand jury for the nation appears increasingly likely.

title: Impeachment Resolution
description: ANNAPOLIS., Md., Feb. 19 (AP)A resolution calling on the House of Representatives to impeach President Nixon has I been introduced by Democrats in the Maryland House of Delegates. But before coming to vote, it must receive a favorable report by the Judiciary Committee, to which it was referred yesterday.

title: PERU WILL REPAY SEIZED COMPANIES
description: The miltary Government of Peru has agreed to pay $76million in compensation for United States companies it has expropriated in recent years, according to announcements by Washington and Lima yesterday.

title: Western Union to Lease Units
description: The Western Union Corporation said yesterday it had agreed to lease satellite transmission capacity to the American Satellite Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Fairchild Industries, Inc., starting next Aug. 1. The contract will run through 1976 and will produce about $5million in annual revenues for Western Union The first Western Union satellite will be launched by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in April and the second in June.

title: Paris Asks Rise in Range For Concorde to Save It
description: PARIS, Feb. 19  The French Government sought today to salvage production of the FrenchBritish supersonic Concorde with proposals to increase its range.

title: Qaddafi Publicly Apologizes to Sadat
description: CAIRO, Feb. 19President Anwar elSadat received an unexpected and extraordinary public apology today from Col. Muammar elQaddafi of Libya.

title: 4 SHOOTINGS LINKED TO HEROIN TRAFFIC
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 (AP) Two persons died of gunshot wounds today, bringing to four the number of those killed in a shooting yesterday that the police say was linked to heroin traffic.

title: AMEX PRICES RISE ON HIGHER VOLUME
description: Prices closed higher on the American Stock Exchange but fell in the overthecounter market yesterday in slightly higher trading.

title: BEANIE PROMISES TO ALLOCATE GAS IF STATE DOESN'T
description: Mayor Beame, calling the metropolitan region's gasoline situation desperate, said yesterday that he had informed, Governor Wilson that the city intended to enact a mandatory allocation system unless the state took such action by Friday.

title: Exorcist, Sting Top Oscar List
description: HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 19The Exorcist, a controversial film about demonic possession, and The Sting, a movie about two con artists, topped the list of Oscar nominations announced today by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Each film received 10 nominations, including those for best picture and best director.

title: Television
Bridge: Kaplan and Kay Combination Changes but Still Triumphs
description: The worldrenowned partnership of Kaplan and Kay was in action with a difference at the New York Hilton Hotel here Monday.

title: ERVIN PANEL ENDS PUBLIC HEARINGS OVER WATERGATE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The Senate Watergate Committee decided today not to hold further public hearings.

title: Connecticut Plans to Make Top Lottery Prize $100,000
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 19 (AP)The Connecticut State Lottery will raise its top prize to $100,000 from $75,00 next month, a spokesman for the Commission on Special Revenue said today.

title: BLACK STUDENTS REPORTED GAINING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP)  Black male students in high schools, who usually are the highest dropout risks, have gained half a grade level in Southern schools receiving Federal desegregation aid, according to a Governmentfunded study released today.

title: ERVIN PANEL ENDS PUBLIC HEARINGS OVER WATERGATE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The Senate Watergate Committee decided today not to hold further public hearings.

title: Books of The Times
description: STRINGER. By Ward Just. 199 pages. AtlanticLittle, Brown. $5.95.

title: Notes on People Ford in Historic Fire Brigade
description: Vice President Ford has accepted membership in person in the historic Friendship Veterans Fire Engine Association in Alexandria, Va., where he lives. The city's Human Relations Council and civil rights organizations complain that the fire brigade practices racial discrimination in choosing its members. Dating to 1774, it had George Washington as one of its original members, and so it annually makes awards on Washington's Birthday to outstanding Americans.

title: Loss of Ford Seat Shakes G.0.P.; Democrats Predict Sweep in Fall
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The loss of Vice President Ford's former Congressional seat to Democrat yesterday left Republicans badly shaken today, while Democrats jubilantly predicted landslide victories this fall.

title: United Aircraft Stock Plan
description: The United Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday its intention to purchase up to 1.1 million shares of its new $8 preferred stock. United issue the stock in connection with its acquisition earlier this month of Essex international. Assuming conversion of all outstanding securities convertible into the $8 stock, United would have approximately 4.2 million shares of the stock outstanding.

title: Pennsy Trustees' Petition On Debt Is Slated Feb. 26
description: Judge John P. Fullam of the United States District Court in Philadelphia yesterday fixed next Tuesday for a hearing on a petition of the trustees of the Penn Central Railroad. They want the Federal Government to meet $10.6million of principal and interest installments due on various locomotives and freight cars.

title: Open Market Unit Voted Some Easing In Monetary Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The Federal Reserve's open market Committee voted with one dissent at its December meeting for a modest easing of monetary policy, it was disclosed today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LEEDS, England, Feb. 19 (AP)Bristol City scored one of the biggest British soccer upsets in recent years today when it defeated previously unbeaten Leeds United, 10, and advanced to the quarterfinals of the English Football Association Cup.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: Page

title: Early Gains in Stock Prices Are Erased
description: Stock prices rose sharply early yesterday amid firedup hopes for an end to the Arab oil embargo and then tumbled just as far when these great expectations proved groundless.

title: Fallen Idol
description: The tenuous leadership of Premier Golda Meir was dealt a severe blow yesterday with the decision of Defense Minister Moshe Dayan to give up his ministerial post unless his political terms are accepted.

title: Central Park Zoo Gets Bear to Replace One Shot in '71
description: The Central Park Zoo put on display a new 2yearold, 350pound polar bear yesterday as a successor to Skaridy, a bear shot by a patrolman in 1971 after it grabbed a man's arm.

title: 9 Firemen Have Tux, Will Travelto Safety Duties at the Opera
description: Three nights a week, when Manhattan fireman Jim Ronayne is not on duty with Engine Company No. 5 or heading to a fire, he is getting ready for a night at the opera.

title: Nebraska Bars Smoking In Some Public Places
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 19 (AP)The Nebraska Legislature banned smoking today in such public places as elevators, theaters, libraries, art museums, concert halls or public buses, unless smoking areas are designated.

title: Rare Liver Cancer Discovered
description: Two more victims of a rare liver cancer have been uncovered among vinyl chloride workers in a B. F. Goodrich Company chemical plant in Louisville, Ky., bringing to six the known cases there of the invariably fatal disease.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Moscow Says U.S. Jailed G.I.'s as Reds
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 19The official Communist party newspaper Pravda told Soviet readers today that thousands of American Communists who fought in World War II were imprisoned after they returned

title: Judge John O. Henderson Dies; Presided at the Attica Riot Trial
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 19 (AP)Chief Judge John O. Henderson of the United States District Court for Western New York died today in Buffalo General Hospital after having undergone emergency surgery yesterday for a ruptured aorta. He was 64 years old.

title: Contract Awards
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation announced yesterday that Korean Air Lines had signed a purchase agreement for five McDonnell Douglas DC10 series 30 widedabin jetliners. The order is contingent on Korean Government approval and completion of financing. The value of the transaction is $155million, including provisions for spare engines, parts and support services.

title: Thunderclap
description: In the closing days of his campaign for Vice President Gerald Ford's former seat in the House, Democrat Richard VanderVeen told audiences: If I win this election, there's going to be a thunderclap that will be heard from one end of this country to the other.

title: God and Man on the StockCar Circuit
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19Let us pray that they have good judgment.

title: Eastern College Hockey
description: DIVISION I

title: KISSINGER TO VISIT MIDEAST TO SPUR A SYRIAN ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19President Nixon announced today that Secretary of State Kissinger would go to the Middle East next week to help get talks under way between Israel and Syria. But he had nothing to say about the lifting of the Arabs' oil embargo against the United States.

title: Sports Today
description: Sports Today

title: Steel Production Rose 2.4% in Week To 2,906,000 Tons
description: Steel production for the week ended Feb. 16 reached its highest weekly total for the year to date and also chalked up its largest percentage gain for any week to date, according to figures released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH F.A. CUP

title: Dayan Demands Coalition With Rightist Opposition
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 19Defense Minister Moshe Dayan served notice today that he would refuse to join Israel's next Cabinet unless Premier Golda Meir's party agreed to share power with the rightwing opposition.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New Brunswick Gets Black Mayor

title: Mall Neighborhood in Fight to. Preserve Charm
description: ALBANY, Feb. 19  As the white marble towers of the South Mall take their final shape, they are casting lengthening shadows over the quiet old residential blocks that surround the huge state office complex.

title: Dance: A Louis Premiere
description: In their first Broadway season, a jointly sponsored one, the Murray Louis Dance Company and the Alwin Nikolais Dance Theater have turned this month into a pretty fair and very attractive sampling of each choreographer's old and new works. Last night, the Louis company opened a twoweek run at the Lyceum Theater, where the Nikolais troupe had performed since Feb. 5.

title: MINIM DENIES HUGHES GIFT AGAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19An aide to Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said today that the Minpesota Democrat had denied under oath an allegation that he personally received a, cash Contribution from the Howard Hughes organization. during the 1968 Presidential campaign.

title: Tenn. Trackmen Win Title Again
description: MONGOMERY, Ala. Feb. 19 (AP)Tenessee, scoring in 12 of the 15 events and sweeping the first three places in the halfmile run, won the Southeastern Conference indoor track meet today for the 10th time in 11 years with total of 69 points.

title: Chinese Criticism Renews Theory of Chou as Target
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 19An official attack on a dead Chinese intellectual for having praised Americans and entertained guests prompted fresh speculation today that Premier Chou Enlai might be one of the targets of the new ideology campaign under way in China.

title: Arthur McGinley, 84, Dies; Sports, Editor in Hartford
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 19Arthur Bosworth McGinley, sports editor emeritus of The Hartford Times and a close friend of Eugene O'Neill, the playwright, who based Ah, Wilderness! on the McGinley family, died today at the Hartford Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in West Hartford.

title: Five Are Freed in Ulster As Result of Police Protest
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 19Five women prisoners were released from Armagh jail today because policemen refused to escort them to court in Belfast, where four of them were to face charges of possessing explosives.

title: Asparagus Fields Struck
description: CALEXICO, Calif., Feb. 19 (AP)The United Farm Workers of America struck the Imperial Valley asparagus fields today and said that 800 to 1,000 workers stayed out to protest Teamsters Union contracts. Sheriff Oren Fox said 250 men and women were picketing. No violence was reported.

title: Their Advice to Debtors: Pay Now, Buy Later
description: Flash the right charge card and out roll the Castro Convertibles. Sofas, sectionals and love seats in custom covers.

title: New Books
description: A Guard Within by Sarah Ferguson (Pantheon Books, $6.95). Of an emotional breakdown and the treatment for it.

title: Rx for Conciliation
description: In the midnineteensixties, medicine rapidly began to cast new and different, shadows primarily because of the perspectives from which it was viewed. Although social movements never begin at a specific instant, they are usually identified retrospectively and dated as having begun with an appropriate event. The crass and poorly explained opposition of organized medicine to Medicare congealed and sealed attitudes that viewed medicine as selfish and mercenary. When the cost of Medicare and Medicaid became so excessive, medical care finally spilled out into the political arena.

title: BEAME PROMISES TO ALLOCATE GAS IF STATE DOESN'T
description: Mayor Beanie, calling the metropolitan region's gasoline situation desperate, said yesterday that he had informed Governor Wilson that the city intended to enact a mandatory allocation system unless state took such action by Friday.

title: Hockey Leagues In Tune
description: Without officials of either league ever having sat at the same bargaining table, the National Hockey League and World Hockey Association formally ended their differences yesterday.

title: Stage: Stoppard's Jumpers Has U.S. Premiere in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18.Tom Stoppard's play Jumpers is simply dazzling. It takes your breath away with its sheer exuberance of literacy, its cascade of words and conspicuous display of intellect, It is also extraoardinarily funny. The play had its American premiere tonight at the Eisenhower Theater of the John Kennedy, Center for the Performing Arts.

title: MONDALE TESTING POLITICS ON COAST
description: CORONADO, Calif., Feb. 18Over breakfast this morning at the edge of the Pacific surf, Senator Walter F. Mondale of Minnesota concluded predictably that he was sufficiertly encouraged by a week of barnstorming in California to continue his exploration of a race for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1976.

title: Red Smith
description: Sports of The Times

title: Celtics BeatPistons as White Stars
description: BOSTON, Feb. 19 (AP)Jo Jo White's hot hand revived the sagging Boston Celtics in the third period today and helped them to a 10797 National Basketball Association victory over the Detroit Pistons.

title: St. John's Surge Tops Boston College, 8072
description: BOSTON, Feb. 19 (UPI)St. John's, shooting 79 per cent in the second half, defeated Boston College, 8072, tonight in a battle of teams seeking a tournament bid.

title: Samuels Sketches His Fiscal Picture
description: ALBANY, Feb. 19Howard J. Samuels, former head of New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for Governor, today made public summary of his income and the taxes he had paid for the last four years. But he did not carry out a promise made last week to make a full disclosure of my net worth, my holdings, everything:

title: SAKHAROV IN APPEAL ON DETAINED RUSSIAN
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 19Dr. Andrei A. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist, has asked for help to save the life of a 34yearold Russian mathematician who is reportedly near death in a mental hospital.

title: Samuels Sketches His Fiscal Picture
description: ALBANY, Feb. 19Howard J. Samuels, former head of New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for Govarnor, today made public a summary of his income and the taxes he had paid for the last four years. But he did not carry out a promise made last week to make a full disclosure of my net worth, my holdings, everything.

title: Two Held as Impersonating Kidnappers of Miss Hearst
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 (UN) A Middle Western couple have been arrested here on charges of impersonating the kidnappers of Patricia Hearst and attempting to collect $100,000 in ransom money, the police disclosed today.

title: CYPRUS DEADLOCK REPORTED AT END
description: ATHENS, Feb. 19Authoritative sources said today that a negotiating breakthrough had been made on Cyprus toward an agreement on restoring peaceful coexistence between the Greek Cypriote majority and the Turkish Cypriote minority.

title: Millay Farm Becoming an Arts Colony
description: AUSTERLITZ, N. Y., Feb. 19 The 700acre farm of Edna St. Vincent Millay here is being transformed into a colony where writers, painters, sculptors, dramatists and poets can work undisturbed in a pastoral setting.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The bodies of two boys missing since Monday night were found yesterday under the ice in Rainbow Pond Lakehurst. The boys, James Walpole, 10 years old, and brother, John, 9, were found by a sheriff's officer about 8:30 A.M. The cause of death was not announced, pending an autopsy. The pond is about a half mile from the motel where the boys had been staying with their parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Walpole.

title: Mackell Says He Knew of Investor Scheme Since '68
description: The jury in the trial of Thomas J. Mackell, the formerQueens District Attorney, heard testimony yesterday given by Mr. Mackell last year that he knew of the existence of a socalled fastmoney scheme since 1968. The 1973 testimony, given to grand jury, involved a scheme run by Joseph Ferdinando, whose prosecution Mr. Mackell is charged with hindering.

title: Cornell Six Wins
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 19An aroused Cornell hockey team played its finest game of the year tonight to defeat the nation's secondranked hockey team, the University of New Hampshire, 54.

title: Scottish Nationalism Comes Out of Slump in Election Issue of Who Owns Offshore
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, Feb. 19The issues elsewhere in Britain's election campaign may be prices, inflation and militant unions, but in Scotland the debate centers on oil, the offshore black gold that the Scots are counting on for an economic revival.

title: House Votes an Increase In Veteran Education Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) The House voted today, 38 to 0, to increase veterans education allowances by 13.6 per cent. The bill would also liberalize requirements for veterans to qualify for school and job training aids.

title: Barr Quits Dalton School Post, Charging Trustees' Interference
description: Donald Barr, the controversial and outspoken headmaster of the Dalton School, one of the city's largest and most selective private schools, has resigned in protest of what he considers the trustee's interference with his leadership.

title: DELAWARE CRASH CREATES OIL SPILL
description: PAULSBORO, Feb. 19 (AP)The crash of two oil tankers in the Delaware River off this port Way spilled 21,500 gallons of oil into the water, the Coast Guard said.

title: MITCHELL, STANS GO ON TRIAL HERE
description: Two of President Nixon's former Cabinet members went on trial yesterday on charges that they had obstructed a major investigation and lied about it to a grand jury.

title: Open Interest
description: (In bushels, 000 omitted)

title: Arzhanov Suspects Drug Use
description: Yevgeny Arkhandv claims he dciesn't need drugs to help him run faster, but he isn't so sure about his European and American rivals.

title: People in Sports: Cowboys' Hill Denies Big Brother Is Watching
description: I'm beginning to get the same impression of the press that President Nixon has, said Calvin Hill, the Dallas Cowboys' running back and player representative, yesterday. Hill was busy denying wire service reports that he had told a Dallas radio station he thought he was being watched for saying on a recent New York City television show he wanted to be traded or that he said the Cowboys had sent for the tapes.

title: Reinecke Will Undergo Test On Lie Detector Over I.T.T.
description: FRESNO, Calif., Feb. 19 (AP) Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, has agreed to give California Lieut. Gov. Ed Reinecke a lie detector test on his part in the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation investigation, Mr. Reinecke said today.

title: Newcombe, Richey Overcome Bumpy Coliseum Tennis Courts
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Feb. 19 In a sense, the Montreal Canadiens were to blame for today's bumpy opening of the World Championship Tennis circuit tournament at Nassau Coliseum. If the National Hockey League club had not balked at changing its date tonight with the New York Islanders, the tennis players might not have found themselves on two lumpy courts spread over ice.

title: NEWS BIAS SEEN TIED TO SCHOOLS
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19Gov. Ronald Reagan, speaking before an assembly of broadcasters at the Century Plaza Hotel, said today that he believed the liberal bias he perceived in the news media had its origins in the schools.

title: Concert
description: Mahler's song cycle, Kindertotenlieder, can be one of the most desolating experiences in all of music. These Songs on the Death of Children are so poignant that the slightest exaggeration in expression can tip the balance toward mawkishness. Christa Ludwig, who sang the cycle with the Cleveland Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Monday night, steered well clear of any such mistake. Her interpretation, in fact, was so restrained that the music took on an austerity and bleakness not often associated with Mahler's music.

title: Gulf Oil Assailed by Simon For Uncooperative Position
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) Gulf Oil Corporation stands alone in taking an uncooperative stance concerning Federal oil regulations, the Federal Energy Administrator, William E. Simon, said today.

title: Stage
description: A pair of works by two leading Swiss dramatists is being shown with varying results on the current off Off Broadway scene. The winner is Friedrich Drrenmatt's The Marriage of Mr. Mississippi, another bright production by the Shade Company. But an updated and Americanized version of Max Frisch's The Firebugs, with music added, flounders disappointingly, even with the professional savvy of the. Joseph Jefferson Theater Company.

title: JACK COLE IS DEAD; A CHOREOGRAPHER
description: Jack Cole, considered one of the most influential choreographers in the American musical theater and in the world for his work on Broadway, in films and in nightclubs, died Sunday in Los Angeles after a brief illness. He was 60 years old.

title: Beame Tells of Job Project For 8,000 Once on Welfare
description: Mayor A. Beame announced yesterday that the city and the Board of Trade would sign contract to provide 8,000 former welfare clients with jobs in the private sector.

title: Jane Marla Robbins Plays Fanny Burney
description: To most people, and I am no exception, the idea of onewoman play, or a oneman play, is about as appealing as a onewheeled bicycle. It was therefore in a somewhat defensive mood that attended Dear Nobody, which opened at the Cherry Lane Theater last night.

title: RATES EXPECTED TO FALL FURTHER
description: Bond markets were mixed yesterday in quiet postholiday trading as a number of major money commercial banks joined the broadening move to a 9 per cent prime lending rate. Among the banks following last Credit 'eek's cut by Markets Bankers Trust were Chase Manhattan, the Chemical Bank, the Bank of New York, Manufacturers Hanover, Philadelphia National, Pittsburgh National, the First National of Boston, the Northern Trust Company, the First Wisconsin National and Wells Fargo

title: Women Voters Find 11 Men in the League
description: TRENTON, Feb. 19The League of Women Voters today discovered that it had men within its midst, all of them in the chapter in Perth Amboy, where the league women defied the organization's national bylaws by admitting them as members.

title: Kennedy's Mother Is Ill With Persistent Headaches
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19 (AP)  Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy, 83yearold mother of the late President Kennedy, was admitted to a hospital today after complaining of persistent headaches.

title: Brazil Devalues Cruzeiro
description: BRASILIA, Feb. 19 (Reuters) The central bank has devalued the cruziero to 6.415/6.455 from its previous parity of 6.30/6.34 to the dollar, according to an official communiqu. This is the second devaluation in less than 20 days. The last one was effective Jan. 31.

title: 8 Stars to Miss A.A.U. Meet in Dispute
description: Eight of America's top amateur track and field athletes, including two world recordholders, George Woods and Francie Larrieu, will be L:missing from the National Amateur Athletic Union indoor championships Friday night because of a dispute over money.

title: CAMBODIAN ATTACKS STOPPED BY REBELS
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 19 (UPI)Government troops reportedly made two attempts to clear insurgent forces out of areas just south of Phnom Penh today, but were stopped by heavy fire.

title: Business Records
description: Tuesday, Feb. 19, 1974

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
New Lithuanian Party Chief
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 19 (AP) Pyatras Griskevicius, chief of the Communist party in Vilna, the Lithuanian capital, has been named head of the party in the Baltic Soviet state, Pravda reported today. Mr. Griskevicius, who is 48 years old, succeeded Antanas Y. Snechkus, who died last month.

title: Women Begin to Emerge From Agnew's NovelinProgress
description: She is a successful career woman at the top of her field, but it's her perfume and her shapely legs that first endear her to the fictional Vice President who is the hero of Spiro T. Agnew's forthcoming political novel, and romance rears its head.

title: NIXON ASKS SHIFT IN AN AID PROJECT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19President Nixon proposed to Congress today a change in the relatively modest program of Federal aid to depressed areas to give the states far more control over the funds. Mr. Nixon said that the 12yearold program, with its detailed Federal controls over grants and loans to areas with high unemployment, has not been effective. But, in a relatively conciliatory message, he offered to continue the present program for another year pending enactment of the new one.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Justices to Study Divorce Law With OneYear Residence Rule
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether states may refuse to grant divorces to anyone who has lived in the state for less than one year.

title: 17 Rifles Stolen From Base
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Feb. 19 (UPI)Two men posing as the Officer of the Day and the Sergeant of the Guard stole 17 M16 rifles from a recruit barracks during the weekend, a Marine Corps spokesman said yesterday.

title: Behavior Control Issue Unsolved
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Twice; in two weeks the Government has called a halt, to behavior modification programs it was fundingzfirst dismantling a project for troublesome inmates in a Federal institution in Missouri, then banning all further use of Federal anticrime money for behavior, modification programs anywhere. But in each case, the Government action was somewhat ambivalent. And in neither case did it resolve the host of issues that critics of the programs had raisedthe propriety of using behavior modification as a law enforcement tool, the results of such use so far, or the extent of such use.

title: Jersey Wary of U.S. Vow of Extra Fuel
description: TRENTON, Feb. 19State officials reacted with restrained optimism today to an announcement by the Federal Energy Office in Washington that 10.6 million additional gallons of gasoline would be allocated to New Jersey during the last nine days of February.

title: People and Business
description: William J. De Lancey, president of the Republic Steel Corporation, has been named chief executive officer. He succeeds Willis B. Boyer, who died on Jan. 31 at the age of 58. Mr. Boyer also held the position of chairman, which has been abolished.

title: POLL SHOWS DEMAND FOR GAS RATIONING
description: A nationwide sample of 1,997 adults interviewed by the Roper Organization in late January indicates that 54 per cent of the American public feels that more drastic steps need to be taken to cope with the energy problem.

title: HIGH COURT LETS DISNEY CASE STAND
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 19 (AP) The Government has lost its bid for a review by the Supreme Court of a tax dispute with Walt Disney Productions. The Government says the case could result in an annual loss of $400million to $500million in taxes from the movie industry.

title: ROBERT AMSTER, 39, BROKERAGE OFFICER
description: Robert L. Amster, vice president for technical analysis of the brokerage firm of Rosenkrantz, Ehrenkrantz, Lyon & Ross, died of cardiac arrest Monday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 39 years old and lived at 33 West 93d Street.

title: Housing Starts Up; Personal Income Off
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Housing starts, following a steep decline, improved slightly in January from a December level that was revised upward, the Commerce Department reported today. The department also reported a rare decline in personal income in January, the first since June, 1972.

title: Law Graduate Held In $607,000 Fraud
description: A 33yearold Harvard Law School graduate, described by the police as independently wealthy but fascinated by the challenge of constructing elaborate schemes to steal money, was arrested yesterday and charged with thefts of $607,000 in bonds.
