Results include the operations of Halsey, Stuart & Co., which was acquired on June 18, 1973.

title: Father Takes Custody of Children And Mother Thinks It Best
description: It began to happen too recently for there to be any statistics, according to Arnold J. Gibbs chairman of the American Bar Association's section on family law.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
PAUL F. CRAIG
description: LONGMEADOW, Mass., Feb. 21 (AP)Paul F. Craig, who retired nine years ago as managing editor of The Springfield Union, died yesterday at his home here. He was 77 years old.

title: Lack of Gasoline Called Peril to Parking Industry
description: New York's parking problem has taken an ironic turn: It's the garage or lot operator who has, the problem now, coping wall halfempty facilities.

title: Prime Rate Reduction Looms; Prices on Big Board Advance
Books of The Times
description: THE VON RICHTHOFEN SISTERS. The Triumphant and the Tragic Modes of Love. By Martin Green. 396 pages. Illustrated. Basic Books. $12.50.

title: Fire Kills Five in Family
description: MILFORD, Mich., Feb. 21 (AP)  A family of five died early today in a fire at their onestory home. The victims, all apparently overcome by smoke, were identified as Raymond Wilhelm, 66 years old; his wife, Paula, 46; their daughters, Jane, 10, and Claudia, 13; and Mrs. Wilhelm's son by a previous marraige, Richard Kinnerly, 17.

title: Company Crabiel Headed Has Records Subpoenaed
description: A grand jury in Trenton received yesterday the records of a major New Jersey contracting company formerly headed by J. Edward Crabiel, the newly appointed Secretary of State.

title: Wealthy Compatriots Underwrite Heart Surgery Here for Poor Greek Children
description: Christina Yahanadzis held her 4monthold son Christos in her arms for a few moments, smiling at him despite the sobering presence of a fishscale row of stitches down the center of his tiny chest.

title: Eastman Kodak Sets Records for Sales and Profit
AIDES SAY HOUSE NEED NOT ALLEGE CRIME TO IMPEACH
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 Lawyers for the House Judiciary Committee flatly rejected today arguments that President Nixon was subject to impeachment only for indictable criniinal offenses.

title: The Man Who Took on Heath Makes Light of Odds
description: SIDCUP, England, Feb. 22  The man who is really running against Prime Minister Heath in this British election campaign is a 30yearold history teacher who is making his first race for the House of Commons and thinks the result here will be closer than many people think.

title: Austrian Women Are 1, 2 in Slalom
description: BREGENZ, Austria, Feb. 22 AP)Annemarie Proell of Austria finished less than half a second ahead of a teammate, Monika Kaserer, today to win the giant slalom in the Austrian Alpine skiing championships.

title: G.M. Shifting Plant in California To Output of Subcompact Cars
description: CHICAGO, Feb, 22 (UPI) The General Motors Corporation said today it would convert it South Gate, Calif., assembly plant to the production of subcompact cars  a change that will give the world's largest auto maker the capacity to build two million small cars a year.

title: Hopes for a Condor chick Pinned on Very Old Bird
description: Long John Silver, 55 years old, of Milwaukee, is at the Bronx Zoo on an assignment that ti lot of peope are depending on. Long John is a condor, and the hope is that he will be instrumental in fulfilling the zoo's hopes of breeding his kind in captivity.

title: Pop Music: Theatricality Marks Billy Joel Songs
description: Like Elliott Murphy, Billy Joel is a singer and song writer from Long Island who hat begun to make it over the last few months. But while Mr. Murphy still seems a bit unformed, Mr. Joelwho opened Wednesday night at Max's Kansas City, Park Avenue South at 18th Street, and continues there through Mondayis fast developing into an important artist.

title: Jackson of A's to Get $135,000
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22 (UPI)  Reggie Jackson, the 1973 American League most valuable player, became the fifth of nine players today to win a salary arbitration case against Charlie Finley, the owner of the Oakland A's. Jackson was granted his request for a $135,000 pact for 1974.

title: Attempted Holdups Of 2 Jewelry Stores Leave 4 Wounded
description: Four persons were shot, one seriously, during two attempted holdups by lone gunmen at jewelry stores in Brooklyn and Manhattan yesterday. One of the robbers fled emptyhanded but the other was seized after a struggle with a prop??ietor and two of his customers.

title: Police Sergeant Charged With Failing To Respond During Youths' Rampage
description: A police sergeant has been charged with failing to respond to a call for assistance during the Feb. 15 rampage by members of youth gangs at the JackintheBox fast food restaurant in St. Albans, Queens.

title: Boy, 16, Who Made 20 Escapes From Reformatory, Flees Court
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 22 A 16yearold boy, who had made a total of 20 escapes from custody, jumped through a window yesterday in Juvenile Court, where a hearing was being held to transfer him to a highsecurity reformatory for youthful offenders.

title: Austrian Women Are 1, 2 in Slalom
description: BREGENZ, Austria, Feb. 22 (AP)  Annemarie Proell of Austria finished less than half a second ahead of a teammate, Monika Kaserer, today to win the giant slalom in the Austrian Alpine skiing championships.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (Reuters)  The Cost Living Council lifted today wage and price controls from the furniture industry, in exchange for a commitment by the largest manufacturers to hold down price increases.

title: Funeral Held for River
description: WEAVERVILLE, Calif., Feb. 22 (UPI)About 90 high school students conducted a mock funeral on the Trinity River near here yesterday as a symbolic protest to what they called the death of the river. As the Trinity High School band played a funeral march, a spokesman for the class told newsmen that the Trinity River dam project had ruined the river's natural fish habitat.

title: Antiques: Silver by Area
description: HARTFORD  Since most people's knowledge of American silver begins and ends with what Paul Revere did when he wasn't out riding, the fact that one of the nation's top private silver collections has been reorganized for better understanding is heartening indeed.

title: Signed Editorials Sought
description: BOISE, Idaho, Feb. 22 (UPI) The Idaho State Senate approved and sent to the House yesterday a measure requiring newspaper editorial writers to sign their articles.

title: MAJOR BANKS CUT THEIR PRIME RATE
description: The First National City Bank, which every Friday morning calculates the interest rate it is going to charge on loans to corporations, decided yesterday to lower its base rate to 8 per cent from 9 per cent, effective Monday.

title: Venezuela Enthusiastic Over Mobil Oil Strike
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 22 (UPI)An oil strike made by the Mobil Oil Corporation in Lake Maracaibo last week has opened the way to possible reserves of 300 million barrels of light grivity crude oil Venezuela's state oil comparry said today.

title: Market Place: Fund to Invest In S. & P. 500
description: In the gogo yearsthe bull markets of the nineteensixties  money managers were a cocky lot who would not be caught in the same performance boat as the market averages.

title: Notes on People
description: Mrs. Richard M. Nixon was named by her husband yesterday to lead the United States delegations to Presidential inaugurations in Venezuela and Brazil next month.

title: Remember George Mason
description: The criminal law sets a general standard of conduct which all must follow.... In an impeachment proceeding a President is called to account for abusing powers which only a President possesses.

title: Inquiry Into Stolen Heroin Focuses on ExDetective
description: Investigators for the state's special anticorruption prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, are focusing on Frank King, a 39yearold former narcotics detective, as the possible mastermind behind the theft of millions of dollars worth of heroin and cocaine from the Police Department property clerk's office, law enforcement sources said yesterday.

title: Sign Milian; Debate Pay Cut
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 22Salary arbitration hearings were scheduled to end today; Fritz Peterson wasn't among those players who chose such hearings. The Yankees start spring training tomorrow; Fritz Peterson doesn't expect to be among the pitchers who will hold their first workout.

title: Wilson Criticizes Samuels On NoShow Job Issue
description: ROCHESTER, Feb. 22 Governor Wilson moved more directly into the political campaign today by defending the state administration against charges of nurturing noshow jobs and by turning the issue on the Democratic frontrunner, Howard J. Samuels.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on motion to recommit conference report on Energy Emergency Act, which was defeated, 60 to 38. Feb. 19.

title: Prof. Donald Giannella, 43, Led Villanova Law Unit
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 Prof. Donald A. Giannella, executive director of the Institute of Church and State of the Villanova University School of Law and managing editor of its periodical, Religion and the Public Order, died today of cancer in Pennsylvania Hospital. He was 43 years old and lived in Rosemont, Pa.

title: Question of Who Is a Jew Again Balking Mrs. Meir
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 22Premier Golda Meir was prevented this week from forming another majority coalition cabinet by an issue that has long aroused Israel  Who is a Jew?

title: REBATE EXPECTED FROM BLUE CROSS
description: TRENTON, Feb. 22Officials of the State Department of Insurance said today that a major portion of the $42.6million surplus amassed in 1973 by Blue Cross of New Jersey would be returned to subscribers.

title: Penn Tops Brown, 8972, Takes Ivy League Lead
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22Strong, accurate and healthy, the University of Pennsylvania probably assured itself of its fifth straight Ivy League basketball championship tonight by trouncing Brown, 8972, to force the Bruin pretenders out of their firstplace tie with the Quakers.

title: Big Board Seats Sold
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday two memberships had sold at $85,000 and $90,000, respectively, compared with a price of $86,000 for the preceding sale, which occurred on Feb. 20. Currently exchange seats are quoted at $81,000 bid and $100,000 offered.

title: Jersey Graft Inquiry Centers on Crabiel
description: TRENTON, Feb. 22  Lawenforcement authorities disclosed today that Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel was the principal target of a state grand jury investigation of corruption in New Jersey highway construction involving alleged collusive bidding and kickbacks to local politicians.

title: Jersey Graft Inquiry Centers on Crabiel
description: TRENTON, Feb. 22  Lawenforcement authorities disclosed today that Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel was the principal target of a state grand jury investigation of corruption in New Jersey highway construction involving alleged collusive bidding and kickbacks to local politicians.

title: New Ford Subsidiary Approved by Japanese
description: TOKYO, Feb. 22 (AP)  Japan's Finance Ministry said today it had approved an application from the Ford Motor Company to set up a whollyowned subsidiary in Japan to import and market the American auto maker's vehicles.

title: Mackell Rests Case After 3 Days on Witness Stand
description: After three days on the witness stand, Thomas J. Mackell rested his case in his conspiracy trial, maintaining he had never assumed responsibility for the Investigation of a $4.4million swindle masterminded by Joseph Ferdinando.

title: Horses & Equipment
Rockefeller Brothers to Build A $4.5Million Archive Center
description: The Rockefeller brothers plan to build a $4.5million publicarchive center in Pocantico Village, in Westchester County, to hold more than 20 million papers about their family's philanthropies, Rockefeller University and the complete personal philanthropic and business records of John D. Rockefeller Sr. and his only son, it was announced yesterday.

title: Kings Point Academy Gets 2 Midshipperson Nominees
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 22Two 17yearold girls named Victoria, both from Valley Stream, L. I., but unknown to each other until yesterday, made history here today. Or, as some feminists would say, herstory.

title: Nixon Loyalists to Widen Appeal In Opposing Impeachment Steps
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22An enthusiastic gathering of Nixon loyalists heard Vice President Ford appeal today for fairness to all the institutions of governmentthe Presidency, Congress and the courts.

title: Favorites Score At Princeton Net
description: PRINCETON. N.J., Feb. 22 All of the topseeded players advanced in the Princeton intercollegiate invitation tennis tournament today, with Manual Diaz of Georgia, who is seeded first, defeating Doug Ebenstein of Brown, 64, 62, and Ken Brightfield of Columbia, 64, 64, to move into the semifinals.

title: OilShale Processing Plans Pushed
description: DENVER, Feb. 22  Two energy companies are pushing ahead to develop oilshale processing plants on privately held land in Colorado and they are expected to begin production before companies leasing Federal shale lands.

title: Shell, in Court, Denies OilPrice Scheme
description: The state and batteries of lawyers for companies in the Royal Dutch Shell family began oral arguments in State Supreme Court yesterday on charges that the companies had schemed to create a heatingoil shortage this winter.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: $700,000 Ransom Frees Atlanta Editor
description: ATLANTA, Saturday, Feb. 23 J. Reginald Murphy, the editorialpage editor of The Atlanta Constitution, was freed unharmed last night after his paper paid $700,000 in ransom to his kidnappers members of a selfproclaimed American Revolutionary Army.

title: State's Energy Chief Almerin Cartwright O'Hara
description: ALBANY, Feb. 22  Are you sure you've got the right man? Mrs. Estelle De Cello, a secretary, asked the reporter who broke the news to her at 8:45 o'clock this morning  that her boss was to be the director of the new state Emergency Fuel Office. But by 11:05 A.M., when he strode, ramrod straight, doubletime past staff and reporters gathered before his offices on the 41st floor of the South Mall Tower, there was little doubt that Maj. Gen. A. C. (Bus) O'Hara was the state's second energy chief in less than a month.

title: I.R.A. and Soldiers Fight Fierce Gun Battle at Border
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 22 (Reuters)Gunmen of the Irish Republican Army fought with British troops today in a furious border duel over the heads of a gypsy, colony.

title: City Presses for Mandatory Rationing
description: Warning that the voluntary system of gasoline allocation has created more chaos than it resolved, city officials yesterday pressed their plan for mandatory regulations.

title: 157 SEOUL TRAINEES LOST IN SEA MISHAP
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 22 One hundred and fiftyseven South Korean Navy trainees were reported missing today after a tugboat carrying them capsized in the harbor of Chungmu, 210 miles south of Seoul.

title: Common Market to Discuss Political Amity in Brussels
description: BONN, Feb. 22  The nine Common Market foreign ministers, whose plans to discuss European political cooperation here were wrecked by FrenchEuropean dissension at the Washington energy conference last week, will try to repair the damage in Brussels March 45.

title: People in Sports: Garvin Calls Norris's Wings a Big Disaster
description: Bruce Norris, the owner of the Detroit Red Wings of the National Hockey League, is the cause of the club's troubles. So said. Ted Garvin, ousted as Detroit coach in November, then dropped as coach of Detroit's Virginia farm club in the American League last Friday.

title: High School Notes
description: Nearly 40 studentsmostly juniors and seniorsat the Barlow School in Amenia, N.Y., take off on Monday for a sevenweek leave from their classrooms during a hiatus known as winterim. The purpose is work, not play.

title: Canton Shows AntiLin Posters Far More Openly Than Peking
description: CANTON, China, Feb. 22 (Reuters)  This South China city has begun a poster campaign in the current mass movement to criticize Lin Piao and Confucius, with slogans far more openly displayed than those in Peking.

title: The Pop Lire
description: Stephen Stills, the rock musician, spent much of his recent New York visitessentially to play two Carnegie Hall concerts  in the company of the city's Latin musicians, even going so far as to sit on a panel devoted to discussing Latin music in Manhattan.

title: Paultz Hits 28, Nets Win, 121113
description: SAN DIEGO. Feb. 22 (UPI) Billy Paultz scored 28 points, Larry Kenon added 24 and Julius Erving had 23 tonight as the New York Nets scored a 121113 American Basketball Association victory over the San Diego Conquistadors.

title: G.O.P. Chief Urges Replacing of Boyd
description: The New York State Republican chairman, Richard Rosenbaum, has recommended to Senators Jacob K. Javits and James L. Buckley the speeding up of the twomonthlong search for a replacement for Edward J. Boyd 5th, the acting United States Attorney who is in the midst of investigations of top Long Island Republicans.

title: Such Things Are Not Done Here, He Said
description: WASHINGTON  I heartily agree with President Nixon's position in the State of the Union Address: One measure of a truly free society is the vigor with which it protects the liberties of its individual citizens and that as technology has advanced in America, it has increasingly encroached on one of those liberties, what I term the right of personal privacy.

title: Zarley Leads Golf by One Stroke
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 22Kermit Zarley held a onestroke lead today with a 36hole total of 139 in the $260,000 Jackie Gleason Inverrary golf classic.

title: Some Oilmen Blame U.S. on Gasoline
description: Some of the nation's major oil companies blame the Government's allocation programs for the chaotic gasoline situation, which continues to worsen at the pump even though inventories of gasoline have reached their highest levels in a year.

title: Senator Williams's Father
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 22 (AP)  Harrison A. Williams, the father of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, died here this morning. He was 85 years old. Mr. Williams retired in 1962 as president of the Norwalk Vault Company in Plainfield, N.J. He leaves, besides his son, his wife, Isabel, and seven grandchildren.

title: Pentagon Official Reports Big North Korean StepUp
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 North Korean forces have been redeployed toward South Korea in a major way over the last few months, according to a Pentagon official.

title: Los Angeles Asks to Hold Olympics
description: The City of Los Angeles, a former Olympic Games host, threw its hat into the arena yesterday to challenge Moscow for the right to stage the 1980 summer games.

title: Knicks Hex Cays Again, 117110
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 22 Even with Dave DeBusschere back on the sidelines, the Knicks had little difficulty demonstrating their traditional supremacy over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight, drubbing the Cays, 117110, before a crowd of 7,781 at the Cleveland Arena.

title: SHORT INTEREST UP DURING MONTH
description: With the short position in Winnebago Industries leaping to 623,195 shares from 99,897 shares and the short position in American Motors surging to 915,227 shares from 355,007 shares in the same, period, the total New York Stock Exchange short interest in the month to Feb. 15 rose to 19,035,000 shares.

title: Smith, Newcombe, Metreveli, Fairlie Gain Semifinals in W.C.T. Tourney
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 22 Stan Smith overcame an Egyptian and John Newcombe turned back a Czechoslovak today as the two top stars remained on their collision course toward a World Championship of Tennis final and the $10,000 first prize at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: 8 Landlords Are Seized Here In Demonstration for Rent Rise
description: Eight landlords were arrested in front of the main offices of the city's Housing and Development Administration yesterday during a demonstration for higher rents that they said were needed to meet rising costs in rentcontrolled apartments.

title: Rothko Executor Alleges Secret Sale
description: The sale of 13 paintings of the late Mark Rothko by Marlborough Gallery to a Lichtenstein gallery affiliated with it was concealed from one of the estate's executors for more than two years, the executor testified yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

title: Mrs. Harris Married To Herbert Sternberg
description: The marriage of Mrs. Judith L. Harris, a medical writer and nutritionist, to Herbert B. Sternberg, board chairman of the Automated Reference Corporation, took place here yesterday. Rabbi Samuel M. Silver performed the ceremony at the St. Moritz Hotel.

title: PRICE INDEX HERE ROSE 9.7% IN 1973
description: Spurred by soaring fuel, food and housing costs, the Consumer Price Index for the New Yorknorthern New Jersey region shot up 9.7 per cent during 1973, for the second largest yearly increase since 1947, according to the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: INMATE RELEASE BACKED BY WILSON
description: ALBANY, Feb. 22Governor Wilson proposed today to extend and make permanent an experimental release program for prison inmates who are enrolled in educational or vocational courses, are called home on family emergencies, or are looking for jobs.

title: ExColonel Says Admiral Gave Officers Data Obtained Illicitly at White House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22A former aide to the Joint. Chiefs of Staff said today that Rear Adm. Robert O. Welander routinely provided key Joint Staff Officers with illicitly obtained White House documents in the last half of 1971.

title: Podiatrists Urged to Act On Faulty Shoe Designs
description: The Podiatry Society of the State of New York paid Ralph Nader to be its guest speaker yesterday at its annual conference here, and Mr. Nader obliged, but used the occasion to assail podiatrists lack of leadership in failing to confront shoe manufacturers and designers who prefer style to safety.

title: Dance: The Limon Company Returns
description: There was an air of renewal at the City Center Downstairs last night. The Jose Limlin Dance Company was opening a fournight New York engagement, its first in some 16 months. There is nothing so remarkable perhaps in that  except that soon after the previous New York engagement the com pany'a leader, Jos Limon, died.

title: Solzhenitsyn Sails for Norway After Day's Visit to Copenhagen
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 22 (Reuters)Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn sailed for Oslo,1 Norway, tonight after taking daylong tour of Copenhagen.

title: Driver Hearings Reset
description: Ignoring its hearing officer's recommendation that 10 suspended harness drivers be reinstated, the State Racing and Wagering Board decided yesterday to conduct a new set of hearings.

title: Rhode Island Jobless Rise
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 22 (AP)Rhode Island's unemployment rate jumped to its highest level in three years during January7.7 per centwith 32,000 workers off their jobs, the State Department of Employment Security reported today.

title: White House Faces Clash With Impeachment Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22The White House and the House Judiciary Committee moved today toward two potential collisions over the panel's inquiry into possible impeachment of President Nixon.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Former Officers Of Equity Funding Indicted by Illinois
description: CHICAGO, Feb, 22 (AP) Five former top officers of the Equity Funding Corporation of America were named yesterday in nine indictments charging violations of the Illinois Securities Act.

title: Berlin Is a Puzzle That Blends Tension With Bustle and Decay
description: BERLIN, Feb. 8This is baffling city. The clichs about it are not all true any more.

title: Shipping/Mails Ail Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time
description: Incoming Passenger and Mall Ships

title: PAKISTAN ADMITS THAT BANGLADESH EXISTS AS NATION
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, Saturday, Feb. 23 Pakistan yesterday recognized Bangladesh, her former eastern wing, in a sudden move preceding the opening here of a major conference of Moslem nations.

title: Charges Dropped Against 4 Accused Of Damaging Bug
description: The United States Government dropped charges yesterday against four men who allegedly destroyed a hidden television camera and eavesdropping device that had been installed in a Brooklyn office by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to monitor activities of the four.

title: Intrastate Rides Asked On Interstate Bus Runs
description: NEWARK, Feb. 22 (UPI)  The State Board of Public Utilities Commissioners today asked 12 companies that operate interstate bus routes to submit plans to serve passengers who want to travel within the state during the energy crisis.

title: TV: Frolic for the Young
description: Ossie Davis and his wife, Ruby Dee, who have been such an adornment to the American theater, have enlisted their friend Harry Belafonte and a group of singularly appealing youngsters to recite poetry and chant songs in a disarming, hourlong television frolic to be shown today at 1 P.M. by the Columbia Broadcasting System. Entitled Today Is Ours,, this is the fourth segment in the networks Saturday Festival of the Lively Arts for Young People.

title: A Glimpse of an Obstreperous Decade
description: The nineteensixties, that obstreperous decade in the international art scene, saw the rise and fall of several movements, each new style following hard upon the heels of the other. It was a great openingup period, beginning with pop art, followed by op art, the various forms of minimal sculpture, kinetic art, the whole artandtechnology syndrome, multimedia extravaganzas, funk art and the beginnings of conceptual art, in which ideas about works of art triumphed over the physical forms themselves.

title: Dollar Falls Sharply
description: The dollar weakened sharply yesterday against most European currencies in foreignexchange trading. The price of geld continued to set records, closing at $163 an ounce in London. Page 39.

title: Born Yesterday Ages Well in Revival
description: The Manhattan Theater Club (at 321 East 73d Street), a lively, prolific performing arts center under the direction of Lynne Meadow, presents a variety of plays (about 60 last season)new works, revivals of classics, staged readings, cabaret entertainments.

title: Wilson Is Given the Power To Act in Gas Shortage
description: Governor Wilson yesterday signed legislation giving him broad emergency powers to deal with the energy crisis and promptly named Maj. Gen. A. C. O'Hara, a longtime state administrator, to take charge of New York's energy program.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PLUCKEMIN, Feb. 22Bert de Nemethy remembers his first thought when he arrived in the United States more than two decades ago.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE AMERICAN FOOD SCANDAL. Why You Can't Eat Well on What You Earn. By William Robbins. 280 pages. William Morrow & Co. $6.95.

title: MOODY'S LOWERS ITS CONED RATING
description: Moody's Investors Service, Inc., downgraded yesterday all of the Consolidated Edison Company's more than $2.8billion of outstanding first and refunding mortgage bonds by one credit notch.

title: PAKISTAN ADMITS THAT BANGLADESH EXISTS AS NATION
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, Feb. 22

title: F.B.I. Says Blacks Run Gang That Operates in Two States
description: F.B.I. agents in Philadelphia said yesterday that they had arrested two men who belong to an organization of black hoodlums that has been engaged in killingforhire, narcotics traffic and an extortion racket in Pennsylvania and New Jersey.

title: Two Kidnappings
description: Nothing could better document the threat of extremism to any society's peace and wellbeing than the simultaneous kidnappings of Patricia Hearst in California and of J. Reginald Murphy, editorial page editor of The Atlanta Constitution, who was released last night. Carried out respectively by apparent radicals of the left and of the right, these anti  social acts masquerading measures of social or political reform have much common.

title: People and Business Government Growth Held Peril
description: While expressing confidence that the younger generation need not worry about any recurrence of the Great Depression, Milton Friedman, the economist, warned a group of college students that their main problem would be to halt a great growth of government.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 33

title: Basketball Today
description: AT GARDEN1:30 P.M.

title: January Durable Goods Orders Rebounded to $42.32Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22New orders flowing to manufacturers of durable goods rebounded part way in January from the sharp decline in December, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: New Liquid Crystal Is Devised
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22The RCA Corporation, which is about to begin the production of liquid crystal displays that illuminate clock and calculator faces, received a patent this week for a distinctive new form. It is opaque until current is applied, and then opens like a venetian blind, disclosing whatever design is underneath. Edward F. Pasierb, a staff associate at RCA Laboratories in Princeton, N.V., and Chan Soo Oh, a former staff member, were granted Patent 3,792,915.

title: Reprisals Are Threatened Unless Italy Frees Arabs
description: ROME, Feb. 22A clandestine Palestinian organization has threatened grave reprisals against Italy unless three Arabs in prison here on terrorism charges are released by next Thursday, according to court sources.

title: BRITISH FOOTBALL
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Mary Decker Eclipses A.A.U. Record For HalfMile
description: Mary Decker, a 95pound, 15yearold halfmiler, helped chauvinistic fans forget victories by New Zealanders in the prestigiuos men's one and three mile runs last night at the Amateur Athletic Union indoor championships.

title: Two Women Who Do Social Work for the Affluent
description: BEDFORD, N. Y.  They have a black looseleaf book filled with the names of Bed ford's better families. They have the keys to the nicer homes, the combinations to the thicker safes, and, for a price, they will do the weirdest jobs.

title: Wallace to Seek a Third Term; Bars Decision on Plans for 1976
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 22Gov. George C. Wallace announced today that he would seek a third term. He is expected to win easily in the May 7 Democratic primary.

title: Deere & Co. Is Expanding
description: Plans for a major expansion of its consumer products factory in, Horicon, Wis., were announced yesterday by Deere & Co. The $10million project would increase the factory's output capacity by 25 per cent. The plant produces the John Deere line of consumer products, which includes lawn and garden tractors, riding mowers and snowmobiles.

title: MUSLIM SLAYINGS OF '73 RECALLED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22In a calm, soft voice, Amin Khaalis told in a pretrial hearing today part of her Story about how a band of armed men forced their way into the center of the local Hanifi Muslims in January, 1973, and killed seven members of the Islamic sect.

title: Music: Boulez Leads a Brainy Brahms
description: Pierre Boulez conducted a Brahms symphony here for the first time Thursday night with the New York Philharmonic, It was the Fourth, a natural choice considering the work's austerity and formal strength, and Mr. Boulez's reading may turn out to be the most fascinatingven to a Brahms symphony this season.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 22 (AP)The new executive director of the World Hockey Association's player union criticized today this week's agreement between the W.H.A. and the National Hockey League as detrimental to players of both leagues. Ron Roberts of Dallas, recently named general counsel as well as executive director of the W.H.A.'s Players Association, said at a news conference he doubted the W.H.A. owners made a good deal in resolving court dispute with the N.H.L.

title: Japanese Extend a Loan Of $100Million for Egypt
description: TOKYO, Feb. 22 (Reuters) Deputy Premier Abdel Kader Hatem of Egypt and his Japanese counterpart, Takeo Mild, exchanged letters today for the extension of a Japanese loan of $100million over the next two years, according to Japanese officials.

title: Over Hump, Over Hill, to Just Around the Corner
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22I knew the gasoline situation was bad but hadn't realized how bad until I heard President Nixon tell Congress we were going to break the back of the energy crisis by the end of the year.

title: Dollar Falls Abroad; Gold Price Hits $164
description: LONDON, Feb. 22The United States dollar weakened sharply today against most European currencies in foreignexchange dealings as the price of gold continued its steady upward march to records.

title: The City WorkForce
description: The magnitude of the jobcreation assignment Mayor Beame has given to his new Council of Economic Advisers is reflected in Federal figures showing that New York City's employment total declined again last year in the face of enormous improvement in the national picture.

title: Egypt Plans to Ease Business Curbs
description: CAIRO, Feb. 22Deputy Premier Abdel Aziz Hegazi promised greater freedom today for private merchants in imports and exports and the removal of some other, limitations on the private sector of the economy.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Early in the season Gordie Howe's 18yearold son, Mark, turned to his father and smiled.

title: Susie Patterson Takes National Slalom in Rain
description: HENNIKER, N. H., Feb. 22 Green, plastic garbage bags for the body and transparent white sandwich bags to cover mittens, were skiing fashion notes today at the Women's National Slalom championship held in a pelting rain.

title: STOCKS CONTINUE TO SHOW ADVANCE
description: The stock market, aided by another cut in the prime lending rate, rounded out a strong threeday rally yesterday. A number of major banks reduced the prime to 8 per cent from 9 per cent.

title: White House Faces Clash With Impeachment Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22The White House and the House Judiciary Committee moved today toward two potential collisions over the panel's inquiry into possible impeachment of President Nixon.

title: Fletcher Is No Match For Connors
description: SALISBURY, Md., (AP) Jimmy Connors had his service broken to open the match, but settled down to easily defeat Ian Fletcher of Australia, 63, 61, in the quarterfinals of the United States indoor open tennis championships tonight.

title: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE
2 New Yorkers Advance
description: TUXEDO, PARK, N. Y., Feb. 22Play started today in the 73d annual Tuxedo Gold Racquet court tennis tournament, with William Haggard of New York defeatMe Peter Graetzer of Tuxedo, 60, 61, and Roger Tuckerman of New York beating George Boynton Jr. of Tuxedo, 62, 62.

title: Clinton C. Johnson, 76, Is Dead; Retired Chemical Bank Officer
description: Clinton C. Johnson, retired executive vice president of the Chemical Bank, died Thursday night at his winter home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 76 years old and lived at 77 Orange Road in Montclair, N. J.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 33

title: Pilic Bows To Mayer In Maryland
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 22 (UPI)Alex Mayer of Wayne, N.J., seeded seventh, upset Nikki Pilic of Yugoslavia tonight, 6.4, 75, to advance to the semifinal round of the United States indoor open tennis championships.

title: The Global Lobotomy Blues
description: (In honor of President Nixon's SovietAmerican peace in our time. A New York Times editorial of Sept: 3, 1973, ends: The World now sees a de facto NixonBrezhnev alliance against dissent in each other's country.)

title: The New Ford Comes Out Swinging in Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 Dismayed by the Republican loss of his old House seat in Michigan, Vice President Ford has shed his Mr. Nice image and has come out swinging against those he calls labor outsiders.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22The Association of American Rail roads reported today that freight craffic on United States railroads during the latest weep totaled an estimated 16.7 bition tonmiles, 5 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same week totaled 527,210 cars, 4.3 per cent over last year.

title: SHAKEY'S SEEKS BLAKELY CONCERN
description: The Great Western United Corporation and Shakey's, Inc. its wholly owned pizza parlor subsidiary, announced yester day that their boards of directors had authorized the signing of a letter of in. tent providing for the acquisition by Shakey's of Blakely Enterprises, Inc, which operates 27 pizza parlors in Colorado, Wyoming and Oregon. Terms were not disclosed.

title: TWA Restoring 747's Use
description: Trans World Airlines announced yesterday it would restore two grounded Boeing 747s to regular service, efective with its March 1 scheduled change. The two jets were taken out of service in early January.

title: Edison Wins Track Title In P.S.A.L.
description: Amid the state's fastest sprint clockings of the season, Thomas Edison defeated DeWitt Clinton for the team title last night in the Public Schools Athletic League citywide indoor track championship at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: Tips for Energy Savers Issued by Government
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 22 (UPI)The Government published today a list of tips for saving energy, including suggestions that Americans wash clothes in cold water with cold water detergents and unplug television sets not in use.

title: 8 Black Businessmen Negotiating to Buy Atlantic City Radio Station
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 22A group of eight black businessmen, seeking to become the first black owners of a New Jersey broadcasting outlet, is negotiating to buy radio station WLDB here for approximately $250,000.

title: Catch 22/23/24
description: It's a Catch22 culture when novelists can command a $1million advance, as reported recently, but $300,000 can't be found anywhere to save part of a city's architectural heritage. (The catch is that money is available where money isn't needed because it will make more money, as Private Yossarian would have known with ultimate certainty.) The decision of Grace Church to demolish its Gothic Revival houses cannot be anything but economically motivated. Unfortunately, the catch applies. There is no money for preservation.

title: RATE OF INFLATION IN JANUARY TOOK 2D BIGGEST JUMP
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  Federal statistics told Americans again today that their pocketbooks were still being hit hard by zooming prices in a prolonged period of inflation.

title: Cuba Trade Issue Fails to Ruffle Kissinger's Talks With Latins
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 22 Secretary of State Kissinger began his new dialogue with the foreign ministers of 24 LatinAmerican and Caribbean governments in give and  take working sessions today.

title: BURKE EXPECTING CONFIDBNCE VOTE
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 22  The Oyster Bay Town Supervisor is expected to receive vote of confidence from the Town Board next week despite a Federal indictment on charge of perjury, a town spokesman said today.

title: TAX AIDE CRITICIZES DEDUCTION BY NIXON
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22 (AP) President Nixon's tax accountant says some of the deductions claimed by Mr. Nixon on his 1970 and 1971 Federal, income tax returns were unwise.

title: Preferential Con Ed Rates To Be Studied by P.S.C.
description: ALBANY, Feb. 22  The Public Service Commission today asserted its jurisdiction over the Consolidated Edison Company's contracts with governments and goverment agencies, including New York City and the Transit Authority, and ordered a study of all of the utility's preferential rate structures, saying it would raise any contract rates it found unduly discriminatory or preferintial.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1974

title: Bryant Realigns Alabama Coaches
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Feb. 22 (AP)Coach Paul (Bear) Bryant has named Curly Hallman to a fulltime position and placed Bud Moore in charge of the offense in completing a reorganization of the University of Alabama football coaching staff.

title: RATE OF INFLATION IN JANUARY TOOK 2D BIGGEST JUMP
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22Federal statistics told Americans again today that their pocketbooks were still being hit hard by zooming prices in prolonged period of inflation.

title: HIJACKER KILLS 2 AND THEN HIMSELF
description: A gunman fatally shot an airport policeman and the copilot of a Delta Air Lines jet yesterday while trying to hijack the plane at BaltimoreWashington International Airport.

title: PETROLEUM IMPORTS SHORT OF FORECAST
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) The Federal Energy Office reported today that petroleum imports last week averaged 4,788,000 barrels a day, about 210,000 moret han was reported by the Ameircan Petroleum Institute, but for the first time below the imports that the agency had forecast as the maximum impact of the Arab oil embargo.

title: British Find Vital Error In Pay Data on Miners
description: LONDON, Feb. 22 (AP) State investigators have uncovered an error that gave false picture of how much miners earn.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Police Lieutenant Mugged

title: Rangers Pin Defeat on Seals, 43
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 22 (AP)A New York Rangers' rookie, Jerry Butler, scored twice in a 43 National Hockey League victory over the California Golden Seals tonight.

title: They'd Life You to Be in Furs All Year While Dining in June, for Instance
description: With the furriers parading their little furs, can spring be far behind? What's more practical, say the men who work in pelts, than it lightweight jacket or fur sweater that doesn't have to be stored in summer, which packs easily and travels from climate to climate and from day to evening?

title: Snowmobile Races Off
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Feb. 22 (AP)The Snowmobile Grand Prix, a sanctioned United States Snowmobile Association event scheduled for tomorrow and Sunday, was canceled today. Bob Kelly of Watkins Glen Grand Prix said two days of rain forced the cancellation.

title: RHODES HOPEFUL ON G.O.P. FUTURE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 The House minority leader, John J. Rhodes, sounding an upbeat theme for Republican congressional candidates, said today that 1974 does not have to be the disastrous political year for Republicans that many people proclaim it will.

title: Amex and Counter Stocks Show Gains
description: Moving sharply higher in moderate trading, prices rose for the seventh straight session yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. Advances also were recorded by the overthecounter market.

title: BUY ORDERS SEND WHEAT PRICES UP
description: An unexpected flood of buy orders swept the grain pits of the big Middle Western exchanges in the last hour of trading yesterday and sent all wheat, corn and soybean prices soaring.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A new parkandride service for New Yorkbound commuters will be started Monday by Transport of New Jersey at the Woodbridge Shopping Center in Middlesex County, between U.S. Routes 1 and 9. A total of 250 free parking spaces have been made available by Stern's department store.

title: HEARST CAPTORS OFFERED 4MILLION
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22 The Hearst Corporation offered today to meet demands for $4million more for free food for the needy, if the Symbionese Liberation Army releases Patricia Hearst unharmed.

title: Zarley Leads Golf by One Stroke
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 22Kermit Zarley held a onestroke lead today with a 36hole total of 139 in the $260,000 Jackie Gleason Inverrary golf classic.

title: Yugoslavia Denies a Writer Passport for U.S. Visit
description: The Yugoslav authorities have prevented Mihajlo Mihajlov, the Yugoslav essayist and chronicler of Soviet concentration camps, from taking part in a California symposium on Problems of Forbidden and Discouraged Knowledge, Mr. Mihajlov's sister reported yesterday.

title: Amnesty Board Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UPI)  Representative Howard W. Robison, Republican of upstate New York, called today for the creation of a national amnesty board to review the cases of young men who chose to avoid the draft rather than serve in the Vietnam war. He urged consideration of conditional amnesty for up to 30,000 young men who avoided the draft and fled the country during the Vietnam era. The proposed amnesty Truman Administration followboard would be patterned after ing World War II.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Traveling Coast to Coast, Bearing the Good News of Feminism
description: Florynce Kennedy was celebrating her 58th birthday in a hotel room in Dallas. An odd place for the black feminist lawyer, who currently lives in San Francisco, to mark the event?

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT Priddy, Feb. 22. 1974.

title: The Patron Saint of the U.N. Is Pontius Pilate'
description: The United Nations Secretariat marked the 25th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights by lastminute withdrawal of promised facilities for Amnesty International's conference against torturefor fear of offending governments engaged in that activity from Saigon to Santiago.

title: 15,787 See Colonels Triumph, 115 to 101
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 22 (UPI)  The Kentucky Colonels delighted the largest crowd of the current American Basketball Association season, 15,787, by leading all the way tonight in a 115101 victory over the Virginia Squires behind Dan Issel's 34 pbints and Artis Gilmore's 20 points and 22 rebounds.

title: Product Safety Unit Issues Another Warning on Lamps
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UPI)The Consumer Product Safety Commission has warned the public about another consignment of novelty lamps that could deliver a fatal shock to users. More than 60,000 of the hazardous lamps may now be on the market, the agency said today.

title: HEARST CAPTORS OFFERED 4MILLION
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22 The Hearst Corporation offered today to meet demands for $4million more for free food for the needy, if the Symbionese Liberation Army releases Patricia Hearst unharmed.

title: Producers of Series and Shows Clash Over PrimeTime Ruling
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22Producers of syndicated television series and the established producers of network shows. are in a contest for the rightofway in the early hour of prime time next fall, in the wake of the Federal Communication Commission's revision of the primetime access rule. The dispute affects several million dollars worth of television production.

title: Prices for Distillates Cut; Talks on Natural Gas Due
description: ALGIERS, Feb. 22 (Reuters)Negotiations are expected to start soon here between Algeria and a group of United States companies led by the, El Paso Natural Gas Company on a new price for natural gas following the large increase in the prices of oil over the last few months.

title: 24 Prospective Jurors Selected For Trial of Mitchell and Stans
description: Judge Lee P. Gagliardi told prospective jurors yesterday that we have made substantial progress in selecting a jury for the trial of John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans in Federal District Court here.

title: N.U.D., Farm Agency Are Hailed for Inaction
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 22 (UPI) The International Association of Professional Bureaucrats will probably make its first joint award this year to the Farm Home Administration and the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the association president, James H. Boren, said today.

title: EDWARD SPRAGUE, SURGEON, IS DEAD
description: NEWARK, Feb. 22  Dr, Edward W. Sprague, a founder and staff surgeon of the Presbyterian Hospital Unit of the United Hospitals of Newark, died yesterday at the hospital. He was 94 years old and lived in Orange at 220 Clairmont Terrace.

title: Snowmobile Races Off
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Feb. 22 (AP)The Snowmobile Grand Prix, a sanctioned United States Snowmobile Association event scheduled for tomorrow and Sunday, was canceled today. Bob Kelly of Watkins Glen Grand Prix said two days of rain forced the cancellation.

title: Aetna Net Up 16.5% in Year
Inquiry Into Stolen Heroin Focuses on ExDetective
description: Investigators for the state's special anticorruption prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, are focusing on Frank King, a 39yearold former narcotics detective, as the possible master mind behind the theft of millions of dollars worth of heroin and cocaine from the Police Department property clerk's office, law enforcement sources said yesterday.

title: New State Agency Intends to Stress Improved Service by Bus Companies
description: TRENTON, Jan. 22  The Byrne administration is shifting financial supervision of the state's bus companies from the Board of Public Utility Commissioners to the Commuter Operating Agency, an arm of the Transportation Department.

title: Art Dawn of Modern American Era
description: In March, 1925, Alfred Stieglitz organized an exhibition called Seven Americans at the Anderson Galleries in New Yotk. According to the subtitle of the catalogue of that exhibition, it consisted of 159 Paintings, Photographs & Things Recent & Never Before Publicly Shown. The artists represented were Arthur G. Dove, Marsden Hartley, John Marin, Charles Demuth, Paid Strand, Georgia O'Keeffe and Stieglitz himself. Sherwood Anderson wroth a poem entitled Seven Alive for the catalogue, affirming, This show is for me the distillation of the clean emotional life of seven real American artists.

title: Symbionese Liberation Army: Terrorism From Left
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22Within less than four months, those who call themselves the Symbionese Liberation Army have come from total obscurity and are note widely regarded by law enforcement officials as the first terrorist group to rise on America's political left.

title: WINE TALK
description: It is all very impressive to know that certain famous wines: are made from very specific grapes grown in very specific vineyards under very specific conditions. With most of the world's wines, however, nothing of the sort ever happens: they are blends. The winemaker's experience and skills enable him to take various wines and blend them, hopefully, into a whole that is greater than its parts. This is true of some expensive winesa member of the Krug family once remarked during a visit here that the Champagne the group was drinking was a blend of 43 winesbut it is particularly true of inexpensive wines.

title: Five Dead in Clashes in Ethiopia Over High Prices and Idleness
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 22 (Reuters) About 300 people were in jail and an estimated five dead here tonight after four days of violence.

title: Long Farah Strike May Be Ended Soon; News Parley Called
description: The long and bitter labor dispute between the Farah Manufacturing Company of Texas and the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America may be close to resolution.

title: Concordia Seminary Chief Scores 2 Schools in Dispute
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 22 (AP)  Enrollment of dissident Concordia Lutheran Seminary students is reported on the rise at the maverick seminary in exile.

title: Mrs. Meir Fails to Induce Mayan to Join New Cabinet
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 22Premier Golda Meir failed again today to persuade Defense Minister Moshe Dayan to serve in her proposed minority cabinet, and she reportedly said that she would take over his post temporarily in the hope that he will reconsider his refusal.

title: Dollar Falls Sharply
description: The dollar weakened sharply yesterday against most European currencies in foreignexchange trading. The price of gold continued to set records, closing at $163 an ounce in London. Page 39.

title: McAdoo: 52, But Celtics Beat Braves
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 22 (AP) Dave Cowens and John Havlicek combined to offset a 52point game by Bob McAdoo and the Boston Celtics maintained their mastery over the Buffalo Braves with a 116109 National Basketball Association victory tonight.

title: CONVICT TESTIFIES AT BRASCO'S TRIAL
description: Prosecution efforts to implicate Representative Frank J. Brasco, a Brooklyn Democrat, in a conspiracy to accept illegal payments for helping trucking company obtain post office contracts continued in Federal Court yesterday.

title: Humphrey Backs Mondale; Says He'll Seek Reelection
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 22 (UPI) Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said today that he would run for reelection to the Senate in 1976 and support fellow Minnesota Senator Walter Mondale for the Democratic nomination for President.

title: Fight in Philippine Town Leaves Rubble and Death
description: JOLO, the Philippines, Feb., 21Scanning a scene of devastation and ruin unlike any this country has seen since World War II, an old man remarked in English as rueful as it was jagged, Sorry this time because of this you see now.

title: $700,000 Ransom Frees Atlanta Editor
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 22  J. Reginald Murphy, the 40yearold editorial page editor of The Atlanta Constitution, was freed unharmed tonight when his newspaper paid a ransom of $700,000 to the self proclaimed American Revolutionary Army that kidnapped him two clays ago.

title: West Germany at the Crossroads
description: BONNWest Germany, which is still Europe's economic dynamo and most effective workhorse, today finds itself at a kind of historical juncture not easily defined. Chancellor Willy Brandt's famous Ostpolitik seems to have lost momentum and while Bonn and East Berlin maintain regular contact, they have not yet agreed on exchange of diplomatic representationfourteen months after signing their basic treaty.

title: DOCTOR REJECTS TOP MENTAL POST
description: Dr. Daniel X. Freedman, head of the psychiatry department at the University of Chicago School of Medicine, has turned down an offer to head the new Federal Alcohol, Drug Abuse and Mental Health Administration.

title: Fight in Philippine Town Leaves Rubble and Death
description: JOLO, the Philippines, Feb. 21Scanning a scene of devastation and ruin unlike any this country has seen since World War II, an old man remarked in English as rueful as it was jagged, Sorry this time because of this you see now.

title: ARLAN'S PERMITTED SHIFT TO CHAPTER X
description: Arlan's Department Stores, the financially troubled discountstore chain, announced yesterday that a Federal judge in New York had granted motion by the Securities and Exchange Commission for Arlan's to be shifted from Chapter XI to ChapterX of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Correction Official Urges Prisons Meet Federal Rules to Get Aid
description: TRENTON, Feb. 22  William H. Fauver, director of the State Division of Correction and Parole, said today that state penal and correctional institutions should conform to national standards before they can become eligible for Federal financial aid.

title: Chicago Board Options Exchange
description: Friday, February 22, 1974

title: Collegians Pass Trotting Tests
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 22Katha Quinn wore the baggy pants owned by John Chapman, the drivertrainer. Her helmet belonged to Tony Giamanco, the trainer or Tony Abbatiello, and her red, blue and white silks are worn by Herve Filson, harness racing's most successful driver.

title: Maxwell Silverman Dead; Shipbuilding Specialist, 47
description: Maxwell Silverman, an oceanographic shipbuilding and inspection specialist, died Feb. 14 on a business trip to Tacoma, Wash. He was 47 years old and lived in Potomac, Md.

title: LABOR MAY URGE NATIONALIZING OIL
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 22  The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations may soon issue an official call for the nationalization of the American oil industry.

title: IRAN TO SEND OIL TO INDIA ON CREDIT
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 22 ran has agreed to supply part of India's oil needs on credit and will invest $300million in a joint venture to develop Iniia's ironore export.

title: Pipeline for Arab Oil Is Set for Eastern Europe
description: Three East European contries have reached agreement on a major oil pipeline project that will carry Arab oil into areas traditionally within the Soviet marketing zone.

title: Islamic Achievement
description: If the Islamic summit currently meeting in Lahore achieves nothing else, its participants will have made notable contribution in persuading host President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan to recognize Bangladesh.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: LIB AND LET LIB The Westbeth Playwrights Feminist Collective consists of five women writers who present their plays on feminist themes in the Westbeth artists' housing center, on West Street, between Bethune and Bank Streets. They've recently set up their own permanent theater in one of Westbeth's large groundfloor galleries, and now, of course, they need help to pay the rent and put on their shows and so on.

title: Prices for Distillates Cut; Talks on Natural Gas Due
description: The Cities Service Oil Company announced yesterday that it would reduce prices of distillates at the consumer level by 2.8 cents a gallon, beginning Monday. The products involved include homeheating oil, diesel fuel and kerosene. At the same time, the company said it would cut prices charged to distributors for these products by 1.8 cents a gallon. In addition, Cities Service will reduce prices for aviation turbine fuel by 2.8 cents a gallon.

title: SEYMOUR WEXLER
description: Seymour Wexler, a textile designer and stylist for Cohn Hall Marx, a division of United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital, after a long illness. He was 46 years old and lived at 576 Harless Place, West Hempstead, L.I.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Comco Electronics Corporation of Fullerton, Calif., announced yesterday receipt of a $31.2million Air Force contract to update the aircraft control and warning system used in the joint air defense of Spain.

title: Los Angeles Asks to Hold Olinnpics
description: The City of Los Angeles, a former Olympic Games host, threw its hat into the arena yesterday to challenge Moscow for the right to stage the 1980 summer games.

title: ADLAI RUST, HEADED STATE FARM MUTUAL
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Feb. 22 (AP)Adlai Hollis Rust, a former president and chairman of the board of the State Farm Mutual Auto Insurance Company, died today at his home here. He was 81 years old.

title: Mets Open Camp, Yanks, Peterson
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 22Nobody ran around yelling you gotta believe, but the New York Mets still raised echoes of the recent past today when they took the field for the first time since the World Series as baseball camps came alive along the Gulf Coast.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Bridge: Knockout Stage Starts Today In Contest for New Yorkers
description: Nearly all of New York's topranked players will be in action today at the New York Hilton, where the knockout stage of the Grand National Team Championship begins at 1:30 P.M. The 16 teams that survived the qualifying contest last month continue on a long road that will end at the Summer Nationals here in July. After tomorrow's play, four teams will survive.

title: House Conservatives Elect
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) Representative Lamar Baker, Republican of Tennessee, has been elected chairman of a 70member group of conservative House Republicans. The election by the Republican Steering Committee was its first since the group was organized a year ago.

title: 4 Seized and 2 Policemen Hurt At a ProNixon Rally in Queens
description: Four antiNixon demonstrators were arrested and two policemen were injured yesterday when a group, of about 250 people attempted to disrupt a Support the President rally sponsored by the Richmond Hill Republican Club in Queens.

title: QUESTIONS
description: I he questions appearing in this column are asked and answered by readers in exchange of gardening knowledge. If you have A question or answer, please send it to Garden News, The New York Times, Times Square, N.Y. 10036. Questions of general interest will be published. Please include stamped return envelope.

title: Head Shaved, Youth Sues
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 23 (AP)A young Californian arrested for hitchhiking in Oregon's Curry County in 1972 has filed a $100,000 damage suit accusing a deputy sheriff of shaving off his shoulderlength hair during a oneday jail sentence. The youth, Arthur Dillon Moore of San Diego, filed the suit Tuesday in United States Court.

title: Islam Nations Press Jerusalem's Return
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, Feb. 23 Moslem nations of Asia, Africa and the Middle East denounced United States support of Israel tonight and demanded immediate withdrawal by the Israelis from all occupied territories.

title: that having a winner can give, and I felt like smiling at everyone
description: Back in Louisville we decided to forego the intake of any more Kentuckiana in the form of visits to the Kentucky Railroad Museum, a 420yearold Douglas fir log, the second largest clock in the world, the first fire station, Zachary Taylor's boyhood home, and the baseball bat museum, and instead had a few more free drinki at the hotel bar before dinner in a very Southern privatemansion restaurant with little parlors with red flocked wallpapers and hearty customers with G.E. convention name tags on their fronts. The juleps had great sheaves of mint sticking out of them and we found out that you can argue about julep recipes and proper mint lengths anytime you want to id Louisville. Such discussion is a local pastime, like disputes over what is perfect corned beef on Houston Street. We looked in vain for dancing in the streets, seeing only clumps of conventioneers shouting hotel room numbers at each other with promises of ailnight parties that would not quite make it Mardi Gras, no more than did the gogo dancers, looking hungry and a bit chilled in a Walnut Street dive. The very last scene of the evening was a cluster of sleepy conventioneers singing Let Me Call You Sweetheart around a piano in an otherwise deserted dance floor, just off the hotel barroom.

title: Dr. Abby L. Wasserman Plaps Marriage to Daniel Paul Jaffe
description: CLIFTON, N. J., Feb. 23Mrs. Robert S. Wasserman has announced the engagement of her daughter, Dr. Abby Lois Wasserman, to Daniel Paul Jaffe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Jaffe of Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Churchill's Grandson Fights to Retain Seat
description: STRETFORD, England, Feb. 23 (UPI)The Winnie and Minnie show is drawing crowds.

title: If it isn't an illness, what is it?
description: As psychiatrists or as laymen, we are still afraid of what we don't knoweven about our own sexuality. We need only think of the revelations of Kinsey and Masters and Johnson to realize how few important studies of sexual behavior have ever been undertaken. And on the subject of homosexuality, despite its presence in virtually all cultures past and present, our lack of knowledge is extraordinary. Little wonder, then, that over the years we have taken for granted a number of sexual facts that now turn out to be the basis for heated controversy.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1974

title: Molloy Captures Queens Track Title
description: Archbishop Molloy scored 211 points and won the Queens Catholic high schools winter track, championship yesterday at the Molloy Field in Jamaica. Holy Cross was second

title: Ration Plan Would Idle Cars One Day a Week
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. called today for a gasoline rationing plan that would require a sticker on every car to show one day a week when that car could not be used. The Connecticut Republican plans to reintroduce a bill on Monday requiring nationwide rationing 30 days after the bill becomes law.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Poor Andrew York. He is a captive of his or suffixes. His previous books have been named The Expurgator, The Predator, The Infiltrator, and so on. Now he serves us THE CAPTIVATOR (Doubleday, $4.95). If you have visions of Jonas Wilde, the licensed killer, simpering his way through this one, exuding charm and killing by captivating his victims, don't worry. Ol' Jonas still can give 007 points on killing with bare hands. And, anyway, there is a meaning  admittedly rare and nearobsolete  to the verb captivate which takes in capture.

title: Ann Blackman Wed in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23Miss Ann Blackman and Michael Putzel, reporters in Washington for The Associated Press, were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Frank E. Robertson, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Putzel Jr., uncle and aunt of the bridegroom.

title: State Loses Its Oldest Winery
description: MADISON  What is said to be New Jersey's oldest winery has passed into oblivion with the sale of the Kluxen Winery at public auction.

title: Minimester Opens At Rider on June 3
description: TRENTONRider College will institute a minimester this June, prior to the opening of its regular summer sessions. The new program will run from June 3 to 14, with final examinations scheduled for June 17.

title: The adventures of Nick Noxin
description: By now the point has become fairly well accepted: it is impossible to satirize Richard Milhous Nixon and his career satisfactorily. And John Seelye's brave try is handicapped by the style as well as the subject. Offhand, the smug, pious moralizing of those old Tom SwiftRover BoysHoratio Alger stories that so captivated our grandfathers and greatgrandfathers would seem to be ideal for this particular caricature. Professor Seelye, of the University of Connecticut English department, has produced an exceptionally faithful reproduction of the genre. It is, in fact, too faithful. As narrative its pedestrian monotony defies all of the author's attempts to keep things moving by injecting special devices.

title: Son to Mrs. Crystal
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 23A son was born Feb. 5 to Mr. and Mrs. David Crystal 2d in the Greenwich Hospital. Mrs. Crystal is the former Miss Judith Stulberg, daughter of Louis Stulberg, president of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, and Mrs. Stulberg of New York. Her husband is a lawyer. The child has been named Philip Edwin 2d for his paternal grandfather, Philip Edwin Crystal of Palm Springs and Laguna Niguel, Calif.

title: Alexei Kosygin has a friend at Chase Manhattan...
description: ... and his name is David Rockefeller. The Premier of the Communist world's most powerful state and the chairman of the capitalist world's third largest bank got to know one another last year when Rockefeller was invited to Moscow to discuss opening a Chase Manhattan office in the Soviet capital. They met again last May when the bank long controlled by the family many consider the personification of American capitalism opened an office at No. 1 Karl Marx Square, only a block from the Kremlin.*

title: Home Improvement
description: AFTER every, severe cold spell this department is literally swamped with queries from homeowners who complain about condensation problems which result in moisture accumulating on attic rafters or floor beams, in crawl spaces, or on the inside of windows, doors, closet walls and other cold surfaces. The problem may be only a slight nuisance or a more serious condition which has caused rotting of wood, peeling of paint, formation of mildew and the development of unsightly stains on plaster ceilings and walls.

title: Janice Doherty Bride in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23Mrs. Janice Reed Doherty of Cape Elizabeth, Me., who retired recently as a columnist for Gannett Publications in Maine, was married here this afternoon to T. Tarpy Schulten of Wobiwich, a former Republican State Senator in Maine. Judge Gerard Reilly, Chief Judge of the District of Columbia Court of Appeals, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Harrison, friends of the couple.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The onceinconsequential routine of obtaining gasoline is now formidable, chaotic and undignified, and it is another manifestation of the proliferating rot within our leadership.

title: Where Can Mental Patients Go?
description: Can thousands of mental patients be released from large institutions into facilities in residential communities without endangering the welfare of the neighborhoods?

title: Pop
description: THERE are two good, solid shocks to be gotten out of Leo. Sayer's Silverbird (Warner Bros. BS 7238), The first is that of seeing a thorougbly professional individualistic team of talents materialize like a vinyl apparition from virtually nowhere.

title: The travels and toils of a seaman
description: Calvin Kentfield went to sea shortly after World War II, when he was in his early twenties. In those days, he had the shyness, brass, impressionability, appetite, ignorance and egotism that are the common portion of young men. He had another quality that is not so common, literary talent  the impulse to turn his experience into something shapely. Eventually he took a vacation from the sea and began to write fiction, short stories and novels. Writing and shopping, he turned out several books. When he left the sea for good, he wrote some more. These memoirs are his seventh book.

title: ROONEY'S DISTRICT MAY BE HOPPED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 The Congressional district of Representative John J. Rooney, Democrat of Brooklyn, has emerged as the prime candidate for dismembering if the Justice Department requires that Brooklyn be reapportioned to create a second black district.

title: On the Road to Mandalay: 16 Square Miles of Temples in Pagan
description: SUPPER on the Burma Airline's onehour flight from Bangkok to Rangoon was a sandwich so thin couldn't be sure what the filling was. Something coconutcolored. It certainly didn't support the wall posters showing the passengers on the Boeing 727 having fun eating and drinking. But then, I consoled myself, I hadn't come to Burma for the sandwiches. I'd come to get a look at Pagan.

title: Andruss Retains Title
description: Bill Andruss of Fordham defended his Metropolitan intercollegiate squash racquets championship yesterday, defeating John Geffrey of Adelphi, 1510, 157, 156, in the 21st annual tournament at Stevens Tech.

title: Vorster, the Strong Man
description: LONDONBy stressing the perennial South African issues of being alerted to halting the advance of international Communism and having the Government's hands free to safeguard white civilization, the National party of Prime Minister John Vorster can be certain that its quarter century in office will be unbroken when the white 17 per cent of the country's population votes in April.

title: Sharp Cut Sought In School Districts
description: TRENTON  Dr. Edward W. Kilpatrick, the acting State Commissioner of Education, is urging the 5,000 members of New Jersey's school boards to reduce the number of districts in order to improve education and for the sake of saving money.

title: U.S. Is Joining Inquiry on Fuel
description: TRENTON  As part of a coordinated statelocal effort aimed at determining the root causes of the continuing energy crisis, the office of the United States Attorney for New Jersey has begun an inquiry into the State's petroleum industry.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
description: (HARVEY) COX: (THE) SEDUCTION OF THE SPIRIT  The City remains our existential polity. It exists at that ... level of life ... between the circle of family and friends on the one hand and imperium of mankind on the other, the level where life must be made civil as well as livable.

title: When to Go Forward and When to Go Back
description: JERUSALEMIf there was any doubt about the unique place Moshe Dayan occupies in the Israeli political spectrum, it was dispelled here last week. The 58yearold Defense Minister emerged simultaneously as the target of the largest spontaneous antiGovernment demonstration in Israel in years, and as the pivotal figure in Premier Golda Meir's efforts to form a successful coalition Government.

title: Car Pools Spread, but Riders Find Them Awkward
description: DETROIT, Feb. 23  Driving their own car to work is as inalienable to many Americans as the pursuit of happiness.

title: Super Midgets Rise From Junkyards
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.Sonny Sanders wiped the grease from his palms on his notsowhite driver's suit and, in a thick Bronx accent undiluted by residence in New Rochelle, said:

title: Sussex and Warren Begin Project to Conserve Resources
description: NEWTON  An ambitious Federally funded program geared to finding and solving environmental problems in Sussex and Warren Counties is finally under way after three years of preparation.

title: Tuna Fleet Reports Catch Is Running Ahead of 1973
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 23 (AP)The American tuna fleet, which set out two weeks late this year because of a strike over the price of fish, is reaping a heavy harvest.

title: Penguins Are Beaten By Bruins
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 23 (AP) Bobby Orr scored one goal and assisted on two others, Don Marcotte scored twice, and the Boston Bruins defeated the Pittsburgh Penguins, 62, today in a National Hockey League game.

title: Pamela Sill Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bertram A. Sill of Laurel Hollow, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Ann Sill, to William David Dexter, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Dexter of Monroe, Conn., and Goshen, N. H. Miss Sill and her fianc are graduates of the University of Rhode Island.

title: Athletic Grants for Women
description: Athletic scholarships for women are on the increase, but the demand far exceeds the supply. There are 400 applicants for 15 scholarships at the University of Miami and, according to Isabella bella Hutchinson, the director of into rcollegiate athletics for women, applications are still pouring in.

title: KRIEGEL GETS AID ON LINDSAY BOOK
description: A foundation established by the Ford Foundation to improve the quality of life in New York City has approved a $25,000 grant to enable Jay L. Kriegel, who was Mayor John V. Lindsay's closest aide, to prepare a history of the Lindsay years.

title: Wilson, on Own, Covers the Hustings
description: UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 23Malcolin Wilson is on his own now, campaigning to keep the job of Governor and making the endless round of political dinners that come enclosed in partisan optimism one after another, like the Inevitable foil wrapping on the banquet circuit's baked potatoes.

title: Energy and Change
description: The motorist waiting on line can hardly be expected to look at the socalled energy crisis with a large perspective; he or she is too worried about being able to get to work. Nevertheless, tentative evidence accumulates that the crisis, if it lasts as long as predicted, could have a redeeming effect on the quality of life in American cities.

title: JOHN DUNBAR DIES; REAL ESTATE MAN
description: John Atkinson Dunbar, a real estate broker, who took a leading part in assembling the land for the United Nations property along the East River, died yesterday at his home, 220 East 73d Street. His age was 73.

title: Boonton Camp Sale to Aid Essex Scouts
description: MORRISTOWN  Although, more than 11,500 youngsters participate in Boy Scout activities in Newark, Irvington and Belleville, and although enrollment in the 425 units in these Essex County cities increases monthly, the financial support for the council that supervises and funds their prohas been dwindling.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Wall Street finally got a brisk rally to cheer about last week as the DowJones industrials bounded ahead more than 35 points to finish at 855.99. Earlier in the month, the Dow had hovered just above the 800 level.

title: Design: New York A.I.A. residential awards
description: New York area architects are in troublemost of it of their own making. For too many of them, oil flows freely, banks thrust 6 per cent mortgages into clients' hands, materials are availableand business is booming.

title: Friendly enemies
description: The squirrel and the bear. It was Gide who semiruefully so described his early acerbic encounter with Cocteau; and we continue to see them as such, as Arthur Peters traces their ambiguous relation through 40 years in the rather tight little world of artistic Paris. Undoubtedly, for all his maneuvering, Cocteau, in this series of exchanges seems far more likeable than Gide. In the seventies, ins the United States at least, be is closer to the artistic mood of the moment. This would not be true of today's Paris.

title: At Brown, Trend Is Back To Grades and Tradition
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 23  In 1969, Brown University took a huge step for a traditionminded Ivy League school. To much national acclaim, it thoroughly revamped its curriculum, making grades optional, dropping nearly all course requirements, and establishing special courses and programs to give students the educational freedom and flexibility they said they desired.

title: Dance
description: MAURICE BEJART is such a likable and honest man, that I continue to feel regretful at not respecting his work more. The other day he was given an awardtogether with Gerald Arpino and Antony Tudor Dance Magazine. His acceptance speech was not just modest in the arts a crook can be modest and frequently isbut had that distinctive mixture of humility and arrogance that so often proclaims the true artist.

title: There's No DoubtJack Nicholson Is a Major Star
description: AL ASHBY'S new film, The Last Detail, adapted by Robert Towne from Darryl Ponicsan's novel, is about the final, desperate spree that two aging career sailors force upon the 18yearold apprentice seaman they're escorting from Norfolk, Va., to the naval prison in Portsmouth, N.H. The kid, a witless innocent whose only failing is his kleptomania, has been sentenced to eight years in the brig for attempting to steal $40 from the polio contribution box that was the favorite charity of the base commander's wife.

title: Stealing People
description: While political kidnapping is a grim tradition among LatinAmerican revolutionary movements, in the United States the idea of stealing a person for political gain has never really caught on. Kidnappings here have for the most part had ransom as the motive. And underground political movements, however militant on the right or left, have generally avoided the crime of kidnapping altogether.

title: Local Craftsmen Set Up a Shop in Brooklyn
