description: Just another boomlet in the arts and crafts explosion? Not to the group of neighbors who own Hand Wrought, a fourmonthold crafts shop at 663 Vanderbilt Avenue in Brooklyn. For one thing, say the owners, It is the only shop of, its kind in Prospect Heights, the small brownstonedotted neighborhood near the southern end of Prospect Park. Also, it is owned and operated cooperatively by 14 local craftsmen as an outlet for their creative energies and a neighborhood focal point.

title: A New TV Series Aids ForeignBorn
description: TRENTONAn experimental television series designed to help the foreignborn adult improve his English is being shown on New Jersey Public Broadcasting stations every Friday at 3:30 P.M.

title: Utility Delays New Plant
description: WESTBORO, Mass., Feb. 23 (AP)The New England Power Company has announced a delay of at least a year in the construction of a $300million generating plant in Salem, Mass. The 880megawatt, fossilfuel plant had been scheduled to open in 1978.

title: Pair Seized After Child Leads Police to Home
description: The mother of a 3yearold boy and her male companion were arrested on drug and weapon charges early yesterday after the police were led to the mother's apartment by the child, who was wandering the streets in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.

title: Mrs. Spruance Wins In Squash Racquets
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 23  Mrs. Halsey Spruance, the defending titleholder, and Ginny Akabane, seeded second to her moved to the, final round of the United States women's squash racquets championship today at the Wilmington Country Club.

title: U.S. SUBMITS BRIEF IN INTEGRATION CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) The Nixon Administration urged the Supreme Court today to erase an appeals court decision demanding citysuburban school busing to achieve racial balance in metropolitan Detroit.

title: Trying to Keep Track of All Those Appeals For Charity
description: WASHINGTONThis is a personal note. It is intended to describe a rather baffling problem, not a solution. The problem is familiar to many people; this is how it seems to me.

title: State Shifts Emphasis in Cultural Aid
description: Long Island's share of state cultural funds was reduced slightly for 197374 as the. New York. State Council on the Arts distributed $451318 among 56 organizations in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. The state funds are also being distributed with a different emphasis this year, with professional performing groups being favored over sttch things as school programs.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: PhoneRate Rise Opposed

title: Podoloff 1 of 3. Named to Shrine
description: SPRINGFIELD, MASS., Feb. 23 (UPI)Maurice Podoloff, the first commissioner of the National Basketball Association, and two other pioneers from the game's early years were named today to the National Basketball Hall of Fame.

title: Waldrop Wins Mile In 3:56.4
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Feb. 23 (AP)Tony Waldrop, a senior at North Carolina, broke the fourminute mile tonight for the sixth straight time indoors this season.

title: Susan Logan Is Fiancee Of Hedrick Whitman 3d
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 23 Miss Susan Logan, an admissions officer at Briarcliff College, and Hendricks Hallett Whitman 3d, a medical student at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, will be married this summer.

title: In Italy, It's a Pocketful of Troubks for Television
description: A FEW weeks ago, Italians found themselves under what newspaper headlines called a toysterious alert. As heavily armed policemen and military personnel conspicuously patrolled the streets, no offcial reason was ever given for the Shortlived alert, but rumor, always a highly refined art in Italy, settled on either a new threat from Arab terrorists or the possibility of a rightwing coup ?? within the country.

title: I.C.4A Title Track Saturday and Sunday At Princeton, N.J.
description: 60Yard DashJesse Owens, Army, and Ike Owens, Navy, 6.1; Mike Sands, Penn State, Marshall Best, Army, Nick Basciano, Maryland, Alfred Daley and Rich Treadwell, Seton Hall, Mike Seitz, Penn, Rich Berryman, Dartmouth, and Joe Newsome, Williams, 6.2.

title: Gardens
description: INDOOR gardeners, who nave never tried vowing exotic succulents from seed have a delightful experience ahead of them. They grow as easily as begonias and make weirdly beautiful house plants.

title: Turbines May Haul Shore Line Trains
description: TRENTON  The Byrne administration is moving cautiously on a costly proposal to electrify the New York & Long Branch Railroad, which serves thousands of Jersey shore commuters.

title: Pacific Islanders More Critical of the U. S.
description: PORT MORESBY, Papua New Guinea  Politically conscious Pacific islanders are increasingly critical of the American role in this emerging region, where the United States directly controls the islands of Guam,, American Samoa and Micronesia, besides a number of barren, uninhabited islands south and west of Hawaii.

title: Recordings
description: LAURITZ MELCHIOR, who died a year ago, was for more than two decades the world's preeminent Wagner tenor. At Covent Garden from the mid twenties to the end of the thirties he had no serious rival as Siegmund, Siegfried or Tristan. Only the outbreak of World War II ended his ascendency at that house.

title: Zurich's Bahnhofstrasse Is the World's Richest Street
description: THE WORLD'S richest street is not the ChampsElyse in Paris, Fifth Avenue in New York or Bond Street in London. It's a little street in Zurich, Switzerland, Called the Bahnhofstrasse, or Railroad Station Street, a name so banal it sounds downright chic.

title: Discoverer of Our Continental Experience
description: September, 1929. The man across the desk from me in a loftlike office in Holyoke House (now gone) was like no other I had ever encountered. He was short, intense, all movement (bobbing his head like the expert pugilist he still was), all eyes and especially all voice. I can hear the voice nowpraising, cajoling, punctuated with more profanity than was then common in academic halls, with whoops of delight, snorts of indignation, and laughter that at times shook the spare and ugly office furniture.

title: Epilogue
description: A delicate matter involving an indelicate amount of money has finally been resolved between the United States and India. An agreement has been reached for the disposal in India of just over $3billion in Americanowned rupees accumulated by the United States from food grain sales to India. In a quiet ceremony in New Delhi last week, Ambassador Daniel P. Moynihan gave the Indian Secretary of Finance a check for 16.64billion rupees, approximately $2billion, as a grant for agricultural development and social welfare projects. The remaining $1billion will be used by the United States in India.

title: The Partners
description: If sometimes it seems the novel is on a lost weekendwords for booze and the ego a terrible drunkthere is always Louis Auchincloss to sober up on. He writes about realities you can verify, an orderly society with values your dad understands, and he believes in telling stories. If Auchincloss himself is to be found in his fiction, it's through his perceptions rather than his visions. Far more important to a reading of Auchincloss is his profession as a Wall Street lawyer than any possible artistic rearrangement he has in mind concerning the nonart of living. Auchincloss is a pouredinconcrete realist, although the concrete is always the best that money can buy. He stands for class and toughmindedness, as the reader may remember from such previous works as The Injustice Collectors, Portrait in Brownstone and The Rector of Jus.

title: Muffy Dent Planning Marriage To John D. Stuart in Summer
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23Frederick Daily Dent, Secretary of Commerce, and Mrs. Dent have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mildred Hutcheson Dent, to John Douglas Stuart, son of Mrs. Richard E. Dole of Lynnville, Tenn., and Charles Edward Stuart of Boyce, Va., who is with Shenandoah Farms there, a realestate concern.

title: Levitt Accuses H.R.A. of Laxity On Forgeries of Relief Checks
description: ALBANY, Feb. 23  State Controller Arthur Levitt charged today that lax procedures in the city's Human Resources Administration had allowed imposters to obtain photo identification cards under false names for use in cashing stolen welfare checks.

title: Wright Victor In Ski Jumping
description: ISHPEMING, Mich., Feb. 23 (UPI)Jeff Wright of Minneapolis took top honors in the Class A Division of the Paul Bietila Memorial skijumping meet today with jumps of 253 and 259 feet. Wright, a member of the United States ski team, jumped to an American record 476 feet at Oberstdorf, West Germany.

title: What's New in Theater
description: THE GREAT MACDADDY, the Negro Ensemble Company's production of a musical by Paul Carter Harrison with music by ColeridgeTaylor Perkinson, got 4 favorable reviews (Barnes, Times; Gottfried, Women's Wear; Wynne, Bergen Record; Glover, AP), 6 mixed (Watts, Post; Wallach, Newsday; Oliver, New Yorker; Clurinan, Nation; Stasio, Cue; Hewes, Saturday Review/World) and 3 negative reviews (Watt, News; Scudder, WINSRadio; Novick, Village Voice).

title: Canclide, or a Very Moving Story
description: LET'S put it this way: If you had a wildly successful and highly unusual show galloping along to the tune of ecstatic reviews and soldout houses and no end in sight, would you close down, put everything in cold storage and then announce plans to reopen, six weeks later, in a completely different place, promising all the while that nothing, not a splinter or stitch of your show's unique staging, would be permitted to suffer or be changed in the slightest? Whew!

title: What They Are Saying
description: Coach John Wooden, in a prophetic comment on the play of his U.C.L.A. seniors before their two recent losses: Mainly it's a matter of telling them something and they nod Yes and they do exactly what you don't want them to do. There were a couple of times one game when we told them during a timeout to change to the fullcourt press, but the adjustment was not made. In other words, we get lip servicethey listen but do not hear.

title: Sabich Takes Pro Giant Slalom
description: BOYNE MOUNTAIN, Mich., Fab. 23Spider Sabich, the former Olympian, captured the $15,000 Benson & Hedges Grand Prix giant slalom today as the professional ski troupe started its western swing. Sabich defeated Renzo Zandegiacomo, the troupe's leading rookie, in the final when the Italian fell in both headtohead final heats. The victory, worth $5,000, advanced Sabich to third place in season earnings with $20,300. Hugo Nindl of Austria tops the list with $27,700, followed by Zandegiacomo with $21,500.

title: NIGERIA'S PRESS LARGE AND ACTIVE
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 16In a strong criticism of Nigeria's federal military Government, a columnist recently wrote in the independent Nigerian Tribune that things were worse in Nigeria now than they have been since independence in 1960.

title: SHAH FINDS NO CUT IN OIL FLOW TO U.S.
description: The Shah of Iran has suggested that the United States is now importing at least as much oil as it did before the Arab embargo was imposed during the Mideast war last October and that the oil industry may have engineered present gasoline shortages here to increase their profits.

title: BRITISH ADS SEEKING REDUCED BIRTH RATE
description: LONDON, Feb. 23 (Reuters) A major publicity camnaign to cut Britain's birth rate has been started under the slogan, What are your chances of getting pregnant tonight? That is the title of a quiz appearing as newspaper advertisements.

title: LILCO Bid For Rise In Rates Assailed
description: MINEOLA, L. I.  The height of unmitigated gall and the public is caught in an evertightening economic vise were two typical reactions by public officials last week to the Long Island Lighting Company's request for a 19 per increase in electric rates.

title: Music: Operaby Argento
description: Although New York's music diet is extraordinarily rich and varied, there is at least one area in which it might be called deficient, and that has to do with American opera evolution and experimentation. In Minneapolis, for example, concoctions stirred up by the Minnesota Opera (formerly the Center Opera) have been considerably more venturesome than fare we create here.

title: Memories and Marks of Two Invaders Linger on the Shores, of Normandy
description: LIKE a vast shrine, the French province of Normandy draws devotees of military history, medieval and modem, who come to stand Where William the Conqueror set out to seize the English throne and where, on DDay almost nine centuries later, the Allied armies waded ashore to begin the conquest of Germany. However remote the events of 1066 and 1944 may seem elsewhere, in Normandy the reminders are all around. Almost every town evokes memories of one invasion or the other; some places recall both. Altogether, the pilgrim has the sense of treading on hallowed ground.

title: Monorail Over the Turnpike?
description: TRENTON  A sleek, 100milesanhour monorail train races northward high above the traffic on the New Jersey Turnpike, making occasional stops at parkandride stations before finally zooming across a dramatic Hudson River suspension bridge and into midtown Manhattan.

title: A gradual chilling, a fear of dreadful things
description: LONDON. Sir, the letter in The Times read, the time for decision has come. The Government must stand firm. If the miners go on strikeand the signs are that they willthen the Government must act swiftly, firmly and effectively. The writer, Andrew Vincenti, went on to suggest that all picket lines be broken, the troops called out and the miners be drafted, if necessary.

title: Windjamming Through the Caribbean
description: YOU should know this about me. I am an organizer. And a worrier, I like to make things happen. I get nervous when they don't. I have been called reliable, responsible, controlling,

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HEERENVEEN, the Netherlands, Feb. 23 (UPI)Sheila Young, the 23yearold skating and cycling world champion from Detroit, led the overall standing at the halfway mark of the world speedskating championships today. The defending champion, Atje KeulenDeelstra of the Netherlands, was second and Tatiana Averina of the Soviet Union third.

title: 6 United States Prelates Meet With Pope in Vatican
description: ROME, Feb. 23Three American Cardinals and three other prelates, representing the Roman Catholic bishops' Conference in the United States, had a joint audience with Pope Paul VI today in the Vatican.

title: Ray to Seek 4th Term
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 23 (AP)Gov. Robert Ray has made an expected announcement that he will seek an unprecedented fourth term. Mr. Ray, a Republican, said last October that he would not run for the United States Senate, but would either return to private law practice or seek another term.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: This Week in Sports
description: Pro Basketball

title: ROSENBERG DATA BEING QUESTIONED
description: The recognition code, one of the crucial bits of evidence linking Julius and Ethel Rosenberg with a Soviet spymaster, has been called into question.

title: Toward a Decision ...
description: Impeachment is a political remedy for grave offenses against the constitutional order. Long unused, its historical origins dusty and unfamiliar, impeachment appears ?? today's Congress as a venture into unknown territory; but two events, one political and one intellectual, pushed the House of Representatives closer last week toward a decision on the impeachment of President Nixon.

title: A Random Ticket Plan For Knicks' Playoffs
description: A limited number of tickets for Knick playoff games will be available for public sale through a postcard selection system.

title: Tenafly Will Vote on Tract
description: TENAFLY  Residents of this Bergen County community will vote tomorrow on whether to float a bond issue and thus try to purchase one of the most highly prized pieces of undeveloped land within 20 miles of New York City.

title: 35,000 Fans Expected At Aqueduct Opening
description: Aqueduct Race track opens the New York thoroughbred season tomorrow, the earliest in the history of the sport in this state. With things relatively serene on the labor front, and with easy accessibility to the track by subway, Tom Fitzgerald, vice president and treasurer of the New York Racing Associaton, is confident that a crowd of 35,000 will be on hand for this earliest of openings. Jack Krumpe, the president of N.Y.R.A., considers Fitzgerald's figure a little optimistic but hopes that he's right, adding that a lot depends on the weather.

title: Return to Syrian Rule Worries a Druse Village
description: HARFA, Occupied Syria, Feb. 19For Abu Yousef, the head of this small Druse village near the IsraeliSyrian ceasefire line, the prospect of a negotiated troopseparation agreement between Israel and Syria looms as a mixed blessing.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: For the last few days, this writer has been making plans for a canoe excursion down Florida's Peace River, one of the several lovely, often wild, streams that meet the saltwater along the state's west coast.

title: Pincay Wins 4th of Day Astride Prince Dantan
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 23 (AP)  Prince Dantan scored his first stakes victory as Laffit Pincay Jr. rode his fourth winner of the day in the $85,300 San Antonio Stakes today at Santa Anita.

title: Navy Keeps Heptagonal Track Title
Editors' Choice
description: Fiction and Poetry

title: Ski Carnival Encounters Bad Weather
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 23  Middlebury College's Mountain Club had no difficulty holding, in marginal conditions, its special slalom event in its annual winter carnival today, but gusty winds and icy surfaces thwarted the scheduled ski jump.

title: Egypt Said to Offer to Negotiate With Israel on Behalf of Syria
description: CAIRO, Feb. 23 (Reuters)Egypt's military delegation at the Geneva peace talks has offered to negotiate with Israel on behalf of Syria, the semiofficial Cairo daily Al Ahram said today.

title: TWO NEW DANCES BY MARTIN GROUP
description: In an odd fashion the often striking parts of Erin Martin's dances interrupt the whole design. The bustle and the glitter, while enjoyable, somehow elude being shaped into a coherent pattern. Miss Martin's company presented the first of two programs Friday evening at the American Theater Laboratory.

title: Patricia Annette Pollock Engaged
description: RYE, N. Y., Feb. 23Miss Patricia Annette Pollock, who expects to graduate in May from Newton (Mass.) College of the Sacred Heart, plans to be married Sept. 7 to Edward Coleman Haley, who is in the management training program at the Chemical Bank in New York.

title: Shore Housing Fans a Dispute
description: POINT PLEASANT Clark's Landing, area residents say, is the last place in town where a person can rent a rowboat and push off into the Manasquan River.

title: TEACHERS PRESSING BALTIMORE STRIKE
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 23The Baltimore teachers strike, now three weeks old, showed no signs of any impending settlement today.

title: RED TIDE OUTBREAK HITS GULF RESORTS
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 23  SFate marine biologists have been investigating a red tide condition off Gulf of Mexico resorts from Clearwater to Sarasota.

title: Diary of a (Theater) Mad Housewife
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn. Oct. 21, 1973. DEAR DIARY: READ a marvelous article on the first page of The New York Times Arts and Leisure Section today. It was most humorous and concerned with the popularity of dinner theaters in the United States today, concentrating on the Coach, Light Dinner Theater just 15 miles from our door.

title: April Is Aim To Launch Courageous
description: Late April is the target date for the launching of Courageous, one of the two aluminum 12meter yachts vying with the wooden Intrepid to defend the America's Cup on Sept. 10 against either France or Australia. The boat is framed and decked and we're planking her now, said Briggs Dalzell, comanager of the Courageous Syndicate. The boat is not far enough along yet, he said, to speculate if it will encounter any of the troubles met by Southern Cross, the Australian aluminum entry, whose mast snapped eight days ago during inshore trials off Yanchep.

title: True Knight Runs 2d
description: HALI ANDALE, Fla., Feb. 23Lazy F. Ranch's Forego, who staggered to a nose triumph over True Knight in the Donn Handicap two Weeks ago, dominated the $120,600 Gulfstream Park Handicap today and defeated True Knight by half a length. The margin was deceptive. The two horses were head and head at the threesixtenths pole, but Forego had his rival measured all the way.

title: Notes: Just 10 Months To Make Yule Plans
description: THERE are still 304 days to Christmas, but if you are thinking of a yearend vacation in the sun, it is not too early to make an airline reservation. Indeed, a few flights are already completely booked from New York to San Juan, Puerto Rico, and St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands, on Friday, Dec. 20, which is 299 days away and the one day of the year when almost everyone who is getting away for the holidays will be wanting to fly. But seats remain available on most flights from Dec. 15 to Dec, 25 to highly popular destinations in the Caribbean, Florida and Mexico, according to this writer's survey of eight carriers.

title: Movies
description: LOS ANGELES FOR years Easterners have been predicting the demise of Hollywood, and although Hollywood is still very much alive, it is changing. One indication is that many of the acclaimed American films of the last year or soSounder, Mean Streets, Sisters, Bang the Drum Slowly, Serpico, Badlandswere independently financed, and began production without the slightest guarantee of distribution.

title: 2 Die in Canada Road Pileup
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 23 (AP)Three trucks collided on an icy highway today and 60 cars piled up behind them, police officials reported. Two persons were killed and 10 injured.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Aaron, Two Others Tied at 210 in Golf
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 23  Tommy Aaron, the Masters champion, oneputted the last seven greens today and gained a share of the 54hole lead in the $260,000 Jackie Gleason Inverrary tournament with Leonard Thompson and Roy Pace with scores of 210.

title: Peronist Rightists Open Fire On a Newspaper Building
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 23 (UPI)The police cordoned off an area surrounding the leftist newspaper El Mundo today after Peronist right  wing youths fired on the newspaper building for about 15 minutes.

title: St. John's Chalks Up 10th in Row
description: St. John's took one more step in its drive to earn a postseason basketball tournament bid last night and stepped on the chances of Seton Hall with a 6853 victory before an exuberant crowd of 5,180 in the Redmen's Queens gym.

title: Stephen Zrike And Sara Docal Plan Marriage
description: WOODBRIDGE, Conn., Feb. 23Mr. and Mrs. Gonzalo C. Docal of Woodbridge, formerly of Havana, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara de Lourdes Docal, to Stephen, Kenneth Zrike. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Warren Zrike of Greenwich.

title: The Region
description: The Nassau County Republican Party, which lived up to its reputation as the best political machine east of Chicago by being one of the few G.O.P. organizations to emerge unharmed by Watergate last November, is dazed and shaken after a series of indictments that has left it vulnerable come November.

title: Linda Bronander Wed to P.J. Haebler
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J., Feb. 23  In St. Luke's Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Linda Karin Bronander, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilhelm Bertil Bronander of Upper Montclair, was married to Paul Joseph Haebler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Haebler of Charleton City, Mass. The Rev. John C. Owens performed the ceremony.

title: SpeedLimit Dispute Erupts in Germany
description: BONN, Feb. 23  A major controversy over superhighway speed limits erupted in West Germany this week. Overnight, a population that accepted speed limit of 100 kilometers an hour (62 miles an hour) in November to save gasoline has rebelled at the idea of accepting higher limits to save lives.

title: Murder and Kidnapping Prove They Exist
description: SAN FRANCISCOAt first there was a reluctance to believe they were real. They came to national attention last November by boasting of the assassination of Oakland's black Superintendent of Schools, but the murder, still shrouded in mystery, did not seem to square with their leftist rhetoric.

title: EDUCATION BOARDS VOW COOPERATION
description: The Board of Higher Education and the Board of Education, traditionally indifferent to each other, are developing new working arrangements that are expected to produce major innovations in school and college practices here.

title: Soccer player, more victim than hero
description: The Glory Game presents to American readers a world as esoteric as Paper Lion did to readers in England. The grass roots of soccer in the United States are growing at a pace which suggests that in 20 years, it could become major national sport. For the moment, however, it's the greedy giants of the gridiron, those opportunists in shoulder pads so chillingly presented to us by George Plimpton, who rule the roost.

title: Michigan Wildlife Groups Plan A Transplant of Timber Wolves
description: MARQUETTE, Mich., Feb. 23 In an effort to increase the dwindling population of wolves in Michigan, four Eastern timber wolves will be flown in from Minnesota this month to the Huron Mountain Club north of here.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Authority

title: France Is Alone
description: The headline over a frontpage editorial in Le Monde last week on France's puzzling performance in the energy crisis was the single word, SEUL...alone. NonGaullist politicians and newspapers in France, except for the Communists, have been lambasting the Pompidou regimeless perhaps for opposing American proposals at the Washington energy conference than for breaking with its eight Common Market partners there. But, despite worldwide opprobrium, the French Government seems curiously unperturbed.

title: F. T. C. TO RELEASE DATA ON INQUIRIES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)The Federal Trade Commission has decided to make public a broad range of actions previously kept secret, Lewis A. Engman, chairman of the commission, has announced.

title: Hijacker Had Picketed White House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23Samuel J. Byck, who killed two persons, critically wounded a third and then committed suicide after an unsuccessful attempt yesterday to hijack a jet at the BaltimoreWashinston International Airport, was no stranger to the Secret Service and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Bridal Planned
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., Feb. 23 Dr. John Colver Wilsey, a surgeon and chief of staff at the Greenwich Hospital, and Mrs. Wilsey have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne DeForest Wilsey, to Paul Scott Marshall, son of Paul Wesley Marshall of Pittsburgh and the late Mrs. Rachel Jones Marshall

title: When Does a Portrait Become a Memento Mori?
description: A LICE NEEL is a portrait painter with a vengeance. The large retrospective of her portraits now on ?? at the Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue (through March 17) is not what one would call a pleasant experience. The exhibition, which includes some 58 works, dating from 1933 to the present, has very few sweet or flattering likenesses. Its is more like a savage chronicle of the cultural celebrities of the American art scene and the bohemian lifestyles of the past decade or more, when Mrs. Neel began to acquire a serious reputetion among New York artists and critics. It is a very personal record, in which the artist seems to have fixed upon the angst, anguish, wretchedness, vanity or arrogance of her subjectsas if life were, always, some form of irremediable disease.

title: Play Ball? First, You Have To Get Out to the Ballpark
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 23Baseball staged its first full weekend of 1974 outdoors today and found that these were indeed times that try men's souls: On the long lines poking into gasoline stations, Tom Seaver worked a crossword puzzle, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn read a Graham Greene, novel and Jerry Grote fiddled with the radio.

title: At the Met: Sour Notes From Backstage
description: THERE'S a job open at the Metropolitan Operaor at least it is open as these lines are written. It's a job that has certain requirements: a good knowledge of music in general: and of opera in particular; a Thorough knowledge of the singing voice; a firsthand knowledge of singers and their capabilities in the opera houses of the world; administrative ability; a knowledge of opera production; a working knowledge of Italian, German and French as well as of English; the ability to get along with musicians; the knack of working up an interesting repertory for a long opera season; a passionate desire for perfection.

title: Neptune Victor In Jersey Track
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 23John Chambers of Neptune led his team to the New Jersey State Group 4 track and field title today at the Jersey City Armory as he set an allgroup record of 6.2 seconds in the 60yard dash.

title: About the Yankees ...
description: Bobby Murcer, the Yankees' highest salaried player, hasn't been offered a raise over last year's $100,000. Clubhouse conversation: Rick Dempsey to Thurman Munson: Hey, Thurman, did you sell your Mercedes? Munson: Now, I couldn't part with it. Listener: Why were you going to sell it? Munson: Because I ordered another one. ... Joe Pactwa, who's trying to make the team as a pitcher after failing as an outfielder, arrived to find nameplate over his locker: Pawacta. . . . plane carrying an advertising streamer caught the eye of the players during the workout. The advertisement was for a local movie theater currently showing a triple feature: Deep Throat, The Devil in Miss Jones and Behind the Green Door.... Bill Sudakis, the first player to take batting practice, hit the first home run for the Yankees in spring training.

title: F.T.C. TO RELEASE DATA ON INQUIRIES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)The Federal Trade Commission has decided to make public abroad range of actions previously kept secret, Lewis A. Engman, chairman of the commission, has announced.

title: Soviet Union Women Win In Nordic Ski
description: FALUN, Sweden, Feb. 23 (UPI)The Soviet Union and East Germany won gold medals today at the world Nordic ski championships. A powerful Russian quartet won the women's 20kilometer relay and HansGeorg Aschenbach captured his second gold medal in the ski jumping by winning on the 90mter hill.

title: Wallace ExAide Paroled
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 23 (UPI)Seymore Trammell, who served as State Finance Director under Goys. George C. Wallace and Lurleen Wallace and handled Mr. Wallace's 1968 Presidential campaign financing, has been paroled from Federal prison. He served 13 months of his fouryear sentence for income tax evasion.

title: Amin Names an ExPrincess As Uganda Foreign Minister
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Feb. 23 (Agence FrancePresse)President Idi Amin has named a former princess as his Foreign Minister.

title: A Salute to Poetry at Monmouth
description: WEST LONG BRANCHMonmouth College is devoting tomorrow to the consideration of poetry.

title: 2 Charged in Atlanta In Editor's Abduction
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 23  The police recovered almost $700,000 in ransom early today after arresting and charging an exconvict and his wife in the abduction of 4. Reginald Murphy, the 40yearold editorialpage editor of The Atlanta Constitution.

title: Daughter to the Kisches
description: A daughter was born to Dr. and Mrs. Alexander L. Kisch of Albuquerque, N.M., on Feb. 2 in the Presbyterian Hospital there. The child, the couple's second daughter, is named Amy Yael.

title: HEARST AWAITING REPLY TO 2D OFFER
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23Randolph A. Hearst waited todal for It response from the kidnappers of his 20yearold daughter to a counterproposal he made yesterday.

title: The World
description: When the public service unions in West Germany struck earlier this month and his Government caved in by granting an 11 per cent raise, it was perhaps understandable that Chancellor Willy Brandt felt betrayed. Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, Der Spiegel and Bild Zeitung, three influential publications of differing political stances, all printed reports, without identifying sources, that he had threatened to resign.

title: Canaan Helps Raise Bail for a Local Youth Accused of Murdering His Mother
description: CANAAN, Conn., Feb. 23Peter Reilly, an 18yearold ??outh accused of slashing and stomping his mother to death ??ere five months ago was wel??omed home to this quiet little ??own in the Berkshire foothills ??his week to the cheers of ??riends and neighbors who ??elped raise $50,000 for his ??ail.Most of the money came in a ??ingle contribution from an outofstate donor who had never ??net the youth. The rest was ??aised through cookie sales, ??lances, doortodoor solicitation and hundreds of small contributions.

title: YEARLY FOOD COSTS FOR FAMILY AT $1,680
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) The yearly cost of a typical family food market basket rose to a new record of nearly $1,680 in January, it was learned today.

title: Hodes's Boedromion Danced In Premiere by Faison Company
description: Any rafters at the Hunter College Playhouse would have rung with the revival shouts of All right, George, turn it out, which punctuated the George Faison Universal Dance Experience's third program on Friday. The audience was rightly enthusiastic, not only because it was so good to see Mr. Faison again, but also because he has a company full of personality and verve. There are some fine dancers, especially the males, lead by Gary DeLoatch. Leah Randolph and Graciela Simpson are notable among the women.

title: Now even whites in Los Angeles say of Bradley:
description: LOS ANGELES. The San Fernando Valley is probably the best example of the spectacular suburban growth that has blanketed the sunbelt states of the West and the South since the war. Thirty years ago it was an isolated area of orange groves and truck farms, untouched by the freeways that have since slashed through the Hollywood Hills, binding the valley in their concrete grasp to the fortunes of the Los Angeles metropolis. Today more than one million people five in this northwestern section of the city, dwelling in comfortable, if unoriginal homes, shopping at convenient, if impersonal malls, eating at fast, if indistinguishable restaurants that have finally created, not a meltingpot culture, but a fryingpan culture. A Big Mac is a Big Mac is a Big Mac.

title: Numismatics
description: MINDBOGGLING is the best way to describe some of the totals in the U.S. Mint's recently released official report of coinage production for 1973. If the year had been just a few days longer the total production of all three Mint facilities. (Philadelphia, Denver and San Francisco) would have reached ten billion coins! The actual total (as shown in the official chart above) was 9, 740,000,000 coinsand that's a mountain of coins that isn't easy to visualize even in these days of big figures. It is of course, the Mint's alltime high; the previous, production record of 9,600,000,000 coins of all denomination was set in 1966.

title: Miss Ireys Is Bride of Earl Gandel
description: Miss Catherine Recknagel Ireys was married yesterday afternoon to Earl David Gandel of New York and Southampton, L. I. The Rev. Franklin Goldthwatte Sherrill 2d, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride in Brooklyn.

title: Television
description: BACK into your hives, all of you. It is time once again to deplore a trend. Gloria Swanson will appear on Tuesday night in a madeforABCTV movie in Which she runs small town because she possesses a strange power. The movie is called Killer Bees. Killer bees?

title: No Longer Marionettes to Visitors From the North
description: RIO DE JANEIROWhat we really want is to be treated as equals, a Brazilian Army officer told a United States reporter a few days ago, trying to hide years of accumulated resentment. He might well have been speaking for the 24 LatinAmerican Foreign Ministers who met with Secretary of State Kissinger in Mexico City.

title: Friday's Fight
description: San DiegoDavid Love, 155 pounds, San Diego, outpointed Chuchu Garcia, 154, Reynosta, Mexico, 10 rounds.

title: New Utrecht, Taft Gain in Playoffs
description: New Utrecht and Taft advanced to the semifinals of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball playoffs yesterday at Staten Island Community College.

title: Georgia George Married
description: Miss Georgia George, daughter of Mrs. John P. Umbach of New York and Spyros George of New Port Richey, Fla., was married here yesterday afternoon to Andreas Eleftheriou, son of Mr. and Mrs. Costas Eleftheriou of Brooklyn, formerly of Nicosia, Cyprus. The ceremony in the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity was performed by the Rev. Anthimos Draconakis.

title: Knicks Beat Hawks, 9890, Here
description: Generale Hospital would have been a more suitable scene than Madison Square Garden for last night's game between the Knicks and the Atlanta Hawks, which the Knicks managed to win, thanks to superior medical insurance, 9890.

title: A Townhouse on Madison Ave. Lives Out Its Numbered Days
description: An undetected Victorian turret on Upper Broadway, a drooping facade on Charles Street such is the stuff of dreams for a New York City building watcher. A building watcher's eyes, like a tourist's, are Usually cast upward, seeking out architectural ornament rather than shopwindow displays, reading New York, the real New York, in its buildings.

title: Louisiana Gets Flood Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)  President Nixon declared today a major disaster for Louisiana because of flooding that began Jan. 21 had caused extensive damage to public and private property. The White House, announcing his action, said that designated areas of the state would now be eligible for Federal relief funds.

title: Rosemary Mac Isaac Wed to P.R. Hundt
description: In the Roman Catholic Church of Our Savior here yesterday afternoon, Miss Rosemary Mac Isaac, Baughter of Mrs. James Walter Mac Isaac of Bayonne, N.J., and the late Mr. Mac Isaac, became the bride of Paul Robert Hundt. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick William Hundt. of Kew Gardens, Queens.

title: Smith and Newcombe Win To Gain Pro Tennis Final
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Feb. 23  Neither Brian Fairlie, Alex Metreveli nor the gloom of night could prevent John Newcombe, and Stan Smith from completing their appointed rounds today at the World Championship of Tennis tournament in Nassau Coliseum. They will meet tomorrow in the final for the $10,000 first prize.

title: Use of Public Transit Soars in Gasoline Crisis
description: The cherished axiom that Americans cannot be enticed out of their automobiles by mass transportation appears to be dissolving under the energy shortage. Many transit lines in the country are experiencing the biggest gains in riders since the postwar boom.

title: Yale Teacher, 79, Rides Bike And Keeps Campus Enthralled
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 23The Rev. Roland H. Bainton, Titus Street Professor of Ecclestical History emeritus at the Yale Divinity School, drove his car to his office the other day. But, that was only because his 25yearold bicycle was being fixed.

title: Is the U.S. Running Out of Wheat?
description: The possibility that American stocks of wheat may be exhausted sometime this spring and that flour and bread may become scarce Items on grocers' shelves should be perceived as part of an issue far beyond the supply of sandwich bread or hamburger buns.

title: Book Ends
description: Ode to Joy. you'll notice that appended to the usual publisher data in the listing for The Joy of Sex on the Best Seller List is paperback price. Joy is indeed busting out all over the bookstores in a largesize paperback format, retailing for $4.95. Simon & Schuster reports the first printing of 625,000 is already sold out and another printing of half a million has been ordered. Crown, who published the hardcover edition, had similar problems keeping up with the demand when its first printing came out. They printed only 15,000 but the book took off, and Crown had to set up an air lift of copies from the printers In Holland. As a $12.95 hardback the book has spent 62 weeks on the list, usually hovering around the numberone spot, and has sold 775,000 copies. Joy is a compendium of sexual techniques, some bordering on the outr, if an ing is outr any more, and earthy, bawdy advice on a wide range of sexual hangups and inhibitions, all copiously illustrated with drawings of couples in Pogronte. On the title page it says edited by Alex Comfort but change that to by Alex Comfort. Dr. Comfort, a British human biologist who now lives in America and an authority on aging, did write the book but professional ethics kept him from advertising it. Originally, Joy was in the form of sexual cookbook, and is still called A Gourmet Guide to Lovemaking, but Crown toned this down. The result is a compromise, with headings such as Sauces and Pickles covering such exotic techniques as  and The publicity woman at Crown tells us that this book is the most stolen free reviewers' copy in history. Publishers Weekly Intended doing a story on this oddity, but unfortunately the copy sent to the reporter doing the story was stolen.

title: COAL RESEARCH UNIT TO BE REORGANIZED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) The Federal Government's Office of Coal Research will be reorganized and expanded to lead an accelerated drive to convert coal into clean energy, Rogers C. B. Morton, Secretary of the Interior, has announced.

title: The Limits of Corporate Responsibility
description: In the wake of the traumatic riots that shook American cities in the 1960's, many businessmen suddenly began sounding like social activists. They stumped the ghetto to recruit the hardcore unemployed, launched training programs for dropouts, and started to counsel and fund minorityowned businesses. Hardly a week passed without a speech by a bluechip executive on corporate responsibility or the new social contract. Then came 1970, a year of recession cum inflation, and many of the companies quickly retreated to the sanctuary of their balance sheets. Scores of voluntary social programs were phased out, like outmoded factories, and many of the hardcore trainees found themselves back on the street. Today, though some gains have been made, black capitalism is little more than. a slogan and corporate programs have scarcely dented urban problems.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: What's Doing in NEW ORLEANS
description: MARDI GRASThe New Orleans carnival season ends with one last citywide street party on Mardi Gras, which means Fat Tuesday in French, and falls this year two days hence. People mainly spend Mardi Grasthe name Fat Tuesday comes from the fact that you gorge yourself just before Lentwalking around the streets drinking and carousing, watching endless parades (from which float riders in bizarre costumes toss beads and trinkets to the throngs that line the curbs), listening to the music of marching bands and dancing if the urge strikes. Citizens are urged to wear masks and costumes. The last of the carnival balls are held in the evening but those are open only to members and guests of the krewes, or organizations, that sponsor them. Mardi Gras is sometimes called the greatest free show on earth, but visitors should not take that literally. Bring money. Many hotels, for example, require a minimum fourday reservation for Mardi Gras, paid in advance. For those who insist on coming without enough money, the Mardi Coalition tries to help by providing lowcost sleeping space, sometimes on the ground at Tulane Stadium, and minimal nourishment. The Coalition's legal services office (call 5045249315) gives legal help to the hundreds of young people who invariably get busted for such offenses as sleeping on the levee or blowing marijuana smoke in a policeman's face. Most hotels are already booked for Mardi Gras but some rooms are left. For information or reservations, phone the Tourist and Convention Commission (5045228772).

description: There are at least three rather unusual things that, ought to be said about the Purdy sisters, Nancy and Patricia:

title: ExPolice Suspect In Narcotics Theft Seems in Seclusion
description: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Feb. 23  Frank King, a 39yearold former member of a special narcotics unit within the New York City Police Department, has apparently gone into seclusion as investigators center their inquiry on his as the possible mastermind behind the theft of $70million worth of narcotics from a police storage office.

title: William E Knowland Is Apparent Suicide; ExSenator Was 65
description: GUERNEVILLE, Calif., Feb. 23William F. Knowland, editor and publisher of The Oakland Tribune and former Republican United States Senator, was found dead of a selfinflicted gunshot wound at his summer home near here today, the Sonoma County sheriff's office said.

title: Music in Review
description: Miss LipsonGruzen In Piano Recital

title: Ostia: To Antiquity By Metro
description: TWO points should be made about Ostia. The first is that it was a thriving city under the ancient Roman empire, with a downtown business district, shops, warehouses and fivestory apartment buildings, considerable amount of which can still be seen. The second point is that Ostia is only a subway ride from the center of modern Rome, making it probably the furthest back in time one can reach in 20 minutes of travel. And for the person who complains that he can see only fragments rather than the whole of ancient Rome, Ostia provides a city of antiquity in its entirety. It was Rome's port, its outlet to the sea for trade and conquest.

title: S.O.R.C. Now a Showcase For Growing Yacht Trade
description: Miami, Feb. 23You don't hear that word, Corinthian, in the yachting set any more. The older establishment types will tell you why. They say there are no Corinthians left in the old fashioned sense, especially on the gamy Southern Ocean Racing Conference, where commercialism is openly accepted. Rewards extend beyond trophies.

title: At Smallest Firms: Biggest Fuel Crisis
description: PLYMOUTH, Mich.  Joe Tate, owner of the Sun Plas. tics Coating Company here, has everything he needs for a new plantthe land, the plans, the steel and a contractor.

description: The Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn may not smell to the heavens, but enough of its odor has reached civic and political leaders to sugled a refreshing change is in the air.

description: C.B.S. News said last night that it had located a diary believed to be that of William A. H. Williams, arrested in the kidnapping of the Atlanta Constitution editorialpage editor, J. Reginald Murphy, The Associated Press reported.

description: Mr. Matalon was the director of Noel Coward's Suite in Three Keys, in which Coward made his last stage appearance, in London in 1966. Mr. Matalon has also staged the American version, Coward in Two Keys, which opens at the Barrymore Theater Thursday at 6:45.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: CONSUMER PRICE INDEX in January rose 0.9 per cent to 139.7 . . . . William J. Feltner, of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, warned that continued in?? of 8 per cent or more would bringe wageprice controls more severe than Phases 1 through 4 . . . . The commerce Department revised the gross national product in the fourth quarter to the annual rate of $1,337.5billion; up $3.5billion from the preliminary estimate, indicating a gain of 1.8 per cent over the third quarter. The rate of inflation for 1973 was revised upward to 8.8 per cent, rather than the 7.9 per cent reported earlier.

description: ROME, Feb. 23A churchSponsored conference here has urged the Roman Catholic clergy to become more involved in the fight against Rome's social ills, and has Called on religious orders to serve the poor instead of the rich.

title: Dave Anderson
description: MESA, Ariz., Feb. 23For nearly 10 years, Alvin Dark has been surrounded by the smog of white supremacy. The winds of change never blow it away. In his role as the manager of the Oakland A's, it hung in the desert air today when the twotime World Series winners opened their training camp. His smog developed when he was managing the San Francisco Giants.

description: RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 23The Burmese Government promulgated a narcotic drugs law this week prohibiting the cultivation of poppy, hemp and other narcotic plants and the production, possession or trafficking of narcotic drugs.

title: Balloonist Feared Downed; Atlantic Search Will Begin
description: WASHINGTON, Sunday; Feb. 24 (Reuters)Thomas Gatch, who is attempting to cross the Atlantic Ocean by balloon, is believed down in the ocean and an air and sea search for him will begin today, according to a spokesman for the Air Transport Association.

description: Miss Kristina Dawn Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Jones of New York and Tampico, Mexico, and Allan John Prager, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Prager of San Mateo, Calif., were married here this afternoon by the Rev. Andrew Mullins at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church. A reception was held in the Belvedere Suite of the Rainbow Room.

title: N.C. State Beats Clemson. As Thompson. Scores 35
description: CLEMSON, S. C., Feb. 23 (AP)North Carolina State, the nation's No. 1ranked basketball team, countered a strong bid by Clemson tonight with a 35point performance by David Thompson and won, 8075.

title: Connors, McMillan Finalists
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 23 (AP)Jimmy Connors, the 21yearold defending champion, routed Alex (Sandy) Mayer, 61, 61, 60, with a brilliant display of tennis tonight and advanced to the final in the United States indoor open tennis championships.

title: Apartment Moratorium Weighed in Southampton
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I.Southampton took a stet toward becoming the second town, in Suffolk County, to curtail apartments last week when the town board set public hearing on a zon ing ordinance amendment that would put a six month moratorium on the building of multiple dwellings and motel units.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  Despite his party's overwhelming majorities in both houses and its control of the Governor's office, State Senator James P. Dugan, the Democratic State Chairman, is meeting considerable resistance to his efforts to have the Legislature approve a new Congressional redistricting plan for New Jersey.

title: Coydog, coywolf or werewolf?
description: Since the almost total extirpation of the Eastern timber wolf, the cougar and the bear, predators have been conspicuously absent in the Northeast. But persistent reports of a mysterious, coyotelike creature have been coming out of New England for several years. Such reports have alarmed many hunters who believe they can better perform the predator function of culling excess deer and other game. But conservationists are pleased: They hope that the coyotelike creature signals a return to a better balance of nature.

title: Miss Higuchi Leads Golf
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 23 (AP)Chako Higuchi, a Japanese professional, took the lead today after the second round of the Australian women's open golf championship. Miss Higuchi shot a 71 for a tworound total of 145, two strokes better than Penny Puitz of Australia, who also shot a 71.

title: U.S. Players Break the Ice With Speed
description: Although Canadian dominance of American collegiate hockey is by no means near an end, the Americanborn player has finally equaled, or perhaps surpassed his rival in the most important phase of the gameskating.

title: Tams End Nets' Jinx By 10297
description: MEMPHIS, Feb. 23  All good things come to an end and the New York Nets' mastery of the Memphis Tams came to just that tonight at the MidSouth Coliseum.

title: Cornell Cold on Guard
description: Peggy Walbridge, a Cornell University senior won the 39th annual National Intercollegiate Women's Fencing Association tournament held at Hunter College yesterday.

title: Cellist Says That Soviet Imposes Quarantine on Him and Wife
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 23The cellist Mstislav Rostropovich has asserted that Soviet authorities have imposed an artistic quarantine on him and his wife, the opera singer Galina Vishnevskaya, apparently because of their friendship with Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn.

title: Nassau and Suffolk Promised Immediate Gasoline Supplies
description: Residents of Nassau and Suffolk Counties, who have been hard hit by the gasoline shortage and were facing the prospect of paying 72 cents a gallon for the fuel, were promised immediate relief yesterday by Governor Wilson.

title: College Gets Japanese Grant
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 23The American subsidiary of C. Itoh & Co., Ltd., a Japanese trading concern, has made a $50,000 grant to the University of Pittsburgh. The grant is the first for a university in the Pittsburgh district from an Asianbased company and the first made to any university by Itoh. It will be used in support of the East Asian Language and Area Center, a part of the University Center for International Studies.

title: Jacqueline Miller Plans Marriage
description: ARMONK, N. Y., Feb. 23Miss Jacqueline Miller, an administrative resident at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston, plans to be married in. April to Daniel Rosenthal, a fourthyear student at the Yale University Medical School. Dr. and Mrs. Michael Miller have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Rosenthal of East Meadow, L. I.

title: COMDR. M'KITTERICK EARLY NAVY FLIER, 83
description: WILTON, Conn., Feb. 23Comdr. Edward Hyslop McKitterick, U.S.N., retired, a member of the first class of Naval aviators, died Wednesday at St. Mary's Hospital in Waterbury. He was 83 years old and lived at 31 Old Ridgefield Road.

title: Nixon Said to Have Balked Charges in Secrets Theft
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23President Nixon personally ordered the special White House investigative unit not to seek prosecution of any suspects in the military snooping on the National Security Council in late 1971, sources close to the inquiry said today.

title: Joan Banks Affianced
description: ALPINE, N. J., Feb. 23The engagement of Miss Joan Marie. Banks to Daniel Joseph Mulcahy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Mulcahy of Silver Spring, Md., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Peter Banks of Alpine. The prospective bride is an alumna of Marymount College in Arlington, Va., and Marymount Manhattan College. Her fianc, a graduate of Syracuse University, and the University of Virgina Law School, is a lawyer with Breed Abbott & Morgan of New York.

title: Zooming Prices
description: The steep new climb in consumer prices last month sharpens fear that the United States is about to join Japan and most of West Europe in the danger zone double digit inflationan inflation rate of more than 10 per cent a year.

title: Independent Gas Dealers Get 2CentsaGallon Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 William E. Simon, Federal energy chief, announced today a twocent per gallon increase in the price of gasoline sold by independent retail dealers effective March 1.

title: American Wives an Asset In British Political Circles
description: LONDON, Feb. 24  Some have been told that the fact that they are not British may harm their husbands' political careers. Yet they have one advantage a British wife doesn't have: in a classconscious society, their accents afford them neutrality.

title: Dignity and Rights Threatened By Data Files, U . N. Report Says
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 23The increased use of computerized personal data systems may well have dehumanizing effects on the individual, vioIating the fundamental human right to personal privacy, United Nations report said today.

title: ROCKLAND OFFICIAL
description: The Commissioner of Social Services of Rockland County, Noah Weinberg, has been accused of being a New York City slumlord who has cheated both the welfare clients who lived in his buildings and the city's Department of Social Services.

title: LATIN COUNTRIES AND U.S. OUTLINE NEW RELATIONSHIP
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 23The United States and 24 LatinAmerican and Caribbean countries today outlined a new relationship anchored in continuing discussion of practical issues between the rich north and the poor south of this hemisphere.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Berkenwald of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elaine Berkenwald, to Dr. Stanley Klughaupt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Klughaupt of Brooklyn.

description: The hemline indicator, despite its past successes, isn't currently telling investors a thing about which way stock prices will go.

title: New & Novel
description: Joel Kurtzman's rapport with the inmates of a mental hospital is as thorough as Ken, Kesey's in One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, which is a lot of rapport. No declarative prolixity, but a narrative shorthand that takes the measure of a cluster of walking wounded. The center of the novel's attention is Bobby Kling, an externally repulsive psychopath. Bobby is inclined to do bodily harm to women, but he is not completely specialized. In tandem with a strongerwilled maniac hamed Harvy, the boys drive around primed with amphetamines and booze, in pursuit of blood; knocking over filling stations, assaulting random strangers, firing a pistol into crowds of children, mutilating derelicts and massacring dogsthat sort of thing.

title: MacDonald and Bijur In Court Tennis Final
description: TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 23Jerry Bijur of Philadelphia gained the final today in the 73d annual Tuxedo Gold Racquetcourt tennis tournament at the Tuxedo Racquets and Tennis Club by defeating Peter Stanley of Philadelphia, 26, 62, 60.

title: Moth Spraying Planned
description: HARRISBURG, Feb. 23 (AP) Some 58,000 acres of eastern Pennsylvania will be chemically sprayed with Dylox, according to la tentative state plan to combat the gypsy moth.

title: Novelist Attacks Time's Edition in Canada
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 23  The author of one of Canada's best selling novels is engaging Time magazine in a battle that goes to the heart of the perennial debate here over what constitutes the Canadian identity.

title: Best Seller List
description: Based on reports from more than 250 bookstores in 110 communities throughout the United States. Weeks are not necessarily consecutive.

title: Fashion: Spring dresses
description: Daffodils will bloom. April 15 will dawn. And the dress will be revived. These are the certainties of spring. This year, there is a trend away from skinny, skimpylooking clothes toward loose, blousey dresses with deep armholes and full sleeves.

title: Davidson Names Farrell
description: DAVIDSON, N.C., Feb. 23 (AP)Ed Farrell, head football coach at the University of Bridgeport, was named head coach at Davidson College today. Farrell succeeds Dave Fagg, who resigned to become an assistant at Georgia Tech.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Two banks have leased 125,000 square feet of office space in the Home Insurance Building at 59 Maiden Lane.

title: Enter Shirley VerrettThrough the Front Door
description: SMALL wonder Shirley Verrett is fond of saying that her real Metropolitan Opera debut occurred last Octoberf  when she blew everybody's mind by singing a historic marathon perfermance of both Cassandra and Dido in The Trojans. It wasn't until then that she really made it big in this town, although she had formally come to the house in 1968. Actually, the black, mezzo first hit the rocky road to the Met in 1961 when she was invited by the Bing administration to sing less than stellar contralto parts in the Wagner opras. Furious with what she considered the insulting idiocy of the offer, Miss Verrett flatly turned it down.

title: Checkerhall Upset Victor, Pays $17.60
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., Feb. 23 (UPI)Checkerhall, scoring his first stakes victory, upset a field of six 3yearolds today at Garden State Park to capture the $26,000 Princeton Stakes.

title: Ideas & Trends Education, Transportation, Inventors, Death
description: Apparently because of the increasing costs, specialization and impersonal nature of medical care in urban centers, more and more citydwellers are traveling into the countryside to consult smalltown doctors for their everyday medical needs.

title: President Picks Ford to Head Panel to Guard Citizens' Privacy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 President Nixon announced today that he was establishing a top priority committee headed by Vice President Ford to forge a personal shield for every American against invasions of privacy from any source  including the Federal Government.

title: Angelina Alioto: She Loves Being California's Newest Celebrity
description: SAN FRANCISCOIt was midafternoon and Angelina Alioto began to fuss with her diamond earrings, blue lam Nina Ricci gown, and the shiny new Navajo necklace she calls her trademark.

title: Keeping Archie Engaging and Enraging
description: BEHIND the anger of Americas foremost WASP bigot, blustering Archie Bunker, are two fiftyish total New Yorkers who have been close friends and partners, off and on, for the past 30 years. Michael Ross and Bernie West, as the story editors for All in the Family, are the chief architects for the plotlines, jokes and jabs that engage and often enrage millions of viewers eack week.

title: Headliners
description: The struggle between the left and right wings of Argentina's Peronists has claimed another victim. Alejandro Giovenco, head of a right wing Peronist organization, was killed when a bomb exploded in his briefcase while he was on his way to an Interrogation of a leftwing Peronist guerrilla accused of plotting an assassination attempt on Argentine President Juan Peron.

title: PROGRESS REPORTED IN RHEINGOLD TALKS.
description: I. Philip Sipser, legal counsel for Locals 3 and 46 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said yesterday that dramatic and substantial movement had been made in negotiations for the purchase of Rheingold Breweries.

title: Will It Ever Be Girl Meets Girl?
description: I READ Aljean Harmetz's article a few Sundays ago. Boy Meets Boy. Hoffman and McQueen ?? Hepburn and Tracy. Well, wasn't it inevitable? Will everyone who still believes in boy meets girl please clap your hands? How many singles bars have you clappers been in lately?

title: Joy Watson Married to George R. Dorin
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 23The marriage of Miss Joy Watson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold William Watson of Dallas, Pa., to George Robert Dorin of Waterbury, Conn., took place here this afternoon. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Dorin of Orange, Conn.

title: Gewertz Wants Fort Dix Acreage for Experimental Farm
description: TRENTON  A Gloucester County Assemblyman is scheduled to meet with Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. in Washington on Tuesday in an effort to enlist Congressional support for the acquisition of 5,000 acres of Federally owned land at Fort Dix. The property would be converted into an experimental ecologicaland conservationist  oriented farm and livestock center.

title: How the Wobbly Yen Got Its Second Wind
description: TOKYOFor more than a year, Japanese financial authorities shovelled dollars out of Japan like demons on fire. Go invest someplace, they said to businessmen. Go buy something, they said to traders. Go see the sights somewhere, they said to tourists

title: Producer of Champions Once a Stable Manager
description: Two decades ago, a quiet, introspective former junior rider of 20 years of age was hired by the United States Equestrian Team as stable manager.

title: Miss Huntington Fiancee Of Kimball P. McCloud
description: GLENBROOK, Nev., Feb. 23Miss Claire Swain Huntington, a descendant of Coils P. Huntington, a founder of the Central Pacific Railroad and the Southern Pacific Railroad and builder of the Newport News Shipping and Drydock Company, and greatgranddaughter of Henry E. Huntington, founder of the Huntington Library and Art Gallery in San Marino, Calif., plans to be married here to Kimball Patrick McCloud at her family's summer home on the shore of Lake Tahoe on June 29.

title: The Book, The Ring, And the Poet
description: Before Dr. Frederick J. Furnivall founded the Browning Society in England, to the halfgiggling halfremonstrances of the poet himself, the United States had its own vigorous Browning cult. Groups of ladies met to wrestle with his knottiness, or drool over his love story, in rooms decorated all in brown, serving brown bread on brown china from a brown tablecloth in the intermissions. Browning onomastically rode the Chicago & Alton: Pauline, Paracelsus and Sordello appeared in the railway timetables. There was a Sordello Club in St. Louis.

title: Food: Winter fruit
description: There is an ancient Italian saying that translates roughly as Don't tell the peasant how good pears are with cheese. He'll steal both of them from you. But this has never been our way. Here we present two capital pear dessertsa handsome tart flavored with ginger, and pears poached in a coffeeliqueurflavored syrup.

title: Ideas&Trends Education, Transportation, Inventors, Death
description: Invention consists in avoiding the constructing of useless combinations and in constructing the useful combinations which are in the infinite minority. To invent is to discern, to choose. Jules Henri Poincard (18541912)

title: Twixt Victor at Bowie
description: BOWIE, Md., Feb. 23Twixt carried top weight of 124 pounds with aplomb to day in the 20th running of the Barbara Fritchie Handi. cap. Established the favorite by the 12,323 fans against nine rivals in the sevenfur. long sprint for fillies and mares, Mrs. John Franklin's Maryland bred scored by 2 lengths over Groton Miss who had the margin of a nose over the third place in the Mattress.

title: The Nation
description: From the beginning of the nation's energy crisis, efforts to cope with it have produced confusion, recriminations and an atmosphere of official scrambling to combat rising prices and inadequate supplies.

title: Tripping the ScienceFantastic
description: Some years ago, as a thankyou for a weekend spent with a cheerfully bekidded family, I sent a volume of excerpts from a dozen children's novels with a note promising a copy of whichever one the kids liked best. In due course back came the vote: Rootabaga Stories, by Sandburg. (A happy incident all around, especially for me, for I had written the introduction to that marvelous book.) The same sort of thing might well be done with TALES BEYOND TIME, compiled by L. Sprague de Camp and Catherine Cook de Camp (Lothrop, Lee & Shepard, $4.95) illustrated by Ati Forberg, a compendium of retold myths and legends for readers 8 to 12 years old, together with contemporary science fiction; and if it leads one to Lloyd Alexander and his priceless time cat Gareth (as only one example) it's a giftgiver's bonus.

title: Ostpolitik: Patient Dream
description: BONNThe twin pillars of Bonn's foreign policy are Westpolitik and Ostpolitik. Westpolitik may summarily be described as reliance upon the United States for diplomatic and military protection. There is no illusion thatin a Hobson's choicethe ninenation European Community could serve as a reasonable substitute for American support or that Europe might become a third superpower.

title: Gas Stations Cut Price
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 23 (AP)  Hudson Oil Company has reduced the price of gasoline nearly 10 cents a gallon and extended business hours at its 16 stations in this area. It's an unusual and temporary situation, a Hudson official said.

title: Federal Court Reform Is Progressing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23After several years of complaints, studies and false starts, the campaign to revamp the Federal judicial system and ease pressure on the Supreme Court appears to be gaining direction and momentum.

title: OFFICIALS PREDICT GAS DROUGHT SOON
description: Senior officials of the Federal Energy Office said yesterday that if the Arab oil embargo was not lifted by the end of April, a gasoline drought could hit wide areas of the country by late spring or early summer.

title: The World
description: While Israeli Premier Golda Meir has tried to salvage a minority government from the confusion and disunity of Israeli politics, her Arab opponents appear for the moment to have gotten together.

title: The Finest Iberia Yet
description: IIT SELDOM happens, but every now and then a recording does come along that really is definitive. In the case of Isaac Albniz's 12movement suite for piano, Iberia, this unlikely circumstance has occurred three times and only because Alicia de Larrocha has been the pianist on each occasion. Her first version, for Columbia in 1959, disappeared into monophonic oblivion some time ago; the second, on Epic eight years later, vanished along with that label's classical line; the third, a new London recording, has just appeared and may it always be with us (CSA 2235, two disks).

title: Byrne Drug Plan Is Opposed
description: TRENTONThe Byrne administration's program for tough, new drug penalties is encountering resistance from a legislative committee chairman.

title: U.S. Milk Corporation Suit Is Moved to Kansas City
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 23 (AP)The Justice Department's civil antitrust suit against the nation's largest milk cooperative is being moved to Kansas City, Mo.

title: Reform Jews Ask Coalition
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) A group of Reform Jewish leaders, citing a vacuum of leadership they said was caused by Watergate, called today for a renewal of the nineteen sixties civil rights coalition to press for solutions to America's domestic social needs. Albert Vorstan, director of the Union of American Hebrew congregations' social action program, said such a coalition would act as a social conscience force aimed at bringing about effective and badly needed social and economic programs.

title: ... on Impeachment
description: In trying to steer his way through the political crosscurrents, Mr. Rodino was materially aided by the legal and historical memorandum submitted last week by the committee's staff concerning impeachment. This survey was the joint effort of the majority and minority staffs headed by John Doar and Albert Jenner, respectively.

title: David Shatz to Marry Karen S. Schiff
description: Dr. and Mrs. Milton Schiff of Brooklyn have announced that their daughter, Miss Karen Sue Schiff, will be married March 10 to David Shatz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Shatz of Hadera, Israel.

title: The Courts Have Not Been Helpful
description: The questions sound like law school hypotheticals. One man shoots another in the head. The victim is rushed to the hospital and hooked up to modern lifesupport systems. Although his heart and lungs are functioning, the doctors decide his brain is dead. His heart is removed and transplanted. Is the assailant guilty of murder? A man has an automobile accident that causes severe brain damage to young girl whose still beating heart is given to a waiting cardiac patient. Can he be convicted of manslaughter, or only of felonious drunken driving?

title: Goal for LaserFusion Power Is Weighed
description: LIVERMORE, Calif., Feb. 23 Unified in their hope of bringing virtually unlimited power to an energyhungry world, American participants in the quest for laserinduced nuclear fusion met here the last two days to take stock in their progress.

title: MOVIE OPENINGS
description: MAN ON A SWINGFrank Perry's drama, written by David Zelag Goodman and starring Cliff Robertson and Joel Grey, Wednesday at Loew's State I and Tower East.

title: Hydrofoil Fires Missile
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 23 (AP)The Harpoon, an experimental longrange antiship missile, has been successfully testfired from a hydrofoil ship, the Navy says. The Harpoon is designed to be fired from surface vessels, submerged submarines and patrol planes at targets 40 or more miles away.

title: In Tennessee, Impeachment Is a 106YearOld Memory
description: GREENEVILLE, Tenn.  Impeachment, a process most Americans are just beginning to understand, is something the people here have lived with for generations.

title: Air Rights Building Is 10, and Struggling
description: The first tenants moved into the Bridge Apartments, the four 32story buildings that straddle the Manhattan approach to the George Washington Bridge, 10 years ago.

title: French connections
description: This is one of the most ambitious, comprehensive and subtly innovative studies of modern France ever written by an AngloSaxon historian. It is also a feast of reading for those interested in France and the French, past and present.

title: 4 Youths Held in Mugging Of Brooklyn Police Officer
description: Four Brooklyn teenagers were arrested yesterday in the Friday morning mugging of a Brooklyn police, lieutenant on a midtown Manhattan street. The police said the service revolver and shield stolen from the lieutenant, Edward Bolson, had been recovered.

title: Blind Read Books With Sighted Friends
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I.An increasing number of blind residents of Suffolk County are enjoying an experience that is ordinarily the privilege, of those who can seesharing real books with those who are not blind.

title: Miss Spelke Fiancee of J.D. Blum
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 23 Mr. and Mrs. Harold S. Spelke have announced the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Shilin Spelke, a doctoral candidate in psychology at Cornell University, to Jeffrey D. Blum, a doctoral candidate in psychology at Yale University. He is a son of Herman Blum and stepson of Mrs. Blum of Fair Lawn, N. J.

title: Fighting the Travel Slump
description: Glenn Hatch, a traveler back from Europe at John F. Kennedy International Airport, seemed pleased wits his trip.

title: Leafrak Plan For Project In Queens Is Fought
description: Will there be another Letrak City In Queen?

title: Photoraphy
description: THE Cosmopolitan Chapter PSA is holding TeachIn III, an allday program of instructive lectures at the Commodore Hotel, 42d Street and Lexington Avenue, on Sunday, March 24. Subjects covered during the various sessions will include color slides, nature, blackandwhite and color printing, motion pictures and stereophotography. The fee for the full day will be $7 and those planning to go must send registration forms in by March 12. These forms can be obtained by writing to Robert Burns, 624. Penn Avenue, Teaneck, N.J. 07666. For more information phone (212) KI 38926.

title: Dr. Frank Stover Is Dead; Jersey Educator Was 64
description: GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Feb. 23 Dr. Frank B. Stover, superintendent of schools of Bloomfield, and a former New Jersey Deputy Commissioner of Edutation, died yesterday at Mountainside Hospital here. He was 64 years old and lived at 28 Lincoln Street.

title: Syncopation Named Best At Providence Dog Show
description: PROVIDENCE, R.L, Feb. 23 A pert bichon frise, Ch. Chaminade's Syncopation, came up with the right beat at the 66th Providence County fixture at the Civic Center today and was named best in show for the fifth time.

title: Garbage, the Cinderella Fuel
description: Garbage is today a vital natural resource.

title: The Casals Festival Carries On
description: THE letterhead for the Festival Casals, which has been taking place in San Juan, Puerto Rico, for the past 16 years, still carries the line PABLO CASALS, MUSICAL DIRECTOR. The outline of the program for this year's festival, to be held June 4 to 22, lists only an assistant music director, Alexander Schneider. Despite the fact that the great musician died last Oct. 22, this billing should surprise no one. There is a fact to justify it: the program was organized before Casals died, and there is an emotional quality to justify it: the spirit of Coals will dominate the festival probably as long as it continues.

title: Letters: On the Perils Of Visiting St. Croix
description: To the Editor: In reference to the article by J. Anthony Lukas, Murder in Paradise: The Case of St. Croix (Travel Section, Feb. 10), I would like to say that I am a fulltime resident of New York (Brooklyn) by birth and a parttime resident of St. Croix by choiceand a happy one.

title: A Yugoslav Experiment, Possibly Noble
description: BELGRADEAfter a wrenching period of selfexamination, Yugoslavia has adopted a new Constitutionits fourth since World War IIthat propounds the idea, in 40,000 words and more than 400 articles, that the working class should govern itself in every sphere. But though the Communist leadership applauded the document as the brightest example of true democracy, some observers see it as a paperingover of deep political and regional schisms that could lead to real trouble. Under the new Constitution, professional managers of industry and career politicians are replaced by the basic organizations of associated labor, worker cells, who will control production and govern the nation.

title: COMPUTER SPURS JURY SELECTION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23This city's largest mass murder trial has developed an apparently innovative jury selection process.

title: Where Churchill Made War
description: BENEATH a government building on London's Great George Street, which lies close to Whitehall and the Houses of Parliament, six bleak rooms remain just as they were When World War II ended 29 years ago. It was into one of these rooms, when the going got rough for Britain in 1940, that Winston Churchill moved a bed and desk, while Mrs. Churchill took refuge in another room across the hall. The sixroom underground stronghold was the Prime Minister's command post. Here his War Cabinet met with him while London reeled under Hitler's blitz, and here throughout the war military intelligence was channeled to be evaluated and relayed to British Allied forces around the world.

title: '40's Gas Rationing Defended
description: WASHINGTON  Coupon rationing of gasoline during World War II is being given a bad name that it does not deserve. The simple and straightforward answer to such criticisms is that the program worked, Exaggerated tales of black marketing and counterfeit coupons now given widespread currency are unjustified. The fact is that less than 5 per cent of the total available gasoline supply found its way into illegal channelsa record that is surprising in view of early and duplicating mismanagement of the rationing and allocation programs.

title: Puns and twists
description: ACROSS

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox
