description: To The Editor: Please spare us any more photos (The Times, Feb. 15) of these big strong sportsmen with their deadly guns in one hand and the carcass of a helpless, unarmed little animal in the other. I am not a fanatic and if the man pictured were starving and had to kill to survive, I'd tell him to kill. But he looks very well fed and the article notes that all hands gathered for a lunch of hamburgers and vegetable beef soupso the seven hares were obviously not shot to keep and soul going.

title: Linda Abram Engaged To Barry R. Goldsmith
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 23Miss Linda Abram and Barry R. Goldsmith, graduates of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, plan to be married on June 16. Mr. and Mrs. Leon M. Abram have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton T. Goldsmith of Seaford, L.I.

title: HUNGRY ETHIOPIA SAID TO SELL FOOD
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 6Ethiopia has been exporting food throughout a major famine that has killed thousands of peasants, and some food grain lies unused in storage bins while vast foreign relief shipments arrive.

title: Virtue and Vice Fight It Out in the Ghetto
description: IF you have ever gone to any of the summertime festivals of street playsexceedingly simple moralities in which Virtue and Vice contend for the souls of ghetto youngstersthat are now regularly held in the Lincoln Center Plaza, you will recognize Ron Milner's What the WineSellers Buy right off. Its bones are the bones of all such exhortations to stay clean. its neighborhood pieties the same neighborhood pieties, its warnings the very same warnings. At the end of the evening a lad who has almost been seduced by a Mephistolike figure into pimping his thoroughly nice girl reaches out to the girl, clutches her tight, and firmly announces We ain't goin his way, it costs too much. The homily has simply been moved indoors to the Vivian Beaumont's main stage, opulently mounted, opened up by its author to cram just as much lifelike detailand perhaps as much dramatic truth into its elementary design as possible.

title: Betty R. Rawls, Fraser A. Lang Wed in Virginia
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Feb. 23 Christ Church Episcopal was the setting here, this afternoon for the wedding of Miss Betty Randolph Rawls and Fraser Alexander Lang. The Rev. William Sydnor performed the ceremony, after which the couple left the church to the tunes of a kilted Scottish bagpiper.

title: AROUND THE Joan Lee Faust
description: A word or two on this venture into starting seeds indoors. The tendency for the tenderfoot is to rush things. If he wants to race his neighbor and have the first tomato crop on the block, he reasons that he should plant his tomato seeds indoors early. Then he will have huge plants to put outdoors, and win the challenge.

title: Plane Used by U.S. Church Is Forced Down Over Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) The State Department reported tonight that an airliner used by a Wichita, Kan., church in international missionary work was forced down in Cuba.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: 5 Missing As Yankees Open Camp
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 23In a more strict and businesslike atmosphere than they have been accustomed to, the Yankees opened spring training today with 16 pitchers, seven catchers and five absentees  three holdouts, one Seventhday Adventist and one noshow, who, someone speculated, might be stuck in a gas line on his way South.

title: UNIVERSITY HIRES A PRISONERPOET
description: FORT WORTH, Feb. 23B. F. Maiz, an Inmate at the Federal Correctional Institution here, Is 51 years old and he has spent seven years behind bars. He is also an unpublished poet.

title: Colby Ending Air R.O.T.C.
description: WATERVILLE, Me., Feb. 23 (AP)Colby College has announced its Air Force R.O.T.C. program will be discontinued. The school said a schedule for phasing out the Reserve Officers Training Corps, now in its 21st years, was yet to be worked out.

title: WILSON MANDATES ODDEVEN SYSTEM OF GASOLINE SALES
description: Governor Wilson, citing gasoline emergency that endangers public health and safety, yesterday imposed mandatory oddeven sales system throughout the state beginning at 12:01 A.M. Tuesday.

title: A KEY A.E.C. RULING SEEN 2 YEARS OFF
description: OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Feb. 22 Atomic Energy Commission officials estimated today that the Government would have about two more years to make a decision on new uranium enrichment plants to fuel the nuclear power industry private companies decide not to enter the business.

title: Smith Breaks Record With Pole Vault of 181
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 23 (AP)Steve Smith ran down the runway for the first time with a new pole he and his father had designed for the way I vault at the International Track Association meet last nightand it worked.

title: High Cost of Food Hits Home
description: LODIThe spiraling cost of food is forcing housewives throughout New Jersey to buy less, eliminate such expensive items as roasts and steaks and to seek out bargains and cheaper brands of frozen and canned goods.

title: Mondrian: He Perfected Not a style But a Vision
description: THIRTY years ago this month, the Dutch painter Piet Mondrian died in New York at the age of 71. Although there is no mention of this anniversary occasion in the catslogue of the Mondrian exhibition now installed at the Sidney Janis Gallery, 6 West 57th Street, the show itself has a distinctly commemorative air. The artist's life, lovingly evoked in photographs, documents and objects, is accorded, if anything, even more attention than his art, and among the works of art there are a significant numberaof sketches and unfinished pictures that give us an unusually intimate view of the artist's working methods.

title: Little League Gets a New Umpire: the Courts
description: TRENTON  The battle between Little League, Inc., and New Jersey has gone into extra innings. Little League has asked the courts to stay an order by the state's Division of Civil Rights that requires it to open its registration rolls to girls.

title: Coast Smoking Ban Eased
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 23 (UPI)The Sacramento City Council has made a lastminute change in its nosmoking ordinance, which became effective today in all retail stores in the city, by allowing smoking in tobacco shops.

title: Photography
description: AT first Julio Mitchel's current exhibit at the Midtown Y Gallery, Two Wards, appears to consist of separate and unrelated essays. The first of these deals with crowds on New York City streets, while the second explores the texture of life at Goldwater Memorial Hospital, which specializes in chronic diseases.

title: Free Rides In Search of Riders
description: It's called the Rush bus in Nashville; the Dash bus in Duluth; the Dart bus in Akron; the Magic Carpet in Seattle. The names are different, but the buses have something in common: A free ride.

title: Some Districts Limited
description: tricts are too small to be operated efficiently and yield the maximum education return on each tax dollar invested, Dr. Kilpatrick said. Some 150 of New Jersey's districts have fewer than 500 students. Twentythree districts are nonoperating. They have few or no students and no schools.

title: Canada Moves to Regulate Foreigners In Work Force
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 23 (UPI)Immigration Minister Robert Andras has announced new regulations requiring unsponsored immigrants to demonstrate that they will meet a specific need on the Canadian labor market.

title: My WaspWaisted, CreamColored Souvenir of Iran
From Many Links, His Own Chain
description: I don't care what Sam Neaman says about me or what kind of shirts or ties he wears, Meshulam Riklis, chairman of the RapidAmerican Corporation, often told his associates, as long as he continues to push out those profits and to produce for me.

title: Moerschel, Boston Cellist, Plays Recital
description: Joel Moerschel, a cellist of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, showed good solo potential in the recital he gave yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hit With Neal Larrabee at the piano, Mr. Moerschel played Beethoven's Sonata No. 2 in G minor, Debussy's Sonata, Ginastera's Pampeana No. 2 and the ChopinFeuennann Introduction and Polonaise Brillante. The remaining work in the program was Kodaly's Santa for Unaccompanied Cello.

title: Poodles Are Still No. 1, but Watch Those Irish Setters
description: Poodles remain America's most popular dogs, as they have been since 1960, but they continue to drop in registrations, according to the 1973 list just released by the American Kennel Club. Of the 1,099,850 dogs recorded last year in the organization's stud book, 193,400 were poodles. This is a decrease of 25,499 from the previous listing. The No. 1 breed reached its peak in 1969, with 274,145. Each year since it has shown a decline, although it has no trouble in keeping the top position; with more than twice as many registrations as the No. 2 breedGerman shepherds. The shepherds has 90,907, which is 10,492 fewer than in 1972.

title: Red Smith
description: John L. Sullivan, the Livingston, Mont., Strong Boy, reminds Teddy Brenner of a lefthanded Jimmy McLarnin. Vito Antuofermo, a Brooklyn character from Bari, Italy, reminds Teddy Brenner of Tony Canzonri. So this night McLarnin and Canzoneri were boxing the windup in the old Garden, said Brenner, who foments fights for the new Madison Square Garden. They met in the middle of the ring for instructions, and when Tony started back to his corner he walked into the hanging microphone. It took 12 stitches to close the cut but there wasn't time then. They mopped the blood off him with a towel and shoved him out for the first round. He was groggy and he lost the round. It was the last one he lost.

title: Flea Markets Survive Gas Crisis
description: ENGLEWOOD  Gasoline crises and fickle tastes of the public, notwithstanding, flea markets are back again.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Soviet Jews

title: To Our Readers
description: Effective today, the newsstand price of the Sunday New York Times has been increased to 60 cents within a 50mile radius of New York City and on Long Island. Beyond the 50mile radius, the price is now 90 cents.

title: SOVIET PLANNING STRONGER FORCES
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 23Defense Minister Andrei A. Grechko today asserted the Soviet Union's intention to keep strengthening, its armed forces, including its arsenal of strategic weapons, despite the resumption in Geneva last Wednesday of the talks on limiting strategic arms.

title: Sex is Congressional
description: Every great fifthrate thinker dreams of discovering the two basic elements into which all things in this world can be divided, and I am no exception. Although loath to publish yet in the scientific journals, I have a theory which has so far passed every test. It holds that all things can be classified as either Presidential or Congressional.

title: Sloop Home First In Lipton Event
description: MIAMI, Feb. 23 (AP)Robon was the first yacht to cross the finish line today and led a field of 100 sailing vessels in the 38mile Lipton Cup race.

title: Margo Victoria. Marusi Wed To Terence P. Boyle, Lawyer
description: RUMSON, N. J., Feb. 23In St. George's bytheRiver Episcopal. Church here this evening, Miss Margo. Victoria Marusi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Augustine R. Marusi of Red Bank and New York, became the bride of Terence Patrick Boyle. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Boyle of Omaha.

title: MADDOX SEEKING GOVERNOR'S POST
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 25  Lieut. Gov, Lester G. Maddox formally announced today his intention to reclaim the Georgia governship.

title: Princeton Plays Most To Exponent Of the Bard
description: PRINCETON  One of Britain's most distinguished Shakespearean actors has taken up temporary residence in Princeton.

title: Construction Problems Mount
description: There's good news and bad news, goes the joke currently making the rounds of the city's construction industry. The good news is that there are no severe delivery problems, The bad news is that there's nothing to deliver.

title: CONTROLLER'S JOB HELD TOO DIFFUSE
description: The Incongruous conglomeration of powers held by the city's Controller was examined in a report made public yesteeday by the State Charter Study Commission.

title: Diphtheria Was Quicker Than Starving
description: For the last year, one grim image has been running through the mind of Moise Pensah, one of the brilliant new generation of African administrators who runs the Food and Agricultural Organization for West Africa. It is the memory of a tribe in northern Chad, a tribe ravaged by eight years of drought. All their cattle were dead and most of their camels. Their undernourished children were too weak to resist an outbreak of diphtheria. But they begged Mr. Pensah to send no drugs. Starvation, they told him, would be too slow a death. Let diphtheria rage.

title: How Alex, Wally, cad and I Tracked a Winner to Churchill Downs
description: THE growing excitement surrounding the hundredth running of the Kentucky Derby coming up on May 4 has got a whole lot of nonhorseplaying people thinking they might make some money by betting on the big race. My only advice is ?? horseplayers. Explain the theory of betting on horses to come in third, I said. They don't have third place any more, said Madeleine. Not on the OTB they don't.

title: Their Crooked Road Now Straightened, Rangers Begin Home Work Tonight
description: OAKLAND, Feb. 23Phase One of the redirection of the New York Rangers was completed last night in a 43 victory over the California Golden Seals, so successfully that it almost embarrasses Emile Francis, the general managercoach.

title: Democrats Ahead 2 to 1 in Poll; Gallup Predicts Big G.O.P. Loss
description: Republican political strength among voters for the Congressional elections this fall remains at the lowest level in the 38year history the Gallup Poll has taken such readings.

title: SpearCarrier for Nixon, and Proud of It
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 I'm just one of Richard Nixon's spearcarriers, says Ken W. Clauson, and proud' of it.

title: Yevoli on Indictments: Tip of the Iceberg
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I.When he was the Democratic candidate for supervisor in Oyster Bay Town ?? fall, Lewis J. Yevoli made a series of charges that the Republican administration was the Most corrupt in the history of Oyster Bay.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Smith Vaults to Mark
description: POCATELLO, Idaho, Feb. 23 (UPI)Steve Smith, once again using his new selfmade pole, vaulted to a world indoor best of 18 feet 1 inches tonight in the International Track Association pro meet to better the 181 he had set only the night before.

title: Oddments of History
Expansion on N.F.L. Agenda
description: MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 23The owners of the 26 teams of the National Football League will hold their annual meeting here beginning Monday with three major subjects and one that they so far regard as minor on their minds. The major topics are expected to be expansion by two or four teams for the 1975 season; changes in rules, and the forthcoming labor negotiations with the Players Association.

title: Beachcombers' Delight
description: NEWPORT, Ore., Feb. 23 (UPI) Mr. and Mrs. Ted Allen, owners of a local motel, went beachcombing recently searching for Japanese floats. They found a 50gallon drum of gasoline that was nearly full. God is taking care of us, said Mrs. Allen. He knows how hate to wait incline.

title: Villeneuve Breaks Snowmobile Mark
description: EAGLE RIVER, Wis., Feb. 23 (AP)Jacques Villeneuve of Berthierville, Quebec, driving an Alouette, shattered a dayold track record today, averaging 78.2 miles an hour in Modified IV semifinals of the United States Snowmobile Association's World Series.

title: North American League Is Adopting a TieBreaker
description: This year the North American Soccer League is instituting a tiebreaking system it describes as really simple. If regulation time ends in a deadlock, five players on each team will alternate in taking five penalty kicks against the rival goalie to determine a winner.

title: Spinellas Have Child
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Feb. 23  A daughter was born last Sunday to Mr. and Mrs. Philip Spinella in North Shore Hospital, Manhasset.

title: Where to Get Information Before You Go
The Battle for Farmers' Seed Money
description: DES MOINES, Iowa Across the chest of a kelly green Tshirt an eager hand is reaching for a corn tassel and the white lettering declares: Official Pollen Puller for Pioneer.

title: Murphy Story: 49 Hours of Tension and Bizarre Politics
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 23  When the tall, heavy, garishly dressed stranger appeared at the door, it was clear this was trouble. He said: I'm Lamont Woods, in a Southern accent quickened by exposure to speech patterns elsewhere.

title: New York and Connecticut Legislators Seek to Coordinate Laws on L.I. Sound
description: ALBANY  Each year, scores of measures pass both houses of the New York and Connecticut legislatures and are signed into law by the governors of the respective states  laws affecting both sides of the Long Island Sound, the waterway that both states share.

title: Caroline Lee Palmer Engaged To John T. Mickle, Bank Aide
description: DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 23The engagement of Miss Caroline Lee Palmer to John Tompkins Mickle of Norwalk has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Lee Palmer of Darien and Delray. Beach, Fla., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Daniel Mickle Jr. of Old Chathani, N.Y.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: The Useful Wolf
description: To those whose notions of the wolf are grounded in such scientific sources as Little Red Ridinghood, an effort to spread the American range of that animal may seem inexplicable. Yet a project with that purpose is now being launched in Minnesota.

title: 20Mile Run Listed Today
description: The Road Runners Club will sponsor the 15th annual Mike Hannon Memorial, a 20mile run through Central Park, today. The race starts at 11 A.M. off Fifth Avenue at 99th Street.

title: Pa. Hall to Induct Miller, DiFilippo
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23 (AP)Edmund J. (Bing) Miller and Dave DiFilippo will he inducted into the Pennsylvian Sports Hall of Fame next Tuesday.

title: Princeton Squash Racquets Queen Seeks Reign Over National Court
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 23Two years ago, Wendy Zaharko, Princeton University women's squash racquets star, did not know if she would walk normally again. Now a senior, she is favored to win the women's intercollegiate championship here next weekend for the second time in three years.

title: TennisTeaching Tour
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23, (Reuters)  Five professional tennis coaches will make a United States  sponsored teaching tour of Egypt, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia between Feb. 26 and March 15, the State Department announced today. The coaches are from the Californiabased Tennis America organization.

title: City May Withhold Funds If Banks Employ Sex Bias
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday he would ask the City Banking Commission to bar the deposit of city funds in banks or trust companies that discriminate against women in credit and mortgage applications.

title: World News Briefs
description: PARIS, Feb. 23 (Reuters)Chile reached basic agreement today with her creditors on renegotiating payments due on a foreign debt of about $4billion.

title: It's a Wonderful Town These Last Few Weeks
description: THE Pierpont Morgan Library is celebrating its 50th anniversary as a public institution with a tripledecker summary of what and where it is in 1974 and how it got that way. The first part, Major Acquisitions, 19241974, opened list week. Fifty should look so good on the rest of us.

title: News of the Screen
description: Cheryl Crawford, a stalwart of the theater as a producer for more than 30 years and as a founding member of the Group Theater in the early nineteenthirties, will now make her debut, as a movie producer with a film based on the career of the late Tallulah Bankhead. She has joined with Joe Calcagno, an Off Broadway producer, to acquire rights to Tallulah, the star's 1952 autobiography published by. Harper and Brothers, and other source materials from Eugenia Rawls, an old friend of the actress and owner of the properties, Miss Crawford reports. Miss Rawls will also be the associate producer of the film.

title: Enoch Powell, a Key Tory, Suggests Foes of Market Should Vote for Labor
description: LONDON, Feb. 23  In a move that angered Conservative party leaders in this decisive week of the election campaign, Enoch Powell, the party's controversial maverick, suggested today that Britons opposed to the Common Market should vote for the Labor party on Thursday.

title: A Dental Clinic for Fairleigh
description: PATERSONShaking and sobbing, the petite 7yearold girl fought to overcome her fear of the dental probe as she reclined in the clinic chair. Suddenly, a firedrill bell pierced the quiet of the cheerfully painted room at the Martin Luther King School, and the child escaped from her torture.

title: Three Movie Men Tell Their Side of the Story
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: CHILD'S DISEASE SPURS RESEARCH
description: An outbreak of Reye's Syndrome, a rare and often fatal disease affecting children from birth to the age of 17 years, has spurred medical researchers to seek means of preventing and curing the ailment, which destroys the liver, brain and other organs.

title: Ski Touring Is Bringing Back Original Image of the Sport
description: WOODSTOCK, Vt.  Clint Gilbert, a local dairy farmer, and Bunny Bertram, a Dartmouth skier, erected America's first uphill ski ride a rope tow  in a local cow pasture 40 years ago.

title: A Portrait of Brezhnev Causes Mild Sensation
description: MOSCOW Feb. 23  A new portrait of Leonid I. Brezhnev by the Soviet artist who was Stalin's favorite portraitist has caused a mild sensation at the current art exhibition in honor of the 25th anniversary of the Soviet Academy of Arts.

title: A. B. Caesar Fiance Of Margaretta Oliver
description: SEWICKLEY, Pa., Feb. 23 George S. Oliver, a vice president of the Pittsburgh National Bank, and Mrs. Oliver have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaretta Wood Oliver, to Austin Brewster Caesar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Caesar 2d of New Canaan, Conn. The wedding is planned for June.

title: ITALIAN PARTIES MAY GET TAX FUND
description: ROME, Feb. 23  Parliamentary leaders seem close to agreement on a draft bill that would introduce state subsidies for political parties, but the plan appears to be highly, unpopular throughout Italy.

title: InterSession Study Plan at Drew Hailed
description: MADISONDrew University's first January Plan program, which offered a month's intensive study during the break between semesters, was a solid success, according to a report submitted to school officials.

title: Flint Breaks Mark With Vault of 147
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 23 Paul Flint of Highland Falls polevaulted 14 feet 7 inches last night to break his New York state scholastic indoor record in the Section 9 track championships at the West Point Fieldhouse.

title: Common Market Will Drop Automobile Insurance Card
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 23 (UPI)The green cardthe proof of insurance needed to drive around western Europewill be abolished within the European Economic Community on May 15, the Common Market has announced.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Talk With Mr. Knopf
description: Mr. Knopf, is it true that you have retired?

title: Impeachment Texts
description: On occasion, on very rare occasions, a book or broadside affects history directly and immediately. Erasmus's revised edition of the New Testament was such a book. We all have our favorite examplesthough not too many of them. In order for a book to affect history, it must generally appear at a time when people are eager to act but do not quite know how to focus and justify their urge. The great book informs, justifies and usually prescribes.

title: Offing the ikons of the passing parade
description: I found this collection of parodies from the National Lampoon gross, tasteless, sophomoric, semipornographic and downright subversive. And if that doesn't make you want to rush right out and buy the book, I will add funnywll, most of the time.

title: World's Stickiest Party Honors WinniethePooh
description: There was Hipy Papy Bthuthdth Thuthda Bthuthdy cake at the world's stickiest party yesterday, when F.A.O. Schwarz lent itself to a honey tasting in honor of WinniethePooh.

title: Profits Up Like Prices For Food Industry
description: The food industry, including supermarket chains that complained about a cost squeeze most of last year, rode higher prices to improved levels of profitability in 1973.

title: So Far, 29 Men and 9 Corporations
description: WASHINGTONOnly the vague shape of the full Watergate criminal case has appeared thus far, a lump of uncertain size protruding through the trials, indictments and negotiated pleas. But already the number of those who have gone before the courts is surprisingly large: 29 men and nine corporations.

title: A Latin Delight Survives in Tampa
description: WHENEVER I go back to Tampa, Fla., where I was born, I spend most of my time bemoaning the breakup of its Latin section, Ybor City, which is really my home town. Or marveling at the growth of Tampa: The fillin that has created new real estate in every cove of Tampa Bay, the new airport that rivals any on the East Coast, the streams of tourists heading for the beaches on the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Mothers May Gain Goal of Playground
description: A group of nine Brooklyn Heights mothers decided last week to shortcut the complicated and tortuous process of obtaining funds from the city's capital budget to renovate a playground just off the Promenade overlooking the waters of New York Harbor. And In spite of their admitted naivete in the political process, they were given a good chance of getting $65,000 to further their project.

title: Chess: Turning the Tables Doesn't Always Turn the Tables
description: Alexander Alekhine was the first to win the world championship by turning his opponent's weapons against him. Although he was dreaded and admired for his incredible fantasies in combination play, he put his natural bent aside to adopt the logical, conservative style of Jose Radl Capablanca, from whom he captured the title in Buenos Aires in 1927.

title: Making It All Too Clear
description: LONDON, Feb. 23  A puzzled reader in Sarasota, Florida, has requested a simple explanation of the British election. The following questionnaire is provided:

title: Aussie Wins Nigeria Golf
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 23 AP)Jack Newton, an Australian shot a fourunderpar 67 today to win the 1974 Nigeria open golf championship with a fourround score of 275. Three British competitors, Christie O'Connor, Ron Shade and Eammon Darcy, shared second place at 279.

title: We Thought of Going to Maine, but the Fjord Was a Better Idea
description: PUSHING aside practicality, my wife and I decided that we and our three children, aged 6, 9 and 11, were ready for a monthlong family trip, We chose Norway.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: This is in reference to the news article Lumber Costs Dropping As Home Prices Rise [Feb. 10].

title: Slouching toward Smyrna
description: There are certain magisterial works of the human mind that alter ordinary comprehension so unpredictably and on so prodigious a scale that culture itself is set awry, and nothing can ever be seen again except in the strange light of that new knowledge. Obviously it is not possible to review such a work, any more than one can review a mountain range: an accretion of fundamental insight takes on the power of a natural force. Gershom Scholem's oeuvre has such a force, and its massive keystone, Sabbatai Sevi, presses down on the gasping consciousness with the strength not simply of its invulnerable, almost tidal, scholarship, but of its singular instruction in the nature of man.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: One of the unhappy consequences of the energy shortage is an increase in unemployment. The rate rose to 5.2 per cent in January from 4.8 per cent in December, the largest monthly increase in four years.

title: Newt's of the Stage
description: In 1945, a teenager by the name of Doris Cole made her Broadway producing debut with Blue Holiday, a variety show that costarred Ethel Waters, Josh White and Katharine Dunham. Since then she has been an expatriate in London, where she became an active stage producer and the only American woman member of the Society of West End Theater Managers.

title: Nathan A. Estes 3d Is Fiance Janice Doherty Of Noel Evangeline Thorbecke Bride in Capital
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 23 Miss Noel Evangeline Thorbecke, a granddaughter of Leopold Stokowsld, the conductor, plans to be married to Nathan Anthony Estes 3d. The ceremony will take place in June in Saratoga, N. Y.

title: Dr. Fritz Dreyfuss Is Dead Israeli Cardiologist Was 63
description: Dr. Fritz Dreyfuss, a leading Israeli cardiologist, died Friday in Tel Aviv. He was 63 years old.

title: Carl J. Grivner Fiance Of Miss Molly Moran
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., Feb. 23  Miss Molly Bridget Moran and Carl J. Grivner plan to be married. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Moran of Oakwood Park, parents of the bridetobe, whose fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl H. Grivner of Luzerne.

title: Golfers Pay Tribute To Werden of Times
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla,, Feb. 23The players who compete on the Professional Golfers' Association tour gave an affectionate sendoff today to Lincoln A. Werden, who has covered golf and other sports for The New York Times since 1928. Werden will retire Feb. 28, and the Jackie Gleason Inverrary Classic here is his last assignment.

title: La Salle, Fairfield Win at Garden
description: Bill Taylor is La Salle's top scorer. The Explorers are usually content to have him score and not tire himself on defense.

title: Austrian Brothers Pace Luge Races
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 23 (UPI)Manfred Schmid and his brother, Rudolf, of Austria took first and second, respectively, today after the opening heats of the international luge competition here. The finals are scheduled for tomorrow.

title: Extra Gas Won't Be Here Until Late This Week
description: The extra eight million gallons of gasoline the Federal Energy Office promised last Tuesday for hardpressed New York service stations in a matter of days will arrive here late this week.

title: Sandra Shaffer Bride of H. S. Tinkham
description: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass.Feb. 23Miss Sandra Charlotte Shaffer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Fiske Shaffer of Suffield, Conn., and Nassau, N.Y., was married here this afternoon to H. Stetson Tinkham of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Linwood Tinkham of Williamsburg, Va. The Rev. Deans W. Ferm, a Presbyteriau minister, performed the ceremony in the Abbey Memorial Chapel at Mount Holyoke

title: RELIGIOUS BALANCE IN LEBANON UPSET
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 23Some toplevel civil service posts were shifted from Christians to Moslems this week, creating an emotional controversy that has shaken the delicate political balance in Lebanon.

title: Demonstration in Frankfurt
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Feb. 23 (AP)About 20 policemen were injured in street fighting today with more than 3,000 stonethrowing leftist demonstrators, the authorities said. At least 20 demonstrators were arrested. They were protesting the eviction of about 50 squatters from four condemned apartment houses.

title: Peking Says Tablet Records China's Presence on Paracela
description: PEKING, Feb. 23 (Reuter's) According to press reports here, Chinese naturalists on the disputed Paracel archipelago have unearthed a tablet that was said to record a Chinese presence on the South China Sea islands over 70 years ago.

title: Dahomey Pats Stress On Traditional Clothes
description: COTONOU, Dahomey, Feb. 23 (Agence France Presse)Traditional African dress is now compulsory for all Dahomeans attending official functions.

title: A Poll Checks on Child Care
description: SUMMIT  A contingent of 40 women volunteers, each wearing a yellow nametag and carrying a 13page questionnaire, started knocking on doors in Summit, New Providence and Berkeley Heights last week.

title: Upsala Will Aid Two Hemophiliacs
description: EAST ORANGEA special blood drive will be held by the Upsala College community on March 4 in an effort to help extend the lives of two Parsippany brothers who are hemophiliacs.

title: Creatures in hiding
description: ACROSS

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: THERE is a growing sense of unease, tension and discontent throughout the land over the state of the nation's economy that seems hardly warranted by its overall performance and prospects. What certainly is justified, however, is grave concern over the horrendous pattern of the various price indexes.

title: Colgate Selects Parr
description: HAMILTON, N.Y., Feb. 23 (UPI)Tom Parr, a quarterback who hold every Colgate University total offense record, will become offensive backfield coach for the Red Raiders following his graduation in June, it was announced today. Parr will replace A. Wallace Hood, who resigned recently to become head coach at Ohio Northern University.

title: BRAZIL IS SEEKING CHURCH HARMONY
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 23Talks, aimed at ending a feud between church and state in this largely Roman Catholic country have been held by the Archbishop of So Paulo and several other prelates with aides of Brazil's Presidentelect, Ernesto Geisel.

title: Common sense and too much dictation
description: It is sometimes hard to believe that there is only one Andrew Greeley. At the age of 45, he is a Roman Catholic priest, a Ph.D. in sociology, a lecturer at the University of Chicago, director of the Center for the Study of American Pluralism of the National Opinion Research Center, the author of 15 books and, it seems, hundreds of magazine articles. According to Time magazine, which described him as a minor industry, Father Greeley writes, by dictating into a tape recorder and editing the transcriptsI believe it.

title: CHILD'S DISEASE SPURS RESEARCH
description: An outbreak of Reye's Syndrome, a rare and often fatal disease affecting children from birth to the age of 17 years, has spurred medical researchers to seek means of preventing and curing the ailment, which destroys the liver, brain and other organs.

title: Nassau Ordered to Give Supplement to U.S. Aid
description: MINEOLA, L.I.  The seedy aged, blind and disabled, caught between local and Federal bureaucracies, cannot be denied emergency funds by the Nassau County welfare agency, Judige Bertram Hartnett ruled here last week.

title: Adolfo Bezamat Marries Miss Tatiana Belosselsky
description: Miss Tetiana Belosselsky, daughter of Serge BelosselskyBeloiersky and the late Mrs. BelosselskyBelozersky, was married here yesterday afternoon to Adolfo Bezamat, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Augusto Bezamat of Santiago, Chile.

title: Jackie Lundmark and Paul Karl Set May. 25 Wedding Date.
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 23  Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth H. Lundmark have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jacqueline Gail Lundmark, to Paul Frederick Karl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Karl.

title: British Industry Fares Better Than Expected in Crisis
HEARST SUSPECTS MAINTAIN SILENCE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24The kidnappers of Patricia Hearst again made no response today to the Hearst Corporation's offer to add $4million to a free food program in exchange for her immediate release.

title: MORE U.S. FUNDS SEEN FOR SCHOOLS
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 24The Federal Government, which now pays 8 per cent of the cost of running the nation's elementary and secondary schools, will be absorbing onethird of the cost 10 years from now, it was predicted here yesterday.

title: Advertising: Publisher on People
description: With the appearance today on the nation's newsstands of the first issue of Time Inc.'s new weekly magazine called People, Richard J. Durrell, publisher, had a few things to say.

title: STATE ALLOCATING EXTRA GASOLINE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 24Governor Wilson announced today that a distribution plan for the state's extra allotment of 30.4 million gallons of gasoline would be initiated tomorrow by the State Emergency Fuel Office.

title: Houston Begins to Feel Gas Shortage
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 23The gasoline shortage so much a part of everyday life on the East Coast has in recent days begun to be felt even in this refining city.

title: TIETJEN IS HAILED BY BERGEN CROWD
description: PARAMUS, N.J., Feb. 24 The central figure in one of the nation's bitterest theological disputes was hailed today by more than 500 supporters at a dinner and reception in the Imperial Manor on Route 4 here.

title: Head of Consumer League Will Give Newark Lecture
description: NEWARK, Feb. 24Ricki Stochaj, the president of the Consumer League of New Jersey, an independent organization founded in 1900, is scheduled to speak on 2020 Consumer Vision at the Newark College of Engineering here at noon this Wednesday. Mrs. Stochaj has headed the volunteer group since 1970. Before that, she was involved in a variety of community affairs, including service as vice president and a board member of the local League of Women Voters and board member and public affairs chairman of the Young Womens Christian Association.

title: U.N. Diplomats Asking Special Status on Gas
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 23An Arab diplomat from one of the richest oil sheikdom says he buys gasoline for cash in New York these days because that way he can remain incognito.

title: A Form of Death Without Honor
description: On a marble wall in the lobby of the Medical Examiner's office at 520 First Avenue is a Latin inscription that translates as:

title: Lee Leads Clinton Into Semifinals
description: Butch Lee, one of the mostsought schoolboy players here, scored 27 points and had nine tseals as he led Clinton into the semifinal round of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship yesterday at Queens College.

title: NEW THEORY GIVEN IN CANCER GROWTH
description: DENVER, Feb. 24  A new Hypothesis to explain the ability of cancer to escape from restraint and destruction by the parent's body was presented here at a meeting of specialists in the use of immunological methods of cancer treatment.

title: State Hearings Scheduled On Con Ed's Energy Plan
description: ALBANY, Feb. 24The Public Service Commission today announced that it would begin hearing next month on an emergency energyconservation plan proposed by the Consolidated Edison Company. The plan would be put into effect if the utility's fueloil supply dropped to less than a fiveday supply.

title: TRIPLING PROFITS SEEN IN MIDEAST
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 19Information gathered from officials of producer nations and European and Japanese buyers in the Persian Gulf region indicate that the profit of Western oil companies operating in the Middle East has jumped in the past year from 30 cents to more than $1 a barrel.

title: Dave Anderson
description: MESA, Ariz., Feb. 24During one of the early baseball salary arbitration sessions, Charles O. Finley, the owner of the Oakland A's, was arguing that his team payroll for 1973 had been among the major league leaders.

title: Manhattan Is Victor
description: NEWARK, Del., Feb. 24Manhattan College scored in the distance medley and the twomile relays and Penn State's Mike Sands of Brooklyn registered victories in the 60yard dash and 440yard run at the annual University of Delaware collegiate track meet today. The Jaspers captured the distance medley relay in 9 minutes 51.6 seconds.

title: EXNIXON WRITER FOR IMPEACHMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24A former speech writer for President Nixon has called for his impeachmentthe first member or former member of the White House staff to do so.

title: DELETION REPORTED IN PLUMBERS MEMO
description: White House documents given to the Watergate special prosescutor's office were altered to delete written authorization by John D. Ehrlichman, former White House aide, for the plumbers unit to obtain material from Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist. Time magazine reported yesterday.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: ITHACA, N. Y.Last month, the Mobil Oil Corporation republished the advertisements on the energy problem that it had placed in newspapers over the preceding twenty months and that said: Anyone who says the energy crisis was a surprise hasn't been reading this newspaper.

title: KNOWLAND DEATH IS CALLED SUICIDE
description: GUERNEVILLE, Calif., Feb. 24 (UPI)An autopsy showed today that William F. Knowland, former Republican leader in the United States Senate, killed himself yesterday with a single .32caliber bullet in the head as he stood on the dock of his $100,000 summer home along the Russian River.

title: Six Firemen Hospitalized After South Bronx Blaze
description: A smoky onealarm blaze broke out in a South Bronx building yesterday, causing six fire fighters to be hospitalized for injuries before it was brought under control, fire officials reported.

title: Mrs. Spruance Wins
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 24  Mrs. Halsey Spruance won the United States women's squash racquets championship for the second straight year by defeating Ginny Akabane of Henrietta, N.Y., 158, 1512, 159, today

title: STATE PREPARING TO ENFORCE RULES ON GASOLINE SALE
description: State and local agencies began planning yesterday for the mandatory oddeven system of gasoline sales that goes into effect at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Nonbidding Award of Tree Contracts In Lindsay Era Is Under Investigation
description: The Department of Investigation is studying the urgency behind a city treeplanting program under the Lindsay administration that compelled the swift awarding of contracts totaling more than $1.7million to three selected large landscape contractors without competitive bidding.

title: British Soccer Results
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Yankee Plays Key Role In an Old Southern Feud
description: Ernie Grunfeld, who found his way to the University of Tennessee basketball court by way of Rumania and Forest. Hills High School in Queens, has made some key contributions to the Volunteers' 157 wonlost record, but none was more important than his 23 points Saturday night against an old rival Vanderbilt.

title: Fuchsberg Heads Committee
description: Jacob D. Fuchsberg, the Democratic party's unsuccessful candidate last year for chief judge of the State Court of Appeals, has been redesignated chairman of the committee of the State Appellate Division, First Department in Manhattan. Owen McGiverh, presiding justice of the Appellate Department, yesterday announced that Mr. Fuchsberg again would head the interprotessional commites of doctors wand lawyers established to coordinate legal efforts in the two professions.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following Is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Margaret Leech Pulitzer, Historian, Is Dead at 80
description: Margaret Leech, the historian, died yesterday at her home 812 Fifth Avenue, following a stroke. She was 80 years old and the widow of Ralph Pulitzer, former publisher of the New. York World, who died in 1939.

title: Newsman Hurt in Cambodia
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 24 (Agence FrancePresse) A French Journalist, Michel Honorin, was wounded in the back today by mortar fragmerits on the Phnom Penh southern front. Mr Honorin, 38 years old, is an editor for Path Gaumont, a newsreel company. He was in satisfactory condition at French Hospital.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 24The position on Israel's Syrian front differs in several respects from that on the Egyptian front, where Secretary of State Kissinger succeeded in mediating a disengagement agreement last month.

title: Havlicek Is Star as Celtics Win
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 24 (AP)John Havlicek sparked a Boston rally early in the second half today and the Celtics rolled to a 11196 National Basketball Association victory over Atlanta. It was their fifth consecutive triumph over, the Hawks' this season.

title: Dr. George A. Van Biesbroeck; Astronomer Studied Twin Stars
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 24 (AP)Dr. George A. Van. Biesbroeck, an astronomer recognized for his work with twin stars, asteroids and comets, died yesterday at his home here. He was 94 years old. Dr. Van Biesbroeck was one of the oldest working astronomers in the world. He was an active University of Arizona research, associate until his death.

title: Soccer Results
description: NATIONAL CHALLENGE CUP Doxa 2. Blue Star 0.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The question arises in many minds today whether the Solzhenitsyn affair is hurting or helping EastWest dtente.

title: Court Rules Town Can't Force Builders To Donate Land for Recreational Uses
description: DOVER TOWNSHIP, Feb. 24 In a decision almost certain to have a statewide impact, Superior Court Judge Edward V. Martino has struck down the common practice by municipalities of compelling developers to donate land for recreational use.

title: By Priscilla W. Laws
description: CARLISLE, Pa.  All of us are familiar with the largescale advertising campaign sponsored by glass, steel and aluminumcontainer manufacturers to convince the public that nodeposit noreturn containers are good for the environment because they can be recycled. Few people realize that this campaign, which has been going on for almost three years, is being sponsored by the nation's glass, steel and aluminumcontainer manufacturers at a cost, so far, of over $10 million.

title: Young Kennedy Released
description: BOSTON, Feb. 24 (AP) Edward M. Kennedy Jr., 12 years old, was released from Children's Hospital Medical Center today after tests and treatment to prevent recurrence of bone cancer that led. to the amputation of his right leg last year.

title: Rise in Car Arson In Massachusetts Linked to Gas Cost
description: BOSTON, Feb. 24The rising cost of gasoline may be adding to the growing number of automobile arson cases in Massachusetts, according to state insurance investigators.

title: Fuel Crisis Is Hobbling Suburbs
description: DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 24Judy Barnett went to church this morning as usual, but to save precious gasoline she iode with her friend Martha Duck, who lives down the road. Later she and her husband, Charles, drove 10 miles to visit hey parents in Fairfield, a trip she once made several times a week but now does only on Sundays.

title: Arts Council Plans Direct Subsidies
description: The New York State Council on the Arts will adopt new policy of providing direct basic support for major cultural institutions if Governor Wilson's request for a $30.5million budget for the arts is approved, says Eric Larrabee, executive director of the arts council.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 29

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Kissinger and Latins See Gains in Mexico Parley
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24Secretaty of State Kissinger was elated by the results of the threeday conference of hemisphere foreign ministers in Mexico City, one of his senior aides said today. A lengthy communiqu issued today documented the work of the conference, which ended yesterday.

title: Nicklaus Distracted On Putt by Love Bug
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 24  When Jack Nicklaus studies a putt, he is the epitome of concentration, and nothing much can distract him. Yet today, on national television, he addressed a putt and then abruptly broke off the action to slap at his right leg.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Yanks' Kline Out to Erase Memories; 2
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 24Whitey Ford, the businesslike pitching coach, stopped in front of Steve Kline in the clubhouse, clipboard in hand.

title: STATE PREPARING TO ENFORCE RULES ON GASOLINE SALE
description: State and local agencies began planning yesterday for the mandatory oddeven system of gasoline sales that goes into effect at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Dartmouth Takes Title In Eastern Ski Meet
description: HANCOCK, Vt., Feb. 24Dartmouth College had to settle for a secondplace tie in the jump today, but scored enough points in the final event of the Eastern Intercollegiate ski competition to win the title with 175 points.

title: FIRE FIGHTER SAVES BROWNSVILLE BABY
description: A 47yearold Fire Departmerit lieutenant, groping his way through the smoke and searing heat of a burning house, rescued an 18monthold girl early yesterday in a Brooklyn fire.

title: MRS. ZALTZBERG, 49; RAISIN COAUTHOR
description: Charlotte Singer Zaltzberg coauthor with Robert Nemirof of the Broadway musica Raisin, died of cancer yesterday at SloanKettering Institute for Cancer Research. She was 49 years old and lived at 330 West 58th Street and Croton.

title: Pace of Growth for Machine Tool Orders Slackens
description: The machine tool industry started the new year with 18 per cent more new orders than in the first month of last year, the National Machine Tool Builder's Association reported over the weekend.

title: $2Million Vermeer Is Stolen in London
description: LONDON, Feb. 24 (AP)A Vermeer masterpiece valued at more than $2million was stolen last night from Kenwood House, Scotland Yard said today.

title: Danish Concern Is GoBetween For U. S. Clients on China Deals
description: COPENHAGEN, DenmarkWhen President Nixon and Chinese leaders were toasting one another in Peking two years ago, some of the loudest cheers back in the United States came from businessmen who saw a new trade horizon opening before their eyes. But with a few exceptions, they're still looking.

title: TV: Meditating on Young Guru and His Followers
description: The Lord of the Universe, an hourlong documentary shown on the Public Broadcasting Service last night; was produced by TVTV, the group that wrested some prominence from cable TV with videotape portraits of the Republican and Democratic National Conventions in 1972. This time the phenomenon under study was Maharaj 31, the pudgy 16yearold Indian guru whose followers believe him to be God After TVTV superbly dissected the guru, his holy family and his followers, more objective viewers might have chosen to laugh, cry or throw up.

title: Chou Stresses Ideological Campaign
description: HONG KONG, Monday, Feb. 25In an unusual public reference to the current ideological campaign in China, Premier Chou Enlai said last night that the campaign Was of mat immediate significance and farreaching historic importance as a continuation of the Cultural Revolution.

title: Shah Firm on Prices
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 24 The Shah of Iran is prepared to make some of his country's oil riches available to poorer countries, but he and his advisers are adamantly against rollback in oil prices.

title: Redesigned Intrepid Shows Improved Speed in First Test Run
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 24The champion 12Meter racing sloop Intrepid, preparing to seek a third straight victory in defense of the America's Cup in September, ran up her sails today in the first test of her new, redesigned hull and keel.

title: Best Bet: Big A to Open Today
description: The earliest opening of the thoroughbred horse racing season in New York's history will take place today at the Aqueduct race track, where a crowd of 35,000 fans (given good weather) is expected. Featuring the opening day's card will be the Paumonok Handicap, for older horses at six furlongs.

title: They Care About an Employe's Problems as Well as His Production
description: WEBSTER, N. Y.  Sue Burton, who has long manoganycolored hair and the sweet open face of a high school homecoming queen, didn't know where to turn when her marriage began to disintegrate. The 31yearold mother of two felt that she didn't have the confidence to try to make it on her ownnor the money for professional counseling.

title: SPANISH BISHOP ASKS BASQUE FREEDOMS
description: MADRID, Feb. 24  The Roman Catholic Church in the northern province of Vizcaya Called today for greater freedom for Spain's Basque minority, apparently defying a Government admonition to stay out of politics.

title: Yankee Plays Key Role In an Old Southern Feud
description: Ernie Grunfeld, who found his way to the University of Tennessee basketball court by way of Rumania and Forest Hills High. School in Queens, has made sortie key contributions to the Volunteers' 157 wonlost record, but none was more important than his 23 points Saturday night against an old rival, Vanderbilt.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: Boogie Lightning, by Michael Lydon, photographs by Ellen Mandel (Dial Press, $6.95). The music and music makers of the nineteensixties.

title: Courage and Dignity of Elderly Poor Surface During Project to Aid Them
description: Courage can be a quiet quality when it breeds in the obscure and joyless corners of the city. For the most part it goes unheralded. But it can be found, if anyone tries hard enough.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Bar Patrons Stripped of Belongings

title: Austrians Rule U.S. Luge Races
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 24  The Schmid brothers from Salzburg, Austria Manfred and Rudolfwill remember the first major international luge races in the United States as enjoyable experiences.

title: ETHIOPIA MOVES TO EASE PROTESTS
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 24Disorder subsided in this capital today after the Government acted to ease some of the grievances that caused a week of rioting.

title: City Goes on Alert In Face of Forecast Of Heavy Snowfall
description: One of the winter's biggest snowstorms was expected to wallop the metropolitan area today, bringing accumulations of 5 to 8 inches, along with hazardous driving conditions and commuting delays.

title: Blast Shatters Windows
description: An explosion yesterday in a Consolidated Edison manhole apparently caused by a short circuit broke windows in several stores and apartments in the vicinity of 331 East 194th Street, off Marion Avenue in the Fordham section of the Bronx. The explosion, which occurred at 12:35 A.M., left a hole 10 feet in diameter in the street but did not interfere with traffic, the police said. Windows in five stores and seven apartments were broken by the blast, which did not cause any injuries, the police said.

title: Gangs Terrorizing Brooklyn Merchants
description: Youth gangs in northern Brooklyn are operating an extortion network which, according to a police official, involves 2,500 youths preying on as many as 200 merchants. He said the gangs might be taking in as much as $1,500 a week.

title: Personal Finance
description: Life insurance salesmen are always looking for customers but when a customer starts looking for a salesman, the salesman very often starts looking for the reason.

title: Grimmer Captures Ski Race
description: FALUN, Sweden, Feb. 24 (UPI)  Gerhard Grimmer gave East Germany another title today by winning the men's 50kilometer crosscountry race, the final event of the world Nordic skiing championships.

title: 7 Bombs Go Off in Mexico
description: GUADALAJARA, Mexico, Feb. 24 (AP)  Seven bombs exploded in Guadalajara and Oaxaca last night, and this morning, the authorities said. Three of the targets were American concerns  PepsiCpla, CocaCola and Union Carbide. No casualties or arrests were reported.

title: Grimmer Captures Ski Race
description: FALUN, Sweden, Feb. 24 (UPI)  Gerhard Grimmer gave East Germany another title today by winning the men's 50kilometer crosscountry race, the final event of the world Nordic skiing championships.

title: Pollution With Reserve
description: Five years ago Federal and state officials came to the conclusion that it was time for the Reserve Mining Company to stop dumping taconite waste into the otherwise pristine waters of Lake Superior, the largest and purest freshwater lake in the world. Only nowfive long years laterdoes it appear likely that the obdurate companyowned jointly by the Republic Steel Corporation and the Armco Steel Corporationwill have to switch to an onland disposal system or close down.

title: Harry Ruby, Song Writer, Dies; Composed Three Little Words
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24Harry Ruby, popularsong composer and writer of Broadway stage scores and movie scenarios, died last night in the Motion Picture and Television Hospital in Woodland Hills. He was 79 years old and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: Petty Is 2d To Allison In Virginia
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 24(AP) Bobby Allison finally ended Richard Petty's domination of the Fairgrounds Raceway today with a threesecond victory in the Richmond 500.

title: ExDetective Is Linked to Drug Dealer
description: The former detective described as the prime suspect in the theft of $70million worth of cocaine and heroin from the New York Police Department served as a bodyguard for the children of major narcotic dealer, lawenforcement sources said yesterday.

title: Dance: Grandeurs of Moor's Pavane
description: The Moor's Pavane, the late Jos Limn's retelling of Othello in moderndance terms, was and remains Mr. Limns indisputable masterpiece. No other choreographer seems to have given the essence of Shakespearean drama in dance with such distillation. Without betraying the source, Mr. Limn was also able to give it another dimension.

title: A Stratton Bid Could Tarnish Samuels's Bandwagon Image
description: Don't get mad; just get even, is a favorite adage of many politicians and it could be a factor in the current Democratic gubernatorial race. Representative Samuel S. Stratton of Amsterdam, for example, insists that he is still considering a gubernatorial candidacy although most Democrats dismiss him as too conservative as well as lacking money and statewide stature.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PARIS, Ky., Feb. 24 (AP)  Secretariat, syndicated for more money than any race horse in history, has until Aug. 1 to prove he can get 60 per cent or more of the mares bred to him in foal or the syndicate folds, the syndicate manager disclosed today. Seth Hancock, president of Claiborne Farm and the syndicate manager, said that revised agreements were mailed this weekend to the 32 syndicate members. The members already have paid $19,000 as a down payment and $28,500 will be due April 1, Hancock said.

title: Kung Futzu
description: WASHINGTONTwo centuries before the birth of Christ, the first emperor of the Ch'in dynasty in China came to the conclusion that the only way to break out of feudalism into nationhood would be to strike at the followers of the philosopher Kung Futzu.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON, Feb. 24Since the days of Bill Bradley, basketball has been the darling of Princeton's winter sports fans. But during the last few weeks eyes have turned toward Princeton's Baker rink and a resurgent Princeton University hockey team.

title: EXNIXON WRITER FOR IMPEACHMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24A former speech writer for President Nixon has called for his impeachmentthe first member or former member of the White House staff to do so.

title: Vast Aid From U.S. Backs Saigon in Continuing War
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 16Ray Harris of Ponca City, Okla., has come back to Vietnam. This time he is not behind die machine gun of an Army helicopter but behind workbench at the Bien Hoe air base, sitting next to South Vietnamese Air Force men and repairing jet fighter engines.

title: Shoes That Make You Waddle Like a DuckAnd They Sell
description: When Peter and Nancy Frangoulis were married in Brooklyn last June the bride wore traditional white and a veil, the bridegroom wore a white suit. If they looked a little like ducks walking down the aisle, it was because they were both wearing their white Earth Shoes.

title: SADAT FINDS U.S CHANGING POLICY
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, Feb. 24President Anwar eiSadat of Egypt said today that United States policy in the Middle East was changing and expressed optimism that Syrian and Israeli forces could be disengaged.

title: Law School's Plan To Aid Minorities Goes to High Court
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24A law school admission dispute that has developed into a national controversy over preferential treatment for racial minorities will be argued before the Supreme Court Tuesday.

title: Kissinger Leaving Today On New Mideast Mission
Issue and Debate
description: The oil shortage has brought forth the argument that there should be a Federal oil corporation  something like the Tennessee Valley Authority.

title: Election Crucial to Mrs. Gandhi Begins in North Indian State
description: LUCKNOW, India, Feb. 24Elections in Uttar Pradesh, the most populous state in northern India, began today with an unusually large turnout of untouchable, or low caste, voters.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 29

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on the peaceful uses of outer space, working group on remote sensing of the earth and task force of the working group10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Miss Jean Rubin Is Married Here To Leslie Finer
description: Miss Jean Rubin, former consultant on public affairs with the Child Welfare League of America, was married here yesterday afternoon to Leslie Finer of London, director of the United Kingdom office of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. Rabbi Ira Eisenstein performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Byron Dobell.

title: At 23, She's Cabinetmaker By Day, Teacher at Night
description: Only small people can fit into it, said Amanda Gimble, gesturing toward a rather originallooking rocker in a corner of her plantfilled living room. Because when I made it, I gauged the size by me.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State Kissinger will leave today on another trip to the Middle East, hoping to bring about negotiations between Israel and Syria on separation of their military forces on the Golan Heights. Some Arab diplomats have suggestedrecently that a Kissinger success would lead the Arabs to end their oil embargo against the United States. But American officials  who had wrongly predicted that the embargo would be lifted after Mr. Kissinger helped arrange the IsraeliEgyptian disengagement accordhesitated to join such speculation. [1:12.]

title: G.O.P. Loss of Labor
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 24  Lying among the debris of the Watergate scandal are the wrecked Republican hopes  fanned by President Nixon's sweeping electoral success in 1972  of wresting a permanent labor constituency away from the Democratic party. Just how far those hopes have gone aglimmering is aptly symbolized by the politicians who have and have not appeared at the winter meeting of the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, being held at the Americana Hotel here.

title: Farah Strike Ends After 21 Months
description: A bitter strike that lasted nearly 22 months at the Farah pants factories in Texas and New Mexico ended yesterday when the company agreed to rehire the 3,000 strikers and to recognize and negotiate a contract with the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America.

title: State Law to Protect Local Wetlands Is Challenged by Dredging Company
description: TRENTON  The American Dredging Company of Philadelphia is challenging the constitutionality of New Jersey's 1970 wetlands law and its implementation, in a test case to determine the state's powers to protect local wetlands.

title: A Deformed Infant Dies After Surgery Ordered by Court
description: PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 24 A severely deformed infant boy, who was operatedon after a state court ordered surgery to save the child's life despite his parents' refusal to authorize the operation, died in the Maine Medical Center here this morning.

title: States Reduce Road Work As Gasoline Revenues Fall
description: State governments are cutting back on new highway construction and delaying re. pairs on older roads because of a decline in gasoline tax rev enues, an Associated Press survey shows.

title: Byrne Seeks to. Shift Base For Jersey Fuel Allocations
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 24 (UPI)  Governor Byrne said tonight he would attempt to have the base year on which New Jersey's fuel allocations were calculated changed from 1972 to 1973.

title: First Aid to Magazines
description: When Congress created the United States Postal Service back in 1970, it expected this semiindependent public corporation to lift delivery of the mails from the incredibly low level of efficiency to which it had sunk even if postal rates would have to be raises some do it. Congress has been disappointed and so are other proponents of the new agency, this newspaper included. The services are hardly improved, if at all, and the cost increases are rapidly becoming intolerable.

title: WILSON RESISTS ON FISCAL LISTING
description: Governor Wilson said yesterday that information on income and tax payments by public officials was not relevant and he refused to say if he would make a total disclosure of his personal finances.

title: Vast Aid From U. S. Backs Saigon in Continuing War
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 16Ray Harris of Ponca City, Okla., has come back to Vietnam. This time he is not behind the machine gun of an Army helicopter but behind a workbench at the Bien Hoa air base, sitting next to South Vietnamese Air Force men and repairing jet fighter engines.

title: Fuel Crisis Is Hobbling Suburbs
description: DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 24Judy Barnett went to church this morning as usual, but to save precious gasoline she rode with her friend Martha Duck, who lives down the road. Later she and her husband, Charles, drove 10 miles to visit her parents in Fairfield, a trip she once made several times a week but now does only on Sundays.

title: Tanzanian Ambassador in Newark on Talent Hunt
description: NEWARK, Feb 24  Paul Bomani, Tanzania's Ambassador to the United States, visited here yesterday on the third stop of a nationwide tour that he said was designed to establish contacts with skilled black Americans who were willing to visit his country and to aid in its economic and social development.

title: Stage: Total Eclipse by the Chelsea
description: There was probably no more violent love affair between two artists than that season in hell for Arthur Rimbaud and Paul Verlaine. It was the subject of Total Eclipse, Christopher Hampton's second play, first produced in London nearly six years ago when the playwright was 22 years old. For some unaccountable reason the play has hitherto lacked a New York showing.

title: Rangers Defeat Flyers, 32, at Garden
description: Mugged, and loving it, the Rangers cooly halted the Philadelphia Flyers last night by 32.

title: Computer Plan Helps Scientists Find Way at Coast Convention
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24With 6,000 scientists and teachers, converging today on this city to discuss subjects ranging from astronomy (including black holes) to zoology (including woodchuck hibernation), a computer program has been developed to tell the conferees who is where.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Gross Trial Starts Tomorrow

title: ROSENBERG FILES RETAINED BY F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24It is a special case.

title: An ExPassaic Rabbi Indicted On Charge of Faking His Death
description: PASSAIC, Feb. 24A former awyer from Spring Valley, who practiced as a rabbi here for the last seven months has been indicted in New York City on charges of faking his dath to collect $201,247 in life insurance. The former lawper, Louis R. Wolfish, was charged by a Federal grand ury with three counts of mail fraud. He turned himself in on Feb. 14 and was released on a $25,000 personal bond. His arraignment is scheduled for March 4.

title: RATES SOFTENING FOR SHORT TERM
description: The downward drift of the lagging and sometimes politically sensitive prime lending rate that commercial banks charge their largest business borrowers is clearly not ended yet. Major moneyCenter banks had lowered this administered rate to 9 per cent in the last week, but several of them acted last Friday to drop the rate another notch to 8 per cent.

title: Indicted Congressman Cancels L.I. Appearance
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I. Feb. 24Representative Angelo D. Roncallo, who was indicted Thursday by a Federal grand jury on charges of extortion and conspiracy, canceled a scheduled appearance today on a panel discussing whether President Nixon should be impeached.

title: Smith Victor In Final
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 24 Stan Smith broke his dry spell today. The automaton from Sea Pines, S.C., defeated John Newcombe, the machine from Sydney, Australia, 6.4, 3.6, 6.3, in the final of the World Championship Tennis tournament at Nassau Coliseum and won $10,000.

title: U.S. Grand Jury Focuses on Troops In Shootings of Kent State Students
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 24Shots from an M1 rifle reverberated at Kent State University near the pagoda on top of the knoll from which National Guardsmen fired on May 4, 1970, killing four students and wounding nine.

title: Met. College Hockey
description: STANDING OF THE TEAMS

title: SADAT FINDS U.S. CHANGING POLICY
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, Feb. 24President Anwar elSadat of Egypt said today that United States policy in the Middle East was changing and expressed optimism that Syrian and Israeli forces could be disengaged.

title: Hal Boyle's Mother Dies
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 25 (AP)Mrs. Margaret Gavaghan Boyle, mother of Hal Boyle columnist for The Associated Press, died today. She was 86 years old. Hal Boyle is a Pulitzer Prizewinning newsman, who after 30 years wrote his final column, for last Friday. He made frequent mention of his mother in his columns, and Mrs. Boyle's name became familiar to thousands of newspaper readers throughout the country.

title: Flight Cuts and Traffic Rise Offset U. S. Airline Fuel Ills
description: Flight cutbacks attributed to jet fuel shortages, combined with slightly betterthanexpected passenger traffic, are helping the nation's domestic airlines achieve something they've sought for a long time: fuller airplanes.

title: Conflict of Interest Alleged In $673,000 Hospital Job
description: The Community Hospital of Brooklyn paid $673,000 on a construction contract to a building concern owned by one of its board members, the Temporary State Commission on Living Costs disclosed last night.

title: To Be French Is to Be French Is to Be French Is to Be French, etc.
description: PARISThe mentality of the molders of French public opinion is byproduct of the mentality of the French political class. That class is ashamed of showing any national feelings. They do express European feelings because it has the illusion of grandeur. That attitude is the key to all. It is so clear that it hardly needs definition: to be for a Europe which is open to any ideology, any special interests, any hidden calculations.

title: Law School's Plan To Aid Minorities Goes to High Court
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24A law school admission dispute that has developed into a national controversy over preferential treatment for racial minorities will be argued before the Supreme Court Tuesday.

title: Ford Foresees Peace Era For the Mideast Nations
description: Vice President Ford said here last night that an era oil peace is within reach, for the superpowers as well as the Middle Eastern countries.

title: Mets Seek to Create Them
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 24The celebrated pitching staff that got the New York Mets to the top of the hill last year had two vacancies today, and the people considered most likely to fill them were a pair of 23yearold Californians named Craig Swan and Bob Apodaca.

title: Delon's Trotter Triumphs in Italy
description: MILAN, Italy, Feb. 24 (AP)Equileo, owned by the French actor, Alain Delon, won the $53,500 Grand Prix Europe trotting race today at the San Siro track here. The 4yearold trotter, driven by Mario Rivara of Italy, was timed in 2:42 for the 2,100meter (about 15/16 miles) distance. Zeccola was second and another Italian horse, Carson, third.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE CRYSTAL GARDEN, By Elaine Feinstein. 176 pages. Dutton. $6.95.

title: Maryland Senate Bars Inquiry Into Political Pressure Charge
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 24The Maryland State Senate has killed legislation calling for an investigation, into charges that the founders of a statechartered bank were targets of pressure to sell stock to associates of Gov. Marvin Mandel.

title: Then Enterprise Is Sick
description: BOSTON, Feb. 24The siege of Troy was in Its seventh year, and the spirit of the Greeks was faltering. Why? In his great speech in Shakespeare's Troilus and Cressida; Ulysses explains to Agamemnon the King.

title: YOUTH FATALLY SHOT IN MUGGING ATTEMPT
description: A 17yearold youth was fatally shot last night when a movie theater security guard fired at four teenagers who had allegedly attempted to mug an elderly couple on Albee Square in downtown Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Post Office Hopes to Avold Ruth as Stamp Prices Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UFI)The Petal Service has asked citizens to avoid building up a crush of mail just befor a the deadline of 12:01 A,M. Saturday when postal rates Will go up by 2 cents.

title: St. Paul Chamber Ensemble Is Heard
description: The St. Paul Chamber Orchestra, a spirited and capable ensemble of 25, players conducted by Dennis Russell Davies, gave a concert Saturday at the Metropolitan Museum with Elly Ameling as soloist.

title: Screen: At the Whitney
description: How often writers wish that they might stroll into their own fictions, or be able to talk with their characters. I. B. Singer does exactly that in Bruce Davidson's delightful film, Isaac Singer's Nightmare and Mrs. Puko's Beard, included in the program of Biographical Cinema playing at the Whitney Museum of American Art until March 6.

title: Nixon Daughter Recovering
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) Mrs. David Eisenhower, President Nixon's younger daughter, Julie, was reported today to be making good progress in her recovery after surgery for a bleeding ovarian cyst, but will have to recuperate for another couple of weeks at the White House, Helen McCain Smith, Mrs. Nixon's press secretary, said Mrs. Eisenhower was resting a lot and taking little walks in the family quarters.

title: Era of Poleless Firehouse Due in '76
description: What is a firehouse without a pole? It is a onestory firehouse, and such a structure does not now exist in New York City. But the Fire Department has plans to build the city's first onestory firehouse.

title: Curling Results
description: AT ST. ANDREW'S G.C.

title: Islanders Lose, 53, To Wings
description: DETROIT, Feb. 24 (AP)Mickey Redmond scored three goals, the final one into an empty net with 22 secondms remaining, as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the New York Islanders, 53, in a National Hockey League game tonight.

title: Reijula Victor In Ski Jumping
description: ISHPEMING, Mich., Feb. 24 (AP)  Pertti Reijula, a Finn attending Northern Michigan University, took first place in Class A of the 87th annual Nordic Series ski jump on Suicide Hill today. Reijula had jumps of 251 and 258 feet for 205 points.

title: Miss Ross Is Wed To Dr. David Link
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 24Miss Margaret Ross, who will graduate in June from the Harvard Medical School, was married here today to Dr. David Link, a senior resident in pediatrics at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. Rabbi Samson Weiss performed the ceremony at the Ross home.

title: Setbacks for Mr. Heath
description: Prime Minister Heath and the Conservatives clearly won opening rounds of Britain's election campaign and seemed headed for a decisive victory Thursday. Now several developments have made that result less certain, reviving Labor party spirits but also encouraging the Liberals, who envision gains that could give them a balanceofpower position between the two larger parties.

title: About New York Chopin and a Psychic Pianist
description: First of all you have the problem, the drug problem, and if you have a youngster of your own you become, oh, concerned, Byron Janis was saying. Mr. Janis, the prominent pianist, was explaining why he was doing a benefit performance for Odyssey House at Carnegie Hall next Sunday, and his good intentions were apparent.

title: Files From Hoover to Backers Reported
description: J. Edgar Hoover, while director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, tried to help reelect Representative John J. Rooney and other Congressional supporters by supplying them With sensitive information about their political opponents, according to a wellplaced source.

title: An Indicted Upstate ExAide Kills Himself After Arraignment
description: The former director of urban renewal and housing in the upstate village of Newark died Saturday night of a selfinflicted gunshot wound, a day after his arraignment on three counts of official misconduct, authorities reported yesterday.

title: Japanese Politely Elbow Their Way Into Roller Derby
description: What ever happened to that stereotype of the Japanese woman who was like a delicate little flower?

title: Robin Too Nears Lead S.O.R.C.
description: MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 24Robin Too II, the 37foot OneTon Class sloop from Marblehead, Mass., won the Lipton Cup Day race yesterday, the fourth event in the six race yesterday, the fourth event in the six race Southern Ocean Racing Conference of over 100 yachts. The fifth event, the 196mile MiamiNassau race, starts off Government Cut here tomorrow.

title: Connors Beats McMillan, Retains Indoor Net Title
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 24 (AP)Jimmy Connors continued his domination of the United States Lawn Tennis Association indoor circuit today as he won National Indoor open title for the second year in a row, trouncing Frew McMillan, 64, 75, 63.

title: Thompson Wins on 68278
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 24Leonard Thompson, a 27yearold pro from Lumberton, N.C., won for the first time on the golf circuit today and quickly donated $10,000 of his $52,000 first prize to the Boys Clubs of America.

title: Ford Foresees Peace Era For the Mideast Nations
