description: Vice President Ford said here last night that an era of peace is within reach, for the superpowers as well as the Middle Eastern countries.

title: Sports Today
description: Golden Gloves, at Holy Family Auditorium, Rockaway Parkway and Conklin Avenue, Brooklyn, 8 P.M.

title: Smith's Vault Is Among 4 Records Set
description: POCATELLO, Idaho, Feb. 24 (AP)Steve Smith vaulted 18 feet 1 inches and bettered his indoor pro pole vault record last Right at an International Track Association Meet, Three other pro word indoor records were set.

title: Ruth Larned, ExOfficial Of Social Welfare Agency
description: Ruth Lamed, who retired in 1954 as associate general director of the International Social Service social welfare agency, died Saturday in the Florence Nightingale Nursing Home. She was 84 years old and lived at 228 East 11th Street.

title: Gangs Terrorizing Brooklyn Merchants
description: Youth gangs in northern Brooklyn are operating an extortion network which, according to a police official, involves 2,500 youths preying on as many as 200 merchants. He said the gangs might be taking in as much as $1,500 a week.

title: THOMAS BROWN JR., U.S. SECURITY EXPERT
description: Thomas R. Brown Jr., who was the State Department's chief of security for the founding conference of the United Nations in San Francisco in the spring of 1945, died Saturday in Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 302 West 86th Street.

title: A Top I.R.A. Leader Is Arrested in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 24 (Reuters)The Belfast leader of the Provisional wing of the outlawed Irish Republican Army has been apprehended by security forces which had sought him for two years, authorities said today.

title: ISRAEL GROUP OPENS DRIVE FOR $5MILLION
description: The National Committee for Labor Israel yesterday opened its 1974 campaign to raise $5million to carry out and maintain health, education and social welfare programs conducted by Histadrut, Israel's labor federation.

title: American and Spanish Units Hunting Atlantic Balloonist
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) Spanish and American military units searched the waters off northwest Africa today for Thomas L. Gatch, the Army Reserve colonel attempting the first manned transatlantic balloon flight.

title: ACCOUNTING UNIT SET HEARING ON CURRENCY
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board announced over the weekend that it planned to hold a public hearing June 10 on accounting issues related to translation of foreign currency.

title: The Arts in Need
description: The Concerned Citizens for the Arts, a group representing over 800 organizations throughout the state, will stage a major appeal in Albany tomorrow to urge the Legislature to provide funds in support of the arts, and to improve the distribution of these subsidies.

title: Dobermans In Sweep at New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 24It was Doberman pinscher night, at the 60th allbreed show of the Elms City Kennel. Club in Veteran! War Memorial Coliseum tonight.

title: Driver Fatally Shot And a 2d Wounded Following Crashes
description: Two men were shot, one fatally, early yesterday during arguments after two similar auto accidents in Brooklyn.

title: Hyphenates Seek Unified Film Approach
description: The hyphenates are beginning to dominate Hollywood.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LOOKING BACK, Gertrude Stein was born 100 years ago, on Feb. 3, 1874, and that haven of bibliophiles, the Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street (TE 86690) is giving her a memorial that speaks volumes. It is in the shape of an enormous assortment of Stein books, letters, manuscripts, photos and other memorabilia displayed in the club's spacious main hall.

title: Dialogue at Tlatelolco
description: Secretary of State Kissinger failed to get his goal of a new Western Hemisphere Community into the communiqu at Mexico City; but he unquestionably succeeded in opening a frank and practical dialogue with the twentyfour Latin American and Caribbean foreign ministersa development as welcome as it is overdue.

title: More Aid Is Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24A new study concludes that about 30 of the world's poorer countries will be the most serious victims of the big increase in the prices of oil, food and fertilizer, but that they can be saved from catastrophe by Rn additional $3billion in aid in 1974.

title: Bridge: TopSeeded Teams Advance
description: All the topseeded teams survived Saturday's knockout play in the Grand National Championship at the New York Hilton Hotel, although some of the matches were close going into the final quarter. An upset seemed possible when Kathie Wei's thirdseeded team trailed narrowly after 48 deals against Fred Atiyeh, but a strong finish gave the Wei team victory by 57 international match points.

title: PARKENING OFFERS RECITAL FOR GUITAR
description: Christopher Parkening is a pretty incredible guitarist, and evidently a lot of people are aware of the fact, judging from the overflow crowd that attended the young Californian's Tully Hall concert Saturday night. There was no specially unusual repertory on his program, but it did cover a lot of stylistic ground, from Renaissance composers to the present, and all of it was superlatively played.

title: A Play by Yevtashenko Is Pat On in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 24  Authorities who canceled a nationally televised poetry reading by Yevgeny Yevtushenko last week after he voiced anxiety over official action against Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn today allowed a performance of his largely antiAmerican play, Under the Skin of the Statue of Liberty.

title: PRODUCTION CHIEF IS NAMED AT MET
description: John Dexter, the British stage director, hat been appointed production, supervisor of the Metropolitan Opera. Schuyler G. Chapin, the Met's general manager, confirmed the appointment, when reached yesterday by telephone on vacation in Massachusetts.

title: Excerpts From Statement Issued After Mexico Talks
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 24 (Reuters)Following are excerpts from the final communiqu issued today after talks between Secretary of State Kissinger and LatinAmerican and Caribbean foreign ministers:

title: Gourmet Caterers To the Wealthy
description: The woman, in a fulllength mink coat from Maximilian (it has mink tails swishing around her ankles), and the man, looking as if he were dressed to go to the theater, come out of their beautifully furnished Fifth Avenue duplex in the prestigious sixties and get into the elevator the service elevator.

title: Court Tennis Final Is Taken by Bijur
description: TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 24Jerry Bijur of Philadelphia defeated Bob MacDonald of New York, 65, 60, 64, to take the 73d annual Tuxedo court tennis tournament today. He also gained permanent possession of the Gold Racquet trophy.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 24Syria's grudging decision to travel the thorny path to troop disengagement with Israel on the basis of the diplomacy of Secretary of State Kissinger appears to be a turning point in a long standing policy of refusing accommodation with her neighbor.

title: U.N. Women Disappointed by a Small Male Turnout at Forum
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Feb. 25Women members of delegations of the United Nations took over the General Assembly hall today for a forum on the wotnen's role in population and economic development but failed to muster much attention from the men who head the 135 United Nations delegations.

title: Filion Has 5 Victors; Triple Pays $5,574
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 25 Herve Filion drove five winners in his six starts tonight at Roosevelt Raceway, just failing in the ninth race to equal the 16yearold track driving mark established by Jimmy Cruise on July 12, 1958.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: HY KAHANER is President of the House of Kahaner Div. of WILLCOX & GIBBS (WGAHEXP)ADVT.

description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: Wheat Stocks Are Depleted by Huge Exports
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 For the first time In a generation, American wheat supplies have been depleted so low that the bottom of the bin is almost in sight.

title: Unlikely Films Score Success Here
description: Can a Canadianmade film about a photographer's pursuit of a wolfpack make big money in New York? Can a low  budget movie starring egrets and alligators on location set records at the neighborhood houses in this sophisticated city? And what are the commercial prospects of a threeyearold German documentary that poses the question: Did intelligent astronauts land on earth 40,000 years ago?

title: SCIENTISTS ASSAIL ORGANIC FOOD FAD
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25 (UPI)The expanding organic food fad is based on scientific nonsense and is unnecessarily raising household food bills and eroding gains of decades of farming advancements, a panel of scientists said today.

title: WILLIAM A. KIRK
description: SHERMAN, Conn., Feb. 25 William A. Kirk, president of W. A. Kirk, Inc., marine insurance brokers at 80 Broad Street in New York, died today in a nursing home at Danbury. He was 81 years old and lived here.

title: Basketball Scoring
NewCar Sales Down 36.8% In Feb 1120 From Year Ago
description: DETROIT, Feb. 25Newcar sales were down 36.8 per cent in the Feb. 1120 period compared with the corresponding period last year. The decline was the steepest since the 1974 model year started in midSeptember.

title: AMFAC HOLDINGS UP AT GULF & WESTERN
description: Gulf & Western Industries, Inc., has increased its holdings in Amfac, Inc., a Honolulubased company engaged in real estate and retailing operations, to slightly more than 10, per cent from a previously reported 7 per cent, according to a filing made by the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: TV Review
description: The advance promotional splash indicated that Killer Bees, the Tuesday Movie of the Week tonight at 8:30 over the American Broadcasting Company television network, just might be good, hokey suspense and fun. But it's a tedious, prolonged bore that makes Alfred Hitchcock's Birds, a homescreen perennial, seem better than ever.

title: 2 Men and 26 Pounds of Heroin Seized
description: Twentysix pounds of heroin, with a street value estimated at $7.8million, were seized yesterday by Federal agents and city policemen in a raid on a North Bronx apartment. Two men in the apartment were arrested.

title: Statistics Make Lucas Chairman of the Boards
description: When Knick fans think of Jerry Lucas, three or four things jump to mind: soaring onehanded jump shots from more than 20 feet from the basket; pinpoint passes to open teammates; a pair of fidgety, bouncing feet during the playing of the national anthem; amazing feats of memory and magic.

title: Businessman Here Accused of Hiring Competitor's Killer
description: A 53yearold businessman was accused yesterday of having hired the killer of a competitor who was murdered in 1972.

title: 2 Groups Reported Investigating Possibility of Perjury by Gray
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The special Watergate prosecutor and a Senate subcommittee are reportedly investigating the possibility that L. Patrick Gray 3d committed perjury when he denied, during hearings last year on his nomination to become diector of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, any knowledge of F.B.I. wiretaps on newsmen and Government officials.

title: State Begins Regulating Sale of Gasoline Today
description: As servicestation operators around the country complained of dwindling gasoline supplies and awaited deliveries of new Federal allocations, New York became today the sixth state to institute a mandatory system of gasoline allocation.

description: BASEBALL

title: Crime Brokerages Reported In Some High Schools of City
description: A state crime expert charged yesterday that in some New York City high schools there were studentrun brokerages where teenagers buy and sell guns, narcotics or the services of youthful male and female prostitutes.

title: State Begins Regulating Sale of Gasoline Today
description: As servicestation operators, around the country complained of dwindling gasoline supplies and awaited deliveries of new Federal allocation's, New York became today the sixth state to institute a mandatory system of gasoline allocation.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Richey Bows To Emerson In Net Upset
description: LA COSTA, Calif., Feb. 25 (AP)Roy Emerson, the 36yearold Australian, surprised Cliff Richey in a 63, 67, 63 upset in the first round of a $50,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today.

title: Policeman Dies in Collision
description: CENTEREACH, L. I., Feb. 25 (AP)Joseph Mascolo, 30 years old, of Selden, a patrolman in the Plandome Village Police Department, was killed early today in his small foreign car, authorities reported. They said the offduty policeman's car and trailer carrying a tractor that had broken loose from a dump truck collided on Jericho Turnpike.

title: ALANSON C. EBERHART
description: Alanson C. Eberhart, a civil engineer and former director of the real estate department of the American Can Company, died Sunday in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Westport, Conn. He was the husband of Mignon Eberhart, the mystery story writer.

title: KALMBACH PLEADS GUILTY TO 2 CAMPAIGN CHARGES; MAY BE JAWORSKI WITNESS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25Herbert W. Kalmbach, President Nixon's personal lawyer and one of his chief fundraisers, pleaded guilty today to allegations that he helped run an illegal Congressional campaign committee in 1970 and tin he promised an Ambassador a boiler assignment in Europe for a $100,000 campaign contribution.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PARIS, Feb. 25 (UPI)Benny Briscoe of Philadelphia knocked out Tony Mundine of Australia in the fifth round of their 12round middleweight fight tonight. Briscoe hammered Mundine, 11 years his junior, to the canvas, to score a major upset. He knocked out the British Commonwealth champion at 2:20 of the fifth round of what was billed here as the unofficial semifinal for the world championship. Boxing sources said the winner would have first go at the world champion, Carlos Monzon of Argentina, assuming Monzon beats Rodriguez Valdes of Colombia in a scheduled June bout and continues his career.

title: Nighttown Rescheduled
description: The opening of Ulysses in Nighttown at the Winter Garden has been rescheduled from March 5 to the week of March 10, according to the producers. The dramatization of the section from James Joyce's Ulysses, starring Zero Mostel, will continue preview performances at the theater.

title: Fine Arts Players Illuminate Bartok In Quartet Series
description: Gone forever, apparently, are the days when the Bartk String quartets were played by four men gritting their teeth and counting beats with a determined and slightly frenzied desperation. These 20thcentury classics are now firmly in the repertory of all selfrespecting quartets and, one may hope, in the ears of those who listen to them as well.

title: Miss McClendon Tells Nixon He's Misinformed on G.I. Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) Sarah McClendon, a newswoman, who has crossed words at news conferences with every President since Dwight D. Eisenhower, had an exchange with President Nixon tonight.

title: ALLENDE'S WIDOW APPEALS TO U. N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 25The widow of President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile, her voice breaking with emotion, appealed to the Human Rights Commission today to condemn the military junta for genocidal repression.

title: Kalb's Guitar Work A Highlight of Blues By His New Group
description: Danny Kalb denied from the stage that his brandnew group was merely a blues bandas it was so billed on Sunday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, part of the producer. Ed Bland's Jazz and Blues series. But from Mr. Kalb's quartet's program, it certainly looked like it.

title: Funds for Service Doctors
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) Facing a diminishing supply of drafted doctors, the Defense Department told Congress today that, to recruit and retain volunteer doctors, it needed an initial appropriation of $37million. Dr. James R. Cowan, the new Assistant Secretary of Defense for health and environment, appeared before a subcommittee of the House Armed Services Committee to support a bonus and pay bill for medical officers.

title: Valley Forge Cemetery Plea
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) Representative Joshua Eilberg, Democrat of Pennsylvania introduced legislation today to establish a veterans cemetery on the site of the Valley Forge?? Military Hospital, which is in the process of being shut down.

title: Briefs on Energy
description: ROME, Feb. 25Libya undertook today to increase her exports of crude oil to Italy by 7 million tons annually to 30 million tonsabout one fourth of Italy's total needs in exchange for technological aid. An accord was signed here at the end of a fourday visit by Libya's Premier, Abdel Salam Jalloud. The agreement, calls for joint ItalianLibyan ventures in the petrochemical, steel and shipbuilding sectors, Italian assistance for Libyan farmers, and other projects. Italian shipyards will build tankers for Libya, under the accord.

title: Subway Vending Machuzes: NoArm Bandits?
Lake Placid Receives Nixon's Support
description: Lake Placid's bid to host the 1980 Winter Olympic Games has the personal backing of President Nixon, the United States Olympic Committee said yesterday. The upstate. New York town, host to the 1932 Games, is bidding against Chamonix, France, and VancouverGaribaldi, British Columbia, for the 1980 Olympics. President Nixon sent a personal aide here Friday to hand deliver a letter to the visiting Lord Killanin, the president of the International Olympic. Committee. The contents were released yesterday. The President wrote: On behalf of the American people, I cordially invite the International Olympic Committee to stage the 13th Winter Games in Lake Placid, N. Y. As a Small, mountainous, winter sports community and as the site of the 1932 Winter Gaines and numerous world Championships, Lake Placid has both the rich tradition and demonstrated ability to conduct the 1980 Winter Games with quality and distinction....I take special pride, therefore, in extending to your and all the men and women of the Olympic movement a welcoming hand and the warm hospitality of the people of the United States for winter competition at Lake Placid in 1980.

title: PRESIDENT SAYS CRISIS IN ENERGY IS OVER FOR NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  President Nixon said tonight that the nation's fuel shortage would continue to be a strious Problem, but he declared that the crisis has passed.

title: It's N.I.T.Picking Time As Colleges Push for Bid
description: Memphis State notified Madison Square Garden that its athletic director would be staying at the Hilton Hawaiian Village in Honolulu just in case there was an urgent message, Memphis State considers, a bid to the National Invitation Tournament an urgent message.

title: Indiana Wins and Retains Lead in Big 10
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Feb. 25 (AP)Led by Kent Benson's 19 points and 12 rebounds, Indiana defeated Michigan State, 9185, tonight and remained at the top of the Big Ten basketball standing.

title: Cotton Markets
description: Contract No. 2

title: Mondale: Family's Man in the Senate
description: WASHINGTONSenator Walter F. Mondale would like to slip a new lens over the microscope through which the Federal Government assesses its actionsa lens that would focus on the family.

title: CibaGeigy Plans Offer
description: The CibaGeigy Corporation said it intended to make an offer later this week at $17 a share net for all the tendered shares of common stock of Funk Seeds International, Inc., of Bloomington, Ill., provided that at least a majority of the 3.4 million common shares are tendered. On Feb. 15 the two companies disclosed they were discussing plans for a possible merger.

title: Jersey Gasoline Retailers Say Suppliers Don't Try
description: SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Feb. 25 A spokesman for more than 3,000 gasoline retailers in New Jersey said today that waiting lines for fuel were shorter than they had been for the last two months. But he said he had seen little evidence that mayor oil companies were making their best efforts to distribute newly allocated fuel to needy stations.

title: Coaches Favor Manhattan Over Navy in I.C.4A Meet
description: Collegiate coaches in the metropolitan area picked Manhattan's competitive class to prevail over Navy's balance and depth in the I. C. 4A indoor track and field championships Saturday and Sunday at Princeton's Jadwin Gym.

title: U.S Experts on China Are Debating the Meaning of the New Turbulence There
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25Official. American China watchers are going through a familiar debate about the meaning of the current turbulence in China only this time they are trying to keep it secret.

title: Million Is Sought for Stolen Vermeer
description: LONDON, Feb. 25A man telephoned a newspaper here tonight saying he had stolen a valuable Vermeer painting here Saturday night and that he would destroy it unlin 500,000 ($1.15million) worth of food was given to the people of Grenada.

title: Al Devore, 63, President Of Men's Store on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 25 (UPI)  Al Devore, president of Sy Devore Clothiers, patronized by scores of celebrities and politicians, died Saturday at Cedars of Lebonon Hospital. He was 63 years old.

title: Mr. Nixon and the Press
description: President Nixon's news conference last evening was the first he has has held in four months.

title: Army Engineers Told to Put Environmental Factors Last
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP)  The Army Corps of Engineers was told at a Congressional hearing today not to allow environmental concerns to overwhelm its work.

title: Wood,Field&Stream
description: Those whose spirits have soared with a hawk as it wheeled high on a thermal over the bare cliffs of a mountain may never wish anything more than a renetition of that private experience, but if they want to learn more about the birds and their habits, the North American Hawk Migration Conference in Syracuse from April 18 to 21 could well be the starting paint.

title: BRITISH PAY ISSUE SEEMS TO RECEDE
description: LONDON, Feb. 25  The question of whether the Conservative ??arty Government miscalculated the pay of the coal miners, which threatened briefly last week to become a major issue in the election campaign, appears to have receded.

title: Florida Cats Live Bait For Greyhound Racers
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb., 25 (UPI)  A bill prohibiting the use of live rabbits, cats, fowl, or other animals in the training of racing greyhounds won unanimous approval in the Florida Senate Commerce Committee today.

title: Jim Walter Is Informed Of F.T.C. Complaint Plans
description: The Jim Walter Corporation announced yesterday it had been informed by the Federal Trade. Commission that the F.T.C. intends to file a complaint alleging that the 1972 acquisition of the Panacon Corporation by the Celotex subsidiary of Jim Walter violated Section 7 of the Clayton Act.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday, Feb. 25, 1974

title: ITALY IN DISPUTE OX AN I.M.F. LOAN
description: ROME, Feb, 25The terms of a proposed $1.2billion standby credit line from the International Monetary Fund to bolster the sagging lira have become an issue that is shaking the Government.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, Feb. 75, 1974

title: TWO DENY SLAYING A COAST EDUCATOR
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25 Two members of the group that is holding Patricia Hearst captive were arraigned today and pleaded not guilty to the charge that they murdered the Superintendant of schools in Oakland.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: GROMYKO WILL GO TO EGYPT FRIDAY
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 25The Soviet Union will send Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko to Cairo Friday on the heels of Secretary of State Kissinger's visit to the Egyptian capital this week, diplomatic sources reported today.

title: HUSSEIN OUSTS TWO IN ARMY PROTEST
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 25 (UPI)  King Hussein has shaken up his armed forces command, Jordan announced today. The action came in the wake of a protest over pay by some army units three weeks ago.

title: VOTE IS ENJOINED ON PALISADES SITE
description: HACKENSACK, Feb. 25  Superior Court Judge Theodore W. Trautwein temporarily enjoined a nonbinding referendum that residents of Tenafly were to vote on today regarding the town's proposed acquisition of a 294acre site on the western slope of the Palisades.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE POLITICAL CRIMINAL, The Problem of Morality and Crime. By Stephen Schafer. 178 pages. The Free Press/Macmillan. $7.95.

title: TAPHAPPEN UNITES TALENT ON THE HOOF
description: Currently the tapdance action is in the auditorium at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle on West 59th. Street. On Sunday afternoons at 3, veterans, young and old, gather in an informal Taphappen for Mama J's Jazz Joint, to embroider those danceable tunes from the nineteenthirties and forties that set everyone's foot tapping.

title: THOMAS HEALY
description: Thomas, Healy, a founding member and executive secretary of the Irish Institute of New York, died Friday in FrenchPolyclinic Hospital. He was 70 years ago and lived at 19614 48th Avenue, Flushing, Queens.

title: N.F.L. Again Delays Expansion Plans; Cities in Running Are Reduced to Five
description: MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 25The National Football League delayed again today on the Matter of adding new teams to its present lineup of 26. At the annual meeting of the owners, it was decided to postpone any action on expansion until a special meeting in late April in New York City.

title: Shift in Wholesale Fuel Prices Allowed to Spur Gas Refining
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) The Federal Energy Office has approved a onecent increase in the wholesale price of gasoline and a corresponding twocent decrease in the price of middle distillate fuel oil, a spokesman for the agency said today.

title: Arabs Weigh Investment Of Oil Revenue in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 25Arab bankers and industrialists are taking a hard look at opportunities to invest their oilderived wealth in Brazil, according to a representative of the Arab League.

title: Fraudulent Marriages Increase as Aliens Seek to Circumvent Immigration Laws Here
description: She couldn't remember the names of her husband's sister's children. He couldn't remember the layout of his wife's little apartment. So Mrs. Ruth Roe is now awaiting probable deportation to Trinidad.

title: BOND PRICES TAKE MIXED DIRECTION
Supreme Court to Hear Plea Over Car Repossessed by Bank Without Notice
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The Supreme Court may have some help for the man who buys a car on the installment plan, only to have the bank repossess it without any notice or hearing on the ground that he is behind in his payments.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (Reuters)  Jerry W. Friedheim, the Pentagon spokesman, said, today that American officials were still holding off starting a formal search for the balloonist. To the best of my knowledge, Mr. Friedheim said, no One has turned up anything as yet. The difficulty is no one knows where to look.

title: Advertising: Drunken Drivers
description: In the last couple of years, Grey Advertising has created two awardwinning campaigns for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in an effort to identify the problem drinker as a major cause of automobile accidents.

title: Traffic Toll Reported Down 23% in January
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP)Deaths on the nation's highways were reduced 23 per cent in January, the first month of the national mandatory 55mileanhour speed limit, the Federal traffic safety director reported today.

title: 200Man Argentine Mission in Cuba For the Start of $1Billion Trade Deal
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 25Morel than 200 Argentine businessmen and government officials went to Cuba today to be on hand for the arrival of the first Argentine manufactured goods to be shipped under a $1.2billion trade deal between the two countries.

title: When the Livin' Is Easy and the Styles Are Simple
description: Love your pants outfits? Content with hemlines in the vicinity of your knees?

title: A $1MILLION VILLA IS SOLD FOR $65,000
description: MORRISTOWN, Feb. 25 (UPI)The unfinished $1million, 25room villa of MedfordT. Jerome, a bankrupt healthspa developer, was sold for $65,000 at an auction today to the contractor who installed its marble bathrooms.

title: City to Name an Official To Slow Business Exodus
description: An economic intelligence chief, a James Bond of the business world with the mission of giving the city early warning of companies planning to leave New York, will be appointed this week by Alfred Eisenpreis, the new head of the Economic Development Administration.

title: Gross Trial Opens Today In U.S. court in Newark
description: NEWARK, Feb. 25The election fraud trial of Nelson G. Gross, former New Jersey state Republican chairman who is charged with falsifying a contribution to former Gov. William T. Cahill's campaign fund in 1969, opens here tomorrow in Federal District Court,

title: WALTER WODAK, 66, AUSTRIAN DIPLOMAT
description: Walter Wodak, Austrian Ambassador to the Soviet Union from 1964 to 1970, died Sunday in Vienna at the age of 66.

title: Dance: Limon's Continued Resurgence
description: Something both very new and very old has happened in American modern dance. It is the complete resurgence of one of our senior companiesand also one of our youngest  the Jose Limn Dance Company. It has recently been giving a remarkably successful season at the miserable location called City Center Downstairs, somewhere that would normally be regarded as a place worse than death.

title: Islanders in Cellar Battle Tonight
Controversy Decimates City's Parks Department
description: After only eight weeks in office as the head of the Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration, Edwin L. Weisl Jr. has already been caught up in a bitter controversy over personnel and policy.

title: GALIMIR ENSEMBLE SPARKLES IN WEBER
description: The New School Concerts are under the general supervision of Alexander Schneider, and the Galimir String Quartet, which appeared in the series Sunday night, played very much in the Schneider tradition. The performances of Mozart's E flat and Schumann's A major Quartets, in other words, may not have offered the last word in elegant finesse, but they were always ardent and involving.

title: LTV's Profits Soar
description: The LTV Corporation yesterday reported big gains in its earnings for the fourth quarter and for all of 1973. Page 58.

title: Brasco Witness Cites Freedom Offer
description: John A. Masiello, the Government's chief witness in the trial of Representative Frank J. Brasco, testified yesterday that the Government had promised him immediate release and relocation to another part of the country with his family in exchange for his cooperation during the trial.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the High School Notes column in The New York Times last Saturday the wrong date was given for the open house celebrating the third anniversary of Park East High School at 230 East 105th Street. The event will be held next Saturday night.

title: Doctors in State Face Revived Rule on A.M.A.
description: The New York State Medical Society has announced that it will require members in the state and county medical societies to join the American Medical Association. The action, which has been adopted overwhelmingly by the state society's House of Delegates, is expected to return to membership in the A.M.A. about 7,000 physicians who dropped out.

title: For Palestinian Refugees, a Flicker of Hope
description: MAMA, Jordan, Feb. 11The war came as a surprise and, frankly, so did the result. We never expected the Arabs to do so well. Now that they have, maybe something will finally change.

title: Squires Halt Rally, Down Tams, 11599
description: HAMPTON, Va., Feb. 25 (AP)George Carter poured in 31 points tonight and five other Virginia Squires hit in double figures as they defeated the Memphis Tams, 11599, in an American Basketball Association game.

title: WRITER COLLIDES WITH SCIENTISTS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25 Immanuel Velikovsky, author of the controversial book Worlds in Collision, locked horns today with the scientific community over his theory that Venus once swept close to the earth.

title: Friedman Blames Fed for Inflation
description: Milton Friedman, Chicago University's iconclastic economist, has charged that the Federal Reserve Boardno matter what excuses it offersplayed a major role in producing our present inflation.

title: BRITISH SOCCER
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Winthrop Aldrich Dies
description: Winthrop W. Aldrich, former board chairman of the Chase National Bank and Ambassador to Britain under President Eisenhower, died yesterday at 88. Page 40.

title: Snow Dampens Big A Opening: Crowd Only 19,350
description: The optimistic expectation of a large turnout at Aqueduct to greet the local thoroughbred racing season was deflated by the weather yesterday. The steady snowfall in the morning, following the scary weather predictions through the night, kept the attendance down to 19,350.

title: Jersey Aides Fear Panic Could Foster an Oil Port
description: TRENTON, Feb. 25  Two State Senators and the acting, Commissioner of the State De partment of Environmental Protection urged today that the Legislature not be panicked by the energy crisis into approving a deepwater oil port off New Jersey.

title: Red Smith
description: It was 1:31 P.M. and summer was a minute overdue before George Cassidy sent 11 selling platers away from the sixfurlong pole at Aqueduct Yesterday. One minute 10 2/5 seconds later, a horse named Royal Quester that had been beaten a total of 130 lengths in eight previous starts was enrolled as the first of 2,358 winners destined to repay backers during the New York Racing Association's longest year. And that figure does not allow for dead heats.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25(UPI)Federal Trade Cons mission staff lawyers have recommended that eight big oil companies be ordered to cut away half of their oilrefining capacity on the East and Gulf Coasts to increase competition in the oil industry, it was reported today.

title: CoachesBid to Exclude Violators From Ratings
description: The National Association of Basketball Coaches will consider asking its members (colege coaches) not to vote foriany, college team in the weakly United Press International rating About poll while that college is under Colleget, penalty from the Sports National Collegiate Athletic Association. If the members approve the action at their convention in Greensboro, N. C., next month, the N.A.B.C. will be following a step taken by the American Football Coaches Association, at its convention last January.

title: Treasury Bills Rose At the Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive today of these shortterm securities.

title: Music
description: Beethoven's Missa Solemnis, although one of the titanic works of its kind, rarely receives a satisfactory performance. The demands he makes on the chorus alone keep the mass safely beyond the standard choral repertory, and its interpretative problems are intricate enough to give even the most accomplished conductors pause.

title: PENALTIES WITHHELD FROM FIRE OFFICERS
description: The Fire Department has agreed to withhold temporarily the imposition of probation and loss of tenure for more than 1,000 fire officers accused of failing to perform their duties during a strike of firefighters last Nov. 6.

title: A Met Comes Home, a Yank Stays Away
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 25Mel Stottlemyre, whose arm needs spring training as much as a lot of Republicans need good lawyers, remained on the Yankees' unsigned and unreported list today.

title: KALMBACH PLEADS GUILTY TO 2 CAMPAIGN CHARGES; MAY BE JAWORSKI WITNESS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 The Watergate special prosecution force has begun an inquiry into President Nixon's handling of the military snooping on the White House in 1971, wellplaced sources said today.

title: Snow Blankets South Jersey But Northern Area Is Spared
description: A coastal storm that threatened a severe snowfall diminished as it passed over, the metropolitan area yesterday leaving only traces on roadways.

title: Winthrop Aldrich Dies
description: Winthrop W. Aldrich, former board chairman of the Chase National Bank and Ambassador to Britain under President Eisenhower, died yesterday at 88. Page 40.

title: Bridge: A LastDitch Gamble Upsets Some Experts in Tourney
description: A desperate lastditch gamble by Ralph Pollenz of Wantagh, L. I., enabled him and his group of young Long Island experts to upset some highranked opponents LI the Grand National Team Championship at the New York Hilton here Sunday night.

title: Pony Castration Suit Filed
description: WAYNESBURG, Pa., Feb. 25 (UPI)A Pittsburgh man sued a veterinarian today for allegedly castrating the wrong pony. Neil Kilmer's suit charged that Dr. Elmer Marx of Waynesburg had performed the operation and asked $6.000 damages, representing the loss of breeding services over a 20year period. The suit, filed in Greene County Court, said the operation was to have been performed on another pony owned by Mr. Kilmer.

title: Today Is Moving Day For Mr. and Mrs. Beame
description: Mayor and Mrs. Beame plan to move to Grade Mansion from their rented apartment in Queens today.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: JUDGE CLEARS 38 IN MITCHELL TRIAL
description: Judge Lee P. Gagliardi tenatively cleared 14 more potential jurors yesterday as jury selection moved tediously forward in the first criminal trial of former Cabinet officers in half a century.

title: Snow Dampens Big A Opening: Crowd Only 19,350
description: The optimistic expectation of a large turnout at Aqueduct to greet the local thoroughbred racing season was deflated by the weather yesterday. The steady snowfall in the morning, following the scary weather predictions through the night, kept, the attendance down to 19,350.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MONTVILLE, Feb. 25 When Will Puentes recently became the first Montville. High basketball, player to score 1,000 points in a career, the game ball was given to his No. 1 fanhis father.

title: Market Place: Profit Problem At DenTalEz
description: Officials of DenTalEz, a Des Moines manufacturer of equipment for the dental profession, inadvertently offered Instruction yesterday in how not to explain a disappointing earnings result.

title: SPANISH PRESS HUNT FOR U.S. BALLOONIST
description: EL AAIUN, Spanish Sahara, Feb. 25 (AP)Spanish military officials, despite diminished hopes of success, kept up a search today for Thomas L. Gatch Jr., a United States, Army Reserve colonel lost after he set out to make the first manned transAtlantic balloon flight.

title: Kissinger in London
description: Secretary of State Kissinger arrived in London yesterday on his way to the Middle East. Officials aboard. Mr. Kissinger's jet said they believed he would succeed in getting Israel and Syria to agree on a formula for the separation of their military forces. Details, Page 3.

title: Checks on Elevators Lag In the Bronx, Goldin Says
description: Elevators in Bronx buildings that the city is supposed to inspect every three months go uninspected for up to four years, Controller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

title: Vietcong Children Learn of a Hero
description: TUONG SON, South VietnamThe Vietcong's hamlet school is a rudimentary mud and straw building set in a clearing; with small childsized bunkers on either side. As a woman teacher writes the day's lesson on a bumpy blackboard, 30 thirdgraders sit with their copybooks in front of them.

title: Women of Year Awards Will Be Televised April 8
description: Women of the Year, 1974 ceremonies honoring women for achievement in eight categories, will be televised live from Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center on April 8, over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

title: I.R.S. CoverUp Charged On U.S. Favors for I.T.T.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25Representative J. J. Pickle has accused the Internal Revenue Service of playing a part in what he calls the cover up of Government favors extended to the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: LTV Profits Rise Sharply
New Jersey Briefs
description: Suicide in Morris County Jail

title: Winthrop Aldrich Dead; Banker and Diplomat, 88
description: Winthrop W. Aldrich, former board chairman of the Chase National Bank, and Ambassador to the Court of St. James's under President Eisenhower, died yesterday at his home, 960 Fifth Avenue. He was 88 years old. He also lived in Providence, R.I., and Islesboro, Me.

title: Sociologists' Aid Bought on Jury Choice
description: BOSTON, Feb. 25Defense attorneys in the trial of former Attorney General John M. Mitchell and former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans at tempted to hire a team of social scientists that has picked winning juries for radicals in a series of cases brought by the Nixon Administration. However, they changed their minds after a preliminary discussion with the social scientists.

title: Stunt Man Dives 7 Stories to Demonstrate New AirBag Rescue Device
description: Dar Robinson made a swan dive off the roof of a sevenstory building in the Breezy Point section of Queens yesterday and, falling 80 feet a second, made a graceful landing onto a 20by25foot air cushion.

title: Wood, Field & Stream Gathering of HawkWatchers
description: Those whose spirits have soared with a hawk as it wheeled high on a thermal over the bare cliffs of a mountain may never wish anything more than a repetition of that private experience, but if they want to learn more about the birds and their habits, the North American Hawk Migration Conference in Syracuse from April 18 to 21 could well be the starting point.

title: Hockey Scoring
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Strip Mining Forever!?
description: The House Interior Committee will decide tomorrow whether or not to report an enfeebled and shadowy substitute for a strong bill to regulate surface mining in way that would effectively protect the land. The strippeddown version, which coal and utilities lobbyists find their liking, would virtually negate an acceptable measure overwhelmingly passed by the Senate last year.

title: Paterson School Dispute Centers on Enrollment
description: PATERSON, Feb. 25  This city's public school system, the third largest in the state, is embroiled in a bitter controversy over whether its budget should be allowed to grow in the face of declining student enrollment.

title: Taiwan Rates U.S. High In ConsumerGoods Sales
description: American consumer goods are the most popular imports in Nationalist China, despite the proximity of Japan and her relatively lower prices, members of a purchasing trade mission said here yesterday.

title: MEANY CITES GAIN IN FARAH STRIKE
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 25 The successful strike of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America against the Farah Manufacturing Company, which ended yesterday with full recognition of the union, will give new impetus to efforts to organize nonunion workers, George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O, declared yesterday.

title: Kissinger Stops in London On His Way to Middle East
description: LONDON, Feb. 25Secretary of State Kissinger arrived here tonight for talks with British officials before going on to the Middle East tomorrow to seek to negotiate a break in the diplomatic impasse between Israel and Syria.

title: Controversy Decimates City Parks Department
description: After only eight weeks in office as the head of the Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration, Edwin L. Weisl Jr. has already been caught up in a bitter controversy over personnel and policy.

title: Sparse Growth Forecast
description: Later, in a questionandanswer period, Dr. Francis H. Schott, the company's chief economist, forecast very little real growth in the economy this year. Wage and price controls is an idea whose tune has past, he added.

title: North Koreans. Reject Bid To Renew Red Cross Talks
description: SEOUL, South Korea. Feb. 25 South Korea proposed today to reopen the longsuspended talks with North Korea under Red Cross auspices on April 9 in Seoul. The North rejected the proposal, made at a meeting of liaison officials of the Red Cross organizations of the two Koreas at Panmunjom.

title: Europeans Reluctant at Parley Of New 12Nation Energy Group
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25A 12nation group set up by the Washington energy conference met at the State Department today to decide how it could deal with further developments in the energy shortage.

title: City U. Board Holds First Open Meeting
description: At its first meeting open to the public and the press since its founding in 1926, the Board of Higher Education yesterday, approved a record budget of more than $100million for campus planning and construction.

title: GOLD AT $170 HIGH AS DOLLAR GAINS
description: LONDON, Feb. 25 (UPI)The price of gold broke records again throughout Europe today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE
3 WITNESSES BACK MACKELL DEFENSE
description: Pressing its argument that Thomas J. Mackell and two aides had assumed a fastmoney scheme was a legitimate business opportunity, the defense yesterday called three of the scheme's victims to the stand. They told the jury they had believed the enterprise was legal.

title: Unlawful Conduct Is Laid to Memorex By I.B.M. in Reply
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has alleged that the Memorex Corporation in an unlawful manner obtained I.B.M. trade secrets, accepting information from industrial espionage rings among other things, and that this offsets any damages that Memorex is seeking from I.B.M.

title: Fred Fulford, 62, Headed United Furniture Workers
description: Fred Fulford, president of the United Furniture Workers of America since 1970, died Friday in the University of Florida Hospital in Gainesville. He was 62 years old.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION OFF 0.7% IN WEEK
description: Steel production for the week ended Feb. 23 dipped by 0.7 per cent from the preceding week to 2,887,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: BOEING EARNINGS AND SALES CLIMB
description: The Boeing Company's aircraft deliveries rose to 156 last year from 99 the year before, the company reported yesterday. Sales in 1973 climbed to $3.34billion from $2.37billion in 1972. And earnings grew 64 per cent to $51.2million, or $2.38 a share, from 1972's $30.4million, or $1.40 a share.

title: With Pumps instate Going Dry, Connecticut Prepares Fuel Bills
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 25Supplies of gasoline ran out in scattered places in Connecticut today as, the General Assembly prepared to give sweeping emergency powers to Gov. Thomas J. Meskill to deal with the situation.

title: Florida Cuts Live Bait For Greyhound Racers
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla, Feb., 25 (UPI)  A bill prohibiting the use of live rabbits, cats, fowl or other animals in the training of racing greyhounds won unanimous approval in the Florida Senate Commerce. Committee today.

title: Notes on People
description: Four years after he won the Nobel Prize for literature, Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn will go to Stockholm to pick it up at the next prizegiving ceremony on Dec. 10, the Swedish Academy announced yesterday. Mr. Solzhenitsyn recently wrote the Academy that now that he has been exiled from his native Russia, he feels free to pick up the prize he won in 1970. At that time he declined to leave Moscow and accept the Nobel gold medallion in Stockholm, for fear he would be refused reentry to the Soviet Union, which has now expelled him. His cash award of about $87,000 was placed in a Swiss bank in his name.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: Letters to the Editor Of City College, Open Admissions and Academic Excellence
description: To the Editor:

title: Worsening of Slum Housing Abandonment Is Feared
description: Roger Starr, the city's top housing official, fears that housing abandonmentwhich has been ravaging New York's slum neighborhoods since the middle nineteensixtiesmay become even worse.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Colonialism 10:30 A.M.

title: A Met Comes Home, a Yank Stays Away
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 25The most traveled man in baseball, and the oldest member of the New York Mets in captivity, is a relief pitcher named Robert Lane Miller. Maybe you can't go home again but, at the age of 35, he is trying and the Mets are hoping.

title: SOVIET ARRESTS 12 OP GERMAN ORIGIN
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 25 (AP) Twelve Soviet citizens of German origin were arrested today during a demonstration demanding perniission to emigrate to West Germany.

title: IRENE B TAEUBER, DEMOGRAPHER, 68;
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 25 Dr. Irene Barnes Taeuber, a senior research demographer at the Office of Population Research of Princeton University and a past president of the Population Association of America, died yesterday at her home in Hyattsville, Md. She was 68 years old.

title: FLORENCE RICE DIES; SCREEN ACTRESS, 67
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 25 (AP) Florence Rice Butler, a former film actress who was the daughter of the late Grantland Rice, the noted sportswriter, died Saturday of lung cancer. She was 67 years old.

title: DR. LLOYD M. GRANGER
description: NEWARK, Feb. 25Dr. Lloyd M. Granger, who retired in 1971 from his dental practice of more than 50 years here, died Saturday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center in New York. He was 75 years old and lived in Lakewood, N.J.

title: U.S. Finds a Gain in New Transit Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25Nixon Administration officials said today that they regarded the new masstransit bill that was voted out last week by HouseSenate conference committee as more acceptable than previous proposals.

title: Chess: The Simplicity of Endings Gives Rise to Complexity
description: Endings more than other phases of the game can be subjected to comprehensive study, Openings are dragged this way and that by a constant influx of new ideas or of old ideas refurbished; study of them provides only a background for work in progress. Middle game situations are so concrete and so varied that they must be learned chiefly by example; they contain much more than any principles can encompass.

title: NIXON ASSERTS A CRIMINAL OFFENSE IS REQUIRED FOR AN IMPEACHMENT; HE DOES NOT EXPECT HOUSE TO ACT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 President Nixon said tonight that he had sought to avoid confrontation with Moscow over the Soviet expulsion of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn in order to go forward with dtente between the two superpowers.

title: State Senate Backs Male Alimony Suits
description: ALBANY, Feb. 25After an impassioned debate described by, participants as setting male against female, the Senate today approved a bill that would permit needy men in divorce proceedings to sue their wives for alimony.

title: Stage: An Amiable Musical Getout!
description: From Kafka to Don Marquis, the writer sits in his room, searches for inspiration and discovers cockroaches. The playwright Joseph Renard is the latest to elevate this common household pest to stardomin his new musical, Getout! (music by Joseph Blunt), currently playing at La Mama.

title: Cities Struggle With Abandoned Houses
description: Chicago, Detroit and Cleveland are among major cities having a serious problem with housing abandonment.

title: NEGOTIATIONS FAIL ON RUTGERS REBELS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 25  Quiet efforts by the Rutgers University administration to pleabargain and avoid campus disciplinary hearings for 150 students who disrupted, a varsity basketball game in December have failed, sources close to the situation said today.

title: Record British Trade Deficit Heats Up Campaign
description: LONDON, Feb. 25The British Government today announced the nation's worst trade deficit in history, and its report promptly became a heated political issue in these final days of the election campaign.

title: RAILWAY ENJOINED ON EXCHANGE BID
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The Federal District Court here permanently enjoined the Florida East Coast Railway Company and its principal officers today from carrying out an exchange offer of common stock for firstmortgage bonds of the carrier. The Securities and Exchange Commission had sought to quash the exchange as fraudulent.

title: Even in Tory Country, They Work Hard at Getting Out the Vote.
description: BOURTON  ON  THE WATER, England, Feb. 22 The chairs in the meeting hall were filled this morning with what looked like the entire annual tweed production of the Isle of Harris.

title: Supreme Court's Actions
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: WHEAT FUTURES CLIMB SHARPLY
description: Conumers received more bad news yesterday from the corn. modity markets: Prices of most foodstuffs and minerals were again bid up sharply by domestic and foreign buyers.

title: Queens and York To Open Tourney
description: The opening round of the City University basketball tournament starts Thursday at Brooklyn College with Queens facing York at 3 P.M., Lehman meeting Hunter at 5, City College opposing Brooklyn at 7 and Medgar Evers facing the winner of a playoff between Baruch and John Jay at 9.

title: Snowball Burns Woman
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 25 (Reuters)Mrs. Vicki Schaaf of Cincinnati was struck in the mouth by a snowball today. She suffered slight burns on her lips and cheeks. The police said the snowball had been doused in gasoline and lighted by a youth who hurled it at her car as it passed.

title: STATIONS EQUIPPED FOR EXHAUST TESTS
description: TRENTON, Feb. 25 (AP)  The Department of Environmental Protection today announced that 1,100 service stations were equipped to give cars a trial test before they underwent the new mandatory state autoemissions inspection.

title: Worsening of Slum Housing Abandonment Is Feared
description: Roger Starr, the city's top housing official, fears that housing abandonmentwhich has been ravaging New York's slum neighborhoods since the middle nineteensixtiesmay become even worse.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1974

title: KALMBACH PLEADS GUILTY TO 2 CAMPAIGN CHARGES; MAY BE JAWORSKI WITNESS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Herbert W., Kalmbach, President Nixon's personal lawyer and one of, his chief fundraisers, pleaded guilty today to allegations that he helped run sin illegal Congressional campaign committee in 1970 and that he promised an Ambassador a better assignment in Europe for a $100,000 campaign contribution.

title: Judge Postpones Hearing For Equity Defendants
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 25 (AP) A pretrial hearing for 16 defendants in, the Equity Funding Corporation of America traud case was postponed today until March 4 because of the judge's illness.

title: Rothko Executor Admits Other 2 Were Trusted Friends of Artist
description: Direct testimony by Morton Levine, one of three executors of the estate of Mark Rothko, the late abstract expressionist painter, was completed yesterday in Surrogate Court. Crossexamination by a lawyer representing the other two executors, who are at odds with Mr. Levine in the case, also began.

title: OIL DEPLETION AID OPENS NEW CLASH
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The Nixon Administration and key members of the House Ways and Means Committee appeared today to be headed for a collision over a proposal for the gradual elimination of the oil depletion allowance.

title: 2 Prisoners Escape From 2 Hospitals With Guards Nearby
description: Two prisoners, one facing seven years in jail for killing his fatherinlaw and the other charged with armed robbery, escaped yesterday in separate incidents at Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn and the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center.

title: Rote Upstages Finalists In Superstars' Tourney
description: ROTONDA, Fla., Feb. 25 (AP)Kyle Rote Jr a talented chip off a famous old block, won three of his four opening final events today and captured a commanding lead in the $123,000 Superstars' tournament.

title: Vietcong Area Still Shows Traces Of G.I.'s Who Fought for It in Vain
description: TUONG SON, South VietnamAmericans have not been here for some time. But at the edge of this tiny hamlet, peacefully nestled between a, mountain and a stretch of sunken green rice paddies, stands something the Americans left behind.

title: Appeals Court Reinstates Ban On Strike by Printers at Times
description: The New York Court of Appeals has reversed an Appellate Division ruling and reinstituted a permanent nostrike injunction against typographical employes of The New York Times.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: INSURER SEEKING ANOTHER VENTURE
description: The $17billion Equitable Life Assurance Society disclosed here yesterday that it was in the market to buy what it called a smallish company that sells car and home insurance.

title: House Panel Schedules Hearings on Behavior Modification in Federal Prisons
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 A Congressional subcommittee has summoned the director of the Bureau of Prisons to a hearing on Wednesday in an attempt to discover the extent and the acceptability of behavior modification in Federal prisons.

title: Japanese Labor Is Termed Not Cheap
description: TOKYO, Feb. 25Labor minister Takashi Hasegawa asserted today that Japan, often condemned for exports based on cheap labor, is no longer a nation of cheap labor and urged Americans and Europeans to recognize that.

title: Nixon Handling of Spying By Military Under inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 The Watergate special prosecution force has begun an inquiry into President Nixon's handling of the military snooping on the White House in 1971, wellplaced sources said today.

title: Kissinger in London
description: Secretary of State Kissinger arrived in London yesterday on his way to the Middle East. Officials aboard Mr. Kissinger's jet said they believed he would succeed in getting Israel and Syria to agree on a formula for the separation of their military forces. Details, Page 3.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1974

title: PRICES ON AMEX MIXED AT CLOSE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday while the index on the overthecounter market was lower despite the fact that advances outnumbered declines. Volume dropped on both marts.

title: People and Business
description: Leon T. Kendall, president of the Securities Industries Association, has been named president and chief executive officer of the Milwaukeebased Mortgage Guaranty Insurance Corporation, the country's biggest private insurer of conventional home mortgages. He succeeds Max H. Karl, 63, who was elected chairman and continues as president and chief executive of the MGIC Investment Corporation, the parent company.

title: PRESIDENT SAYS CRISIS IN ENERGY IS OVER FOR NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  The nation's fuel shortage will continue to be a serious problem, but the crisis has passed, President Nixon said tonight.

title: Indian Government Describes Economy As the Worst Ever
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 25The Indian Government gave grim account of the nation's economy today, describing the current fiscal year as the nation's worst period.

title: Michigan Pistol Ban Sought
description: LANSING, Mich., Feb. 25 (UPI)  Police Commissioner Philip G. Tannian, of Detroit began a statewide petition drive today to outlaw handguns in Michigan and require the state to buy all pistols currently in circulation.

title: Assembly Democrats Beat G.O.P. Bill Calling for EscrowAccount Interest
description: ALBANY, Feb, 25The Democratic minority in the Assembly tonight beat back a Republicansponsored bill providing, with exceptions, for interest on money held in mortgage escrow accounts. The Democrats said the bill would fool the people of the state into believing they would be getting interest payments on the accounts.

title: STUDY FINDS HARM TO ENVIRONMENT
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 25The overall level of environmental quality in the United States has sagged slightly in the last year, the nation's largest conservation organization says.

title: Rally in Stocks Falters As the Volume Declines
description: Stock prices drifted downward yesterday, following last week's strong rally that was based on hopes for an early end or easing of the Arab oil embargo.

title: COL. FRANCIS GREENE, ARMY EDUCATOR, 73
description: Col. Francis Martin Greene, U.S.A. retired, assistant director and director of physical education at the United States Military. Academy at West Point from 1942 to 1951, died Friday in Vassar Hospital, Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He was 73 years old and lived on Vail Road, Poughkeepsie.

title: American Absurdity
description: New York's experimental program of furloughs, leaves and workstudy release for prison inmates has been successful enough, Gov. Malcolm Wilson said the other day, to be made permanent part of the state's correctional program.

title: Kent State Hearings Resume
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 25 (UPI) Testimony resumed today in the Federal grand jury investigation of the 1970 Kent State shootings after a twoweek recess. Part of the investigation in the last two weeks included a trip to the site of the shootings on the Kent State University campus, where four students were killed and nine were wounded by the Ohio National Guard during an antiwar demonstration on May 4, 1970.

title: U.S. EASING REPAIR OF PLANES ABROAD
description: The Treasury Department has decided to change a Customs Service regulation to give United States, airlines broad opportunities to repair planes abroad, according to department sources.

title: State's New GasolineSale Rules
description: Following are the regulations affecting the sale of gasoline that go into effect today in New York State:

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: The Handel Society, created for the glory of the master composer, is starting its fifth season at 8 tonight in Carnegie Hall, Seventh Avenue and 57th Street (CI 77459), and it's going to be an hors d'oeuvre affair rather than one main dish as usual.

title: End of an Era?
description: WASHINGTONA case being argued in the Supreme Court today raises the question whether it is constitutionally permissible for social institutions: to help blacks overcome the cumulative effects of past, discrimination and deprivation by taking affirmative action in their behalf. Specifically, can a university discriminate marginally in favor of black candidates for admission, as many private and public universities now do?

title: BAN ON CAB CRUISING IN MIDTOWN UPHELD
description: A city regulation banning cruising by taxis in midtown between 34th and 59th Streets was upheld in State Supreme Court here yesterday.

title: Thomas H. Cullen Jr., 73, Dead; Served on State Supreme Court
description: Thomas H. Cullen Jr., who retired in 1970 as a State Supreme Court justice for Brooklyn and Richmond after Serving in various city courts since 1933, died Friday at his home, 200 Congress Street, Brooklyn, He was 73 years old.

title: SALT Resumes
description: After a year of futile sparring and a threemonth recess, the SovietAmerican strategic arms limitation talks (SALT II) have resumed in a mood of deep seriousness.

title: The Case For Gaspeachment
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25Soliloquy composed while falling off to sleep: I will not think about gasoline. I will not think about gasoline. Will riot think about gasoline. Will not think about gasoline. Will not think about gasoline. Not about gasoline. Not about gasoline. Not gasoline. Not gasoline. Not gasoline. Gasoline. Gasoline. Gasoline! Gasoline! Gasoline! Gasoline!

title: Nixon Discloses He Rejected Request By Jaworski to Testify Before a Jury
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 President Nixon disclosed tonight that he had been asked to testify before a Watergate grand jury but had declined to do so on the ground that it was constitutionally improper.

title: Touche Ross & Co. Censured Over Audits of U.S. Financial
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, moving to make accounting firms more responsible for detecting fraud in corporate financial statements, censured and disciplined yesterday Touche Ross & Co., one of the Big Eight of the profession, for improper conduct in auditing the 1970 and 1971 statements of U.S. Financial, Inc.

title: Coal Gasification Plant Mapped
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 25A little noticed coal gasification project, with a large potential impact on coalrich regions and the nation's electric and gas utilities, was announced here and in Los Angeles last week.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the High School Note column in The New York Times last Saturday the wrong date was given for the open house celebrating the third anniversary of Park East High School at 230 East 105th Street. The event will be held next Saturday night.

title: Fraudulent Marriages Increase as Aliens Seek to Circumvent Immigration Laws Here
description: She couldn't remember the names of her husband's sister's children. He couldn't remember the layout of his wife's little apartment. So Mrs. Ruth Roe is now awaiting probable deportation to Trinidad.

title: Subway Vending Machines: NoArm Bandits?
description: If you called the complaint telephone number on the photo machine near the Grand Ventral shuttle at the Times Square subway station to complain that you had deposited money but had received no pictures, you probably got po answer. If you did, it was from a passerby who informed you that you were calling a pay telephone at the corner of 103d Street and First Avenue.

title: Gains Reported Against G.I. Drug Use in Europe
description: WASHNGTON, Feb. 25The commander of the United States Army in Europe reported today that while discipline among the troops, in West Germany was still only fair, progress was being made in controlling drug use.

title: The Pahlevi Plan
description: The pledge of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran to contribute $1 billion toward a new development fund and other international arrangements to help ease the impact of soaring oil prices is a welcome if limited step toward undoing a little of the damage to impoverished countries that has been caused worldwide by the oilproducing states of the Middle East and elsewhere.

title: The Stage
description: There are some wormy stage repertory companies, large and small, in our midst. But a visit to the ACSTA unit (the American Center for Stanislaysky Theater Art), now entering its fourth season, as new tenants of the Greenwich Mews Theater, 141 West 13th Street (PL 55120), is a tingling refresher course in what theater is really all about.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd called on any citizen who had been victimized by a youth gang to make a complaint to the police. He said the police could do nothinz unless citizens reported crimes.

title: ASPIN HITS A LOAN FOR BECHTEL WORK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) Representative. Les Aspin has charged an apparent conflict of interest in a $157million ExportImport Bank loan for liquefied natural gas plant in Algeria.

title: O'NEILL SAYS NIXON WILL QUIT IN SPRING
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 25 (AP)  Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Democrat of Massachusetts, said today that he thinks President Nixon will resign in April or May.

title: C.B.S. CITES MISUSE IN ARCHIVE CASE
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System, responding to criticism of its suit to enjoin Vanderbilt University rom recording newscasts and renting the tapes to th e public, has explained that it did not oppose the idea of a television news archive but rather the unauthorized duplication and editing of the broadcasts. C.B.S. said that this removes from the network control over its own product.

title: The Lehigh Gains in Effort To Sell Jersey City Branch
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25(UPI)The Lehigh Valley Railroad won Federal Court permission today to sell its National Docks branch rightofway in Jersey City for $500,000, provided it first obtains authority from the Interstate Commerce Commission to abandon the spur.

title: Nuclear Test Planned
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 25 (AP)An underground nuclear test with a yield between 20,000 and 200,000 tons of TNT will be conducted at the Nevada Test Site Wednesday, the Atomic Energy Commission announced today. The weaponsrelated test, codenamed Project Latir, may cause an earth tremor to be felt outside the boundaries of the test site northwest of here.

title: Lin and Mao: A Theory
description: CHESTERTOWN, Md.According to Peking's official story of Lin Piao's crimes, he was a traitorous villain who had attempted to assassinate Chairman Mao, Tsetung several times to restore capitalism in China, and when the latest attempt miscarried in early September, 1971, he tried to flee to the Soviet Union aboard an air force plane that crashed and burned in Outer Mongolia.

title: Joseph A. Gilleaudeau, 80, Stetson Hat Company Aide
description: Joseph, A. Gilleaudeau, retired Eastern sales manager of the John B. Stetson Hat Company and a former vice president and treasurer of the Brooklyn Dodgers baseball club, died Sunday in United Hos pital, Port Chester, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, N.Y.

title: AGENCY EXEMPTION ON OIL CURB ENDED
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 25The Federal Energy Office rescinded today the exemption of state and local governmental agencies from price controls on oil by publication in the Federal Register of its adoption Jan. 15 of that exemption.

title: LEON MANDEL DIES, LED CHICAGO STORE
description: Leon Mandel, who retired as board chairman of the Mandel Brothers department store in Chicago in 1960, when it was merged with Wieboldt Stores, Inc., died Friday in Palm Beach, Fla., where he lived. His age was 72.

title: Weston Triumphs Over Saurennann
description: Harold Weston Jr. of New York outpointed Mario Saurennann of Philadelphia last night in a 10round welterweight bout at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum. Each fighter weighed 150 pounds.

title: Good Reading News
description: In actual percentages, the improvement of the socalled reading scores  the tested reading achievement of the city's public school pupils  may seem insignificant. What matters more than the slight reduction of those who read below their normal grade level is the fact that an unbroken, tenyear downhill slide has been reversed. Even more encouraging, the most substantial improvement has occurred at the level of the most severe retardation. In 1973, almost 5 per cent fewer youngsters were two or more years below grade than in 1972.

title: Kellogg Co. Is Expanding
description: BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Feb. 25 (UPI)  The Kellogg Company announced plans today to construct a $50million plant in Lancaster, Pa., to manufacture and distribute readytoeat breakfast foods. It said the plant was part of a $100million expansion program announced several months ago. The Lancaster plant, it said, would open in 1976 and would employ 350 persons.

title: People in Sports: Checkup for Martin
description: Billy Martin, the manager of the Texas Rangers, flew yesterday from the team's spring training headquarters at Pompano Beach, Fla., to Washington for a complete physical examination.

title: A Leading Writer Is Held in Uruguay
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 24Buried in the inside page on crime and sex in Uruguay's leading newspaper, El Pais, 12 days ago was an article headlined Pornographic Publication: Five Detained.

title: BUDGET HEARINGS DRAW APPROVAL
description: Capitalbudget hearings at City Hall have never been what you'd call a smash hit. The script is confining; too many dollar signs and decimal points. Still, the hearing always drew a good crowd, and that is what city government and show business are all about.

title: CHEMETRON GAINS A SOVIET PROCESS
description: The Chemetron Corporation announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement with Moscow to manufacture and market a welding process developed in the Soviet Union.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Koppers Company announced yesterday in Pittsburgh that it would design and build a $60million coke plant for the WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation's Follansbee, W. Va., plant. The new battery of 79 coke ovens, 20feet high, is scheduled to begin operations in May, 1976.

title: NORRIS E. PHILLIPS OF TILE INDUSTRY, 79
description: OLEAN, N.Y., Feb 25Norris E. Phillips, a leading spokesman for the American ceramic tile industry, died yesterday at the Scottsdale (Ariz.) Memorial Hospital while visiting his daughter, Mrs. Kay Scripter. He was 79 years old and lived here.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Domestic and Foreign Affairs
description: Following is a transcript of President Nixon's news conference last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: SHOP TALK
description: My son was always beautifully dressedhe's an only grandson and an only nephew on either side, said Linda Cohen of her 5yearold. But everyone I know has children the same age, so I never had anyone to give the clothes away to. And they were always in such good condition.

title: Briefs On The Arts
description: A new production of Jerome Robbins's New York Export, Op. Jazz and a revival of Gerald Atpino's Viva Vivaldi! will highlight the City Center Joffrey Ballet's spring season, which opens next Wednesday at the City Center 55th Street Theater.

title: A Few Soviet Tank Experts In Peru, Pentagon Aides Say
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI) Pentagon officials reported yesterday that two or three Russian technicians were in Peru to train Peruvian soldiers in the use of Soviet tanks bought last year.

title: Joseph Striker, Actor, 74, Played in King of Kings
description: Joseph Striker, a film and stage actor in the nineteentwenties and early thirties, died Sunday in St. Barnabas Hospital, Livingston, N. J. He was 74 years old and lived at 4 Riverside Drive in Cranford, N.J.

title: KALMBACH VIEWED AS A KEY WITNESS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Herbert W. Kalmbach, Presiden Nixon's personal lawyer, returned to the special Watergat?? prosecutor's office today t?? continue assisting lawyers ther?? with the preparation of the?? case, according to a wellplace?? source.

title: FOREIGN SECURITIES
Dissident Ethiopia Troops Seize Asmara
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 26Elements of the Ethiopian Army today reportedly seized control of Asmara, the nation's second largest city, to back demands for higher pay.

title: Two Mates Win, 2 Lose ArbitrationFinale for Michael
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb, 26While Mel Stottlemyre engaged in negotiations that brought him a favorable contract and ended his fourday holdout, four other Yankees gave mostly favorable reviews today to baseball's revolutionary salaryarbitration procedure.

title: F.P.C. Permission Sought For $212.5Million Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI) Two natural gas transmission companies asked the Federal Power Commission today for permission to construct a $212.5million pipeline through Idaho, Washington and Oregon.

title: The Value of a Living ExPresident
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, N. Y.Since my own early days, the United States has always had at least one living exPresident, one who had acquired wisdom and experience in office and the detachment and objectivity that came with departure from office.

title: Edward G. Robinson Jr. Is Dead; Late Screen Star's Son Was 40
description: Edward G. Robinson Jr., the son of the late screen actor, died yesterday. Mr. Robinson, who was 40 years old, was found unconscious by his wife, Nan, in their West Hollywood home. His death was attributed to natural causes.

title: Stocks Rise on Amex and overtheCounter Market
description: After a slow start, prices on the American Stock Exchange picked up steam during the day and closed higher in slightly steppedup trading. A similar situation prevailed in the overthecounter market.

title: Expansion Candidates Cling to Hope in N. F.L.
description: MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 26They packed up their elaborate stadium models today, waved goodby to the last owner, paid the hotel bills heavily weighted with entertainment costs and went home empty. They are the pitchmen, the people seeking what some regard as the absolute ultimate in life, an expansion franchise in the National Football League.

title: Male Complaints Scuttle Ladies' Night at Yonkers
Nixon Assails Democrats On Education and Health
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 26President Nixon, in a surprise move, accused Congressional Democrats today of acting irresponsibly on education legislation and of failing tomove fast enough on health insurance.

title: EVERETT W. NEWCOMB
description: Everett W. Newcomb, retired treasurer and vice president of the Georgia Kaolin Company, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital, Wolfeboro, N. H. He was 80 years old and lived in Tuftonboro, N. H.

title: Clue to Control of Hibernation Found
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26Blood taken from a hibernating animal in winter has been found to contain a substance that initiates offseason hibernation when it is later injected into an animal of the same species.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: 2 COUNTS DROPPED IN MACKELL TRIAL
description: Two counts of official misconduct against Thomas J. Maccell, the former Queens District Attorney, and two aides were dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh.

title: AMERICAN ELECTRIC IN EARNINGS JUMP
description: The American Electric Power Company reported yesterday a 16.8 per cent jump in its earnings in the 12 months to Jan. 31, and its directors voted to increase the June quarter dividend from 47 cents to 50 cents a share.

title: Frank Assunto, Trumpeter; Formed Dukes of Dixieland
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 26 (AP)Frank Assunto, a jazz trumpeter and leader of the Dukes of Dixieland, died yesterday after a brief illness. He was 42 years old.

title: A Zestful Rockefeller Steers Choices Study
description: With characteristic gusto, Nelson A. Rockefeller, now a private citizen at the age of 65, has plunged into a new endeavor with the enthusiasm and dedication he has devoted to such projects as the Albany Mall and the vast expansion of the State University during his 15 years as the state's chief executive.

title: Soviet Aid to Arabs For Mideast War Put at $2.6Billion
