description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)  Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, estimated today that it had cost the Soviet Union more than $2.6billion to supply and equip, Arab nations as result of the Mideast War.

title: People and Business
description: Marshall F. Smith yesterday was named president of Indian Head, Inc. He succeeds Richard J. Powers, 48, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the diversified industrial company.

title: WELFARE CHECKUP FAULTED BY LEVITT
description: ALBANY, Feb. 26Delays in New York City's welfare eligibility recertification program are costing more than $100million a year, and at the present rate, the program will not be completed for more than seven years, State Controller Arthur Levitt asserted today.

title: PAUL SAMPLE, 77, ARTIST, TEACHER
description: HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 26Paul H. Sample, artistinresience emeritus at Dartmouth College, died today in Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital at the age of 77. He had suffered heart attack yesterday at his some in Norwich. He leaves his wife, the former Silvia Howand, and a son, Timothy.

title: Cochrans Triumph In Slaloms
description: WILMINGTON, N. Y., Feb. 26  It was Cochran Day at Whiteface Mountain today. Two members of the famous skiracing family from Richmond, Vt., Bob and Barbara, scored impressive CanAm slalom triumphs in subfreezing weather.

title: 7.5% RISE IN RENT IS APPROVED HERE
description: The State Court of Appeals has given final approval to rent increases of up to 7.5 per cent a year in many of the city's one million rentcontrolled apartments.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: REGENTS WILL TRY TEACHING CHANGE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 26The State Education Department will begin to implement a controversial new approach next year to teachertraining that places greater emphasis on actual teaching in the classroom and less on formal course requirements, a department official told a committee of the State Board of Regents here today.

title: Tories Want to Help Only the Truly Needy
description: LONDON, Feb. 26Geoffrey and Ann Ball live on a quiet square three blocks from Hyde Park, Their house, one of a row of expensive new town houses, has four floors. Whatever small domestic anarchies may be produced by their three daughters are kept well out of sight.

title: Louis Klebenov Dies at 73; Vending Company Official
description: BOSTON, Feb. 26  Louis H. Klebenov, a founder of the ABC Vending Corporation, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Newton, Mass.

title: Defamation Trial of Maheu v. Hughes Corporation Opens on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26 What may be known in years to come as a historic confrontation in the law of defamation  Maheu v. Summa Corporation  opened in United States District Court here today.

title: SOVIET STRESSES TRADE CONDITIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26The Soviet Foreign Trade Minister, Nikolai S. Patolichev, said today that even though RussianAmerican trade has expanded substantially in the last two years, there is a long way before us.

title: Appeal Planned on Order Releasing Reading Scores
description: TRENTON, Feb. 26Lawyers for the New Jersey Education Association, a teachers group, will appeal to the United States Supreme Court tomorrow in an effort to stop the publication of statewide testing scores of New Jersey students.

title: MISS BALL TO END HERE'S LUCY SHOW
description: Lucille Ball, who for most of 23 years has been a Monday night fixture on the Columbia Broadcasting System's television schedule, has advised the network that she will discontinue her weekly series, Here's Lucy, next fall, voluntarily ending a primetime run that has been the longest in television history.

title: 3 UTILITIES' OUTLAYS TO TOP $526MILLION
description: Two Midwestern utilities and one in California announced yesterday construction programs totaling more than $526million.

title: Head of Guard in Kent Shootings Questioned 6 Hours Before Jury
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 26The Federal grand jury investigating the shootings at Kent State University began to focus this week on the higher officials who made the decisions to bring National Guardsmen on the campus.

title: Fog Over Britain
description: One of the most divisive and confusing British election campaigns of the century will end at the polls tomorrow with not only the results but the pattern of government for the shortrun future very much in doubt. The only constant turned up by the threeweek campaign and confirmed by opinion polls is a virtually unprecedented voter distrust of the two big partiesthe governing Conservatives and the opposition Labor.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Tied by Canucks
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Feb. 26The New York Islanders and the Vancouver Canucks played to a 11 tie in their National Hockey League game tonight in the Nassau Coliseum before many dissatisfied fans in the crowd of 11,121.

title: President Will Meet Broadcasters in Texas
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI)The National Association of Broadcasters announced today that President Nixon would appear March 19 at its convention in Houston and would participate in a question and answer session.

title: Jaworski Forecasts Action On Indictments by Friday
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Special Prosecutor Leon Jaworski said today that he believed his office now knew the full story of the Watergate affair and predicted that major indictments in the coverup phase of the ease would come as early as Thursday or Friday.

title: MILITARY BUDGET SPURS ECONOMY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger said today that next year's military budget was increased at the last minute by more than $1billion by the White House to help provide a stimulus to a lagging domestic economy.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space, working group on remote sensing of the earth by satellite 10:30 A.M., 3 P.M. and 8:30 P.M.

title: Liberals Hope to End along Slumber
description: LONDON, Feb. 26  Mr. and Mrs. Guy Wingfield have been voting for the tiny Liberal party for years. After the election Thursday, they think, it will no longer be tiny.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 41

title: Central Park Follies
description: There is a new version of an old drama called Up In Central Park. It is taking place at the Arsenal, and nobody knows who the players are. Directions call for the presence of commissioners and planners but they're almost all gone. There are rumors that the Arsenal empty.

title: Ruth Sonneborn, 74, Dies; Wrote Books for Children
description: Ruth A. Sonneborn, author of books for children and manager since 1936 of the bookstore of the Bank Street College of Eduflation, died Sunday in Doctors Hospital. She was 74 years old.

title: PRESIDENT'S VIEW ON IMPEACHMENT DISPUTED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Republicans and Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee challenged today President Nixon's assertion that he could not be impeached except on the basis of evidence that he had violated criminal law.

title: DiGregorio Has a Lock on RookieofYear Honors
description: Ernie DiGregorio of the Buffalo Braves for rookie of the year. There is no one else.

title: A Zestful Rockefeller Steers Choices Study
description: With characteristic gusto, Nelson A. Rockefeller, now a private citizen at the age of 65, has plunged into a new endeavor with the enthusiasm and dedication he has devoted to such projects as the Albany Mall and the vast expansion of the State University during his 15 years as the state's chief executive.

title: INDICTED L.I. AIDE TO STAY IN OFFICE
description: OYSTER BAY,. L. I., Feb. 26 John W. Burke, the Oyster Bay Town Supervisor who was indicted by a Federal grand jury last week on a charge of perjury, reiterated today that he would remain in office despite requests that he suspend himself pending the outcome of a trial. The Town Board unanimously supported his stand.

title: Expansion Candidates Cling to Hope in N.F.L.
description: MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 26They packed up their elaborate stadium models today waved goodby to the last owner, paid the hotel bills heavily weighted with entertainment costs and went home empty. They are the pitchmen, the people seeking what some regard as the absolute ultimate in life, an expansion franchise in the National Football League.

title: Tanker Flat Tires Prolong Agony
description: Things fell flat yesterday for earlybird motorists waiting upwards of two hours in the gloom and chill at one of the West Side's biggest gasoline stations on the first day of mandatory gasoline allocations.

title: Earnings Up at WarnerLambert, Borden and ScheringPlough
description: The WarnerLambert Company posted record results yesterday for last year and its fourth quarter. Foreign sales accounted for about 40 per cent of the total and about a third of annual profits. A spokesman for the company said foreign sales were the fastestgrowing segment of the business.

title: St. John's Trounces Holy Cross
description: Glen Williams, a freshman; played a starring role as St. John's ran off an easy 9872 college basketball victory over Holy Cross last night, before 3,497 fans at Alumni Hall in Jamaica.

title: Soltis Takes First Place In Chess Tournament Here
description: Andrew Soltis, the chess reporter for The New York Post, has scored 63 to win the seventh annual GoldwaterMarshall masters' chess tournament at the Marshall Chess Club here.

title: Differing Dominates Talk Of Business and Politics
description: An allday conference attended by some 100 businessmen and several Government officials yesterday found the two groups often behind separate battlements.

title: $300Million in Red, City Freezes Hiring And Curbs Spending
description: A modified municipal job freeze has been imposed to help the city control a budget that is running in the red by $300million.

title: Bolet's Romantic Pianism Evokes Giants of the Past
description: For the Most part, Jorge Bolet gave a hyphenated concert in Carnegie Hall on Monday evening. BachBusoni; StraussTausig; StraussSchulzEyler; WagnerLiszt. (Somehow the 24 Preludes of Chopin's Op, 28 also managed to sneak in.) Mr. Bolet's action was quite deliberate. As one of the most prominent pianists of the romantic revival, he put on his program a great deal of music that was popular at the turn of the century but that has since slipped into disrepute. The audience reaction he evoked, with a standing ovation and all, showed that there is life in the old girls yet.

title: ASHES SYMBOLIZE STARTING OF LENT
description: Today is Ash Wednesday, the beginning of the penitential season of Lent for most of the world's Christians.

title: Soviet Awards Go to Troops In the Chinese Border Area
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 26 (UPI)The Soviet Union today announced special decorations for troops in the tense Chinese border area, possibly an indication of new troubles along the frontier.

title: A New President Is Set for I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday major management changes and corporate restructuring, including the election of John R. Opel as president.

title: U.S. HELPING CAIRO ON SUEZ OPENING
Procter Heir Pleads Guilty
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 26 (UPI)  Frederick W. Procter, 51yearold heir to the Procter & Gamble trust, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal court to two counts of possession of marijuana. Government prosecutors dropped six other marijuana charges against Mr. Procter when he leaded guilty to the two possession charges.

title: 300 Lobby in Albany for Wilson Budget on the Arts
description: ALBANY, Feb. 26  More than 300 representatives of art organizations across the state gathered in the State Capitol today to lobby for the $30.5million for the arts requested in Governor Wilson's 197475 budget.

title: Dance: Limon Showcase
description: The Jos Limn Dance Company ended its miniseason at the City Center Downstairs on Monday night. In this basement setting, the company gave 14 different works in four programsa formidable achievement. This was a showcase for the new Limn company, and it could scarcely have been better illuminated.

title: Mr. Kissinger and the Europeans
description: LONDON, Feb. 28Secretary of State Henry Kissinger stopped off briefly in London on his way to the Middle East. He stayed at Claridge's, with a marine outside his door all night; watched President Nixon's press conference on the B.13:44, talked briefly, on the phone with Jiremy Thorpe, the Liberal leader; called on Foreign Secretary Sir Alec DouglaiHome; had lunch with Prime Minister Heath, and flew off.

title: Women Rebelling In Track
description: Growing discontent, with the policies and practices of the Amateur Athletic Union is causing a rebellion in women's track and field.

title: London Gold Price Soars Above $175
description: LONDON, Feb. 26The gold rush continued throughout the European bullion markets today as the metal surged above $175 and touched $184 an ounce here before settling back at the close.

title: Wilson Calls for Increase. In State's Highway Funds
description: ALBANY, Feb. 26Governor Wilson today proposed a record state highway appropriation with the, addition of $64.5million more, as his office expressed the hope that by the time the highways were built there would be enough gasoline to drive on them.

title: YOUTH WHO ESCAPED 20 TIMES IS SEIZED
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 26  Francisco Rodrigue, a 16yearold problem youth said to have made 20 escapes from juvenile authorities  including a leap last Thursday through a courtroom window  was recaptured last night hiding in a barrel.

title: St. John's Trounces Holy Cross
description: Glen Williams, a freshman, played a starring role as St. John's ran off an easy 9872 college basketball victory over Holy Cross last night, before 3,497 fans at Alumni Hall in Jamaica.

title: Lucius Pitts, Educator, Is Dead; President of Paine College, 59
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., Feb. 26 (AP) Lucius H. Pitts, president of Paine College since 1971, collapsed and died while at work in his campus office last night. He was 59 years old.

title: PRICES DECLINE IN BOND TRADING
description: Prices declined in the bond markets yesterday, a move widely attributed by participants to remarks early in the day by the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Arthur E. Burns, and subsequent sequent action by the board itself. Mr. Burns, in testimony before the SenateHouse Joint Economic Committee, discounted the merits of a reduction at this point in the discount rate, which now stands at a record 7 per cent.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: U.S. Olympic Prospects Cautioned

title: 6 Marxists Here Absolved Of Imprisoning a Member
description: A Manhattan grand jury has absolved six members of Marxist group here of charges of having unlawfully imprisoned a member of the group, Alice Weitzman.

title: Plan to Crash Plane In White House Laid To Dead Hijacker
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI) Samuel J. Byck, the wouldbe hijacker who died attempting to commandeer an airliner at Baltimore last week, intended to crash the aircraft into the White House, the columnist Jack Anderson reported today.

title: Advertising: Shortage Effects
description: The economy of shortage could act as a great scouring pad (pink or blue) on the tarnished image of advertising, a group of its besmirched practitioners heard yesterday.

title: Top Democrats Say U.S. Energy Crisis Has Not Subsided
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26President Nixon's declaration that the energy crisis had subsided to the status of a problem drew heated contradictions today from Democratic Congressional leaders and a mild endorsement from the Federal Energy Office.

title: Tied by Canucks
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Feb. 26The New York Islanders and the Vancouver Canucks played to a 1.1 tie in their National Hockey League game tonight in the Nassau Coliseum before many dissatisfied fans in the crowd of 11,121.

title: About New York
description: Alfred J. Scotti was at his home in Garden City, L. I., yesterday, showing his scrapbooks, talking about his life, and remembering bad guys he had sent to prison, or as he sometimes called it, the can.

title: Two Mates Win, 2 Lose ArbitrationFinale for Michael
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb, 26While Mel Stottlemyre engaged in negotiations that brought him a favorable contract and ended his fourday holdout, four other Yankees gave mostly favorable reviews today to baseball's revolutionary salaryarbitration procedure.

title: Fun for Children, Indoors and Out
TWO SAIGON BASES REPORTED OVERRUN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 26 (AP)North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops have overrun two Governmerrt bases in the Mekong Delta and inflicted heavy casualties on the defenders, reports from the field said today. Nearly 150 of the estimated 1,000 men defending the two bases were reported killed, wounded or missing, a casualty rate of nearly 15 per cent. Communist losses were not known.

title: Rival for Gov. Sargent
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass., Feb. 26 (AP)  Former State Commerce Commissioner Carroll Sheehan announced today that he would seek the Republican nomination for Governor. He said that Gov. Francis W. Sargent had misdirected the commonwealth and had neglected social programs.

title: MITCHELL PANEL NEAR COMPLETION
description: A pool of potential jurors to try John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans fell just short of completion yesterday, setting the stage for formation of a jury by late today or tomorrow.

title: Chock Full O'Nuts Set to Get Rheingold
description: William J. Black, chairman of Chock Full O'Nuts, said last night that he expected to complete an agreement with Pepsico in the next two or three days for a takeover of the Rheingold Breweries.

title: Jaworski Forecasts Action On Indictments by Friday
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Special Prosecutor Leon Jaworski said today that he believed his office now knew the full story of the Watergate affair and predicted that major indictments in the coverup phase of the case would come as early as Thursday or Friday.

title: E. David Proctor Is Dead: Former Gulf Oil Chairman
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Feb. 26 E. David Proctor, retired chairman of the board of the Gulf Oil Corporation, died Sunday.

title: Gross Trial Judge to Sequester Jury
description: NEWARK, Feb. 26Judge Lawrence A. Whipple said today in the Federal District Court that he would sequester the jury in the trial of Nelson G. Gross, the former State Republican Chairman, on campaign fraud charges.

title: Yogi Back, Finds Cool Reception
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 26Yogi Berra finally ended his fourday junket to the. Mardi Gras tonight and rejoined his shivering New York Mets on the eve of their first fullsquad workout of spring training.

title: CATENA IS FREED BY COURT ORDER
description: TRENTON, Feb. 26Gerardo Catena, the reputed successor to the late Vito Genovese as the preeminent Mafia figure in New Jersey, was released from prison today after a State Superior Court judge ruled that any further incarceration on several contempt charges would be unconstitutional.

title: Dexter to Stress Mind Over Money
description: John Dexter, newly named production supervisor of the Metropolitan Opera, firmly believes in Brecht's Law, which states: the Ideal amount of rehearsal time for any theatrical production is always one week more. But Mr. Dexter, the 48yearold British director who was chosen for the freshly created post in the wake of Rafael Kubelik's resignation as music director, also insists that opera must cut its suit according to the times.

title: East and West of the Rhine
description: BONNChancellor Willy Brandt is not as pessimistic about strengthening the European. Community as are some of his colleagues in other countries who have begun to feel rather gloomy as a result of resurgent French nationalism and the West's failure to unite on a common oil policy during the energy crisis.

title: HOUSE PANEL BLOCKS LAND PLANNING BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 The House Rules Committee unexpectedly voted today to block approval of a Senatepassed national land use and planning bill that had been strongly opposed by lobbyists for real estate, mining, industrial and ranching interests. Environmental groups had vigorously supported it.

title: Ingenuity of 7 Youths And a Pump Is Balked
description: What appeared to be an unofficial allocation program instituted by seven youths was interrupted in Brooklyn yesterday. They were charged with using an electric pump to transfer gasoline from somebody's else car to their own.

title: STRIPMINE CURBS UPHELD IN REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 26On the eve of a vote in the House Interior Committee on an attempt by the coal industry to Weaken proposed Federal regulation of strip mining, industry representatives opposing strict controls suffered a setback today.

title: Market Place: Funds Favoring Energy Stocks
description: Shifting currents in the stock market late last year appear to have favored the energy stocks as much as any industry group.

title: E. TOMLIN BAILEY
description: NORWICH, Conn., Feb. 26E. Tomlin Bailey of Old Lyme, former consul general of Hamburg, Germany, died Saturday at UncasonThames Hospital. He was 66 years old.

title: GRAM'S NET OFF; PENNEY UP FOR 73
description: Two of the country's largest retail chains issued sharply varying reports yesterday. The W. T. Grant Company said that it had a sharp decline in earnings on higher sales for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31, while the J. C. Penney Company announced an 11.8 per cent rise in its net on increased sales for the year ended Jan. 26.

title: Rioting by Students Closes The University of Nairobi
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 26 (Reuters)  The University of Nairobi was closed indefinitely today after two days of rioting by students demanding the removal of a departmental head.

title: Levy, at The Composer Speaks, Lets the Music Say It for Him
description: Marvin David Levy didn't speak very much Monday eveWing at The Composed Speaks concert in Town Hall. His new work, In Memoriam W. H. Auden, occupied only onequarter of the program in the first place. And he neither prefaced it with any spoken explanation nor followed it with much in the way of response to written or spoken questions. The few questions were answered succinctly if wittily, but Mr. Levy nervously said goodnight before the audience had time to overcome its own diffirence.

title: $300Million in Red, City Freezes Hiring And Curbs Spending
description: A modified municipal job freeze has been imposed to help the city control a budget that is running in the red by $300million.

title: BURNS DEFENDS FEDERAL RESERVE
description: The chairman or the Federal Reserve Board, Dr. Arthur F. Burns, denied yesterday that the central bank deserved major blame for the country's recordbreaking inflation rate. He rejected the charge of a Federal Reserve critic, Prof. Milton Friedman or the University of Chicago, who said earlier this week that loose monetary policy was the major cause of price pressures now sweeping through the economy.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (Reuters)The Federal Home boan Bank Board issued today its final regulation to permit Federal savings and loan associations to issue flexiblepayment mortgage loans. The normal payment on an 8 per Cent, 30year, $30,000 mortgage is $220 a month. Under the fiexiblepayment plan, the borrower could pay as little as $200 a month for the first five years and then $230 a month teethe remaining term.

title: CATENA IS FREED BY COURT ORDER
description: TRENTON, Feb. 26Gerardo Catena, the reputed successor to the late Vito Genovese as the preeminent Mafia figure in New Jersey, was released from prison today after a State Superior Court judge ruled that any further incarceration on several contempt charges would be unconstitutional.

title: 46Day Tax Bills Sold At Treasury Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 The United States Treasury auctioned 46day taxanticipation bills today. The results were:

title: ExPostal Official Links Rep. Brasco to Kickback
description: A former Post Office official, testified in Federal Court here yesterday that Representative Frank J. Brasco agreed in 1968 to take a secret $17,500 kickback from a financial agent who had been negotiating a loan to a Bronx trucking company controlled by an alleged Mafia captain.

title: Ulster Is Also Voting, but the Main Issue There Is How to Stop the Violence
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 26While Thursday is election day in Northern Ireland as it is in the rest of Britain, the focus here has not been on economic issues.

title: G.O.P. Leader Promoted
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI)Mary Louise Smith, Republican National Committee member from Iowa, today was appointed cochairman of the committee. The chairman, George Bush, named Mrs. Smith to succeed Janet J. Johnston, who resigned.

title: Snow Stops Reactor Shroud
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 26 (UPI)The 66mile trip of a 150,000pound atomic reactor shroud on a rig headed for a proposed new nuclear plant M suburban Philadelphia was interrupted by heavy snows yesterday It was forced to park on Route 72, 10 miles from Chester, Pa., where it began its trip.

title: Bill Would Require City Aides To Reveal the Source of Incomes
description: A bill requiring elected and top administrative officials to disclose the sources, but not the amounts, of outside income was introduced into the City Council yesterday by Carter Burden, a Democrat who represents the Upper East Side.

title: BottleBomb at Wailing Wall Explodes After Evacuation
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 26 (Reuters)A bottle filled with explosives blew up at the Wailing Wall in the Old City here, shortly after all worshippers and visitors had been evacuated from the area, the police said.

title: Rote Jr. Top Superstar; To Donate Part of Prize
description: ROTONDA, Fla., Feb. 26 (AP)Kyle Rote Jr., a 23yearold ministerial student and soccer player, won the annual Superstars' tournament today. For finishing first in the twoday competition, he received the $25,000 top prize. In addition, he won bonus, and qualifying money for a total of $53,400.

title: Chapter X for Westgate
description: The Westgate California Corporation, once the keystone of C. Arnholt Smith's financial empire, has filed for reorganization under Chapter X of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. Page 59.

title: Inquiry Finds OwnerDealers Forced Out
description: A month long investigation after by district attorneys in six cities has fairly well established Con in our minds that independent systematically eliminated, a spokesman for the prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Get Word of Reed's Return
description: The Knicks learned late yesterday afternoon that Willis Reed, their injured captaint will be coming back to National Basketball Association competition soon. Then, buoyed by the news, they put out one of their finest defensive efforts of the season to drub the Capital Bullets, 8571, at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: New Books
description: All Our Kin: Strategies for Survival in a Black Community, by Carol. B. Stack (Harper & Row, $7.95).

title: Man Who Says He Stole Vermeer Makes Second Ransom Demand
description: LONDON, Feb. 26  A man who asserted that he had stolen a painting by Jan Vermeer valued at up to $5million telephoned a London newspaper today demanding free kerosene for the old people of Highgate, the area from which the painting was snatched last Saturday.

title: N.B.A. to Meet March 7
description: The National Basketball Association Board of Governors will hold a special meeting on March 7 in Chicago. On the agenda will be possible expansion for 1974 75 season, playoff schedules for 1974 and the 197475. regularseason schedule.

title: Arizona Track Coach Is Pat on Probation
description: DENVER, Feb. 26 (UPI)The Western Athletic Conference Council placed Willie Williams, Arizona's track coach, on probation for one year today and prohibited Arizona from recruiting or issuing track scholarships during the coming year.

title: U.S. Trade Office in Soviet Idle
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 26The American commercial center, opened formally with great fanfare last Oct. 3 by Secretary of Commerce Frederick B. Dent, now sits empty and idle, crippled by lack of funds for the equipment to operate it.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Going out Guide
description: HIGH NOON The most talented group performing in New York regularly, before sundown, may well be Afro/ American Total Theater, the company that has taken over the theater in the round on the main floor at the Martinique Hotel, 49 West 32d Street (5657134). Their shows are beautifully spirited and professional, even without considering that it's a twoaday, at 12:15 and 1:15 Mondays through Thursdays (they've started a Friday night, 8 P.M. performance show, too).

title: Juror Is Excused Because of Illness At Squire's Trial
description: Special to The New York Times

title: EAST ORANGE HITS SNAG ON AMNESTY
description: EAST ORANGE, Feb. 26A municipal plan to waive the extra costs charged motorists paying parking tickets issued prior to 1973 during a monthlong amnesty period here, may be foiled unless the proposal receives proper judicial approval.

title: CANARSIE DIGS IN FOR SCHOOL FIGHT
description: An order by Chancellor Irving Anker that calls for more black and Puerto Rican pupils in two predominantly white elementary schools in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn will be contested by community school board officials, one of them announced yesterday.

title: Top Democrats Say U.S. Energy Crisis Has Not Subsided
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26President Nixon's declaration that the energy crisis had subsided to the status of a problem drew heated contradictions today from Democratic Congressional leaders and a mild endorsement from the Federal Energy Office.

title: TV: Bernstein Mass, in Yale Production, Being Shown Tonight
description: Tonight at 8:30, public television's Theater in America series is presenting MassA Theater Piece for Singers, Players and Dancers, which was composed by Leonard Bernstein for the 1971 opening of Washington's John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. The performance was recorded before an audience during last summer's European premiere of the work at the Vienna Konzerthaus.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Counterfeit $115,000 Seized

title: G.A.O. Says Insufficient Funds Peril Deadlines for Water Pollution Control
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 The Nixon Administration was accused by the General Accounting Office at a Senate hearing today of failing to provide the research and development funds necessary to meet the clean water standards of the 1972 Water Pollution Control Act.

title: Chinese Told to Stress Study in Ideological Drive
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 26Reports from the provinces in China disclose new admonitions to Communist party officials to place study before action and avoid factional strife in the ideological campaign now sweeping the country.

title: Many Coal Mines Closing Because of Gas Shortage
description: CHARLESTON, W. V., Feb. 26 (AP)  Mines producing 100.000 tons of coal a day were shut down today as miners in West Virginia and Virginia complained that they could note get enough gasoline to get to work.

title: Bridge: Freewheelers Emerge Best On Borderline Opening Bid
description: For nearly a quarter of a century, there have been two schools of thought among New York experts on the subject of borderline opening bids in first and second seat.

title: Bridge:
description: For nearly a quarter of a century, there have been two schools of thought among New York experts on the subject of borderline opening bids in fitst and second seat.

title: Petition Under Chapter XI Filed by Rosenau Brothers
description: Rosenau Brothers, Inc. the country's largest maker of children's dresses, yesterday filed a petition for voluntary bankruptcy under the Chapter XI provisions of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The United States Olympic Committee has warned all college athletes that they could lose their Olympic and PanAmerican Games eligibility if they followed the National Collegiate Athletic Association ruling allowing them to be professionals in one sport and amateurs in another.

title: Letter Explaining Nixon Refusal to Appear at Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 26Following is the text of a letter from James D. St. Clair, special counsel for the President, to Chief Judge Harold H. Greene of the Superior Court of the District of Columbia regarding President Nixon's refusal to appear at a hearing to determine whether he must testify at the California trial of John D. Ehrichman:

title: Gulf Dealer on L. I. Sells Imported Gas' At 69.9c a Gallon
description: ELMONT, L. I., Feb. 26 Dear patient customer, the letter of apology begins. Because of the urgent needs of our customers, we decided to purchase the imported gasoline at the higher price rather than close down our pumps completely.

title: WORKER IS KILLED IN BLAST IN LINDEN
description: LINDEN, Feb. 26One employe was killed and three others were lightly injured today when a 10,000gallon tank of chemicals exploded at the American Cyanamid Company plant here.

title: Girl, 3, Who Got a New Liver, Dies of Causes Held Unrelated
description: A 3yearold girl from Alden, N. Y., who was given a second liver in a transplant operation employing an experimental technique last November, died Monday night at the Memorial SloanKettering Center. Hospital spokesmen said the death was apparently unrelated to the organ transplant.

title: Suzanne Guerlac Is Bride of Charles P. Stevenson Jr.
description: In the chapel of St. James' Episcopal Church yesterday afternoon, Miss Suzanne Guerlac, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Henry Querlac of Ithaca, N. Y., became the bride of Charts Portr Stevenson Jr., son of M. and Ms. Stevenson of Buffalo and Southampton, L. I.

title: Westgate Former Key Company Of Smith, Plans Reorganization
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 26The Westgate California Corporation, the battered keystone of what had been a billiondollar finacial empire controlled by C. Arnholt Smith, today petitioned for reorganization under Chapter X of the Federal BankAct.

title: Saigon Defended by U.S. Tour Group
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI) A group of current and former Government officials just back from a tour of SouthVietnam said today that the only danger to the Saigon Government was from an outpouring of propaganda in the United States.

title: An Optimist on Energy
description: To paraphrase the folk singer, Where has all the gasoline gone? The Shah of Iran says the United States is getting as much oil as it did before the embargo, but President Nixon and William E. Simon, the energy administrator, say they know how much oil we are not getting. Public confusion over the energy crunch persists despite the President's assurance that, while the crisis has been passed, the problem remains.

title: Questionable Questions
description: Televised Presidential news conferences offer the rare  in Mr. Nixon's case, all too rare  opportunity to put direct questions to the Chief Executive and to elicit personal replies in full view of the American people. The adversary nature of these confrontations thus inevitable and indeed desirable. As the only substitute for question period in the parliamentary form of government, a noholdsbarred approach by the press is clearly in the interest of the people's right to know.

title: Air Fare to Europe Rising 7% More on Costs of Fuel
description: The cost of air travel to Europe, which has already risen about 16 per cent over the last year, will be increased an additional 7 per cent on April because of rising fuel costs, according to airline sources.

title: Chock Full O'Nuts Set to Get Rheingold
description: William J. Black, chairman of Chock Full O'Nuts, said last night that he expected to complete an agreement with Pepsico in the next two or three days for a takeover of the Rheingold Breweries.

title: Red Smith
description: Social Note: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Jackson Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., are enjoying a few days rest in Venice, Fla. Nine days ago Mr. Snead tied for second in the $150,000 Glen Campbell Los Angeles open golf tournament and collected $13,875. Last Sunday he tied for 15th in the $260,000 Jackie Gleason Inverrary at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and earned $3,900. Understandably weary approaching his 62d birthday, Mr. Snead passed up this week's tournament in Orlando and took Mrs. Snead to Venice, where a telephone call yesterday Sports elicited the information that he was out, on of the golf course. The names of the suckers and amount of the Nassau have not been The Times disclosed.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A plainclothes transit patrolman shot and killed a teenage gunman yesterday afternoon when he reportedly surprised him and a companion as they tried to hold up a change booth at the Van Sicklin Avenue elevated station of the IRT New Lots line in Brooklyn. The yo'uth, tentatively identified as Randell May, was killed after he reportedly fired a shot at Patrolman Auderitk Wiltshire; who hall been hiding near the booth. The, police said that Patrolman Wiltshire, and a partner, were on stakeout duty because of a number of recent holdups at the station.

title: TOP ALLENDE MEN REPORTED ON ISLE
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 26Leading supporters of Chile's late President, Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens, are being held in a desolate concentration camp on Dawson Island in the Strait of Magellan, according to a report last week in Brazil's leading political magazine, Visgo.

title: Countess Hadik, 63; Was a Descendant Of the Vanderbilts
description: Countess Bla Hadik, a daughter of the late Count and Countess Laszlo Szchenyi and a descendant of the Vanderbilt family, died yesterday in Lisbon, apparently of a stroke.

title: 7.5% RISE IN RENT IS APPROVED HERE
description: The State Court of Appeals has given final approval to rent increases of up to 7.5 per cent a year in many of the city's one million rentcontrolled apartments.

title: Dissident Ethiopia Troops Seize Asmara
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 26Elements of the Ethiopian Army today reportedly seized control of Asmara, the nation's second largest city, to back demands for higher pay.

title: BROWN JURY GETS SHOOTOUT DETAILS
description: Despite defense objections, details of a February, 1972, shootout between the police in St. Louis and alleged members of the socalled Black Liberation Army were read yesterday to the jury in the murder trial of Henry S. Brown.

title: V.A.Acknowledges Lack of Information On Late Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 The head of the Veterans Administration conceded today that his agency had no information on the number of Vietnam veterans who have had problems receiving their monthly education checks.

title: Vietnamese Agree to Free All Prisoners by March 6
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 26 (UPI)Vietcong and Saigon negotiators agreed today to free all remaining Vietnamese prisoners of war by March 6, a Government military spokesman said.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: International Labor Unit Names Frenchman Chief
description: GENEVA, Feb. 26  Francis Blanchard, a 57yearold Frenchman, was elected today as director general of the International Labor Organization, a United Nations specialized agency with 124 member nations.

title: Union Leaders Broaden Their Vision At Arden House a Columbia Retreat
description: HARRIMAN, N. Y., Feb. 26 Joe Vitelli, 31 years in the needle trades, son of a dressmaker, a former paratrooper and a guard at the postwar Nuremberg trials, lightly touched the azaleas under the somber portrait of the late Mrs. Mary Williamson Averell Harriman. Sol, he said to a friend, these flowers are real.

title: State Says 7 Oil Companies Persist in Dealer Rebates
description: The state charged yesterday In Supreme Court here that seven major oil companies in New York had continued their practice of offering anticompetitive discriminatory rebates to some service stations despite the companes' contention that the practice was halted with the onset of the gasoline crisis.

title: 800 Photos of Rothko Art Are Introduced at Trial
description: The brilliant colors of the paintings of the late abstract expressionist Mark Rothko were introduced yesterday into the quiet legal proceedings that have dealt with them as estate assets in Surrogate's Court.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: CANARSIE DIGS IN FOR SCHOOL PIGHT
description: An order by Chancellor Irving Anker that calls for more black and Puerto Rican pupils in two predominantly white elementary schools in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn will be contested by community school board officials, one of them announced yesterday.

title: BISHOP W.H.MEAD, 53, OF DELAWARE DIES
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 26  The Right Rev. William Henry Mead, seventh Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Delaware, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home here. He was 53 years old.

title: City Schools Hint Suburbs Are Needed in Integration
description: The central Board of Education Said yesterday that despite the city's best efforts its racial integration program was in jeopardy because of the flight of whites from the city. In a report to the State Board of Regents, it declared:

title: CONTROLS REDUCE GASOLINE TIEUPS ON FIRST DAY HERE
description: The lines of motorists wait., ing to buy gasoline were re ported shorter around the city yesterday as drivers with evennumbered license plates became the first to pull up to the pumps under the new, statewide oddeven mandatory allocation system.

title: Samuels Says Labor Chiefs Endorse Him for Governor
description: Attempting to squelch longstanding reports that many labor leaders oppose his gubernatorial candidacy, Howard J. Samuels announced yesterday that he had been endorsed, by seven regional labor leaders.

title: For the Defense
description: Since the Watergate scandals began, there has been an implicit conflict of interest between Mr. Nixon, occupant of the Presidency, and Mr. Nixon, potential defendant in a criminal indictment. Much of the trouble in which he now finds himself had its origin in his evident certainty that the power and prestige of the Presidency would always provide an impenetrable shield for questionable or even clearly illegal acts.

title: State Warned on Pollution
description: TRENTON, Feb. 26 (UPI)The top Federal environmental official for New York and New Jersey told Governor Byrne today the state could lose almost $600,000 if water pollution contral programs were not upgraded and implemented. It's not so much a warning as a fact of life, said Gerald Hansler of the United States Environmental Protection Agency after the meeting with Mr. Byrne.

title: Amoco Plans Plant in Texas
description: Plans for the construction of a multimilliondollar plant for the manufacture of highdensity polyethylene were announced yesterday by the Amoco Chemcials Corporation, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana). The plant, with a rated capacity of 300 million pounds a year, will be built at Alvin, Tex.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: ENGLEWOOD, Feb. 26It happened 34 years ago today: St. Cecilia High School of Englewood, coached by the late Vince Lombardi, defeated Bogota, 6 to 1, in basketball as Lombardi, a man who would not move an inch when he thought he was right, and Ev Hebei, the other coach, refused to give in to each other's tactics. Bogota's players would hold the ball; Lombardi's players would let them.

title: Notes People
description: Once a year, the town of Liberal, Kan. (pop. 13,471), gets its name in the newspaper because of pancakes. Yesterday being Shrove Tuesday, Liberal did it again, supplying this year's winner of the arinual Shrove Tuesday International Pancake Race.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Islamic Pageantry
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, Feb. 25 Col. Muammar elQaddafi of Libya slipped a small camera out of his pocket and began taking photographs of fellow delegates in the Punjab Assembly Hall. President Idr Amin of Uganda turned and smiled.

title: Glamour Issues Lead Late Stock Rally
description: Stock prices rallied late yesterday with glamour issues leading. Joining in the recovery were oil, fertilizer and nonferrous metal issues. Trading volume improved along with prices.

title: Smoke Kills 3 in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (UPI) Smoke from a smoldering mat tress, believed to have been ignited by a cigarette, killed a 36yearold woman and her two sons today. Iris Jimerson and her children, Eric, 8, and Bruce, 7, died of smoke inhalation, firemen said. They were found dead in separate beds in the same room of a threebedroom West Side apartment, firemen, said.

title: Benjamin Adler, Cotton Broker Who Backed Stage Shows, Dies
description: Benjamin Adler, a cotton broker known for his accuracy in forecasting price fluctuations of the raw fiber, died Monday at Beth Israel Hospital, He was 84 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.

title: Meyer, Who Also Left G.O.P., Seeks Reid's Seat in Congress
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 26Assemblyman J. Edward Meyer, a former Republican who joined the Democratic party three months ago, said today that he was a candidate for the Congressional seat being vacated by Ogden R. Reid, another former Republican.

title: Kenyon & Eckhardt Names Aide
description: Nadeen Peterson, one of the better known women on the creative side of the agency business, is leaving Lord Geller Federico Peterson, where she has been creative director, to join Kenyon & Eckhardt. She will be director of the K. & E. Creative Workshop, a new unit that will be formed around her and which, as its first assignment, will have the Helena Rubinstein account.

title: COL. P. F. HENNESSEY
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Feb. 26Cal. Parker F. Hennessey, Commissioner bf Public Safety and chief of the State Police for eight years, died yesterday in the Augusta General Hospital. He was 62 years old.

title: FLIGHT CUT CLEARED ON AMERICAN ROUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (Reuters)  American Airlines received approval today from the Civil Aeronautics board on a plan to, suspend certain flights between the United States and the South Pacific pending decision on a proposed exchange of routes with Pan American World Airways.

title: Israeli Labyrinth: Party Politics
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 26 When the Israeli Army finally withdrew from the west bank of the Suez Canal last week, many of the tanks and armored vehicles rattling across the waterway bore painted slogans bidding good riddance to their 129day stay in Egypt. One tank, however, with an eye toward what lay ahead in Israel, advertised: From the wars in Egypt to the war of the Jews. The reference, of course, was to the religiouslegislation issue in the protracted political crisis at home. Dragging on for eight weeks, it has vastly complicated Premier Golda Meir's efforts to form coalition cabinet.

title: People in Sports
description: Mike Andrews is suing Charlie Finley, and Finley was caught by surprise when notified about it yesterday.

title: MERCK IS SEEKING HUBBARD FARMS
description: Merck & Co., Inc., a leading drug manufacturer, announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire Hubbard Farms, Inc., of Walpole, N.H., for 902,000 common shares of Merck. Based on the closing price of Merck yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange of 78, up , the transaction is valued at $70,356,000. Hubbard Farms is involved in poultry genetics and the development and production of broiler and layer breeding stock.

title: Rebozo Switched Cash From Hughes To New Envelopes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Charles G, Rebozo, President Nixon's close friend, changed envelopes containing a $100,000 campaign contribution from Howard Hughes to avoid additional problems for the President's reelection campaign, cording to sworn testimony Mr. Rebozo filed in Federal court here today.

title: Walker Performs 4 Piano Fantasies Spanning the 1800's
description: Donald Walker put together an interesting program at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night, the young pianist's second recital here since his debut two tal here since his debut two years ago. There were four largescale fantasies that, taken together, spanned the 19th century: Beethoven's Sonata quasi una fantasia (Op. 27, No. 1), of 1801; Schumann's Fantasia (Op. 17), 1836; Chopin's Fantaisie (Op. 49), 184041, and Scriabin's Fantasy Sonata, 189297.

title: HEARST KIDNAPPERS ARE SILENT ON OFFER
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26The kidnappers of Patricia Hearst continued to maintain silence today on an offer made to them for a $4million contribution to a free food program in exchange for her release.

title: Estep, McManus, Reid in Net Upsets
description: MIAMI, Feb. 26 (AP)Sixthseeded Patrice Dominguez of France became the first upset victim in the $50,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today when he lost, 64, 60, to Mike Estep of Dallas in the opening round. In other upsets, Jim McManus of Berkeley, Calif., ousted Manual Orantes, the No. 1 Spaniard, 63, 63, and Raz Reid of Greenville, S. C., a qualifier, downed Erik Van Dillen, the Davis Cup player, 62, 46,75.

title: Cavett's Revised Radicals Show Now Set for March 21 by A.B.C.
description: Dick Cavett's company, Daphne Productions, and the American Broadcasting Company have reached a compromise on the program featuring radical leaders of the nineteensixties that the network had refused to put on the air Feb. 7, Its scheduled date. The network's objection to the program, which had been taped the previous day, was primarily that it lacked ideological balance.

title: City Schools Hint Suburbs Are Needed in Integration
description: The central Board of Education said yesterday that despite the city's best efforts its racial integration program was in jeopardy because of the flight of whites from the city. In a report to the State Board of Regents, it declared:

title: Rote Jr. Top Superstar; To Donate Part of Prize
description: ROTONDA, FN., Feb. 26 (AP)Kyle Rote Jr., a 23yearold ministerial student and soccer player, won the annual Superstars' tournament today. For finishing first in the twoday competition, he received the $25,000 top prize. In addition, he won bonus and qualifying money for a total of $53,400.

title: Nixon Erred in Citing Deduction by Wiesner
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26The White House said today that President Nixon regretted naming Jerome B. Wiesner, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, on national television as among those who claimed a tax deduction for papers donated to the National Archives.

title: 3 PAPERS TERMINATE JOINT NEWS SERVICE
description: A consent decree proposing to terminate a joint sales arrangement between news services operated by The New York Times and by The Chicago Daily News and The Chicago SunTimes was approved yesterday by the Department of Justice.

title: 150 Teachers Strike
description: PLAISTON, N.H., Feb. 26 (AP)  About 150 teachers in the Timberlane Regional School District struck today in the final phases of contract neogtiations on mediation and arbitration.

title: Laborites: AntiTory Not ProWilson
description: LONDON, Feb. 26Leslie Bethell a 37yearold lecturer at University College, London, has a Ph.D. in history, spends his summer vacations studying in Brazil and will cast a reluctant vote for the Labor party in the general election Thursday.

title: Krisiloff Aims to Fulfill Boyhood Dream
description: They began practice yesterday for the opening race of the United States Auto Club's Championship Trail without Mike Krisiloff. But they won't get far without the certified public accountant from Parsippany, N. J. Krisiloff will leave in two days to join his son, Steve, one of the upcoming stars of the Indytype racers at Ontario, Calif.

title: PRESIDENT'S VIEW ON IMPEACHMENT DISPUTED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Republicans and Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee challenged today President Nixon's assertion that he could not be impeached except on the bass of evidence that he had violated criminal law.

title: PRILES AT PEAKS FOR GOLD COINS
description: The flight from paper money into precious metals turned into a stampede yesterday on both sides of the Atlantic, sending prices of gold, platinum, silver and baser metals to historic highs again. Perhaps significantly, many traders in the grains and some other basic foodstuffs chose the day to sell out and convert paper profits into currency, causing those commodities to slump.

title: Mrs. Warren Wed To Ottavio Oliveira
description: Mrs. Judith Ericksen Warren was married here last evening to Ottavio Bomfim Oliveira, a journalist. The Rev. John B. MacNab performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: EGYPT HOLDS 26 FROM U.S. BRIEFLY
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 26Twentysix American members of the United Jewish appeal rode Into Egyptian captivity today while on a bus tour of the Suez Canal area. They were freed after 10 hours.

title: French in Phnom Penh a Shrinking Set
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 22It used to be that many of the Frenchmen in this former colony would snub any other foreigner who could not speak their language expertly. Theirs was, by and large, an exclusive Phnom Penh set, whose members begrudged the war not so much for its violence as for its disruption of their charmingly decadent existence.

title: LAW SCHOOL SUIT ON QUOTAS OPENS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26A lawyer for a student twice rejected by the University of Washington Law School told the Supreme Court today that his client would have been admitted with the same academic record if he had been black.

title: From Belle Harbor to Gracie Mansion: Saga of a Long, Rewarding Moving Day
description: Oh, I'm going to have a ball. I'm going to love it, oh, I am, said Mary Beame.

title: ITALY CONVICTS 103 IN BIG GRAFT CASE
description: ROME, Feb. 26The biggest criminal trial ever held in Italy has ended with prison sentences totaling 350 years meted out to 103 elderly defendants found guilty of malfeasance and graft. But none of them will ever go to jail.

title: FASHION TALK
description: New Yorkers got a close look of Christian Dior's longer skirts yesterday and the sky didn't fall in. In fact, some of them rather liked it.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE EMPTY MIRROR, By Janwlllem van de Watering, 145 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $5.95

title: College, School Result
description: BASKETBALL

title: NIXON BARS ROLE AT EXAIDE'S TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26President Nixon refused on constitutional grounds today to appear as a witness at the trial in California of John D. Ehrlichman, his former adviser.

title: Eastern Airtines Net Loss
description: Eastern Airlines reported yesterday a net loss of $4.8million for January. The loss included a $5.4million increase in the carrier's fuel bill over the same month last year. Floyd D. Hall, Eastern's chairman and president, said, while the month's results were clearly unsatisfactory, operational performance and traffic results were better than management's projections.

title: SENATE UNIT BARS RAISE IN CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Setting the stage for a potentially troublesome floor vote in an election year, a divided Senate committee recommended to day that members of Congress forego a proposed pay rise over the next three years while other top Federal officials receive salary increases.

title: CONTROLS REDUCE GASOLINE TIEUPS ON FIRST DAY HERE
description: The lines of motorists waiting to buy gasoline were reported shorter around the city yesterday as drivers with evennumbered license plates became the first to pull up to the pumps under the new, statewide oddeven mandatory allocation system.

title: Nixon Assails Democrats On Education and Health
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26President Nixon, in a surprise move, accused Congressional Democrats today of acting irresponsibly on education legislation and of failing move fast enough on health insurance.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: XEROX DISCLOSES 3% RISE IN PRICES
description: The Xerox Corporation advised its domestic commercial customers by mail yesterday that prices for most of its business products would be increased by an average of 3 per cent. The company also anflounced that for the first time some transportation expenses for copiers, duplicators, and accessories . . . will be borne by customers on equipment installed after April 1.

title: 150 Teachers Strike
description: PLAISTON, N.H., Feb. 26 (AP)  About 150 teachers in the Timberlane Regional School District struck today in the final phases of contract neogtiations on mediation and arbitration.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:
7 POLICEMEN FACING CHARGES IN PASSAIC
description: PATERSON, Feb. 26  The Passaic County Police Director, Kenneth A. Hill, said today her would file Municipal Court complaints and departmental. charges against seven patrolmen for allegedly vandalizing the cars of their superior officers.

title: U.S. Airmen in Europe Alert for Lost Balloonist
description: RAMSTEIN, West Germany, Feb. 26 (UPI)  The United States Air Force said today that it had advised crews flying regular missions to keep their eyes open for a missing American balloonist, Thomas L. Gatch Jr., presumed down at sea.

title: Vote by Senate Asks PhaseOut of 0.P.I.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (Reuters)The Senate voted today to phase out the Overseas Private Investment Corporation as a direct insurer of United States companies abroad over a sixyear period.

title: YALE'S MORY'S LOSES ITS LIQUOR LICENSE
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 27 Mory's, the legendary New Haven restaurant frequented by generations of Yale University students and faculty members, has lost its liquor license in the face of a court challenge by Women's Rights Activists.

title: Women Rebelling In Track
description: Growing discontent with the policies and practices of the Amateur Athletic Union is causing a rebellion in women's track and field.

title: JUDITH BLEGEN SINGS FIRST ADINA AT MET
description: Since the heroine of Donizetti's L'Elisir d'amore is hardly the deepthinking type, some sopranos tend to play her as a flirtatious soubrette, and let it go at that. Judith Blegen, taking her first Adina at the Metro politan Opera on Monday night, added the human qualities of tenderness and warmth to her fetching portrayal, wrapping it all in singing that gained steadily in confidence as the comedy tumbled on.

title: Desks Can Be Just Work SpaceOr a Statement About Life
description: To most people a desk is a box, an anonymous wood or metal box with a hole to hide one's knees for seven hours a day.

title: 2,000 Protesting Fire Fighters Call O'Hagan Policies Perilous
description: City fire fighters demonstrated at City Hall yesterday to protest policies of Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan, that they said were jeopardizing fire protection.

title: Governor Marks 21 + 39 Birthday
description: ALBANY, Feb. 26Governor Wilson, who was 60 years old today, celebrated instead the 21st anniversary of my 39th birthday. He sliced up a cake on his ceremonial glasstopped desk in the Red Room for newsmen, who ate it and engaged in the usual picturetaking banter about slicing up his budget and let them eat cake.

title: Colts Hire Don Doll
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 26 (AP) Don Doll, an experienced assistant coach in the National Football League, was named defensive coordinator and secondary coach for the Balitmore Colts today.

title: Senate Bill Seeks To Halt BuildUp In Indian Ocean
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) Legislation was introduced in the Senate today to ban a proposed $29million upgrading of United States military facilities on the Indian Ocean island of Diego Garcia.

title: A Dream Before the Crunch
description: LONDONNobody in Britain sees the election tomorrow as offering any solution to the country's problems, although few ere yet prepared to discuss it as the last spasm of a dying parliamentary democracy.

title: TAXEXEMPT BONDS SHOW STEADY TONE
description: Bond prices turned mixed yesterday with the taxexempt sector described as steady, while the corporate and Government markets eased.The bulk of the day's activity as far as new offerings were concerned took place in the taxexempt market where several issues were accorded good firstday response.

title: Cultural Aide Named
description: Irving Goldman, head of the Shubert theater and realestate empire, was appointed yesterday as the city's $1aday. Commissioner of Cultural Affairs. Details, Page 29.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Feb. 10 frontpage article Decades of Inaction Brought Energy Gap was an extensive and on the whole; reasonably wellbalanced analysis of hew the energy crisis in this country developed as a result of many years of inadequate (and often nonexistent) governmental policymaking.

title: Nixon Compromise On Minimum Wage Hinted by Brennan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The White House offered today to compromise with Congress on a new minimum wage bill. The offer raised the probability that a higher minimum wage would be enacted within the next several weeks.

title: Sadat, in Postwar Glow, Is Really the Boss Now
description: CAIRO, Feb. 27On Sherif Street in the heart of Cairo's business district a visitor's eye was caught by a book in the display window of a small stationery store.

title: Breitel Urges Appointing Most Judges
description: ALBANY, Feb. 27Charles D. Breitel, the state's Chief Judge, today proposed sweeping changes in the state's court system, including the appointment of all judges of the major trial parts, and the merger of the major courts of first instance with the Supreme Court.

title: WILLIAM LEIDT DIES; EPISCOPAL EDITOR, 73
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Feb. 27 William E. Leidt, director of publications of the executive council of the Episcopal Church, a post he had held from 1939 until his retirement in 1963, died today at the age of 73.

title: HANOI HINTS FOCUS ON ECONOMIC GAINS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb, 28North Vietnam's leaders have begun an ambitious twoyear economic reconstruction and development plan and, at the same time, appear to have decided upon a holding pattern in the South, according to information from Hanoi.

title: Cabinet Quits in Ethiopia As Troop Mutiny Spreads
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Thursday, Feb. 28  A military mutiny in the northern city of Asmara spread yesterday, and the Cabinet of Emperor Haile Selassie resigned under pressure of the mutineers' demands.

title: Nixon Compromise On Minimum Wage Hinted by Brennan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The White House offered today to compromise with Congress on a new minimum wage bill. The offer raised the probability that a higher minimum wage would be enacted within the next several weeks.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED
Music: Miss Farrell's Versatility Shown in Handel
description: How many sopranos can you name in the next halfminute who have sung with even modest success both the last act of Glitterdiimmerung and florid Baroque arias? Not on records, you understand, but live. Eileen Farrell's name would be on any list, and it would be a short one.

title: Red Cross Month
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) President Nixon proclaimed March as Red Cross Month today and urged citizens to join, serve and support the American Red Cross.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Newark Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson told a panel government and business officials that, with innovative planning and cooperation between government, industry and the academic community, the city could become the major transporation center in the northeast. The Mayor also said he had formed a special transportation study panel headed by Harry Wheeler, Newark's Manpower Administratdr. The panel includes representatives from major businesses in the Newark and New York metropolitan area as well as transit officials of railroads, containership companies, airlines and trucking companies.

title: Rally by Stocks Continues, But Advance Rate Slows
description: The stock market stretched its rally phase yesterday, but the rate of advance slowed down. Recently depressed drug issues, along with selected glamours and oils, were among the gainers.

title: Nigeria Finds Roads Pave Way to Progress
description: OKUMITA, Nigeria  We used to walk from here to Calabar to sell the skins of leopards, snakes and crocodiles and the tusks of elephants, Etai Okum remembered this morning, and the trip might take five days or even a week.

title: Three Latin Nations Seen In Accord on Tariffs Bid
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 27 (UPI)  Argentina, Uruguay I and Paraguay could reach an agreement to act as a bloc of beefexporting countries to obtain a relaxation of the tariff barriers imposed by the European Economic Community, sources close to the Uruguayan Foreign Ministry said today.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Witness Testifies No Firearms Were Found at Wounded Knee
description: St. PAUL, Feb. 27A deputy United States marshal testified today that Government derriolidon teams found no firearms when they searched Wounded Knee after, the South Dakota village was surrendered to them by insurgent Indians last year.

title: EHRLICHMAN BARS PLEA BARGAINING WITH PROSECUTOR
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27John D. Ehrlichman, offeredan opportunity to plead guilty to a single Federal charge in exchange for his cooperation with the Watergate special prosecutor, has turned down the proposal.

title: Spain Said to Hold Bishop Who Urged Basque Freedoms
description: MADRID, Thursday, Feb. 28 The Roman Catholic Bishop of Bilbao, the Most Rev. Antonio Anoveros Ataun, was reported early this morning have been detained by the police in his home following call for greater, freedoms for the Basque people that was issued in dozens of Basque churches over the weekend.

title: ROTHKO INTENTION DISPUTED AT TRIAL
description: Did Mark Itothko, the abstract expressionist painter, intend the 800 paintings he left to be sold commercially after his death or disposed of to museums and other selected buyers under circumscribed conditions?

title: 2 Gasoline Concerns Cut Their Supplies in March
description: Gasolinebuying lines were markedly shorter throughout the city yesterday on the second day under the state's mandatory allocation program, but the announcement of reduced supplies of some brands next month caused concern among the dealers affected.

title: Milk Group Asks Return of $100,000. Given Nixon Drive
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 27 (UPI)The chief lawyer for Associated Milk Producers, Inc., the nation's largest dairy cooperative, said in a letter released today that the organization had made a $100,000 illegal contribution to the Committee for the Reelection of the President and wanted the money back.

title: Study of Quake Finds Need To Revise Building Codes
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 27Analyses of recordings made during the 1971 earthquake that took 59 lives in San Fernando, Calif., have shown that the jolts to buildings by such quakes or those of greater magnitude were twice as severe as had been expected when the California buildings codes were drafted.

title: HOUSING POLICEMAN MAKES BIAS CHARGE
description: The State Division of Human Rights has ruled that there is probable cause to believe that the Housing Authority Police Department engaged in an unlawful discriminatory practice in denying a detective a promotion last year.

title: 2 Gasoline Concerns Cut Their Supplies in March

title: Catena Goes Back to Yardville After Just One Day of Freedom
description: YARDVILLE, Feb. 27 (AP)Gerardo Catena, smiling and dressed in a conservative business coat and suit, returned to prison here today less than day after he was released.

title: Rosi Mittermaier Victor In Special Slalom Race
description: ABETONE, Italy, Feb. 27 (AP)Rosi Mittermaier of West Germany won the special slalom race today, the first World Cup event held since the world championship.

title: Citizens Study Panel to Urge Broad CampaignLaw Changes
description: ALBANY, Feb. 27A citizens study panel has agreed to urge a broad campaign reform law that would set up a State Elections Commission with powers to police elections, set tighter spending anti disclosure restrictions on candidates, and permit contributions through tax checkoffs. The panel wants the charges made in time for this year's elections.
