description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Gromyko in Syria Unexpectedly Just After Kissinger Departs
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 27Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, showing new burst of vigor in Soviet Middle East diplomacy in an apparent effort to avoid being upstaged by the United States, flew unexpectedly to Syria today.

title: Assembly Approves CleanNames Bill
description: ALBANY, Feb. 27The Assembly today passed and sent to the Senate a bill prohibiting corporate names that are coarse, indecent or obscene, that ridicule or degrade any individual, group, or government agency or that indicate or imply an unlawful activity.

title: Court Reform Politics
description: When Chief Judge Charles D. Breitel addressed the Legislature yesterday, he accomplished something that even the Chief Justice of the United States, Warren E. Burger, has been unable the legislaable to do: adtive branch on the condition of the courts. That the Legislature granted Judge Breitel's request to speak gave notice that court reform has become a major political issue in the state.

title: $40,000 FINES SET IN 4 SEASONS CASE
description: Glenn R. Miller and Gordon H. McCollum, former officials of the investment banking house of Walston & Co., were each fined $40,000 by a United States District Court Judge here yesterday for stock fraud and conspiracy Involving Four Seasons Nursing Centers of America, Inc.

title: FRANK F. SOULE
description: DEERFIELD BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27Frank F. Soule, who retired in 1957 as vice president and advertising director of Conde Nast Publications, Inc., died yesterday. He was 84 years old.

title: City Gives Shubert Chief A Top Culture Role at $1
description: Irving Goldman, head of the Shubert realestate and theater empire, was appointed yesterday as the city's $1ayear Commissioner of Cultural Affairs.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saying Time

title: The British Election: Who, What and Why
description: The polls will be open rom 7 A.M. to 10 P.M. today throughout BritainEngland, Scotland and. Walesand Northern Ireland.

title: CHANGES IN TENURE AT CITY U. DISCUSSED
description: The Chancellor of the City University, Robert 3. Kibbee, said yesterday that he and staff groups were discussing changes in the tenurequota policy, adopted by the lameduck Board of Higher Education last Oct. 29.

title: House Votes Energy Bill Despite Threat of a Veto
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27The emergency energy bill, fought over in Congress since November, was passed by the House today and sent to President Nixon, who has threatened to veto it.

title: Testing Dtente by Arms Curbs
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Dtente is frayed. The Soviet Union's recent activities in the Middle East give us somewhat less than full assurance that it is a force for peace. The United States goes on worldwide military alert in response to what it considered a Soviet provocation. Talks on mutual and balanced force reductions and on the limitation of strategic arms are on the verge of stalemate. We stand on the brink of another fullfledged arms race.

title: Senate Confirms Holton
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) The Senate today confirmed President Nixon's nomination of former Gov. Linwood Holton of Virginia as Assistant Secretary of State for Congressional relations.

title: The Mayor Goes to Washington to Lobby
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 Mayor Beame met with Congressional leaders today in seeking funds for New York City, and appointed former Representative Emanuel Celler as the unsalaried adviser to the Mayor on Congressional matters.

title: Sifting Past for Space Visitors' Tracks
description: "Chariots of the Gods?" which landed yesterday at 122 theaters in the metropolitan area, is, as its title implies, questionable fare. This film version of the theories advanced by Erich Von Daniken, the 38-year-old former Swiss hotel employe, in three successful books on the possibilities of extra-terrestrial visitors to Earth eons ago, simply evolves as a placid, postcard picturesque but unconvincing travelogue that sometimes captivates the eye but rarely the mind.The author, as well as the German producers who shot the film in 1971 (excerpts were shown on television more than a year ago), must be credited with moving about the remote areas of the globe to illustrate their clues to mysteries surrounding enigmas. The trip touches down at, among other points, Egypt's pyramids, Mayan temples, Incan cities, Baghdad, Japan and various Biblical sites, without really solving those enigmas.Wasn't it possible, the narrators ask, that the 14th-century frescoes in a Yugoslavian monastery showing what seem to be astronauts and space ships suggest visits from super-intelligent beings from outer space long ago? And what about the possibilities of other-world visitors to our planet in the dim, unrecorded past who could have left the know-how to build the scientifically precise pyramids or formulate the Mayan calendar, construct Incan cities, carve colossal statues on faraway Easter Island and Iay out what seem to be air-landing strips in remote Peruvian plains that pre-date history?Unfortunately, until science verifies the author's and the film's assumptions and findings, "Chariots of the Gods?" merely rolls through a succession of pleasantly exotic places while posing a slew of unanswered questions.

title: Scientist Fears Wide Food Shortage
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 27Dr. J. George Harrar, president emeritus of the Rockefeller Foundation, told a national conference of scientists here today that present levels of technology and natural resources will be unable to feed the expected world population of the future.

title: Calley Free on $1,000 Bond Bx Order of Civilian Judge
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Feb. 27Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., convicted by a military court of the murder in 1968 of at least 22 Vietnamese civilians at My Ltd in South Vietnam, was released today on personal bond of $1,000 by order of a civilian judge.

title: Paper Asks Impeachment
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 (UPI)  The Philadelphia Daily News, maintaining that the only logical last step has been avoided for too long already, called in an editorial today for the impeachment of President Nixon. The newspaper supported Senator George S. McGovern, Democrat, in the 1972 Presidential race.

title: Suit Filed in Turnpike Chain Crashes
description: HACKENSACK, Feb. 27The first of what is expected to be a series of suits growing out of a chain of accidents last Oct. 23 that killed nine persons and injured 40 others has been filed in Superior Court here against the New Jersey Turnpike Authority.

title: $1 Checkoff Pushed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) Ten Senators joined today in a series of Senate speeches urging income taxpayers to use the dollar checkoff on their tax forms. By checking a box on the Federal income tax form, each taxpayer may direct that $1 of his tax payment be placed in a fund for equal allocation to major political parties to finance the 1976 Presidential election campaign.

title: Dj Vu in Alabama
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala. The case of the United States of America v. Dr. Virgil B. Chrane might be comical if the consequences were not so serious the consequences being the loss of his livelihood and probably his liberty as well.

title: Squibb Approves 21 Split
description: A 2for1 stock split was authorized yesterday by the board of the Squibb Corporation to become effective May 20 if approved by shareholders. The board will consider at its May 7 meeting an increase of about 4 per cent in the dividend rate on its common stock for the second quarter. This would be 42 cents a share on the present stock and 21 cents a share on the split shares.

title: Sadat, in Postwar Glow, Is Really the Boss Now
description: CAIRO, Feb. 27On Sherif Street in the heart of Cairo's business district a visitor's eye was caught by a book in the display window of a small stationery store.

title: The Past and Future Of a Maori Soprano
description: If all had gone as the Metropilitan Opera and Kiri Te Kanawa planned it, the 28yearold soprano from New Zealand would still be anticipating her Met debut as Desdemona in the performance of Verdi's Otello to be given next Thursday.

title: Celtic Bows in Soccer
description: BASEL, Switzerland, Feb. 27 (UPI)  F. C. Basel defeated the Scottish League champion, Celtic Glasgow, 32, in their European Champions Cup first leg quarterfinal soccer match today. The other quarterfinals will be played next Wednesday.

title: Land Use Bill Knifed
description: Not for years has the House Rules Committee done anything as highhanded as its sudden and completely unexpected knifing of major legislation calling for land use planning. After years of consideration and study, a bill to this purpose was passed by the Senate last June by a vote of 64 to 21. The House Committee on the Interior recently approved it, 26 to 11, and urged its early consideration. The Administration had originally promoted it as a high priority issue, as indeed it is; governors had pressed for it and conservationists from one end of the country to the other had called for its enactment.

title: Little League Loses Effort To Delay Admitting of Girls
description: TRENTON, Feb. 27 (AP)  A State appeals court has turned ??own a request by the Lime League to stay an order issued earlier this month by the Division on Civil Rights that would require the Little League to al??ow girls to join its program in New Jersey.

title: Canada's Gross Product Rose 7.1% in Year
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 27 (AP) Canada's real gross national product advanced 7.1 per cent in 1973, indicating the strong expansion of the Canadian economy under way since the beginning of 1971 continued through last year at an accelerated pace, Statistics Canada said today.

title: F. C. C. Bars Delay In New Access Rule On PrimeTime TV
description: By a 50 vote, the Federal Communications Commission yesterday refused to delay the effective date of the revised primetime access rule to September, 1975, denying the appeal of an organization of independent television producers.

title: John Koerner, Marbleizer; Did Work at White House
description: YONKERS, Feb. 27  John (Hans) Koerner, who spent more than 50 years as a marbleizer grainer and mural painter, died today at St. John's Hospital. His age was 83 and he lived here.

title: A JURY IS SELECTED IN THE GROSS CASE
description: NEWARK, Feb. 27 (UPI)Following hours of outofcourt questioning about the possible effect of pretrial publicity, seven men and five women were sworn as jurors today in the conspiracy trial of the for mer Republican state chairman, Nelson G. Gross.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today a bill establishing conditions under which the death penalty could be imposed for certain serious Federal crimes.

title: In Hearsts' Home Town, the Mansions Are Shuttered
description: HILLSBOROUGH, Calif., Feb. 27Suddenly, the privacy is gone. The streets are filled with cars, television cameramen cruise the neighborhood, and reporters and sightseers are everywhere. It has been a painful experience for this town that had always been so careful in protecting its anonymity. It had kept out every business. It had never permitted sidewalks, only private driveways. It had not even allowed its name used on a directional marker at the nearby freeway.

title: French Cabinet Quits for Realignment
description: PARIS, Feb. 27  Premier Pierre Messmer and his Cabinet resigned today, and President Pompidou promptly reappointed him to form a new and streamlined one.

description: Irving Goldman, head of the Shubert theater and realestate empire, was appointed yesterday as the city's $1aday Commissioner of Cultural Affairs. Details, Page 29.

description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va.Meeting James Mulligan, you might think at first that his life fell into a standard American pattern. He is a naval officer in midcareer, a captain who lives here in a nice suburban house and goes to business school, a thoughtful man with a muscular build.

Emcee (Willkommen) of Cabaret, is working this week and next at the Empire Room of the WaldorfAstoria, Park Avenue and 50th Street (3553000). He's an attractive songanddance man, and his lithe frame and expressive eyes move every moment during this hourlong, happy and lively interlude, during which lie holds the stage while the Bob Rosengarden Orchestra makes the music (and plays also for dancing between shows).

description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., announced yesterday a temporary shutdown, of methanol production at its plant in Beaumont, Tex., as a result of a fire last Saturday. The faculty is one of the world's largest methanol plants with capacity of about 200 million gallons ai year.

The committee will study the problems of the arts here and make recommendations to him about what the city can do about solving them.

title: TAFT MARDIROSSIAN
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 27Taft Mardirossian, a consulting engineer who had worked on the Air Force Academy in Colo?ado Springs, the Socony Mobil Building in New York and the Prudential Center in Boston, among other structures, died Monday in St. Agnes Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 12 Maplemoor Lane.

title: Douglas DC3 Plant to Close
description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, Calif., Feb. 27 (UPI)  The Santa Monica, Calif., plant of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, birthplace of the famous DC3 that became a military and civilian workhouse in World War II, will be closed July 1, 1975. The company announced yesterday that the 124acre site would be phased out in the interest of greater efficiency and economy to meet the demands mends of the highly competitive aerospace environment.

description: Dorotea Elman is a tall, reedslender and handsome Cariocan, a Yale graduate, mother and graphic designer.

description: ACROSS

title: DeButts of A.T.&T. Expresses Guarded Optimism
description: Guarded optimism about the economic outlook for 1974 was expressed yesterday by John D. deButts, chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the world's largest business enterprise.

description: Eddie Belmonte, one of the nation's top jockeys, was freed In $1,500 bail yesterday following his arrest for allegedly shooting his wife, Debra, in a family argument at home in Garden City, L. I.

title: 45 Years on Ethiopian Throne Haile Selassie
description: He built a railroad and opened factories to process food, make clothing and manufacture construction materials. He has even begun plans for building his country's first earth  satellite communications station. But under Emperor Haile Selassie I, ruler of Ethiopia for almost half a century, these changes in the economic condition of his feudal northeast African nation did not happen overnight, Nor, in his view, should they have.

title: JAILS CHIEF BACKS BEHAVIOR SYSTEM
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27The director of the Federal prison system told a Congressional subcommittee today that behavior modification was an integral part of many prison programs and that it would continue to be used on inmates whenever appropriate.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP)Legislation setting up a commission to regulate the nation's $500billion a year commodities exchange business was tentatively approved today by the. House Agriculture Committee by a 16to2 vote. Representatives Steven D. Symms, Republican of Idaho, and Edward Young, Republican of South Caroline, dissented. Final formal approval by the committee is expected soon, sending the legislation to the full House for action.

title: Cabinet Quits in Ethiopia As Troop Mutiny Spreads
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Thursday, Feb. 28A military mutiny in the northern city of Asmara spread yesterday, and the Cabinet of Emperor Haile Selassie resigned under pressure of the mutineers' demands.

title: Soviet Steps Up Criticism of U.S. Base
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 27The Soviet press, which has mounted a major campaign against American plans to expand naval facilities on the island of Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean, charged today that this step would sharpen the threat to the independence of countries in the region,

title: Film:It's Murder With Too Few Suspects:The Cast
description: Murderous mysteries can't and shouldn't conform to recipes. But the omission of certain staples may frustrate us. Suspects are rather like saltyou need enough to season the whole stew, to enliven the range of the ingredients. Frank Perry's "Man on a Swing," which opened yesterday at Loews State and Loews Tower East, lacks momentum because it's scant on potential killers. Out of sheer desperation, I even tried to suspect the righteous police chief (Cliff Robertson, nicely baffled)an exercise that wasn't fair to either of us.A young woman is killed, and the police are perplexedto the extent of waxing sentimental about the murderer. The chief, who never met her, carries her picture in his wallet; there's lyrical music whenever she appears in a smiling flashback. It's stressed that she was "full of life" and fond of swimming, and she looks much prettier than most after strangulation.Amid this bath of pathos, Joel Grey appears as a clairvoyant who's eager to help the police. He knows so much that he must be the killer. But maybe he isn't. And perhaps he's not a true seer. Still, as the plot disintegrates like an old shower curtain, it's a pleasure to watch Mr. Grey at work. That fragile ability, the savage changes of mood, the quietly ecstatic smile on the lemur's face, the thrashing body that relives the murder, his bright calm confidence in his giftall yield a fine performance. Sinister and timid by turns, assertive or uncertain, he gives the movie an energy that isn't in the script.George Voskovec is deftly shrewd as an expert on extrasensory perception and Elizabeth Wilson, as a psychiatrist, can convey more professional aplomb with an "Ah?" or a "Mmm" or the snap of her handbag than many of the garrulous movie-shrinks of the past. But Dorothy Tristan has a thankless role as the police chief's pregnant wife.All in all, Frank Perry's cast is superior to his material. We're told that "Man on a Swing" was based on a real case. But that's not gripping, since this is a conventionally made picture. The soundtrack is overworked, to put it kindly: spurts of guttural music or throbbing tremolos insist that a key turning in a lock or a ringing phone or a knock on a door are important. (Often, they're not.) And the dud ending is rather insulting. Why be faithful to facts that we don't know, especially since all of the characters are disguised? Invention and distortion and imaginationbad reporting, if you likecould have made a better movie. A thriller, in fact.

title: First Banc Group Set to Acquire First National Bank of Toledo
description: The First Banc Group of Ohio, Inc., a bank holding company, announced yesterday it had reached a preliminary agreement to acquire the First National Bank of Toledo for stock valued at more than $32million. The holding company said the agreement called a for it to exchange 1.905 of its shares for each share of First National Bank of Toledo.

title: Fiasco on Rents
description: The demagogic decision of the City Council last June to gain political popularity by killing the computerized formula for establishing fair rents in 1.2 million rentcontrolled apartments in this city has now boomeranged in a way that threatens double trouble for tenants.

title: Court Rules Union Can't Waive Right To Pass Leaflets
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27The Supreme Court ruled today in a 6to3 vote that a union cannot bargain away the right of its members to distribute labor literature during off hours at their place of work, even if their contract forbids it.

title: Elks Lose Tax Exemption Because of Racial Policy
description: TRENTON, Feb. 27  A State Superior Court judge has ordered the Bergen County community of Rutherford to end the propertytax exemption of the local lodge of the Benevolent and Protective Order of the Elks on the ground that while the lodge was free to discriminate against blacks, could not do so at public expense.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: FRANKLIN LAKES, Feb. 27When the basketball season ends next month for Ramapo High School, at least one team member, highscoring forward Bob Kleinert, knows precisely where he'll be heading: onto the tennis Court to resume his spot as No. 1 singles player on the top high school squad in the state.

title: NATO PARLEY SET ON CONSULTATIONS
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 27High Foreign Ministry officials from the 15 Atlantic allies are expected to meet here March 13 in an effort to improve the alliance consultation system, which was severely strained by the October war in the Middle East.

title: Small Ski Resorts Hurt By Lack of Snowmakers
description: JAY, N. Y., Feb. 27Operators of most of the smaller ski centers in this Adirondack country have suffered through an unusually poor year in liftticket sales. One of the reasons, of course, is that none of them is equipped with artificial snow machines. Of course, I know that ski resorts in the Adirondacks are not the only ones with lots of red ink in their books, said George Winter, proprietor of the local Paleface Ski Center. But I'm not discouraged. After all I didn't go into this business expecting to get rich right away.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1974

title: Hays Opposes Public Subsidies for House and Senate Campaigns in Election Reform Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27Representative Wayne L. Hays, Democrat of Ohio, a key figure in the Congressional debate over campaign financing reforms, said today that he opposed public subsidy of House and Senate campaigns.

title: Business Pose by U.S. Spies Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27A high United States official said today that more than 200 American intelligence agents were stationed abroad posing as businessmen.

title: Fireman Wins Right to Sell City His invention, a LifeSaving Tool
description: A City darter provision forbidding business dealings, between the city and its employes was bent yesterday when the Board of Ethics ruled that a city fire fighter could sell an unusual lifesaving device to the Fire Department.

title: KRIEGEL DROPS BID FOR A BOOK GRANT
description: Jay L. Kriegel, one of the closest aides to former Mayor John V. Lindsay, withdrew his application yesterday for a $25,000 grant to prepare a history of the Lindsay years.

title: A Fugitive in Gallo Case Surrenders
description: Joseph Yacovelli, the reputed Mafia leader who was sought for questioning in connection with the murder of Joseph Gallo, surrendered yesterday after having spent two years in hiding.

title: Supernomad
description: The most immediate danger as Secretary Kissinger undertakes another of his shuttle services to the capitals. Of the Middle East is that of exaggerated expectations.

title: U.S. Assails Bill to Let S.E.C. Restrict Trading to Exchanges
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27The Justice Department told a Senate antimonopoly panel today, that legislation giving the Securities and Exchange Commission even temporary and discretionary power to restrict trading in listed stocks to the floors of national exchanges was against the public interest.

title: Sellers Predominant
description: The price of almost every commodity traded for future delivery slumped yesterday, often by the daily permissible limit, after weeks of unprecedented advances.

title: 2 TEACHER GROUPS HALT MERGER TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) The National Education Associdtion broke off merger talks tonight with the nation's other major teachers' union, the American Federation of Teachers, the association announced.

title: Eric Leyton, 58, Engineer At Sarnoff Research Center
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 27Eric M. Leyton, a staff engineer at the David Sarnoff Research Center here, died yesterday in Geneva while attending the International Radio Consultive Committee meeting at the request of the State Department. He was 58 years old and lived here.

title: Emerson Loses To Newcombe
description: LA COSTA, Calif., Feb. 27 (AP)Topseeded John Newcombe needed only 57 minutes to subdue a fellow Australian, Roy Emerson, 62, 6.1, today in the second round of the $50,000 World Championship Tennis tournament.

title: Copper Terms Sought
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation and the Anaconda Company have reiterated their desire to come to terms with Chile on compensation for expropriated copper holdings. Page 55.

title: Bridge: TeenAge Players Make Marks In Metropolitan Area Events
description: Perhaps more than ever before teenage players are making their mark in tournaments here, as evidenced by the Grand National Knockouts last weekend for which three young experts were qualified.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: 633d Soviet Craft Orbited
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 27 (AP)The Soviet Union launched into orbit today the 633d unmanned earth satellite in a secret series, the Soviets press agency Tass reported it said that the satellite had been shot into an elliptical orbit 174 miles by 321 miles and that the first revolution had lasted 92.2 minutes.

title: Project Gasifies Coal in Ground
description: HANNA, Wyo., Feb. 27Poking through the snows of the vast, windy landscape just south of here are a few dials, valves and pipes. These, along with an assemblage of trailers and compressors, are the modest signs of a renewed Government effort to make underground gasification of coal an economic process.

title: Fugitive in the Gallo Case Surrenders
description: Joseph Yacovelli, the reputed Mafia leader who was sought for questioning in connection with the murder of Joseph Gallo, surrendered yesterday idler having spent two years in hiding.

title: Times Declares Dividend
description: Directors of The New York Times Company declared yesterday a 15centpershare qua?? terly dividend on the Class ?? ??nd Class B common stock, pa?? able March 26 to shareholder of record March 15. The regula?? quarterly dividend of 1.37 ?? share on the 5 per ce?? cumulative prior prefereno stock was also voted for pay ment April 1 to shareholders o?? record March 15. Stockholder of record March 15 will be au?? thorized to vote at the company's annual meeting acheduled for April 23 at the Bil?? more Hotel.

title: STATE WELCOMES TIDELANDS RULING
description: TRENTON, Feb. 27  The State Attorney General's office and the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission lauded today a state Superior Court ruling that will enable the State Attorney General to settle hundreds of tidelands disputes without waiting for the completion of the state's vast and scientifically sophisticated mapping program for determining its riparian rights.

title: Japanese Executives Scolded About Oil
description: TOKYO, Feb. 27For the last three days, a score of prominent Japanese company presidents have been sitting in the national Legislature like chastened schoolboys while legislators tonguelashed them for alleged business abuses arising from the oil crisis.

title: Santiago Rides Special Legend, $38.20, To 1Length Victory in the Rosetown
description: An hour before the main race at Aqueduct yesterday, Angel Santiago was bemoaning having finished second four times in the earlier races on the card. When told that second wasn't too bad, the young Panamanian shook his head vigorously and said, No, I think only about winning.

title: LILCO BID FOR RAISE ROUNDLY ASSAILED
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 27Such terms as unmitigated gall, irresponsible, unconscionable and unbelievable were applauded by more than 300 customers here today as the, Long Island Lighting Company's request for a $58million annual increase in electric rates was denounced at a Public Service Commission hearing.

title: People in Sports
description: Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds, the most valuable player in the National League last season, signed his 1974 contract yesterday for a reported $160,000. Now, quipped Rose, I can pay that $250 fine I received during last year's playoffs. He was fined for a scuffle with Bud Harrelson of the Mets at second base in a game at Shea Stadium.

title: Pilot's License Revoked
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) The Army private who stole a helicopter Feb. 17 and led police on an aerial chase ending on the White House lawn has lost his pilot's license. The Federal Aviation Administration yesterday revoked the civil private pilot certificate held by Pfc. Robert K. Preston, 20 years old.

title: Contract Awards
description: WheelabiratorFrye Inc., has received a $55million order for air pollution control equipment from the American Electric Power System, the two companies announced here yesterday. The contract covers three electrostatic precipitator systems for three new coalburning generating units that A.E.P. will build on the Ohio Riverone at New Haven, W. Va. and two at sites to be selected.

title: Solzhenitsyn's Wife Says Soviet Requires a Month to Approve Export of Books
description: MOSCOW, Feb 27 (UPI) Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's wife said today that Soviet authorities had told her at least a month was needed to approve export of his personal library. She said she would not leave without the books.

title: Another Cent to Be Added in 7 to 10 Days
description: American motorists, already paying record prices for gasoline, will pay 2 cents more a gallon at the pump tomorrow and another cent within the next week or 10 days.

title: Manhattan Is Defeated In Overtime
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Feb. 27 (AP)Warren Baker scored a season  high 31 points tonight to lead West Virginia to a 101100 doubleovertime college basketball victory over Manhattan.

title: ANNE VANDERBILT, SOCIETY FIGURE, 65
description: Mrs. Anne Colby Vanderbilt, who was First Lady of Rhode Island in 1939.40 during the Governship of William H. Vanderbilt, then her husband, died yesterday after a stroke at her home, 755 Park Avenue. She was 65 years old.

title: Energy Office Eases Rules In Bid to Spur Oil Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 27 (AP)The Federal Energy Office acknowledged today serious deficiencies in its crude oil allocation program and announced several major changes intended to increase oil imports into the United States.

title: YALE CLUB STOIC ON DIRTY KITCHEN
description: Whitney Travis, the manager of the Yale Club, sighed a stoic sigh and addressed himself to question about the Health Department's report yesterday that it had found mouse excreta in the club's restaurant kitchen.

title: Chess: Positional Sacrifices Offer A Wealth of Possibilities
description: The object of a positional sacrifice is the eventual recovery of the material given up with a concomitant improvement of the position. The most elementary case occurs in the ending with White king on Q5, pawns on QB5 and QN5, Black king on Q2, pawn on QB2. The one and only way to achieve a draw for Black is to cripple the White pawns by means of 1 ... PB3chl; 2 PxPch, KB2.

title: Chess: Positional, Sacrifices Offer
description: The object of a positional sacrifice is the, eventual recovery of the material given up with a concomitant improvement of the position. The most elementary case occurs in the ending with White king on Q5, pawns on QB5 and QN5, Black king on Q2, pawn on QB2. The one and only way to achieve a draw for Black is to cripple the White pawns by means of 1 ... PB3ch!; 2 PxPch, KB2.

title: Consumer Notes
description: What with higher rates for electricity and gas, and fuelcost adjustments, some consumers, looking more closely at their utility bills, have questioned the estimated bills, which are compiled without meter readings.

title: Democrats Given Edge in Ohio House Race
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 27Only three times in this centuryin 1912, 1936 and 1964have the conservative voters of Ohio's First Congressional District sent a Democrat to Congress, Next Tuesday, in the View of local politicians, there Is a good chance they will do so again.

title: KISSINGER BRINGS MRS. MEIR A LIST OF P.O.W.'S IN SYRIA
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 27  Secretary of State Kissinger brought Israel today a list ofprisoners held by Syria since the war last October. In response, Israel agreed to hold talks with the Syrians aimed at separating their forces on the Golan Heights front.

title: KISSINGER BRINGS MRS. MEIR A LIST OF P.O.W.'S IN SYRIA
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 27  Secretary of State Kissinger brought Israel today a list prisoners held by Syria since the war last October. In respouse, Israel agreed to hold, talks with the Syrians aimed at separating their forces on the Golan Heights front.

title: CAPTIONS FOR DEAF TO BE SHOWN ON TV
description: The first test of a new system through which captions can be made to appear on the television screen for viewers with defective hearing will be conducted next month on Public Broadcasting Service affiliates in 12 cities, including WNYCTV, Channel 31, in New York.

title: Homes Razed as U.S. Evicts Tocks I. Squatters
description: SHAWNEE, Pa., Feb. 27Armed with pistols and carrying gas canisters, 90 Federal marshals in blue jump suits evicted 65 squatters from Federal property here, today in an unannounced raid that took place shortly after dawn.

title: Biathlon Title to Finn
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 27 (Reuters)Juhani Suutarinen of Finland, scoring five straight bullseyes at his last firing session, won the world biathIon title at Raubichi, near Minsk, today. He took the 20kilometer ski race in 1 hour 12 minutes 4.74 seconds.

title: $200,000 IN COINS HIJACKED IN QUEENS
description: A van transporting an estimated $200,000 in coins to a Manhattan coin exchange was hijacked on the Long Island Expressway in Long Island City, Queens, last evening.

title: Dance: Atypical, Louis
description: The Murray Louis Dance Company, which now has only a very few performlances left at the Lyceum Theater, is one of the most interesting of the major moderndance troupes. It very skillfully combines nonliteral dramaa kind of dramatic accent  with choreography that, unlike most American moderndance choreography, owes a debt to the German school of Mary Wigman.

title: Percy Would Give Tax Data
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI)  Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, said to day that if he seeks the 1976 Republican Presidential nomination he will release all his personal income tax figures for the years he has held public office.

title: Sadat Is Ready to Accept Guerrillas in Rome Attack
description: CAIRO, Feb. 27 (AP)President Anwar elSadat has agreed to allow five Palestinian guerrillas accused of an attack on a Pan American World Airways jetliner at the Rome airport last December to come to Cairo from Kuwait, the semiofficial newspaper Al Ahram reported today.

title: Nixon to Visit Chicago For a Speech March 15
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP)President Nixon will address an executives organization in Chicago on March 15, the White House announced today.

title: Pilot's License Revoked
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) The Army private who stole a helicopter Feb. 17 and led Pplice on an aerial chase ending on the White House lawn has lost his pilot's license. The Federal Aviation Administration yesterday revoked the civil private pilot certificate held by Pfc. Robert K. Preston, 20 years old.

title: ANTHONY MORATTO SR.
description: Anthony D. Moratto Sr., who founded the Police Athletic League's drum and bugle corps in the midnineteenfifties, died Monday evening, apparently of a heart attack, in his Brooklyn home. He was 80 years old.

title: Japanese Executives Scolded About Oil
description: TOKYO, Feb. 27For the last three days, a score of prominent Japanese company presidents have been sitting in the national Legislature like chastened schoolboys while legislators tonguelashed them for alleged business abuses arising from the oil crisis.

description: The Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies announced yesterday the appointment of Harlan Cleveland, Francis Keppel and Walter Orr Roberts as pro. gram directors for three of the institute's longrange study and research projects.

title: Index Up Sharply in January, Off for December
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Erratic movements in a Government index issued today underlined the confusion over the economic outlook.

title: Philip Morris Sets Split
description: The directors of Philip Morris, Inc., yesterday declared 2for1 split in the common stock, to be distributed in the form of a 100 per cent stock dividend on May 31 to holders of record April 25. The board intends to increase the quarterly dividend to 40 cents a share on the split shares from the present 35cent rate, commencing with the July dividend.

title: U.S. Opposes Detroit Integration Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The Nixon Administration asked the Supreme Court today to reject a desegregation plan for Detroit that would combine the largely black city schools with heavily white suburbs in a single metropolitan district.

title: Personal Finance: Joint Bank Account
description: Many married couples and family members like the idea of joint bank accounts. In case of sickness or accident, a joint account can provide ready access to money for the alternate owner.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: Notes on People
description: Mayor Peter Flaherty of Pittsburgh, a popular party maverick, said yesterday he would be a candidate for the Democratic nomination for the Senate seat now held by Richard S. Schwelker, a Republican. Mr. Flaherty said he would run as an independent, and was not interested in his party's endorsement.

title: 2 Australian Aides Held at Gunpoint By an Aboriginal
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Thursday, Feb. 28 (Reuters)An Australian aboriginal held two Government officials at gunpoint today in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

title: State Reports Serious Lapses In Felony Drug Case in Queens
description: The chairman of the State Select Committee on Crime said yesterday an investigation of 24 felony narcotics cases in Queens had found serious lapses in the sentencing process in State Supreme Court.

title: House Votes Energy Bill Despite Threat of a Veto
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27The emergency energy bill, fought over in Congress since November, was passed by the House today and sent to President Nixon, who has threatened to veto it.

title: MRS. MEIR IS GIVEN DELAY ON CABINET
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 27Premie Golda Meir today obtained an other postponement of the deadline for presenting a new cabinet to President ?? Katzir.

title: Trudeau Proposes Economic Program
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 27Prime Minisier Pierre Elliott Trudeau's minority Government, pressed by a hungry opposition eager to take advantage of soaring inflation find abrasive sectional dissatisfactions with the Ottawa administration, outlined a broad longrange program of economic and social legislation today.

title: MRS. JACOB HOLTZMANN
description: Mrs. Lillian Plotz Holtzmann, the widow of Jacob L. Holtzmann, a former member of the New York State Board of Regents and a wellknown lawyer who died in 1963, died on Tuesday in Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 75 years old and lived in the Stanhope Hotel, Fifth Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Osaka Judge Awards Sums Jo Residents Near Airport
description: OSAKA, Japan, Feb. 27 (AP)  A district judge today panned flights at Osaka International Airport between 10 P.M. and 7 A.M. because of the noise and ordered the Government to compensate 264 persons living near the field.

title: HOMER F. GLOVER
description: ROSWELL, N. M., Feb. 27Homer F. Glover, who started the Glover Packing Company in 1941 and built it into a national beef and pork distribution company with plants in several states, died Monday. He would have been 66 years old today.

title: 3 Arabs Are Freed on Bail After Conviction in Rome
description: ROME, Feb. 27A Rome court today sentenced three Arabs to prison terms of five years and two months for terrorist activities, and then freed them on bail. The three also were fined $2,500 each.

title: Things Old and New Enliven an Evening At Clarion Concert
description: Newell Jenkins and his Clarion Concerts Orchestra rummaged more or less successfully through some 17thcentury and 18thcentury music in Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night. They came up with some known quantities: Corelli's Concerto Grosso in D (Op. 6, No. 4), with its poignant slow movement, and Mozart's Piano Concerto in B flat (K. 450).

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: BAINBRIDGE, Ga.  A warm wind moaned in the tall pines, rain threatened but never came, quail were plentiful, and the world seemed new.

title: A JUSTICE STUDY ASSAYS INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 A Justice Department study of the impeachment process says there is no precedent for a President to withhold information under a claim of executive privilege and warns of a constitutional confrontation of the highest magnitude if President Nixon does so.

title: Swedish Parliament Passes Charter Downgrading King
description: STOCKHOLM, Feb, 27 (Reuters)The Swedish Parliament today overwhelmingly approved a new Constitution downgrading the monarchy and making King Carl XVI Gustaf a ceremonial figurehead.

title: Panel Acts to Raise Tax On Oil Operations Abroad
description: WASHINGTON Feb. 27The House Ways and Means Committee tentatively approved today some changes in the tax laws that would add about $500million annually to the taxes paid to the Government by American corporation$ mainly oil companies that have operations in foreign countries.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Market Place: 2 Coast Views
description: Part of the Los Angelesbased Shareholders Management Company's investment team was in town yesterday, and its members were optimistic that the fiveyear bear market would end soon.

title: LINCOLN NATIONAL SHOWS PROFIT DIP
description: The Lincoln National Corporations a holding company for the Lincoln National Life Insurance Company and seven other life insurance companies, reported yesterday higher net income for last year although the fourthquarter net was down somewhat because of a loss on investments.

title: Gold Frenzy
description: Only four years ago the freemarket price of gold was as low as $34.75 an ouncebelow the then official price of $35. But accelerating world inflation, the loss of confidence in national currencies and the tremendous boom in world commodity prices have now caused gold to soar to heights almost beyond the dreams of avarice. Yesterday the gold price in the London market opened at $178before falling back to close at $174.

title: Marjorie Barkentin, Adaptor Of Ulysses in Nighttown, Dead
description: Marjorie Barkentin, who wrote the dramatization of Ulysses in Nighttwn, from James Joyce's Ulysses, died yesterday at her home, 16 West 16th Street. She was about 83 years old.

title: SALE RESTRICTIONS A BURDEN TO SOME
description: Motorist as disparate as physicians and nonmedallionor gypsycab drivers, who have had the usual problems getting gasoline, face an even more uncertain future because of the, state mandatory restrictions.

title: Obstruction of Justice
description: The President has decided not to comply with our outstanding requests for recordings for the grand jury investigations of the Watergate breakin and coverup and certain dairy industry contributions, asserting that to do so would be inconsistent with the public interest and the constitutional integrity of the office of the Presidency.... The President has refused to reconsider this earlier decision to terminate his cooperation with this investigation.

title: Copper Concerns Deny Chile Expropriation Accord
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation and the Anaconda Company reiterated their desire yesterday to come to terms with Chile on compensation for their expropriated copper holdings. However, they denied strongly that an agreement was near.

title: Film: Breathing Life Into Cops and Robbers Style:'Busting' Stars Elliott Gould as Detective Hyams's Production Opens at 2 Theaters
description: Peter Hyams's "Busting" is this week's new cop film and a good one for a change. It's not great but it's a cool, intelligent variation on a kind of movie that by this time can be most easily identified by the license numbers on the cars in its chase sequences. The film opened yesterday at the Cinerama and RKO 86th Street Twin 2 Theaters."Busting" is about a Mutt and Jeff team of Los Angeles vice-squad detectives. Keneely (Elliott Gould), the tall one, chews bubble gum, walks slightly stooped and talks in the manner of someone modeling himself on the hero of an Elliott Gould movie. Farrel (Robert Blake) walks like a man who wants to be tall and knows he never will be. It doesn't worry him but it makes him a little tougher than most other guys.Keneely and Farrel live entirely in their work. They spend most of their time arresting people who are more of an emotional than a physical threat to society: call girls, massage-parlor employes and the clientele of homosexual bars. Keneely and Farrel feel no obsessive sense of mission. It's just what they do to keep traffic moving, like street cleaners.It is one of the ironies of "Busting" that when the two detectives do get involved in their work, when they decide to go after the Mr. Big responsible for the large Los Angeles multi-million-dollar rackets as well as the petty ones, they get clobbered, both by the hoods and by their Police Department superiors who might, I suppose, represent the attitudes of the society whose servants they are.Mr. Hyams, who wrote and directed "Busting," brings off something of a feat by making a contemporary cop film that is tough without exploiting the sort of right-wing cynicism that tells us all to go out and buy our own guns.It is also comparatively humane. That is, it acknowledges that when cops and robbers are shooting it out in public places, the bystanders often get hurt. When Keneely and Farrel pursue some heroin pushers through a late-night market in a running gunfight, the movie communicates the terror of the onlookers as much as it does the suspense of the pursuit. It is this level of awareness that separates "Busting" from the kind of junk peddled by most of the other current cop movies."Busting" is the first theatrical film to be directed by Mr. Hyams, though he has directed films for television and wrote the screenplay for "T.R. Baskin," a movie that never stopped talking. The screenplay for "Busting" is a huge improvement, but it's Mr. Hyams's talent as a director that is most apparent in the visual emphases and in the performances.I suspect that the personalities of Mr. Gould and Mr. Blake, rather than the screenplay, are responsible for the definition given the roles of Keneely and Farrel. They try a little too hard for eccentricity but they're successful at creating identifiable characters.So, too, is Allen Garfield, who plays the Mr. Big as fat, edgy family man who simply can't keep up with the hip talk of the two cops who have set out to ridicule him to justice. Every verbal duel results in his losing a small bit of finger or the tip of an ear lobe. Nothing vital, but you know that more than anything else he resents his squareness."Busting" hardly overturns any film traditions, but it gives a little life to an exhausted genre.

title: Calley Free on $1,000 Bond By Order of Civilian Judge
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Feb. 27Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., convicted by a military court of the murder in 1968 of at least 22 Vietnamese civilians at My Lai in South Vietnam, was released today on personal bond of $1,000 by order of a civilian judge.

title: Meeting on Relations of India, Pakistan and Bangladesh Is Expected Soon
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 27Talks between India, Pakistan and Bangladesh are expected shortply in an effort to work out travel, communications and diplomatic ties among the three nations.

title: January's Total Cut by Increased Cost of Oil Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The United States ran a trade surplus for the seventh straight month in January, the Commerce Department reported today. The surplus was somewhat smaller than December's, however, largely because of the increased prices of petroleum imports.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Since he's the last of the breed  you know, champagne walls and carpeting, chandeliers, mirrors and couture collections  functioning in New York, Scaasi takes himself seriously. Fluttery capelets, ruffles around the neckline, dashing dcolletages, flower prints and face powder colors are all in his outrageously flattering bag of tricks. Of course, that's what couturiers are for. If they didn't go in for the flattery, who would bother with the fittings?

title: Studs Lonigan's Creator, Reaching 70, Savors New Life Style
description: H. L. Mencken called him the best living American novelist, but Charles Poore twitted him for his cinderblock style. And a Stalinera Soviet critic assailed him as a gangster of the pen.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Metropolitan Briefs
description: Byrne Declines to Back Crabiel

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 27 (UPI)  A fortyninemember United States team, one of the youngest ever to go abroad, worked out today for Saturday's track meet with the Soviet Union. The Soviet team includes four Olympic champions, two of whom are world recordholders.

title: RATIONING OF GAS OPPOSED IN SURVEY
description: Gasoline rationing is opposed by more than half the American public, according to a Gallup Poll released yesterday.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Senate Confirms Holton
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) The Senate today confirmed President Nixon's nomination of former Gov. Linwood Holton of Virginia as Assistant Secretary of State for Congressional relations.

title: Dispute Over Lost Tape Erupts at Brasco Trial
description: Federal Judge Inzer B. Wyatt yesterday ordered the United States Attorney for Maryland to appear in Federal Court here Saturday morning to clear up a dispute over a missing tape in the corruptionconspiracy trial of Representative Frank J. Brasco of Brooklyn.

title: TV Review
description: Personally, it offends me, commented Peter Lawford, the actor, about the continuing exploitation of Marilyn Monroe. The remarks were admirably reasonable except for one jarring detail. They were made near the end of a 90minute television pastiche called Marilyn Remembered, this week's most prominent exercise in exploitation. The program was shown last night at 11:30 o'clock on the American Broadcasting Company's Wide World of Entertainment series. The host for the entire affair was Peter Lawford.

title: Courts Seen Holding Key To CitySuburb Integration
description: Any action compelling city and suburban school districts to exchange students for purposes of racial integration would depend on the courts, the State Education Commissioner, Ewald B. Nyquist, said yesterday.

title: Accord on Professor Is Reached At Institute for Advanced Study
description: The Institute for Advanced Study, a camp dividedfaculty majority opposing the director has agreed on a professor to replace the one whose appointment initiated the split.

title: Retreats From Highs
description: LONDON, Feb. 27A hiatus set in today in the upward spiral of the price of gold.

title: Saigon and Communist Soldiers Reported in Plain of Reeds Clash
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 27 (AP)Hundreds of Communist and Saigon Government troops battled along the northern edge of the Plain of Reeds yesterday about 70 miles southwest of Saigon, Government sources said today.

title: Advertising: Winning Formula
description: The account management side of ad agencies, frequently maligned by those on the creative side, had its importance publicly recognized, yesterday by William Bernbach, one of the great creative lights in industry history.

title: Met Cancels New Forza
description: As part of its budgettightening, the Metropolitan Opera has decided to cancel next season's new production of Verdi's La Forza del Destino, according to operatic sources. The Met will refurbish the current production, replacing costumes that were burned in a warehouse fire and building a new set for the Rataplan scene, omitted in the old production. Shirley Verrett, who was to sing Preziosilla, has dropped out of the revival.

title: Theodore lserman, Lawyer, Dies; Helped Draft TaftHartley Act
description: Theodore R. Iserman, a senior partner in the law firm of Kelley Drye Warren Clark Carr & Ellis and a prominent laborrelations lawyer, died yesterday in Long Island College Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Court Reform Politics
description: When Chief Judge Charles D. Breitel addressed the Legislature yesterday, he accomplished something that even the Chief Justice of the United States, Warren E. Burger, has been Linable to do: address the legislaLive branch on the condition of the courts. That the Legislature granted Judge Breitel's request to speak gave notice that court reform has become a major political issue in the state.

title: Mafia Links to U. S. Business Unit Found
description: NEW ORLEANS  Known underworld figures in this area have for years enjoyed a cozy relationship with the local office of the Small Business Administration and have been able to obtain loans easily, an investigation by The New York Times has found.

title: Books of The Times
description: ENORMOUS CHANGES AT THE LAST MINUTE. By Grace Paley. 198 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $6.95.

title: Pingry Spurs Effort to Sell Its Campus in Elizabeth
description: ELIZABETH, Feb. 27  The Pingry School, situated here for more than a century, has stepped up efforts to sell its 32acre campus as part of a program under which the prestigious independent institution hopes to move 28 miles west to a site in Bernards Township.

title: British Will Vote Today; Polls Put Heath Bit Ahead
description: LONDON, Feb. 27The British election campaign ended tonight, with the governing Conservatives holding a narrow but shrinking lead over the opposition Labor party.

title: Car Rates May Climb, Industry Report Says
description: The auto insurance industry, increasingly concerned about the clamor for rate cuts because of the reduction in driving, has begun to talk seriously of the strong possibility that rates will not go down but may go up.

title: RALPH A. VILLANI, A NEWARK MAYOR
description: NEWARK, Feb. 27Ralph A. Villani, Mayor of Newark from 1949 until 1954, died this morning after having suffered a heart seizure at his home in Northwood. He was 72 years old.

title: Sighting of U.S. Balloon In Canaries Is Reported
description: SANTA CRUZ DE TENERIFE, Canary Islands, Feb. 27 (UPI)  Policemen and villagers said today that they had seen what appeared to be the balloon of the American adventurer Thomas Gatch, missing on a transAtlantic flight, but the sighting could not be confirmed.
